headline: Mixed Opening Lines in Knicks’ Courtship of Anthony

lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — It didn’t take long for Steve Mills to address his primary mission in assuming the Knicks’ top executive position last week, courtesy of his former and once again benefactor, James L. Dolan. On N.B.A. media day, Mills explained how the job opportunity appeared suddenly, announced the exercising of an option year for Coach Mike Woodson and then got down to the business of what promises to be a season of breathtaking pandering to Carmelo Anthony.

headline: Greece: A Vow to Erase a ‘Shame’
abstract: Prime Minister Antonis Samaras suggested on Monday that he wanted to eradicate Golden Dawn, the neo-fascist xenophobic political party that is facing a government crackdown.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Antonis Samaras of Greece suggested on Monday that he wanted to eradicate Golden Dawn, the neo-fascist xenophobic political party that is now facing a major government crackdown on charges it is a criminal organization involved in murder, attempted murder, blackmail and other crimes. Mr. Samaras, who was visiting New York for the meeting of the United Nations General Assembly, said in a reception sponsored by the American Jewish Committee that his government had no tolerance for the party’s anti-immigrant intimidation tactics and other fascist behavior. “We are dedicated in completely eradicating such a shame,” he said. “We must do it within the context of our democratic Constitution. But we have to go all the way and do whatever it takes.” His remarks appeared to go beyond previous statements about trying to curb the power of Golden Dawn, which has 18 members in Parliament. Over the weekend, the police arrested six of them, including the party’s leader.

headline: Israel: Egyptian Rescuer Is Honored
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Arabs', 'Jews and Judaism', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Mohamed Helmy, an Egyptian doctor who hid a Jewish woman in a cabin in Berlin during World War II, became the first Arab honored by Israel’s Holocaust memorial.
lead_paragraph: An Egyptian doctor who hid a Jewish woman in a cabin he owned in Berlin during World War II has become the first Arab honored as part of the “Righteous Among the Nations” by Yad Vashem, Israel’s Holocaust memorial. Starting in 1942, the doctor, Mohamed Helmy, provided the cabin to one of his patients, Anna Boros, then 21, and also helped her mother, stepfather and grandfather survive the war, according to a news release Yad Vashem issued Monday. He was aided by a German woman, Frieda Szturmann, who also has been added to the “Righteous” group, now more than 24,800 people from nearly 50 countries. “I will be grateful to him for eternity,” Ms. Boros wrote of Dr. Helmy after the war. She moved to Brooklyn and died in the 1980s, according to Yad Vashem. Dr. Helmy died in 1982.

headline: Indonesia: Australian Leader Aims to Halt Flow of Asylum Seekers
abstract: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia pledged Monday to work with Indonesia to stop the flow of people traveling by boat to Australia to seek asylum.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Tony Abbott of Australia pledged Monday to work with Indonesia to stop the flow of people traveling by boat to Australia to seek asylum, even as his new government pursued a tough policy of turning back vessels that has created diplomatic tension between the countries. Mr. Abbott, who traveled to Indonesia for talks, has come under fire for continuing a policy that ships asylum seekers arriving by boat to third countries for processing and denies them the right to ever settle in Australia. Mr. Abbott’s own plans for combating people smuggling — including forcing boats packed with asylum seekers back into Indonesian waters, buying up boats and gathering intelligence in Indonesian villages — have been heavily criticized by Indonesia. Migrants from the Middle East and South Asia pay smugglers to get them into Indonesia and then onto rickety boats that make the perilous voyage to the Australian territory of Christmas Island, where the migrants can apply for asylum. On Friday, a vessel carrying about 100 people from Lebanon, Pakistan and Iraq sank off West Java, killing at least 36 people.

headline: Going Long. Going Short.
abstract: How the gaps within and around a story speak as large as the text itself.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always wanted to go long, as in writing that big behemoth of a saga called the “Great American Novel,” no matter the absurdity of questing after such a holy grail. I thought the best way to understand the endless ribbons of America’s highways, the oozing boundaries of our suburbia and the rhythms of life they induce in us, resided in an ever expansive aesthetic of maximalist comprehensiveness, full of crisscrossing tentacles of story lines and sentences bursting with syntactic curlicues. Our souls sprawl with this land, after all. Think of the labyrinthine universe of David Foster Wallace, the dense weight of William Faulkner’s past (which I share only literarily, not genetically) or Saul Bellow’s overflowing, burbling prose.

headline: Bookshelf | A Big Book of Architectural Entertainment
abstract: Pin-Up, the chatty biannual magazine that pairs far-flung personalities such as Rem Koolhaas, Hedi Slimane and Daniel Arsham for wide-ranging conversations has published a tome collecting 57 of its best interviews.
lead_paragraph: Publications devoted to architecture typically follow a narrow blueprint. There are shelter magazines, like the now-defunct Nest and The World of Interiors, that chronicle the in-good-taste décor of worldly aesthetes; scholarly journals that treat buildings in abstract theoretical terms; and quaint Martha Stewart-esque titles chock-full of how-tos for painting bedroom walls the just-so shade of robin’s-egg blue. So when Pin-Up, a self-described “magazine for architectural entertainment,” first came out in 2006, its low-key tête-à-tête format, antidesign typography and droll intellectual tenor was as subversive as it was groundbreaking. “The one thing that has always been consistent from Issue 1 was to have a more conversational tone within the context of broader architectural discourse and not have everything be so serious or jargony,” said Felix Burrichter, Pin-Up’s editor and founder (and a T contributor). “Pin-Up: Interviews” (powerHouse Books, $30), a new collection of 57 interviews that have appeared in the magazine’s past 16 issues, demonstrates just that.

headline: Bivouac and Bushwhackers
abstract: Life for men behind the front lines during the Civil War was often as perilous as fighting at the front.
lead_paragraph: Five days after the Battle of Chickamauga, trainloads of Union wounded continued to rumble through Murfreesboro, Tenn., on their way to Nashville hospitals. Cpl. Joseph W. Ely of the 19th Michigan Infantry, who was stationed in Murfreesboro, a town in middle Tennessee, wrote in his diary about one wounded soldier who “fell off the cars at 12 o’clock and was picked up this morning. The cars had run over his legs. The feet were taken off this morning.” Judson Austin, one of Ely’s comrades, wrote to his wife that “the cars are loaded so full that the boys that are not too bad off ride on top of the cars & often riding all day they get tiard & sleepy. This is the way they get tumbled off & run over.”

headline: John Armleder, the Artist Who Believes in Everything
abstract: Since having a brain tumor removed, the 66-year-old has abandoned gray matter as a subject, but his genre-hopping new show at Nahmad Contemporary still offers plenty of food for thought.
lead_paragraph: “My dream is to go to a show and wonder, ‘Who is that artist?’ and find out it’s my work,” said John Armleder, the Swiss painter, sculptor and performance artist who spent the past few years recovering from the removal of a brain tumor. “Before I got ill, I did wall paintings with models of brains,” he said. “Both myself and the guy who published those paintings landed up with brain problems.” Now, the 66-year-old is back on the scene with an untitled, unthematic show at Nahmad Contemporary, on the Upper East Side. Unlike most artists, Armleder didn’t oversee the installation. “I consider the artwork to exist as itself,” he said. “It’s the person who looks at it who gives its meaning.” In fact this show was conceptualized and curated by Joe Nahmad, the 23-year-old art dealer and gallery owner whose older brother was implicated in an F.B.I. poker raid last April.

abstract: The show’s celebration of busy women was complemented with soft iterations of everyday makeup and hair.
lead_paragraph: Stella McCartney’s models were aglow with simple, soft makeup and hair. To make sure the eyes weren’t lost in otherwise neutral faces, Pat McGrath used a taupe brown eye liner to draw a pseudo-cat-eye, which popped under subtle but full eyebrows. The hairstylist Eugene Souleiman ditched styling products altogether to focus instead on a clean head of hair. “Texturally, the hair is very light,” he explained. “It’s freshly washed, blown out straight with a round brush. The hair is literally draped over one ear, and pulled into a very taut ponytail.” The slightly messed tresses were in line with the show’s celebration of the chic, ever-on-the-go woman. Souleiman achieved the humble detail by lightly massaging the scalp, “just to bring out these little imperfections,” he said.

headline: Restaurant Report: Girasol in Los Angeles
abstract: The chef at this new spot procures up to 80 percent of his restaurant’s seasonal ingredients from local food purveyors.
lead_paragraph: When Alice Waters opened Chez Panisse in 1971, her philosophy was simple yet, for the time, radical: use seasonal, local ingredients whenever possible. The idea transformed eating in California and, eventually, the rest of the country. So what exactly is California cuisine these days?

headline: It’s No Longer on His Face, and It’s Got Ambitions
abstract: With unflagging energy, the opera “The Nose” powerfully seconds the irreverent zaniness of the Gogol story on which it is based.
lead_paragraph: William Kentridge’s 2010 staging of Shostakovich’s first opera, “The Nose,” was one of the Metropolitan Opera’s most acclaimed productions of recent seasons, and for a critic just catching up with it when it was revived on Saturday afternoon, it was easy to see why. With unflagging energy and unfettered imagination, it powerfully seconds both the irreverent zaniness of the Gogol story on which the opera is based and the teeming exuberance of Shostakovich’s music.

headline: Like People You Know, Driven Yet Exhilarated
abstract: Pacific Northwest Ballet is presenting a triple bill of works by Twyla Tharp, including a premiere, “Waiting at the Station,” at McCaw Hall in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The happily galvanized look of Pacific Northwest Ballet’s artists in “Air Twyla,” a triple bill of pieces by Twyla Tharp, is a marvel — and a sure sign of the inspirational effect this choreographer has upon dancers. Since its three works span 31 years, from “Nine Sinatra Songs” (1982) to “Waiting at the Station” (a world premiere), the program demonstrates much of the amazing diversity of Ms. Tharp, one of the very few living choreographers to whom the word “great” should be applied.

headline: Movement Made for Listening
abstract: “Ha!,” by the Moroccan choreographer Bouchra Ouizguen, is built around the sounds of the Moroccan aita tradition.
lead_paragraph: In the near darkness, it takes eyes awhile to adjust. Aural information dominates at first: rhythmic exhalations that sound human. As your pupils dilate, and the light very slowly brightens, four shapes, white and pulsing, grow discernible. The pace of the brightening doesn’t quicken, but recognition, when it comes, dawns instantly. The shapes are heads, bobbing like derricks. The blacknesses below the heads are bodies.

headline: Northern Spy Lifts Cloak on Koreas’ Deadly Rivalry
abstract: In his memoir, a North Korean agent captured on a mission provides a rare, firsthand look at the often lethal spy war that North and South Korea waged for decades.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — On Oct. 24, 1995, as a man now known as Kim Dong-sik hiked up a rain-slick mountain road in Buyeo, about 95 miles south of Seoul, he could not shake off a foreboding. He and another North Korean agent had sneaked into South Korea by boat 52 days earlier on a mission to bring home a Communist spy who had been working in the South for 15 years. The latest message from their superiors said the spy had been instructed to wait for Mr. Kim in a temple in Buyeo, disguised as a Buddhist monk named Jawoon.

headline: Wisconsin: Judge in Abuse Case Won’t Step Down
abstract: The judge refused to recuse himself from a case involving the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milwaukee after it was suggested he had a conflict of interest because relatives are buried in archdiocesan cemeteries.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has refused to recuse himself from a case in which he ruled in favor of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milwaukee in bankruptcy proceedings, and against creditors, who include hundreds of sexual abuse victims. Judge Rudolph T. Randa denied the creditors’ motion suggesting that he had a conflict of interest because his family members are buried in archdiocesan cemeteries. Judge Randa had ruled in late July that the archdiocese did not have to turn over millions of dollars in its cemetery trust fund to the abuse victims and other creditors, because it would “substantially burden” the church’s free exercise of religion. In denying the recusal motion on Tuesday, Judge Randa wrote that the care and maintenance of his parents’ burial crypts will not be substantially affected by his decision.

headline: Arizona: Court Upholds School Funding Program
abstract: The state Court of Appeals on Tuesday upheld a lower court’s ruling affirming the constitutionality of a program that directs public money to pay for private school tuition for some students.
lead_paragraph: The state Court of Appeals on Tuesday unanimously upheld a lower court ruling affirming the constitutionality of a program that directs public money to private bank accounts to pay for private school tuition and educational services for some students. The Arizona School Boards Association and other groups sued to block the program, saying that it violated the state’s Constitution because it directed private funding to religious schools, among other arguments. The appeals court ruled that the program, designed by the Goldwater Institute, a conservative group, “expands the options to meet the individual needs of children.” Open to special-needs students at first, the program is available to one in five public school students in the state.

(HBO) IN GOOD COMPANY (2004) A 51-year-old advertising executive (Dennis Quaid) finds his life turned upside down when a young shark (Topher Grace, above right, with Mr. Quaid) arrives on the scene to take over his department and his office — and sleep with his daughter (Scarlett Johansson). This “engagingly lightweight drama,” written and directed by Paul Weitz, “is a gently revisionist fairy tale about good versus evil set on the battlefield of contemporary corporate culture, a site of our leading blood sport,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Mostly, though, the movie is about men. Men without fathers, men without sons, men with wives who work and make them feel like less than a man and men with wives who, like Dan’s wife, Ann (Marg Helgenberger), give them the gift of both an exquisitely preserved figure and a fertile womb.” She added, “I don’t believe for a single second how Mr. Weitz ends his fairy tale, but I mean it as a compliment to say that I wish I did.”

headline: Daniel Radcliffe’s Next Trick Is to Make Harry Potter Disappear
abstract: The child star has graduated from Hogwarts.
lead_paragraph: Before Daniel Radcliffe became the most famous child actor in history, he was just a child: an only child, a poor sleeper, a nonstop talker, a picky eater. He was also disarmingly sweet. In the screen test he took at age 10, in 2000, for the first Harry Potter film, “Harry Potter and the Sorcerer’s Stone,” he smiles brightly, ebullient, his delight in being there apparent; he is concentrating, concentrating so hard at one point that he mouths words under his breath while waiting to deliver a line, but even still, when he does finally speak, he is all natural sincerity. His face is a flawless little-boy face, his eyes huge and cerulean blue. One eye occasionally blinks more slowly than the other, but no matter. He turns, compliantly, this way and that when asked. About four minutes into the footage, someone places the iconic round glasses on him, and there he is: Harry Potter, boy wizard, the chosen one. The adult voice on the video says: “Those look good.”

headline: The Nomads’ No Man’s Land

lead_paragraph: FREE ZONE, Western Sahara — Some parts of the Sahara are more of a no man’s land than others. The most extreme example is the so-called Free Zone, a strip in the Western Sahara, with territory occupied by Morocco to the west and Algeria to the east. Strewn with mines and inhabited by just a smattering of nomads, the area is controlled by the Polisario Front, a state in exile that has been based in refugee camps in southwestern Algeria since 1976, when Morocco annexed Western Sahara after Spain’s colonial forces withdrew.

headline: In Vienna, New Energy Amid Old-World Charm
abstract: Craftspeople, artists and shopkeepers are breathing new life into an area near the city’s museum district.
lead_paragraph: In Vienna’s bohemian Seventh District, craftspeople, artists and shopkeepers are breathing new life into a handful of old cobblestone streets known as Spittelberg. Steps from the MuseumsQuartier, the city’s museum district, the neighborhood overflows with Old World charm and hidden garden restaurants. It wasn’t always picturesque. Named after a hospital built here in the 1500s, the hill filled in over the centuries with low-rent housing, taverns and brothels. By the 1970s, the red light district was headed for demolition, but locals insisted on preservation instead. Restored Biedermeier buildings on pedestrian lanes now house galleries, boutiques, bars and restaurants. With summer tourists gone, Viennese enjoy strolling and dining outside on pleasant autumn evenings.

headline: A Poet Reckons With Her Inheritance
abstract: Tess Taylor, a descendant of Thomas Jefferson, talks about her new collection, “The Forage House,” her ancestors and race.
lead_paragraph: In her recently published collection of poems, “The Forage House” (Red Hen Press), Tess Taylor, a descendant of the white branch of Thomas Jefferson’s family, explores her personal history, sifting through not just records but the very dirt of her ancestors’ property and the bones buried there. She saw “unearthed remains of slave cabins — cracked pipes, a few buttons” and witnessed how archaeologists use these bits to recreate the past. In a recent e-mail interview she talked about her ancestors, including Appalachian forebears “who kept Scottish ballads alive for centuries” in remote parts of North Carolina, about slavery and about the role of poetry.

headline: A Park Slope Mom Raises a Hunter

It would have come as no surprise to him (or probably anyone of his generation) that my 14-year-old son Booker’s proudest possession is his newly acquired hunting license, and that he fully intends to take down a deer this fall.

headline: When the Government Shuts, Even Web Sites Go Down
abstract: The decision by agencies such as NASA to take down their sites this week has gotten a lot of attention.
lead_paragraph: When the federal government last shutdown in 1995, most agencies and departments had either no presence on the Internet or a very basic Web site. Since then, agency Web sites have become the primary public face of the government for most Americans who do not live in or near Washington. So it’s perhaps not surprising that the decision by agencies such as NASA and the Library of Congress to take down their sites this week has gotten a lot of attention.

headline: Finding Talking Points Among the Underdogs
abstract: Malcolm Gladwell sets out to explore two ideas in his new book: that there is greatness and beauty in David-Goliath fights; and that “we consistently get these kinds of conflicts wrong.”
lead_paragraph: The world becomes less complicated with a Malcolm Gladwell book in hand. Mr. Gladwell raises questions — should David have won his fight with Goliath? — that are reassuringly clear even before they are answered. His answers are just tricky enough to suggest that the reader has learned something, regardless of whether that’s true. A recent posting on Goodreads, a Web site that bolsters enthusiasm for books and reveals no-baloney reasons readers like them, lauds the power of Mr. Gladwell’s entertaining insights into the not quite obvious. “Do you really want to be surprised all the time?” a commenter identified as Dr. A. Taubman asked this week about Mr. Gladwell’s latest, “David and Goliath.” “The world is disconcerting enough already.”

One night, at a party in her honor, as paparazzi hovered, Ms. Cyrus dismissed shock at her budding sexuality as largely a media fabrication. “I think it’s fun to read about,” she said, before adding that she didn’t think the public at large actually cares.

headline: Cuomo Enlists Pataki and McCall to Help With Tax-Cut Plans
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo named a pair of his onetime rivals to develop proposals for the State Legislature to consider.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Wednesday that he wanted to reduce taxes next year, when he will be seeking re-election, and he named a commission led by a pair of his onetime rivals to develop proposals for New York State lawmakers to consider.

headline: Shutdown Provides Material for Late Night
abstract: While few people may be laughing on Capitol Hill, the government shutdown is irresistible fodder for late-night comedy. The subject has been at the top of every monologue, and the inspiration for several much-viewed comedy bits.
lead_paragraph: While few people may be laughing on Capitol Hill, the government shutdown is irresistible fodder for late-night comedy. The subject has been at the top of every monologue, and the inspiration for several much-viewed comedy bits.

headline: Shutdown Hurting Intelligence Efforts, Director Says
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The director of national intelligence cited an “extremely damaging” situation in regard to intelligence agencies’ abilities to support military and diplomatic efforts around the world.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday where the director of national intelligence, James R. Clapper Jr., was testifying, senators of both parties expressed alarm about the impact of the government shutdown on intelligence gathering. Roughly 70 percent of the intelligence agencies’ civilian employees have been furloughed.

headline: In Myanmar, Revival of Attacks on Muslims
abstract: The deaths and the burning of houses in the city of Thandwe occurred just hours before President U Thein Sein arrived as part of a scheduled visit to cool religious tensions.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A resurgence of religious violence in western Myanmar this week has left six Muslims dead and dozens of homes destroyed, a senior police officer said Wednesday.

headline: Why The Right Fights
abstract: The historical roots of contemporary conservative intransigence.
lead_paragraph: To understand how we ended up in this strange political moment, with the federal government shuttered in pursuit of a political goal that most elected Republicans concede is well-nigh-impossible to achieve, it’s worth talking not only about polarization and redistricting and the conservative media landscape and anti-Obama sentiment and the weakening of institutional party power, but also about a more basic, often-underappreciated element in how many movement conservatives regard the history of the last forty years. To explain this point, I’ll start with a quote from David Frum’s great book “Dead Right,” which was written in the early 1990s, in what seemed like a period of exhaustion and defeat for limited-government conservatism, just before the 1994 congressional sweep gave that movement new political life. Here’s how the Frum of that era — who was much more of a small-government rigorist than he is today — depicted the Reagan years and their implications for the right:

headline: A Sampling of Old and New, Side by Side
abstract: At the Fall for Dance Festival, American Ballet Theater presented an old modern dance, José Limón’s “Moor’s Pavane,” while Ballet Hispanico’s contribution was a world premiere.
lead_paragraph: The aim of the Fall for Dance Festival is introductory. Its sampler programs are selected for variety, yet there are lessons, intended or not, to be gleaned from the juxtapositions. In this year’s third program, on Monday at City Center, the lessons were about old and new.

headline: Next Time, Libraries Could Be Our Shelters From the Storm
abstract: As the New York region prepares neighborhoods for the next disaster, why not look to some natural community centers, branch libraries?
lead_paragraph: Two big storms and a major blackout have battered New York City since the Sept. 11 attacks. Climate change threatens higher tides and more extreme heat. Architects and engineers look for ways to respond.

headline: Family Trees of Familiar Scions
abstract: Three new comedies — “The Millers,” “Sean Saves the World” and “Welcome to the Family” — stand out for their veteran leads.
lead_paragraph: Pedigree matters.

headline: The Afro as a Natural Expression of Self
abstract: The style’s current iteration bears little kinship to the anti-gravity hair flaunted in the late 1960s by Angela Davis and other icons of the Black Power movement.
lead_paragraph: Dante de Blasio’s towering Afro, a supporting player in his father’s mayoral campaign, riveted attention once more last week when it caught the eye of President Obama. Introducing Bill de Blasio at a Democratic fund-raiser in Midtown, Mr. Obama digressed to point out, “Dante has the same hairdo as I had in 1978. Although I have to confess my Afro was never that good.”

headline: There’s Bad Blood on Bourbon Street
abstract: “The Originals,” a spinoff from “The Vampire Diaries” starting Thursday on the CW network, centers on conflict among vampires and werewolves in New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Like practically any television show or movie set in New Orleans, “The Originals” works in a reference to gumbo within the first 10 minutes in an effort to establish its bayou bona fides. For this show, the wearying device is particularly apt because the series itself is a sort of gumbo. The creators tossed everything they could think of — vampires, witches, werewolves, an extra-human pregnancy, New Orleans itself — into a pot and hoped that something would bubble up that matched “The Vampire Diaries,” of which this show is a spinoff.

headline: Food Matters | An Italian Town Says Yes, Please, to Cheese

headline: BlackBerry Said to Be of Interest to Cerberus
abstract: It was not clear whether a confidentiality agreement would ultimately lead to a bid for BlackBerry, whose largest shareholder, Fairfax Financial Holdings of Toronto, has made a preliminary offer of $9 a share.
lead_paragraph: Cerberus Capital Management is seeking a confidentiality agreement that would allow it to examine the books and internal operations of BlackBerry, a person briefed on Cerberus’s plans said on Wednesday.

headline: Jakob Arjouni: Excerpts From His Work
abstract: Selections from the work of the German crime novelist.
lead_paragraph: The German crime novelist Jakob Arjouni died of pancreatic cancer on Jan. 17. He was 48. Melville House in Brooklyn has just published an English translation of his “Brother Kemal,” the first novel featuring his Frankfurt-based private eye Kayankaya in more than a decade, and the last in the series. Below are excerpts from two of Mr. Arjouni’s previous novels, which were translated from the German by Anselm Hollo. The excerpts appear courtesy of Melville House.

headline: A Master of Crime Fiction in a Nation Lacking Them
abstract: Jakob Arjouni, who proved there could be such a thing as German crime fiction, raced against cancer to finish the fifth installment in his best-selling series.
lead_paragraph: George Bernard Shaw once remarked that there were two things that Germans have no talent for: revolution and crime novels. Jakob Arjouni proved him half wrong, at any rate.

headline: Mama’s Molotov Cocktails
abstract: In “The Velocity of Autumn” at Arena Stage in Washington, Estelle Parsons is a feisty old woman who becomes an urban terrorist to avoid being forced from her Brooklyn home.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Going gently into that good night, or going gently anywhere at all, is obviously not an option for Alexandra, the heroine of “The Velocity of Autumn,” a slight but genial new play by Eric Coble at the Arena Stage here. Although we first see her slumped comfortably in an armchair, wearing a festively colored dress and listening to a little Berlioz, the 79-year-old Alexandra, played with wonderful grit and wit by the great actress Estelle Parsons, is armed for bear.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Debate over the federal government shutdown has tended to focus on those it hurts: veterans, tourists barred from the Lincoln Memorial and Yellowstone National Park, and giant-panda enthusiasts deprived of their publicly funded panda cam.

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — It would have been hard to think of a better metaphor: A fire-breathing dragon was bearing down on the Detroit Institute of Arts.

headline: Oaks in Their Midst

lead_paragraph: As a city couple searching for a place to put down roots, Jeff Jordan and his wife, Sally Librera, had made several predictable stops, including San Francisco and Manhattan. But they ended up someplace totally unexpected.

headline: Domino 3.0
abstract: A beloved magazine returns from the dead (again). And this time it’s all about commerce.
lead_paragraph: It certainly looked like a magazine start up. There was the eager — and tiny — young staff in a scruffy office on West 38th Street decorated with Blu Dot furniture, a couple of Moroccan rugs and their own artwork. Elaina Sullivan, the market editor, had painted canvases à la Rothko. On a wall blackened with chalkboard paint, someone had drawn a medley of picture frames. With no real budget for photography, Michelle Adams, the new magazine’s editor in chief; Brittany Ambridge, the photo director; and Robert Leleux, the creative director, had shot, styled and written nearly every feature. Ms. Ambridge was also responsible for retouching the photos, and Ms. Adams had been making sales calls.

headline: Germans Win d’Orsi Senior Trophy
abstract: At the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, the 96-board d’Orsi Senior Trophy final was between teams from Germany and the United States.
lead_paragraph: At the world championships in Bali, Indonesia, which ended on Sunday, the 96-board d’Orsi Senior Trophy final was between Germany (Michael Elinescu, Entscho Wladow, Ulrich Kratz, Bernhard Strater, Reiner Marsal and Ulrich Wenning) and USA-2 (Carolyn Lynch, Mike Passell, Roger Bates, Garey Hayden, Marc Jacobus and Eddie Wold). The Americans lost a heartbreaking match by 11 international match points, primarily because they conceded 24 imps on the four slam deals in the final 16-board session.

headline: A Poetic Rebel Full of Salt and Vinegar
abstract: “Life Is a Bitch,” Mary Foster Conklin’s cabaret show devoted to Fran Landesman’s words, includes some of Landesman’s verses and more than a dozen of her songs.
lead_paragraph: “Life is a bitch, full of hangups, full of hurt/First love makes you itch, then it dishes you to the dirt.” No, it’s not Dorothy Parker. Those words belong to Fran Landesman, a hard-living outspoken cynic, who might be described as the Dorothy Parker of jazz lyrics.

lead_paragraph: As an architect who favors modern interiors that are free of clutter, West Chin admits to a preference for the absence of color as well.

headline: Nick Offerman’s Sawdust Vies With Stardust
keywords: ['Carpentry and Carpenters', 'Wood and Wood Products', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The actor from “Parks and Recreation” talks about his other life, as a woodworker.
lead_paragraph: Nick Offerman is a lucky guy, as he humbly and repeatedly submits in his new memoir, “Paddle Your Own Canoe” (Dutton, $26.95). He is married to the actress Megan Mullally, and after years of being passed over for roles, he has come into his prime as a character actor (what a casting agent once told him would be his “sheriff years”), starring as the bacon-loving, whiskey-drinking, sawdust-sniffing Ron Swanson on “Parks and Recreation.”

headline: There Is Nothing Like This Dame
abstract: “Mildred Fierce,” making its New York premiere, is a loving musical parody of the movie that won Joan Crawford her Oscar.
lead_paragraph: It was probably inevitable. There are many pillars of gay culture, but among the sturdiest are an affection for musical theater and a love for the great dames of cinema and the sometimes gloriously melodramatic vehicles that the studio system built to accommodate them. And here it is: “Mildred Fierce.” This show, making its New York premiere, is a loving musical parody of the movie that won Joan Crawford her Oscar and cemented her as a tough, suffering Warner Brothers heroine after her ignominious release from her MGM contract.

headline: Scrutinizing Nature, Sorrow and Oneself With a Subjective Lens
abstract: Manohla Dargis and A. O. Scott examine highlights of “Views From the Avant-Garde” at the New York Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: This year’s New York Film Festival has been notable for, among other qualities, the number of jumbo offerings, including selections weighing in at three hours or more. The embrace of the cinema of duration continues to somewhat overwhelming effect in “Views From the Avant-Garde,” the festival’s annual lineup of experimental work that this year includes a mind-bending, back-challenging 202 works (17 features, 185 shorts).

headline: No Seat at Table for Soccer Players’ Union
abstract: Theo Van Seggelen, the general secretary of FIFPro, said a shift of date to a winter World Cup in 2022 would raise a host of potential  concerns for his group.
lead_paragraph: As the members of FIFA’s executive committee gather in Zurich this week to discuss — among other things — when to play the 2022 World Cup in Qatar, one of world soccer’s powerful figures is already thinking ahead.

headline: A Tea Tray Inspired by Istanbul Mosques
keywords: ['Tea', 'Maison Et Objet (Trade Show)', 'Design', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Zeynap Fadillioglu’s Kubbe tray takes its name from the Turkish word for “dome.”
lead_paragraph: Zeynep Fadillioglu’s Kubbe tray looks like a modern version of the metal tea trays seen in Moroccan and Egyptian markets, but its inspiration is narrower: “kubbe” is Turkish for “dome,” and the designer was thinking of the mosques in her home city, Istanbul. Ms. Fadillioglu knows something about mosques: she led the team that designed the interiors of the strikingly modern Sakirin mosque on the Asian side of the city, whose dome is 130 feet in diameter and trickles glass raindrops from a chandelier suspended there. The tea tray, part of her first collection of furniture and accessories, was introduced at the Maison et Objet show in Paris last month. It is handmade in Turkey of walnut, oak or maple, and costs about $893. Information: (90-212) 287-0936 or zfdesign.com.

headline: Discounts at Broadway Panhandler, Roubini Rugs, Y Lighting and Kartell

lead_paragraph: Some items are up to 60 percent off at Broadway Panhandler, through Sunday (a Wüsthof Classic 8-inch bread knife with bamboo cutting board, usually $150, is about $60); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

headline: John Derian Pulls Up a Chair
abstract: The designer has a new East Village shop filled with furniture inspired by his travels.
lead_paragraph: John Derian introduced furniture four years ago, but don’t feel bad if you didn’t notice: the pieces were often hidden amid decorative pillows and antiques in the designer’s two East Village stores. They finally stepped into the limelight last week with the opening of John Derian Furniture on 8 East Second Street. All the chairs, chaises, sofas, benches and ottomans in the 900-square-foot storefront are influenced by furniture Mr. Derian found during his travels. “Most are 17th-, 18th- and 19th-century European and American designs that we tweaked,” he said. Though the shop is more sparsely decorated than his other stores, it does have a wall of antique oil paintings and a life-size cloth horse that was once in a saddlery. Upholstery fabrics include hand-dyed velvets and Belgian linen from Libeco Lagae. Prices start at $1,185 for a Mignonette chaise. Information: (212) 677-3917 or johnderian.com.

headline: Cabinets of Curiosity
abstract: Storage pieces displayed at Mint in London are filled with surprises.
lead_paragraph: For the London Design Festival, which ended last week, Mint, one of the city’s leading design stores, presented Cabinets of Curiosity, cupboards that took everyday storage to poetic heights.

headline: A Quartet Gets Loopy

lead_paragraph: Studio Four NYC, which produces custom rugs for interior designers, has partnered with four of its frequent collaborators to introduce its first rug collection. Amanda Nisbet Design, Carrier and Company, Katie Ridder and Tilton Fenwick each designed two patterns in three color schemes, which are available to regular consumers and the trade.

headline: After the Deluge, This
abstract: In Long Beach, N.Y., reconstruction is prolonged and painful, with decisions guided by a single, unanswerable question: When will it happen again?
lead_paragraph: In Long Beach, N.Y., reconstruction is prolonged and painful, with decisions guided by a single, unanswerable question: When will it happen again?

headline: Dark Water: A Year After Hurricane Sandy
abstract: Residents of one Long Island community are still reckoning the damages.
lead_paragraph: LONG BEACH, N.Y. — In lines at the grocery store and the post office here, the usual pleasantries are still squeezed out by talk of the slow pace of reconstruction, spiking flood insurance premiums and whether the hospital, movie theater or sports club will ever reopen. Nearly a year after Sandy, you hear the same refrain everywhere: “Hey, how are you doing? Are you guys back home yet?” About a quarter, possibly more, are not.

headline: Improving Your Home Network
abstract: There are ways to minimize some of the most common shortcomings of home networks if you are willing to experiment.
lead_paragraph: NETGEAR is best known as a company that makes the routers that direct Wi-Fi traffic on home computer networks, but its fastest growing product isn’t a router. It’s a device called a network extender, which is meant to improve — and extend — a home’s balky Wi-Fi signal.

lead_paragraph: A California jury decided on Wednesday that Michael Jackson’s final concert promoter, A.E.G. Live, was not responsible for the pop star’s death.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Veterans will be able to visit the World War II Memorial while the government is shut down, Carol Johnson, a spokeswoman for the National Park Service, said in a Twitter message on Wednesday.

headline: Lee Thornton, Ex-White House Reporter, Dies at 71
abstract: The first black woman to cover the White House for CBS News, Ms. Thornton also was a co-host of “All Things Considered” on NPR, a news program producer for CNN and a teacher of journalism.
lead_paragraph: Lee Thornton, a radio and television journalist who covered the White House for CBS News during the Carter administration, became a host of “All Things Considered” on NPR and produced “Both Sides With Jesse Jackson” for CNN, died on Sept. 25 at her home in Bethesda, Md. She was 71.

lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS, Syria — After weeks of threats and negotiations over Syria’s chemical weapons stockpile, an advance team of international weapons inspectors has begun to take the first steps toward dismantling the arsenal. Early indications suggest that they are in for a long, hard slog.

lead_paragraph: After months of internal rifts and a trustee meeting last weekend, Sidney A. Ribeau, the president of Howard University, announced Tuesday that he would resign at the end of the year.

headline: Obama Says He Won’t Negotiate Until Government Reopens
abstract: President Obama said he would not negotiate with Republicans until they agreed to approve legislation that would reopen the government.

abstract: A federal judge unsealed documents in a case involving a tech entrepreneur who refused to give the government broad access to data on users of Lavabit, his secure e-mail service, one of whom was Edward J. Snowden.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — One day last May, Ladar Levison returned home to find an F.B.I. agent’s business card on his Dallas doorstep. So began a four-month tangle with law enforcement officials that would end with Mr. Levison’s shutting the business he had spent a decade building and becoming an unlikely hero of privacy advocates in their escalating battle with the government over Internet security.

headline: Braves’ Free Swingers Face Dodgers’ Staff of Aces

lead_paragraph: In the mid-1990s, when baseball added the division series to be played before the league championship series, nobody said much about the randomness of the postseason. The Atlanta Braves ruled the National League and simply owned the new round.

headline: Yankees Begin Negotiations to Bring Back Girardi

lead_paragraph: Brian Cashman met with Steve Mandell, the agent for Joe Girardi, as planned on Wednesday and began negotiations for a new contract for Girardi. The meeting was said to be a good one and the sides will continue talking.

headline: France: Court Throws Out Cases Claiming Racial Profiling by Police
abstract: A court in Paris threw out lawsuits that claimed illegal racial profiling by the police engaged in public identity checks and pat-downs.
lead_paragraph: A court in Paris on Wednesday threw out lawsuits that claimed illegal racial profiling by the police engaged in public identity checks and pat-downs. The decisions will be appealed, said Lanna Hollo, a legal officer for the Open Society Justice Initiative, an advocacy organization that supported the lawsuits. In linked but separate civil cases, 13 black and Arab men requested 10,000 euros, about $13,600, in damages from the state after being stopped and in some cases frisked by the police; none of the stops were followed by further police action or charges. The court found that the men had been unable to prove racial motives for the identity checks, which are widely viewed in France as a legitimate policing tactic. A 2009 study conducted by French researchers and the Open Society Justice Initiative found that Arabs and blacks were as much as eight times more likely to be stopped than whites.

headline: Social Networks in a Battle for the Second Screen
abstract: Facebook and Twitter are vying to become the nation’s digital water cooler as they woo networks and advertisers.
lead_paragraph: After “Breaking Bad” drew 10.3 million viewers to one of the most crowd-satisfying finales in television history on Sunday, Twitter and Facebook raced to tell the news media about the throngs who shared their instant reactions to the show on the social networks.

headline: Finally Secure in the Desert, the Coyotes Devote Their Focus to the Ice
abstract: After years of financial troubles nearly caused them to move, the Phoenix Coyotes have high hopes with a new ownership group.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Just three months ago, the Phoenix Coyotes were less than five days from moving to Seattle. Yet that was not the closest call during the team’s long period of instability. At one point in 2010, they came within 15 minutes of moving to Winnipeg.

headline: Fish or Cut Bait
abstract: The military commission system created to try 9/11 terrorists is on life support. The country would be better off pulling the plug.
lead_paragraph: It was the most important military commission case to come before any court in the more than seven years since the Supreme Court invalidated the Bush administration’s first effort to set up military commissions to try Guantánamo detainees for war crimes.

headline: Iran’s President Responds to Netanyahu
abstract: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran dismissed the verbal assault on his credibility by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel the day before at the United Nations General Assembly.
lead_paragraph: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran on Wednesday dismissed the verbal assault on his credibility by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel the day before, during a speech at the United Nations General Assembly. Mr. Rouhani was quoted by Iranian news agencies as saying Mr. Netanyahu’s speech reflected what the Iranian leader called Israeli alarm at the signs of rapprochement between Iran and the United States. “Israel is upset to see that its sword has gone blunt and Iran grows more powerful by the day,” the Fars News Agency quoted Mr. Rouhani as saying. Mr. Netanyahu, who considers Iran his country’s most dangerous enemy, said in his speech that the Iranian leader was seeking to deceive the world by asserting an earnest desire to resolve the impasse over Iran’s disputed nuclear program. Mr. Rouhani, who visited the United Nations last week, spoke by telephone with President Obama on Friday, the first such contact between the leaders of Iran and the United States in 34 years.

headline: Why Are There Still So Few Women in Science?

lead_paragraph: Last summer, researchers at Yale published a study proving that physicists, chemists and biologists are likely to view a young male scientist more favorably than a woman with the same qualifications. If they did hire the woman, they set her salary, on average, nearly $4,000 lower than the man’s. Surprisingly, female scientists were as biased as their male counterparts.

As our eyes (from behind 3-D glasses) adjust to the vast darkness, illuminated by streaks of sunlight refracted through the Earth’s atmosphere, we detect movement that is recognizably human and hear familiar voices. Those tiny figures bouncing around on that floating contraption — it looks like a mobile suspended from a child’s bedroom ceiling — are people. Scientists. Astronauts. Movie stars. (Sandra Bullock and George Clooney in spacesuits, as Mission Specialist Ryan Stone and Mission Commander Matt Kowalski; Ed Harris, unseen and unnamed, as “Houston” down below).

headline: Not Shrews. Princes and Kings.
abstract: Some famous examples of actresses who have played important male roles in Shakespeare plays over three centuries.
lead_paragraph: In Shakespeare’s plays, women put on men’s clothes so they can travel where they like, marry whom they like, and speak their minds. Actresses from the 1600s to the present have followed suit — literally — dressing as men in search of better parts and more lines. Here are some of the most famous examples of Shakespearean male drag. ALEXIS SOLOSKI

abstract: The French hope to force elections and access to aid in the chronically dysfunctional  Central African Republic, which has suffered months of violence.
lead_paragraph: France is drafting a United Nations Security Council resolution aimed at stabilizing the Central African Republic, the chronically dysfunctional country in which a transitional government has failed to stop months of lawless rampaging, atrocities and dire shortages that are attracting extremist militants from neighboring states.

abstract: Stagehands who went on strike on Wednesday, causing the cancellation of Carnegie’s opening-night concert, agreed to work on Thursday night as negotiations continue.
lead_paragraph: A concert at Carnegie Hall by the American Symphony Orchestra went on as scheduled Thursday night, a day after a strike by union stagehands caused the cancellation of the hall’s gala opening concert, which had been scheduled for Wednesday evening.

headline: Can You Read People’s Emotions?
abstract: The “Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test” measures a person’s ability to understand others’ emotional states.
lead_paragraph: Are you tuned in to the emotions of others? Or have you been accused of being insensitive?

headline: For Better Social Skills, Scientists Recommend a Little Chekhov
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Empathy', 'Medicine and Health', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research']
abstract: A new study found that reading literary fiction leads to better performance on tests of empathy, social perception and emotional intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Say you are getting ready for a blind date or a job interview. What should you do? Besides shower and shave, of course, it turns out you should read — but not just anything. Something by Chekhov or Alice Munro will help you navigate new social territory better than a potboiler by Danielle Steel.

headline: Both Men and Women Should ‘Uncover’ Family Responsibilities at Work
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Families and Family Life', 'Family Leaves', 'Parenting', 'Women and Girls', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Employees who “cover” their family needs at work (calling doctor appointments meetings, and waiting until no one can see them to leave early for the school concert) contribute to workplace cultures that don’t respect the need for flexibility.
lead_paragraph: Of course people cover up aspects of themselves on the job. The workplace is generally no place for a rehash of a drinking binge or to flaunt your Axl Rose tattoo (depending, of course, on the workplace). But when people cover up their families’ needs, they’re putting family responsibility in the category of “things we don’t talk about at work,” and the results are wide reaching.

headline: Manning Has Time to Hit Right Notes
abstract: Eli Manning might have made one too many rap videos in the offseason, but William C. Rhoden says Manning is the perfect quarterback to lead the Giants out of their early season funk.
lead_paragraph: Eli Manning might have made one too many rap videos in the offseason, but William C. Rhoden says Manning is the perfect quarterback to lead the Giants out of their early season funk.

headline: What to Do With Your Retirement Plan if You Change Jobs
abstract: Some questions to consider about your 401(k) account with a previous employer: Cash it out, roll it over or let it ride?
lead_paragraph: Kya Gream, 25, recently started a new job as a medical office assistant in Champaign, Ill. Her old employer sent her a thick packet about her options for rolling over her retirement plan, but she has not taken the time yet to digest the information, since it looks a bit daunting.

lead_paragraph: That Blanche DuBois — what a cutup!

headline: California Institute of Technology Tops English Magazine’s University Rankings
abstract: The California Institute of Technology has been ranked the best university in the world by the Times Higher Education magazine of London for the third year in a row.
lead_paragraph: The California Institute of Technology has been ranked the best university in the world by the Times Higher Education magazine of London for the third year in a row, leaving Harvard University and Oxford University tied in second place.

lead_paragraph: Designers discuss their work on recent book covers.

headline: San Francisco Ballet Reaches Agreement With Dancers’ Union
abstract: The ballet company and the union representing its dancers resolved their dispute, meaning that performances in New York will proceed.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Ballet has resolved its dispute with its dancers, the ballet company and the executive director of the dancers’ union confirmed on Thursday. On Wednesday, the dancers voted “significantly” in favor of accepting the Ballet’s offer, said Alan Gordon, the executive director of the American Guild of Musical Artists. The company’s planned New York tour, which includes performances at Lincoln Center, will go ahead as planned, he and Ballet officials said.

headline: Obama Will Not Unilaterally Raise Debt Limit
abstract: President Obama will not invoke a constitutional amendment to unilaterally increase the nation’s debt limit if a continued impasse with House Republicans causes that ceiling to be breached Oct. 17, his spokesman said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will not invoke a constitutional amendment to unilaterally increase the nation’s debt limit if  an  impasse with House Republicans causes that ceiling to be breached Oct. 17, his spokesman said.

headline: Papa’s Kitchen
abstract: Inside the tiny Filipino restaurant in Woodside, Queens, where it’s karaoke night every night.
lead_paragraph: Inside the tiny Filipino restaurant in Woodside, Queens, where it’s karaoke night every night.

headline: Listen Up | The Fiery, Fashion-Forward Stylings of Iggy Azalea
abstract: The Australian rapper, who got noticed in a big way for her outfits at the shows in New York and Europe last month, is about to release an EP. An exclusive remix of the title track has its premiere here.
lead_paragraph: The trash-talking Australian MC Iggy Azalea knows that her modelesque, fashion-forward appearance is at odds with her persona. “It’s just easier to be aggressive than to play nice,” she said with a laugh. The 23-year-old, who dropped out of high school and moved from the small town of Mallumbimby, New South Wales, to Miami when she was 16, broke out in 2011 with a pair of explicit videos that caught the attention of the rapper T.I., now her mentor, who appears on Azalea’s new EP, “Change Your Life” (out Oct. 8 from Island Def Jam). A remix of the title track by DJ Shift Key has its premiere here. Azalea says she’s still getting used to the experience of being remixed. “It’s like changing a hair color,” she said. “It’s nice, but it takes some getting used to.”

headline: Closing the Government to Save Face
abstract: The Republicans’ crusade, ostensibly about dismantling health care reform, is really about showing angry constituents that they’re willing to fight.
lead_paragraph: Marlin Stutzman was, until today, a little-known Republican back-bencher, representing northeast Indiana in the House. But with just one off-message statement that he was quickly forced to retract, he became the prominent public face of the House Republicans who are refusing to re-open the United States government.

headline: Sing for Your Dinner
abstract: Papa’s Kitchen, a tiny restaurant in Woodside, Queens, serves serious Filipino comfort food and karaoke.
lead_paragraph: “Purple Haze” crashes from the speakers as stingrays flap languidly across the flat-screen TV. The singer, leaning over the rubble of his dinner (monumental pig hooves, broken crab shells), nails every throwaway whoop. The crowd, if that’s what you can call three tables, erupts.

headline: Exploring the Challenges and Opportunities in the New Communication Climate
abstract: An exploration of the challenges and benefits that come as environmental communication moves to social networks and the Web.
lead_paragraph: I just returned from my first visit to Japan, which was limited to a small slice of Tokyo, a megacity offering a dizzying mix of ancient and modern, exuberant consumption and reflective modesty. I was there to speak at an annual forum on the environment organized by the Asahi Shimbun newspaper.*

headline: Car Chase, White House to Capitol, Has Fatal End
keywords: ['Capitol Building (Washington, DC)', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: A woman with a young child was shot to death after turning her vehicle into a weapon, ramming her way through barriers at the White House and on Capitol Hill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A woman with a young child was shot to death after turning her vehicle into a weapon on Thursday afternoon, ramming her way through barriers outside the White House and on Capitol Hill.

headline: A Tortilla Trove Inspired by Street Food
abstract: Fresco, a Mexican restaurant in West Haven, evokes the simplicity of the food stalls and carts in Mexico City’s main square.
lead_paragraph: Homemade corn tortillas — supple, tender, pleasantly chewy and with a deeply satisfying flavor — bear little resemblance to the packaged discs sold in supermarkets. Fortunately for those of us without a tortilla maker, they are being served seven days a week, hot off the press, at Fresco, a Mexican restaurant in the Savin Rock area of West Haven.

headline: Warhol Death and Disaster Work to Be Sold by Sotheby’s
abstract: “Silver Car Crash (Double Disaster),” from Andy Warhol’s 1963 “Death and Disaster” series, will be put up for auction by Sotheby’s.
lead_paragraph: After Christie’s announced that “Balloon Dog (Orange),” Jeff Koons’s 10-foot-high sculpture resembling a child’s giant party favor, would be the star of its Nov. 12 postwar and contemporary-art auction, it started an international advertising campaign featuring the lovable pooch. The auction house also sent gushing e-mails to its top clients that read, “The Stage Is Set to Make History.”

headline: For Med Students, Love From the Drug Rep
abstract: Medical students and trainees are interacting with pharmaceutical representatives less than in earlier years, but roughly half have received some kind of gift from industry a new study found.
lead_paragraph: In the social and culinary wasteland that was residency training, it had been easy for Cheryl, a bubbly brunette in her mid-30s, to become our den mother. She never tired of listening to our grousing, had unerring taste in take-out, made it a point to come to our parties when invited and every so often brought in a plate of her homemade brownies.

headline: Book Covers: Before and After
abstract: Four designers discuss their work on recent book covers.
lead_paragraph: In the latest installment of “Before and After,” four book designers discuss recent examples of their work. Each designer shared early concepts for a cover as well as the final design that ended up on the book.

headline: In Louisiana, a Craft Brew Tour
abstract: The new Louisiana Craft Brewery Trail is designed to showcase beers made in the state.
lead_paragraph: Louisiana recently introduced a new craft brewery trail, aimed to complement the state’s rich culinary and music tourism.

keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Social Media', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: The first “Twitter experience hotel” was introduced this summer, sharpening the divide between vacationers who prefer digital immersion and those who seek digital detox.
lead_paragraph: First there was vacation.

headline: When Israel Stepped Back From the Brink
abstract: Firsthand testimony challenges the popular but misguided narrative that Golda Meir’s government was on the verge of using nuclear weapons in 1973.
lead_paragraph: NEXT week is the 40th anniversary of the Yom Kippur War, perhaps the most traumatic moment in Israel’s history. On Oct. 7, 1973 — the second day of the war — Israel’s borders along the Suez Canal in the south and the Golan Heights in the north collapsed under a massive assault by a coalition of Arab armies. Israel was caught unprepared.

headline: ‘If You Are Normal, You Search for Mushrooms’
abstract: In Russia, where mushroom hunting is a popular pastime, the author heads into the woods to find a sometimes elusive prize.
lead_paragraph: What is it with Russians and their mushroom hunts?

headline: Want to Go to the Olympics? Don’t Tarry
abstract: With the Winter Games in Sochi, Russia, just four months away, here’s some guidance if you’d like to make the trip.
lead_paragraph: Questions about the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, abound. Some people wonder whether the construction of the Olympic Park and other infrastructure in the resort city along the Black Sea will be completed when the Games begin on Feb. 7 (or will be worth the expected price tag of $50 billion). Others question the ethics of attending an event in a nation that recently passed a law that is widely interpreted as an effort to restrict open advocacy of homosexuality.

headline: 'Only'

lead_paragraph: Joseph J. Lhota's first television ad for the general election campaign focused on some of the similarities between him and his opponent, Bill de Blasio.

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A group of powerful rebel brigades in northern Syria is struggling to defuse an armed standoff pitting insurgents against an affiliate of Al Qaeda for control of a strategic town near the Turkish border.

lead_paragraph: The first general election ad from the de Blasio campaign features excerpts from the candidate's primary night speech.

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Russian Foreign Ministry said Thursday that it evacuated its embassy in Libya after armed men stormed the complex the day before, apparently seeking revenge for the killing of a Libyan Air Force officer.

headline: The Trip Up the Mountain That Left 11 Dead
abstract: “The Summit,” which recreates a perilous climb from 2008, accepts the age-old truth that if there is a mountain, someone will try to reach its peak.

headline: After Fraud, Regulators Go After a Bank
keywords: ['Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: A government action against TD Bank, brought in connection with a customer’s Ponzi scheme, is noteworthy because it is so rare.
lead_paragraph: You can’t run a Ponzi scheme without a bank.

headline: Now Screening | The King of Modern Longboarding Looks Back
abstract: A short documentary sponsored by Van’s highlights the influential career of Joel Tudor, who helped repopularize longboard surfing.
lead_paragraph: The surf legend Joel Tudor has appeared in more than 100 surf films, but “The Ductumentary,” a documentary short presented by Vans that will have its premiere on Monday, is the first one he’s been involved with making. It’s a portrait of the Duct Tape Invitational Series, an unorthodox longboarding contest that Tudor, the two-time longboarding world champ, started in 2010 as an antidote to the Association of Professional Surfing’s longboard competition circuit. At 25 minutes, the documentary is equal parts surfer porn and examination of Tudor’s roots and impact on the sport.

headline: A Treacherous Trip Through the Mind of a Spy
abstract: “The Farm,” a darkly serious one-act play now at the Penguin Repertory Theater, pits a C.I.A. agent against an agency therapist.
lead_paragraph: Finn and Parker are not just another patient and therapist facing off in a dreary institutional office. They both work for the C.I.A., and they both have significant secrets to keep. But then that’s how they were trained.

headline: Forgotten Fabergé Comes Out of the Attic
abstract: A Fabergé figurine of Empress Alexandra’s Cossack bodyguard that was found in an attic will be auctioned at Stair Galleries in Hudson, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Russian royals loved to collect figurines of their subjects. The Fabergé workshops produced about 50 sculptures in semiprecious stones and gold representing peasants, servants and the occasional Gypsy singer and street sweeper.

headline: The Writer and Man, Evermore
abstract: The Morgan Library & Museum, in its “Edgar Allan Poe” exhibition, includes personal items from Poe’s life, as well as some of his original manuscripts.
lead_paragraph: Edgar Allan Poe, among the unluckiest and most misunderstood of writers, is the subject of a tasteful, thoughtful exhibition that opens on Friday at the Morgan Library & Museum — about 100 years too late to do his reputation much good. Among Poe’s misfortunes is that many of his American contemporaries found his work morbid and unreadable. In some ways, he was the Mickey Rourke or Jerry Lewis of 19th-century letters, better appreciated in France, by writers like Baudelaire and Mallarmé, than he was at home.

headline: Visiting a Forgotten Nest of Early European Melody
abstract: The fourth triennial New York Early Music Celebration, a festival of period-instrument performances, delves into Polish music of the 11th through 19th centuries.
lead_paragraph: MUSICIANS who specialize in early music might take umbrage at the suggestion that the major works of the German, Italian, French and English repertories have been thoroughly picked over. Yet in recent seasons, there has been a restlessness among these players that has led them to investigate less traveled works by composers from Spain, Latin America and other countries that were largely overlooked in the early-music boom’s first few decades.

headline: Development Comes With Downsides in Cambodia
abstract: “A River Changes Course,” a documentary about Cambodia from Kalyanee Mam, looks at environmental degradation and urban migration.
lead_paragraph: Kalyanee Mam’s documentary “A River Changes Course” has won several prizes at film festivals, and deservedly so. Her intimate portrait of three Cambodian families struggling to maintain their ways of life amid environmental degradation caused by development is a beautiful example of the form. Instead of delving into the politics of their plight, Ms. Mam delivers a universal story.

headline: Colorful Guests Around the Plaza
abstract: The artist Aaron Curry has populated Lincoln Center’s Josie Robertson Plaza with 14 thin metal sculptures.
lead_paragraph: COMING of age in San Antonio in the 1970s and ’80s, the artist Aaron Curry knew nothing about opera or ballet — or fine art, for that matter. His preferred entertainment was “Scooby-Doo” and “Jonny Quest” cartoons, “Star Trek” episodes and Iron Maiden heavy-metal music. “I grew up watching TV,” he said one afternoon in the shade of Lincoln Center’s leafy London plane trees. “I’d sleep with it on.”

headline: Giant Hornets Kill Dozens in China
abstract: The Asian giant hornets, which can grow to two inches long, have left 42 dead and hundreds injured in Shaanxi Province.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Swarms of giant hornets have killed 42 people in Shaanxi Province and injured more than 1,600 in recent months, according to Xinhua, the official news agency. Government officials have yet to figure out why their attacks have been so widespread and deadly.

headline: Uncaging the Cage Fighter Within
abstract: You can’t fight in a professional mixed martial arts competition in New York, but in Lower Manhattan you can train as if you’re going to.
lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH New York still bans live professional mixed martial arts competitions, that regulation has no bearing on training. And this year the Ultimate Fighting Championship — the sport’s biggest promoter — opened its first gym in New York City.

headline: Advice From Elders Rivets a Couple on the Path to Marriage
abstract: In “Walter: Lessons From the World’s Oldest People,” Hunter Weeks and Sarah Hall ask about keys to longevity.
lead_paragraph: One way to hit a conversational dead-end at a dinner is for a couple to gush over an unusual shared hobby. “We’re just really into brewing craft kvass right now,” they might announce, while giving each other mincing grins. “We’ve never felt better. And you would not believe the varieties!” It may be difficult for two so enmeshed in their own private world to realize that not everyone shares their enthusiasm.

headline: Victim of Military Hazing to Be Immortalized in Opera
abstract: The Washington National Opera has commissioned a work based on the story of Pvt. Danny Chen, a young Chinese-American soldier from New York City who committed suicide in Afghanistan two years ago.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 3, 2011, Pvt. Danny Chen, a 19-year-old Chinese-American soldier from New York City who had been hazed and racially taunted by fellow soldiers, climbed into a guard tower on a military base in Afghanistan and killed himself with a gunshot to the head.

headline: Swimming With White Horses Away From the Battlefield
abstract: “Vikingdom” could best be described as a cross between a violent video game and a black light fantasy poster.
lead_paragraph: It’s difficult to know how to categorize “Vikingdom,” an English-language Malaysian epic starring a Briton (Craig Fairbrass) and an accentless Aussie (Dominic Purcell) as Vikings battling the god Thor (Conan Stevens, from “Game of Thrones”).

headline: The Thinking Person’s Guide to Elizabeth Gilbert
abstract: Does enjoying “Eat, Pray, Love” have anything to do with anything?
lead_paragraph: The magazine’s profile of Elizabeth Gilbert a couple of weeks ago not only drew comments about that author’s well-known book, “Eat, Pray, Love,” but it also instigated a debate about readers’ own intellects.

headline: BRIC House Celebrates Opening Weekend
abstract: The venerable BRIC arts incubator celebrates its first weekend in its new Fort Greene, Brooklyn, home with music and art.
lead_paragraph: Since it was founded in 1979, the annual Celebrate Brooklyn! music festival in Prospect Park — the strains of which the Miser has been known to enjoy, cold beverage in hand, as they stream through the living room window on summer nights — has been the primary public face of BRIC, an arts and technology incubator operating out of modest headquarters in a former vaudeville playhouse.

headline: Video of Police Chase and Eyewitness Reports of Shooting Near U.S. Capitol
abstract: Photos from the scene where gunshots prompted a lockdown at the United States Capitol.
lead_paragraph: Jordan Sekulow, executive director of the American Center for Law and Justice, was in his office at Second Street and Constitution Avenue Northeast in Washington when gunshots erupted outside, prompting a lockdown at the nearby United States Capitol about 2:30 p.m. Thursday.

headline: ‘Robert Motherwell: Early Collages’
abstract: A look at the new show at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.
lead_paragraph: A look at the new show at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

headline: A Hit Maker by Any Name
abstract: “A. K. A. Doc Pomus” focuses on the life of the writer of several early rock ’n’ roll successes.
lead_paragraph: Directed by William Hechter and Peter Miller, “A K A Doc Pomus” shines a light on the soulful, big-hearted man behind many magic moments in popular music. Born Jerome Felder, he called himself Doc Pomus, and, hobbled by childhood polio, he reached down deep, bringing forth hundreds of songs, some of them among the most poignant pop ever written. This static documentary portrait relies on the usual panning over photos and tag-team interviews, but the format, like the radio length of a song, doesn’t get in the way of its subject’s heart.

headline: Wheelies: The Pit of Vipers Edition
abstract: Chrysler’s SRT cuts Viper production to a mere trickle, and the old Packard plant in Detroit is going up for auction.
lead_paragraph: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

headline: Anything for a Laugh
abstract: Ranbir Kapoor stars as a thief in the romantic comedy “Besharam.”
lead_paragraph: Babli is a lovable lout, a cocky car thief in Delhi with loud shirts and the inevitable heart of gold. But that’s not enough for a Bollywood hero. Babli’s also an orphan who gives his ill-gotten gains to the orphanage where he grew up and still lives, sharing a bed with his sidekick, T2, as in “Terminator 2.”

headline: Your Essential Thanksgiving Recipes
abstract: Are there recipes from The New York Times archive that are essential to your holiday table?
lead_paragraph: Updated | Nov. 7, 2013 We are no longer taking suggestions for essential Thanksgiving recipes, but we would love to keep hearing your thoughts and comments on dishes you consider Thanksgiving favorites. Feel free to continue posting in the comments section below.

headline: Stability, a Real Suburban Curve Ball
abstract: Kenny Powers, a character in the returning “Eastbound & Down,” used to be foulmouthed, smug and bigoted, but now threatens to be a real hero.
lead_paragraph: Last week, on the season premiere of “Eastbound & Down,” Kenny Powers was back, sort of. A schlub in a company-issued shirt and a would-be Michael Scott for a boss, he was a shell of the boorish ex-big leaguer he once was. The first words he uttered, sitting in his car on the way to work, were, “Love NPR.” He might as well be dead.

headline: Scenes From Capitol Hill During Lockdown
abstract: The Capitol was locked down briefly on Thursday afternoon after shots were fired in front of the building.
lead_paragraph: The Capitol was locked down briefly on Thursday afternoon after shots were fired in front of the building.

headline: Twitter I.P.O. Filing Opens Books on High-Flier
abstract: In making public its prospectus, Twitter sets the clock on one of the most anticipated stock sales of the year and shows how important mobile is to its business.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10 p.m. | SAN FRANCISCO — If Lady Gaga were to send a message to her 40 million followers on Twitter summarizing the company’s debut on Wall Street, it might very well say: “Twitter IPO. Mobile. Born This Way.”

headline: At the S.B.A., Disaster Loans Continue, but Little Else
abstract: Over the last two years, the agency has guaranteed an average of $93 million in capital every business day to small businesses — all of which is now suspended.
lead_paragraph: For the Small Business Administration, the government shutdown is not as complete as one might think. Nearly 40 percent of the agency’s employees remain on the job, according to a shutdown plan published on the agency’s Web site. But even so, the agency has stopped processing regular small-business loans, leaving would-be borrowers in limbo.

headline: Iran Frees Another Reformer, but Netanyahu Warns Iranians, in Persian, Not to Be ‘Dupes’
abstract: Iran released another political prisoner, and Israel’s prime minister slipped into Persian to suggest that only “sadeloh,” or “dupes,” would be fooled by the nation’s recent diplomatic overtures.
lead_paragraph: As Iran released another political prisoner on Thursday, Israel’s prime minister slipped into Persian to suggest that only “sadeloh,” or “dupes,” would be fooled by recent diplomatic overtures from the clerical government in Tehran.

headline: Unzipped

lead_paragraph: Ever since the 40th anniversary of my first novel, ‘Fear of Flying,’ peeped over the horizon, I’ve been thinking a lot about storytelling — why certain stories stick with us and others don’t.

headline: Let’s Read About Sex
