abstract: A group of novelists, memoirists and poets tell us about working blue: what novels first inspired them, what nouns they strive to avoid and who they think writes sex best.
lead_paragraph: Writing about sex can be uniquely powerful — and perilous. A group of novelists, memoirists and poets tell us about working blue: what novels first inspired them, what nouns they strive to avoid and who they think writes sex best.

headline: With Shutdown, Questions About Visiting National Forests
keywords: ['Camps and Camping', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: Camping facilities at national forests are officially closed after the government shutdown, but some roads remain open.
lead_paragraph: While closing gates around a national park or monument is relatively simple, closing a forest is not. Newspapers and radio and television news operations around the country are reporting that while offices and facilities within the national forests have been closed, the land is still open to outdoor enthusiasts.

headline: New York City Opera Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The 70-year-old troupe seeks bankruptcy protection from its creditors, including the New York City Ballet.
lead_paragraph: New York City Opera, which was founded 70 years ago to help bring opera to the masses, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on Thursday after an urgent $7 million fund-raising appeal fell short last month.

headline: He’s Back for More Blood
abstract: Thomas Kretschmann stars in “Argento’s Dracula 3D,” a film directed by Dario Argento.
lead_paragraph: When insects are the best thing in your movie, it’s probably time to retire.

headline: The Numbers Behind Twitter
abstract: Like many tech companies seeking to go public, Twitter is growing fast but still isn’t making a profit, according to its newly filed prospectus.
lead_paragraph: Updated to include international revenue statistics.

headline: Twitter’s Letter to Shareholders Is Short and Lightweight
abstract: Unlike Google and Facebook, which used their I.P.O. filings to write long, high-minded letters about their business philosophies, Twitter wrote a letter that was brief, but touched on similar notes.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s ancestors, Google and Facebook, used their initial public offering filings to write long letters about the high-minded philosophies of their companies. But Twitter’s letter in its filing, which was made public on Thursday, was much more succinct — perhaps fitting for a company that has popularized short bursts of information.

headline: A Painter’s Cut-and-Paste Prequel
abstract: “Robert Motherwell: Early Collages,” at the Guggenheim, focuses on works from the 1940s and ‘50s, before he turned to his elegant mode of Abstract Expressionism.
lead_paragraph: Abstract Expressionism is overrated. And it wasn’t initially a movement or style at all. It was a bunch of unalike artists, some great, some not, who shared a city, a war, some ideas and a bar, circa 1940. Pretty much everything else, including a fecund two-decade fad for soulful painting that grew from that moment, was largely a product of marketing and myth spinning.

headline: Cuba in America, Onstage and Unbound
abstract: Michele Rosewoman’s set at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola promoted her new album with New Yor-Uba.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Michele Rosewoman’s long-running project New Yor-Uba, which she revived for a new album and two nights of performances at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola, still looks good on paper and sounds better in practice.

headline: Cowboy With a Cause
abstract: “Running Wild: The Life of Dayton O. Hyde” tells how one man created a horse sanctuary.
lead_paragraph: “People were telling me it couldn’t be done,” the craggy, white-haired man in the denim shirt says. “And that’s the wrong thing to say to a cowboy.”

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: baby smells, health insurance and food-borne illness. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: baby smells, health insurance and food-borne illness. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Shots Fired Near the Capitol
abstract: Law enforcement officers shot a woman during a car chase from the White House.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement officers shot a woman during a car chase from the White House.

headline: Vigneault Still Learning About His Rangers as Season Opens
abstract: Alain Vigneault is about to start his 12th season as an N.H.L. coach, but he admitted to nerves on Thursday before his first game with the Rangers.
lead_paragraph: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Alain Vigneault is about to start his 12th season as an N.H.L. coach, but of course this time is different. After the morning skate ahead of the Rangers’ opener against the Phoenix Coyotes here Thursday, he talked about how he felt as he prepared to coach his first regular-season game with the Blueshirts.

headline: Huddled Masses, Studiously Eyed
abstract: Lewis Hine, the subject of two shows at the International Center for Photography, pursued a kind of illustrated sociology rather than photojournalism.
lead_paragraph: With so much contemporary art photography devoted to the slippery nature of photography itself, it’s a good corrective to regularly visit the International Center of Photography, an institution founded on faith in the medium as a window on empirical reality. Among the non-navel-gazing shows on view there are a pair devoted to the pioneering documentarian Lewis Hine (1874-1940), whose subjects included immigrants arriving at Ellis Island, children working in factories and coal mines, families living in Lower East Side tenements, black Americans and men building skyscrapers.

headline: Car Chase and Gunshots in the Capital
abstract: Car Chase and Gunshots at Capitol Hill
lead_paragraph: Car Chase and Gunshots at Capitol Hill

headline: Touching on Modern, Hip-Hop and Tap
abstract: The fourth program of this year’s Fall for Dance festival embraces the series’s aesthetic of diverse styles.
lead_paragraph: Every Fall for Dance program — this year, especially — shows marvelously mind-widening diversity. Most dancegoers have relatively narrow tastes, but the festival ignores that. Each year, it keeps drawing our attention to things we hadn’t seen, didn’t know, might have missed, new and old; it loves to place dissimilar genres side by side. Its every performance sells out and is lustily cheered; I ardently hope that it leads people to see examples of dance they’ve never visited before.

headline: A Shooting Star Lights Up Manhattan
abstract: “Linsanity,” Evan Jackson Leong’s documentary, looks at how Jeremy Lin became a basketball sensation.
lead_paragraph: It was only 20 months ago, but seems far more distant: that stretch in February 2012 when Jeremy Lin, a relative unknown from the end of the bench, took over as a guard for the New York Knicks and promptly tore through the N.B.A. He scored more points in his first five starts than any other player in nearly 40 years, peaking with 38 against the Los Angeles Lakers (Kobe Bryant managed only 34 that night).

headline: Back in the Blue Saddle, for a Gallop to Abstraction
abstract: The Neue Galerie’s Kandinsky exhibition examines a 15-year period in which the artist moved from Expressionism to clean-edged abstraction.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers might be forgiven for greeting “Vasily Kandinsky: From Blaue Reiter to the Bauhaus, 1910-1925,” at the Neue Galerie, with a shrug and a distinct feeling of déjà vu. Wasn’t it just three years ago now that the Guggenheim mounted a full retrospective, a delirium-inducing helix of Kandinskys?

headline: ‘Extreme Measures’
abstract: Photos from the Chris Burden show at the New Museum.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the Chris Burden show at the New Museum.

headline: The Intoxicating, Tradition-Steeped Charm of New Orleans
abstract: In spite of its difficulties, the Big Easy has hung on to its seductive authenticity. It’s still ripe for discovery, for transplants and locals alike.
lead_paragraph: With its last-frontier appeal and magical mixed bag of culture, New Orleans is quietly luring a circle of expats, who find an evolving city that’s just the right amount of undone.

headline: Living and Killing in a Materialist China
abstract: In “A Touch of Sin,” the director Jia Zhang-ke presents four stories, based on real events, that illustrate a country’s social and political upheaval.
lead_paragraph: A blistering fictionalized tale straight out of China, “A Touch of Sin” is at once monumental and human scale. A story of lives rocked by violence, it has the urgency of a screaming headline but one inscribed with visual lyricism, emotional weight and a belief in individual rights. You can feel the conviction of its director, Jia Zhang-ke — one of the few filmmakers of any nationality who weighs the impact of social and political shifts on people — in every shot. In “A Touch of Sin,” the world isn’t an amorphous backdrop, pretty scenery for private dramas, it is a stage on which men and women struggle to fulfill basic moral obligations, including recognizing one another’s humanity.

headline: Andy Warhol Schlepped Here
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Art', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: For the photographer Christopher Makos, a West Village walk-up has been home for 40 years. The scene has changed a bit.
lead_paragraph: All the art in the photographer Christopher Makos’s modest four-room apartment in a six-story walk-up building in the West Village is by friends or fellow scene-makers, a roll call of the New York art world of the ’70s and ’80s: Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Bruce Weber, Cindy Sherman, Jeff Koons, Donald Baechler, Keith Haring. Mr. Makos lives much as he did in that era, a bohemian who brushes his teeth in the kitchen sink because his bathroom has only a toilet and a cast-iron tub.

headline: What I Love | Christopher Makos
abstract: Mr. Makos West Village walk-up is hung with art by Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Bruce Weber, Cindy Sherman and others.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Makos West Village walk-up is hung with art by Andy Warhol, Roy Lichtenstein, Bruce Weber, Cindy Sherman and others.

headline: The Stuff of Building and Destroying
abstract: The New Museum’s survey of Chris Burden’s performances and sculptures expands and rebalances our understanding of his art.
lead_paragraph: “Chris Burden: Extreme Measures” at the New Museum is a superb survey, but also a kind of transfiguration. It liberates the Los Angeles-based Mr. Burden from the clutches of history, expanding and rebalancing our understanding of his art.

headline: One Holds the Cards, the Other Is Bluffing
abstract: In “Runner Runner,” Justin Timberlake joins Ben Affleck in running an offshore Internet gambling site.
lead_paragraph: In “Runner Runner,” directed by Brad Furman from a script by Brian Koppelman and David Levien, Ben Affleck and Justin Timberlake face off, cleft chin to cleft chin, in a battle for ... well, what, exactly? The attention of the audience? Of Gemma Arterton, who plays virtually the only female character in the movie not employed as a hooker or a stripper? Huge sums of money? All of the above, or whatever.

headline: Plain or Painted? In Any Case, Unfaded
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Although some Greenwich Village row houses were built in plain brick, paint is now part of their personality.
lead_paragraph: We now live in a culture in which everything must be original. We have to strip the paint off our oak paneling. Our architecture has to look as if it had always been there. Our jeans have to be faded. But original can turn around and bite you, as shown in the perplexing case of 90 Macdougal Street, a house in the Macdougal-Sullivan Gardens complex, between Houston and Bleecker Streets.

headline: Comedy Listings for Oct. 4-10
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York.
lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Leader of Cancer Center Works on Changes After Feedback
abstract: Ronald DePinho, the president of the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center, has ambitious plans in leading the institute’s efforts to combat the disease.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Ronald DePinho, the president of the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center, part of the University of Texas, becomes animated when he talks about his ambitious plans in leading the institute’s efforts to combat the disease.

headline: Theater Listings for Oct. 4-10
abstract: A guide to theater productions in New York, with a special note of shows in previews or about to open.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Movie Listings for Oct. 4-10
abstract: A critical guide to movies playing in New York, including film series.
lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Is There Really a Market for That?
abstract: In “Concussion,” by Stacie Passon, a woman finds an escape from the tedium of her marriage by becoming a prostitute catering to other women.
lead_paragraph: “Concussion,” written and directed by Stacie Passon, deals with the age-old challenge of keeping that special spark alive. How do you find meaning in lives that seem to consist of routine, much less appreciate desire in its complexity and vividness?

headline: Hurdles for Condo Buyers
abstract: Increasingly, condo governing boards are emulating co-ops, asking buyers to complete lengthy applications and provide extensive financial information.
lead_paragraph: In New York, buyers intent on getting a co-op know to brace themselves for the notoriously invasive approval process. But increasingly, condominium buyers are also being asked to fill out lengthy applications and provide detailed financial information to buildings’ governing boards.

headline: Push for a Shift Could Affect Governor’s Race
keywords: ['Elections, Comptrollers', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Governors']
abstract: Debra Medina, a Republican pursuing a state comptroller seat, said she has received requests to instead run for governor as an independent, which could benefit another candidate.
lead_paragraph: Why would anyone want Debra Medina to run for governor as an independent?

headline: A Japanese Welcome, and Korean-Style Barbecue
abstract: Gyu-Kaku, a giant chain in Japan, has made a bold move into Westchester with new and different tastes and a diverse appeal.
lead_paragraph: With close to 800 locations in Asia and the United States, and three outposts already in Manhattan, could Westchester County be far behind? Apparently not. Last June, Gyu-Kaku settled into White Plains, a bold move in an area jammed with restaurants offering every culinary variety — or so one would think. With its very Korean spin on Japanese barbecue, Gyu-Kaku has managed to bring new and different tastes to the city center’s growing dining scene.

headline: Game Firms Get Great Tax Deals, Maybe Too Great
keywords: ['Computer and Video Games', 'Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Texas is ranked second in the nation in video game employment, and some say the reason is the unusually generous incentive arrangements that companies receive.
lead_paragraph: In the lobby of the Twisted Pixel Games studio in Austin, a futuristic motorcycle welcomes visitors with an electric blue glow. The robotic motorcycle stars in LocoCycle, a new video game produced almost entirely in Texas.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for Oct. 4-10
abstract: A selected guide to performances of indie rock, punk, rap and electro-pop in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Prices may not reflect ticketing service charges. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: A Wedding? Uncork the Rancor
abstract: In “A.C.O.D.,” the hero tries to prevent his fractious divorced parents from spoiling his brother’s wedding.
lead_paragraph: “A.C.O.D.,” an unfunny comedy about a guy mooning over his parents’ divorce decades later, is so eager to please it’s hard to hate. But it’s sluggish even at 87 minutes, clichéd and gives you nothing of interest to look at other than some familiar faces. Early on, during one of its inertly staged and shot conversations between two people — the kind that switches between over-the-shoulder shots, the performers frozen on their marks and drained of animation — one of the character’s words didn’t match his mouth. The words just kept coming, and so did the perfunctory rest of it.

headline: Jazz Listings for Oct. 4-10
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A selected guide to performances of classical music in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent classical performances: nytimes.com/classical. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Sell Them Trees, Then Steal Them Blind
abstract: Paul Giamatti and Paul Rudd play professional thieves attempting to give up crime in “All Is Bright,” a new film directed by Phil Morrison.
lead_paragraph: The wry tone of “All Is Bright,” a sardonic, smart screwball comedy that teams Paul Giamatti and Paul Rudd as professional thieves trying to “go straight” by selling Christmas trees in New York City, is defined by its droll soundtrack of holiday favorites. Familiar carols are reduced to bouncy instrumental elevator music with a hint of jazz and a smirk on its face.

headline: Dance Listings for Oct. 4-10
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent dance performances: nytimes.com/dance. A searchable guide to these and other performances is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Majority Disapprove of Shutting Down Government Over Health Law
abstract: A wide majority of Americans disapprove of shutting down the federal government over differences about the 2010 health care law, including a majority of those who oppose the law, according to the latest CBS News poll.
lead_paragraph: A wide majority of Americans disapprove of shutting down the federal government over differences about the 2010 health care law, including a majority of those who oppose the law, according to the latest CBS News poll.

headline: Museum and Gallery Listings for Oct. 4-10
abstract: A critical guide to the visual arts in New York and the region.
lead_paragraph: Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of recent art shows: nytimes.com/art. A searchable guide to these and many other art shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Fleeing Her Troubles for a Host of New Ones
abstract: “I Used to Be Darker” is an intimate journey through the lives of an unraveling family.
lead_paragraph: A ballad of photographs, music and memories — both the old we savor and the new we consciously construct — “I Used to Be Darker” picks at the seams of an unraveling family and watches to see what will happen.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Bulgaria and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Bulgaria. Italy, Nigeria and Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Bulgaria. Italy, Nigeria and Myanmar.

headline: The Pleasure of Crime
abstract: A lawyer at the center of Ponzi scheme found a song to identify with: the Eagles’ “Life in the Fast Lane.”
lead_paragraph: The question that I am most often asked about Ponzi schemes is “Why?” Didn’t the person behind the scheme know that it was inevitable he would be caught? That he would be sent to prison?

headline: Obama on Government Shutdown
abstract: The president addressed people at the M. Luis Construction Company in Rockville, Md.
lead_paragraph: The president addressed people at the M. Luis Construction Company in Rockville, Md.

headline: Dallas, 1963, Redux
abstract: The docudrama “Parkland” evokes the chaos, panic and sickening bloodshed around President Kennedy’s shooting, concentrating on the responses of secondary players.
lead_paragraph: “Parkland,” Peter Landesman’s taut but unsatisfying docudrama about the Kennedy assassination, is mercifully short. For the events depicted, no matter how familiar, still hurt. Watching the movie is like enduring dental surgery without anesthesia. You clench your fists, suck in your breath and remind yourself that the pain will end. And when it does, sooner than expected, you sigh with relief.

headline: Spare Times for Children for Oct. 4-10
abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: LIVE BAT ENCOUNTERS

headline: Fighting School Bullies With a Camera
abstract: In “The Dirties,” two best friends who love making and talking about movies confront high school bullying.
lead_paragraph: Remarkable as much for its insights as for its audacity, “The Dirties” approaches school violence with a comic veneer that slowly shades into deep darkness. Capturing the downward spiral of Matt (played by the director, Matt Johnson), an excitable high schooler terrorized by bullies and obsessed with bloodthirsty movies, this found-footage exercise unfolds with shocking credibility.

headline: Twitter’s Biggest Risk? Losing You
abstract: In Twitter’s I.P.O. filing, the company said the quality of its users posts will determine if people will continue to use the social media site.
lead_paragraph: Even though Twitter’s staff has ballooned to about 2,000 employees, having talented workers isn’t nearly as crucial for the company as having quality users.

headline: Her Huddled Masses? They Must Settle for a 47-Foot Imitation
abstract: As tourists were turned away from the Statue of Liberty in New York Harbor because of the government shutdown, the statue’s smaller twin at the Brooklyn Museum was open, if just as desolate.
lead_paragraph: A New York vacation is not a New York vacation without a visit to the Statue of Liberty, and so, on Thursday afternoon, a tourist from Kuwait strolled up to Lady Liberty’s plinth and turned toward the camera, smiling broadly. His wife took a photo with her iPhone, tilting it up to make sure she captured the entire statue, crown to toe.

headline: A Feminist’s Daughter Finds Love in the Kitchen
abstract: A child’s expression of admiration for her mother is food for thought.
lead_paragraph: On Mother’s Day last spring, my 10-year-old daughter listed some things she loves about having me as her mother. The first two surprised me: “You make my lunch most days,” she began, “and you make dinner.” Other observations followed, including that I am “huggy” and “smart.” But first came the kitchen.

headline: Telling Them Not to Take a Hike
abstract: How to tell friends that their children aren’t welcome on a trip.
lead_paragraph: We are planning a hiking trip with three other couples. One of them is now asking to bring their two adult children, who are in their early 20s. We would prefer the children not come; they would inevitably change the dynamic of the trip. So we exchanged e-mails on the subject with their parents. We wrote, “We assumed this was an old geezers’ trip.” Our friends replied, “Assumed or preferred?” How should we respond and still keep the peace?

headline: Spare Times for Oct. 4-10
abstract: A listing of crafts fairs, parades, film festivals, literary talks and other cultural events in New York.
lead_paragraph: Literary Events (Friday through Sunday) The literary smorgasbord known as The New Yorker Festival is offering ample servings of readings, discussions and screenings with writers, actors and others, at several locations. Online sales are closed for many events, but tickets to some notable ones are still available.

headline: Love Triangle, With Mom in the Middle
abstract: Macdara Vallely’s “Babygirl” centers on a teenager who is trapped in a love triangle with her mother’s boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: Set in a vibrant Puerto Rican community in the Bronx, “Babygirl” is a gently knowing coming-of-age tale about the dangers of combining intellectual precociousness with emotional immaturity.

headline: Making Life, and Your Cat, Sit Still
abstract: Mimi Vang Olsen paints portraits of homes and of pets.
lead_paragraph: When Mimi Vang Olsen is commissioned to paint a portrait of a home and its inhabitants, her goal is not simply to record the color of the walls and the style of the sofa. Her aim is to produce a small, richly textured domestic drama, studded with the tiny but telling details that reveal the true nature of those who call the setting home and the intricate emotional relationships that bind them.

headline: Pet Portraitist
abstract: Mimi Vang Olsen, a painter of cats, dogs and domestic scenes, works out of a Hudson Street storefront.
lead_paragraph: Mimi Vang Olsen, a painter of cats, dogs and domestic scenes, works out of a Hudson Street storefront.

headline: Events in Westchester
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Stress Brings Out a Real Monster in Him
abstract: In the comedy “Bad Milo!” Ken Marino plays a mild-mannered accountant with a vengeful critter living in his colon.
lead_paragraph: The premise of “Bad Milo!,” Jacob Vaughan’s devilish comedy about a mild-mannered accountant with an angry critter lodged in his colon, is not nearly as gross as it sounds. For one thing, the anal intruder — which resembles a hairless troll doll — is rather cute. And for another, Mr. Vaughan is more eager to inspire giggles than gag reflexes.

headline: Events in Connecticut
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Twitter’s Evolution From Side Project to Wall Street Hopeful
abstract: Twitter’s filing for its initial public offering showcases the different ways that Twitter is used.
lead_paragraph: “People are at the heart of Twitter.”

headline: A Heartbreaking Loss for One and All
abstract: “Bridegroom,” directed by Linda Bloodworth-Thomason, is about an unmarried gay couple in their 20s and the hardships faced by one of the men when the other dies in an accident.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by a viral YouTube video and deftly directed by Linda Bloodworth-Thomason (“Designing Women”), “Bridegroom” is about an unmarried gay couple in their 20s and what happens when one of them dies. That’s the simple summary of this simply told but exceptionally moving documentary.

headline: Taking the Stigma Out of Dyslexia
abstract: “Dislecksia” is a humorous documentary about a serious subject: what dyslexia is and how to treat it.
lead_paragraph: “Dislecksia: The Movie,” directed by Harvey Hubbell V, is an informative, entertaining survey about what dyslexia is and how to treat it. A central theme is that the condition, estimated to affect up to 35 million Americans, is not a learning disability, but a learning difference.

headline: Elvin R. Heiberg III, General Who Took Blame for Hurricane Katrina Failures, Dies at 81
abstract: General Heiberg, as head of the Army Corps of Engineers, regretted his decision to stop fighting for barriers to protect New Orleans.
lead_paragraph: Lt. Gen. Elvin R. Heiberg III, who rose to the top of the United States Army Corps of Engineers in the 1980s and decades later expressed regret for failing to fight hard enough to build floodgates that he believed might have protected New Orleans from Hurricane Katrina, died on Sept. 27 in Arlington, Va. He was 81.

headline: Phantom Crises (Wonkish)
abstract: Show me the model!
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis is puzzled by a Ken Rogoff column that sorta-kinda defends Cameron’s austerity policies. His puzzlement, which I share, comes at several levels. But I want to focus on just one thing: Rogoff’s assertion that Britain could have faced a southern Europe-style crisis, with a loss of investor confidence driving up interest rates and plunging the economy into a deep slump.

headline: Newcomer’s Rite of Passage
abstract: In “Five Dances,” Ryan Steele plays a young dancer who goes through a newcomer’s rite of passage at a New York dance company.
lead_paragraph: Five people rehearsing in an otherwise vacant dance studio: That pitch may not appeal to everyone, but fans of the movement arts and ensemble acting will appreciate the possibilities. Yet few of those possibilities are explored with any depth in “Five Dances,” a promising though static new film that never leaves its taciturn shadows for a single emotionally gripping moment.

headline: Breaking From Recent Tech Tradition, Twitter Forgoes Multiple Stock Classes
abstract: The decision by Twitter to have just one class of stock marks a big change from the big Internet I.P.O.’s of the last several years, in which companies rolled out multiclass stock structures aimed at preserving control for the company’s founders.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s initial public offering highlights many of the social network’s differences from rivals like Facebook. But the company’s prospectus highlights one unexpected change: the lack of multiple classes of stock.

headline: In Store | Old-World Luxury, For Sale Downtown
abstract: Atelier Courbet, a new gallery and shop in SoHo, highlights contemporary design that employs time-honored techniques.
lead_paragraph: After doing everything from curation to publicity for design-world stars like Thom Mayne and Dror Benshetrit and luxury goods companies like LVMH, Melanie Courbet has ventured out on her own to indulge her passion for craftsmanship. At Atelier Courbet, her new SoHo gallery and shop in a 19th-century building on Mott Street, which opens Saturday, she will offer contemporary design by companies and workshops that use Old World techniques to produce everything from spoons to bicycles.

headline: Friends Come Together for an Intervention
abstract: Friends try to stage an intervention for an alcoholic buddy holed up at his family’s old cabin upstate in Craig DiFolco’s “Last Day of August.”
lead_paragraph: Can’t a guy just get away for a few months at his family’s old cabin upstate? Do his city friends have to show up unannounced, en masse, all concerned and overhelpful?

headline: The Twitter Wealthy
abstract: Twitter disclosed the details of its planned initial public offering, offering the names of potential Twitter millionaires and one billionaire.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s public filing for an initial public offering says it has over 100 million daily users. It also has a few very lucky takers.

headline: Something Creepy This Way Comes
abstract: Things are far from pastoral when a preacher moves his family to a small town in “Nothing Left to Fear,” directed by Anthony Leonardi III.
lead_paragraph: A girl proves to be a pain to her relatives in “Nothing Left to Fear,” a horror trifle about a minister’s family discovering that its new rural neighborhood is a passageway to a demonic petri dish — or something otherwise Hell-like. Dan Bramford (James Tupper of “Revenge”) and his wife, Wendy (Anne Heche), want only to assimilate into their congregation. But their adolescent daughters have boys on their minds, and that, of course, means jeopardy.

headline: Board Battle Leads to Exit of Telecom Italia Chief
abstract: Franco Bernabè resigned as chief executive of Telecom Italia on Thursday after a dispute on how to reduce the company's debt load.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Franco Bernabè resigned as chief executive of Telecom Italia on Thursday after he clashed with some of the European telecommunications company’s major investors.

headline: Big Canadian Carrier Shuns New BlackBerry Phone
abstract: Rogers Communications, one of the first carriers in the world to offer devices from BlackBerry, will not sell the ailing smartphone maker’s new Z30 phone.
lead_paragraph: Rogers Communications, based in Toronto and one of the first carriers in the world to offer devices from BlackBerry, will not sell the ailing smartphone maker’s new flagship Z30 phone, the president of its wireless unit said on Thursday.

headline: Wall Street Seeks to Soothe, While Preparing for Trouble
abstract: Financial executives are making some early preparations on the possibility of a default on public debt should Congress fail to raise the debt ceiling.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street is preparing for the government to bounce its first check.

headline: Official’s Big Salary in California City May Lead to Prison
abstract: The former administrator of Bell, who became an emblem of municipal corruption for his inflated salary, unexpectedly avoided a trial that was about to start.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Robert Rizzo, the former city administrator of Bell, Calif., accused of looting millions from city coffers, pleaded no contest to all 69 charges against him on Thursday, prosecutors announced.

headline: Armenian Church, Survivor of the Ages, Faces Modern Hurdles
abstract: Leaders of the Apostolic Church, which has outlasted conquest, genocide and government-imposed atheism, are confronting challenges like entrenched secularism and disaffection with organized religion.
lead_paragraph: ECHMIADZIN, Armenia — In this ancient city, tucked in a valley that has witnessed the rise and fall of empires, King Tiridates III converted to Christianity and declared Armenia to be the world’s first Christian state. The year was 301, more than a decade before the Emperor Constantine put Rome on a similar path.

headline: Tunisian Ex-Soccer Player Extradited
abstract: Nizar Trabelsi, who was sentenced to a decade in prison in Belgium in 2003 for planning a suicide bombing for Al Qaeda, will face charges in an American court.
lead_paragraph: A former Tunisian soccer player who was sentenced to a decade in prison in Belgium in 2003 for planning a suicide bombing for Al Qaeda against a military base there — which is also used by NATO — has been extradited to the United States to face similar charges in an American court, the Justice Department announced Thursday. The player, Nizar Trabelsi, 43, was indicted under seal in 2006 in the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. Prosecutors say he traveled to Afghanistan in the spring of 2001 and met with Osama bin Laden and, later, Muhammed Atef, a chief military planner for the terrorist group. The indictment accuses him of obtaining chemicals in Europe to build a 1,000-kilogram bomb and joining others to scout the military base, Kleine Brogel Air Base, as a potential target for a suicide attack.

headline: Ballmer’s Bonus Shrinks on Weakness of Windows

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft‘s board of directors has again penalized the company’s chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, for the company’s performance by giving him a smaller bonus than he was eligible for.

Putin.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Elijah Zarlin was handcuffed outside the White House two years ago for joining in weeks of protests against the Keystone XL pipeline. His arrest would have been an ordinary rite of Washington, except for one thing: Mr. Zarlin had been an aide at the headquarters of Barack Obama’s first presidential campaign.

headline: Russia: A Legal Victory for Kasparov

abstract: Garry Kasparov, the chess champion and opposition politician, on Thursday won a ruling against the Russian government for an illegal arrest at a Moscow rally in 2007.
lead_paragraph: Garry Kasparov, the chess champion and opposition politician, on Thursday won a ruling against the Russian government in the European Court of Human Rights for an illegal arrest at a rally in Moscow in 2007. In the past, Mr. Kasparov has been arrested on pretexts like an allegation that he bit a police officer’s finger while protesting last year against the conviction of members of the band Pussy Riot. The court found that the 2007 arrest was “disproportionate to the aim of maintaining public order” and ordered Russian authorities pay Mr. Kasparov about $13,500 in damages.

headline: In Autumn, a Taste of the Season

lead_paragraph: Wanda Jacobson understands the appeal of fresh wood-pressed apple cider on a crisp autumn afternoon. What continually surprises her is what people will do to get it.

headline: Russia: More Charges for Greenpeace
keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Piracy at Sea', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: Prosecutors have now pressed piracy charges against the entire crew of a Greenpeace International ship, including the captain; the ship’s cook and doctor; and two freelance journalists.
lead_paragraph: Russian prosecutors have now pressed charges of piracy against the entire crew of the Greenpeace International ship the Arctic Sunrise, including the captain, Peter Willcox; the ship’s cook and doctor; and two freelance journalists who were among the 30 people aboard last month when Russian authorities seized the vessel during a protest in the Arctic Ocean. The prosecutors charged 16 people on Thursday and 14 on Wednesday. The charges carry a maximum sentence of 15 years in prison upon conviction. The activists said their attempts to scale the side of a Russian oil platform were meant to call attention to the environmental hazards of drilling in icy northern waters.

headline: U.S. Accuses 13 Hackers in Web Attacks

headline: Weary but Spirited, the Well-Traveled Rays Roll Into Fenway

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Tampa Bay Rays arrived here just after 4 a.m. Thursday, their fourth city and second country in five days. They were exhausted but satisfied, having won three straight win-or-go-home games.

headline: Britain: Online Surveillance Challenged
abstract: Three British organizations said they had filed a legal challenge to the online surveillance programs of the British spy agency the Government Communications Headquarters.
lead_paragraph: Three British organizations said Thursday that they had filed a legal challenge in the European Court of Human Rights to the online surveillance programs of the British spy agency the Government Communications Headquarters. The groups are seeking to have the court declare the collection of metadata, including e-mails and social media messages, in secret programs revealed by the American intelligence analyst Edward J. Snowden to be an illegal breach of the right to privacy. The case, financed through donations, has been brought by English PEN, the Open Rights Group and Big Brother Watch, as well as by a German activist. The government said that a similar challenge could not be brought in domestic courts, but that a complaint could be made only to the Investigatory Powers Tribunal, which does not act in public.

headline: Jack Dorsey Gave Evan Williams His Voting Power at Twitter

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Fearing that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was on the verge of ordering an airstrike on Iran’s nuclear plants, President Obama sent two emissaries here almost exactly a year ago to stop him. Warning that the White House could not abide an attack in the run-up to the November elections, the Americans persuaded the prime minister to give the newest sanctions time to bite, according to Americans and Israelis familiar with the tense exchanges.

headline: Experts See Potential Ways Out for Obama in Debt Ceiling Maze

abstract: The view that President Obama could continue borrowing without Congressional authorization is based on three arguments: presidential power, a provision of the 14th Amendment and constitutional obligations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Even as President Obama insists that he would be powerless to save the economy from catastrophe should Congress fail to raise the nation’s debt ceiling, some law professors say he does have options. They may be politically unattractive, unpalatable to the financial markets and subject to legal challenges, these experts say, but these choices are better than failing to live up to the nation’s financial commitments.

headline: Bats and Balls May Need an Introduction

headline: How a Debt Ceiling Crisis Could Do More Harm Than the Shutdown
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Most economists and investors view the debt ceiling as a much more significant issue for the economy which has the potential to set off a global financial crisis.

Most economists and investors view the debt ceiling as a much more significant issue for the economy, with the potential to set off a global financial crisis. What is all the concern about? Here is an attempt to answer the basic questions.

headline: India: Ex-Official Is Jailed in Graft Case
abstract: An Indian court sentenced Lalu Prasad, a former chief minister of the state of Bihar, to five years in prison for corruption on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: An Indian court sentenced Lalu Prasad, a former chief minister of the state of Bihar, to five years in prison for corruption on Thursday after he was found guilty of participating in a scheme in which officials created false receipts and siphoned off $6 million worth of public funds earmarked for animal husbandry for more than a decade. The sentence effectively bars him from participating in the coming national and state elections. Mr. Prasad is the first major political figure affected by a Supreme Court order disqualifying politicians who are sentenced to prison terms of more than two years. More than 40 politicians, bureaucrats and suppliers were sentenced in the case, but Mr. Prasad is by far the most significant. His party controls four parliamentary seats allied with the national governing party, and he is a loyal supporter of Sonia Gandhi, the president of the Congress Party.

headline: Is Miguel Cabrera the Hero of the Post-Steroid Era?

lead_paragraph: Miguel Cabrera looked as if he were wearing pajamas, untucked and mismatched, as he lumbered around the Detroit Tigers’ clubhouse in a sweaty gray T-shirt and a pair of Nike shower shoes. Known to his teammates as Miggy, Cabrera wore his hair dense down the middle and bare on the sides — in what he called “a faux-hawk.” In an era in which even baseball players have come to resemble souped-up Eastern bloc Olympians, Miggy packs more of a stonemason physique: he is 6-foot-4 with massive arms and torso, but also a noticeable paunch of fluctuating size and, God bless him, well-articulated man-boobs. Yet he is the reigning American League M.V.P. and quite possibly the best hitter of his generation. (One of the fun parts about writing about baseball is inviting a “best of his generation” debate before the first paragraph is even over.)

lead_paragraph: Phillip Swagel is a professor at the School of Public Policy at the University of Maryland and was assistant secretary for economic policy at the Treasury Department from 2006 to 2009.

headline: The Short-Seller Stands Tall
keywords: ['Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Hedge Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The hedge-fund manager William Ackman on hunting elephants and aggravating friends.
lead_paragraph: Your fund, Pershing Square Capital Management, took a $500-million loss on its investment in J. C. Penney. How did that feel?  I’m not emotional about investments. Investing is something where you have to be purely rational, and not let emotion affect your decision making — just the facts.

headline: Drinking Like Hemingway

lead_paragraph: A critical assessment of Brooklyn’s authors; why you’re gaining weight on Sundays.

headline: Why I Silence Your Call, Even When I’m Free
abstract: There might be a human with genuine needs on the other line.
lead_paragraph: My cousin Stacey in San Francisco called recently. We hadn’t spoken since she visited me the previous month, and I missed her. I was sitting in my office, catching up on e-mail while refreshing my Twitter feed every few minutes. Hardly too busy for a chat.

headline: When Meta Met Data
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'English Language', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The advent of metadata shows us just how much — and how little — we truly know.
lead_paragraph: Lost in all the anxiety and hand-wringing over revelations about big data, personal privacy and the National Security Agency is another unfortunate, and consequential, societal development: A transformation in the meaning of “meta.” This has happened specifically in relation to metadata — the transactional digital information that pinpoints the date and time you called someone, for example, or locates the spot from which you last accessed your e-mail account — but also to our larger understanding of the concept of meta; our metaunderstanding, as it were.

headline: Dead Man’s Burden
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Wills and Estates', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Cancer', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Prostate Cancer']
abstract: Against their will; for their own good.
lead_paragraph: A family member died last winter and named me and my sister the heirs to his estate. In a letter accompanying the will (but not part of it), he asked us to donate several thousand dollars to certain organizations. Some of these are extremely right-wing groups, which we feel border on the fringe: paranoiac with no objectivity, with ties to militant political organizations. We feel conflicted about this — we want to honor our relative’s wishes but really take offense to some of these groups. L.B., CALIFORNIA

headline: And Then Steve Said, ‘Let There Be an iPhone’
abstract: An age of darkness ended with a searing light, which shook the earth, and the great device was rendered unto thee.
lead_paragraph: The 55 miles from Campbell to San Francisco make for one of the nicest commutes anywhere. The journey mostly zips along the Junipero Serra Freeway, a grand and remarkably empty highway that abuts the east side of the Santa Cruz Mountains. It is one of the best places in Silicon Valley to spot a start-up tycoon speed-testing his Ferrari and one of the worst places for cellphone reception. For Andy Grignon, it was therefore the perfect place for him to be alone with his thoughts early on Jan. 8, 2007.

lead_paragraph: What’s floating in the East River?

headline: Who Made Movie Popcorn?
abstract: A widow’s Depression-era triumph.
lead_paragraph: In the 1920s, movie palaces rose up around the country like so many portals into a glamorous world. After you bought a ticket, you might pass through gilded archways and ascend a grand staircase lighted by a crystal chandelier to find your velvet seat. Eating was not meant to be part of the experience, says Andrew F. Smith, author of “Popped Culture: A Social History of Popcorn in America.” Theater owners feared that audiences would strew popcorn and peanuts on those crimson carpets. They hung signs discouraging people from bringing in food from vendors parked outside and didn’t sell it themselves.

headline: Bridging the Gap Between High School and College, at a Price
keywords: ['Sabbaticals and Career Breaks', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Education', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: A year off to pursue learning outside of academics is increasingly common for new high school graduates, but it can cost as much as a year’s college tuition.
lead_paragraph: MY older son is about a month into his freshman year at college, and like most of his classmates, is adjusting to new roommates, classes and doing his own laundry.

lead_paragraph: Investors have an enormous hunger for shares of the Potbelly Corporation, it seems.

lead_paragraph: The world’s largest photography museum is coming to Marrakesh: the Marrakech Museum for Photography and Visual Art is scheduled to open in 2016 near the Menara Gardens on the outskirts of the old city.

headline: The Gun Report: October 4, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: For practical, common sense ideas regarding gun control, maybe we should look to Canada, Adam Gopnik wrote on The New Yorker’s Web site on Tuesday. Gopnik’s parents live in Ontario, “surrounded by crops, animals, and pests—and indeed by farmers who need and use rifles.” In order to procure a gun for, say, culling a raccoon infestation, you need to fill out an application for a license and take a gun-safety course—and if your current or former spouse doesn’t sign your application, the police have to inform them that you’re applying for a firearms license.

headline: Getting It Right: Lore Segal Talks About ‘Half the Kingdom’
abstract: Ms. Segal’s new novel is set at a hospital where Alzheimer’s disease is spreading at a rapid rate.
lead_paragraph: Lore Segal published her first novel in 1964. “Other People’s Houses” was a semi-autobiographical story about a young girl growing up in England after Hitler took control of Austria. When Ms. Segal was 10 years old, she left Vienna for England as part of the Kindertransport program. She moved to New York in 1951. In her new novel, “Half the Kingdom,” older hospital patients are mysteriously contracting Alzheimer’s disease at a rapid rate. In The New York Times Book Review, Patricia T. O’Conner wrote: “Fans of Segal’s fiction should feel right at home in this darkly comic novel.” In a recent e-mail interview, Ms. Segal, 85, discussed what the book says about aging, the recurring characters in her fiction, whether she ever thinks of retiring and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: A Call for Self-Restraint at the U.N.
abstract: The United National Security Council has been hamstrung by counterproductive vetoes.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It has taken more than two years and 120,000 deaths in Syria for the United Nations Security Council to finally cease being paralyzed by vetoes and make a decision.

headline: Sex Lives
abstract: New books by Daniel Stern, Sophie Fontanel and Susan Ostrov Weisser.
lead_paragraph: SWINGLANDBetween the Sheets of the Secretive, Sometimes Messy, but Always Adventurous Swinging LifestyleBy Daniel Stern  Touchstone, $26.

headline: 1912: Titanic Disaster
abstract: A look back at The Herald’s coverage of the Titanic disaster in 1912.
lead_paragraph: “The Titanic, new White Star liner, founders off Newfoundland; reports are most contradictory, but appalling loss of life is feared,” said The New York Herald, a forerunner of the International Herald Tribune, describing one of the worst maritime disasters in history.

headline: Let’s Do It
abstract: Writers on embracing the comedy in writing about sex.
lead_paragraph: “Birds do it,” Ella Fitzgerald sang. “Bees do it. Even educated fleas do it.” Musicians have always had an easy time expressing lust. Without sex, most of Prince’s work would be a John Cage-like experiment in complete silence.

headline: Love During Wartime
abstract: Two couples wait for safe passage to New York in David Leavitt’s novel of 1940 Lisbon.
lead_paragraph: The big story is Lisbon in 1940: the last way out of Europe as the Nazis advance, a neutral port full of spies and desperate refugees. Thousands of them have struggled south from France, managed the almost impossible trick of getting the right papers with the right stamps at the right time in the right place, and now they’re waiting to see if they can arrange passage out. Lisbon in 1940 is famously melodramatic; it’s where Ingrid Bergman was heading at the end of “Casablanca.”

headline: No Sex Please, We’re Buddhist
abstract: The characters in Tim Parks’s novel chafe at the restrictions of a retreat.
lead_paragraph: Last summer my beloved, who is on a meditation kick that has reshaped the contours of his disposition in a most agreeable way, attended a weekend retreat at a Zen monastery. While there, he tucked his wallet under a mattress and returned from a serenity session to find it some $200 lighter. It was a small price to pay for a lesson in detachment, he later concluded, as I audibly gritted my teeth.

headline: Acquired Tastes
abstract: Jesse Bering examines notions of deviance and the wide-ranging triggers of human desire.
lead_paragraph: “The finding of an object,” Sigmund Freud wrote a century ago in his “Three Essays on the Theory of Sexuality,” “is in fact a refinding of it.” The patterns and paths our lusts will take, what we will yearn to do and have done to us and whom we will wish to do these things with — to a great extent, our erotic longings are laid down early, beginning in childhood and even infancy. Freud has lost currency in recent decades, but few in the field of sex research, no matter how they qualify his premise or dismiss him as unscientific, would argue that our early experiences don’t have the power to profoundly shape our later cravings, and two experiments described in Jesse Bering’s “Perv: The Sexual Deviant in All of Us” lend indirect proof.

headline: What You Wish For
abstract: Elissa Wald’s heroines confront their darkest urges.
lead_paragraph: Discussing his classic noir tales of adultery and murder, “The Postman Always Rings Twice” and “Double Indemnity,” James M. Cain set forth a concept he called the “love rack.” For him, it meant finding a way to manipulate readers into caring about his criminal characters and their plight, and surrendering to the story. The term’s connotations of torture were apt. In Cain’s novels, desire is a prison, a death trap. If the author can seduce the audience into investing in that desire, and the fate of the lovers in its thrall, the reader essentially joins them on that rack, with each plot twist proving another pull of the rope, another turn of the screw.

headline: Cherry Bombshells
abstract: A hard-rock history of the Runaways.
lead_paragraph: “A girl can do what she wants to do,” Joan Jett sings in her anthem “Bad Reputation,” “and that’s what I’m gonna do.” Similar sentiments drove the Runaways, Jett’s first group and perhaps the first teenage, all-female hard-rock band signed to a major American label. Despite defiant assertions of independence like the classic “Cherry Bomb,” the band remains cruelly underrated, a perception Evelyn McDonnell seeks to rectify in her scrupulously researched “Queens of Noise.” Ambition and self-determination are prevailing themes: for these women, pursuing those aims in the 1970s could be brutal, especially when contending with adolescent hormones.

headline: Rosedud
abstract: Behind the making of a movie known as the “Citizen Kane” of awful.
lead_paragraph: If you have not already done so, please see “The Room.” Certain films elicit so much joy they cannot be recommended highly enough. “The Room” is such a film. Not because it is good. No. “The Room” is not a good film. It is bad. Some call it “the best bad movie ever made.” But “bad” does not do it justice. In fact, no adjective I know fully conveys the comprehensive artistic disaster that is “The Room.” Perhaps some Amazonian tribe has a word that means “something so terrible it achieves a certain kind of majesty,” but in English we do not.

headline: The Price of Equality
abstract: The success of well-educated elite women often comes at other women’s expense, a professor argues.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Sheryl Sandberg asked the members of a mainly female audience of undergraduates at Harvard University to stand up if they thought one day they could be C.E.O. of their company or even president of the United States. Many stayed seated. For the chief operating officer of Facebook and the fledgling elite she was addressing, one crucial barrier on the road to gender equality may well be what Sandberg calls the leadership ambition gap — the lack of women with the self-confidence to “lean in” like men.

headline: In Performance: Orlando Bloom
abstract: The actor performs a scene from the new Broadway production of Shakespeare’s “Romeo and Juliet.”
lead_paragraph: The actor performs a scene from the new Broadway production of Shakespeare’s “Romeo and Juliet.”

headline: Yoga Has Limited Menopause Benefits
abstract: Menopausal women who did yoga had improvements in insomnia symptoms, but no significant improvements in hot flashes, night sweats, depression or anxiety.
lead_paragraph: Many women seek natural alternatives to hormone replacement therapy to treat menopause symptoms. Some have turned to yoga, but a rigorous new trial shows that its benefits may be limited, at best.

headline: The Devil’s Own
abstract: Jeanette Winterson’s novella explores the events surrounding England’s 1612 Pendle Hill witch trials.
lead_paragraph: Many readers of Jeanette Winterson’s new novel will already have traveled with her to 17th-century England in her 1990 novel “Sexing the Cherry.” Like most of Winterson’s work, that early book is brief, copious and sometimes astonishing — Clarendon’s “History of the Rebellion” meets “Naked Lunch.” In “The Daylight Gate,” Winterson now puts her mind to the Pendle Hill witch trials of 1612, whose 400th anniversary has occasioned a small outpouring of fiction and poetry.

headline: Hell Hath a Fury
abstract: In “Alex,” Pierre Lemaitre adapts Stieg Larsson’s blueprint with moves of his own.
lead_paragraph: I can tell you in just two words why ALEX (MacLehose, $24.95), a thriller by the fashionable French author Pierre Lemaitre, was such a sensation in Europe. Partisan politics. Just kidding! The two words are — sadistic sex.

headline: Songs of Experience
abstract: The blocked poet from Nicholson Baker’s “Anthologist” turns to writing music.
lead_paragraph: When we first met Paul Chowder, the hyper-garrulous narrator of Nicholson Baker’s 2009 novel “The Anthologist,” he was furiously blocked on writing the introduction to an anthology of rhyming poetry, and somewhat less furiously blocked on salvaging his relationship with his longtime girlfriend, Roz. What came seeping from around those blockages was a mordant and effervescently graceful disquisition on the nature of poetry, poets, failure and the “interesting blind pain of wrongness”: a riff-tastic essay masquerading as a novel, or vice versa. The voice of Paul Chowder — prickly, whimsical, genially pedagogic, opinion-stippled and often lavishly intelligent — supplied the vessel, yet poetry, the novel’s subject and in some sense its main character, provided the sustenance.

headline: Now Screening | A Train Film to Celebrate Doug Aitken’s ‘Station to Station’ Tour
abstract: In this clever short, which played during the just-completed art caravan, the artist Thomas Demand pulls off a visual trick that makes references to the origins of cinema.
lead_paragraph: By now the resounding whistle of Doug Aitken’s “Station to Station” art train has blown all the way across the country, from New York City to the Bay Area. The “nomadic happening,” as the artist called it, brought artists, musicians and other creative visionaries together for exhibitions and performances in cities like Pittsburgh, Kansas City and Santa Fe last month. “What I really like about Doug is that he wants to communicate with the whole world,” said the German photographer and sculptor Thomas Demand, one of the project’s participants, who has known Aitken for nearly two decades.

headline: Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, Who Ousted U.S. From Vietnam, Is Dead
abstract: General Giap, whose victory at Dien Bien Phu forced France from Vietnam, later waged a long battle with the United States military that eventually sapped America’s political will to fight.
lead_paragraph: Vo Nguyen Giap, the relentless and charismatic North Vietnamese general whose campaigns drove both France and the United States out of Vietnam, died on Friday in Hanoi. He was believed to be 102.

headline: Image of the Day: October 4
abstract: Supporters of the Indian National Congress celebrated after the union cabinet gave a nod to the proposal for creating India’s 29th state.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: FROM THE RUINS OF EMPIRE: The Revolt Against the West and the Remaking of Asia,  by Pankaj Mishra. (Picador, $17.) This is a superb history of Asian intellectual responses to Western colonialism in the 19th and 20th centuries, from Ottoman Turkey to Meiji Japan. Mishra tells this story through the biographies of two independent thinkers: the itinerant Persian-­born agitator Jamal al-Din al-Afghani and the Chinese reformer Liang Qichao.

headline: Netanyahu Plans to Meet With European Leaders on Iranian Nuclear Talks
abstract: Benjamin Netanyahu, the Israeli prime minister, hopes to influence coming negotiations over what he described as a “comprehensive international struggle.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said Friday that he would meet with European leaders next week in hopes of influencing the negotiations scheduled to begin Oct. 15 over Iran’s nuclear program, part of what he described as a “comprehensive international struggle.”

headline: Inside the List
abstract: In “The Lowland,” which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3, Jhumpa Lahiri finally writes at length about her home state of Rhode Island.
lead_paragraph: Ocean State: Jhumpa Lahiri grew up in Rhode Island, right next to the state university’s main campus in Kingston, but you’d never know it from her first three books. Outside of her brief author’s biography, the state never makes an appearance in the story collections “Interpreter of Maladies” and “Unaccustomed Earth,” while in the novel “The Namesake” it earns just two passing mentions: once during a school field trip and once when the protagonist’s train is delayed by a suicide on the tracks “somewhere in Rhode Island.”

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SIGNATURE OF ALL THINGS,  by Elizabeth Gilbert. (Viking, $28.95.) In this winning novel by the author of “Eat, Pray, Love,” a botanist’s hunger for explanations carries her through the better part of Darwin’s century, and to Tahiti.

headline: Golden Boy With Silver Hair
abstract: As many orchestras and their conductors are struggling, Riccardo Muti and his Chicago Symphony Orchestra are thriving with style.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Claiming an ever-smaller slice of the cultural pie and with fewer media outlets to spread the word, orchestras and their conductors struggle for visibility these days. But there are signs that Riccardo Muti, the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra since 2010, has solved the problem better than most.

headline: No Comment Necessary: What If the Government Defaults?
abstract: In the event of a debt limit impasse, get ready for a catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: In a Thursday report, the Treasury Department explained what would happen if Congress were to refuse to raise the federal debt limit.

headline: When Converting a Roth I.R.A. Back to a Traditional One Makes Sense
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Income Tax', 'Individual Retirement Accounts']
abstract: Because going from a tax-deferred I.R.A. to a tax-free Roth has huge implications, the government gives people a chance to change their minds.
lead_paragraph: WHEN it comes to making financial decisions to save on taxes, you don’t usually get a do-over. Just ask all those people who rushed to make large tax-free gifts to family members at the end of last year before a historically high exemption was set to expire. Not only did the exemption not end, but it was increased for 2013. And there was no way to get those tax-driven gifts back.

headline: Snowboarding at the Cardrona Halfpipe
abstract: Every August, the world’s best snowboarders come to work on big-air and physics-defying in Wanaka, New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: Every August, the world’s best snowboarders come to work on big-air and physics-defying in Wanaka, New Zealand.

headline: How Parents Handle Teenage Drinking
abstract: Looking for advice from parents who successfully handled the question of raising teenagers to drink responsibly as adults — or those who muffed it, and think they know where they went wrong.
lead_paragraph: This week’s New Parent, Old Parent question really gets to the heart of why we created this collaboration between Booming and Motherlode. Back when he was in the thick of it, my colleague Mike Winerip wrote a column about how much he was struggling with how to handle the question of teenage drinking. Did he have to take a complete no drinking stance, he asked? Or should he assume that some drinking was inevitable, and try to teach moderation rather than abstinence? He was, he writes, assailed just for asking the questions — but what’s truly interesting is who the parents who knew exactly what to do about teenage drinking turned out to be: the parents of younger children.

headline: Company Man
abstract: In this novel’s dystopian future, a giant multinational corporation manages everyone’s life.
lead_paragraph: Patrick Flanery’s first novel, “Absolution” (2012), was a beautiful book of secrets, a multilayered tale of post-­apartheid South Africa. His second, “Fallen Land,” is very different in style and substance, a dystopian story set on the outskirts of an unnamed Midwestern city that bears some resemblance to Omaha, where Flanery was raised.

lead_paragraph: Snowboarders flock to New Zealand’s South Island in August to take advantage of the halfpipe at Cardrona Alpine Resort.

lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn is finally abandoning his battle against Dell‘s sale to its founder.

headline: Summer Camp for the Winter Olympics
abstract: Every August, the world’s best snowboarders flock to Wanaka, New Zealand, where the only Olympic-size halfpipe anywhere in the world is open at that time of year.
lead_paragraph: WANAKA, New Zealand — From the bottom, they look like butterflies, dropping soundlessly into the halfpipe and soaring high above its walls, spinning and flipping, flashes of color cascading over the whiteness. It’s only after they skid to a stop and lift their bug-eyed goggles that you see the dreadlocks and soul patches, the Rockstar and Monster energy-drink logos, the tie-dye slickers and the ubiquitous ear buds.

headline: Nets’ Kidd Receives Two-Game Suspension
abstract: As expected, the N.B.A. on Friday barred Nets Coach Jason Kidd for two games after he pleaded guilty in July to a drunken-driving charge.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — The N.B.A. on Friday imposed a two-game suspension on Nets Coach Jason Kidd, who pleaded guilty in July to a drunken-driving charge.

abstract: Julian Assange of WikiLeaks is having a moment on the big screen.
lead_paragraph: Before there was a documentary about WikiLeaks — before there was a major motion picture about its founder — Julian Assange was a star.

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — As President Obama made apologetic calls to Asia to cancel his planned trip to the region, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, was taking a star turn in some of the same countries Mr. Obama would have visited.

headline: With No New Plan, Boehner Makes Angry Plea on Shutdown
abstract: Four days into the crisis, Congress appeared no closer to a resolution, and Speaker John A. Boehner urged President Obama to negotiate over his health care law.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans emerged from a closed-door meeting on Friday with no new strategy to end the budget standoff and an angry plea to President Obama to negotiate over his health care law.

abstract: From Bonnie and Clyde Days in Reeds Spring, Mo., to the Korean Grand Prix, there’s plenty to keep motoring aficionados busy this weekend.
lead_paragraph: A bite-size sampling of concours, cruise nights, auctions, club races and other upwellings of car culture happening across America this weekend.

headline: New Fashion Runway: Wall Street
abstract: Michael Kors had extraordinary success with an initial public offering of his brand nearly two years ago, leading other designers to consider the same.
lead_paragraph: With his red-carpet gowns, lush cashmere sweaters and jet-set shoulder totes, Michael Kors has influenced fellow designers across the globe.

headline: The First Illicit Thing You Read
abstract: The Book Review’s favorite stories from readers about the first illicit work of literature they ever read.
lead_paragraph: In the Book Review’s Sex Issue, a select group of writers shared their memories of the first illicit thing they ever read. More than 200 readers also wrote on The New York Times’s Web site about their experiences with books, poems and other works of literature that their parents or teachers might not have wanted them to read.

headline: Delivering the News, All of It, in 2 Minutes
abstract: The company Prologue did the title sequence for “The Fifth Estate,” a movie about Julian Assange and WikiLeaks.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The mission: re-create the history of the news media in two minutes or less.

lead_paragraph: The number of unemployed adults in the euro zone countries reached a record high in August, despite a continued decline in Germany.

lead_paragraph: In the new Broadway production of “Romeo and Juliet,” Orlando Bloom and Condola Rashad star as the doomed young lovers.

headline: Q. & A. | Greg Lauren on His Foray Into Fragrance
abstract: Ralph Lauren’s nephew has already made his mark on worlds of art and fashion, and now he ventures into beauty with his new unisex scent, the latest in Barneys New York’s designer fragrance collection. Bespoke bonus: he decorated every single bottle.
lead_paragraph: With his fifth ready-to-wear collection behind him, the 43-year-old L.A. artist-turned-designer Greg Lauren will make his fragrance industry debut on Tuesday, when his namesake unisex fragrance hits shelves at the Barneys New York flagship on Madison Avenue. “I thought this would have the same emotional themes that I’d want to express in my collection, which never feels like a fragment is made for men and another for women,” said Lauren, a nephew of Ralph Lauren. The exclusive scent is the second in the luxury department store’s designer fragrance collection, which started in 2012 with a L’Wren Scott creation. Made by the New York perfumer Ralf Schwieger, whose work includes Lipstick Rose by Frédéric Malle and Eau des Merveilles by Hermès, the blend’s sweet aroma is built around tonka beans, vanilla and coconut, offset by a musky veil of sandalwood, amber and moss.

headline: The Building Has 1,000 Eyes
keywords: ['Real Estate Brokers', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Cameras', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Large and small, doorman or no, New York City residences are stepping up their reliance on surveillance equipment.
lead_paragraph: Some of the wealthiest people in New York City live at 740 Park Avenue: the industrialist David Koch and the financier Stephen Schwarzman, among others. It’s hard to pass the board inspection; it’s very hard to get past the vigilant doormen.

headline: Carnegie Hall and Stagehands Settle Contract Dispute
abstract: Carnegie Hall and its stagehands have settled the yearlong contract dispute that led to the cancellation of Carnegie’s opening-night concert.
lead_paragraph: The negotiations lasted more than a year and led to a strike that canceled Carnegie Hall’s planned opening night for the first time in the hall’s 122-year history. But after only two days, the dispute between Carnegie’s management and its stagehands was settled on Friday, and the hall announced that it was fully back in business.

headline: Trading an African Dashiki for Union Blue
abstract: America’s leading advocate for black emigration became an ardent recruiter for the Northern war effort.
lead_paragraph: “We most heartily endorse the earnest and energetic efforts being put forth by Mr. Delaney, and John Jones of this city, towards the enlistment of volunteers for the Artillery Brigade, to be composed entirely of colored men,” announced The Chicago Tribune on Oct. 2, 1863. The article focused on black Union recruitment in the city, a process that had been in full swing for months across the North and Union-occupied South. But the paper was burying the lede: by the fall of 1863 Mr. Delany – Martin Robison Delany, the nation’s foremost advocate for black migration out of the country – had become one of Uncle Sam’s best recruiters.

lead_paragraph: Nobody knows what punk rock truly is. Some have defined it well: Kurt Cobain simply said, “Punk rock means freedom.” Others not so well: A 1992 Subaru commercial insisted that the Imprezas were “just like punk, except it’s cars.” In “Next Stop, Nowhere,” a 1982 episode of the television procedural “Quincy M.E.,” a murder has taken place in a club and a concerned parent describes punk to Jack Klugman’s titular coroner as “violence-oriented music that does nothing but reinforce all those bad feelings.” The episode is now the go-to example for getting the punk spirit horribly wrong on screen.

headline: In Maui’s Upcountry, Where the Paniolo Roam
keywords: ['Ranches', 'Cowboys and Cowgirls', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Instead of beaches and surf shacks, this part of Maui features ranches, rodeos and a paniolo — Hawaiian cowboy — tradition.
lead_paragraph: At the Oskie Rice Arena, the Friday night lights hung in the damp, mid-December Hawaiian air. Beaming through Maui’s notorious red clay dust, the lights served as a backdrop to one of the Upcountry’s biggest annual events. On the metal bleachers, families were bundled against their idea of the cold: a winter chill that sank just below 60 degrees. There were coats, blankets and hoodie strings pulled tight. There was Portuguese soup and Puerto Rican stew at the family-run concession stands, where the handwritten menus were scrawled in thick felt marker, crossed through as the “onolicious” fried ice cream or pork with tofu and macaroni ran out.

headline: Treasures of the Cinque Terre
abstract: Two years after a torrential rainfall struck the area on Italy’s Ligurian coast, a visit reveals both recent recovery and timeless pleasures.
lead_paragraph: It was a stroke of luck, really, that my luggage was lost when I flew to Italy this summer to visit the jewel box villages of the Cinque Terre — five heart-stoppingly picturesque hamlets on the Ligurian coast, dotted with pastel houses nestled amid terraced hills that drop to the jade and lapis waters of the Mediterranean. All I had with me were my eyes and feet. For the next few days, that would be all I needed. Unencumbered, I could leap lightly onto trains and trails, feeling sorry for the heavily laden travelers around me, even as I mourned the absence of my hiking sandals. And I saw at once that the Cinque Terre (pronounced CHING-kway TAY-ray) should not be reserved as a bucket-list destination: they are best seen pre-bucket, while you are still limber enough to hop on and off platforms and boats, scamper up winding medieval staircases and clamber onto slick sunning rocks in secluded coves and on friendly beaches.

headline: In the Cinque Terre, Sun, Sea and Sweeping Scenes

lead_paragraph: Views from Italy’s Ligurian coast.

headline: Terror That Melts From the Screen
keywords: ['Movies', '3-D Devices and Effects', 'Video Recordings and Downloads']
abstract: The horror movie “House of Wax” (1953), starring Vincent Price, inspired a wave of 3-D releases in the 1950s. Now it’s on 3-D Blu-ray.
lead_paragraph: As sexy as the technology may be, digital 3-D hasn’t exactly conquered the entertainment landscape. ESPN’s decision this summer to end its three-year-old stereoscopic sports channel strongly suggests the format will never be adopted as an across-the-board industry standard. But the format (or gimmick, depending on your point of view) does seem to have established a niche for itself. 3-D is now a more or less obligatory adornment for computer-animated family films and the high-end action franchises, although — despite rare exceptions like Ang Lee’s “Life of Pi” and Alfonso Cuarón’s “Gravity” — the process hasn’t found a foothold in straight dramatic filmmaking. Depth, it seems, is appropriate only for shallow subjects.

headline: Hapless and Hopeless

lead_paragraph: During the Bush years, I would often run into people mocking W for being stupid. I never thought he was — incurious, anti-intellectual, but not stupid. And the people around him certainly weren’t stupid — cynical, dishonest, but not stupid, especially regarding matters political.

headline: As Defense, a Handwritten Lesson on Senate Procedure
abstract: After criticism from conservatives, Senator John Boozman released a letter to constituents explaining a vote to end debate on a budget bill.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator John Boozman, Republican of Arkansas, took the unusual step of publicly releasing a handwritten letter to constituents explaining his choice on a procedural vote on stopgap spending legislation last week. Mr. Boozman, first elected in 2010, was one of 25 Republican senators who joined all of the Senate’s Democrats in voting to cut off debate on the measure. After that cloture vote, the Senate removed language in the spending bill that would have defunded the new health care law on a party-line vote. Mr. Boozman voted against removing the House-passed defunding provision, and against final passage of the spending bill itself.

headline: Shhh. Silence Being Observed.
abstract: In “There Will Never Be Silence,” the Museum of Modern Art examines John Cage’s influence on visual artists who also explored issues of space, time and physicality.
lead_paragraph: There’s been a lot of noise about silence lately. Last month, art and music lovers poured into an Upper East Side church to hear the first New York performance of Yves Klein’s “Monotone-Silence Symphony,” a composition conceived around 1947, featuring a D chord followed by 20 minutes of silence. Around that time John Cage composed “4’33”,” first performed in August 1952, when the pianist David Tudor sat at a piano on a stage in Woodstock, N.Y., stopwatch in hand, without playing a single note. For 4 minutes 33 seconds, nothing but ambient sound could be heard.

John Ford questioned Wayne’s imperious nobility with “The Searchers” (1956), but Howard Hawks got there first, with “Red River” (1948), playing at the Museum of the Moving Image on Friday as part of its Complete Howard Hawks series.

headline: The Return of ‘The Nose’

lead_paragraph: Happily, the Metropolitan Opera has brought back its brilliant production “The Nose,” by Shostakovich, a hit of the 2010 season. The baritone Paulo Szot, who made a noteworthy house debut as the hapless, noseless bureaucrat Kovalyov, returns. Valery Gergiev conducts the sardonic score. The yellow beauties would jump into your basket at the touch of a pocketknife blade.
