headline: Detroit Institute of Arts Mulls Transfer to State
abstract: The Detroit Institute of Arts is proposing changing hands, in return for a revenue stream from the state..
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Institute of Arts, whose collection has become a target of creditors in Detroit’s federal bankruptcy case, is formulating a proposal to protect the museum that might include asking Michigan’s governor, Rick Snyder, to consider state take-over of the city-owned museum, the Detroit Free Press reported.Many of the masterpieces in the museum’s collection are being appraised by Christie’s auction house at the behest of Kevyn Orr, Detroit’s emergency manager, who has said that he has no intention of selling the art but that none of the city’s assets can be taken off the table as the bankruptcy case proceeds.The new proposal would ask the state to begin providing substantial funding to the museum that would allow the museum to provide money to the city that might otherwise be found only by selling art. At a business luncheon on Thursday in Detroit, Mr. Orr said that the museum might consider long-term leases of art works as another way of avoiding any sale. “I’m deferring to them to save themselves,” he told business leaders, referring to the institute.

Later, in a discussion about going to the movies, a “second feature” is mentioned, as though the audience always got to watch two films for the price of one.

The Pirates’ starter, Gerrit Cole, had given up a flyout to the wall to start the inning, then walked Matt Carpenter. Fans at Busch Stadium — a red-clad capacity crowd announced at 45,999 — stood, roared and waved white towels as the perennial postseason star Carlos Beltran strode to the plate.

Apothecary bottles filled with dried roots and herbs. The bodies of beetles and scorpions, neatly mounted under glass. A wooden light fixture whose frame, when viewed from a certain angle, suggested a pentagram.

lead_paragraph: The soprano Deborah Voigt is still wondering whether, during a crisis in confidence, she made the right decision last month to withdraw from the season-opening production of Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” at the Washington National Opera. She had sung Isolde to acclaim in important productions over the previous 10 years. But last month, she found the long, punishing role beyond her current vocal capacities.

headline: No News Is Good News
abstract: Pat Kiernan, the morning news anchor for NY1, uses his day off to sleep until 8, take his family to Central Park and run errands in the car.
lead_paragraph: Five days a week, Pat Kiernan, the morning news anchor for NY1, is awake before dawn, rushing from his brownstone in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to his station’s studios in Chelsea, where his broadcasts help the rest of us get ready for our day. It’s no surprise, then, that on the weekends, Mr. Kiernan, 45, likes to relax close to home with his wife, Dawn, a client-service representative for Nielsen, the television research firm, and with their daughters, Lucy, 11, and Maeve, 9. “On Sundays especially, I get to live on a more or less human schedule,” he said. But the reprieve is short-lived, and work invariably returns early Monday.

headline: Audrey Gelman, the Girl Most Likely
abstract: If Audrey Gelman, political ingénue and fashion darling, didn’t already exist, her friend Lena Dunham might have invented her as a character.

Mr. Spitzer, the scandal-plagued ex-governor, had a 15-point lead in the polls, coming off appearances on Jay Leno and Bill Maher.

headline: The Wages of Pop Music

lead_paragraph: A J Michalka, the star of “Grace Unplugged,” used to record with her sister in the teen-pop duo Aly and A J. (They now perform as 78Violet.) The songs were sturdy, melodic and espoused wholesome self-reliance. Aly went on to embody female independence in the charming film “Bandslam” and the TV series “Hellcats.” A J, alas, has succumbed to “Grace Unplugged,” which feels like a religious tract more than a movie.

And in “Mob Boss: The Life of Little Al D’Arco, the Man Who Brought Down the Mafia” (Thomas Dunne Books, $27.99), the veteran crime reporters Jerry Capeci and Tom Robbins spin a gripping, novelistic biography of the diminutive man behind the big mouth.

headline: Editor’s Letter | The Journey
abstract: What is the real value of travel? In our latest issue, writers and their subjects delight in aspects of places tourists might overlook and thrill seekers would likely never see.
lead_paragraph: IN OUR SIGN OF THE TIMES ESSAY this month, our columnist Andrew O’Hagan takes on the notion that “good” is often really good enough, particularly when it comes to travel. In this age of bucket lists and extreme travel, in which we seek the extraordinary, the unique, the rare — longing to rocket into space or plummet beneath the sea — O’Hagan wonders if we’ve forgotten that the real value of travel is simply pleasure and inspiration. He makes the case that “the Ultimate Experience now poses a threat to the kind of small revelations that make us happy.” These we often find if we are looking where we might not expect.

headline: Daughters Inheriting the Practice

headline: The Nodding Ladies’-Tresses Orchid, Ever Young
abstract: A flower named for its braided stems seems designed for easy and abundant pollination.
lead_paragraph: Every autumn there are one or two perfect days when winds from the north sweep summer south, combing the season’s thick clouds into mare’s-tails and sending its insects, birds and milkweed seeds packing. Recently, on a day like this, I stood in a scruffy Bronx field. Summer’s last pink flowers and goldenrods’ chrome yellow blooms were intertwined with the brick-red leaves and frosty blue berries of Virginia creeper. There was a biting chill in the air that heightened the earthy, sour scent of leaves decomposing.

headline: Man on Fire Is Hospitalized in Washington

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A week in which the capital was first shaken by a shutdown of the federal government and then rattled by a car chase and shooting on Capitol Hill ended Friday with scenes of a medical helicopter evacuating a man who the police believed set himself on fire on the National Mall.

headline: T Fall Travel Issue
abstract: In T Magazine’s Fall Travel issue, we discover a more contemplative mode of getting there, and being there, whether the destination is a place or something less defined.
lead_paragraph: The concept of leisurely travel has been in flux in recent times. As Andrew O’Hagan points out in his essay, the concept of “fine,” or perhaps “good enough,” has been lost in an age of “awesome” superlatives and extreme travel. In T Magazine’s Fall Travel issue, we discover a more contemplative mode of getting there, and being there, whether the destination is a place or something less defined. Whether with Michael Kimmelman finding Marseille, France, despite a slew of ambitious development projects, as gloriously scrappy as ever, or with the surreal and severe beauty of Craig McDean’s portraits from Iceland’s wilderness, a sense of really being present, a sense of place, is more important than a contrived sense of adventure. We also explore the Restoration Hardware tycoon Gary Friedman’s desire to become a force of disruption in the contemporary art world, a resurgence in appreciation for almost-forgotten Indian Modernist furniture and a family’s attempt to reinvigorate one of Britain’s most famous gardens by restoring its traditional agriculture. headline: Saudi Arabia: New Infections Raise Virus Cases to 136
abstract: Saudi Arabia has confirmed six new infections from the potentially fatal MERS virus, the World Health Organization reported Friday.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia has confirmed six new infections from the potentially fatal MERS virus, the World Health Organization reported Friday, raising the total number of cases worldwide to 136. Most of the cases, which have resulted in 58 deaths, have been in Saudi Arabia. The latest cases, the W.H.O. said in a statement, afflicted three men and three women, all from the Riyadh region. MERS stands for Middle East Respiratory Syndrome. It is believed to be spread by bats and possibly camels. The concentration of MERS cases in Saudi Arabia has raised concern about the possible spread of the infection during the annual pilgrimage to Mecca and Medina later this month, when millions of Muslims from around the world visit the kingdom.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9:05 P.M. (Showtime) THE MASTER (2012) Philip Seymour Hoffman portrays Lancaster Dodd, the leader of the Cause, a therapeutic, religion-tinged cult built around using painful questions to delve into a subject’s past and get at the root of negative emotion and destructive behavior. Joaquin Phoenix (above left, with Mr. Hoffman) plays Freddie Quell, a World War II Navy veteran and alcoholic wreck who seeks solace through Dodd’s method. And Amy Adams is Peggy Dodd, the latest of her husband’s wives and the hidden hand that guides his empire. “ ‘The Master’ is really more Freddie’s story than Dodd’s, and some of the film’s drama resides in the struggle between the two characters — and perhaps the two actors — for supremacy,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times about this film written and directed by Paul Thomas Anderson, which earned its three principals Oscar nominations. “ ‘You’ll be my protégé and my guinea pig,’ Dodd says to Freddie shortly after their first meeting. There turns out to be a lot more to it than that. They are father and son, guru and disciple, passionate friends and bitter competitors locked in a relationship whose sexual undercurrents are as palpable and mysterious as the motion of water under the surface of the ocean.” The film, he added, “is wild and enormous, its scale almost commensurate with Lancaster Dodd’s hubris and its soul nearly as restless as Freddie Quell’s. It is a movie about the lure and folly of greatness that comes as close as anything I’ve seen recently to being a great movie.”

headline: An Audience Without an Opera
abstract: City Opera closes its doors, leaving behind the people who were its real cultural legacy.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the New York City Opera announced that it was closing its doors and filing for bankruptcy, ending its 70-year existence orphaned, homeless, broke and all but out on the street. It was a disappointing demise to what was once an enterprising and insouciant company, a kind of scrappy newsboy thrust among the city’s elite, thanks to Fiorello La Guardia, who founded it in 1943. Its end was as au courant as it could be — a failed Kickstarter campaign and a final performance of “Anna Nicole,” just the kind of production unlikely to turn up at the Metropolitan Opera, just the kind you might use to explain why this city needs two major opera companies.

headline: Great Betrayals
abstract: Being lied to has a corrosive, life-changing impact.
lead_paragraph: AS a psychiatrist I find that friends frequently seek me out to discuss problematic events in their lives; it comes with the territory and I’m usually happy to do it. But I was surprised and shaken to hear from an old friend that her husband of nearly 25 years had long been accruing and hiding from her a huge credit card debt (in the six figures). Even after divulging his secret, the husband had lied about the amount, with the sum increasing every time it was discussed. And right from the start, he refused to document where the money was spent. He left it for his wife to ruminate on, trying to puzzle it out. The disclosure wreaked financial and emotional havoc on their family.

headline: Readers Comment on the Government Shutdown
abstract: Readers weigh in on my column about the government shutdown and debt limit crisis.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column lacerates the House Republicans for the government shutdown and the flirtation with a debt limit default. To me, this isn’t politics as usual but a rare instance of a political party causing deliberate economic and national security damage in hopes of gaining leverage on another issue. The national security consequences haven’t garnered enough attention, and they’re compounded by something I didn’t have space to mention–President Obama’s cancellation of his Asia trip itinerary. At a time when there is broad agreement that we should recalibrate our diplomatic efforts to focus more on Asia, this is an instance when we’re backing away from Asia because of this domestic political crisis. And China is the winner. So read the column, please, and share your thoughts on it.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:30 P.M. (13) MOYERS & COMPANY The novelist Wendell Berry, above, a farmer, environmentalist and literary agrarian voice, sits down with Bill Moyers to discuss a no-compromise plan to save the earth. The interview was taped at St. Catharine College in Kentucky — home to the new Berry Farming and Ecological Agrarianism Program — during a two-day celebration of the 35th anniversary of the publication of Mr. Berry’s seminal book, “The Unsettling of America.” “It’s mighty hard right now to think of anything that’s precious that isn’t endangered,” Mr. Berry says. “There are no sacred and unsacred places; there are only sacred and desecrated places. My belief is that the world and our life in it are conditional gifts. We have the world to live in on the condition that we will take good care of it. And to take good care of it we have to know it. And to know it and to be willing to take care of it, we have to love it.”

headline: Bryan Cranston Is Headed to Broadway
abstract: Fresh off his popular run as the drug kingpin Walter White on the cable series “Breaking Bad,” Mr. Cranston will make his Broadway debut as Lyndon B. Johnson in the play “All the Way.”
lead_paragraph: The Emmy Award winner Bryan Cranston, fresh off his popular run as the drug kingpin Walter White on the cable series “Breaking Bad,” will make his Broadway debut this season as Lyndon B. Johnson in the play “All the Way,” the producer Jeffrey Richards said on Sunday. The play, which wraps up a sold-out production on Saturday at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., received mixed-to-favorable reviews there; the notices for Mr. Cranston’s performance were strong, and producers are counting on his star power to drive ticket sales in the move to Broadway.

headline: Afghan Presidential Hopefuls Are Told to Leave Guns at Home
abstract: As the deadline to register approached, the list of candidates included men with checkered pasts, and there was concern violence and fraud would mar the coming vote.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The deadline for registering as a candidate in Afghanistan’s coming presidential election was Sunday, and the election commission had a request for contenders: When you come to declare your candidacy, do not bring your gunmen.

headline: Abortion Vote Exposes Rift at a Catholic University
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Loyola Marymount trustees will decide Monday whether to remove coverage for elective abortions from the faculty and staff health care plans.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Not three weeks have passed since Pope Francis said the church had grown “obsessed” with abortion, declaring, “We have to find a new balance.” But on the campus of Loyola Marymount University, overlooking this city’s west side, a fight over abortion now threatens to rip the school asunder.

headline: Mideast Unrest as Foil to Promote Keystone Pipeline
abstract: TransCanada, the company trying to build the Keystone XL pipeline, is distributing a new round of ads in support of its stalled project.
lead_paragraph: TransCanada, the company trying to build the Keystone XL pipeline, is distributing a new round of ads in support of its stalled project.

headline: Instruments of Danger in Weapons Case Were Dogs, Authorities Say
abstract: Courts have long grappled with the question of canine weaponization, and over the years judges have mostly arrived at the same conclusion: if you use Fido as a weapon, he becomes one.
lead_paragraph: James Austin stood in front of a two-story Brooklyn row house, watching his puppy, Dutchess, play with a pair of pants while, a few feet away, a friend’s dog, Stoney, was tethered to a fence. At that moment, they were companions — both to him and in the eyes of the law.

headline: U.S. Said to Hold Qaeda Suspect on Navy Ship
abstract: With the capture of Abu Anas al-Libi, only a few Qaeda operatives indicted in the 1998 bombings of two American embassies in East Africa are believed to be still at large.
lead_paragraph: An accused operative for Al Qaeda seized by United States commandos in Libya over the weekend is being interrogated while in military custody on a Navy ship in the Mediterranean Sea, officials said on Sunday. He is expected eventually to be sent to New York for criminal prosecution.

headline: Despite Good Intentions, New Targeting Rule Creates Problems
abstract: The targeting rule was meant to protect defenseless players and reduce head injuries. But the implementation of the rule, an automatic ejection, could impact the national title race.
lead_paragraph: The changes to college football’s targeting rule — and the subsequent backlash — speak to a quandary all football faces.

headline: Zoos Try to Ward Off a Penguin Killer
abstract: Malaria, an unrelenting killer, is stalking captive penguins, which lack natural resistance to the avian version of the disease.
lead_paragraph: Zoos all around the world love penguins. They’re cute, they don’t require much space, they never eat zookeepers. And children adore watching them, especially at feeding time.

headline: Marketers Chase Evolving Consumer
abstract: Speakers at an annual conference said the pace and scope of technological and societal changes required what one called a “constant reinvention” of the marketing process.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — THE senior executives who spoke at a major marketing conference here seemed to be auditioning for a reality show called “Extreme Makeover: Corporate Edition.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Oct. 7
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'States (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Netanyahu Dressed Down After Appeal to Iranians
abstract: In response to remarks Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel made to BBC Persian, Iranians took to Twitter to inform him that they do, in fact, wear jeans and listen to Western music.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel tried to take his campaign against the Iranian leadership to Iran’s young population last week, saying that if they were truly free, they would be able to wear jeans, listen to Western music and participate in free elections.

headline: From Irving Berlin to Bon Jovi: An American Songbook Devotee Gives Rock Hits a Twist
abstract: The singer, pianist and songwriter Tony DeSare, who usually performs standards from the American Songbook, offers more recent fare with a pop-jazz twist at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: It’s all in the arrangement. If you take a rock song like the Bon Jovi hit “You Give Love a Bad Name” and perform it in a pop-jazz style, it becomes a latter-day standard in the American Songbook. Or does it?

headline: U.S. Names Roster for World Cup Qualifiers
abstract: Coach Jurgen Klinsmann named his 20-man roster on Sunday for World Cup qualifying matches against Jamaica and Panama.
lead_paragraph: Injuries and inaction played a role when Jurgen Klinsmann, the United States national team coach, selected his 20-man roster for the two final matches in regional World Cup qualifying.

headline: Strife Joins Minnesota Musicians in Concert
abstract: Minnesota Orchestra musicians, embroiled in a heated battle with management, held three weekend concerts conducted by Osmo Vanska.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — By the end of a disastrous week, classical music fans in this city sorely needed something positive to hang onto, however fleetingly. And, happily, they got momentary relief over the weekend in three concerts by the players of the Minnesota Orchestra, conducted by Osmo Vanska.

headline: Ivy League Home for a Cartoonist’s Vast Archive
keywords: ['Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Archives and Records', 'Art', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Magazines', 'Comic Books and Strips', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Al Jaffee, best known for the three-panel fold-ins in Mad magazine, is donating many of his cartoons, along with other material from his personal archives, to Columbia.
lead_paragraph: Al Jaffee started out as a professional cartoonist in the early 1940s, and he has been at it ever since. Although best known for the three-panel fold-ins that Mad magazine has run since 1964, he has also produced work for Timely Comics, the forerunner of Marvel, for Playboy and Esquire, for the short-lived satirical magazine Humbug, and for The Moshiach Times, a Jewish family magazine that has carried his secret-agent strip “The Shpy” for the last 25 years.

headline: Federal Reserve to Unveil a Redesigned $100 Bill
abstract: The new $100 bill will have modern and colorful anti-counterfeiting features, overcoming problems that postponed its debut for more than two and a half years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve will begin circulating a new $100 bill on Tuesday with some modern and colorful anti-counterfeiting features, after overcoming problems that postponed its debut for more than two and a half years.

headline: A Multiplicity of Musicians With Many Traditions and Narratives
abstract: Vijay Iyer’s “Open City” employed 18 musicians performing composed material and creating in the moment while onstage.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — The first striking thing about “Open City,” Vijay Iyer’s large-ensemble suite heard twice over the weekend at Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University here, wasn’t sound but a kind of theory of possibility suggested by the sight of the 20 people onstage.

headline: An Environmental Album Recaptured in a Concert
abstract: “Documerica” paired the music of the string quartet Ethel with evocative images from an Environmental Protection Agency project in the 1970s that documented America’s relationship to its land.
lead_paragraph: At a time when we are awash in a constant deluge of digital images shared by friends and strangers through Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and Flickr, it can be hard to recall when we were less instantly and intimately connected. In the 1970s, though, the world was still analog. Most photographs needed developing, usually by specialists. You posted an image by sticking it in an envelope, then into a mailbox. Sharing photos meant passing prints from hand to hand, or maybe gathering in a darkened den to watch dutifully while a relative or neighbor showed vacation slides.

headline: Giants Follow a Losing Formula
abstract: After battling back to take a third-quarter lead, the Giants were undone by Eli Manning’s interceptions in the fourth as the backup quarterback Nick Foles led the Eagles to victory.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Flawed teams find ways to lose, and by now the Giants must recognize the pattern. Interceptions, fumbles, penalties, blown coverages, even poor coaching decisions — this year’s Giants are dexterous and resourceful architects of defeat.

headline: Lamenting Slavery and Celebrating a Culture
abstract: The singer Christine Salem embraced the African-rooted tradition of maloya in a World Music Institute concert at Symphony Space.
lead_paragraph: There was no mistaking the African roots of Christine Salem’s new music — a tradition called maloya that has been honored by Unesco as part of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity — when she opened the World Music Institute’s season on Friday night at Symphony Space. Ms. Salem (pronounced sah-LEM) sang in a robust contralto and, much of the time, shook a sugar-cane rattle called a kayamb that was a blur of motion as it pinpointed breakneck 6/8 rhythms. She was backed by only two other percussionists and harmony singers, David Abrousse and Harry Perigone.

headline: Scratching a Muse’s Ears
abstract: In “Dog Songs,” the best-selling poet Mary Oliver finds inspiration in love, impermanence and canine companionship.
lead_paragraph: Mary Oliver has spent most of her life with a mind ripe with poems — and with at least one steadfast dog by her side. It seems fitting then that her latest collection revels in the carrying on of dogs. “Dog Songs,” out from Penguin Press on Tuesday, is a sweet golden retriever of a book that curls up with the reader, with 35 poems and one essay about the dogs who have shared Ms. Oliver’s days.

headline: Point-Blank Perspectives on a Fatal Bullying Case
keywords: ['Bullies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Television']
abstract: The documentary “Valentine Road,” on HBO, is based on a 2008 shooting in which a junior-high-school student shot and killed a fellow eighth grader.
lead_paragraph: Events that received widespread news coverage when they happened can be difficult to turn into documentaries, but “Valentine Road” does an impressive job of making a 2008 shooting at a junior high school in Oxnard, Calif., horrifying and disheartening all over again.

headline: Survivor Among a Lifetime of Ghosts
abstract: Alice McDermott’s new novel, “Someone,” follows an ordinary girl from an Irish-American family through the milestones of her life.
lead_paragraph: One Saturday morning, as the heroine of Alice McDermott’s quietly exquisite new novel is just developing a classic case of preteenage insolence, her mother summons her to the kitchen for a cooking lesson. It’s all in a day’s work, but the girl, Marie, takes it for granted that her mother has already done the family’s laundry and hung it out to dry. This is a book so deft that even the damp shirts and school blouses on the clothesline have some import. Marie sees them “hung upside down by their hems, their arms waving in a way that made me grow dizzy in sympathy.”

headline: Swarm of Rivals Seeking Share of Social Media Pie
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Ahead of its I.P.O., Twitter must  prove it can fend off a younger generation of nimble social services that offer clever new ways for people to connect and share.
lead_paragraph: Twitter, poised to make its splashy entrance on Wall Street, has helped define modern social networking. But while seeking to establish itself as an Internet powerhouse, it must also prove it can fend off a rising threat from a younger generation of nimble social outlets that offer clever new ways for people to connect and share content.

headline: U.S.-Polish Showdown at Bali Tournament
abstract: Following on from Saturday’s column, we move to the diagramed deal, the penultimate board in one quarterfinal of the Transnational Teams world championship last month in Bali, Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Following on from Saturday’s column, we move to the diagramed deal, the penultimate board in one quarterfinal of the Transnational Teams world championship last month in Bali, Indonesia. The eventual winners, Mark Gordon, Pratap Rajadhyaksha, David Berkowitz, Alan Sontag, Jacek Pszczola (known as Pepsi) and Michael Seamon from the United States, were locked in a tense battle against Polish Students (Stanislaw Golebiowski, Piotr Tuczynski, Pawel Jassem, Jakub Wojcieszek, Michal Klukowski and Piotr Zatorski).

headline: Supreme Court Precedents in Play
abstract: The new Supreme Court term, which starts Monday, is notable for the number of major precedents that may be overruled or revised.
lead_paragraph: The new Supreme Court term, which starts Monday, is notable for the number of major precedents that may be overruled or revised.

lead_paragraph: Scenes from the new Broadway musical at the Neil Simon Theater.

headline: What the Artists Are Doing
abstract: A debut by Amy Johnson.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — It’s always nice to start a brand new solving week with a debut. Today, Amy Johnson’s byline appears in The New York Times, and I would like to welcome her by saying that I enjoyed her puzzle. It’s great to see a debut puzzle that’s relatively clean and has such nice long fill. I also liked her colorful theme.

headline: ‘Fall for Dance’
abstract: Images of performances by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and other companies.
lead_paragraph: Images of performances by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater and other companies.

headline: Hip-Hop in Mixed Company of Swans and Other Woodland Creatures
abstract: The final program of Fall for Dance featured the Los Angeles company Bodytraffic, Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo, Sidi Larbi Cherkaoui’s “Faun” and the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.
lead_paragraph: The fifth and final program of this year’s Fall for Dance Festival was like a day at the cinema: the dancing equivalent of a short film, two cartoons and, at long last, a movie. The program, presented on Friday at City Center, got off to a ponderous start with a work that had its origins as a Sadler’s Wells London production. While that connection doesn’t automatically mean clunker, there are trademarks to such imports: ever-torquing limbs and more than a dash of melodrama.

headline: Divers Recover 83 More Bodies From Migrant Ship
abstract: The death toll, now at 194, is likely to grow following the disaster near an Italian island in the Mediterranean.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Divers searching the underwater wreckage of a migrant ship that capsized last week in the Mediterranean Sea recovered another 83 bodies on Sunday, raising the death toll to 194, a figure that is likely to keep growing.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The European Parliament weighs how to regulate electronic cigarettes, while JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo kick off Wall Street’s third-quarter earnings season on Friday.
lead_paragraph: E-CIGARETTES The European Parliament, meeting in Strasbourg, France, plans to vote on Tuesday on a broad set of proposed tobacco regulations — the most contentious of which is how to regulate electronic cigarettes. Advocates of e-cigarettes say they are less harmful than conventional cigarettes, because users inhale nicotine-infused vapors instead of smoke. Despite the products’ growing popularity, some European public health officials want them regulated as medical devices. Even if tobacco industry lobbyists prevail in getting the European Parliament to back a less stringent form of regulation, the vote would be only a step in a European rule-making process for e-cigarettes that could continue into next year or beyond.

headline: World Bank, Rooted in Bureaucracy, Proposes a Sweeping Reorganization
abstract: The new leader has a plan to sort the sprawling bank’s operations by the kinds of projects involved, like agriculture or energy, rather than by region.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jim Yong Kim, the genial American physician who took over as the president of the World Bank last year, recently conducted a survey of its 10,000 employees. The survey revealed a “culture of fear,” pervasive “fear of risk” and a “terrible” environment for collaboration at the huge development institution, which lends more than $30 billion a year and works in more than 100 countries.

headline: Sex, Doubt and the Pope
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Encyclicals', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Sex']
abstract: Unless the pope rejects the Church’s stance on homosexuality, birth control and abortion, his recent remarks are just changes of style and tone.
lead_paragraph: Many liberal Catholics have been encouraged by Pope Francis’s comments about sexual ethics in a recent interview. His general point was that these are lesser matters, not to be emphasized at the expense of the church’s essential message of healing and salvation. Asked about homosexuality, he simply evoked God’s love for all humans: “when God looks at a gay person, does he endorse the existence of this person with love, or reject and condemn this person? . . . In life, God accompanies persons, and we must accompany them, starting from their situation. It is necessary to accompany them with mercy.” More widely, he said: “We cannot insist only on issues related to abortion, gay marriage and the use of contraceptive methods . . . . The dogmatic and moral teachings of the church are not all equivalent. The church’s pastoral ministry cannot be obsessed with the transmission of a disjointed multitude of doctrines to be imposed insistently.”

headline: Nielsen to Measure Twitter Chatter About TV Shows
abstract: The company’s new product, Nielsen Twitter TV Ratings, professes to measure the activity and reach of Twitter conversation about shows.
lead_paragraph: Only 98,600 people wrote messages on Twitter about the two-hour season premiere of “Grey’s Anatomy” last month. That’s a tiny fraction of the 9.3 million who, according to Nielsen, watched the show that night.

headline: Being Mayor
abstract: Bill de Blasio is running a great campaign. Can he run New York?
lead_paragraph: IN electing their next mayor, New Yorkers have a choice between a man with impressive political gifts but limited management experience and a seasoned manager who seems politically tone deaf.

headline: Abraham Nemeth, Creator of a Braille Code for Math, Is Dead at 94
abstract: Told that blind people could not do math, Dr. Nemeth developed a customized code that even captured the complexities of differential calculus.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Nemeth, whose frustrations in pursuing an academic career in math prompted him to develop the Nemeth Code, a form of Braille that greatly improved the ability of visually impaired people to study complex mathematics, died on Wednesday at his home in Southfield, Mich. He was 94.

headline: The Boehner Bunglers
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'National Debt (US)', 'Tea Party Movement', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Don’t underestimate the incompetence factor.
lead_paragraph: The federal government is shut down, we’re about to hit the debt ceiling (with disastrous economic consequences), and no resolution is in sight. How did this happen?

headline: Pakistan Army Chief Says He Will Retire Next Month
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Despite media speculation to the contrary, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani confirmed he will step down on Nov. 29, creating an opening for a new army chief.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Pakistan’s army chief, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, confirmed Sunday that he would retire next month, laying to rest media speculation that he would extend his term or take a powerful new position in the military.

headline: A. C. Lyles, Prolific Producer of Westerns, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Lyles rose from the mailroom to a lucrative niche at Paramount Pictures, employing underused stars in profitable low-budget westerns.
lead_paragraph: A. C. Lyles, who rose from the mailroom to producer at Paramount Pictures and created a string of profitable low-budget westerns, died on Sept. 27 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 95.

headline: A Balancing Act Around Lake Tahoe
abstract: A development plan satisfies some environmental groups and political leaders in California and Nevada, but critics say it will open the door to more development than proponents claim.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif. — Protecting this natural wonder, set in a mountain-ringed bowl 6,225 feet atop the Sierra Nevada, would have been difficult enough. But its placement, straddling the California-Nevada border, brings the two states into play, with sometimes-competing visions for the lake’s future.

headline: 4 Held in Iran Nuclear Site Plot
abstract: Four people, most likely employees of Iran’s nuclear program, were suspected of planning to sabotage one of its nuclear sites, an official told reporters.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — The Iranian authorities have arrested four people suspected of planning to sabotage one of the country’s nuclear sites, the chief of Iran’s nuclear program told reporters on Sunday.

headline: When Wealth Disappears
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Recession and Depression', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: We are reaching end times for Western affluence. We must accept economic honesty and recognize that promises made during good times can no longer be easily kept.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — AS bad as things in Washington are — the federal government shutdown since Tuesday, the slim but real potential for a debt default, a political system that seems increasingly ungovernable — they are going to get much worse, for the United States and other advanced economies, in the years ahead.

headline: At a Nissan Plant in Mississippi, a Battle to Shape the U.A.W.’s Future
abstract: The United Automobile Workers is taking a campaign global to promote a unionization effort at Nissan’s plant in Canton, Miss.
lead_paragraph: CANTON, Miss. — The United Automobile Workers — desperate to make inroads in the anti-union South where Toyota, Volkswagen and other foreign automakers have assembly plants — has never tried a unionization drive quite like the one at the Nissan plant here.

headline: Ain’t That Peculiar
abstract: Whether it’s the night before, or right before, a game, Jets players and coaches have quirks to attend to.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The night before every Jets game, safety Jaiquawn Jarrett shuts off his cellphone, as he used to do in college. In a separate room at the team hotel, right guard Willie Colon has two hours of acupuncture treatment. As needles poke and prod Colon, linebacker Antwan Barnes takes a 45-minute shower while rhythm and blues music plays in the background.

headline: Old Warhorse Is Having Trouble Finding His Stride
abstract: Jaromir Jagr, 41, has played 99 games and scored 89 points against the Devils, but now they are counting on their former nemesis to score for them.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Like most everything in his career, Jaromir Jagr’s three-week tenure with the Devils has been eventful.

abstract: The Jets travel to Atlanta to play the Falcons.

headline: Using Twitter to Move the Markets
abstract: Over the course of three Twitter posts about Apple from the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, the company’s market capitalization rose about $17 billion.
lead_paragraph: Last week, while everyone was wondering what Twitter is worth after the unveiling of its I.P.O., I spent some time on a little different math. How much could a single post on Twitter be worth?

headline: As DVRs Shift TV Habits, Ratings Calculations Follow
abstract: What is notable about the start of the new fall TV season, according to network executives, is a surge in not just delayed viewing, but very-delayed viewing.
lead_paragraph: One day after Fox introduced the Headless Horseman drama “Sleepy Hollow” last month, the television world was impressed by its overnight rating, a 3.4 among adults age 18 to 49. Fox knew it would grow: based on last season’s viewing trends, Fox figured the premiere episode would finish between a 5.1 and a 5.4 rating once seven days of digital video recorder playback were added.

headline: Despite Hazards, Street Skateboarding Thrives
abstract: Two deaths in New York City in recent weeks have not deterred the traffic-dodging riders of longboards.
lead_paragraph: They race through the streets of New York, cruising through the cityscape as they try to outmaneuver taxis and dodge car doors swinging open.

headline: Rival Factions in Strike Underscore the Fissures in Post-Chávez Venezuela
keywords: ['Strikes', 'Steel and Iron', 'Nationalization of Industry', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The government claims a strike at a steel mill was prompted by American meddling, but strikers say they are owed unpaid bonuses and other benefits.
lead_paragraph: CIUDAD GUAYANA, Venezuela — Rival union groups squared off outside this country’s biggest steel mill last week, arguing over whether to continue a lengthy strike at the government-run plant. Each faction blasted its message at top volume over loudspeakers, trying to drown the other out. Pushing and shoving ensued, along with dueling renditions of the national anthem.

headline: Pirates Beat the Averages and the Cardinals in Game 3
abstract: The Pirates lead the series against the Cardinals two games to one and a victory Monday will send them to the N.L. Championship Series.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Kevin Siegrist had never pitched in the major leagues before early June. Five years ago, he was drafted in the 41st round. But pedigree hardly matters to the St. Louis Cardinals, who develop their prospects well and expect results when they reach the majors.

abstract: The man, a Kenyan of Somali origin known as Ikrimah, was not captured, and there is as yet no evidence that he was killed in the firefight on the Somali coast early Saturday.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The target of the American commando raid in the Horn of Africa, a Kenyan of Somali origin known as Ikrimah, is one of the Shabab militant group’s top planners for attacks beyond its base in Somalia, an American official said Sunday.

headline: Ailing Midwestern Cities Extend a Welcoming Hand to Immigrants

abstract: Cities like Dayton, Ohio, have started “immigrant friendly” programs in hopes of reviving their economies.
lead_paragraph: DAYTON, Ohio — Fighting back from the ravages of industrial decline, this city adopted a novel plan two years ago to revive its economy and its spirits: become a magnet for immigrants.

headline: Necessity Is the Mother of Reinvention as Players Shift Roles During the Postseason
abstract: Subtle moves in the postseason to the lineup, as demonstrated by the Tigers and Athletics managers, are not unprecedented.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Need and comfort often clash in the postseason, when a manager places a player in an unfamiliar role or asks him to perform a seldom-required task.

headline: Alabama Museum, in Area Where Stars Found Sound, Seeks an Audience: Tourists
abstract: The struggling Alabama Music Hall of Fame, near where the Muscle Shoals sound was born in the 1960s, is scheduled to reopen on Oct. 17.
lead_paragraph: TUSCUMBIA, Ala. — A tentative revival is under way in this rural nook of northwest Alabama, a holy place in the evolution of rock ‘n’ roll and home to a museum noticeably light on tourists.

headline: Mismanaging the Vote in New York City
abstract: The city still can’t seem to deal with voting in the computer age, and the problems go well beyond counting.
lead_paragraph: Around the country, voting seems to be getting easier — not perfect, but certainly better. One glaring exception is New York City. Instead of leading the way to better, fairer, cleaner elections, the city’s Board of Elections runs a slow, often loony system that can’t seem to deal with voting in the computer age. New Yorkers who voted in a mayoral primary last month were forced to use ancient voting machines because the board couldn’t figure out how to make sure the newer optical-scanning machines would work for a possible runoff three weeks later.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (HBO2) SHAME (2011) A handsome Manhattanite named Brandon (Michael Fassbender, above) hooked on sex finds his routine disrupted by the arrival of his sister (Carey Mulligan), whose neediness threatens his detached self-control — and whose self-destructive tendencies fuel his own — in this drama from the director Steve McQueen. “We’re not bad people,” she says in a teary message on his cellphone. “We just come from a bad place.” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times: “Is ‘Shame’ the name of something Brandon does feel, or of something the filmmakers think he should feel? The movie, for all its displays of honesty (which is to say nudity), is also curiously coy. It presents Brandon for our titillation, our disapproval and perhaps our envy, but denies him access to our sympathy. I know, that’s the point, that Mr. McQueen wants to show how the intensity of Brandon’s need shuts him off from real intimacy, but this seems to be a foregone conclusion, the result of an elegant experiment that was rigged from the start.”

headline: A Bombing Suspect, and the Rush to Judgment
keywords: ['Olympic Games (1996)', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'News and News Media', 'Baby Boomers']
abstract: While many news outlets identified what they said was the leading suspect in the 1996 Olympics bombing, the executive editor held The Times back.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Retro Report video tells the story of Richard Jewell, an innocent man, who in the summer of 1996 was painted by some news media outlets as being a likely suspect in a bombing at the Atlanta Olympics, which killed one person and injured more than 100 others. Using archival footage and recent interviews with the lead players, the video explains how a good deal of the newspaper and television coverage relied on unidentified law enforcement sources to cast Mr. Jewell in the worst possible light. It was nearly three months before the federal government cleared him, and almost a decade before Eric Rudolph, a violent anti-abortionist, pleaded guilty to the bombing. Below, The Times’s main reporter on the story recalls lessons learned.

I finally got around to it. I used two-thirds whole wheat flour and one-third all-purpose flour in this very pink batter. Ms. Boyce uses a mixture of quinoa flour and all-purpose, which shows off the bright color of the beets to a better effect. I think millet flour would be a good choice too. It’s important to purée the roasted beets until they’re really smooth; I found using a powerful hand blender was more effective for this than my food processor.

headline: The Day My War Ended
keywords: ['Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: An Army officer recalls what he saw and felt on duty in Baghdad on Oct. 7, 2003, a day he says signaled a tipping point in the war in Iraq.
lead_paragraph: Standing shoulder to shoulder with hundreds of heavily armed paratroopers, I looked around at all of us, breathing heavily, angry and resentful, surrounding the Baya mosque in Baghdad. The previous morning, we had arrested the head imam because he was stockpiling weapons in the mosque. Now, under amber street lamps casting wicked shadows, his followers were gathered, demanding his release. My adrenaline was still pumping from the explosion minutes earlier, when one of them tossed a grenade at our line of troops, injuring more than a half-dozen soldiers and civilians. After that, order descended into a running street battle, soldiers wrestling protesters, bodies slamming into the hard concrete. Months of pent-up aggression were suddenly released in a cathartic, chaotic performance.

headline: Feeling For | Backpackers and Businessmen Alike Check Into Hlemmur Square in Reykjavik
abstract: A new hostel and luxury hotel in one, from the same hotelier who brought New York the Standard East Village and New Orleans the Hotel Modern, offers chic accommodations for a modest price.
lead_paragraph: Klaus Ortlieb, a German-born hotelier who made his mark stateside with the Hotel Modern in New Orleans and two properties in New York City (the Gotham Hotel and the Standard East Village), proves once again that building a successful hotel is not unlike throwing a much-talked-about party. It’s all about appealing to a wide range of guests. So for the new Hlemmur Square hotel in Reykjavik, he designed a high-low model to accommodate the discerning traveler at any budget. The 26 shared, hostel-style rooms are available for as little as $20 per night, while the 18 private rooms, on a separate, plusher floor, cost as much as $182. A far cry from the standard-issue budget digs of yore, the hostel suites offer duvet-covered beds, complimentary local telephone calls and optional room service. And the upgrade to a private room comes with the usual boutique hotel comforts: modern décor (earth tones and oak parquet floors, gray walls dotted with black-and-white photographs of Old Reykjavik), extra-cozy beds (made with up with Lissadell linens) and stunning, top-floor views (of the city’s boldly colored roofs).

I’m an architect by training and I like seeing new places and how they are designed, so I don’t really mind the travel.

headline: Tending to Colombia’s Disappeared and Their Final Homes
abstract: Juan Manuel Echavarría’s brief documentary, “Réquiem NN,” chronicles a symbiosis between anonymous victims of violence in Colombia and the residents of a town where bodies are buried.
lead_paragraph: The double N in the title of “Réquiem NN” is no misprint: It stands for sadness and, very probably, suffering. In this brief documentary, the Colombian artist Juan Manuel Echavarría chronicles the stacked tombs of anonymous victims from his country’s decades of violent internecine conflict. Each is marked with the abbreviation for “no name” in Spanish, but as shown here, the unknown dead enter a kind of second life through the residents of Puerto Berrío, where bodies found in the nearby Magdalena River are buried.

headline: When Clothes No Longer Make the Man
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Until now, the importance of clothes has been both central and stable in fiction.
lead_paragraph: As I watched the coverage of Milan’s fall fashion week — the penultimate of a month of fashion shows that began in New York and ended in Paris last Wednesday — I thought of Giacomo Leopardi, the great Italian poet and moralist. Leopardi fancifully portrayed fashion as death’s sister. In a dialogue between the two, Fashion explains to Death what they have in common: “We both equally profit by the incessant change and destruction of things here below…” I was struck by the special relevance of Leopardi’s statement to one earthly realm in particular: the writing of fiction, where the device of disclosing the nature of character through clothes seems to be all but destroyed.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — He is Jewish. He is Latino. He can break dance and play jazz piano. He speaks nearly impeccable Spanish. He has talked longingly about growing his own vegetables and maybe even raising his own chickens. He lives on this city’s hip east side.

headline: ‘A Short History of the Highrise’
abstract: An interactive documentary explores the 2,500-year history of vertical living and issues of social equality in an increasingly urbanized world.
lead_paragraph: At a time when Manhattan luxury condos can cost tens of millions of dollars, residential high-rise buildings made of glass have become symbols of gargantuan excess and privilege. But the history of vertical living goes far back in time and extends around the globe — from the biblical Tower of Babel, to Arizona cliff dwellings to the Soviet Khrushchyovka towers.

headline: Argentina: Surgery for President
abstract: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner will undergo surgery  to drain an accumulation of blood near her brain resulting from a recent head injury, her doctors said.
lead_paragraph: President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner will undergo surgery on Tuesday to drain an accumulation of blood near her brain resulting from a recent head injury, her doctors said Monday. The doctors, Facundo Manes and Gerardo Bozovich of Fundación Favaloro, a private hospital in Buenos Aires, said they opted for the surgery after Mrs. Kirchner was found on Sunday to have a tingling sensation and a slight loss of muscular strength in her left arm. Mrs. Kirchner’s spokesman had revealed Saturday that she had sustained a previously undisclosed “skull trauma” in August, and that doctors had told her to rest for 30 days as a result of the injury, which involves chronic bleeding between the surface of her brain and her skull.

headline: Obama and the Debt
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'Fourteenth Amendment (US Constitution)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: Despite what the president says, he has the power to avoid a debt default.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, N.J. — THE Republicans in the House of Representatives who declare that they may refuse to raise the debt limit threaten to do more than plunge the government into default. They are proposing a blatant violation of the 14th Amendment, which states that “the validity of the public debt of the United States, authorized by law” is sacrosanct and “shall not be questioned.”

headline: China: Big Energy Project Planned
abstract: China is planning to build its largest coal gasification energy project in the western region of Xinjiang, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency.
lead_paragraph: China is planning to build its largest coal gasification energy project in the western region of Xinjiang, according to a report by Xinhua, the state news agency. The $30 billion project is in the Zhundong area of the Changji Hui Autonomous Prefecture, and it is expected to produce 30 billion cubic meters of gas per year, Xinhua reported Sunday, citing Xinjiang officials. The project will need an input of 90 million tons of coal per year and is expected to create 18,000 jobs, Xinhua reported. The article said “coal gasification is expected to be a key sector in the country’s clean energy initiative.” The coal gasification process can result in severe discharge of pollutants if it is not properly controlled.

headline: A Transcendence Grounded in Austere Contemplation

Known for creating dances with high-energy explosiveness, Ms. Skaggs has become more contemplative, more deliberate. She has slowed things down.

headline: Walking on Sydney’s Wild Side
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'ABORIGINES']
abstract: In February, Sydney Harbour was named Australia’s newest National Landscape, highlighting the natural wonders that dot the region.
lead_paragraph: The blue-tongued lizard eyed me suspiciously but remained still long enough for photographs, while a kookaburra laughed and a diminutive wallaby rustled in the brush. Rock engravings of fish and kangaroos marked ceremonial sites of Aboriginal ancestors. Scented forests of eucalyptus and gum trees shaded our path over sandstone and thin topsoil, classic Outback topography surprisingly concealed on the outskirts of Sydney.

headline: The Meaning of Mountains

lead_paragraph: Pemba Gyalje Sherpa was part of the group of climbers who, in early August 2008, began the last leg of their summit of K2, a mountain in the heart of the Karakoram Range in northern Pakistan. At 28,251 feet, K2 is second in height only to Everest, but its peak is even steeper, colder and more desolate than its Himalayan sister.

lead_paragraph: Hollywood’s leading ladies and men have been wearing shoes by Salvatore Ferragamo since before the invention of talkies. In 1954, Audrey Hepburn famously wore suede Ferragamo ballet flats in “Sabrina,” and more recently, Drew Barrymore and Nicole Kidman have appeared in films wearing Ferragamo footwear. The latest ingenue to be associated with the brand, Kaya Scodelario, was cast by Ferragamo itself. The 21-year-old actress, best known for her role in the British TV series “Skins,” recently embarked on a whirlwind adventure, traveling from her hometown of London to Florence, Los Angeles and Shanghai to shoot “Walking Stories,” an online-only romantic comedy that Ferragamo will release in eight parts this month, every Tuesday and Thursday beginning today, at ferragamo.com. “We literally went around the world in two weeks,” she said.

headline: David vs. Goliath
abstract: A diminutive Confederate ship helped revolutionize naval warfare.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after 9 p.m. on a dark October night in 1863, four intrepid Confederates launched one of the most daring attacks of the Civil War. Nestled into the David, a cigar–shaped vessel 50 feet long and barely 5 feet in diameter, they steamed toward one of the Union Navy’s mightiest warships, the New Ironsides, on blockade duty in Charleston harbor. Each member of the crew — Capt. William T. Glassell, the pilot Walker Cannon, the assistant engineer J. H. Toombs and the seaman James Sullivan — carried a shotgun and revolver. But the real damage they intended was to come from a 134-pound explosive charge of at the end of a 30-foot spar extended from the prow of their vessel.

abstract: The civil war has exacted a brutal toll, yet at a funeral for a soldier from a coastal town, grief was tempered with loyalty for the government.

As a commander handed the dead man’s mother a Syrian flag folded into a neat triangle, the scrape of branches shifting in the wind could be heard over quiet sobs and prayers.

lead_paragraph: There were more luxurious fine-dining restaurants in New York than Corton, which closed this summer after nearly five years in TriBeCa, but very few that could deliver as many high-wire thrills. Paul Liebrandt’s cooking challenged you to pay attention. The precisely calibrated flavors might be contained in a single mouthful, or might unscroll themselves as you ate your way across several plates. The harmonies were multilayered, and so were the rewards.

headline: In Canarsie, a Coalition of the Tried-and-True

The streets are relatively clean, the rows of one- and two-family homes often well maintained, the living-room-carpet-size lawns conscientiously mowed.

headline: The Shadow of the Sequester
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The idea that sequestration was a huge “win” for the G.O.P. is making the current impasse worse.
lead_paragraph: A final point on the debt ceiling, before I turn to less exasperating subjects: One of the underappreciated dynamics making the current mess worse is the fact that both left and right, for somewhat different reasons, have embraced the idea that the outcome of the last debt ceiling deal  — sequestration, with its butcher-knife cuts to domestic programs and defense — was a straightforward win for Republicans, and a huge concession by the Democrats. For liberals, this idea has fed into the widespread “never again” attitude where debt ceiling negotiations are concerned. (“We can’t get blackmailed like that a second time!”) For conservatives, it’s encouraged deeply implausible ideas about what they can expect the White House to offer them this time. (“We basically won outright in 2011, so why not try to go for Obamacare repeal this time around?”)

headline: Moving to the Cadence of an Elizabethan Text

His wife, Gu Kailai, was sentenced to life in prison last year for the murder of a British businessman. The family associate said that Mr. Bo’s lawyer had filed the appealed soon after the sentencing. The higher court judges are likely to review the appeal on paper rather than hear arguments in court, the family associate said. Political analysts said the higher court is unlikely to overturn the verdict, since party leaders were almost certainly the ones who had determined the verdict.

headline: No Physicist Is an Island
keywords: ['Physics', 'Science and Technology', 'Higgs Boson', 'Nobel Prizes', 'Large Hadron Collider']
abstract: Science is an intensely collaborative pursuit, and prizes to individuals are rarely able to capture the full nuance of the historical reality.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — THE physicist Richard Feynman liked to gripe about what he called “Alfred Nobel’s Other Mistake.” The first mistake was the invention of dynamite. The second was creating the Nobel Prizes. Mr. Feynman thought it was ridiculous that something as material as a cash prize should be awarded to something as grand and open-ended as scientific research. (The griping wasn’t a matter of sour grapes; Mr. Feynman shared a well-deserved prize for physics in 1965.) This year’s physics Nobel has just been awarded to François Englert and Peter Higgs, for what is simply called “the Higgs mechanism.” But while Mr. Englert and Mr. Higgs undoubtedly deserve acclaim, bestowing an award on them alone distorts the nature of modern physics research.

headline: The Scent of the Wild in Williamsburg
abstract: Juniper Ridge, the West Coast maker of wild fragrances, brings its process and natural ingredients to the East Coast for a two-month pop-up shop in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A bearded, flannel-shirt-wearing backpacker from the Cascade Mountains of Portland, Ore., is not your typical perfumer. But in the case of Hall Newbegin, an obsessive love for the outdoors inspired him to create Juniper Ridge, a wild-crafted line of handmade colognes, soaps and incense, based in Oakland, Calif. First introduced at farmers’ markets in the Bay Area in 1998 and now carried in thoughtfully curated shops like Shelter Half in Los Angeles and Steven Alan Home in New York, Newbegin’s artisanal goods have a hyper-local focus. He forages aromatic plants, mushrooms, tree trimmings and moss on the trails around the West Coast, then distills everything using an old-fashioned enfleurage process to create essential oils that smell like the Mojave Desert after the rain or a dusky summer evening along the Timberline Trail on Mount Hood. “People say the scents remind them of camping,” said Newbegin, who currently lives by Mount Tamalpais in Northern California and trained in herbal medicine before becoming what he calls a “wildness nose.” The latest additions to his forest-centric range are two addition to his line of “backpacker’s colognes”: Big Sur, which is infused with wild sage, and Yuba River, a blend redolent of cedar log cabins and the richness of hiking-boot leather. Like all Juniper Ridge products, they’re made without petrochemicals or synthetic ingredients — “just real stuff from real places,” Newbegin explained.

It was here, one breezy day in 2006, according to legend, that Jack Dorsey ordered burritos with two co-workers, scaled a slide and, in a black sweater and green beanie, like a geeked-out Moses on Mount Sinai, presented his idea for an Internet service that would allow users to update their current status and share what they were doing. “That playground right up there is where I first brought up the idea,” Dorsey, whose present-day uniform is a white Dior dress shirt and tailored dark blazer, told CNBC earlier this year.

They still can’t face the reality that Obama won’t offer any concessions, of any kind, under threat. headline: The Color of Royalty, Bestowed by Science and Snails
keywords: ['Snails', 'Dyes and Dyestuffs', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: In ancient Rome, purple dye that signified royalty came from a very unlikely source — marine snails, boiled down for the pigment locked in their shells.
lead_paragraph: We now take brightly colored fabric for granted. There were far fewer pigments available to the people of antiquity, and most of them were somewhat drab by today’s standards. Throughout the Mediterranean, the dye Tyrian purple was prized above all others. In ancient Rome, fabric dyed with Tyrian purple was worth its weight in gold. Its intense color, as well as its expense, made it a favorite of royalty and nobility and it was coveted as a status symbol. The association between purple and royalty that persists in many cultures today originated with this ancient pigment.

headline: 36 Hours in Sarajevo, Bosnia and Herzegovina
abstract: Creative energy and natural beauty mix with a complicated history during a weekend in this capital city.
lead_paragraph: At midday in Sarajevo, muezzins call from minarets as church bells echo through the Dinaric Alps. Street cars rumble past hookah smokers and cafegoers. Chic women click-clack down cobbled alleyways. The city’s charisma is intoxicating, but the hustle and bustle belies a tragic past. In 1992, Bosnia-Herzegovina’s capital went from a beacon of diversity, with Yugoslav Muslims, Christians and Jews worshiping within feet of one other, to the site of a nearly four-year siege claiming more than 11,000 lives. But much has changed over the last decade or so. The creative spirit that Sarajevans fought to preserve is very much in evidence these days. Neighborhoods, cradled in this valley and ringing the foothills, are fertile entrepreneurial grounds and a testament to the epochs that came before. Cafes, theaters, boutiques and restaurants have sprouted among buildings in myriad styles, including Ottoman, Secessionist, Communist and modern. And locals and visitors alike are rediscovering the surrounding mountains on the slopes that hosted the 1984 Winter Olympic Games.

When he stepped to the front of the stage to sing other songs, away from the microphones, his guitar and voice were indeed all Mr. Drexler needed in the intimate hall. abstract: Lar Lubovitch Dance Company performed at the Joyce on Tuesday night, opening with a series of duets before revisiting a substantial piece from 2000.
lead_paragraph: The veteran choreographer Lar Lubovitch, an art major before he discovered modern dance, has spoken about how he sees the stage as a canvas. Instead of using brush strokes to give a painting a sense of momentum, he relies on bodies that ripple through space, pause to crest and then sweep lushly in another direction. When they succeed, Mr. Lubovitch’s dances are visceral paintings come to life.

headline: Listen Up | An Avant-Garde Artist Makes a Bid for Pop Stardom
abstract: This new track, a remix of the song “Gravity” from Arp’s latest album, “More,” will make you want to dance.
lead_paragraph: Alexis Georgopoulos took the moniker under which he makes music, Arp, from a defunct manufacturer of analog synthesizers. It was a fitting name for the kind of music the 39-year-old, New York-based artist made on the albums “In Light” (2007) and “The Soft Wave” (2010): instrumental outings with minimalist repetition and exploratory electronics that owed more to minimalist composers like Steve Reich and Philip Glass than anything resembling pop music. But on his new album, “More,” it becomes clear from the opening strains of the first track, “High-Heeled Clouds” — a dreamy ballad featuring breathy vocals, melodic keyboard lines and a hooky chorus — that Georgopoulos is taking the music in a more tuneful direction.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Google’s Anti-Aging Start-Up, and the Man Tied to Silk Road
abstract: Wednesday’s highlights from around the Web include details on Google’s efforts to stop us from getting old. Plus, an attempt to piece together the life of the purported libertarian mastermind behind Silk Road, an online drug market.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Alice Lives Between Fantasy and Reality
abstract: The heroine in “Once Upon a Time in Wonderland” is Lewis Carroll’s Alice, and the action moves between the human world and a fantasy realm.
lead_paragraph: “If I get high enough, I can see the Hatter’s house,” Alice says in the premiere on Thursday night of ABC’s “Once Upon a Time in Wonderland.” If we could get high enough, maybe we could see some reason to sit through this Disneyfied pastiche of Lewis Carroll and “1,001 Nights.” Or maybe not.

headline: Neighborhood Joint: Park Delicatessen
abstract: In Crown Heights, a deli-themed florist and skateboard shop attracts a varied customer base.
lead_paragraph: In Crown Heights, a deli-themed florist and skateboard shop attracts a varied customer base.

headline: Blurring Boundaries, Sharpening Ideas
abstract: The French Institute Alliance Française’s Crossing the Line festival mixes and matches genres in performance.
lead_paragraph: The term “transdisciplinary” is heard a great deal. But what does it actually mean? Does it go beyond using text in your dance piece, or video in your play? Does its very nature ask artists to question our understanding of genre, or to destabilize what it is that audiences think they are seeing?

headline: Investigating a Grudge During a Day in Berkeley
abstract: The Frugal Traveler tries to sort out some long-simmering jealousy issues during a stop in the California college town.
lead_paragraph: I’ve long held a grudge against graduates of the University of California, Berkeley. As the graduate of a pricey private university in the wintry northeast, I’ve never been able to shake the uneasy feeling that they got a similar education at a fraction of the cost in far nicer weather.

headline: ‘So I Told Hitler’ and Other Film Re-Enactments
abstract: The recovered and restored films in the Museum of Modern Art’s To Save and Project festival include two anti-Nazi movies from the mid-1930s.
lead_paragraph: A film festival that includes a pair of Weimar-influenced pre-code Hollywood musicals, three classic cartoons by John and Faith Hubley and a 1936 docudrama in which an American re-enacts her imprisonment in Nazi Germany might fairly be called eclectic. Or it might be called To Save and Project, as the Museum of Modern Art titles its annual survey of recently restored movies, which returned this week for its 11th edition. Organized by Joshua Siegel, an associate curator in the museum’s film department, the festival has a sweeping nature that suggests how much work is being done to reclaim film history — and how much more needs to be done. This year’s program contains some 75 feature films and shorts from archives around the world.

headline: Not a Teachable Moment, but a Respectful One
abstract: Thursday’s episode of “Glee” is the first to address the disappearance of Finn, the character played by Cory Monteith, who died this summer from a toxic combination of drugs and alcohol.
lead_paragraph: “Glee” isn’t just another comedy about the horrors of high school. Now in its fifth season, this cheeky Fox show has become a cabaret-meets-after-school-special that sneaks in as many life lessons as it does pop songs. In a recent episode, there was even a reminder about the importance of meningitis vaccines.

headline: Reincarnation of Treasured Instrument
abstract: Wu Man will have her new instrument when she performs Lou Harrison’s Concerto for Pipa With String Orchestra in the season-opening concerts of the Hartford Symphony Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: This was a sound no musician should have to suffer: the destruction of her longtime instrument. In Wu Man’s case, in June, it was a loud crack, heard from her seat as a flight attendant, trying to stow her pipa in a coat closet up front, dropped it, breaking its neck.

headline: After an Introduction by de Blasio, a Brooklyn Hospital Hired His Wife
abstract: The chief executive of a Brooklyn hospital told Chirlane McCray, Mr. de Blasio’s spouse, that she had no job open at the moment, but that she could invent one.
lead_paragraph: Sometime around 2005, a Brooklyn city councilman introduced his wife, who was looking for a new job, to the head of a hospital in his district.

headline: Meredith Whitney Appears to Be Trading Brokerage Firm for Investment Fund
abstract: The termination of Meredith Whitney Advisory Group’s brokerage license follows a rocky period for the onetime star analyst.
lead_paragraph: Meredith A. Whitney appears poised to leave the industry that lifted her to fame.

headline: Wu Man Plays the Pipa
abstract: The musician performs a piece on her pipa, a traditional Chinese instrument.
lead_paragraph: The musician performs a piece on her pipa, a traditional Chinese instrument.

abstract: New polls have found increasing frustration with a dysfunctional government, as well as disagreement about the debt limit and how Congress should handle it.
lead_paragraph: More than a week into the government shutdown, a number of new polls have found rising exasperation with a dysfunctional government and economic concern, as well as disagreement about the debt limit and how Congress should handle it.

headline: Video Offers Glimpse of Russia’s Ban on Gay ‘Propaganda’ in Action on a Moscow Street
abstract: Video recorded this week during the arrest of gay rights activists in Moscow shows what Russia’s legal ban on “propaganda for nontraditional sexual relationships” looks like in practice.
lead_paragraph: Video recorded this week during the arrest of gay rights activists in Moscow shows what Russia’s legal ban on “propaganda for nontraditional sexual relationships” looks like in practice.

headline: No Pastrami, but Skateboards and Zinnias
abstract: A skateboard and flower shop keeps vintage boards in an old deli cold case, and has bouquets of seasonal flora.
lead_paragraph: Michael J. Sclafani and Valentine Leung didn’t exactly set out to open a deli-themed florist and skateboard shop.

headline: Artisanal Housewares
abstract: An architect finds nothing but good in supporting craft experts in poor countries.
lead_paragraph: Conscientious shoppers may prefer to buy socially responsible design — objects produced in a way that promotes the well-being of the artisans in Third World countries who make them — but the products have not always been easy to find or sophisticated enough to satisfy the tastes of some consumers. In recent years, however, that has begun to change, as collaborations between designers and artisans have flourished.

headline: Start Spreadin’ the News
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Roman & Williams recently completed the Viceroy New York Hotel, the design firm’s biggest building yet.
lead_paragraph: The Viceroy New York, a 29-story brick hotel at 120 West 57th Street, is the latest and largest building designed by the architectural studio Roman & Williams. And it is filled with its signature touches, like shiny black fluted Italian glass block, crown molding, ultra-veined marble and a strategic use of brass. Rooms are “well-appointed modernist cabins in the sky,” said Robin Standefer, a founder of the firm. Over all, the hotel reflects a narrative that is “artistic, refined and glamorous — a way of looking at Uptown, and 57th Street in particular, that seems to have been lost in the last 20 years,” she said.

headline: If It’s All About Location, Does the Sky Count?
abstract: Forget how many trees were killed to produce this hefty coffee table book and just enjoy the subject, which is treehouses.
lead_paragraph: For many, a treehouse signifies questionable construction and freedom from adult supervision. But the projects in “Tree Houses” (Skyhorse Publishing, $50) show how a child’s hideaway has experienced a renaissance in material, sophistication and design. The Copper Cube, for instance, a metal-clad guesthouse in Germany, sits on stilts and has electricity and even a full bath. In Sweden, a saucer-shaped enclosure tied to trees with cables and aptly called the UFO is accessible via a retractable take-me-to-your-leader staircase. But traditionalists, fear not: there are plenty of fairytale-like cottages, too.

headline: Not Built in a Day
abstract: A designer translates Roman monuments and museum-quality art (guess which) into stylish wallpaper.
lead_paragraph: When David Nosanchuk wandered around Rome with a camera a couple of years ago, he didn’t realize he was making wallpaper. But Mr. Nosanchuk, a New York designer, had been invited to contribute ideas to Flavor Paper, a Brooklyn producer of avant-garde wallcoverings. And at some point he saw potential in his luminous prints of the Pantheon and Bernini’s Colonnade at St. Peter’s Basilica.

headline: A One-of-a-Kind, From Sketch to Auction
abstract: Jonathan Ive and Marc Newson collaborate on a desk that will be sold at Sotheby’s.
lead_paragraph: On Nov. 23, Sotheby’s New York will host an auction of items selected by the designer Marc Newson and Apple’s senior vice president for design, Jonathan Ive, to benefit (RED), the charity founded by Bono and Bobby Shriver. Mr. Newson described the 40-odd lots as “stuff we ourselves would kill to have,” including an anodized aluminum desk that he designed with Mr. Ive for the occasion.

headline: Discounts at Vermont Woods, DwellStudio, De La Espada and Lumens
abstract: Bargains on beds, lighting and more.
lead_paragraph: Vermont Woods furniture is 15 percent off, Friday to Tuesday (a queen-size Modern Incline bed, regularly $2,394, will be about $2,035); (888) 390-5571, vermontwoodsstudios.com.

headline: Light up the Cigars: It’s a Chair
abstract: Jan Habraken on performing marriages between famous furniture pieces to create a museum-worthy chair.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Arts and Design, known as MAD, takes another leap beyond its origins in traditional craft with “Out of Hand: Materializing the Postdigital,” an exhibition of new technologies that dominate many of today’s conversations about design. The show, which opens on Wednesday and runs through July 6, will present objects created through 3-D printing, digital weaving and computer-controlled milling. Included alongside the forward-thinking work of well-known designers like Ron Arad, Zaha Hadid and Maya Lin is a project by the Dutch-born designer Jan Habraken that represents his attempt to breed the ultimate chair. Mr. Habraken, is the founder of FormNation, a New York company. Recently he met a reporter in his Manhattan studio to discuss the concept of chair eugenics, or “chairgenics.” (This interview has been edited and condensed.)

lead_paragraph: A Park Slope Victorian goes Hollywood mod.

lead_paragraph: Even for Park Slope, the house is a showstopper, blooming with intricate mahogany paneling inlaid with mother-of-pearl, and nestled into a block just a few streets away from P.S. 321, the much-coveted elementary school.
