headline: Europe Pledges Aid to Italy for Refugees
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The European Union’s top official visited an Italian island where a boat capsized last week and announced that Italy would receive $40.5 million to deal with refugees.
lead_paragraph: ROME — The European Union’s top official on Wednesday visited the Italian island of Lampedusa, where a crowded boat capsized last week, killing hundreds of migrants, and announced that Italy would receive an additional 30 million euros, or $40.5 million, from the union to help deal with refugees.

headline: Longtime Florida Congressman to Retire
abstract: Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, the longest-serving Republican in Congress, said Wednesday that he would retire in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Representative C. W. Bill Young of Florida, the longest-serving Republican in Congress, said Wednesday that he would retire in 2014. “It’s my time,” Mr. Young, 82, told The Tampa Bay Times. He has long served on the Appropriations Committee, including a stint as chairman from 1999 to 2005, and is known for bringing millions of dollars to his district. A moderate Republican, Mr. Young came to Congress in 1971, at a time when most Southern conservatives were still Democrats. He said that he admires the spirit of Tea Party Republicans, but is “a little disappointed” with the current gridlock.

headline: Paul McCartney Makes Surprise Stop in Queens
abstract: Paul McCartney performed at the Frank Sinatra School of the Arts in Astoria, Queens, to promote his new album, “New.”
lead_paragraph: A half-century after Beatlemania swept Britain, Paul McCartney faced squealing teenage girls once again when he performed on Wednesday afternoon in the Tony Bennett Concert Hall at the Frank Sinatra School of the Arts in Astoria, Queens. They didn’t scream all the way through the songs, as their grandparents might have, but they stayed on their feet — clapping, waving their arms, singing along — through oldies like “Eight Days a Week,” “Ob-La-Di, Ob-La-Da,” “We Can Work It Out” and “Blackbird.”

headline: Cutbacks in U.N. Food Assistance Set Off Outcry in Gaza
keywords: ['Food Aid', 'Palestinians', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'International Relations', 'Budgets and Budgeting']
abstract: The United Nations Relief and Works Agency pointed to a $55 million budget shortfall and said the cuts were based on a re-evaluation of Gaza’s needs.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — Hundreds of women and children protested cutbacks in a United Nations food-assistance program on Wednesday, the latest in a growing backlash by Palestinian refugees and their offspring in this forlorn coastal strip against the agency that for decades has provided them with nutrition, education and health services.

headline: Struck by the Wish to Own
abstract: Alison Ehrmann wanted to buy an apartment on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: Alison Ehrmann lived in the quintessential brownstone on a quiet block on far West 100th Street. Her one-bedroom rental had high ceilings, exposed brick and a tiny kitchen. Her rent was $2,000 a month, just $200 more than when she moved in nine years ago. “I had great landlords, and they really valued good tenants,” she said.

headline: Risk to Food Safety Seen in Furloughs
abstract: Food experts say the government shutdown is endangering what Americans eat, with all inspections of domestic food except meat and poultry halted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The government shutdown is endangering what America eats, food safety experts said this week, as all inspections of domestic food except meat and poultry have halted and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recalled furloughed workers to handle a salmonella outbreak that sickened hundreds of people in 18 states.

headline: A Winner, to Get You There
abstract: Citymapper, which won the M.T.A.’s App Quest contest, suggests various routes and means of transportation (teleporter included), details on Citi Bikes, even calories burned if you walk or pedal.
lead_paragraph: I was a bit disappointed when I saw that  Citymapper had won the 2013 Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s App Quest competition when the results came out a couple of weeks back. Judging by its name, I figured it was just another piece of utilitarian software to help people figure out the city. I was hoping that the winner of the competition, held for apps that complement the transit experience, would be imaginative, like the runner-up, Subculture.FM. Not something so brusque, so practical, so obvious as a map.

headline: A Russian Region Neither at War Nor at Peace, but Facing a Crackdown
keywords: ['Olympic Games (2014)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Police', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Russian authorities, determined that nothing will mar the Olympics in Sochi, have been accused of human rights violations.
lead_paragraph: MAKHACHKALA, Russia — The race lasted only a few seconds and ended with the sound of a gunshot. Shamil Abdulayev, who was 24 years old at the time, had tried to run away from a group of men he knew were bent on abducting him. They wore ski masks and traveled in a white Lada sedan with tinted windows.

headline: Real Estate Boom in Phoenix Brings Its Own Problems
abstract: The housing rebound has come faster in Phoenix than elsewhere, but starter homes are scarce, and prospective buyers are having a hard time finding a place to live.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Here, where the housing market endured one of the hardest crashes anywhere during the recession, the rebound has come faster than in most parts of the country, fueled by a vigorous job market, a sturdy rise in home values and an all-around sense that the worst of times is in the distant past.

keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Courts and the Judiciary']

lead_paragraph: If there is a heaven for iconic taxicabs, with a sneering Travis Bickle at the pearly gates, New York City is almost certainly its top feeder market.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Gov. Jerry Brown on Wednesday expanded access to abortion in California, signing a bill to allow nurse practitioners, midwives and physician assistants to perform a common type of the procedure, an aspiration abortion, during the first trimester.

headline: Researchers Press for Broad Ban on Hockey Fights

lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, Minn. — Researchers at a Mayo Clinic conference on concussions in hockey called Wednesday for a ban on fighting at all levels of the sport, eight days after a Montreal Canadiens enforcer was hospitalized because of a fight on opening night of the N.H.L. season.

headline: The Yellen Fed? Precise and Predictable

lead_paragraph: There are no fast rules for running the Federal Reserve, but Janet L. Yellen has a few.

headline: A Cupboard of My Own
abstract: Some children grow up feeling themselves to be the center of the universe, but I always knew I was a very tiny drop in the ocean of other people’s lives.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, England — At the start of the 1960s, my parents bought a corner shop and moved into the house above it with their five children. Ten years later, I, the accidental sixth, was born. By the time I was 9, my brother and sisters had grown up and either temporarily or permanently moved out, leaving behind them a museum of abandoned items. Cluttering every shelf and corner were forgotten cardigans, orphaned dolls, discarded purses and grayscale strips of pouting photo-booth faces.

headline: In a Polluted Stream, a Pathway to Peace
abstract: An issue that Palestinians and Israelis can work together on.
lead_paragraph: MORRO BAY, Calif. — PEACE talks are under way again in Jerusalem. If the past is any guide, the two sides are stymied over difficult issues like settlements and borders. The negotiators badly need a new approach, and one is right beneath their feet, in the Kidron Valley, the deep ravine that runs from the Old City through the West Bank toward the Dead Sea.

headline: The Curious Curse of the Oakland A’s

headline: The Expulsion of the Consuls
abstract: Why the South expelled British diplomats, and how that helped doom the Confederacy.
lead_paragraph: By Oct. 8, 1863, Britain had crossed the line — at least in the eyes of Judah P. Benjamin, the Confederate secretary of state. Benjamin’s frustration rang out loud and clear from a letter he wrote that day to Allan Fullarton, Britain’s acting consul in Savannah, Ga. Fullarton’s offense? Like other consuls, he was helping British subjects in the Confederacy avoid conscription, which Confederate officials were increasingly applying to citizens and noncitizens alike. Britain allowed that foreign-born men could be required to take part in emergency local defense but denied the Confederacy’s right to draft them into regular military service. But to Benjamin, every time a foreign consul took it upon himself to determine the reach of Confederate conscription, he made an unacceptable assault upon the Confederacy’s sovereignty.

lead_paragraph: “Captain Phillips,” a movie that insistently closes the distance between us and them, has a vital moral immediacy. It was directed by Paul Greengrass, the British filmmaker who quickened the pulse of contemporary action cinema with the second and third installments in the Bourne franchise, features that proved yet again that big-screen thrills and thought need not be mutually exclusive. headline: Getting Into the Spirit
abstract: A former mental hospital in West Virginia, rumored to be a hotbed of paranormal activity, lets visitors search for their own ghost story to tell.
lead_paragraph: Everyone has a ghost story, or at least that’s how it has always seemed to me. My mother’s best friend used to tell a doozy about a soldier she met when she was a bookkeeper in the Air Force. He claimed to be a ghost, then proved it by walking into the middle of a moonlit airfield and disappearing before her eyes. Another friend of my mother’s used to bring over a Ouija board when she baby-sat for me. As that plastic pointer whizzed around the board (with seemingly little help from her fingers), she spoke of the messages that the spirit world sent to her on a regular basis.

abstract: Umami Burger, which started with a single shop in Los Angeles, brings burgers with memorable toppings to Greenwich Village.
lead_paragraph: Umami is sometimes defined as the flavor beyond all flavors, the flavor that cannot be described, but my waitress at Umami Burger in Greenwich Village has no time for such reveries.

headline: Jeff Fluhr of Spreecast, on Finding Employees Who Fit
abstract: Mr. Fluhr, who started StubHub and now leads the social video platform Spreecast, says experience is overrated.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Jeff Fluhr, chief executive of Spreecast, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant.

headline: Living With Cancer: Hospital City
abstract: Sometimes a hospital visit turns into a nightmarish journey through Hospital City, a labryinth of exam rooms and hospital beds where we often are poked, prodded and confused.
lead_paragraph: When you travel to cancer central, you may find yourself more perplexed by the currency, language, customs, costumes, cuisine and time zone than you would have been if you had landed in Timbuktu. In Hospital City, you can lose your way as well as your confidence in everything you took for granted.

headline: Growing Up With a Disabled Sibling
abstract: Does the sibling with Down syndrome inevitably get all the attention?
lead_paragraph: “Mom, when are you going to write a book about me?” my 7-year-old son, Noah, asked as we sat on the floor of his room, surrounded by packing materials from the box that had arrived earlier that day. Inside were copies of my new book, each with a picture of me holding Noah’s brother, Henry, on the cover. Henry has Down syndrome, and the book is about the first three years of his life. Noah had come home to find Henry admiring it while I danced around taking photos for our Facebook page. Noah stood by watching the commotion patiently enough. He understood that Henry was having his turn. He just wanted to know whether the next book would be about him.

headline: Crawford Rediscovers Himself With Los Angeles
abstract: Carl Crawford, sent to the Dodgers in a salary-dumping trade after a miserable run with the Red Sox, has been a welcome addition and has shown signs of returning to form.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Of all the indicators suggesting the return to form of Carl Crawford, a player once thought to be worth $142 million, the biggest was not the three home runs he hit in the last two playoff games for the Los Angeles Dodgers, the diving catch he made over the railing near the left-field stands or a comfortably stolen base.

abstract: Mary-Louise Parker is back on Broadway in “The Snow Geese.”
lead_paragraph: As her Showtime series “Weeds” was nearing its eighth and final season last year, Mary-Louise Parker kept haranguing her agents to send new plays her way. But while she was itchy to find a vehicle back to her first love, theater, a part of her also felt that she would never act onstage again.

headline: In Uganda, a Chance to Work With Gorilla Researchers
abstract: A safari company in Uganda is offering travelers an opportunity to work with gorilla researchers in Bwindi Impenetrable National Park.
lead_paragraph: In addition to staring in awe at a rare African species, safari-goers can give an assist to science by working with gorilla researchers. Uganda-based Premier Safaris has partnered with the renowned gorilla expert Dr. Gladys Kalema-Zikusoka to offer research-focused itineraries to see mountain gorillas in Bwindi Impenetrable National Park.

headline: When Bird Was a Fledgling
abstract: Stanley Crouch’s extended riff on Charlie Parker is less a standard biography and more an exploration of aesthetics and ideas, about America in the first half of the 20th century and black intellect and feeling.
lead_paragraph: The ideal way to ingest Stanley Crouch’s new book is probably on audio, late at night, while driving between the major cities of the Midwest, your headlights pushing past truck stops and dying cornfields. You’ve got to be willing to submit to the spell Mr. Crouch is working to cast.

headline: Danish Art’s Subtler Sides at Scandinavia House
abstract: A Manhattan exhibition displays neo-Classical and early Modern canvases; in Brooklyn, a free event at St. Francis College blends Haitian and Dominican traditions.
lead_paragraph: The Miser has a soft spot — if you can call it that — for Denmark’s arch-brooders. Given their outsize influence on contemporary culture, you might be tempted to associate the likes of Kierkegaard and Lars von Trier with a distinctly Danish sensibility. But the Danish contribution to Western art isn’t limited to histrionic bursts of angst, irony and the absurd. “Danish Paintings From the Golden Age to the Modern Breakthrough,” an exhibition opening this weekend at Scandinavia House, brings together a selection of masterpieces from the late 18th to the 20th centuries that make use of subtler, more austere aesthetics.

headline: A Turnabout From Manga to Zen
abstract: “Rebirth,” an exhibition of work by Mariko Mori at Japan Society, has themes of Buddhism, physics and ancient cultures.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a full decade since Mariko Mori’s last New York museum show, and viewers who remember that exhibition might not even recognize the artist in “Rebirth: Recent Work by Mariko Mori,” at Japan Society. The futuristic fashion plate of Ms. Mori’s earlier photographs and videos — the artist herself, in Manga-inspired get-ups — seems to have vanished, and so has her contemporary Japanese landscape of malls, airports and business districts.

headline: Holding Court in All Their Petaled Glory
abstract: Chrysanthemums are given royal treatment in “Kiku: The Art of the Japanese Garden” at the New York Botanical Garden.
lead_paragraph: THE stately chrysanthemum, one of nature’s noblest flowers, harbors a dark secret. It enjoys pain.

headline: Whoa, Are Snow White and Mulan Really Working the Street?
abstract: In “Escape From Tomorrow,” a family vacation at a Disney park takes on a macabre cast after the husband and father receives bad news.
lead_paragraph: Jim (Roy Abramsohn) is a doughy dad on a Disney vacation with a pair of cute towheaded kids and a nagging wife (Elena Schuber). Shortly after Jim receives an unwelcome call from his boss — firing him without warning or explanation — things turn weird. The theme park that promises magic for the masses takes on a decidedly sinister cast. Is it all in Jim’s head, or does evil stalk the happiest place on earth?

lead_paragraph: A judge on Thursday cleared the way for same-sex marriages to start in New Jersey in two weeks, dismissing the state’s request to prevent the weddings until after an appeal of the court decision allowing them is completed.

abstract: Photos from Turkey, Northern Ireland, Thailand and Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Northern Ireland, Thailand and Saudi Arabia.

headline: Toughing It Out, Against All Odds
abstract: “The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete” follows two boys through one tough Brooklyn summer.
lead_paragraph: There are times in “The Inevitable Defeat of Mister & Pete” when the emotions it stirs up are so naked and unembarrassed that it feels as if you’ve entered a cinematic time machine back to the silent era, to when child actors like Jackie Coogan gutted you with sentiment. Coogan played the title character in Charles Chaplin’s glorious 1921 weepie “The Kid,” the urchin with the tight grip around the Tramp’s neck and lock on the audience’s affections. The heartbreakers in “Mister & Pete,” a melodrama about two children slipping through the cracks, shed fewer tears than the Kid did — poverty can toughen even the most tender bodies — but their hold on you is as fierce.

headline: Sally Field, Ken Burns and Philip Roth Honored by Scholarly Society
abstract: Ms. Field, Mr. Roth and Mr. Burns will be inducted into the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, along with Herbie Hancock, Martin Amis, Roz Chast and Natasha Trethewey.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:02 a.m. Friday | Last year, Sally Field won an Oscar nomination for her portrayal of Mary Todd Lincoln. This weekend, she’ll be making a turn as another first lady, Abigail Adams.

headline: T FALL DESIGN
abstract: Two generations of one of England’s most celebrated families — Emma, Issy and Stella Tennant — make beautiful, unusual and deeply personal art that draws from the natural world.
lead_paragraph: Two generations of one of England’s most celebrated families — Emma, Issy and Stella Tennant — make beautiful, unusual and deeply personal art that draws from the natural world.

headline: Lamentation for a Home of Punk Rock
abstract: “CBGB” is an elegy to that defunct nightclub in the East Village, and its owner and presiding spirit, Hillel Kristal.
lead_paragraph: Because of the cruel accidents of age and geography, I never set foot in CBGB during its 1970s punk heyday. So I can’t look at “CBGB” — Randall Miller’s sweet and nostalgic elegy to that defunct club and its owner and presiding spirit, Hillel Kristal, known to all, whether they actually knew him or not, as Hilly — and say, with the authority of experience, “It wasn’t like that.” I will leave it to others to point out the film’s lapses of chronology, taste and historical detail. But on the other hand, I would swear on a stack of Dead Boys T-shirts and a first pressing of Richard Hell and the Voidoids’ “Blank Generation” that it could not possibly have been like that: so silly, so trivial, so boring.

headline: Mixing and Matching Many Tastes of Japan
abstract: The TriBeCa bar Shigure offers 24 shochus and 8 shochu cocktails, as well as Japanese beers, sakes and food.
lead_paragraph: Takahiro Okada, a manager of the TriBeCa bar Shigure, said there were two ways customers could enjoy the distilled spirit shochu, a specialty of the house.

lead_paragraph: What can machine learning and statistics do for fantasy football? It turns out, quite a bit.

headline: Why Alice Munro Is Canada’s First Nobel Prize Winner for Literature (With an Asterisk)
abstract: If there were a Canadian Mount Rushmore, it wouldn’t memorialize four politicians. They would be Munro, Atwood, Ondaatje and . . .
lead_paragraph: Alice Munro, the Canadian writer who’s widely acknowledged as the greatest living short-story writer (and, according to Jonathan Franzen, the best living North American fiction writer, period), was named the winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature this morning.

headline: For Finger Lakes Rieslings, Smashed Potatoes Inspired by Costata
abstract: These wines lay out the welcome mat for a brunch featuring crisp, deeply burnished potatoes.
lead_paragraph: On my first visit to Costata, Michael White’s SoHo steakhouse, I was bowled over by the crisp, deeply burnished smashed potatoes. I got the recipe, and then I waited for a wine inspiration. Of course, with a robust bottle of red and a slab of grilled meat, I’d have been done with it. But I wanted to give the potatoes marquee billing.

headline: A Life Ravels Out, and a Brooding Family Sets Forth
abstract: James Franco directs and stars in the first film adaptation of Faulkner’s “As I Lay Dying,” a book that has long been considered unfilmable.
lead_paragraph: William Faulkner’s novel “As I Lay Dying,” published in 1930, is about a family hauling the dead body of one of its members on a journey of several days over rough terrain in a mule-drawn cart. That might be one definition of a fool’s errand, the primary fool being Anse Bundren, a stubborn, suspicious and toothless Mississippi farmer who insists on burying his wife, Addie, in her hometown. Another definition might be the attempt to turn Faulkner’s splintered, lyrical book into a movie. In this case the fool would be James Franco, who directed and stars in the first film adaptation of a book that has long been considered unfilmable.

headline: Janet Joy
abstract: A member of my tribe.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been remiss in not writing anything about Janet Yellen’s nomination to head the Fed; partly that was because I wasn’t sure exactly what to say, and how to explain why I and so many other economists are really happy with her selection.

headline: In New Case, Former Leader of Pakistan Is Arrested
abstract: A court ordered Pervez Musharraf detained after approving an application from a cleric who wanted Mr. Musharraf tried for his role in the deadly siege of the Red Mosque in Islamabad in 2007.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Pakistani police arrested Pervez Musharraf, the nation’s former military ruler, on Thursday, opening a new criminal prosecution against him that frustrated plans by his supporters to fly him out of Pakistan.

headline: Peering Past New York’s Locked Doors
abstract: Several October events offer a chance to feast on a cornucopia of architecture and design in New York, with access to places that are usually off limits.
lead_paragraph: THE New York fall cultural calendar is a busy one. The fashion world has September all sewn up, and between auctions and openings, the art world has November all nailed down. The holidays hold December hostage. That leaves October.

headline: Jilted, and Communing With a Serial-Killing Cannibal
abstract: Paul Cameron Hardy’s “feeling” examines a woman in free fall after a relationship who strikes up a conversation with Jeffrey Dahmer.
lead_paragraph: There are probably a good number of you out there who would never see a play that trades on the portrayal of a creepily charming Jeffrey Dahmer character. Who can say if this number is higher or lower than the number of you who would be persuaded to attend for precisely that same reason?

headline: Oh, Hey, Romeo, What’s Up?
abstract: Adapted by Julian Fellowes of “Downton Abbey” fame, “Romeo & Juliet,” starring Hailee Steinfeld, won’t sound all that familiar to students of Shakespeare’s text.
lead_paragraph: Passions and nostrils flare in the latest screen version of “Romeo & Juliet,” a sufficiently entertaining, adamantly old-fashioned adaptation that follows the play’s general outline without ever rising to the passionate intensity of its star-cross’d crazy kids. Adapted by Julian Fellowes, who’s taken liberties with the original text, and dutifully directed by Carlo Carlei, it deploys the familiar emotional beats — if not all the lines — along with the usual mixture of comedy, romance and tragedy. Shot in the actual Verona and at other Italian attractions, it looks pretty, feels light and moves fast, with a 118-minute running time that’s in keeping with the original’s “two hours’ traffic of our stage.”

headline: Taking Off to Find Yourself? Be Sure a Self Is There
abstract: “Bike America” follows a 20-something woman who joins a group on a cross-country cycling trip.
lead_paragraph: Those of us who have rolled our eyes at the narcissistic entitlement of millennials  — come on, you know you’ve done it — are gently scolded in Mike Lew’s bumpy road comedy, “Bike America,” for failing to recognize the genuine desperation beneath their whiny self-absorption.

headline: Strong Start for ‘American Horror Story’
abstract: The season premiere Wednesday night attracted more than 5.5 million viewers.
lead_paragraph: Cable television demonstrated again Wednesday night that it can produce powerhouse drama that can match or exceed anything on network television – the latest example being the new season of the FX drama “American Horror Story.”

headline: All He’s Got to Do Is Save the World
abstract: In the violence-filled “Machete Kills,” Danny Trejo is called upon to ward off catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: Until your eyes glaze over after about a half-hour, “Machete Kills” might put a twisted smirk of guilty amusement on your face. The high point of those opening minutes is a fantastically gaudy fake trailer for a sequel, “Machete Kills Again ... In Space,” which embodies the director Robert Rodriguez’s nostalgia for trashy B-movie exploitation flicks.

headline: Reliving the Show That ‘Dropped Like a Bomb’
abstract: “The Armory Show at 100: Modern Art and Revolution” looks at the impact that an exhibition in 1913 had on artists and critics.
lead_paragraph: The International Exhibition of Modern Art, otherwise known as the Armory Show, woke American art from its provincial slumbers 100 years ago. Was it a good thing or a bad thing, and is there any reason to care about it now? With more than 100 works from the original exhibition and a big, richly illuminating catalog, “The Armory Show at 100: Modern Art and Revolution” at the New-York Historical Society offers an excellent opportunity to ponder such questions.

headline: A Room Is Tense as African Rhythms Meet Jazz
abstract: Ginger Baker, in a rare New York appearance with his jazz quartet, raised tensions and spirits at the Iridium.
lead_paragraph: Behind the drums at Iridium on Wednesday night, Ginger Baker leaned back, his chin drawn in toward his Adam’s apple, holding his sticks toward the bottom, his time as far back as his posture, head fixed within a narrow swiveling perimeter, wide eyes on amber alert.

lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — The 2013 Carnegie International is a welcome shock to the system of one of the art world’s more entrenched rituals. This lean, seemingly modest, thought-out exhibition takes the big global survey of contemporary art off steroids.

headline: BBC and Discovery Cut Back on Collaborations
abstract: The BBC and the Discovery Channel are essentially dissolving a relationship that dates to the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: The BBC and the Discovery Channel are essentially dissolving a relationship that dates to the 1990s and delivered natural history programs like “Blue Planet,” “Planet Earth” and “Life” to American viewers. Some of the BBC’s wildlife documentaries and films will be co-produced by its cable channel BBC America instead of Discovery in the future, the British broadcaster said Wednesday. Discovery will continue to work with the BBC on some programs, but will also strike deals with other producers for science and natural history programs. The two collaborators have become more like competitors over the years. Discovery is increasingly an international brand, and it wants to have worldwide rights to its programming; meanwhile, the BBC wants to bolster its own branded channel in America. The two companies said they had mutually agreed to go their separate ways.

headline: Starting a Vapor Trail
abstract: Addressing e-cigarette users, smelly teenage athletes, condolence notes and a preference for the outdoors.
lead_paragraph: I was recently at a dinner party at a friend’s house. In the middle of the meal, a young woman pulled out an electronic cigarette, took two puffs, then put it away. A few guests clearly wondered about the white smoke she exhaled. Shouldn’t people excuse themselves to indulge their addictions in private? This bothered me because she was among friends and shouldn’t have needed the security mechanism of a cigarette. What do you make of this?

lead_paragraph: How much does the cash-drunk New York art industry care about racism, neocolonialism, wanton consumption, persistent sexism, environmental spoilage or any other global realities? Next to not at all. How much does the same industry care about big, superbly made objects that pleasure the eye? Hugely.

abstract: The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality is appealing a lawsuit because of the judge’s statement that the state’s natural resources include the air and atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality is appealing a lawsuit that it has already won — one that was filed by children. Environmental advocates say the appeal shows that the state will go to any lengths to fight the suggestion that it address climate change.

headline: In the Finger Lakes, Devotion to Riesling Shows
abstract: What’s most exciting about the Finger Lakes is knowing that the region is just beginning to discover a sense of its own potential.
lead_paragraph: I’ve consumed rieslings from all over the United States. Smith-Madrone, Trefethen and Stony Hill make fine rieslings in Napa Valley, but these are legacy vines.

headline: Democracy Is Instrumental to a Maestro-Free Ensemble
abstract: The pianist Brad Mehldau performed his “Variations on a Melancholy Theme” with the Orpheus musicians at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: What the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra, which opened its 41st season on Wednesday at Carnegie Hall, has always done best is to reanimate war horses. The concentration, intensity and hair-trigger responsiveness it takes for 35 or 40 musicians to play without a conductor can translate into excitement and volatility, as it did here in Beethoven’s “Eroica” Symphony.

headline: The Melancholy Effects of Growing Older in Gay Culture
abstract: Miguel Gutierrez’s “myendlesslove,” at the Abrons Arts Center, reflects on sex, desire and aging.
lead_paragraph: The current reconstruction of Miguel Gutierrez’s “myendlesslove,” which opened on Wednesday at the Abrons Arts Center at Henry Street Settlement, dates to 2006, when the original piece received its first and last performance. But its roots are actually older. In 2005, Mr. Gutierrez choreographed “Retrospective Exhibitionist,” a piercing solo that explored the plight of a performer with fearlessness, innocence and humor. It was raw in a way that only New Yorkers can pull off; his tools, other than his own body, included a television and a boom box.

headline: A Photographer With Problems
abstract: The protagonist of “Forgetting the Girl” has trouble with women and with the recesses of his mind.
lead_paragraph: There’s a moment when the thriller “Forgetting the Girl” leaves behind the twitches of its characters’ psychological troubles and moves headlong into the full-bodied shivers. Directed with unerring atmospherics by Nate Taylor, this dark tale — in which Jungian shadows eventually get their close-ups — reminds us of a simple truth: Some people are flat messed up.

headline: Libidinous Specters in the House
abstract: “Ghost Team One” is a potty-mouthed variation on the “Paranormal Activity” subgenre.
lead_paragraph: The “Paranormal Activity” concept spawns yet another comic variation (after “A Haunted House” and “Scary Movie V”) with “Ghost Team One,” a rude and somewhat crude effort in which typewriter-font intertitles, a mobile camera and staccato surveillance video intersect with a stream of slacker potty talk. A drunken Sergio (Carlos Santos) is lurching around a boisterous house party he’s hosting with his sex-obsessed roommate Brad (J. R. Villarreal) when he stumbles upon what seem to be spectral lovers canoodling in a closet. Their house, it turns out, might be haunted by a long-dead brothel madam. An investigation kicks into high gear after Brad inadvertently copulates with a ghostly visitor.

headline: Flights of Fancy
abstract: After a terrorist bomb explodes in an art museum, the young narrator of Donna Tartt’s new novel, “The Goldfinch,” becomes the protector of a 17th-century painting.
lead_paragraph: Let us consider the problems of the long novel, in which the heft is apt to come in for almost as much critical examination as the content. There is, for instance, Jack Beatty’s famous critique of James A. Michener’s “Chesapeake” (865 pages): “My best advice is don’t read it; my second best is don’t drop it on your foot.” Presumably, Beatty read it — or at least skimmed it — before offering these helpful hints, but you get the idea. In this hurry-scurry age, big books are viewed with suspicion, and sometimes disdain.

headline: Madame Restell’s Other Profession
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: New York’s second apartment building may well have been the 1876 Osborne, commissioned by an woman in the abortion trade.
lead_paragraph: In July, the Streetscapes column looked at the claim that the 1870 Stuyvesant was the first New York apartment house, and decided in the affirmative. But no one is on solid ground in declaring a first unless he can also propose a second, and it turns out that runner-up is a lot harder to find than the winner. Whereas the Stuyvesant was built by an old New York family, the likeliest No. 2 is the work of a woman shunned by society.

headline: Rewarding Stellar Credit
abstract: Borrowers with superior credit scores see a slight easing in mortgage terms.
lead_paragraph: Lending terms are easing up for borrowers who have superior credit. But mortgages are no easier to come by for applicants with unexceptional FICO scores.

headline: Spare Times for Oct. 11-17
abstract: A listing of discussions, author readings, recreational activities and other cultural events.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Next Level: East Side Access Photographs by Hiroyuki Suzuki’ (through Oct. 27) Sometimes you have to dig deep to discover something beautiful. For the Japanese photographer Hiroyuki Suzuki — who has drawn inspiration from the scope and energy of major construction projects in Tokyo, Shanghai and Dubai — that meant descending 18 stories below Grand Central Terminal to capture images of the work now under way for the nearly $8.3 billion East Side Access Project, which will connect Long Island Rail Road trains in Queens to the Terminal in Manhattan. He started photographing in 2011, the year work began; it is expected to be completed in 2019.

headline: Canadian Carrier Backtracks on BlackBerry Snub
abstract: Rogers said the BlackBerry Z30 would be available for order online and through a service that ships orders to its stores and directly to business and government customers.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — BlackBerry has received a bit of good news. Rogers Communications, Canada’s largest wireless carrier, has backtracked on its earlier decision not to sell BlackBerry’s new flagship smartphone.

headline: Afterlife? What Afterlife?
abstract: In “I Will Follow You Into the Dark,” Mischa Barton is a religious skeptic whose boyfriend mysteriously disappears.
lead_paragraph: Good for nothing besides the employment of insipid young actresses, films like “I Will Follow You Into the Dark” believe that romance is best dealt with in hurried montage and that a crisis of faith is an acceptable substitution for a personality.

headline: Insufficiently Conservative? Take That!
abstract: John Cornyn, the senior United States senator from Texas, is not conservative enough for some of his fellow Republicans’ tastes. And primary voting is just four months away.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: For Girls, Their Own Way to Reach the Heavens
abstract: The Lower Eastside Girls Club now has a $20 million clubhouse with classrooms, a recording studio, even a planetarium.
lead_paragraph: Lyn Pentecost settled into a plush, comfortable seat in a planetarium in Manhattan. No, not that planetarium. This one is for only girls.

headline: Happenings | Mexican Summer, the Little Indie Label That Could, Throws an Anniversary Bash
abstract: The imprint behind artists like Best Coast, Ariel Pink and Washed Out has shown that music publishing can still thrive in this day and age. To celebrate five years of success, the label is throwing an awesome party.
lead_paragraph: For certain indie rock aficionados, a release put out by the Greenpoint, Brooklyn, record label Mexican Summer carries as much weight as a 10.0 review on the review site Pitchfork. Founded in 2008 by Andrés Santo Domingo, Keith Abrahamsson and Tom Clapp as the more tuneful offshoot of their rock-oriented imprint Kemado Records, Mexican Summer has since become a bastion for experimental pop, not to mention a model for successful music publishing in the 21st century. The label, which took its name from a track by the folk singer Marissa Nadler, one of its artists, has enjoyed one success after another. The first LP by the scrappy guitar-pop band Best Coast moved more than 100,000 copies (and subsequently landed in a Windows ad), a sizable number even for a major these days. The garage rocker Kurt Vile, the lo-fi experimental weirdo Ariel Pink and the chillwave act Washed Out have also experienced success with Mexican Summer. A considerable percentage of the label’s sales are on vinyl, according to Abrahamsson.

headline: This Week's Movies: Oct. 11, 2013
abstract: The New York Times movie critics on “Captain Phillips,” “CBGB,” and “Romeo & Juliet.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times movie critics on “Captain Phillips,” “CBGB,” and “Romeo & Juliet.”

headline: Boxer’s Tale, Fashioned by a Fighter
abstract: As he fights cancer, Fred Ho prepares a new musical work about the Muhammad Ali.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the experimental composer Fred Ho answered the door of his apartment on a quiet, leafy street in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn recently, he seemed much as he always has: beefy and muscular, with a warm smile that, over the next hour, would return to accompany some robustly expressed views about music and politics. If he had not mentioned that he felt too weak to sit, and preferred to speak while lying on his living room sofa, you probably would not guess that he is seriously ill — that, in fact, he is in the final stage of colorectal cancer, which he has been fighting since 2006.

headline: Where Séances Go Badly
abstract: “Cassadaga,” set in a Florida town that is a hub for psychics, centers on a deaf artist looking for solace after her sister’s death.
lead_paragraph: Cassadaga, Fla., has been called “the Psychic Capital of the World.” With its dilapidated Queen Anne mansions and its oak trees dripping with Spanish moss, this ghostly hub seems like the perfect setting for a horror story about an obsessed spirit harassing a lonely artist.

headline: Building for the Sake of Deconstruction
abstract: The Forsythe Company performed “Sider,” an elliptical dance work relying partly on sheets of cardboard, on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Do you like to solve puzzles? William Forsythe’s “Sider,” which had its United States premiere on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, offers puzzles upon puzzles, and analogies, too. Yet where most puzzles tantalize with intriguing pieces of a larger picture that make you want to put together, the surface of “Sider” is as enticing as a sheet of cardboard.

headline: You Only Live Forever
abstract: In William Boyd’s continuation of Ian Fleming’s spy series, 007 is dispatched to a war-torn African country.
lead_paragraph: Discussing one of his country’s most famous exports during a visit to the Soviet Union in the 1980s, John le Carré described James Bond as “a sort of licensed criminal who, in the name of false patriotism, approves of nasty crimes.” One has the sense, he told Radio Times in 2010, that Bond “would have gone through the same antics for any country really, if the girls had been so pretty and the martinis so dry.” It’s an accusation that has existed in various forms ever since the publication of “Casino Royale” in 1953. Bond’s creator also suffered doubts, as any reader of Andrew Lycett’s expansive 1995 biography, “Ian Fleming” (recently republished by St. Martin’s Press), will know. While working on “Moonraker,” the third of his 14 Bond books, Fleming complained that Bond’s future was “nothing but a vista of fantastic adventures on more or less the same pattern, but losing freshness with each volume.”

headline: On the Market in Aspen, Colo.
abstract: Homes in ski country offering from one to five bedrooms and priced from $1,150,000 to $15,500,000.
lead_paragraph: Homes in ski country offering from one to five bedrooms and priced from $1,150,000 to $15,500,000.

headline: She’s Where the Work Is
abstract: Joanna Gleason made her cabaret debut at 54 Below on Wednesday with songs and stories of her career.
lead_paragraph: As Irving Berlin names alternative occupations to the theater in “There’s No Business Like Show Business,” a butcher and a baker lead the list. To those you might add the Baker’s Wife, from the Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical “Into the Woods.” Joanna Gleason portrayed that character so movingly that I fell in love with her when I first saw the show in 1987.

headline: Russia: Shake-Up at Space Agency
abstract: Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev fired the general director of Russia’s space agency on Thursday as part of a shake-up that had been expected after embarrassing rocket failures.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Dmitri A. Medvedev fired the general director of Russia’s beleaguered space agency on Thursday as part of a shake-up that had been expected after a series of embarrassing rocket failures. The dismissed official, Vladimir A. Popovkin, was appointed to lead the agency, Roscosmos, in 2011 after a failed rocket launching destroyed three satellites needed for a Russian global navigation system. Mr. Medvedev said that Oleg Ostapenko, a deputy defense minister with long experience in space operations, would be the agency’s new chief. A leadership change at Roscosmos was widely expected after the failed launching of an unmanned Proton-M rocket in July. It was the fourth failed Proton launching in three years.

headline: The Joys of Being Wendish, Festival and All
abstract: In the 19th century, Wendish immigrants from eastern Germany arrived in Texas. Today their descendants keep their culture alive with an annual festival in Serbin.
lead_paragraph: SERBIN — In a light-filled 19th-century Lutheran church with red stenciling above the blue and white balcony, worshipers prayed and sang in German. It was the closest the visitors to this Central Texas community could come to honoring their heritage now that almost no one in Texas knows Wendish, the Slavic language their ancestors spoke in Germany.

headline: A Piece of Italy for Everyone
abstract: The chef at Fortina, a new restaurant in Armonk, spent boyhood summers on an island near Naples, and his cooking is a sort of exuberant take on tradition.
lead_paragraph: Leaving Fortina on a Friday night this autumn, a tiny patron in a pink tutu clasped hands with her parents and happily chirped her newfound word: “Ciao! Ciao! Ciao!” Passing them on the way in, a young woman in a black sequined shift and very high heels texted as she teetered toward the door. I have never in my dining experience witnessed such a seamless transition from kiddie hour to singles scene.

headline: Prison Oversight Faulted in Ariel Castro’s Death
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Kidnapping', 'Falsification of Data', 'Asphyxiation, Choking, and Suffocation', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Guards did not make the required checks on Ariel Castro, the Cleveland man convicted of holding three women captive for a decade, on the day he hanged himself in his cell, a state report said.
lead_paragraph: Prison guards in Ohio falsified records and failed to properly complete their rounds on the day Ariel Castro, the man convicted of holding three women captive in his Cleveland home for a decade, hanged himself in his cell last month, according to a state report released Thursday. The report suggested that Mr. Castro may have asphyxiated himself during a sexual act.

headline: Boeing 787, Grounded in Norway, Nearly Fixed
abstract: The jet, owned by Norwegian Air Shuttle, has been grounded for two weeks because of software malfunctions involving the brake warning lights and a faulty hydraulic pump.
lead_paragraph: Boeing is almost finished repairing several balky systems on a new 787 Dreamliner operated by Norwegian Air Shuttle, the latest airline to complain about annoying malfunctions, the airline’s chief executive said Thursday.

headline: Pentagon’s Top Weapons Expert to Retire
abstract: Ashton B. Carter, the Pentagon’s top expert on budgets and weapons, announced Thursday that he was retiring as deputy defense secretary.
lead_paragraph: Ashton B. Carter, who built upon academic specialties in medieval history and theoretical physics to become the Pentagon’s top expert on budgets and weapons, announced Thursday that he was retiring as deputy defense secretary. Mr. Carter, 59, was central to an emergency effort under former Secretary Robert M. Gates to rush heavily armored transport vehicles to Iraq. The initiative was hailed by troops as a lifesaving defense against roadside bombs. He was promoted to deputy secretary in 2011 and oversaw the complex task of devising strategy in a time of declining budgets, and he was said to have been under consideration when Mr. Obama picked Chuck Hagel to follow Leon E. Panetta as secretary.

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: He Died as He Loved to Live, on the Edge
abstract: The documentary “McConkey” shows how the extreme skier and BASE jumper Shane McConkey pursued thrills until the end.
lead_paragraph: Shane McConkey took huge risks in pursuit of his dreams, pulling off feats that most people can hardly fathom (and some dismiss as foolish): big-mountain skiing, base jumping from glaciers, skiing off cliffs à la the chase scene in “The Spy Who Loved Me.” In 2009, he died the way he lived — doing what he loved — and a new documentary, “McConkey,” serves as a rousing testament to that freewheeling spirit.

headline: Pentagon Drops Backup Helmet for F-35 Pilots
abstract: When a more sophisticated helmet ran into problems, a backup was ordered. But the higher-tech model is improving.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon said on Thursday that it had decided to stop working on a conventional backup helmet for pilots of the new F-35 fighter jet and stick with a troubled, but improving, higher-tech model.

headline: A Senator Raises Privacy Questions About Cross-Device Tracking
abstract: In response to a Times article, Senator Edward J. Markey asked the Federal Trade Commission to investigate mobile ad companies that track consumers across devices to show them ads based on their Web browsing and mobile habits.
lead_paragraph: A lawmaker has asked the Federal Trade Commission to investigate online ad companies that track consumers across devices, like showing them ads on their phones based on Web sites they visit on a computer.

headline: From Rock Album to Stage Musical
abstract: The documentary “Broadway Idiot” observes the metamorphosis of “American Idiot” from record to stage show, and of Billie Joe Armstrong from rock star to stage actor.
lead_paragraph: “Broadway Idiot,” a documentary by Doug Hamilton about the making of the Broadway show “American Idiot,” never feels as if it were delving too deeply into the creative process, which turned a best-selling Green Day album into a stage musical. But as a chronicle of how one rock star slowly fell victim to the Broadway bug, it’s kind of amusing.

headline: A Glass, Maybe a Bottle, and a Few Plates
abstract: Francesca’s Wine Bar and Bistro draws capacity crowds a year after its opening.
lead_paragraph: Francesca’s Wine Bar and Bistro, in Collinsville, is more than just an intimate place in which to enjoy a glass of merlot or pinot noir. It is also the nearest thing this former mill town has to a fine-dining establishment.

headline: Two Are Charged in Plan to Send Goods to Taliban
abstract: The men, Humayoun Ghoulan Nabi, 27, of Queens, and Ismael Alsarabbi, 32, of Brooklyn, were taken into custody Monday after an investigation that began in 2011.
lead_paragraph: Two New York City men have been arrested on charges that they sought to supply the Taliban and other terrorist fighters with warm clothes and equipment for use in wintertime battle with United States forces in Afghanistan, the authorities said on Thursday.

headline: Hitting Pay Dirt
abstract: The documentary “Symphony of the Soil” celebrates the nurturing powers of the ground beneath our feet.
lead_paragraph: Unlike many recent documentaries about our careless stewardship of the planet, Deborah Koons Garcia’s “Symphony of the Soil” doesn’t feel like a rap on the knuckles. Unfolding with gentle joy and an unexpected beauty, this ode to the miracle of the Earth’s topmost layer gives us a newfound respect for the ground beneath our feet.

headline: Health Act Embraced in California
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid']
abstract: California is building the country’s largest state-run health insurance exchange and has already expanded Medicaid coverage for the poor.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — There are radio and television commercials galore, along with Twitter and Facebook posts and scores of highway billboards. There are armies of outreach workers who speak Spanish, Tagalog, Cambodian, Mandarin and Cantonese, all flocking to county fairs, farmers markets, street festivals and back-to-school nights across the state. There are even dinner parties in Latino neighborhoods designed to reach one family at a time.

headline: A Bizarre Scavenger Hunt in San Francisco
abstract: “The Institute” wavers between documentary and exploratory simulation in exploring an alternate-reality game.
lead_paragraph: Spencer McCall’s puzzling documentary “The Institute” wades into the mysteries of an experiment in alternate-reality gaming that took place a few years ago in San Francisco. Curious gamers loved the scavenger hunt/ sub-Pynchon intrigues, engineered by benevolent creators representing a supposed organization; we learn about it, a little, which is not quite the same as playing along.

headline: In Florida, Opposition by the State and Snags in Signing Up on the Web
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Lawmakers refused to create a state insurance exchange, and the federal government’s Web site is so error-prone that enrolling is a daunting task.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Be it gold, silver or bronze level, there are two ironclad requirements for buying health insurance in Florida on the federal online exchange: patience and persistence.

headline: Court the Soul, Pummel the Sexuality
abstract: “God Loves Uganda” explores the role of the American evangelical movement in promoting a Ugandan proposal to imprison or even execute homosexuals.
lead_paragraph: A searing look at the role of American evangelical missionaries in the persecution of gay Africans, Roger Ross Williams’s “God Loves Uganda” approaches this intersection of faith and politics with some fairness and a good deal of outrage.

headline: Suit Filed Against Warner Bros. in Screenplay Theft
abstract: A lawsuit accuses Warner Brothers of stealing the screenplay of its 2012 movie “Trouble With the Curve” and of manufacturing evidence in their defense.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Warner Brothers responded harshly on Thursday to a legal complaint over the authorship of its Clint Eastwood baseball movie, “Trouble With the Curve.” But its opponents did not back down.

headline: VW Plant Opens Door to Union and Dispute
abstract: Every VW plant in the world has a works council that gives labor a voice at the management table. But selling the idea at its plant in Tennessee has been tough.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The face-off between Volkswagen and the United Automobile Workers over organizing the company’s new plant in Tennessee is rapidly becoming a global clash of cultures.

headline: Serenity, and a Few Sly Smiles, for the U.S.
abstract: The squad appeared to be in disarray in March but has since won several qualifiers and clinched a berth in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — At its core, soccer is a game of rhythm and flow. But the international version is fundamentally stunted.

lead_paragraph: Investors embraced signs of a political compromise that could avert a default on government debt, sending stocks surging on Thursday.

headline: Wheelchair Racer Could Be First to Win 3 Major Marathons in a Season
abstract: Tatyana McFadden is training for the Chicago Marathon, where she will try to become the first person — able-bodied or disabled — to win three major marathons in one year.
lead_paragraph: CHAMPAIGN, Ill. — On a recent afternoon, Tatyana McFadden wheeled her racing chair onto a quiet street to begin a training session. She rolled through the University of Illinois campus here, past the football stadium, by a cemetery and then a residential street lined with bungalows. Cornfields were in the distance. Her legs, which she has never used to walk, were tucked beneath her torso.

headline: Blue Cross Plans Jump to an Early Lead

headline: Outside National Parks, Feeling Squeezed by the Shutdown
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The shutdown’s economic toll is particularly evident in gateway communities to the recreation areas, where local businesses live or die on tourist traffic.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGDALE, Utah — In the 10 days since Zion National Park closed its gates, the community on its doorstep has become a shutdown ghost town. Hotel rooms are dark, and housecleaners are working half-shifts. Herds of campers and sightseers have streamed away along the only highway out of town, and canceled reservations from New Zealand, California and Germany are piling up every day.

headline: Gay Rights Protests Follow Gergiev to Carnegie Hall
abstract: Shortly after Mr. Gergiev walked onto the stage at Carnegie Hall, several members of Queer Nation began protests.
lead_paragraph: The furor in the West over Russia’s new law placing restrictions on the discussion of homosexuality continues to dog the conductor Valery Gergiev, who is one of Russia’s most important cultural exports these days. Mr. Gergiev, a prominent supporter of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, who signed the law, drew protests Thursday night at Carnegie Hall, just as he did last month at the opening night of the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Lapsed, but Listening
abstract: The church Pope Francis envisions would be a “home for all,” not “a nest protecting our mediocrity” — that’s strong stuff, and long overdue.
lead_paragraph: Just days before he got the diagnosis of the cancer that would kill him in 2011, Christopher Hitchens was flinging word bolts at pilgrims while promoting his book “God Is Not Great.” After his presentation, I asked him why, given that so few Americans self-identify as atheists, his book had found such a large audience.

headline: Fed Up With Fund-Raising for My Kids’ School
abstract: The holes parents are being asked to fill for public schools keep getting deeper. Our city must take some responsibility for it.
lead_paragraph: AMID the flurry of school notices coming home in my kids’ backpacks, the PTA donation envelope carries a nostalgic pang. I remember thinking, only four years ago as my first child entered school, that a modest contribution to the PTA was my only cash obligation to New York City’s public schools — beyond being a dutiful taxpayer, of course.

headline: Two Brazilian Brothers to Pay Nearly $5 Million in Insider Trading Case
abstract: The S.E.C. says that Rodrigo and Michel Terpins of Brazil acted on inside information about the H.J. Heinz takeover to turn $90,000 into $1.8 million.
lead_paragraph: The bullish bet on H. J. Heinz flashed all the telltale signs of insider trading.

headline: Dealing With Default
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'National Debt (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: There are no good choices if we hit that debt ceiling. Which bad choice would do the least harm?
lead_paragraph: So Republicans may have decided to raise the debt ceiling without conditions attached — the details still aren’t clear. Maybe that’s the end of that particular extortion tactic, but maybe not, because, at best, we’re only looking at a very short-term extension. The threat of hitting the ceiling remains, especially if the politics of the shutdown continue to go against the G.O.P.

headline: Libya’s Security Crisis
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials', 'Kidnapping']
abstract: The United States and Europe have a role to play in helping to build an army and a government in Libya.
lead_paragraph: The American commando operation that snatched a suspected leader of Al Qaeda from his neighborhood in Tripoli, while successful, does not offer a permanent strategy to the threat from extremists in Libya. That point was reinforced on Thursday when the country’s prime minister, Ali Zeidan, was briefly kidnapped by militia members in apparent retaliation for his consenting to the raid.

headline: An Inadequate Offer From the House
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'National Debt (US)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Editorials']
abstract: It is not enough to delay a financial default. Republicans must also reopen the government before negotiations can begin.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John Boehner on Thursday said he was willing to delay briefly a disastrous default of the country’s financial obligations but was not willing to reopen the government. “I would hope that the president would look at this as an opportunity and a good-faith effort on our part to move halfway — halfway to what he’s demanded,” he said.

headline: Gambling on Loaded Language
abstract: A New York State judge should not allow lawmakers to skew the wording on a ballot in a way that tips the scales in favor of a pro-gambling outcome.
lead_paragraph: New York voters will decide in November whether to allow seven new casinos to open across the state. Gov. Andrew Cuomo and most members of the Legislature are strongly in favor of these casinos. But they do not have the right to skew the language on the ballot, as they have contrived to do, in a way that tips the scales in favor of a pro-gambling outcome.

headline: A Nobel Prize for Alice Munro
abstract: Ms. Munro was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature for her masterly short stories, a body of work that has deepened and widened over her career.
lead_paragraph: Over a long career, Alice Munro’s work has deepened and widened, so that coming new to one of her stories, you find all the others in your mind, mapping in some vestigial way a Canadian geography that feels continuous, no matter how much the stories shift in time and place.

headline: Jerry Kill Makes a Difficult, but Prudent, Call
abstract: Minnesota Coach Jerry Kill, who had a seizure and missed last Saturday’s game at Michigan, has stepped away to focus on treating and managing his epilepsy.
lead_paragraph: Those who knew Jerry Kill best, who watched him go through seizures in packed stadiums and return to work as if nothing happened, dreaded the situation that unfolded Thursday. They dreaded the day that Kill, an epileptic who inspired thousands of fellow epileptics, would step away from coaching.

headline: In Africa, Seeking a License to Kill
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: African leaders must not be allowed to withdraw their countries from the International Criminal Court. It will only encourage greater government corruption.
lead_paragraph: CAPE TOWN — MEMBERS of the African Union will meet in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, today to discuss recent calls by some African leaders to withdraw from the International Criminal Court. These calls must be resisted. The continent has suffered the consequences of unaccountable governance for too long to disown the protections offered by the I.C.C.

headline: For CVS Regulars, Ads Tailored Just to Them
abstract: CVS heard complaints about coupons creating cash register receipts that spanned five or six feet and has gone online with its offers.
lead_paragraph: ONCE, the letters in the name of the CVS drugstore chain stood for Consumer Value Store. Now, they could also stand for Customized Virtual Shopping.

headline: Saudi Women Drive, Despite Ban, and Find Some Support on the Kingdom’s Roads
abstract: A brief flurry of civil disobedience on the roads of Saudi Arabia this week, by women who flouted the kingdom’s ban on female drivers, was intended to build support for a mass demonstration later this month.
lead_paragraph: Last Updated, Friday, 11:30 a.m. | A brief flurry of civil disobedience on the roads of Saudi Arabia this week, by women who flouted the conservative kingdom’s ban on female drivers and documented it on Twitter and YouTube, ended on Thursday in a predictable manner — with an image of officers pulling alongside one car, captioned simply, “Police stopped us.”

lead_paragraph: Patricia Dresch and her husband, George, lived in their home in Tottenville, Staten Island, for about 30 years, a wood-frame house where they raised two daughters.

headline: C.I.A. Warning on Snowden in ’09 Said to Slip Through the Cracks
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: When Edward J. Snowden worked as a C.I.A. technician in 2009, he was suspected of trying to break into classified files, but a report was never forwarded when he left to become an N.S.A. contractor, officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just as Edward J. Snowden was preparing to leave Geneva and a job as a C.I.A. technician in 2009, his supervisor wrote a derogatory report in his personnel file, noting a distinct change in the young man’s behavior and work habits, as well as a troubling suspicion.

headline: Kochs and Other Conservatives Split Over Strategy on Health Law
keywords: ['Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'National Debt (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The splintering is a sign of growing concerns, among even staunch conservatives like the billionaire brothers Charles and David Koch, that the strategy of taking on health care at any cost may have backfired.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Under attack for the government shutdown, some of the most vocal elements of the conservative wing of the Republican Party are publicly splintering, a sign of growing concerns among even hard-core conservatives that the defeat-health-care-at-any-cost strategy may have backfired.

headline: Undercover Police, Just About Everywhere
abstract: In response to the attacks on Sept. 11, New York City now has a sturdy legion of undercover officers who have taken up residence in many surprising regions of civic life.
lead_paragraph: It may not have occurred to people that New York City needed to deploy an undercover detective to spy on Occupy Sandy, a relief operation run by activists that delivered food and supplies to parts of the city ruined by the hurricane. headline: Inconvenient Uncertainties
abstract: The climate is getting hotter. We just can’t predict exactly how hot.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE headline in The New York Times yesterday was succinct. “By 2047, Coldest Years May Be Warmer Than Hottest in Past, Scientists Say.” Not, say, “around 2050” or “within our lifetime.” The specificity makes the crisis feel real, imminent and terrible. Call it a convenient truth. The story was about a new study published this week in the journal Nature that calculated that by 2047, the average temperature will be hotter across most parts of the planet than it had been at those locations in any year between 1860 and 2005.

headline: Coop and Papa, Manning Up in Good Times and Bad
abstract: “Cooper & Hemingway” examines the friendship between Gary Cooper and Ernest Hemingway, who shared a love of the outdoors but had strikingly different personalities.
lead_paragraph: Gary Cooper and Ernest Hemingway, two models of American virility, had similarities, not least as outdoorsmen: Cooper grew up on a farm in Montana, and Hemingway was a big-game hunter and deep-sea fisherman. But they were also a study in contrasts: Cooper worked with movie crews; Hemingway labored alone. Cooper was understated and conservative, Hemingway volatile and a liberal. The mix, as John Mulholland’s exhaustive documentary “Cooper & Hemingway: The True Gen” demonstrates, made for a friendship spanning decades.

headline: What’s on Friday

(ABC) UNBREAKABLE: ONE GIRL CHANGING THE WORLD On Oct. 9, 2012, Malala Yousafzai, a teenage spokeswoman for girls’ education in Pakistan, was shot in the head by Taliban attackers. Her story of courage and determination captured the public’s imagination and inspired a global movement, resulting in her nomination for the 2013 Nobel Peace Prize. If she wins on Friday, she will be the youngest recipient ever. In this special edition of “20/20,” Ms. Yousafzai, above, speaks with Diane Sawyer about her passion for learning amid threats, the moments leading up to the assassination attempt, her recovery and her new memoir, “I Am Malala.” Margaret Warner will also interview Ms. Yousafzai on “PBS NewsHour,” at 7 on Channels 13 and 49.

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Israeli man who was a colonel in the reserves was fatally bludgeoned in the Jordan Valley area of the West Bank on Friday, according to the Israeli military, and security forces detained five Palestinians in connection with the attack.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Those long-forgotten posts on social networks, from the pasta someone photographed to the rant about her dentist, are forgotten no more. Social networks want to make them easier to find, and in some cases, to show them in ads.

keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Nationalization of Industry', 'Foreign Investments']
abstract: The center-right government said that the pensions revamp is nothing more than an accounting change and does not amount to nationalization.
lead_paragraph: Ignoring warnings that it could deter foreign investment, the Polish government has announced a draft bill that would require private pension funds to transfer about 35.2 billion euros, or $47.6 billion, in government bonds to the state in February.

headline: Daily Report: Google to Sell Users’ Endorsements
abstract: Google announced an update to its terms of service that allows the company to include adult users’ names, photos and comments in ads shown across the Web, based on ratings, reviews and posts they have made on Google Plus and other Google services like YouTube.
lead_paragraph: Google, following in Facebook’s footsteps, wants to sell users’ endorsements to marketers to help them hawk their wares, Claire Cain Miller and Vindu Goel report.

headline: Royal Mail Shares Surge in Debut
abstract: A 38 percent increase reignites criticism that the government sold a majority of Britain’s main postal service too cheaply.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 12:39 p.m. |

headline: Toyota Recalls 10,000 Models for Windshield Wiper Problem
abstract: A range of 2013-14 Toyota models, including the Camry, Avalon and Corolla, are being recalled for a wiper switch problem that could short out the windshield wipers.
lead_paragraph: Toyota will recall about 10,000 of its newest and most popular models to fix a problem with the windshield wiper switch, the automaker said Thursday. The action covers 2013-14 Camry and Camry Hybrid models, the 2013 Avalon and Avalon Hybrid and the 2014 Corolla.

headline: Off the Charts: And the Last Shall Be First
abstract: Oct. 9 has twice been a turning point for stocks in this century. After the 2001 recession, the American market hit bottom on Oct. 9, 2002, and then peaked exactly five years later, on Oct. 9, 2007. American stocks underperformed most of the world during that five-year period, but have outperformed in the six years from 2007 to now. Within the United States, sectors that lagged in the earlier period have been strong more recently.

headline: Small Businesses in Mumbai Bear Brunt of High Inflation
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Fruit', 'Home Appliances', 'Indian Rupee (Currency)', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Small Business']
abstract: As India battles with slowing growth, rising inflation and a weakened rupee, small businesses across the country are among the worst affected.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI— Nayan Lapsia spent much of a humid Wednesday afternoon looking despairingly at the idle cash register at his store in Crawford Market, a colonial-era open-air market in the heart of Mumbai, India’s financial capital. Though customers have stopped by fleetingly to glance at goods, things were unusually quiet at his shop, Shah Bhavanji Kunvarji & Company, which is stacked with all manner of spices and dry fruit.

headline: Amber Teething Necklaces Pose Choking Hazard
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Asphyxiation, Choking, and Suffocation', 'Babies and Infants', 'Children and Childhood', 'Medicine and Health', 'Parenting']
abstract: Baltic amber necklaces have become popular as an alternative treatment to ease teething pain, but they can pose a suffocation hazard.
lead_paragraph: When model Gisele Bündchen posted a photo of herself and her young child on Instagram this summer, the snapshot, which showed her infant daughter wearing tiny earrings, ignited debate on blogs about the appropriate age for ear piercing. But a more serious concern, missed in many of the discussions, was the delicate necklace of amber beads looped around the baby’s neck.

headline: The Costs of Fantasy Politics
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: Why it makes no sense for Republicans to continue fighting on these lines.
lead_paragraph: As of this morning, there’s reason to hope that some time next week the government shutdown will end, the debt ceiling will be temporarily raised, and I’ll be able to write a follow-up to my column on Pope Francis, or something about what should be the political story of the moment — the don’t-call-it-trainwreck debut of Healthcare.gov — or even (who knows?) something more esoteric and random and fun. But for today, let me go one more round with Ben Domenech, who wrote yesterday in defense of a Republican strategy that would lift the debt ceiling while keeping the government shutdown going, and going, and going — a move that I likened on CNN to postponing a murder-suicide in order to just concentrate on slitting your own wrists, but which Domenech regards in a more favorable light. To my previous suggestion that the shutdown is ratifying the public’s pre-existing distrust of G.O.P. governance, he writes:

headline: The War On The Poor Is A War On You-Know-Who
abstract: Still race after all these years.
lead_paragraph: Lots of people have been referencing this Democracy Corps report on focus-group meetings with Republicans, and with good reason: Greenberg has basically provided a unified theory of the craziness that has enveloped American politics in the last few years.

headline: Don’t Feed the Trolls
abstract: I won’t, anyway.
lead_paragraph: Some readers have been asking when I’m going to reply to certain rants aimed my way. The answer is, never.

headline: Skills Practice | Concise Writing
abstract: How can students apply lessons from an article on the art of writing Twitter bios to their own writing?
lead_paragraph: This week, the third in our new Skills lesson series, Sarah Gross, an enthusiastic Twitter user and “connected educator,” suggests using an article on the art of the Twitter bio to teach lessons about concise writing and word choice.

headline: Five Fillings for Stuffed Peppers
abstract: Peppers make a great home for some delicious, untraditional but healthy fillings.
lead_paragraph: These roasted yellow peppers are filled with a savory mix of quinoa seasoned with garlic and parsley and tossed with Manchego or Parmesan cheese. The roasted peppers make a nice contrast in color and flavor to the sweet tomato sauce. You’ll get plenty of Vitamin C and lycopene from both the peppers and the sauce in this dish.

headline: The Fed’s Downward Trend at the Top
abstract: The path of interest rates has followed the relative heights of the Fed’s leaders.
lead_paragraph: Since Paul Volcker, who stands 6 foot 7, left the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve in 1987, each successive Fed leader has stood at least a bit closer to the ground. Interest rates, coincidentally, have followed a similar path. With Janet Yellen poised to take over, the federal funds rate — a benchmark that sets the overnight cost of borrowing for banks — is effectively zero.

headline: An Academic Home
abstract: Andrew K. Rose, a colleague of Janet Yellen at the University of California, Berkeley, discusses Ms. Yellen's role as a professor.
lead_paragraph: Andrew K. Rose, a colleague of Janet Yellen at the University of California, Berkeley, discusses Ms. Yellen's role as a professor.

headline: My Fake Levantine Romance
abstract: Our cultural differences blinded me to the obvious.
lead_paragraph: Our first date was at the best hummusia in Israel. We sat hillside in a white stone building, while the hummus, soaked with olive oil and topped with pine nuts and Egyptian brown beans, melted in our mouths like clotted cream. We were a few miles from Jerusalem on a scorching desert afternoon, in the Arab village of Abu Ghosh, a town known not only for its hummus but also for its peaceful relationship with nearby Jewish settlements.

headline: Parts and Labor (and Luck)
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Automobile Service Stations', 'Deafness']
abstract: The squeaky wheel; a loud-and-clear decision.
lead_paragraph: I recently took my car to a mechanic because it had suddenly started making an alarmingly loud noise when the brakes were applied. He removed and cleaned the brake pads, but the noise persisted. After three more hours, he finally declared it a mystery. He didn’t charge me anything, and I didn’t offer to pay. But the following day, the brakes made significantly less noise, and now they are barely audible. Am I obligated to return to his shop and offer payment? ANAT CHEMERINSKI, BALTIMORE

headline: Who’s Winning the Architecture Arms Race?
abstract: Hint: It’s the place spending an estimated $6 billion a year on it.
lead_paragraph: Answer: Baku, Azerbaijan, where the government is spending an estimated $6 billion a year on architecture projects. As we wrote in February, Azerbaijan’s leaders want to make their capital city a destination for the rich and fabulous. The latest example: the Heydar Aliyev Center designed by Zaha Hadid, for whom it offered the rare opportunity of nearly total design freedom. Every roof and ceiling panel is different, Hadid says. Though the center does not officially open until Nov. 1, people are already climbing on its base, says the photographer Iwan Baan. “But I haven’t seen any skateboarders yet.” Maya Lau

headline: Catie Marron: Blame Pastis, Not the High Line
keywords: ['Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The High Line co-chairwoman on private wealth, public spaces and the sanitization of the Meatpacking District.
lead_paragraph: Your book, “City Parks: Public Places, Private Thoughts,” is an anthology of writers musing about their favorite public parks. What was the genesis of the idea?  I went to Paris for the first time when I was 23. We went to the Luxembourg Gardens one morning, and I was nearly moved to tears. It became my favorite place in the world. Whenever I was in Paris, I would insist on going there, even on the way to the airport.

headline: Why Don’t We Dance Anymore?
abstract: Watching dancing on YouTube doesn’t count.
lead_paragraph: When a dance move is born, the air is heavy with promise. Think of Chubby Checker, doing the twist with casual grace on “American Bandstand.” Think of that first surreal nightclub scene in “Sweet Charity,” in which Shirley MacLaine’s young dancehall hostess is mesmerized by a troop of dancers serving Bob Fosse’s unique style of über-mod gesticulation. Think of Jennifer Beals’s solo audition in “Flashdance,” the movie that led to a million ripped sweatshirts. Think of Michael Jackson’s first moonwalk.

abstract: The secret to making it in the N.F.L.; Mario Batali’s wine of the season; who is an essential employee anyway?

headline: Nicolas Jaar Tests the Limits of Dance Music
abstract: Would you care for a little Ethiopian jazz with your techno?
lead_paragraph: When Nicolas Jaar was 17, he e-mailed a piece of electronic music, which he made on his laptop, to a record label in Brooklyn. He’d heard an interview with the owner of the label, Wolf + Lamb, who was going on about house music and “elasticity.” Jaar felt he knew exactly what the guy was talking about. Wolf + Lamb agreed to put out Jaar’s first E.P. and invited him to perform at a somewhat sketchy space called the Marcy Hotel in Williamsburg. At the time, Jaar was a senior at the Lycée Français on Manhattan’s Upper East Side.
