headline: Autumn of the Jackass
abstract: What’s left for Johnny Knoxville?
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the old man in the cardigan and the backpack-toting boy sitting on an outdoor bench in a Los Angeles suburb were an image of harmless innocence: just a drowsy octogenarian being looked after by his fidgety grandson. When the old man leaned back, closed his eyes and appeared to nod off, the cherubic child took out a permanent marker and pulled off its cap. With painstaking precision, the boy proceeded to write the word “fart” in thick capital letters on his grandfather’s forehead.

headline: Who Made That Android Logo?
abstract: Finding inspiration for a robot on a bathroom door.
lead_paragraph: Irina Blok may have drawn one of the most recognized logos in the world, but her association with the green Android has not made her famous. Blok can think of only one incident when she garnered the public’s attention for designing it. In 2010, she and her 6-year-old daughter were in a movie theater waiting for “Alice in Wonderland” to begin when an Android logo flashed on the screen. Her daughter, Blok recalls, suddenly stood up and yelled, “My mommy invented that!” Everyone in the row in front of them turned around to stare. Blok was so embarrassed, she says, that she sank down behind her tub of popcorn.

headline: Ahab, Huck and Walt
abstract: Literary types were following along on Twitter during the final episode of “Breaking Bad.”
lead_paragraph: Norman Mailer once said of “The Sopranos” that the “wide canvas” associated with the Great American Novel was “moving to television.” “The Wire” has been compared to the work of Dickens. So it makes sense that literary types were following along on Twitter when “Breaking Bad” wrapped up on Sept. 29.

headline: Sports
abstract: The best of Red Smith, and new books by Eduardo Galeano, Samuel G. Freedman and Jonathan Schuppe.
lead_paragraph: AMERICAN PASTIMESThe Very Best of Red SmithEdited by Daniel Okrent  Library of America, $29.95.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: The actor Nick Offerman, whose autobiography, “Paddle Your Own Canoe,” is No. 8 on the hardcover nonfiction list, says: “I have no intention of ever ceasing to enjoy red meat.”
lead_paragraph: Ode to Meat: As Ron Swanson, the gruff parks director on NBC’s sitcom “Parks and Recreation,” Nick Offerman plays America’s cuddliest libertarian outside Rand Paul. (Inside Rand Paul it’s too dark, Groucho Marx never said.) How much overlap exists between Offerman and his character? It’s a question the actor — who grew up on an Illinois farm, loves woodworking and deplores the increasingly “soft” temperament of his hometown — invites in his autobiography, “Paddle Your Own Canoe,” new on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 8.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SAN MIGUEL,  by T. Coraghessan Boyle. (Penguin, $16.) In Boyle’s mesmerizing 14th novel, two utopians from different eras — Will Waters, a veteran of the Civil War, and later, Herbie Lester, a World War I veteran — establish private idylls on the desolate Channel Islands off the California coast. As these men pursue dreams of freedom and self-reliance, their wives grapple with the hardships of raising a family in brutal isolation.

headline: It’s Not Just Political Districts. Our News Is Gerrymandered, Too.
abstract: The government shutdown reflects a political system that reinforces extremism. The news media system isn’t much different lately.
lead_paragraph: I read an interview this last week with someone who gets his news from a narrow band of information providers.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: PERV: The Sexual Deviant in All of Us,  by Jesse Bering. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) Melissophilia, climacophilia, titillagnia: Bering provocatively examines notions of deviance and the wide- ranging triggers of human desire.

headline: International Arrivals
abstract: Three picture books illuminate the complex journey home that begins in an unfamiliar place.
lead_paragraph: Whether they’re arriving by boat, plane or a great gust of wind, characters in three new picture books find themselves in unknown territory. Their stories focus not on the voyage over but on the complex journey that begins upon arrival, as they learn how to navigate a puzzling new world until it gradually turns into a place that feels like home. While many children’s books about the experience of immigration are rooted in particular cultures and histories, all three of these books emphasize the universal aspects of acclimating to the unfamiliar.

headline: Thrills and Chills
abstract: In two novels set in eerily similar Londons — one Victorian, one modern — young adventurers fight to keep sinister forces at bay.
lead_paragraph: Where would teenage mysteries be without idiotic antics like going down to the docks alone late at night or opening haunted lockets? And where would Victorian London be without Undead motifs like fog and Scotland Yard? In two new middle-grade novels, Colleen Gleason and Jonathan Stroud have vamped up the familiar world of Holmes and Watson — and Scooby-Doo and Nancy Drew — to paranormally exhilarating effect.

headline: Views of the Rebellion
abstract: Gene Luen Yang’s linked graphic novels present opposed perspectives on a Chinese uprising.
lead_paragraph: The slow crackup of China’s last imperial dynasty during its “century of humiliation” was so fantastical it could have been made up by a comic book artist: an aspiring civil servant failed his entrance exam, fell into a delirium, dreamed he was the younger brother of Jesus Christ sent to deliver China from the Qing dynasty and ignited the Taiping Rebellion in 1850. Twenty million people died in the ensuing chaos. In the late 1890s, peasants from the north, affronted by Western influence in the empire, formed a secret society to practice the martial and spiritual disciplines of Chinese folk religion, which some believed made them invulnerable to European bullets and cannon fire. The belief did not survive the test of experience, but did earn the Boxer Rebellion an enduring place in popular memory.

headline: Selling a Hoarder’s Home: The Trouble With Stuff
abstract: Selling the home of a hoarder can be a challenge. You can’t, for instance, stage it. But in a tight market, such places often sell quickly anyway.
lead_paragraph: The one-bedroom condo on Park Avenue was described by the broker, Jeffrey Tanenbaum of Halstead Property, as a “hoarder’s paradise, with seven cats, one dog and 12 armoires packed to the brim.”

headline: Catsaway
abstract: Two feline brothers, one cautious and one intrepid, go on an accidental nautical adventure.
lead_paragraph: Even for two cats lucky enough to be born in the fishing port of Lunenburg, Nova Scotia, in its 19th-century heyday, the usual rules of sibling rivalry apply. “Don’t be a chicken, be a cat! Be adventurous!” Cecil, hearty and omnivorous, taunts his brother Anton, who would rather doze off to sea chanteys than chase rodents. But when Anton is pressed into service as a mouser on the bark Mary Anne, he’s forced to exert himself as never before. Cecil, hoping to catch up with his brother, stows away aboard another ship and finds he is not always as popular at sea as he was at home.

headline: The Killer Went Postal
abstract: Jayne Anne Phillips’s novel centers on a real murderer who lured widows with love letters.
lead_paragraph: Jayne Anne Phillips is not sentimental. From her debut story collection, “Black Tickets,” right through to the extraordinary novel “Lark and Termite,” her fiction teems with missed chances and tough luck, and her characters — even the children — are resilient hard cases. So about 50 pages into “Quiet Dell,” Phillips’s latest novel, any reader familiar with her work might wonder if there’s some trick afoot, maybe even a case of identity theft.

headline: Pride, Prejudice and Drudgery
abstract: The world of the people who laid the fires, cooked the meals and fetched the horses for Jane Austen’s Bennet family.
lead_paragraph: Beloved books like “Pride and Prejudice” or “Gone With the Wind,” or books left unfinished like “The Mystery of Edwin Drood,” have always prompted efforts to imagine a continuing life for their characters. We cling to them in hopes that some of the qualities of Austen or Mitchell or Dickens can be recaptured, restoring our sense of delight, maintaining the mysterious bond that returns us to Mrs. Bennet declaring that “Netherfield Park is let at last” or Scarlett O’Hara deciding to wait until tomorrow to think about her problems. Alas, with few exceptions, these efforts rarely satisfy.

headline: Today in Small Business: An Entrepreneur for Halloween
abstract: Beer that sells for $2,000 bottle. A marijuana-delivery service. And a “canine Airbnb.”
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Talk of the Townies
abstract: Allan Gurganus’s novellas expose the lives of residents of the fictional community of Falls, N.C.
lead_paragraph: In his 2004 introduction to Barry Hannah’s story collection “Airships,” Richard Ford noted that writers like Donald Barthelme and Gertrude Stein “banged themselves and their sentences against conventional and intransigent American prose syntax, grammar and diction, with often unsustained results — failing most often to express the matter at hand.” The distinguishing mark of literary greatness, Ford suggested, remains the combination of the two: a fresh sentence-level flair and a rigorous focus on the story at hand. Yet he mentioned only a handful of writers who have managed it: William Faulkner, Alice Munro, Raymond Carver and of course Hannah himself.

headline: Foreign Indiscretions
abstract: A young woman on a study-abroad program in Argentina is arrested for her roommate’s murder.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t believe she did a cartwheel,” Lily Hayes’s mother laments almost halfway through Jennifer DuBois’s psychologically astute second novel, which takes not only its title but its controlling metaphor from this gymnastic feat. The cartwheel in question — performed during an interrogation in a Buenos Aires police station — is so amazingly tone-deaf it ends up casting Lily as the killer of her beautiful American roommate, Katy Kellers, stabbed to death while Lily was navel-gazing in the night without a solid alibi.

headline: No Faith in Progress
abstract: Jonathan Franzen translates Karl Kraus, the Viennese satirist of technology and modernity.
lead_paragraph: The name Karl Kraus means little to German speakers anymore, and less to most Americans. So why has a celebrated contemporary American novelist brought out an annotated translation of two literary essays by this Viennese satirist who was born when Ulysses Grant was in the White House and died before Franklin Roosevelt completed his first presidential term? The full answer comes only toward the end of Jonathan Franzen’s engrossing, highly original volume. But that slow burn is part of his purpose. As a declared enemy of the easy response in an instant-access culture, Franzen finds in the unduly neglected Kraus a model of how to provoke readers while at the same time getting them to do some work.

headline: Killing Giants
abstract: Malcolm Gladwell examines the ways adversity can be an advantage in disguise.
lead_paragraph: To judge by “David and Goliath,” Malcolm Gladwell’s favorite word is “we.” In fact, it’s been his favorite word since his first book, “The Tipping Point,” launched his enormously successful career writing about how the world doesn’t necessarily work the way “we” think it does.

headline: Earth Control
abstract: We need to slow our rate of procreation if we want to survive, Alan Weisman argues.
lead_paragraph: If we wanted to bring about the extinction of the human race as quickly as possible, how might we proceed? We could begin by destroying the planet’s atmosphere, making it incapable of supporting human life. We could invent bombs capable of obliterating the entire planet, and place them in the hands of those desperate enough to detonate them. We could bioengineer our main food sources — rice, wheat and corn — in such a way that a single disease could bring about catastrophic famine. But the most effective measure, counterintuitive as it may be, would be to increase our numbers. Population is what economists call a multiplier. The more people, the greater the likelihood of ecological collapse, nuclear war, plague.

headline: Spies Like Us
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Inside the N.Y.P.D.’s intelligence unit.
lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of 9/11, the New York Police Department began regarding Islamic “houses of worship — and everyone who prayed there — as possible criminal organizations,” Matt Apuzzo and Adam Goldman tell us in “Enemies Within.” For that reason, those houses of worship get special attention from officers in the department’s intelligence unit.

headline: Special Forces
abstract: American counterinsurgency efforts in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Particular military strategies become identified with particular wars, often giving rise to confusion about whether the war’s outcome is due to the strategy or to something else. Debates persist, for example, about how much credit David Petraeus’s counterinsurgency strategy should get for the temporary de-escalation of violence in Iraq several years ago. Now the United States is out of Iraq, and the war in Afghanistan has come to be seen as the embodiment of counterinsurgency.

headline: The Gun Report: October 11, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: A man charged with killing a bystander in Columbia, S.C., has been granted immunity from prosecution after citing the state’s Stand Your Ground Act. In the early morning hours of April 17, 2010, an S.U.V. filled with teenage boys had been threatening Shannon Scott’s 15-year-old daughter, driving by their home and firing a gun. Shortly after, Darrel Niles, 17, a high school basketball player, drove by, and mistakenly believing Niles was involved with the earlier menacing, Scott, 33, shot him in the head with a .380 bullet, killing him instantly.

headline: New Chapter, Old Story
abstract: Daniel Jonah Goldhagen maintains there is a resurgence in global anti-Semitism.
lead_paragraph: In “The Devil That Never Dies,” Daniel Jonah Goldhagen reports that there has been a worldwide rise in lethal anti-­Semitism. If he had to pick a role model for the new generation of Jew-haters, he might settle on an elderly Sunni cleric named Yusuf al-Qaradawi.

headline: The Fox Says, ‘I Can Make You Famous’
abstract: Bard and Vegard Ylvisaker, the Norwegian brothers behind “The Fox (What Does the Fox Say?),” made the hit song as a joke.
lead_paragraph: Studio 6A, the Rockefeller Plaza home of NBC’s “Late Night With Jimmy Fallon,” was filled with artificial smoke and laser lights when Bard and Vegard Ylvisaker arrived. These Norwegian brothers, who had spent the previous days traveling from Oslo to London to New York, did not seem to be particularly fazed as they surveyed their surroundings, which included a squad of dancers in fox masks and makeup, two long rows of full-length mirrors and a man dressed in a head-to-toe horse costume.

headline: Mass Evacuations as Cyclone Phailin Nears India’s East Coast
abstract: The meteorological department has warned of extensive damage to mud homes, power lines and communication systems from the cyclone, expected to hit Orissa and Andhra Pradesh Saturday evening.
lead_paragraph: Officials in Orissa and the northern part of the adjoining Andhra Pradesh state, scrambled Friday to evacuate thousands of people from the coastline as a major cyclone headed for landfall from the Bay of Bengal.

headline: Concerto for Piano and YouTube
abstract: The pianist Valentina Lisitsa restarted her stalled career using an extensive collection of YouTube videos.
lead_paragraph: Visitors browsing through the YouTube channel of the pianist Valentina Lisitsa can watch her in hundreds of videos. There are live webcams of her practicing at her home in North Carolina, long blonde hair tossing and brow furrowed in concentration as she reads through new works. There she is in a red gown playing Schumann’s “Traumerei” at a concert in Seoul, and recording Rachmaninoff’s Concerto No. 3 at the Abbey Road Studios in London.

headline: It’s No Longer the Economy, Stupid
keywords: ['Gallup Poll', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It took dysfunctional government to displace the economy from the top spot in public concerns, according to a Gallup poll.
lead_paragraph: It’s no longer the economy, stupid — it’s the government.

headline: Popcast: Ylvis and the New Clout of Novelty Pop
abstract: Dave Itzkoff and Ben Ratliff discuss the YouTube popularity of “The Fox.”
lead_paragraph: This week: the chart semiotics of a novelty hit.

headline: A Bridge Between Western Science and Eastern Faith
keywords: ['Monasteries and Monks', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Science and Technology', 'Meditation', 'Buddhism']
abstract: A small band of Tibetan monks and a team of translators have been working to bring Western science to the monastic education system in India.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Quantum theory tells us that the world is a product of an infinite number of random events. Buddhism teaches us that nothing happens without a cause, trapping the universe in an unending karmic cycle.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Jonathan Franzen’s ‘Kraus Project’
abstract: Mr. Franzen discusses his new book, a translation and annotation of two essays by the Viennese satirist Karl Kraus.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Edmund Fawcett reviews Jonathan Franzen’s “Kraus Project,” in which Mr. Franzen translates and annotates the work of Karl Kraus, the Viennese satirist of technology and modernity. Mr. Fawcett writes:

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Captain Phillips,’ ‘CBGB’ and ‘Romeo & Juliet’
abstract: Times critics on “Captain Phillips,” “CBGB,” and “Romeo & Juliet.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on “Captain Phillips,” “CBGB” and “Romeo & Juliet.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Parents Offer Best Advice to Steer Clear of Teenage Drinking
keywords: ['Alcohol Abuse', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Parenting', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Older parents discuss their strategies and approaches when it comes to drinking by the newer generation’s teenagers.
lead_paragraph: This past week’s topic for New Parent/Old Parent was teenage drinking and how to deal with it as a parent (and there were comments). The first thing that struck me was that in all my time moderating reader comments, I can’t remember so many as lengthy and nuanced — an indication, I think, on how complex and difficult the issue is and how much it can vary from child to child and from family to family. I was also touched by how many of the responses conveyed a sense of parental humility. I have worked hard to be a very good parent, but boy, did I fail on this front … a lot.

headline: In a Bid for Men’s Wearhouse, a Merger Battle With Modern Strategies
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: While Men’s Wearhouse is currently saying no to a merger with Jos. A. Bank, it may soon find itself pressured by the new shareholder forces in our capital markets.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, the first volleys of a war started when Men’s Wearhouse issued a news release rejecting a $2.3 billion takeover offer from Jos. A. Bank Clothiers. For spectators, it is not only a battle to watch for its outcome but also for how hostile takeovers have evolved.

headline: A Bash Brother Returns to St. Louis, Wearing Dodger Blue
abstract: The hitting coach Mark McGwire and outfielder Skip Schumaker will try to help the Dodgers beat their old team, the Cardinals, as the N.L.C.S. begins on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — During a team workout Thursday afternoon at Busch Stadium, Mark McGwire, the Los Angeles Dodgers’ hitting coach, stood near the batting cage surrounded by reporters eager to gauge his feelings about his return here to face the Cardinals in the National League Championship Series, which begins Friday night.

keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']

lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain’s national court has approved the indictment of Hu Jintao, the former Chinese president, as part of an investigation into whether the Chinese government tortured and repressed the people of Tibet as part of an attempted genocide.

lead_paragraph: The mother of Kenneth Bae, an American Christian missionary serving a 15-year term of hard labor in North Korea’s penal system, visited him for 90 minutes in a “very emotional reunion” on Friday at a Pyongyang hospital where he has been convalescing since the summer because of poor health and severe weight loss, Mr. Bae’s sister reported on Friday.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Montreal; Key West, Fla.; California
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Beat Nation: Art, Hip Hop and Aboriginal Culture, Montreal An exhibition of contemporary aboriginal art, above, will be at the Musée d’Art Contemporain de Montréal from Oct. 17 to Jan. 5. Beat Nation will feature painting, sculpture, installation, performance and video works that reflect the juxtaposition of urban culture with traditional identity, according to the show’s organizers. Performances, tours, gallery talks and workshops planned in collaboration with aboriginal artists are scheduled.

abstract: The Irish poet, who died in August, will be honored in November at three free public events in New York.
lead_paragraph: The poet Seamus Heaney, who died in August at age 74, will be honored next month at several free public events in New York.

headline: When Having a Nanny Cam Isn’t Enough
abstract: Tips on how to avoid pitfalls in the employment of household help.
lead_paragraph: HAVING recently hired a new nanny, I received a refresher course in running a miniature human resources department. It’s a costly process filled with terror to varying degrees — from being sure you’ve picked the right person to complying with labor, wage and tax laws that are easy to run afoul of.

headline: Are Competing Bankruptcy Plans a Good Thing?
abstract: As LightSquared’s creditors get prepared to consider which of four reorganization plans to vote for, it bears noting how much Chapter 11 has been changed by the 2005 amendments to the bankruptcy code.
lead_paragraph: As LightSquared’s creditors get prepared to consider which of four reorganization plans to vote for, it bears noting how much Chapter 11 has been changed by the 2005 amendments to the bankruptcy code.

headline: Many Tune In to a Sad Night on ‘Glee’
abstract: The episode Thursday night, which addressed the death of the actor Cory Monteith via the death of the character he played, drew 7.4 million viewers.
lead_paragraph: Though it was hardly what the show or the Fox network would ever have wanted, Thursday’s episode of “Glee” — which dealt with the death of the character played by Cory Monteith, the star who died of a drug overdose in July — lifted that series to its best ratings in a year.

headline: A Familiar Look From 2(x)ist
abstract: On Thursday night before an enthusiastic and largely male crowd whose own six-pack days seemed well behind them, 2(x)ist showed its spring 2014 collection.
lead_paragraph: In an article in the Thursday Styles section several months ago, headlined “Less Ab. More Flab,” my colleague Eric Wilson wrote of how increasing numbers of underwear companies were toning down their advertising — flashing less flesh and featuring more realistically shaped models than the god-like specimens who flaunt their startling good looks from any number of billboards and bus shelters around the city.

lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Romeo & Juliet.”

abstract: Years after the death of John Howard Yoder, many Mennonites still grapple with the conflict between his beliefs and his behavior toward women.
lead_paragraph: Can a bad person be a good theologian?

headline: Up Is Down: Republicans Defend D.C.
abstract: Republicans are backing D.C. Mayor Gray in his quest to exempt his city from the shutdown.
lead_paragraph: In their strategy of cherry picking popular programs to exclude from the federal government shutdown, House Republicans were particularly gleeful in approving a proposal to make an exception so that the District of Columbia city government can fund its budget.

headline: Strong Demand for Royal Mail Stock May Not Translate to Lloyds Shares
keywords: ['Postal Service and Post Offices', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: Lloyd’s may be tempted to focus its next share sale on retail customers after strong demand for the postal service’s shares. But the differences between the two offerings warrant a different approach.
lead_paragraph: The Lloyds Banking Group shouldn’t get too cocky after the sharp rise in Royal Mail’s shares. Lloyds, a state-backed British bank, may be tempted to focus its next share sale entirely on retail customers after strong demand sent the postal service’s shares up 36 percent in their first few hours of trading. But the differences between a secondary offering from Lloyds and Royal Mail’s primary one warrant a different approach.

headline: Movie Review: 'Captain Phillips'
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Captain Phillips."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews "Captain Phillips."

headline: Follow the Tracks of the Crime Drama
abstract: “Eight Deadly Shots” — a five-and-a-quarter-hour film made as a mini-series for Finnish TV in 1972 — is being promoted as a forerunner of today’s crime shows.
lead_paragraph: It says a lot about the current cultural pre-eminence of television that the Museum of Modern Art is promoting Mikko Niskanen’s “Eight Deadly Shots” — a five-and-a-quarter-hour film made as a mini-series for Finnish TV in 1972 — as a forerunner of “The Wire,” “Breaking Bad” and “The Killing.”

headline: At Citi, Pandit Is Gone but Is Still Serving the Bank’s Shareholders
abstract: Michael L. Corbat has accelerated some cost cuts and clarified strategy around the edges, but the bank’s broad direction was already in place and is serving shareholders well, the authors write.
lead_paragraph: Michael L. Corbat is approaching his first anniversary as chief executive of Citigroup. The bank’s chairman, Michael E. O’Neill, installed him after organizing a putsch to oust Vikram Pandit as C.E.O. The new boss has accelerated some cost cuts and clarified strategy around the edges, but the broad direction is still Mr. Pandit’s. Either way, it is serving shareholders well.

headline: Making Tracks With a New Old Sound
abstract: The pop singer Diane Birch got admiration but little traction from her 2009 debut. Four years and some writer’s block later, she’s trying again.
lead_paragraph: There are very few pop musicians under the age of Dolly Parton who wouldn’t bristle at being called “old-fashioned,” and yet the Brooklyn-based singer-songwriter Diane Birch understands that her biography and music could lead someone to believe that she may possess such qualities.

headline: United Has a High-Minded New Magazine
abstract: Rhapsody, a new magazine from United Airlines for first-class passengers and club members, features writers like Joyce Carol Oates.
lead_paragraph: United Airlines’ latest attempt to polish its first-class service doesn’t involve flat-bed seats or on-demand television. Instead, United is appealing to the intellectual senses of its elite travelers, with Rhapsody, a monthly literary and luxury lifestyle magazine edited by Ink Publishing, the in-flight media company.

headline: A Sun Rises on a Plunge Into Abstraction
abstract: The Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker and her troupe, Rosas, bring “En Atendant” (2010) and “Cesena” (2011) to the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: BOCHUM, Germany — The audience members had gathered in the darkness at 4.30 a.m. in the Cour d’Honneur of the Palais des Papes in Avignon, France. When Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker’s “Cesena” began, with a screaming man running in a circle, they couldn’t at first see anything. Then, as dancers and singers arrived onstage, and the unearthly sounds of the polyphonic medieval music known as ars subtilior filled the air, the sun rose, slowly revealing the performers. By the end, everyone was bathed in the morning light.

headline: Darkness Falls; Still, She Sings
abstract: When it comes to musicals, Selma, the heroine of “Dancer in the Dark,” prefers Hollywood to Vladivostok.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to musicals, Selma, the heroine of “Dancer in the Dark” (2000), prefers Hollywood to Vladivostok — or so we’re told when she’s on trial for murder. This may not be true of Lars von Trier, whose movie seems to reference, in its song-and-dance sequences, Soviet films as much as American ones.

headline: High School Classmate Reflects on Yellen
abstract: Charles Saydeh reflects on his junior high and high school classmate, Janet Yellen.
lead_paragraph: Charles Saydeh reflects on his junior high and high school classmate, Janet Yellen.

headline: What Has All This Done to Us?
abstract: “Out of Hand: Materializing the Postdigital” which opens on Tuesday at the Museum of Arts and Design, will present work by 80 architects, designers and artists.
lead_paragraph: This week brings an ambitious show that should be required viewing for anyone who is curious — and that should be everyone — about the ways digitalization affects, facilitates, improves, inspires and sometimes ruins various forms of visual culture. “Out of Hand: Materializing the Postdigital” which opens on Tuesday at the Museum of Arts and Design, will present the efforts of some 80 architects, designers and artists from 20 countries, with the designers in the majority. Presenting digital-dependent work from the last decade, displays will run the gamut from life-changing (if not saving) to frivolous, among them dinnerware, sports shoes, furnishings, clothing, buildings and various forms of three-dimensional art. Those represented include Bathsheba Grossman, Greg Lynn, Marc Newson, Magnus Larsson, Roxy Paine, Frank Stella, Zaha Hadid and J. Mayer H. Architects (whose seemingly astounding Metropol Parasol, completed in 2011, spans a plaza in the old quarter of Seville, Spain). The show may harbor a bit much in the way of jewelry and bad art, and most of the buildings will be represented by photographs, but new and useful information should compensate. (Through July 6, 2 Columbus Circle, 212-299-7777, madmuseum.org)

headline: Some Stones Shine Brighter
abstract: “Gem Hunt,” which begins on Tuesday night on the Travel Channel, follows three experts as they roam the world looking for precious stones.
lead_paragraph: A jewelry store is generally a staid, rather somber place, reminiscent of a museum or library. But a jewel’s journey to reach a glass case can have a considerably livelier start.

headline: Prizewinner, and So Much More
abstract: Caroline Shaw, the youngest-ever winner of the Pulitzer Prize for music, will appear in New York this week.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t really call myself a composer,” Caroline Shaw told Zachary Woolfe in an interview in The New York Times in April. Earlier in the week, a Pulitzer Prize jury had begged to differ, making Ms. Shaw, at the age of 30, the youngest-ever winner of the music prize, for her “Partita for Eight Voices.” Ms. Shaw, for her part, prefers to think of herself as a musician: She sings as a soprano in Roomful of Teeth, the dynamic a cappella ensemble for which she wrote “Partita,” and plays violin in the American Contemporary Music Ensemble, also known as ACME.

headline: There’s Beauty in All This Mess
abstract: David Dorfman Dance is plunging with abandon into themes of time, memory and fear in “Come, and Back Again.”
lead_paragraph: David Dorfman Dance is plunging with abandon into themes of time, memory and fear in “Come, and Back Again,” which comments on matters like the eccentricities of family life, the resilience of the human spirit and what Mr. Dorfman calls “the beauty of our personal messes.” For the elaborate production, the Brooklyn sculptor Jonah Emerson Bell has designed a large wall, built from refuse, personal mementos and found objects, on which portraits by Caledonia Curry will be projected.

headline: Activity Does Not Always Equal Productivity
abstract: True productivity means finding the right balance between taking care of what is truly urgent and focusing on what is less pressing but will most likely add the most enduring value.
lead_paragraph: In all likelihood, you get more done today than you ever have before. That’s mostly because you can do so much more, so much faster, wherever you are, through e-mail, texting, instant-messaging, Twitter and posting.

headline: Combine Sounds; Hear What Happens
abstract: Ben Vida will be playing a new piece, “Damaged Particulates,” in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Ben Vida played acoustic guitar and trumpet in the Chicago minimalist quartet Town & Country, which for nearly 10 years used repetition, drones and delicate, drumless sonorities to get to intense places carefully, like post-prog chamber music, or a Slint-Morton Feldman collaboration.

headline: A Headstand Without a Helmet? The Postal Service Halts ‘Just Move’ Stamps
abstract: Why is the Postal Service holding a series of stamps with images of active children? Because some of those active children might get hurt.
lead_paragraph: “Let’s Move!”

headline: Peas in a Vintage-Soul-Style Pod
abstract: Jess Wolfe and Holly Laessig of the indie band Lucius talk about their lives, work and hairstyles.
lead_paragraph: Jess Wolfe and Holly Laessig are not sisters, or even related in any way, but they have been merrily twinned as the frontwomen of the indie band Lucius for nearly a decade. Both 28, they met as students at the Berklee College of Music and then, post-graduation, moved to Brooklyn in 2007 to forge a musical career. “We knew we wanted to work together and sing together and write together,” Ms. Laessig said. “But we were just kind of experimental, and that’s why it took so long to come into what we are now.” After assembling a band through friends and neighbors, their first album as a five-piece, “Wildewoman,” is due Tuesday from Mom + Pop Music. But their act — with Andrew Burri, Peter Lalish and Ms. Wolfe’s husband, Dan Molad, on drums, guitars and bass — has already earned fans for its girl-group harmonies and resourceful rhythms; for their Tiny Desk concert on NPR, they turned an empty cashew container into a drum. They’ve performed with Wilco, and worked as jingle writers and in commercials. (Those were their voices in the Mercedes ad with Willem Dafoe broadcast during the “Breaking Bad” finale.)

headline: Pakistani Girl, a Global Heroine After an Attack, Has Critics at Home
abstract: There were mixed feelings in Pakistan as speculation grew that the teenager, who was shot by the Taliban for championing education for girls, might win a Nobel.
lead_paragraph: SWAT VALLEY, Pakistan — The question for the class of 10th graders at an all-girls school here in this picturesque mountain valley was a simple one: How many of them, a district official wanted to know, had heard of Malala Yousafzai?

headline: Portuguese, Right Down to the Olives
abstract: At Fado, a silent video travelogue, folk music and photographs complement dishes like a succulent roast chicken and a pan-seared skate wing topped with salsa.
lead_paragraph: Fado is a treat: a charming restaurant with the best Portuguese food I’ve ever had (including during recent meals in Portugal). On my first visit to this three-year-old Huntington restaurant, I spent the night kicking myself for not having come sooner.

headline: Bill Weir Leaving ABC for CNN
abstract: The former “Nightline” anchor will have an as-yet-undefined anchor role at CNN and will also cover the technology world.
lead_paragraph: The former “Nightline” anchor Bill Weir will join CNN next month in an as-yet- undefined anchor role as well being as the network’s chief “innovation correspondent,” covering developments in the technology world.

headline: United Nations Human Rights Chief Condemns Mass Executions in Iraq
keywords: ['Capital Punishment', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Navi Pillay condemned Iraq’s execution of 42 prisoners over two days this week as “obscene and inhuman” and warned that they undermined efforts to reduce violence.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations human rights chief, Navi Pillay, on Friday condemned Iraq’s execution of 42 prisoners over two days this week, denouncing such mass executions as “obscene and inhuman” and warning that they undermine efforts to reduce violence and achieve a more stable society.

headline: Homage to the Vegetable and the Local
abstract: D’floret restaurant is appealingly modest, homey and cheerful, with Dennis Foy cooking the foods he loves, with deep knowledge.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Foy, the onetime lord of Tarragon Tree, the ’70s and ’80s destination restaurant in Chatham that helped give birth to the farm-to-fine-dining aesthetic, celebrates the vegetable and the local at his year-old restaurant in Lambertville.

headline: Jets’ Willie Colon Attends to His South Bronx Roots
abstract: Jets offensive lineman Willie Colon left the Melrose Houses in 2001 for Hofstra University and then his N.F.L. career, but he returns often to see relatives and longtime friends.
lead_paragraph: The quarter-mile strip of asphalt and concrete connects the pillars of Willie Colon’s life in the South Bronx. It does not have an official name. It is an access road that branches off Concourse Village East, a road that is now paved, not covered in dirt and dust and gravel as it was more than a decade ago, when it bridged the chaos of Colon’s neighborhood and the structure of his school.

headline: Honeymoon in Vegas
abstract: Tony Danza stars in this new musical at the Paper Mill Playhouse.
lead_paragraph: Tony Danza stars in this new musical at the Paper Mill Playhouse.

headline: G.O.P. Helps Americans Like Government
abstract: There’s nothing better than shutting down government to remind people of how much they need it.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot of terrible news for Republicans inside the new NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll, but one of the worst bulletins is this: Americans are becoming more appreciative of government.

headline: Cruz Is Heckled During Speech
abstract: While speaking at the Voter Values Summit, an annual gathering of social conservatives, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas was repeatedly interrupted by protesters.
lead_paragraph: While speaking at the Voter Values Summit, an annual gathering of social conservatives, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas was repeatedly interrupted by protesters.

headline: Doughboy in Love and Battle
abstract: King Vidor’s 1925 silent wartime drama “The Big Parade” comes in a Blu-ray derived from an original negative, not a print.
lead_paragraph: At this moment, there’s probably no better way of dispelling the tiresome myth that silent films were technically and dramatically crude than by directing skeptics to the radiant new Blu-ray of “The Big Parade” from Warner Home Video. Directed by King Vidor, and originally released by MGM in November 1925, this tale of three buddies caught up in what then was called the Great War was one of the most financially successful films of the silent era. It played for almost two years at the Astor Theater in New York and enjoyed similar success worldwide.

headline: From Ring-a-Ding Swagger to Swooning Romanticism
abstract: “Honeymoon in Vegas,” a musical that just opened at the Paper Mill Playhouse, is set in a surreal time-warp version of that city while evoking classic Broadway tradition.
lead_paragraph: MILLBURN, N.J. — Many a tut has been tutted in recent years over the contamination of Broadway by the spirit of Las Vegas, the world capital of the flashy, boozy floor show. So I am happy to report that you can score one for Team Broadway. The delightfully unexpected “Honeymoon in Vegas,” which opened this week at the Paper Mill Playhouse here, has wrestled the neon mirage of its title into the solid, satisfying shape of a classic Broadway musical.

headline: Days After Disaster, Another Migrant Ship Sinks Near Italian Island
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: At least 27 bodies were recovered, a week after another accident left more than 300 people dead.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A ship filled with migrants apparently trying to reach Europe capsized in the Mediterranean Sea on Friday about 100 nautical miles southwest of the island nation of Malta, sending rescue boats and helicopters racing to the scene, officials said. At least 206 passengers were rescued, and 27 bodies were recovered.

headline: Assured That It’s Just Meant to Be
abstract: A couple who met in elementary school and connected years later after each has suffered tragedy and loss, see fate in bringing them together.
lead_paragraph: When she met a schoolmate, Alejandro de Castro, in 1992, Carly Brien instantly thought, wow, was he handsome — well, as third graders go.

headline: Glaad Sees Improvement in Depictions of Gays and Lesbians on TV
abstract: The organization found no network “excellent” in its diversity, but most of the biggest networks were found to be “good,” according to a new report.
lead_paragraph: No television network is “excellent” when it comes to representations of gays and lesbians, but most of the nation’s biggest networks earn a grade of “good,” Glaad, formerly known as the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, said in a study released on Friday.

headline: The Culture Paradox of 21st-Century New York
abstract: While New York has become an increasingly inhospitable place to incubate a career as an artist, it has become an ever easier place to experience and consume the arts.
lead_paragraph: Last week The Guardian  published an essay by the singer-songwriter David Byrne, which received a fair amount of attention online, arriving under the headline “If the 1% Stifles New York’s Creative Talent, I’m Out of Here.”

headline: Artists on Artists | William Kentridge on the Subtle Drama of the Indian Minimalist Nasreen Mohamedi
abstract: The influential South African artist reflects on the late abstractionist, whose work he discovered for the first time during a trip to India earlier this year.
lead_paragraph: The South African artist William Kentridge is best known for creating low-tech animated films, often based on charcoal drawings, that explore the painful effects of apartheid. He describes his current show (“Second-hand Reading,” at Marian Goodman Gallery through Oct. 26) as being about “the excess of making.” Filled with drawings of trees, people and text made on the pages of old encyclopedias, the show also includes several animated videos and sculptural sound pieces, including one built from drums and percussion instruments and another that transforms old sewing machines into a hand-cranked phonograph.

Even the four attackers captured on security cameras are being called “pink shirt, white shirt, black shirt, blue shirt,” because investigators are not sure of their real names, said an official who had been briefed on the investigation.

It can be a complicated balancing act for our elementary-age daughters, as some days end up overstuffed, some logistically impossible, some wide open. Still, compared to when we were children, the opportunities they get to sample on a weekly basis is mind-blowing.

keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: Mr. Priebke, who was under house arrest in Rome, helped organize the execution of 335 men and boys at the Ardeatine Caves in 1944.

abstract: The composer Aaron Copland’s currency was more than just his signature ballet scores and concert work.
lead_paragraph: Amid the awards crowding the walls of Aaron Copland’s former home in Cortlandt Manor, N.Y., hangs a neatly framed movie advertisement with a modest distinction of its own: The ad, from a 1961 issue of Variety, focuses its sales pitch on the composer, Copland, not the star or the director. For more than two years, federal authorities have been examining whether Infosys misused visas to bring temporary technology workers from India. In its report, the company said the Department of Homeland Security had “found errors in a significant percentage” of its hiring records.

headline: She Doesn’t Just Play a Mother on TV
abstract: Betsy Brandt, who now appears in “The Michael J. Fox Show” after five seasons on “Breaking Bad,” spends days off taking in Manhattan and her new home, with her husband and two young children.
lead_paragraph: Betsy Brandt says she did not learn much about how to cook methamphetamine during her five seasons on “Breaking Bad.” But she did get hooked on the show. Speaking three days before its finale last month, she said she still had not accepted that it was ending. “You’ll probably hear me screaming out the window,” she said. Nevertheless, she has moved away from the dark side to a comedic role on “The Michael J. Fox Show,” in which, Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times, she “harks back to Suzanne Pleshette on ‘The Bob Newhart Show.' ” Since moving to New York in June, Ms. Brandt, 40, has been living in an apartment on the Upper West Side with her husband, Grady Olsen, 40, who works for OpenText, a software company, and their two children, ages 4 and 8.

But on Friday, Gov. lead_paragraph: Janet K. Ruttenberg hovered over a 15-foot-long piece of paper that was spread across the grass in Central Park. It was an unusually balmy October afternoon and she was painting one of her favorite subjects: the Sheep Meadow. Wielding a 40-inch-long brush, she dabbed some yellow paint and described the curious pull of the vast lawn, with its tableaux of couples, families and single New Yorkers, all set beneath the elegant skyline of Central Park South.

headline: Britain: Rules for Press Proposed
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Britain’s three main political parties on Friday agreed on a plan to regulate the country’s newspapers, but the proposal faced heavy criticism from the press.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s three main political parties on Friday agreed on a plan to regulate the country’s newspapers, but the proposal faced heavy criticism from the press, casting doubt over its future. Because of worries about press freedom, the government wants newspapers to agree voluntarily to be governed by a new regulatory body and whatever rules it sets up, and has suggested some incentives to win their cooperation. The move to tighten regulations follows a phone-hacking scandal that emerged in 2011 and led to the closing of a newspaper in Rupert Murdoch’s media empire. Under the plan agreed to Friday, the new regulator could impose fines of up to $1.3 million for violations of its code of conduct. Several prominent newspaper groups argue that any regulatory body set up by politicians could be used to control the news media. It is unclear if the parties will now press ahead with their plan or try again to win more media support.

headline: Rolling the Dice on Food-Borne Illnesses
keywords: ['Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The shutdown increases the risk that the public will suffer from contaminated products.
lead_paragraph: The government shutdown has caused staff reductions at two important federal health agencies, increasing the risk of serious harm to American consumers from food-borne illnesses. The two agencies — the Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention — have decided to focus their remaining resources on imminent threats. But they have shut down very important work that allows them to spot potentially serious problems in advance and take steps to head them off. The longer Congressional Republicans allow the shutdown to continue, the greater the danger of harm.

headline: The Villain in ‘Gravity’ Is Real
abstract: Space debris isn’t just a Hollywood fantasy. And so far, there’s no agreed upon way to remove it.
lead_paragraph: The new movie “Gravity,” in which George Clooney and Sandra Bullock play astronauts adrift in space, has been variously praised as a riveting drama and criticized for scientific inaccuracies. But the phenomenon that sets the plot in motion is not a Hollywood fantasy. It is space junk, a very real villain. While Mr. Clooney and Ms. Bullock are out completing repairs, they hear that a Russian missile strike on a satellite has caused a chain reaction, with the debris taking out other satellites, and that flying bits of metal are coming their way. They survive the initial collision, but the junk ruins their shuttle.

headline: ‘Wolf Hall’ Mini-Series With Mark Rylance Is Coming to PBS’s ‘Masterpiece’
abstract: Mr. Rylance will play Thomas Cromwell, the powerful minister to Henry VIII, in a television adaptation of Hilary Mantel’s Booker Prize-winning novels “Wolf Hall” and “Bring Up the Bodies.”
lead_paragraph: A big British costume drama, adapted from big British literary works with a big British star, is coming to PBS’s “Masterpiece”? Well, of course it is. But in this case, it’s still a big deal, because the literary works are “Wolf Hall,” Hilary Mantel’s Booker Prize-winning novel about the ascent of Thomas Cromwell, and its similarly decorated sequel, “Bring Up the Bodies.” And the star is Mark Rylance, the Tony and Olivier Award-winning actor, who will portray Cromwell, the powerful minister to Henry VIII, in this television drama.

headline: With a Huge Line to Cover, the Jaguars Can Still Hope
abstract: The game between the Denver Broncos and the Jacksonville Jaguars is shaping up to be a brutal mismatch, one that has become the talk of the N.F.L. — and of bookmakers.
lead_paragraph: Gamblers everywhere have an adage: there is no such thing as a bad game if you have money on it. The Denver Broncos and the Jacksonville Jaguars will demonstrate that again Sunday in what will be, by all indications, a brutal mismatch, one that has become the talk of the N.F.L.

headline: After Steady Presence for Years, Kenseth Is Driver to Beat in Chase

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) THE HOBBIT: AN UNEXPECTED JOURNEY (2012) Bilbo Baggins (Martin Freeman, above) sets out with the wizard Gandalf (Ian McKellen) and a posse of dwarfs to battle a dragon in Peter Jackson’s adaptation of J. R. R. Tolkien’s first Middle-earth fantasy novel, part of a planned trilogy. Richard Armitage plays the exiled dwarf king Thorin, who leads the expedition through a series of encounters with orcs, elves, trolls and other beings. Andy Serkis returns, with the assistance of computer generation, as Gollum. “The meeting between Bilbo and Gollum, which takes place in a vast, watery subterranean cavern, is the one fully enchanted piece of ‘An Unexpected Journey,’ ” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It’s a funny, haunting and curiously touching moment that summons the audience to a state of quiet, eager attentiveness. Even if you aren’t aware of the apocalyptic importance of Gollum’s precious ring, you feel that a lot is at stake here: Bilbo’s life and integrity; Gollum’s corroded soul; the fate of Middle-earth itself.” He added, “If only some of that feeling animated the rest of the movie.”

St. Louis had not managed much against the Los Angeles Dodgers’ starter, Zack Greinke, an old antagonist, in Game 1 of the National League Championship Series, and the score remained tied going into the ninth.

headline: From the Archive Come Brides of The Times
abstract: Waltzing out of the Lively Morgue come the brides from Times past, well-to-do women of the 1920s and ’30s, whose studio portraits were made at a time when the country’s economy and marriage rates were plunging.
lead_paragraph: Into the Lively Morgue they descend, rich and richer alike, the well born and the even more well off. Cue the organ music: here come the brides. These women marched down the aisle during the 1920s and 1930s, as the country’s economy and marriage rates were plunging — and they marched into The New York Times’s portrait studio in the days before or after their weddings, defying the adage that women wear their wedding gowns one time only.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Oct. 11, 2013
abstract: This week on Money Talking, Joe discusses the debt ceiling.
lead_paragraph: The federal government could default on its debt if it does not increase the amount of money it can borrow by October 17. This week on Money Talking, Joe Nocera and Rana Foroohar of Time magazine examine what will happen to the economy and Wall Street if Washington doesn’t raise the debt ceiling. Domestic and foreign investors are closely watching and making decisions that could affect the nation’s economy for years to come.

headline: And Now, From the Woman Poised to Run the Fed ...
abstract: Over the years, Janet L. Yellen has occasionally been asked about being a female economist, providing a bit of insight into how she has viewed her rise in a male-dominated field.
lead_paragraph: Last week, after President Obama nominated Janet L. Yellen, the Brooklyn-born, Brown-and-Yale-educated economist, to lead the Federal Reserve, commentators praised her intellect and expertise. But they were also quick to celebrate the fact that she would be the first woman to hold the top job at the 100-year-old central bank. Fairly typical was the sentiment expressed by Justin Wolfers, a University of Michigan economist, who wrote on Bloomberg View: “Tonight, I feel reassured that my daughter’s economic future is in good hands. I also plan to tell her that she, too, can grow up to become the most powerful economist in the world. It’s a potent stimulus.” Ms. Yellen seems more at ease speechifying in the realm of monetary policy and inflationary models than discussing her gender. But over the years, she has occasionally been asked about being a female economist, providing a bit of insight into how she has viewed her own rise in a male-dominated field.

headline: Haiti’s Imported Disaster

headline: Fighting Back Against Revenge Porn
abstract: A few states are fighting back against revenge porn — publishing sexual photos without permission.

abstract: Anti-poverty programs unfairly shortchange childless adults.
lead_paragraph: For impoverished Americans, the biggest obstacle to health insurance remains the refusal of 26 mostly Republican-led states to expand their Medicaid programs as called for under the health reform law. As a result, up to an estimated eight million people will get no help at all because they earn too little to buy subsidized coverage on the new insurance exchanges and too much to qualify for Medicaid in states that won’t expand their programs.

headline: Monarchs Fight for Their Lives
abstract: The long-term survival of monarch butterflies may be in doubt.
lead_paragraph: The more you know about monarch butterflies, the more extraordinary they seem. Their life cycle — the adaptive web of behaviors they have evolved — is almost unbelievably complex. They migrate en masse (this month, as a rule) from all across the Midwest and Northeast to just a few high altitude sites in Mexico, where they winter, sheltering in profusion beneath a canopy of fir trees, from whose trunks they draw the residual heat they need to stay alive. Winter past, they migrate thousands of miles northward, where they lay their eggs on milkweed plants, the only plant a monarch caterpillar can eat.

headline: The Death of Willie Sherman
abstract: William T. Sherman’s beloved son, struck down by disease in 1863, continued to haunt the general for the rest of his life.
lead_paragraph: It was no secret that 9-year-old Willie was the favorite child of William Tecumseh Sherman. In fact, his wife, Ellen, reproved him repeatedly for making his preference for Willie uncomfortably obvious to their other children. But on the evening of Oct. 3, 1863, the boy lay dead in a Memphis hotel room. Sherman would write the next day to Ulysses S. Grant that Willie was “the one I most prised [sic] on earth.” But Willie’s death was the tragic consequence of a series of decisions for which Sherman would blame himself the rest of his own life.

headline: A Surprising Case Against Foreign Aid

lead_paragraph: IN his new book, Angus Deaton, an expert’s expert on global poverty and foreign aid, puts his considerable reputation on the line and declares that foreign aid does more harm than good. It corrupts governments and rarely reaches the poor, he argues, and it is high time for the paternalistic West to step away and allow the developing world to solve its own problems.

Franklin’s strong core was obvious on Friday well before she joined a dozen of her University of California swimming teammates in the afternoon for their weekly hourlong dance class, which, to their dismay, featured more segmental rotations than hip gyrations.

headline: Sticky Wages and the Macro Wars
abstract: The significance of a bit of reality.
lead_paragraph: Simon Wren-Lewis, following up on Bryan Caplan, makes the case that downward nominal rigidity of wages is simply a fact, attested to by overwhelming evidence. Furthermore, it’s a fact that we understand fairly well in terms of behavioral economics. So he suggests that the unwillingness of many macroeconomists to incorporate this fact in their models — because it doesn’t have “microfoundations” — says something disturbing about the state of the field.

headline: Chipping Away at Sex Trafficking in America
abstract: Readers comment on my column about sex trafficking right here in America.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written a good deal about sex trafficking in other countries over the years, from Cambodia to India, Pakistan to Philippines. But I probably haven’t written enough about the problem right here in America, and in the last few years I’ve tried to remedy that. My first aim is to remind people that this is a major problem at home, and that a lot of prostitution is less voluntary than people usually assume. The second aim is to show that the problem isn’t hopeless, and that there are things we can do about it.

lead_paragraph: Growing up in the San Felipe Courts housing projects of Houston’s Fourth Ward, Kenny Rogers used to walk to elementary school through better neighborhoods, admiring what he came to recognize as the mark of success: automatic water sprinklers. In the 1980s, in the middle of a run that earned him 12 Billboard-chart-topping albums and 24 No. 1 hits, Mr. Rogers built an 18-hole golf course at his home near Athens, Ga., and covered it in automatic sprinklers. “I’d spend hours sitting on a golf cart admiring them,” Mr. Rogers says. “I like to joke I have them inside my house now.”

headline: Quick Evacuation Efforts Help India Minimize Deaths From Cyclone
abstract: Reports after a powerful storm struck the country’s eastern coast showed the success of an operation that moved more than 800,000 people to safety.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The powerful cyclone that struck India’s eastern coast this weekend washed away thousands of mud homes, knocked down power lines, blocked many of the region’s roads and damaged crops and fishing boats. But reports from the region on Sunday showed the success of one of the biggest and most rapid evacuations in India’s history, an operation that moved more than 800,000 people to safety.

headline: Wage Flexibility in Doctrine and Policy (Wonkish)
abstract: I didn’t say that it was a good thing.
lead_paragraph: I probably should have made clear in my post on sticky wages that I was arguing for stickiness as a central issue in the history of macroeconomic thought, not as a central issue in current policy. I’ve been arguing for years that when you’re in a liquidity trap wage flexibility actually hurts rather than helps; this is the paradox of flexibility, which arises, roughly speaking, because under current conditions the aggregate demand curve is upward-sloping thanks to debt and balance sheet effects.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (AMC) THE WALKING DEAD Season 4 of this zombie-apocalypse series finds Rick (Andrew Lincoln, above) and his band of heroes settled into prison, where Hershel (Scott Wilson) provides farming lessons; a decision-making council sets rules for the growing population; meals are cooked in a communal kitchen; children are going to school; and new romances are blossoming — though not all will survive. “The challenge with any extended zombie narrative is striking the right balance between gut-munching action and undergraduate philosophy seminar, and the first two episodes this season are pretty talky,” Mike Hale wrote about this latest round in The New York Times. Of course, he added, “ ‘The Walking Dead’ has become one of the most popular shows on television by consistently getting the balance right.” In “Talking Dead,” at 10, Chris Hardwick, the show’s host, discusses the evening’s “Walking Dead” episode with Nathan Fillion. And in “Comic Book Men,” at midnight, Lou Ferrigno visits the filmmaker Kevin Smith’s New Jersey comic-book store, Jay and Silent Bob’s Secret Stash.

It was the third such attack in less than a month.

headline: Op-Ed and You
abstract: Anything can be an Op-Ed. We’re interested not only in policy or government, but anything that’s opinionated and that we believe our readers will find worth reading.
lead_paragraph: I often go out and talk to people who are interested in getting Op-Eds published in The Times. I do it because we need you, the reader, the writer. People certainly don’t write for us for the money; the payment, frankly, is peanuts. They write for the influence, for the chance to reach an audience, to say something that’s been bothering them, driving them crazy, something that no one else seems to be saying.

headline: In Washington State, Home of Highest Minimum Wage, a City Aims Higher
abstract: Voters in the blue-collar Seattle suburb of SeaTac will soon decide whether to raise the local minimum wage to $15 from $9.19 an hour, a move that could have profound implications.
lead_paragraph: SEATAC, Wash. — Washington already has the highest state minimum wage in the country, at $9.19 an hour. Soon, voters in this tiny city south of Seattle will decide whether to push the local minimum even higher.

headline: What’s Your Favorite Punk Film?
abstract: With the release of a new film about the legendary club CBGB, it’s a chance to look at how the big screen does punk. Tell us your favorite film about the era.
lead_paragraph: “CBGB,” a fiction feature on the legendary club where so many punk bands got their start, hit theaters this weekend. A.O. Scott had this to say about the film. Whether you agree with him or not, one thing is certain: it’s hard to get punk right on film. Last week, Marc Spitz surveyed a few people who know a thing or two about punk, and they offered their own ideas about the ultimate punk movie. Their candidates included:

headline: World Leaders Press the U.S. on Fiscal Crisis
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The fiscal problems of the United States dominated meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in Washington this weekend.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Leaders at World Bank and International Monetary Fund meetings on Sunday pleaded, warned and cajoled: the United States must raise its debt ceiling and reopen its government or risk “massive disruption the world over,” as Christine Lagarde, the fund’s managing director, put it.

headline: ‘Gravity’ Still the Heavyweight to Beat at the Box Office
abstract: “Gravity” remained the No. 1 film at the North American box office over the weekend with an estimated $44.3 million. “Captain Phillips” finished second and took in about $26 million.
lead_paragraph: Near-perfect reviews helped “Captain Phillips” sail to very solid ticket sales over the weekend, but the pirate thriller still got a bit lost in the wake of the phenomenon that is “Gravity,” which continued to perform at summer levels. “Gravity” (Warner Brothers) repeated as the No. 1 movie in North America, taking in an estimated $44.3 million, for an astounding two-week total of $123.4 million, according to Rentrak, which compiles box office data. Imax ticket sales for the 3-D space drama, which stars Sandra Bullock as a stranded astronaut and was backed by a flawlessly executed marketing campaign, have been particularly strong.

headline: Dozens of Pilgrims Die in Stampede on Bridge in India
abstract: At least 89 people died after thousands of pilgrims crossing a bridge to a temple in Madhya Pradesh State panicked because they believed the bridge was about to collapse, officials said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Thousands of pilgrims in northern India panicked on Sunday when they thought the narrow bridge they were crossing was collapsing, Indian officials said. The resulting stampede left at least 89 people dead and about a hundred more injured.

headline: They Have No Idea

headline: Steve Bartman Remains Invisible, 10 Years Later
abstract: Chicagoans vividly remember Bartman, the fan who deflected a foul ball in 2003. Some wonder whether an appearance by Bartman would reopen wounds or lift Chicago’s curse.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Steve Bartman sat in the first row down the left-field line for Game 6 of the National League Championship Series between the Chicago Cubs and the Florida Marlins at Wrigley Field on Oct. 14, 2003. He wore a green turtleneck and had headphones over his Cubs cap. By the end of the night, he was the most infamous fan, perhaps, in the history of American sports.

lead_paragraph: A leading children’s advocacy group is challenging the educational technology software industry, an estimated $8 billion market, to develop national safeguards for the personal data collected about students from kindergarten through high school.

headline: Google Jousts With Wired South Korea Over Quirky Internet Rules

abstract: South Korea, while leading in so many wired ways, has strong rules governing the Internet, including some on mapping services.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea is one of the world’s most digitally advanced countries. It has ubiquitous broadband, running at speeds that many Americans can only envy. Its Internet is also one of the most quirky in the world.

headline: Oscar Hijuelos, Who Won Pulitzer for Tale of Cuban-American Life, Dies at 62
abstract: Mr. Hijuelos’s 1989 book, “The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,” was his best-known work. His characters faced the conundrums of assimilation while holding on to an ethnic and national identity.
lead_paragraph: Oscar Hijuelos, a Cuban-American novelist who wrote about the lives of immigrants adapting to a new culture and became the first Latino to win the Pulitzer Prize for fiction for his 1989 book, “The Mambo Kings Play Songs of Love,” died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 62.

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Scott Frost became Oregon’s offensive coordinator before this season. Nice gig, if you can get it, the college football equivalent of a hefty inheritance, when an embarrassment of offense basically falls into one’s lap.

lead_paragraph: The only time it was obvious that it was Joshua Weilerstein’s subscription debut with the New York Philharmonic was at the start of the orchestra’s concert on Saturday evening, after he had jogged past the players and skipped onto the podium.

headline: Contemporary Group Tries a Wagner Foray
abstract: Alarm Will Sound, a contemporary ensemble, expanded its territory to Wagner on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The idea of the adventurous contemporary-music ensemble Alarm Will Sound including a work by Wagner on a program seemed like a vegetarian restaurant featuring a steak tartare appetizer. But on Friday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium, the group opened its yearlong residency there with Wagner’s “Siegfried Idyll.”

lead_paragraph: Sometimes television accidentally presents illuminating, dismaying contrasts, and Lifetime and HBO have inadvertently combined to serve up a doozy.

headline: Nothing Daring
abstract: A smooth Monday offering by Zhouqin Burnikel and D. Scott Nichols.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — Zhouqin Burnikel is rapidly becoming one of my favorite early week constructors. Her puzzles are smooth and enjoyable, just the right way to kick off our solving week.

headline: A Singleton Once More, Now at 51 With Kids
abstract: Helen Fielding, returning to her heroine in the third novel in a series, presents Bridget as a 51-year-old mother with a 29-year-old boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: Bridget Jones, R.I.P. You’re not dead yet, but you might as well be. In “Mad About the Boy,” Helen Fielding’s latest installment in this once-lovable series, there is a page that lists the things that have mattered to Bridget, now 51 and struggling mightily to take an interest in her two young children. They are: her weight, her number of Twitter followers, the number of texts she has exchanged, her difficulties writing a screenplay, a household infestation of lice and a head count of her boyfriends. The only conceivable reason to read about all this is that old habits die hard.

headline: A World of Childhood Innocence Intersects With a Grown-Up Reality
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera is celebrating Britten’s 100th birthday with a revival of Tim Albery’s 1996 production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.”
lead_paragraph: It’s no surprise that Britten’s 100th birthday, arriving on Nov. 22, has been overshadowed all year by the two titans of opera, Verdi and Wagner, who turned 200. Even the Metropolitan Opera, which has long been kind to the British master, unveiled gleaming new productions of Verdi’s “Rigoletto” and Wagner’s “Parsifal” but is celebrating Britten with just a revival: “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” which opened on Friday evening.

headline: Making a Serious Point With Eggshells
abstract: The French choreographer Jeanne Mordoj explains what it means to be female in “La Poème,” part of the festival Walls and Bridges.
lead_paragraph: The Walls and Bridges festival continued on Friday with another round of minilectures — speakers focused on gender identity and female representation — and a performance by the French choreographer Jeanne Mordoj. In the program, held at New York Live Arts, the highlight was “La Poème,” a dance that drew on Ms. Mordoj’s circus training to explore the feminine body. By the end, she had morphed into an otherworldly creature, but she had to crack a lot of eggs to get there.

headline: Mixing Fairy Dust With Urban Grit
abstract: In The Wolf Among Us, fairy-tale characters live in secret in New York City after being cast out from their homelands.
lead_paragraph: Video-game players are the original binge viewers. Long before Netflix’s “House of Cards” and “Orange Is the New Black” dispensed with the notion that television needed to be rationed and served in single helpings once a week, video games allowed their gluttonous players to feast at an array of all-you-can-eat buffets.

headline: Dancing to His Tune, After the Music Stops
abstract: In “A Response to Dig Deep,” part of the festival Walls and Bridges, Arkadi Zaides performed a dance interpretation of Julia Wolfe’s composition at New York Live Arts.
lead_paragraph: One obvious idea behind Walls and Bridges, a French-American festival now running in New York, has to do with making connections — or building bridges — between ideas and art. On Thursday at New York Live Arts, the topic was the link between music and the body. As the writer and documentary filmmaker Elena Mannes, one of the evening’s speakers, said, “Scientists believe that we came into the world prepared to respond to music.”

headline: Keeping It Real in a Time of Tumult
abstract: The new albums of Pusha T and Cam’ron show they have held true to the elements that established them as forces to begin with.
lead_paragraph: You may not remember the mid-2000s, so here’s a quick refresher. It was the dawn of the rap Internet as it looks now: the one that led to stars like Drake; the one that, thanks to ease of access, started to sustain global fan bases for even the most regional rap heroes.

headline: The Gang’s All There, Talking Art in Qatar
abstract: As Qatar raises its profile in the contemporary art world, dealers and artists don’t want to miss out.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — The art-world equivalent of McDonald’s golden arches, Damien Hirst’s candy-colored spots, now covering the exterior of the exhibition space Al Riwaq, glaringly mark this Persian Gulf city as a player in the increasingly branded art world. And the exhibition inside, which includes all the touch points in the career of Mr. Hirst, 48, is just one of a constellation of openings organized to attract a who’s who in the art world (or at least a who’s afraid of being left out).

headline: Playing Cat and Mouse With Searing History
keywords: ['Art', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era']
abstract: “Anne,” a new exhibition at the Museum of Tolerance in Los Angeles, offers ample historical context on Anne Frank’s life and death, yet ends with generalized lessons on “making the world a better place.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — What lessons do we learn from Anne Frank? Since her diary is the chronicle of an education, we learn what she learns: the lessons of daily life and early adolescence, acquired during a horrific time. We watch a meticulously observant girl, age 13, evolve into a self-consciously observant young woman, age 15. We watch — as one of Philip Roth’s characters pungently remarked — a fetus growing a face.

headline: Well, One Thing Led to Another and Eventually to Beckett
abstract: Lelia Goldoni, 77, stars in “Beckett Solos,” a three-play program directed by Alec Duffy.
lead_paragraph: It’s one thing to see plays by Samuel Beckett with their intimations of mortality; it’s quite another to see a 77-year-old performing in them. Lelia Goldoni, a dancer and actor who appeared in John Cassavetes’s seminal 1959 independent film, “Shadows,” attended the Hoi Polloi theater troupe’s 2011 adaptation of that film and struck up a working relationship with the company’s artistic director, Alec Duffy. The result of their creative pairing is “Beckett Solos,” a program of three short plays, two of which Beckett wrote for his longtime muse Billie Whitelaw. It’s a splendid convergence of actor, director and playwright.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Oct. 14
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Company Reports']
abstract: Goldman Sachs, Bank of America and Google are due to report earnings, and European finance ministers are meeting in Luxembourg.
lead_paragraph: EUROPEAN CURRENCY The Eurogroup of finance ministers from the 17-member euro currency union will meet Monday in Luxembourg. On Tuesday, the ministers will be joined by their counterparts from the other 11 members of the European Union that do not use the euro. Compared with such meetings in the recent past, there is no crisis to address. But the members will be concerned about whether the United States can avoid a credit default, the repercussions of which could upset Europe’s incipient economic recovery.

James’s best-selling novel because of a scheduling conflict, according to a statement by Universal Pictures. Mr. Hunnam was cast as the wealthy entrepreneur Christian Grey in September alongside the actress Dakota Johnson, who is to play Anastasia Steele.

headline: ‘Stars of David’ to Return in Concert Form

lead_paragraph: A new production of “Stars of David,” which transforms interviews with Jewish figures like Gloria Steinem, Aaron Sorkin and Joan Rivers into songs, will begin a five-week New York run next month at the DR2 Theater, the producers announced Sunday. Based on Abigail Pogrebin’s 2005 book “Stars of David: Prominent Jews Talk About Being Jewish ” and directed by Gordon Greenberg (“Working”), the Off Broadway production will be different from the world premiere engagement presented by the Philadelphia Theater Company at the Suzanne Roberts Theater last year. Instead of a musical, it will be a concert presentation.

headline: Royal Opera House Plans Simulcasts in U.S.
abstract: The Royal Opera House in London has announced that part of its lineup from the 2013-14 season will be simulcast for the first time in more than 500 movie theaters in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The Royal Opera House in London has announced that part of its lineup from the 2013-14 season will be simulcast for the first time in more than 500 movie theaters in the United States. The series begins with Puccini’s “Turandot” on Oct. 24 and 27. The other works scheduled for 2013 are Puccini’s “Tosca” on Nov. 7 and 10 and Verdi’s “Vêpres Siciliennes” on Dec. 5 and 8. Also planned are Wagner’s “Parisfal” (Jan. 9 and 12); Puccini’s “Bohème” (Feb. 6 and 9) and “Manon Lescaut” (July 17 and 20); Mozart’s “Don Giovanni” (March 13 and 16); Verdi’s “Nabucco” (April 3 and 6) and “La Traviata” (May 8 and 11). Tickets are at screenvision.com/roh.

Health insurers and generic drug companies have prevailed in most states over brand-name pharmaceutical companies.

lead_paragraph: Akili Walker made a living controlling sound. An Oz of audio, he could tweak a song working behind a huge mixing board in a recording studio for perfectionists like Prince, or get 30,000 people at an LL Cool J concert to throw their hands in the air. headline: After Downtown Fire, a Historic South Carolina City Ponders Its Next Steps

headline: Setting Pace, Ireland Predicts December Exit From Bailout

headline: Pulling Aid Away, Shutdown Deepens Indians’ Distress

A mother of three, she relies on lease payments from the Bureau of Indian Affairs on land owned by her family, which can run up to a few hundred dollars a year, to pay for food and electricity. But since the partial shutdown of the federal government began on Oct. 1, Ms. Costa, 41, has not received a check.

headline: Tigers Find a Place on the Field for Peralta, and His Bat Answers Questions

It is a subtle strip on the 231-foot-wide expanse, and Detroit Tigers Manager Jim Leyland hopes it remains a nonfactor during the American League Championship Series here.

He soon encountered federal provost guards, who ordered him to halt. headline: The Dixiecrat Solution
