abstract: Can we end the crisis in governance with a new alliance in Congress?
lead_paragraph: So you have this neighbor who has been making your life hell. First he tied you up with a spurious lawsuit; you’re both suffering from huge legal bills. Then he threatened bodily harm to your family. Now, however, he says he’s willing to compromise: He’ll call off the lawsuit, which is to his advantage as well as yours. But in return you must give him your car. Oh, and he’ll stop threatening your family — but only for a week, after which the threats will resume.

headline: The Bay of Bengal, in Peril From Climate Change
abstract: Regional cooperation is essential to battle threats that transcend borders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — NEARLY one in four people on earth live in the countries that border the Bay of Bengal. The region is strategically vital to Asia’s rising powers. Its low-lying littoral — including coastal regions of eastern India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Myanmar, Thailand, Malaysia and Sumatra — is home to over half a billion people who are now acutely vulnerable to rising sea levels. Storms are a constant threat; over the weekend, a cyclone, Phailin, swept in from the bay to strike the coastal Indian state of Odisha, leading to the evacuation of some 800,000 people.

headline: Inequality Is a Choice
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Income Inequality', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Income inequality results more from political decisions than economic forces.
lead_paragraph: It’s well known by now that income and wealth inequality in most rich countries, especially the United States, have soared in recent decades and, tragically, worsened even more since the Great Recession. But what about the rest of the world? Is the gap between countries narrowing, as rising economic powers like China and India have lifted hundreds of millions of people from poverty? And within poor and middle-income countries, is inequality getting worse or better? Are we moving toward a more fair world, or a more unjust one?

But instead, the money is going to a police initiative that will collect and analyze reams of surveillance data from around town — from gunshot-detection sensors in the barrios of East Oakland to license plate readers mounted on police cars patrolling the city’s upscale hills.

headline: Will New York’s Political Watchdog Pass the Test?
abstract: Concern is growing that the work of the commission that was created to end corruption in Albany is being compromised.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo had the right idea when he formed a commission to help end the scandal epidemic in New York State. He appointed a respected group of experts, asked them to come up with ways to cut the sleaze, promised them independence and asked for a preliminary report by Dec. 1. As that deadline nears, however, there is growing concern that the Commission to Investigate Public Corruption, also known as the Moreland Commission, could become little more than a branch of the governor’s political network. If so, it will be another Potemkin committee, issuing another report.

You realize those computer failures that have hampered sign-ups in the early days — to the smug delight of the critics — confirm that there is enormous popular demand. You have probably figured out that the real mission of the Republican extortionists and their big-money backers was to scuttle the law before most Americans recognized it as a godsend and rendered it politically untouchable.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (13) 56 UP (2013) In 1964, the director Michael Apted interviewed 14 British 7-year-olds for a television documentary, returning to film the same children every seven years as they progressed into adulthood. This latest installment finds the subjects, like Tony, left, settling into middle age. “As in the earlier movies, Mr. Apted again folds in older material from the ages of 7, 14 and so on, to set the scene and jog memories,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “The abrupt juxtapositions of epochs can be jarring, unnerving or touching — sometimes all three — as bright-faced children bloom and sometimes fade within seconds. An analogous project in print or even still photographs wouldn’t be as powerful, because what gives the ‘Up’ series its punch is not so much its longevity or the human spectacle it offers, but that these are moving images of touchingly vibrant lives at certain moments in time and space. The more you watch, the more the movies transform from mirrors into memory machines, ones that inevitably summon reflections of your own life.”

headline: The Clone Named Dolly
keywords: ['Cloning', 'Stem Cells (Embryonic)', 'News and News Media', 'Research', 'Biology and Biochemistry', 'Sheep']
abstract: The uproar over Dolly the sheep and human embryonic stem cells, revisited in a Retro Report video, shows how emotions can cloud understanding of science.
lead_paragraph: This week’s Retro Report video tells the story of Dolly the sheep, the first clone of an adult mammal. The Scottish scientists who created her recall the painstaking process of trying to get the experiment to work. After hundreds of tries, they successfully took a cell from an adult sheep, fused it to another sheep’s unfertilized egg and implanted the resulting embryo in a surrogate mother. But Dolly’s birth, and the rush of media attention that followed when the news broke in 1997, gave way almost instantaneously to fears and speculation about what this discovery meant for humanity’s ability to manipulate biology. The debate only intensified in 1998, when an American scientist isolated human embryonic stem cells, which can develop into any type of cell in the body, raising the hope of a new field of regenerative medicine. Here, one of the science reporters who covered the debate for The Times offers a rearview commentary.

headline: A Feeding Instinct Starts in the Womb
abstract: Opening the mouth to feed is an important element of nursing, an instinct fetuses develop in the womb.
lead_paragraph: Hungry babies instinctively open their mouths as their mother’s breast or a bottle draws near. Now, researchers from England and France report that this instinct — the anticipation of touch — is a skill fetuses teach themselves in the womb. Studying scans at monthly intervals between 24 and 36 weeks of pregnancy, the scientists found that the youngest fetuses were more likely to touch their heads and that as they matured, they began to touch their mouths more. And by 36 weeks, the fetuses began to open their mouths before they touched them.

headline: When We Next See Our Hero ...
abstract: William Boyd, authorized by the Ian Fleming estate to write a new James Bond book, has set his novel in Africa.
lead_paragraph: Fans of James Bond movies aren’t likely to recognize the hero of this new James Bond novel. Fans of the original Ian Fleming books may have less trouble seeing aspects of their man here, if only dim resemblances. Which doesn’t mean that “Solo,” by William Boyd, isn’t a perfectly well-carpentered and, at times, suspenseful novel. (He was tapped by the Ian Fleming estate to write the latest installment of 007’s adventures.) It just doesn’t feature a hero, who — aside from some pretty generic traits like an eye for the ladies, an ability to kill and an appreciation for expensive cars and a good meal — really feels like the Bond we have come to know over the last five decades.

There are none to be found in “Mike Kelley,” the exhibition, a sprawling retrospective of the prolific multidisciplinary creator at MoMA PS1 in Queens, which appeared earlier this year at the Stedelijk Museum in Amsterdam and will travel to the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles next spring. There is, however, one piece that can clearly be read as an inflection point in his career. It’s also a worthy introduction to Kelley’s practice.

headline: Shopping for Fall Fashion? Relax: You’ll Look Great
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Shoes and Boots', 'iPhone']
abstract: A look, when paired with a T-shirt or a blouse and heels, evokes an appealing simplicity.
lead_paragraph: Before Olivia Kim was named the director of creative projects at Nordstrom this year, she worked at Opening Ceremony, where she played an influential role in its many indie discoveries and unconventional collaborations. Now she has unveiled her first project for Nordstrom: a series of pop-ups. The first, in eight Nordstrom stores (items are also sold online), is called French Fling and is a homage to all things French. The custom-built installations were designed by Rafael de Cárdenas, and the design firm M/M Paris did the graphics. Among the handpicked selection of goods are Olympia Le Tan clutches (in a limited run of 16), $1,295 to $1,595; and New Era caps with titles of Jean-Luc Godard films across the front, $35. Gift items from the Parisian shop Merci, available for the first time in the United States, include home goods and this Liberty-print medallion, $10, which can be worn as a necklace or wrapped around the wrist. See nordstrom.com/pop for information.

headline: How to Feed the World
abstract: The world produces enough food for everyone. So why do people go hungry?
lead_paragraph: It’s been 50 years since President John F. Kennedy spoke of ending world hunger, yet on the eve of World Food Day, Oct. 16, the situation remains dire. The question “How will we feed the world?” implies that we have no choice but to intensify industrial agriculture, with more high-tech seeds, chemicals and collateral damage. Yet there are other, better options.

To Tian Xuan and his 20-something friends barbecuing outside their Cherokee-brand trailer in Beijing, it felt like an idyllic scene out of a Hollywood movie — except for the insects and the industrial-strength smog that had drifted in from nearby Hebei Province.

There were mahogany cabinets filled with plants from the East India Company, including the two tea leaves whose discovery launched the Indian tea trade. There was an antelope net made of baobab bark, from David Livingstone’s storied Zambezi expedition more than 150 years ago.

headline: Between Big Cities, a Road Passes the Russia Left Behind
abstract: Along the highway between Moscow and St. Petersburg — a 12-hour trip by car — one sees great neglected stretches of land that seem drawn backward in time.
lead_paragraph: LYUBAN, Russia — A few times every day, the high-speed train between St. Petersburg and Moscow barrels through the threadbare town of Lyuban. When word gets out that the head of Russia’s state railway company — a close friend of President Vladimir V. Putin — is aboard, the station’s employees line up on the platform standing at attention, saluting Russia’s modernization for the seconds it takes the train to fly through. Whoosh.

headline: The 180-Pound Gorilla in the Operating Room
abstract: The treatment of Holli, a female gorilla with a stomach abscess, offers an inside look at how the Bronx Zoo cares for animals who fall ill.
lead_paragraph: There was unrestricted viewing of Disney and National Geographic DVDs, and a stock of favorite snacks. But Holli — who goes by a single name — was not a model hospital patient. While recovering from complicated surgery in September, she methodically yanked out every staple from her 10-inch-long incision. Another time, she looked a medical resident in the eye and ripped a catheter from her arm. Boredom gave way to tantrums.

For some family members, toggling between the two is easy; for others, it’s so befuddling that it discourages any straying from cable at all.

abstract: Japan’s former prime minister, once a supporter of nuclear power, now wants a total ban.
lead_paragraph: “Zero nuclear plants.” With this recent call, Japan’s very popular former prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, is again in the limelight. His bold new stance challenges his protégé, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, whose policies would restart as many nuclear power plants as possible (now all shut down), and even promote the export of nuclear reactors. Mr. Koizumi deems the pursuit of nuclear power “aimless” and “irresponsible.”

headline: Unearthed: A Possible Stop Along the Revolution
abstract: A historian says recently discovered construction elements in the basement of a 19th-century beer garden on the Bowery convinced him that it was the site of the Bull’s Head, a famed Colonial-era tavern.
lead_paragraph: Maybe George Washington slept there, or maybe he only watered his horse and ordered stronger stuff for himself. Either way, David Freeland sounded excited as he crossed the threshold where a famous Colonial-era tavern, the Bull’s Head, once welcomed thirsty out-of-towners.

headline: When the News and the Novel Collide
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: What happens when a fiction writer is caught off-guard by current events?
lead_paragraph: I thought I knew what I was writing about. Three years ago, when I started working on my second book, I imagined it would one day be a quiet, multigenerational novel revolving around a thousand-year-old synagogue in Cairo. At the time, I wasn’t thinking much about current events. The book was set mostly in the past. And Egyptian politics were, at the time, relatively stable. In early 2010, Hosni Mubarak was beginning his 30th year as president of Egypt, the Muslim Brotherhood was outlawed and Tahrir Square was nothing more than a traffic circle in the middle of Cairo. Over the past three years, all this has changed. At first I tried to convince myself that my novel was unrelated to the revolution that toppled Mubarak. But eventually I realized that the book would have to adapt. The landscape of my imagination had shifted beneath my feet.

abstract: Senate negotiators need to ensure that a tentative agreement to reopen the government doesn’t give in to Republican blackmail.
lead_paragraph: The Senate, forced to extinguish the wildfire set by the House, is nearing a deal to reopen the government and end the imminent threat of default by the United States government. Some of the provisions in the deal are troubling, and senators need to ensure that it doesn’t in any way give in to Republican blackmail. If they can do so, the agreement may finally represent a way to end the crisis without encouraging blackmail when the debt ceiling comes up again.

abstract: We need to make “debt-ceiling moments” less fraught with peril, less prone to stalemate, and more conducive to productive negotiations.
lead_paragraph: THERE’S a lot of talk these days about raising the debt ceiling, to create time for more meaningful budget negotiations. But why should anyone expect Act II of this tragedy to unfold any differently from Act I? What we need most isn’t more time, but to change the debt-ceiling game itself, to make “debt-ceiling moments” less fraught with peril, less prone to stalemate, and more conducive to productive negotiations.

headline: As China Moves to Lower Professor’s Profile, Colleges Are Seeking to Raise Theirs

There was his 2009 public letter that ridiculed the technical school degree held by the nation’s propaganda minister and the interview he gave last year to Radio Free Asia, describing China as a “Communist one-party dictatorship.”

headline: China: Tourists Rescued on Mt. Everest

lead_paragraph: Chinese rescuers had evacuated by Tuesday morning 86 tourists trapped by heavy snowfall at the north base camp of Mount Everest, at an altitude of 17,000 feet in central Tibet, according to Xinhua, the state news agency. The tourists, all but 13 of them Chinese, had been ready to go to a lower altitude after sightseeing when the storm hit on Monday, Xinhua reported, citing the local government. No casualties were reported on Monday. Without proper acclimatization, severe altitude sickness can occur at 17,000 feet. Unlike the south base camp in Nepal, which is usually reached by trekking, the north base camp draws tourists who often drive up by jeep and visit the nearby Rongbuk Monastery.

headline: Ethiopia: 2 Men Killed While Preparing a Bomb for an Attack, an Official Says
abstract: The explosion took place Sunday afternoon as thousands were gathering in the capital, Addis Ababa, to watch a World Cup qualifying soccer game between Ethiopia and Nigeria
lead_paragraph: Two Somali men killed in a bomb blast were believed to have been plotting an attack in Ethiopia when they accidentally blew themselves up, Redwan Hussein, Ethiopia’s minister of information, said on Monday. The explosion took place Sunday afternoon as thousands were gathering in the capital, Addis Ababa, to watch a World Cup qualifying soccer game between Ethiopia and Nigeria. Security officials found grenades, a revolver and explosives at the scene, Mr. Redwan said. He characterized it as a terrorist plot but said it was not yet clear who was behind it. The Shabab militant group, which claimed responsibility for last month’s attack on a Kenyan shopping mall, carried out a pair of bombings in Uganda during the broadcast of the World Cup final in 2010. Like Kenya and Uganda, Ethiopia has troops in Somalia. The two men killed in Sunday’s blast were in the country illegally, Mr. Redwan said. He said that the attackers had apparently intended to strike multiple targets but that the bombs had detonated unexpectedly before the men could execute their plan.

headline: China: 6-Year Term for Protester in Blast
abstract: A court in Beijing sentenced a man to six years in prison after finding him guilty of detonating a homemade bomb in Beijing’s Capital International Airport in July, state-run news media reported.
lead_paragraph: A court in Beijing sentenced a man to six years in prison on Tuesday after finding him guilty of detonating a homemade bomb in Beijing’s Capital International Airport in July, state-run news media reported. The man, Ji Zhongxing, had been trying to draw attention to his allegations that officials in Dongguan, an industrial city in far southern China, ignored his complaints that security officers there beat him so severely in 2005 that he was unable to walk and had to use a wheelchair. The blast badly injured Mr. Ji and slightly wounded a police officer. The case kindled widespread debate in China, with some Internet users voicing sympathy for Mr. Ji and his ire with government officials. Dongguan officials said they had given him compensation of 100,000 renminbi, or about $16,400, on condition that he drop his complaints. Mr. Ji pleaded not guilty to the charges. His lawyers argued that he had not meant to detonate the explosive, the China News Service reported. The maximum sentence for the charge was 10 years in prison.

The justices declined to hear a variety of related attacks on the agency’s authority to address climate change.

lead_paragraph: Fans of the NBC musical comedy-drama “Smash” — they were out there, and you know who you are — were bereft when this ratings-challenged series was canceled last spring, leaving audiences forever in the dark about the future of its roster of fictional Broadway stars and striving performers.

headline: Dear Twitter, Please ‘Like’ This
abstract: While social networks copy each other’s features all the time, is it time for Twitter to adopt Facebook and Instagram’s “like” button?
lead_paragraph: Social media Web sites sure do like to copy one another. Facebook adopted the hashtag and follow features from Twitter. Twitter knocked off fancier profile pages from Facebook. Instagram added Twitter’s @-symbol. Twitter introduced filters after Instagram.

headline: A Little Bit Pregnant: The Numbers Game
abstract: They say you can’t be a little pregnant, but in I.V.F. it’s different. The embryo may implant – but it may be a bad embryo.
lead_paragraph: They say you can’t be a little pregnant, but apparently that’s not true for IVF patients, where half the work is already done: the embryo has been placed inside your uterus; its job is to implant for you to be considered “pregnant.” But getting those two pink lines on the pregnancy test stick is not the same as actually having a “viable” pregnancy – a euphemism for a live, healthy baby.

headline: A Push to Sell Testosterone Gels Troubles Doctors
abstract: Many doctors worry about the risks of prescription gels that are increasingly being sold as lifestyle products, to raise dipping levels of the male sex hormone as men age.
lead_paragraph: The barrage of advertisements targets older men. “Have you noticed a recent deterioration of your ability to play sports?” “Do you have a decrease in sex drive?” “Do you have a lack of energy?”

headline: Aston Martin Shops for High-Flying Customers
abstract: In an effort to reach affluent potential customers, Aston Martin is pairing its fast, expensive cars with Learjets.
lead_paragraph: Aston Martins don’t fly in quite the same way that Learjets do, but the maker of high-end sports cars hopes to appeal to the same crowd. That’s how I, a writer who normally covers the aviation industry, found myself plodding along the Henry Hudson Parkway last week in a $200,000 Aston Martin DB9 Volante.

headline: Fey and Poehler to Host Golden Globes for 2 More Years

lead_paragraph: At least in the case of hosts, the Golden Globes organizers know a hit when they see one, so they jumped at the chance to bring back Tina Fey and Amy Poehler to headline their annual awards show for the next two years.

headline: CMJ: The Deluge Begins
abstract: This year’s CMJ Music Marathon, five days and nights of showcases by some 1,400 acts, plus many more “unofficial” concerts, starts Tuesday in New York.
lead_paragraph: Just look for the guitar cases in being toted in midafternoon on Ludlow Street on the Lower East Side. As sure as autumn leaves or candy corn, they are the sign of an October ritual: the CMJ Music Marathon, five days and nights of band showcases that starts Tuesday in New York City, centered on the Lower East Side and Williamsburg.

headline: Listen Up | Cut Copy’s Billboard-Topping Strategy
abstract: The Aussie group created installations in the Australian outback and the Chilean mountains to promote its forthcoming album, which mixes guitars and dance sounds.
lead_paragraph: To announce their fourth record, “Free Your Mind” (out Nov. 5 on Loma Vista/Modular), the Australian dance-rockers Cut Copy decided to forgo the usual marketing approach. “Putting a song up on YouTube seemed like a bit of anticlimax,” said Tim Hoey, the group’s guitarist and sampling maestro. Instead, they unveiled a multimedia campaign that began on Sept. 6, when they put up billboards emblazoned only with the words “free your mind” in six far-flung locations around the globe: a small town in South Wales, the mountains of Chile, Mexico City, Detroit, a California desert and a village in the Australian outback.

headline: The GOP Tax
abstract: Around $700 billion in waste and much higher unemployment. Hooray!
lead_paragraph: Macroeconomic Advisers has a new report out about the effects of bad fiscal policy since 2010 — that is, since the GOP takeover of the House. The way it’s written, however, might confuse some people. They say that combined effects of uncertainty in the bond market and cuts in discretionary spending have subtracted 1% from GDP growth. That’s not 1% off GDP — it’s the annualized rate of growth, so that we’re talking about almost 3% of GDP at this point; cumulatively, the losses come to around $700 billion of wasted economic potential. This is in the same ballpark as my own estimates.

headline: Battling Cancer in Taiwan, a Popular Microblogger Comes Under Attack in Beijing
abstract: A Communist Party magazine has denounced Kai-Fu Lee, one of China’s most popular online commentators, amid a crackdown on opinion leaders on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Kai-Fu Lee, the former head of Google China, has nearly 52 million followers on Sina Weibo, China’s Twitter equivalent, and over a million on Twitter itself. He is an immensely popular speaker on the university lecture circuit in China; a celebrity who has criticized censorship on China’s heavily censored Internet; a Big V, for verified Weibo personality, in this Weibo-mad country. In fact, he’s one of the biggest of the Big Vs, with only four others, all movie stars, with larger followings.

abstract: Why the Republican civil war isn’t entirely substance free.
lead_paragraph: Late last week, as the G.O.P. descended ever-deeper into civil war, Matt Yglesias and Jonathan Chait both had pieces up marveling at the absence of any actual policy disagreement between the populists driving the shutdown and the establishment/leadership/Senate Republicans trying to find a way out. “Intra-party schisms … are usually rooted in policy,” Chait wrote, but “mainstream Republicans and the tea party have fallen out almost entirely over political tactics.” Yglesias agreed, contrasting the party’s split on foreign policy, where there’s a big substantive gap between the Rand Paul/Justin Amash/Mike Lee libertarian wing and the more hawkish old guard, with the purely tactical split on economic policy:

headline: The Real Rebels of the Civil War
abstract: It was the slaves, not the Southerners, who led the real rebellion.
lead_paragraph: War is always accompanied by a battle for truth, and combatants for truth wield language as their weapon. In the Civil War, words were often misused. Connotations changed. Strictly speaking, it wasn’t even a civil war, since the battle was not about who would control the entire United States, but whether part of the country could secede.

headline: The Watchful Years, Before the Howling Began

John Krokidas’s debut feature, “Kill Your Darlings,” is intent on studying these not-yet-Beats in their fledgling state, as they write the first drafts of their own legends.

headline: The N.S.A. May Have Your Address Book

In her column today, Sylvie Kauffman of the French newspaper Le Monde, one of our new Op-Ed contributors, recalled this quote from President Obama: “With respect to the Internet and e-mails, this does not apply to U.S. citizens and it does not apply to people living in the United States.”

abstract: The two nations have been unable to conclude talks on civilian nuclear energy because American companies have refused to accept the liability framework that the Indian government set in place in 2010 to deal with nuclear accidents.
lead_paragraph: Following Prime Minister Manmohan Singh’s visit to the White House last month, President Obama announced that the first commercial agreement between an American company and India had been achieved. The details of this agreement —reportedly worth just $16 million — are more modest than Mr. Obama’s rosy language might suggest. Some propriety information will be transferred from Westinghouse to the public-sector Indian Nuclear Power Corporation, but the signing of a reactor contract remains a long distance away.

headline: States Begin to Open National Parks
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Statue of Liberty']
abstract: After receiving approval from the Department of the Interior and the National Park Service, states have reopened parks and attractions like the Grand Canyon and Mount Rushmore.
lead_paragraph: Several national parks and attractions that had been closed because of the government shutdown have reopened this week, after the Department of the Interior and the National Park Service gave state officials approval to use state funds and, in some cases, donations from local corporations, to run the facilities, The Associated Press reported.On Saturday, Grand Canyon National Park saw its first tourists since it closed on Oct. 1; on Sunday, the Statue of Liberty welcomed visitors again; and on Monday, Mount Rushmore followed suit. Other states have joined them, including Utah, which committed $1.67 million to reopen five national parks for a 10-day period that began on Friday.

headline: A Reno Neighborhood Drinks in Style
abstract: Bars, breweries and gastro pubs in the Midtown District are breaking with Reno’s seedy past.
lead_paragraph: As Nevada’s second city, Reno was once a boomtown of gambling, vice and quickie divorces. The city struggled as tribal casinos proliferated in neighboring California in the last decade, sapping the demand for just-across-state-lines slot machines and blackjack tables. Never as cosmopolitan as its “Biggest Little City” motto suggests, Reno has long had a night life dominated by second-rate casinos, strip clubs and the diviest of dive bars. Those days, however, are disappearing.

headline: Romário, a World Cup Champion, Is Now a World Cup Dissenter
abstract: Romário led Brazil to a World Cup title as a player in 1994, but as a congressman from Rio de Janeiro he says hosting the event next year is a waste of money.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — He has never been like the others. It is not his way. When Romário de Souza Faria was a boy playing soccer on the streets of Jacarezinho, he dominated the neighborhood pickup game, the pelada, day after day after day. When he became a star for club and country, he sometimes arrived for training in a helicopter. When his career was at its peak and he became an icon throughout the world, he reveled in a social life so rambunctious that he once said, “If I don’t go out at night, I don’t score.”

headline: Where There’s Smoke

Then it can start asking what it has to do to be truly competitive with the world’s top soccer nations, teams like Spain and Germany and Italy. If England doesn’t win today, it will almost certainly have to go through a difficult, last-ditch playoff next month. Then, no matter how things turn out — Brazil or staycation — it can start asking what it has to do to be truly competitive with the world’s top soccer nations, teams like Argentina and Brazil.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Oct. 8 – 15, 2013
abstract: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.
lead_paragraph: Answer the 10 questions below to see what you know about the people and events making news this week.

headline: Trucks and Architecture: Ford’s Design Chief Chats With Architects
abstract: Ford’s J Mays brings pickup truck design to a panel about architecture.
lead_paragraph: The pickup wars seem to be at their peak, or close to it. Ford, General Motors and Chrysler duked it out at the Texas state fair recently, unveiling even more chrome trim and special model options.

headline: Iran’s Foreign Minister Invokes 9/11 Attack to Argue for Collective Security
abstract: Iran’s foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, told NBC News that one lesson of the Sept. 11 attack was “That an island of security in an unsecure world is impossible.”
lead_paragraph: Before the start of talks on Iran’s nuclear program in Geneva on Tuesday, the Iranian foreign minister, Mohammad Javad Zarif, referred to what he called a lesson of the terrorist attacks in the United States on Sept. 11, 2001 in an interview with NBC News.

headline: Yellen on Long-Term Unemployment
abstract: Janet L. Yellen addresses long-term unemployment at the 2013 National Association for Business Economics Policy Conference.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen addresses long-term unemployment at the 2013 National Association for Business Economics Policy Conference.

headline: House Republicans Look to Vote on New Bill
abstract: House Republican leaders rushed out a new proposal Tuesday afternoon that would reopen the government and extend its borrowing authority.
lead_paragraph: House Republican leaders rushed out a new proposal Tuesday afternoon that would reopen the federal government through Dec. 15, extend the government’s borrowing authority until Feb. 7 and eliminate government contributions to all lawmakers, White House officials and their staff, who must already purchase health insurance on the health care law’s insurance exchanges.

headline: Le Bilboquet Reappears, and More Restaurant Openings
abstract: A chic but tiny hot spot reopens at more than twice its original size; after Sandy, a restaurant is reborn; a husband-and-wife team starts anew and more.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Holiday Weekend Gives Broadway Shows a Lift
abstract: Audience demand over the Columbus Day weekend results in some box-office records.
lead_paragraph: The producers of several hit Broadway shows capitalized on audience demand over the Columbus Day weekend, selling more premium-priced tickets than usual – at costs of up to $477 a seat – and breaking box-office records in some cases.

headline: Coming Tonight: Fact-Checking the Debate
abstract: The New York Times political unit will be live-blogging the first televised debate between the two leading candidates for mayor, Bill de Blasio and Joseph J. Lhota.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times’s political unit will be live-blogging the first televised debate between the two leading candidates for New York City mayor: Bill de Blasio, a Democrat, and Joseph J. Lhota, a Republican. Throughout the 60-minute debate, we will be illuminating the shades of truth and exaggeration in what the candidates say, and calling out any inaccuracies or out-and-out howlers in the assertions they make.

headline: Signs of Affection, or Not, at the Old Ballgame
abstract: In a series of pictures from the Times photography archives we look at baseball signs through the years.
lead_paragraph: Rules of grammar need not be obeyed. Sloppy penmanship and cornpone humor are welcome. The bigger the better.

headline: Living in Bound Brook, N.J.
abstract: This low-lying riverside community, with roots dating to the Revolutionary War era, has benefited from recent investment in a flood abatement system.
lead_paragraph: This low-lying riverside community, with roots dating to the Revolutionary War era, has benefited from recent investment in a flood abatement system.

headline: In Bound Brook, Reaching a Truce With Floodwaters
abstract: A flood-prone community in Somerset County prepares for new development after taking protective action.
lead_paragraph: To some New Jerseyans devastated a year ago by Hurricane Sandy, locales inland may have seemed enviably safe. But storms take many forms and can strike anywhere. Although Sandy wasn’t seriously damaging to Bound Brook, 35 miles southwest of New York City and 40 in from the potentially punishing surf of the Jersey Shore, the same could not be said of Hurricane Floyd, an entirely different kind of storm, when it hit in 1999.

headline: The Frenzy and Swagger of China’s Restaurant Scene
abstract: A handful of standout restaurants from Shanghai, Beijing and Hong Kong.
lead_paragraph: A handful of standout restaurants from Shanghai, Beijing and Hong Kong.

headline: U.S. Ends Panama’s World Cup Run and Saves Mexico
abstract: With two late goals, the United States eliminated Panama from advancing to the World Cup. The victory kept Mexico’s hopes alive.
lead_paragraph: It was the perfect end to a bizarre day of World Cup qualifying: the United States saved Mexico.

headline: Ultra Dining at Ultraviolet
abstract: At the restaurant Ultraviolet in Shanghai, the chef Paul Pairet has taken dining and turned it into theater, adding ambient music, unorthodox utensils and enhancing scent.
lead_paragraph: At the restaurant Ultraviolet in Shanghai, the chef Paul Pairet has taken dining and turned it into theater, adding ambient music, unorthodox utensils and enhancing scent.

headline: Carey Mulligan Favors the Brighter Side of Autumn
abstract: The actress looked cheerfully seasonable in a Dior strapless number at the premiere of her new film.
lead_paragraph: The Girl: The actress glowed in a sunny yellow strapless matte silk and wool crepe dress at the premiere of her new film “Inside Llewyn Davis” today at the 57th BFI London Film Festival.

headline: A Push to End Securities Fraud Lawsuits Gains Momentum
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Litigation against companies for disclosure violations of the federal securities laws has been a big business, and opponents are fighting to end it.
lead_paragraph: A group of pro-corporate forces has begun a behind-the-scenes fight at the Supreme Court. You may not have heard about it, but it could just end shareholders’ ability to sue companies for securities fraud.

headline: Top Earners Recover Their Losses, and Then Some
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Recession and Depression', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: The country’s wealthiest people are enjoying a soaring recovery from the recession, thanks in large part to rising real estate and stock values and low-cost loans.
lead_paragraph: FOR most Americans, the economy over the last 10 years has felt like a slog interrupted by a punch: the recession came amid years of stagnation. But for America’s top earners, the experience has been more like whiplash: a boom followed by a bust followed by a boom.

headline: Through Yahoo Earnings, a Window Into Alibaba’s Performance
abstract: According to a Yahoo earnings presentation, its Chinese partner reported $707 million in profit attributable to ordinary shareholders. That’s up 159 percent from the same time a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Want to know how the Alibaba Group is doing, as the Chinese Internet giant moves forward with its potentially enormous initial public offering?

headline: Seeing Its Own Money at Risk, China Rails at U.S.
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Credit and Debt', 'National Debt (US)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']
abstract: A commentary from an official news agency called for a “de-Americanized world” as Chinese officials worry about more than a trillion dollars in American public debt their country holds.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — China has become shrill in its criticism of the fiscal train wreck in the United States, arguing that the answer to a potential government default is to begin creating a “de-Americanized world.” Beijing’s alarm is understandable, given that it is the world’s largest investor in American public debt, with at least $1.3 trillion in holdings.

headline: Menu-Inspired Note Cards, Manchego Cheese and More
abstract: Recommendations for the week of Oct. 15.
lead_paragraph: To Send: A Line of Printed Products Borrows From the Past

headline: Captured in Libya, 1998 Bombing Suspect Pleads Not Guilty in a Manhattan Court
abstract: Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai is accused of playing a role in the 1998 bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa that killed 224 people.
lead_paragraph: A reputed Al Qaeda operative who was recently captured in Libya made his first public appearance on Tuesday in a packed courtroom in Manhattan, seeming far more dour and haggard than defiant.

headline: China’s Dining Acrobatics
abstract: A flush of wealth and an influx of business travelers have given rise to distinctive, imaginative restaurants. A list of standouts captures the variety of China’s new scene.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Some restaurants place you close to the surf, its perfume in the air and its music in your ears, while others nestle you in the woods. Some put you next to the Seine, others beside aquariums bursting with tropical colors.

headline: Intel Reports Earnings Drop as Its Industry Changes
abstract: The company, the world’s largest semiconductor maker, exceeded expectations with a reported net income of $2.95 billion, on revenue of $13.5 billion.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — This used to be Intel’s world. Now Intel just lives in it, hopefully at a solid profit.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 7: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
abstract: While injuries wreak havoc on real football teams, they can also create opportunity on fantasy squads, as is the case with the Eagles’ Nick Foles.
lead_paragraph: Each waiver wire week seems to have a different theme (running backs benched for fumbling, little-known players having huge games, a change in starting quarterbacks, free agents signed off the street), and this week’s theme is injured starters.

headline: Boehner’s Last Stand
keywords: ['National Debt (US)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: House Republicans don’t care what they win in exchange for raising the debt ceiling, as long as they win something.
lead_paragraph: The nature of Speaker John Boehner’s final battle with the White House on the budget crisis is now clear: It doesn’t matter what House Republicans win in exchange for raising the debt ceiling and re-opening government, as long as they win something.

headline: Sondheim Working on a Revised Version of ‘Company’
abstract: A major revision of the Tony Award-winning musical “Company” would make the central character, Bobby, a gay man.
lead_paragraph: The acclaimed composer Stephen Sondheim and the Tony Award-winning director John Tiffany (“Once”) are collaborating on a major revision of Mr. Sondheim’s celebrated 1970 musical “Company,” a project that Roundabout Theater Company is eyeing for a possible production, according to Mr. Sondheim and others involved.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Washington, Italy, Russia and India.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Washington, Italy, Russia and India.

headline: Traveling Through Time to Fight Witchcraft Mania
abstract: In “Sarah Flood in Salem Mass,” two friends travel back through time to try to right some wrongs in the era of the witchcraft trials.
lead_paragraph: Work, God and his book, violence and fear: these made up the staple diet of most of the residents of Salem, Mass., back in the Puritan way back. At least they do in Adriano Shaplin’s tart but overloaded play “Sarah Flood in Salem Mass,” at the Flea Theater.

headline: Developers End Fight Blocking 2 More Luxury Towers in Midtown
abstract: Gary Barnett and Steven Roth reached a deal to allow each to build a residential skyscraper between 57th Street and Central Park South with views of Central Park.
lead_paragraph: The transformation of a once dowdy stretch of 57th Street into Billionaires’ Row reached new heights on Tuesday, as two of New York City’s leading developers reached a truce that paves the way for two more ultraluxury towers on the northern edge of Midtown.

headline: The Agony of an Artist’s Commitment
abstract: The newest life of the sculptor Camille Claudel, by the French director Bruno Dumont, picks up where the 1989 film left off.
lead_paragraph: The brutally austere films of the French director Bruno Dumont scrutinize human behavior with a chilly, quasi-scientific detachment that borders on misanthropy. His characters are pitiable creatures whose baser instincts are in conflict with their spiritual aspirations. The sexual couplings in his movies are anti-romantic; his lovers rut like farm animals.

headline: BlackBerry Breaks Silence in Open Letter
abstract: While the ad does not explicitly mention the uncertainty surrounding the company, it gives several reasons for its customers to keep the faith.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Weeks after announcing that it was up for sale and soon after announcing a $1 billion quarterly loss, BlackBerry broke its silence on Tuesday to allay growing concerns about the company’s future.

headline: Ad Share Slips Again at Yahoo
abstract: The company’s share of display ad revenue fell 7 percent as it continued to lose ground to Google and Facebook.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The honeymoon is over.

headline: Khe-Yo and Whiskey Soda Lounge Ny
abstract: Inside two new places that are turning New Yorkers on to Asian dishes that might have been treated with extreme caution not long ago.
lead_paragraph: Inside two new places that are turning New Yorkers on to Asian dishes that might have been treated with extreme caution not long ago.

headline: Carson, as Seen by Sidekick (Not Ed)
abstract: This book by Johnny Carson’s longtime lawyer and friend Henry Bushkin tells the good, the bad and the ugly about a man who was television’s biggest star for decades.
lead_paragraph: Henry Bushkin’s “Johnny Carson” is that rare celebrity tell-all by an author who knows whom and what he’s talking about. Though early readers have been shocked, just shocked, by Mr. Bushkin’s treachery, they have also been drawn ravenously to his book.

headline: The Erosive Effect of Expenses on a Portfolio’s Value
keywords: ['Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Mutual Funds', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Investors can cut portfolio costs and increase returns if they are careful about where they put their money.
lead_paragraph: THE punishing impact of investment expenses on wealth is like wind, sun and rain pounding on painted wood over time. There is a lot of damage.

headline: Have to Ask What the App Costs? It’s Not for You
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Applications', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Apps and digital concierges are reaching out to the affluent with carefully curated and vetted offerings.
lead_paragraph: THE superrich have always had magazines, hotels and retailers catering to the special needs of their stratosphere. So it’s no surprise that the digital world has caught up.

headline: Closed-End Funds Offer Bargains to Careful Buyers
abstract: Because of market uncertainty, the funds, which invest mostly in bonds, are currently trading at prices below their asset values.
lead_paragraph: THERE may be no free lunch, but if you place an order for an obscure type of investment called a closed-end fund, you stand a good chance of buying stocks or bonds at well below the going price.

headline: Gay Marriage Ruling Brings New Planning Choices
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Wills and Estates', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'Income Tax', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Though the Supreme Court struck down the 1996 Defense of Marriage Act, state laws can still muddy the waters for those trying to rethink their financial arrangements.
lead_paragraph: BEYOND its psychological and political impacts, the Supreme Court ruling last June that married same-sex couples were entitled to federal benefits and tax advantages is prompting many to rethink their financial arrangements.

headline: Rich Americans Snap Up Irish Castles for Love and Discounts
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Palaces and Castles', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Many with deep pockets and traceable Irish roots pay cash to buy castles and manor houses at bargain rates.
lead_paragraph: FIRST-TIME visitors to Humewood Castle in Kiltegan, County Wicklow, can’t help it. They simply say, “Wow.”

headline: Help in Planning Investments Meant to Outlive You
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Wills and Estates', 'Financial Planners', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Experts offer tips for setting up a survivor portfolio to run on autopilot and ease loved ones’ minds.
lead_paragraph: IT was Mark Antony in Shakespeare’s “Julius Caesar” who said “the evil that men do lives after them, the good is oft interred with their bones.”

headline: Advisers Go Extra Lengths to Keep Wealthy Clients
abstract: Firms have offered concierge services, space for family meetings or compilation of family histories.
lead_paragraph: KAREN McNEILL has a Ph.D. in history from the University of California, Berkeley, and is considered one of the foremost authorities on Julia Morgan, the architect who designed Hearst Castle, William Randolph Hearst’s 90,000-square-foot coastal retreat. Ms. McNeill has written extensively about Morgan, who designed some 700 buildings and helped open the field of architecture to women.

headline: Blasts Kill 2 and Injure an American in Myanmar
abstract: Since Friday, six explosions have hit hotels, a Buddhist pagoda, and restaurants in Yangon and two regions north and northeast of the city.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A series of unexplained blasts across Myanmar over the past several days has left two people dead and raised anxiety in the country’s main city, Yangon, where an explosion on Monday at a luxury hotel injured an American tourist.

headline: At 28, Writer Is Youngest to Receive Booker Prize
keywords: ['Man Booker Prize', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Eleanor Catton was awarded the Man Booker Prize for “The Luminaries,” a tale set in 19th-century New Zealand that explores identity, greed and human frailty.
lead_paragraph: Eleanor Catton was awarded the Man Booker Prize on Tuesday for “The Luminaries,” an immersive tale set in 19th-century New Zealand that explores identity, greed and human frailty.

headline: Coast Guard Stops Renewing Ship Certificates
abstract: With the government shutdown, the Coast Guard has stopped renewing the maritime version of a car’s registration papers.
lead_paragraph: In better times, vessels over five tons were supposed to have a valid “certificate of documentation,” the maritime version of a car’s registration papers. But with the government shutdown, the Coast Guard has stopped renewing them.

headline: A New Terminal at Incheon Airport
abstract: Incheon International Airport in South Korea will have a new terminal before the 2018 Winter Olympics.
lead_paragraph: South Korea’s Incheon International Airport broke ground late last month on a new terminal, set to open in 2018 before the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang.

headline: Office Romance: Broadsheet Silhouette
abstract: A photograph of the debut issue of The International New York Times, as part of our series on the beauty in everyday office life.
lead_paragraph: As part of her series capturing the beauty in everyday office life, Kathy Ryan photographed Marvin Orellana, a photo editor at the magazine, reading the debut issue of The International New York Times this morning.

headline: Europeans Are Faulted Over Using Funds to Support Like-Minded Voices
abstract: Critics say the European Union’s practice of funding policy groups that tend to be supportive rather than critical limits discussion and fuels disenchantment over the push for greater integration.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — During heated wrangling late last year over the size of a new long-term budget for the European Union, Notre Europe, a Paris-based policy group, wanted to make its voice heard. So it put one of its researchers on a small radio station in the French city of Nantes to answer questions and promote its vision of a “more effective” — and bigger — budget controlled by Brussels.

headline: Mother of American Imprisoned in North Korea Leaves Without Him
abstract: The mother of Kenneth Bae, who has been incarcerated for nearly a year, expressed thanks to the North Korean government for letting her see her son.
lead_paragraph: The mother of Kenneth Bae, the ailing American missionary serving a 15-year sentence of hard labor in North Korea, said on Tuesday that “it broke my heart to leave him behind” after the North Korean authorities had permitted her to visit him in a Pyongyang hospital.

headline: The Crunchy Lure of Southeast Asia
abstract: New forums for Thai food in Brooklyn, and Laotian cuisine in TriBeCa.
lead_paragraph: Crunching on grilled pig snouts at a Thai restaurant in Brooklyn the other night, I reflected on how far New York has come.

headline: A Sequel to Tempt ‘Flute’ Fans
abstract: On Wednesday, Amore Opera presents the American premiere of “Das Labyrinth,” a fully staged sequel to “The Magic Flute” that incorporates some of the signature features of Mozart’s original.
lead_paragraph: Pamina is in trouble. The Queen of the Night and her three ladies have abducted her in the midst of her greatest trial. Who will help Tamino rescue her so that he can be reunited with her under the benevolent eye of Sarastro? Don’t count on Papageno. He’s fallen prey to the bewitching sister of Monostatos, that cunning slave. With her marriage to Papageno in doubt, Papagena is jealous and alone; perhaps the time is ripe for Monostatos to make his move. Pamina may just have to rescue herself.

headline: The Most Lucrative Form of Flattery
abstract: When a makeup or skin product becomes trendy, imitations aren’t far behind.
lead_paragraph: “I grew up in Iowa: when your entire world is drugstore makeup, you don’t know the difference between a knockoff and the original,” said Dagny Heimisdottir, 23, an administrative assistant who now lives in Minneapolis and can spot copycat cosmetics immediately, and often writes about them on her beauty blog.

headline: Heirs Press Austria to Return Looted Klimt Frieze
abstract: The current dispute over the “Beethoven Frieze” does not hinge on wartime plundering, but rather on how stolen art was handled after the war ended.
lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, Austria has made significant progress in restoring art and property looted by the Nazis during World War II. Now the government’s commitment to that goal is facing a new test, with the filing of a claim on Tuesday for the return of one of the nation’s most celebrated artworks: the “Beethoven Frieze,” by Gustav Klimt.

headline: Tech Rivals Lay Down Arms for Youth Coding
abstract: Amazon, Microsoft, Apple and Google are encouraging schools, parents and teachers to introduce students to programming during Computer Science Education Week, which runs Dec. 9 to 15.
lead_paragraph: It’s somewhat rare for Amazon, Microsoft, Apple and Google to agree on something, so it’s noteworthy when they pause for a kumbaya moment over something like educating youth programmers.

headline: Twitter Reports Sharp Rise in Revenue
abstract: Twitter reported in an amended prospectus for its initial public offering that its revenue surged in the third quarter and that the number of its users had increased.
lead_paragraph: As Twitter prepares to hit the road to begin peddling its stock to the public, the company disclosed new revenue numbers on Tuesday that may help it persuade investors to buy the shares.

headline: NBA 2K14, Infinity Blade III, Rain, Pokémon X and Pokémon Y
abstract: Reviews of NBA 2K14, Infinity Blade III, Rain and Pokémon X and Pokémon Y.
lead_paragraph: NBA 2K14

headline: Mexico Takes Bloomberg-Like Swing at Soaring Obesity
abstract: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s foundation has joined the fight against obesity in Mexico, where President Enrique Peña Nieto wants to tax sugary drinks.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Rosa Isela Sandate kicked her drinking habit about six months ago and swears she will never go back.

headline: Credit Agency Places U.S. on ‘Ratings Watch’
abstract: Just days before the government could default on some of its obligations, the credit rating agency Fitch has put the United States on a “negative ratings watch.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just days before the government could default on some of its obligations, the credit rating agency Fitch has put the United States on a “negative ratings watch.” Fitch reaffirmed the country’s sterling AAA credit rating, but warned that Congressional intransigence has put the full faith and credit of the government at risk.

headline: What’s a Group of Nice Toys Like You Doing in a Creepy Hotel Like This?
abstract: “Toy Story of Terror!” brings this cast of friends to the small screen, where they encounter an evil hotelier.
lead_paragraph: Once the annual avalanche of Halloween-themed episodes, specials and movies overtakes TV, you probably don’t expect to be using the word “charming” very often. But charming perfectly describes one such entry, “Toy Story of Terror!,” on Wednesday night on ABC.

headline: The Cancer Divide: Jessy
abstract: Jessy Acen, 30, who has advanced breast cancer, contends with her own poverty and with Uganda's limited resources in her fight to stay alive.
lead_paragraph: Jessy Acen, 30, who has advanced breast cancer, contends with her own poverty and with Uganda's limited resources in her fight to stay alive.

headline: Many Dramas, Now Playing With Food
abstract: The playwright Neil LaBute has constructed a multi-episode series of one-acts for DirecTV.
lead_paragraph: Neil LaBute has written some fine plays, including “reasons to be pretty.” But “Full Circle,” a rare foray into television, mostly proves that even he can’t make anything consistently interesting out of a bunch of insufferable people yacking over dinner about problems of their own making.

headline: Reporter Tied to Snowden Leaks to Leave Guardian
abstract: Glenn Greenwald was offered a “once-in-a-career dream journalistic opportunity that no journalist could possibly decline,” he wrote on his blog.
lead_paragraph: Glenn Greenwald, the lawyer and writer who provided the biggest journalistic disclosure of the year when he published revelations from Edward J. Snowden about government surveillance, said on Tuesday that he would be leaving The Guardian, the British daily, for a new journalistic venture.

headline: Breast Cancer as Death Sentence in Uganda
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Breast Cancer', 'Cancer', 'Chemotherapy', 'Emotions', 'Hospitals', 'Photography', 'Radiation', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: On an assignment in Uganda reporting on early breast cancer detection, Lynsey Addario photographed a cancer ward that serves four countries — as the region is scarce of expertise and supplies.
lead_paragraph: Lynsey Addario, a contract photographer for The New York Times, went to Uganda in July on assignment with Denise Grady, who was pursuing a story about early cancer detection and treatment in Uganda. An interactive feature, where you can share your own stories about surviving breast cancer or stories about someone you know who has or had breast cancer, is viewable here, and Ms. Grady’s story appears in Wednesday’s paper. Ms. Addario, reached via phone from London, where she lives, spoke with James Estrin. Their conversation has been edited.

headline: A Spark Snuffed by Drink and Ire
abstract: In “Burton and Taylor,” Dominic West and Helena Bonham Carter portray the famous lovers and stars, who knew how to hurt each other the most.
lead_paragraph: Tempestuous love affairs cool down. Even Elizabeth Taylor couldn’t remain, as Richard Burton once described her in his diary, “an eternal one-night stand.”

headline: Williamstown Artistic Director to Lead Friends of the High Line
abstract: Jenny Gersten, who has been artistic director of the Williamstown Theater Festival for three seasons, will become executive director of the organization that runs the High Line park in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Jenny Gersten, the artistic director of Williamstown Theater Festival, will step down at the end of the year to become executive director of Friends of the High Line, the nonprofit organization that runs the former elevated railway, the festival announced on Tuesday.

headline: Belafonte Sues Heirs of Martin Luther King Jr.
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Archives and Records', 'Wills and Estates', 'Memorabilia and Souvenirs']
abstract: Harry Belafonte has filed a lawsuit in federal court against the three surviving children of one of his closest friends over items that used to be in Mr. Belafonte’s collection of King memorabilia.
lead_paragraph: Harry Belafonte is 86, an age that tends to focus the mind on putting one’s affairs in order. And that is why, Mr. Belafonte says, he has filed a lawsuit in federal court against the three surviving children of one of his closest friends: the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: Uganda Fights Stigma and Poverty to Take On Breast Cancer
abstract: Women in Africa face long delays in treatment, a problem that Uganda is hoping to confront with a new hospital and clinic.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — Mary Namata unbuttoned her dress in an examining room at Mulago Hospital, revealing a breast taut and swollen with grape-size tumors that looked as if they might burst through the skin.

headline: Without Taking Sides, Vets Call for End to Shutdown
abstract: Facing steep, prolonged cuts in benefits, a coalition of 33 military and veterans groups huddled at the World War II Memorial on Tuesday to demand that lawmakers reopen the government.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jon Kromer knows all too well the threat the government shutdown poses to military veterans and their families.

headline: For a Young Woman, Late Treatment and a Grim Diagnosis
abstract: Jessy Acen, 30, must travel nearly 200 miles to the Uganda Cancer Institute to be treated for an advanced case of breast cancer.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — Related Article: Uganda Fights Stigma and Poverty to Take On Breast Cancer

headline: JPMorgan Expected to Admit Fault in ‘London Whale’ Trading Loss
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Aside from admitting some wrongdoing, the bank is expected to pay about $100 million to resolve the case with Commodity Futures Trading Commission as soon as this week.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:25 p.m. | For JPMorgan Chase, fines totaling billions of dollars are no longer sufficient to placate the government. Now the bank’s regulators want something stiffer: a mea culpa.

headline: Two Windows Into Cancer, the Imperiled Moose
abstract: New research tries to break through cancer’s protective shield and women with breast cancer in Uganda face terrible challenges; the weather turns on North America’s forest giant.
lead_paragraph: New research tries to break through cancer’s protective shield and women with breast cancer in Uganda face terrible challenges; the weather turns on North America’s forest giant.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Angela Ahrendts Earns Her Stripes, and Eric Schmidt’s Face on Google Ads
abstract: Tuesday’s highlights from around the Web include a 2010 profile of Apple’s new head of retailing and reactions to Google’s new shared endorsements.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 2,271 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 2,271 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: Can Marfa Bring Its Magic to Manhattan?
abstract: The small West Texas town is bringing its outsize cultural energy to the Big Apple in a series of environmentally focused arts events organized by Ballroom Marfa.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to be a scientist, engineer or policy maker to weigh in on the impact of climate change. Right now, all around New York City, visual artists, architects and performers are tackling the subject as part of Marfa Dialogues/New York, a two-month series of environmentally engaged public events.

headline: Oregon Father’s Memorial Trek Across Country Ends in a Family’s Second Tragedy
abstract: Joe Bell, who was walking across the country to memorialize his gay son, who committed suicide after being bullied, was killed by a tractor-trailer in Colorado.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — As he made his way across the country, Joe Bell walked through rain squalls, slept in ditches and talked to anyone who would listen about how his gay son had killed himself after being taunted and bullied at school.

headline: Yet Another Way to Mock China’s New Rich
abstract: The phrase tuhao, once used by the Communists to describe feudal landlords, has been appropriated by China’s online masses deride the vulgar tastes of the country’s new rich.
lead_paragraph: When Apple introduced the iPhone 5s in China last month, demand was predictably overwhelming. Less predictable, however, was the online reaction when the gold-colored version of the phone sold out almost instantly.

headline: Fact-Check: Lhota and Republicans
abstract: Mr. de Blasio and Mr. Lhota are having an argument about whether Mr. Lhota shares the views of the national Republican party. Mr. de Blasio says he does; Mr. Lhota says he doesn’t.

headline: Fact-Check: De Blasio Raising Taxes
abstract: Mr. Lhota charged that Mr. de Blasio has a history of raising taxes. Indeed, in 2003, while Mr. de Blasio was in the City Council, the Council voted to raise property taxes by 18.5 percent, as well as to increase the city sales tax and the income tax for top earners.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Lhota charged that Mr. de Blasio has a history of raising taxes. Indeed, in 2003, while Mr. de Blasio was in the City Council, the Council voted to raise property taxes by 18.5 percent, as well as to increase the city sales tax and the income tax for top earners. headline: Sorry, Kids. We Ate It All.
abstract: The ones who will really get hit by all the cans we’re kicking down the road are young people. Are they paying attention?
lead_paragraph: Eventually this shutdown crisis will end. And eventually the two parties will make another stab at a deal on taxes, investments and entitlements. But there’s one outcome from such negotiations that I can absolutely guarantee: Seniors, Wall Street and unions will all have their say and their interests protected. So the most likely result will be more tinkering around the edges, as our politicians run for the hills the minute someone accuses them of “fixing the deficit on the backs of the elderly” or creating “death panels” to sensibly allocate end-of-life health care. Could this time be different? Short of an economic meltdown, there is only one thing that might produce meaningful change: a mass movement for tax, spending and entitlement reform led by the cohort that is the least organized but will be the most affected if we don’t think long term — today’s young people.

The 65-year-old former leader had tried in vain to be sent to Rwanda. In a recent letter to the court he said it would be easier for his family to visit him in Africa. Mostly housed in elegant Renaissance buildings, the shops especially stand out because many preserve the increasingly hard-to-find tradition of making everything by hand.

headline: The Octopus That Almost Ate Seattle
abstract: The giant Pacific octopus is, in the words of a Seattle conservationist, a “glamour animal.” It is also tasty. Therein lies the conflict.
lead_paragraph: In the months leading up to the hunt, Dylan Mayer trained twice a week in his parents’ swimming pool, asking friends to attack him, splay their arms and grab him, drag him to the surface and shove him below it, pull off his mask, snatch his regulator, time his recovery. By last Halloween, he was ready, and as the light began to fade that afternoon, the broad-shouldered 19-year-old jumped into a red Ford pickup truck with his buddy and drove some 40 minutes from Maple Valley, Wash., to West Seattle. They arrived at Alki Beach around 4 p.m., put on their wet suits and ambled into Cove 2. Then they slipped into Elliott Bay, the Space Needle punctuating the city line in the distance like an inverted exclamation point.

headline: In Thailand, Redefining the Tastes of Childhood
abstract: When American parents raise children in other cultures, they find that the foods of their childhood seem foreign to their own children.
lead_paragraph: I grew up on turkey and cheese sandwiches, Frosted Flakes and Capri Suns. In elementary school, I proudly traded my Fruit Roll-Up for Kraft’s cracker and cheese dip and my Cool Ranch Doritos for California Raisins. I was an all-American girl growing up in homogeneously backwater north Florida. This was the land of hamburger cookouts and pizza parties. Yoo-hoos after a long day of water skiing. A trip to IHOP for pancakes and eggs after a Sunday Southern Baptist revival.

headline: Max Irons: Out of Character, but in His Element
abstract: Mr. Irons, who plays a king on TV, can claim a regal bloodline of his own as a son of Jeremy Irons and Sinéad Cusack.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Wednesday, the British actor Max Irons accompanied a reporter to the Cloisters, the museum devoted to the art of medieval Europe. It was a setting that may have felt familiar to King Edward IV, the character Mr. Irons plays on the Starz series “The White Queen,” a lusty take on the Wars of the Roses.

abstract: Knight Capital’s settlement with the S.E.C. stems from a wave of accidental stock orders on Aug. 1, 2012, that reverberated through the market and resulted in a $460 million loss for the trading firm.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Aug. 1 2012, Knight Capital, Wall Street’s biggest trading firm, sent out a wave of accidental stock orders – more than four million – that reverberated through the market and eventually resulted in a $460 million loss for the firm.

headline: On the Verge | Trousdale, Los Angeles’s Forgotten Architectural Mecca, Makes a Comeback
abstract: Once a chic address for Hollywood stars, the neighborhood features spades of midcentury masterpieces, which are luring a fresh crop of glamorous Angelenos.
lead_paragraph: Once favored by the leading lights of Old Hollywood, the Trousdale section of Los Angeles fell out of fashion in the ’70s — its trove of midcentury architecture tarted up or torn down — only to be rediscovered by a new wave of glamorous Angelenos devoted to preserving its unique style. It’s ready for its close-up, again. See the slide show.

headline: New York Guitar Festival to Return in January
abstract: The festival will run for three weeks in Manhattan starting on Jan. 10, with many free events.
lead_paragraph: When David Spelman presented the last installment of the biennial New York Guitar Festival, in 2012, he mused, in a New York Times interview, about putting the festival on hiatus. But when he was asked whether that meant that there would be no 2014 festival, Mr. Spelman said, “I always answer my cellphone. And I don’t like to say no.”

headline: Boehner Supports Deal, but Says G.O.P. ‘Fight Will Continue’
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: House Speaker John A. Boehner threw his weight on Wednesday behind the Senate deal to reopen the government and avert a default. He pledged to continue fighting President Obama’s health care law, but in a different manner.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Speaker John A. Boehner threw his weight on Wednesday behind the Senate deal to reopen the government and avert a default. He pledged to continue fighting President Obama’s health care law, but in a different manner.

headline: Facebook Eases Privacy Rules for Teenagers
abstract: Teenagers will now be able to post items that can be seen by the public, making it easier for the social network to turn a post into an ad that can be shown widely.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Facebook has loosened its privacy rules for teenagers as a debate swirls over online threats to children from bullies and sexual predators.

headline: Even a Doomed Queen Just Wants to Have Fun
abstract: “Reign,” making its debut Thursday on CW, focuses on the tumultuous teenage years of Mary, Queen of Scots.
lead_paragraph: Every new television season should have a camp classic, but it’s been hard to find one among the grindingly dull shows trotted out this fall. ABC’s “Betrayal” had promise, with some risible plots and ripe performances (Henry Thomas as a brain-damaged scion and James Cromwell as his imperious dad are a hoot), but it’s just not enough fun.

headline: The Golden Years of Tavern on the Green
abstract: The restaurant’s cabaret phase, and other archival photos from this New York institution’s colorful past.

headline: Cyrus’s ‘Bangerz’ Hits No. 1
abstract: Miley Cyrus easily clinched the top spot on Billboard’s album chart.
lead_paragraph: With a blitz of media and constant online chatter, Miley Cyrus easily clinched the top spot on Billboard’s album chart this week. “Bangerz” (RCA), her latest, opened with 270,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, becoming Ms. Cyrus’s fifth No. 1 album, including three released under her Disney alter ego, Hannah Montana. “Bangerz” also tops the charts in Britain, Canada, Australia and Ireland this week. Ms. Cyrus, 20, has been perhaps the most unavoidable figure in pop culture since at least Aug. 25, when her hypersexed, tongue-wagging performance stole the show at the MTV Video Music Awards.

headline: Jury Rules for Mark Cuban in Setback for S.E.C.
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission’s loss could reignite concerns about the agency’s struggles in the courtroom.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:42 p.m. | The government mocked Mark Cuban as a winner in “his mind,” claiming that the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks basketball team possessed a “competitive edge” that drove him to insider trading.

headline: At the New York Premiere of ‘Her,’ a Party Makes Do Without Its Voice
abstract: Some in the audience were troubled by the larger questions the film raises about romantic love and our overdependence on technology.
lead_paragraph: One important guest was missing from the New York premiere of “Her,” the new movie from Spike Jonze, which closed the New York Film Festival on Saturday night: the woman who plays the title character.

headline: A Lesson in Time Management for a Wagner Coach
abstract: Bashir Mason, 29, is balancing his duties as men’s basketball coach at Wagner with student teaching, his final requirement for a master’s in education.
lead_paragraph: The first-grade students at Public School 80 entered Room 108 single file at 8:10 on a clear and blustery morning on Staten Island, placed their book bags in cubbyholes and waited. It was time for Bashir Mason to check their homework.

headline: Gadgets to Help the Party Host
abstract: A robotic bartender will soon join a group of gadgets to help you throw a holiday or tailgate party to remember.
lead_paragraph: The stresses of hosting a party can pile up this time of year. Whether it’s for a holiday get-together or a tailgate extravaganza, drinks must be mixed and food must be cooked, preferably with a carefree attitude that puts your guests in awe of your party-throwing prowess.

headline: Life on Ships That Make World Go Round
abstract: In “Ninety Percent of Everything,” the British writer Rose George catches a ride on a giant container ship.
lead_paragraph: Rose George is a young British journalist who writes smart books about subjects we mostly prefer not to think about. Her last one, “The Big Necessity” (2008), about human waste and society, is among the best nonfiction books of the new millennium. Give the paperback edition to the person in your life who never puts down the toilet seat.

headline: Times Reporter Plans to Take Fight to the Supreme Court
abstract: The Times’s James Risen, protecting a confidential source, says he “will go to jail if necessary.”
lead_paragraph: For James Risen, an investigative reporter for The Times, the bad news just keeps on coming. When I wrote about him in late July, a federal appeals panel had just ruled against him in a case related to a leak investigation.

headline: How to Get Your Last Name Posted After You Win a Learning Network Student Contest
abstract: If you have been chosen as a winner in a Learning Network contest at any time since Sept. 2013, you can now follow these directions to have your last name added to the announcement.
lead_paragraph: We like having student contests on The Learning Network, and we run them regularly.

headline: On Glowing Pickles and Undiscovered Galaxies: Student STEM Contest Winners
abstract: Eleven winners of the contest we ran in collaboration with Science Times this September describe engaging, hands-on projects in science, math and engineering.
lead_paragraph: A video sent in by  one of many students who entered our contest from a Project Lead the Way school.

headline: An Assassin Abroad: Peter Savodnik Talks About ‘The Interloper’
abstract: Mr. Savodnik’s new book looks at the time Lee Harvey Oswald spent living in the Soviet Union.
lead_paragraph: For most of us, Lee Harvey Oswald exists most vividly in downtown Dallas, poised to make the worst kind of history. In his new book, “The Interloper,” Peter Savodnik recounts Oswald’s time living and working in the Soviet Union. He went in 1960, with the hopes of building a permanent existence there after a childhood of frequent moves. He found his future wife, and became a father for the first time, but he returned to the United States in 1962, bitterly disappointed in his failure to start over in Russia. Mr. Savodnik argues that this time overseas reveals a great deal about Oswald’s personality and his infamous crime. In a recent e-mail interview, Mr. Savodnik discussed Oswald’s time in Minsk, the Russian view of conspiracy theories and more. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Robert Rauschenberg and Photography
abstract: A new show Pace/MacGill Gallery explores photography’s role at the center of Rauschenberg’s work.
lead_paragraph: A new show Pace/MacGill Gallery explores photography’s role at the center of Rauschenberg’s work.

headline: Taking Flight Without Taking Off
abstract: Fly the Dream, a new virtual entertainment store, offers customers the opportunity to simulate flying an F-16 Falcon.
lead_paragraph: Travelers who fancy themselves flyboys and girls can test their skills at Fly the Dream, a new virtual entertainment store where customers can navigate a simulated flight of an F-16 Falcon, a single-engine fighter aircraft developed by General Dynamics for the Air Force in the early 1970s.

headline: Aggression Unleashed, and Moderated Too, in Pumped-Up Touring Return
abstract: Nine Inch Nails, with Trent Reznor as its frontman and creative force, brought its “Tension” tour (the band’s first since 2009) to Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: Trent Reznor’s recent record with Nine Inch Nails, “Hesitation Marks,” represents a self-possessed next move for a band whose old meanings have been displaced, if not entirely eclipsed. The currents that it rose from in the late ’80s — harsh and jabbering industrial music, creep-out cinema, roaring psychosexual anger — long ago became normalized; as elements of art, those things live and die on immediate response and don’t get the kind the group desires anymore, especially from fans in their 40s.

headline: A ‘Wild’ Book Tour With a Soundtrack
keywords: ['ARCTIC NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE', 'Books and Literature', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Environment', 'Hunting and Trapping', 'Polar Bears', 'Turtles and Tortoises', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries']
abstract: As an author reads about the strange relationship between people and wild animals, accordions and strings provide a soundtrack.
lead_paragraph: As I dig out of a mountain of work built up after recent travels in Asia, I’m enjoying listening to Jon Mooallem read excerpts from “Wild Ones,” his alternately amusing and unsettling book about the human species’ dysfunctional relationship with all manner of wild animals (he focuses on the American subspecies of humans).
