lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kerri and Brian Kaley, a New York couple, were unable to hire a lawyer to defend themselves against serious criminal charges because the government had frozen their assets. That seemed to trouble several justices at a Supreme Court argument on Wednesday.

headline: 110 Seconds With Pogue: Windows 8.1

lead_paragraph: The Times’s David Pogue weighed in on the updates to Microsoft’s Windows 8 operating systems, one of which is designed for desktops, the other for tablets.

headline: Ronan Farrow to Host Show on MSNBC
abstract: Mr. Farrow, son of Mia Farrow and Woody Allen, will take over an hour of the cable channel’s weekday schedule starting early next year.
lead_paragraph: The search for new hosts for cable news programs turned up a familiar name on Wednesday when MSNBC announced that it had hired Ronan Farrow, son of Mia Farrow and Woody Allen, to take over an hour of its weekday schedule starting early next year.

abstract: After a year of tinkering with the much-criticized Windows 8, Microsoft unveils (drumroll) Windows 8.1. The changes are many and useful.

Boehner explained to his conference that he would be taking up the Senate deal and likely passing it with the help of Democratic votes, Republican lawmakers were already regrouping for the next fight.

headline: Roundup at the Chelsea Hall, With Flinging, Stumbling, Collapsing
abstract: The Lar Lubovitch Dance Company includes a premiere, “Crazy 8’s,” in its second program at the Joyce Theater in its 45th anniversary season.
lead_paragraph: Forty-five years is a long time, as far as choreographic careers go — long enough, in Lar Lubovitch’s case, to have created more than 100 works. That kind of experience might bring a certain comfort with trying new ideas. A dance about cowboys? Hey, why not?

headline: Rhapsody in Deal to Expand in Latin America
abstract: The subscription music service is expanding to six Latin American countries through a bundling deal with Telefónica.
lead_paragraph: Rhapsody, the subscription music service, is expanding to Latin America through a bundling deal with Telefónica, one of the world’s largest telecom providers.

headline: Forget the Spoonful of Sugar: It’s Uncle Walt, Uncensored
abstract: Producers of the Disney movie “Saving Mr. Banks,” about the filming of “Mary Poppins,” say the studio did not pressure them to sanitize the portrayal of Walt Disney.
lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif. — In the coming movie “Saving Mr. Banks,” a comedic drama about the turbulent making of “Mary Poppins” in the 1960s, Walt Disney acts in a very un-Disney way. He slugs back Scotch. He uses a mild curse word. He wheezes because he smokes too much.

headline: Be as Creative as a Kindergartner
abstract: Tom and David Kelley of the design firm IDEO talk about their new book, “Creative Confidence,” which offers a range of strategies for winning back the kind of creativity evident on a kindergarten playground, using “design thinking” methodologies their firm popularized.
lead_paragraph: Tom and David Kelley are brothers behind the design and consulting firm IDEO known for designing the first Apple mouse and an early laptop computer. David Kelley also founded the d.school Institute of Design at Stanford while Tom Kelley wrote the popular book “The Art of Innovation,” in 2001.

headline: Milder Accounts of Hardships Under Mao Arise as His Birthday Nears
abstract: As the 120th anniversary of Mao Zedong’s birth approaches, some are playing down the devastation of the famine that gripped China from 1958 to 1962.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The famine that gripped China from 1958 to 1962 is widely judged to be the deadliest in recorded history, killing 20 to 30 million people or more, and is one of the defining calamities of Mao Zedong’s rule. Ever since, the party has shrouded that disaster in censorship and euphemisms, seeking to maintain an aura of reverence around the founding leader of the Communist state.

headline: Muscle and Speed Win a Crowd’s Adulation
abstract: Denis Matsuev, piano soloist performing with the Mariinsky Orchestra, drew a demonstrative audience at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The Mariinsky Orchestra‘s three-concert stand at Carnegie Hall, which ended on Tuesday evening, was billed as a 60th-birthday celebration for its music director, Valery Gergiev. And Mr. Gergiev was indeed the center of attention at the first concert, last Thursday (reviewed earlier), when he led a long program of Stravinsky ballet scores and was the target of protests by gay-rights activists for supporting the candidacy of the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, who is limiting dialogue on homosexuality in Russia.

headline: Urban Living
abstract: The next mayor should keep architecture and planning front and center, a critic argues.
lead_paragraph: The next mayor should keep architecture and planning front and center, a critic argues.

headline: States Report Health Insurance Application Numbers
abstract: Minnesota’s state-run health insurance exchange reported on Wednesday that 5,569 households had completed applications for coverage in the first two weeks of operation, representing 11,684 people.
lead_paragraph: Minnesota’s state-run health insurance exchange reported Wednesday that 5,569 households had completed applications for coverage in the first two weeks of operation, representing 11,684 people. The exchange portal has run relatively smoothly after struggling with technology problems for a few days after it opened on Oct. 1, said April Todd-Malmlov, the executive director.

headline: Reflections on a Couple of Boston Homers
abstract: A portly Boston cop hailing a home run in the Fenway bullpen? This was a meme before it was a meme.
lead_paragraph: Before Torii Hunter even finished flipping over the wall at Fenway Park on Sunday night, before he even hit the ground, the image of his flailing legs juxtaposed against the raised arms of a triumphant Boston police officer had already become a baseball classic.

headline: An Artist Who Gets a Lift From Gravity
abstract: Beginning tomorrow in Los Angeles, John Knuth will exhibit process-based pieces derived from light bulbs, melted sugar and smoke that rely on gravitational pull for their shape.
lead_paragraph: John Knuth comes from a school of artists who allow nature to activate their works. But unlike some who let their pieces be entirely dictated by the whims of the elements, the Los Angeles-based artist remains involved with the process, exerting a measure of control over his science-based abstractions. His recent series of fly paintings — in which he fed the insects pigment, which they then regurgitated onto canvases — were ironically beautiful gradients of pointillist abstraction. For his next body of work, which he will create on site at Human Resources, an art space in Los Angeles’s Chinatown, the process is even messier.

headline: Building a Better City
abstract: The next mayor needs to consider a wide range of design and development issues to assure New York’s competitive future.
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 1, the next mayor — either Bill de Blasio, the Democratic candidate, or Joe Lhota, the Republican — will face a fiscal cliff of unpaid bills. Schools will need to be saved, union contracts negotiated — the future of New York envisioned.

headline: A Computer Championship in Indonesia
keywords: ['Cards and Card Games', 'Bridge (Card Game)', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The computers Jack and WBridge5 competed for a title last month.
lead_paragraph: How would you compare humans with computer programs when it comes to playing chess or bridge?

headline: Making Opera of Art and Vice Versa
abstract: The artist William Kentridge is hard at work on an opera, Berg’s “Lulu,” designing in miniature for a 2015 opening.
lead_paragraph: As a flickering projector beamed film fragments and India ink drawings into a dollhouse-size model of the Metropolitan Opera’s gold proscenium in a small workroom not far from the real stage, the artist William Kentridge was explaining how some of the embryonic images flitting by would be developed over the next two years into his new production of Alban Berg’s “Lulu.”

headline: One Met Isn’t Enough
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art will be showing William Kentridge’s video “The Refusal of Time” starting on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: When “The Refusal of Time,” a multimedia installation and meditation on time by the South African artist William Kentridge had its premiere last summer at (d)ocumenta 13 in Kassel, Germany, Neal Benezra, director of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, had his eye on acquiring it.

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: Shutdown Dysfunction, and Smile, You’re Being Tracked
abstract: Wednesday’s highlights from around the Web include an argument that Silicon Valley’s denizens have actually delighted in the political fiasco resulting from the government shutdown. Plus, a claim from a French organization that there’s no such thing as “anonymous data.”
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Thierry-Maxime Loriot, Curator of the Jean Paul Gaultier Exhibition
abstract: The Gaultier exhibition was built by Mr. Loriot, someone who has been inside the fashion world.
lead_paragraph: THE RUFFLE-AND-ROSETTE-FESTOONED corset that was being prepared for the Jean Paul Gaultier fashion exhibition making its long-awaited tour stop in New York at the Brooklyn Museum, beginning Oct. 25, had discreet panels of stretch fabric sewn into the sides. It was a spring 2011 sample created for Beth Ditto, the outspoken singer who once took Topshop to task for not offering larger sizes, who once pointed out that Karl Lagerfeld is a former “fat kid,” and who is not someone you would ever have expected to be found on a designer runway.

headline: Kim Kardashian’s Ex Sells the Engagement Ring
abstract: The ring, which reportedly cost Kris Humphries $2 million, was auctioned on Tuesday for $749,000 (including the commission). Twitter users respond.
lead_paragraph: Kris Humphries, the Boston Celtics player known formerly as Kim Kardashian’s husband, has sold the 20.5-carat engagement ring he gave to his former wife. The ring, which reportedly cost him $2 million, was auctioned on Tuesday by Christie’s in New York for $749,000 (including the commission). That topped the auction house’s presale estimate of $300,000 to $500,000, but Twitter users were quick to point out the losing numbers.

headline: New York Department Stores Revamp Cosmetics and Fragrance Sections
abstract: Many New York department stores are revamping their areas devoted to cosmetics, skin care and fragrances.
lead_paragraph: With increasing competition from specialized retailers like Sephora and Ulta, as well as the Internet, several New York City department stores have, perhaps necessarily, decided to give their areas dedicated to cosmetics, skin care and fragrances a makeover.

headline: Furor Over Yahoo Mail Changes
abstract: An upgrade to Yahoo Mail has longtime users summoning their online pitchforks.
lead_paragraph: It has become the online equivalent of a riot.

headline: Columbia to House a Trove of Prokofiev’s Items
abstract: Items and papers that once belonged to the composer Sergei Prokofiev, mostly from 1918 to 1938, will be more accessible to scholars.
lead_paragraph: A foundation dedicated to Sergei Prokofiev will give a priceless trove of musical manuscripts, letters and other items belonging to the composer — including a suitcase — to the Rare Book & Manuscript Library at Columbia in an effort to make them more accessible to scholars. Most of the materials represent Prokofiev’s work from 1918 to 1938, the years he visited or lived in the West.

headline: Two Longtime Gossip Columnists Share Their Secrets (Well, Some of Them)
abstract: George Rush and Joanna Molloy, the media duo who dished dirt for the tabloids, are back and they have a lot of material to draw from.
lead_paragraph: When gossip columnists get a juicy tip but the sourcing is problematic, there’s a tradition called the blind item, in which the subjects are described in detail but not named. As in: What married media duo could not stop bickering during a two-and-a-half-hour interview with a reporter?

headline: A Line of Luxe Basics Made for Dancing
abstract: Nili Lotan’s performance-based presentation of her spring collection was a refreshing alternative to the usual fashion shows, and highlighted the clothes’ simple, utilitarian grace.
lead_paragraph: Nili Lotan, whose namesake line of luxe basics is a wardrobe staple for both celebrities and everyday, on-the-go women, introduced her spring 2014 collection last Thursday with a performance in her TriBeCa showroom. The Israeli-American designer said that the “very minimal, clean, pure” aesthetic of her 25 new pieces remained true to the vision of her very first collection a decade ago. To present the clothes, she commissioned LeeSaar the Company to incorporate them into an original modern dance, but because the spring looks weren’t designed specifically for dancers, she faced a few obstacles in preparing for the unusual show format. “It’s not models, so you’re not dealing with size 2,” she said. “They’re short and they’re big-muscled, and it was a challenge because most of the samples are a size 2, size 4.” She wound up designing special briefs for the dancers to perform in.

headline: Settlement Report Finds Banks Giving Timely Mortgage Relief

abstract: Under the $25 billion national mortgage settlement intended to help at-risk homeowners, more gave up their homes in short sales than stayed in their homes through debt reduction.
lead_paragraph: The $25 billion national mortgage settlement, intended to help homeowners affected by the housing crisis, appears to be running ahead of schedule, according to a new report by the monitor of the program.

headline: Lifted From a Russian Lake, a Big, if Fragile, Space Rock
abstract: As Russian officials on Wednesday retrieved a 1,250-pound fragment of a meteor that exploded last February over Chelyabinsk, the rock broke — and broke a scale.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russian officials on Wednesday retrieved the largest fragment so far of a meteor that exploded in February over the city of Chelyabinsk, but as divers and a mechanical winch lifted it from the bottom of a lake, the rock broke into three pieces, and then broke the scale — literally — when all together it weighed in at more than 1,250 pounds.

headline: After Decades, a Water Tunnel Can Now Serve All of Manhattan
abstract: The most recently completed section of Water Tunnel No. 3, considered the largest capital construction project ever undertaken in New York City, was opened on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Of all New York City’s sprawling mega-projects, the water tunnel snaking beneath the grid — connecting the Bronx to Upper Manhattan, Upper Manhattan to Central Park, Central Park to Queens, and, eventually, Queens to the western edge of Brooklyn — is perhaps the hardest to love.

lead_paragraph: Brad Cloepfil, an architect known for designing buildings like the Seattle Art Museum and the Museum of Arts and Design in Manhattan, developed his interest in wine in a roundabout way.

headline: Discounts at Jonathan Adler, Garnet Hill and Others
abstract: Bargains on glassware, furniture and pillows.
lead_paragraph: Selected glassware is 30 percent off at Apartment 48 Thursday through Oct. 31 (the Mod hourglass, regularly $38, is about $27); (212) 807-1391, apartment48.com.

headline: Waltzing With the Stars
abstract: Stillfried Wien in TriBeCa sells design from German-speaking Europe.
lead_paragraph: Although Vienna was a birthplace of modernism, its contemporary designers get scant notice in the United States. At least, that’s the view of Michael and Anna Trubrig, a Viennese couple who recently opened Stillfried Wien in TriBeCa to offer vintage and new items from Austria, Germany and Switzerland.

headline: Don’t Try This in Yoga Class
abstract: Pablo’s new Circa lamp rotates and bends for extreme versatility.
lead_paragraph: Pablo Pardo, a Venezuelan-born industrial designer who worked for Fisher-Price and DaimlerChrysler, started his own lighting company, Pablo, in San Francisco 20 years ago. The business has grown in prestige because of products like Circa, a new lamp that supplies balanced light via a flat-panel LED screen. A round shade-like element, which houses the LEDs, rotates a full 360 degrees and tilts 45 degrees to send the light were it is needed. The lamp also features a four-stage dimmer control and, on most of the models, a USB port for charging mobile gadgets.

headline: If You Could Make It There, You Were Made
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Eight homes on Strivers’ Row in Harlem will be open to the public on Oct. 20.
lead_paragraph: They were built as speculative housing in the last years of the 19th century, two blocks of elegant town houses in Harlem, divvied up between three architectural teams, including one led by Stanford White. When they were finished, ownership was restricted to whites only. But by the 1920s, the King Model Houses, named for their developer, David King, and known colloquially as Strivers’ Row, had become home to black artists, socialites and professionals like Scott Joplin, Eubie Blake and Dr. Louis T. Wright.

headline: Bonnie Prints
abstract: A wallpaper collection from Lake August was inspired by the designer’s trip to Scotland.
lead_paragraph: Scotland has inspired schoolgirl uniforms, a New Year’s Eve song and a Mel Gibson epic, and now it must be credited for wallpaper patterns by Lake August, a Los Angeles company. Alexis Hartman, Lake August’s founder and designer, resolved to start the business while traveling in Scotland a few years ago and realized her ambition earlier this year.

headline: Chip Kidd: Start Making Sense
abstract: The designer on his new book, “Go: A Kidd’s Guide to Graphic Design.”
lead_paragraph: After 27 years of designing book covers for Knopf, Chip Kidd, the noted graphic artist, novelist and interpreter of superheroes in books like “Batman: Death by Design,” is passing on his wisdom to children. “Go: A Kidd’s Guide to Graphic Design”($17.95) came out this week from Workman Publishing. In 150 highly legible and humorous pages, it manages to teach the principles of form, content, color, type and even a bit of history.

headline: Putting Their Stamp on It
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: A couple switches coasts, settling into what was once a library. Apparently, a former occupant approves.
lead_paragraph: When Karen Gilliam and Sara Van Beckum began renovating their home in Portland, Ore., which once served as the local branch library, they weren’t planning to live there full time. The couple, who are voice-over artists, were based in New York City and intended to split their time between New York and Oregon.

headline: China, Spitting and Global Tourism
abstract: Spitting is a major reason Chinese tourists can feel unwelcome abroad, commentators say. Westerners find it disgusting. Should China modify its behavior, or expect others to deal with it?
lead_paragraph: Living in Beijing a long time, you learn to anticipate a spitter. The crackling crescendo may begin as he nears, leaving you wondering — is it a territorial thing? Then the finale: a terrific “ptchoo!” and an opalescent glob whirling like a tiny Frisbee into the gutter or onto the pavement near your feet. Or your eye, as happened to my companion standing downwind from a spitter at an open train window, in the western region of Xinjiang.

lead_paragraph: It was awkward, in more ways than one.

headline: Scattered by War, Syrians Struggle to Start Over

abstract: The plight of a family that fled to Jordan shows how the war has forced Syrians to remake their lives in new and often unwelcoming places.
lead_paragraph: MAFRAQ, Jordan — Watering the plants on her balcony back home in Syria this spring, Wedad Sarhan took delight in how they were stirring to life after the winter months. A jasmine tree filled the small balcony with its sweet scent. An apricot tree, planted eight springs earlier, was blossoming for the first time.

headline: Theater, Dance, Film, Pop: Don’t Pin Him Down
abstract: The opera composer Nico Muhly has classical projects on tap, of course, but also works in other performing arts.
lead_paragraph: His schedule crowded and his list of collaborators long, Nico Muhly has many other projects planned for this year and next in addition to “Two Boys,” opening on Monday at the Metropolitan Opera. His recent New York premieres have ranged from the melancholy score for the choreographer Benjamin Millepied’s “Neverwhere,” which had its debut with New York City Ballet last month, to sensitive music for a new production of “The Glass Menagerie,” now on Broadway. Here is a look at nine other Muhly projects, from arrangements for an Icelandic pop artist’s lushly wistful new album to songs for an eminent mezzo-soprano and pianist.

headline: When the Gold Dust Settles
abstract: Eleanor Catton’s Booker Prize winner is a mystery set in 19th-century New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: “The Luminaries,” Eleanor Catton’s remarkable second novel — the winner of this year’s Man Booker Prize — is a lot of things, and I mean a lot, but above all, perhaps, it is a love story, one that takes all of 826 pages to truly arrive. And it’s not even a novel in the normal sense, but rather a mass confabulation that evaporates in front of us, an astrological divination waning like the moon, the first section 360 pages long (or are those degrees?), the last a mere sliver. But it’s a sliver that delivers.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Playing a game in the East for the first time this season turned out to be just what the Rangers needed. They dominated the Washington Capitals, 2-0, on Wednesday, their most impressive outing of an otherwise dreadful start to the campaign.

headline: Massachusetts: Bomb Suspects’ Sister in Court
keywords: ['Boston Marathon Bombings (2013)', 'Counterfeit Money and Financial Instruments']
abstract: A sister of the Boston Marathon bombing suspects Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev appeared in a South Boston district court Wednesday to address an outstanding warrant.
lead_paragraph: A sister of the Boston Marathon bombing suspects Tamerlan and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev appeared in a South Boston district court on Wednesday to address an outstanding warrant for her arrest. The woman, Ailina Tsarnaeva, 23, was arraigned in January 2011 on a charge that she misled an investigator looking into the passing of a counterfeit bill at a Boston Applebee’s; the warrant was issued when she failed to appear later for a court date. Prosecutors say that she knew members of the group that allegedly used the bill, but that she lied to the police about the incident. On Wednesday, Judge Michael C. Bolden released Ms. Tsarnaeva, who now lives in New Jersey, on $1,500 personal recognizance and required her to check in weekly with probation officers. She could face up to 2.5 years in prison if convicted.

headline: Iran's Nuclear Talks in Geneva

headline: Massachusetts Schools Dial Back on Obesity Reports
abstract: The state Public Health Council voted Wednesday to stop automatically sending letters home with public school students about their weight.
lead_paragraph: The state Public Health Council voted Wednesday to stop automatically sending letters home with public school students about their weight. The state is one of 21 that collect data about students’ body mass index, but some parents say the letters with their children’s results can cause self-esteem problems and the risk of bullying. The testing will continue in Grades 1, 4, 7 and 10 with increased confidentiality protections; parents will receive results only if they ask for them.

Provopoulos, the governor of the Bank of Greece, who has played a crucial role in keeping Greece out of bankruptcy and in the euro zone.

headline: Body of Nazi War Criminal Moved to Airport in Rome After Clashes

abstract: The body of a notorious Nazi commander, who orchestrated the killing of 335 Italian civilians seven decades ago, was moved to a military airport on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Elisabetta Povoledo reported, a funeral for Erich Priebke, a former Nazi officer who died under house arrest in Rome last week while serving a life sentence in Italy for the wartime massacre of more than 300 civilians, was called off on Tuesday, after angry protests and clashes at a church run by renegade Catholics.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans conceded defeat Wednesday in their bitter budget fight with President Obama over the new health care law, agreeing to end a disruptive 16-day government shutdown and extend federal borrowing power to avert a financial default with potential worldwide economic repercussions.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Former Vice President Dick Cheney was so close to death in 2010 that he said farewell to his family members and instructed them to have his body cremated and the ashes returned to Wyoming, he writes in a new book on his long battle with heart disease.

headline: Thin at Running Back, the Giants Sign Hillis

lead_paragraph: The Giants on Wednesday signed the free-agent running back Peyton Hillis, who rushed for 1,177 yards for the Cleveland Browns three seasons ago. Hillis, a 6-foot-1, 245-pound, six-year veteran, has played for Denver, Cleveland and Kansas City. He was also with Tampa Bay during the preseason this year.

headline: Larry Benoit, ‘Babe Ruth for Hunters,’ Is Dead at 89
abstract: Mr. Benoit tracked whitetail deer through northern New England and southern Canada for more than seven decades and became one of the nation’s most revered deer hunters.
lead_paragraph: Larry Benoit, who tracked whitetail deer through the snowy woods of northern New England and southern Canada for more than seven decades, shooting at least 200 of the biggest and most prized specimens, known as trophy bucks, while becoming one of the nation’s most revered deer hunters, died on Oct. 8 at his home in Duxbury, Vt. He was 89.

headline: Obama Addresses Deal to End Fiscal Dispute

headline: Assault of Dutch Diplomat in Moscow Frays Ties Between Russia and the Netherlands

lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The year 2013 was officially supposed to be one of cultural exchange to highlight the friendship between Russia and the Netherlands. But lately, the most common exchanges between officials have been threats and legal actions amid an intensifying quarrel over the arrest and prosecution of Dutch citizens detained by the Russian Coast Guard aboard a Greenpeace ship flagged in the Netherlands.

headline: Hugh White on ‘The China Choice’
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: In a new book, Hugh White, a former Australian government defense official and now a professor of strategic studies at Australian National University, argues that by accommodating China, the United States would reduce what he sees as the escalating chance of war.
lead_paragraph: Australia has always been one of the United States’ most loyal allies, but now that the Australian economy depends mightily on the sale of iron ore to China, attitudes are a little more blurred. So perhaps it is not surprising that a provocative thesis — that the United States should share power with China in the Asia-Pacific region — should come from a former Australian government defense official.

headline: Stumbling Blocks in Reducing Balance on a Student Loan

headline: Sebelius Stands Firm Despite Calls to Resign

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kathleen Sebelius, the secretary of health and human services, has no intention of bowing to Republican demands that she resign after the troubled rollout of President Obama’s health care law, people close to her said Wednesday. And the White House expressed “full confidence” in her.

headline: Second Thoughts on Voter ID
abstract: Could a federal judge’s admirable candor about making a mistake on a decision have an effect on whether such laws will continue to be upheld?
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Richard Posner, a highly respected federal judge, offered an unusual admission. He had made a mistake, he said, in voting to uphold one of the country’s first voter-ID laws. As courts in Texas, North Carolina and other states deal with litigation over ever-stricter versions of such laws — all enacted in the name of preventing nonexistent fraud — the question is what effect Judge Posner’s admirable candor could have.

headline: The Disappearing Moose
abstract: A warming climate and an eroding winter are doing grievous harm to the species, which is dying off across North America.
lead_paragraph: For such large creatures, moose are a relatively hidden species. They are hard to count. They live where humans do not like to go, along the boggy fringes of northern lakes and rivers where the sound of summer mosquitoes fills the air. They thrive in cold weather, and their well-being depends on sharp, cold autumns and late springs, which protect them from their most important predator: not the wolf, but the winter tick.

lead_paragraph: Robin Hammond just “thought it was cool” when he enrolled in a photography program in Wellington, New Zealand. But he soon found a serious calling as a photographer while paging through a copy of W. Eugene Smith’s “Minamata” in his college library.

abstract: The abortive evacuation was arranged in a small-scale local deal that some aid workers and others had hoped could become a blueprint for building trust.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — It seemed promising until the shelling started: under a brief cease-fire, 200 civilians were preparing to evacuate on Wednesday from a rebel-held town near Damascus that the government has blockaded for months. Their flight was arranged in a small-scale local deal that some aid workers and others hoped could become a blueprint for building trust and, perhaps, helping to end the war.

headline: A Tree Grows in Canada
keywords: ['Constitutions', 'Women and Girls', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Defense of Marriage Act (1996)']
abstract: Canada views its constitution as “a living tree capable of growth and expansion.” Such a tree is still alive in the United States — at least for now.
lead_paragraph: This Friday is Persons Day in Canada, a special day on the country’s calendar that commemorates, of all things, a judicial decision. It was on Oct. 18, 1929, that the Privy Council, a court in London that served then as the highest appeals court for Canada, declared women to come within the definition of “persons” in Canada’s basic law, thus qualifying them for appointment to the national Senate. It was, Beverley McLachlin, the chief justice of Canada, said in a speech earlier this year, “the beginning of a rights revolution that would transform Canadian society.”

headline: Door May Open for Challenge to Secret Wiretaps

abstract: Prosecutors for the first time are telling a defendant that evidence came from eavesdropping, setting up a legal test of the government’s sweeping warrantless surveillance program.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five years after Congress authorized a sweeping warrantless surveillance program, the Justice Department is setting up a potential Supreme Court test of whether it is constitutional by notifying a criminal defendant — for the first time — that evidence against him derived from the eavesdropping, according to officials.

headline: Latin America Brings Up Its Dead, Seeking Truth to Help Settle the Past

headline: My Cloistered Teenage Soul
abstract: I spent my high school years pretending to be someone else. So how could I call the reunion my own?
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, I found myself shifting nervously in the driver’s seat of a parked rental car and avoiding the rearview mirror, afraid I’d catch a disquieting glimpse of my adolescent self glaring back. I’ve never come entirely to grips with him — or rather, I’ve never entirely forgiven him his lies and his cowardice. And now that I was about to walk into my 20-year high school reunion, his ghost was unbearably palpable.

headline: Juror’s Gesture Livens CityTime Fraud Trial

abstract: Investor relief at a fiscal deal was tempered by the knowledge that it would not end budget crises in Washington. | A jury cleared Mark Cuban of wrongdoing in an insider trading case. | The restaurant company Darden is facing pressure to break itself up. | The governor of the Bank of Greece faces an investigation into whether he abused his position.
lead_paragraph: Investor relief on Wednesday at the last-minute agreement to raise the nation’s borrowing limit and end the government shutdown was tempered by the knowledge that the deal did not represent a permanent solution to the budget crises that have become more frequent in recent years, Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. Under the deal, the government will be financed through Jan. 15 and the Treasury will have borrowing powers until Feb. 7 — at which point sharp political divisions could re-emerge.

headline: What A Drag
abstract: It’s not just discretionary spending.
lead_paragraph: As many people have been pointing out, the economic costs of GOP attempts to rule by extortion didn’t begin with the shutdown/debt crisis, and haven’t ended with the (temporary?) resolution of that crisis. The now widely-cited Macroeconomic Advisers report estimated the cost of crisis-driven fiscal policy at 1 percentage point off the growth rate for three years, or roughly 3 percent now. More than half of this estimated cost comes from the “fiscal drag” of falling discretionary spending, with the rest coming from a (shaky) estimate of the impacts of fiscal uncertainty on borrowing costs.

headline: Key to Ants’ Evolution May Have Started With a Wasp

headline: The Blood and Tears, Not the Magnolias
abstract: Steve McQueen’s “12 Years a Slave,” based on the true story of Solomon Northup, drives straight to the heart of the cruelties of oppression.
lead_paragraph: “12 Years a Slave” isn’t the first movie about slavery in the United States — but it may be the one that finally makes it impossible for American cinema to continue to sell the ugly lies it’s been hawking for more than a century. Written by John Ridley and directed by Steve McQueen, it tells the true story of Solomon Northup, an African-American freeman who, in 1841, was snatched off the streets of Washington, and sold. It’s at once a familiar, utterly strange and deeply American story in which the period trappings long beloved by Hollywood — the paternalistic gentry with their pretty plantations, their genteel manners and all the fiddle-dee-dee rest — are the backdrop for an outrage.

lead_paragraph: Robert Rauschenberg, an artist of towering achievement, painted not only with the brush. He also employed, in his works on canvas, the photographs he took throughout his life, as well as found objects. Although the progression of his work aligns with Abstract Expressionism, Minimalism, Pop Art and Conceptual Art, no one movement can claim him. Rauschenberg said that when it came to photography, “the camera is the transport for my eye and carries my seeing from place to place.”

headline: Why Don’t More Owners Open Their Books?

For more than 35 years I’ve found that, when I share meaningful information with the people who work with me, our performance as a company improves. The process of sharing a company’s financial performance is known as open-book management.

headline: Market Report | What’s Black and White and Swirled All Over?
abstract: Designers are concocting new patterns of marble that are showing up on soft, silky clothing and in precious jewels and accessories.

Balenciaga printed icy variations onto the soft silk of a T-shirt and the structured leather of a pair of pumps, and Josh Goot used it on a silk skirt that looks like it’s made of actual stone. Other designers showcased the pattern in the precious materials of jewels and accessories. Lele Sadoughi created a classic bracelet with the timeless motif; Monique Péan encrusted rough, marbled agate with a showstopping design of shiny pavé diamonds; Ralph Lauren used antique-looking shades of marble for a modern iteration of standby tortoiseshell sunglasses; and Stella McCartney contrasted the bold, geometric lines of a clutch with swirling lines of black and white.

headline: The Challenge of Diabetes for Doctor and Patient
abstract: A diabetes diagnosis must trigger a flurry of life changes and is something patients will live with for the rest of their lives.
lead_paragraph: My patient was miserable — parched with thirst, exhausted and jumping up to go to the bathroom every few minutes. His vision was blurry and he’d been losing weight the last few weeks, despite eating voraciously. I’d only just met him, but I was able to diagnose diabetes in about a minute. What was unusual was that this was a scheduled office visit; usually, patients with such overwhelming symptoms are the provenance of emergency departments and urgent care centers.

headline: Was It All Boehner’s Fault?
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why the shutdown fiasco was more a failure of followership than leadership.
lead_paragraph: As a follow-up to my post on the lessons of the shutdown, and my insistence on the essentially indefensible folly of what we’ve just witnessed from House Republicans, let me say something about the alternative interpretation that’s come up in a number of mini-debates I’ve had on Twitter over the last week or so, with conservative writers like the Weekly Standard’s Jay Cost and Sean Davis of the nascent webzine The Federalist. Against my indictment of the Republican caucus as a whole, they’ve basically argued that the seeming irrationality of G.O.P. strategy across the last few weeks mostly just reflects the mistakes, shading into incompetence, of John Boehner’s negotiating strategy, rather the kind of deeper, essentially methodless dysfunction that I see when I look at the House Republicans. At bottom, these interlocutors think that the House Republicans are a fairly normal majority with a serious leadership problem, and they think I’m a victim of what you might call the pundit’s limited-horizon problem, which fails to work in vitally-useful knowledge — political science research in Cost’s case, business-school theory in Davis’s case — that would pin more of the responsibility on Boehner, and less on his backbenchers. (You can also read a more personalized version of this argument here, from the pseudonymous blogger Thomas Crown, which is based on a slight misreading of a tweet I wrote to Davis — such are the perils of Twitter! — but which works off the entirely correct assumption that my analysis of internal House dynamics lacks the benefit of sustained personal experience with high-stakes negotiations in politics, law or the business world.)

headline: The Strong, Largely Silent Type
abstract: In J. C. Chandor’s “All Is Lost,” Robert Redford is a sailor adrift in the Indian Ocean.
lead_paragraph: True solitude is a rarity at the movies, for those of us in the audience contending with yakkers and texters, and for the people on screen as well. The lonesome strangers of the old westerns almost always had a town to ride into or out of, a buzz of social life to contrast with their individualistic ways. Even movies that emphasize the isolation of their main characters tend to provide them with companions, human or otherwise. Piscine Patel in “Life of Pi” had his tiger, Richard Parker; Chuck Noland in “Cast Away” had Wilson the volleyball. Those guys did a lot of talking, even when nobody else was around.

headline: Avoiding a Foul

lead_paragraph: A few years ago, my husband left me after I discovered his series of extramarital affairs. One of his trysts was with a local soccer mom. Her young son plays on the same team as mine; they live on the same block as us, and we travel in the same social circles. (She remains in her marriage; my ex is not present in our lives.) headline: Seems This Anarchist Is a Laptop Hogger

lead_paragraph: At the very end of “The Fifth Estate,” the filmmakers offer their subject, the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, a chance at pre-emptive rebuttal. Not the actual Assange, of course, but the actor Benedict Cumberbatch, with platinum locks and an Aussie accent providing an uncanny simulacrum. Asked what he thinks of “the WikiLeaks movie,” Assange snorts that it’s more like “the anti-WikiLeaks movie,” bashes the books it’s based on and casts imperious doubt on its accuracy.

headline: Old Informs New at Dual Frieze Fairs in London
abstract: Since the Frieze art brand in London mushroomed into two simultaneous fairs, an appreciation of history has become more evident in the contemporary version.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Minutes after the Frieze Art Fair opened here Wednesday morning for V.I.P. collectors, Mark Fisch, a New York real estate developer, paused in front of a table at the booth of a Berlin gallery called Contemporary Fine Arts. On display were 10 carefully arranged replicas of Greek and Roman objects — urns, vases and animals — each copied from works at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where Mr. Fisch happens to be on the board. Fashioned from Play-Doh, they were made this year by the Bruce High Quality Foundation, a Brooklyn artist collective, and were included in a recent retrospective of the collective’s work at the Brooklyn Museum. Now the faux antiquities are priced at $6,500 to $38,000 each.

headline: Throwaways, Put Together Just So
abstract: The Tony Feher retrospective at the Bronx Museum of the Arts features his sculptural configurations of wine bottles, bottle tops, pieces of glass and rope, and other detritus.
lead_paragraph: Almost anything, even the most banal object, can be beautiful if you see it in the right way. If you’re not good at seeing that way, it helps to have someone present things to you in certain arrangements. That’s where the sculptor Tony Feher comes in. A much-admired but less-than-famous New York artist (born in Albuquerque in 1956), Mr. Feher organizes the kinds of things that most people throw away into simple but surprisingly exciting configurations.

headline: It’s Not Nice to Fool the Bullied Daughter
abstract: Bullied in the school gym, the telekinetic teenager again wields her power in the remake of “Carrie.”
lead_paragraph: The last time we saw Carrie White, she was looking a little, well, red around the gills. She had just taken a splashy blood bath in Brian De Palma’s 1976 horror freakout “Carrie,” and then settled in for what looked like the big sleep. Stephen King’s tormented teenager proved a restless soul, though, and returned in a 2002 television movie and a short-lived 1988 Broadway musical that was revived off Broadway again in 2012. Now she’s back, as they like to say in movie ads, in a fine, largely faithful screen remake, directed by Kimberly Peirce that stars Chloë Grace Moretz as its goddess of gore. It’s hard to keep a franchise crazy down, especially one that can be retrofitted for today’s fears.

lead_paragraph: There was a time on Broadway when “to be Hirschfelded” meant you’d earned the right to burst out the stage door and scream, “I made it!”  Al Hirschfeld, who died in 2003 at 99, was a master illustrator whose line drawings were highly coveted by performers who dreamed of being depicted in his signature squiggles and swoops. During a career that spanned over 80 years, his work appeared in the pages of The New York Times, on the walls of the Museum of Modern Art and on album covers, movie posters and postage stamps.

As the Cuban missile crisis unfolded, the book confirmed the president’s belief that war was more likely to break out by accident than by design, and in the folly of a brinkmanship that leaves no fallback position short of actually fighting.

headline: Two Boys’ Schooling, for 13 Years of It
abstract: Parents document their son and one of his friends, from kindergarten through high school, in “American Promise.”
lead_paragraph: Late in the documentary “American Promise,” one of its directors, Michèle Stephenson, sits next to her adolescent son, Idris — one of the movie’s subjects — as he reads a disheartening e-mail. They’ve been opening college admissions notices and wading through some bad news. The two are shown separately and together, and at times in close-up. (Participants either talk directly to the camera — and sometimes to the various silent camera persons, who are introduced in the final credits — or avoid its gaze.) You can see every flicker in their faces, which allows you to notice and think about the glassiness in Idris’s eyes. He never cries, but you may find yourself on the verge.

headline: His Subject, Himself
abstract: Claudia Roth Pierpont’s look at Philip Roth’s career is a critical biography of the old school.
lead_paragraph: American anti-Semitism, which was running high throughout the 1930s, steadily increased after the onset of war. During the entire period, polls showed, well over a third of the populace stood ready to back discriminatory laws. Nor was this a mere offshoot of the general xenophobia spawned by isolationism. Every synagogue in Washington Heights was desecrated (and some were smeared with swastikas); in Boston, beatings, wreckings and defilements had become near-daily occurrences by 1942. The disgraceful fever, which ruled out all but a trickle of immigration and so cost countless lives, reached its historic apogee in 1944 — by which time the Holocaust was more or less complete.

headline: Fame and Infamy
abstract: J. Michael Lennon’s full-scale biography of Norman Mailer does not sand the corners of a career and life with plenty of texture and lots of sharp edges.
lead_paragraph: It could be said that Norman Mailer was a man and a writer halfway between fame and infamy and yet with little in the way of middle ground. He was, in varying combinations, a world-class drinker, feuder, provocateur, self-mythologizer and anti-feminist. He was a war protester, a mayoral candidate, a co-founder of The Village Voice, as well as a wife stabber, a serial husband (of six wives), and a father (of nine). He was a boxer, an actor, a filmmaker, a poet and a playwright. He was also a journalist and a novelist of enormous and singular narrative inventiveness and thrust, a two-time Pulitzer Prize winner, and one of the least boring and most tireless and tiresome public figures of the last half of the 20th century.

headline: After 15 Years, Still a Mix of Dance and Dare

lead_paragraph: During the first half of the Silk Road Ensemble’s concert at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening, the audience behaved impeccably. Its members assumed what George Bernard Shaw would have called their “churchiest expression” and held back applause until the end of each work. Then came Shane Shanahan’s percussion solo in Giovanni Sollima’s “Taranta Project.”

headline: Jaded, Maybe, but Not Ready for Vegas
abstract: “Paradise,” written and directed by Diablo Cody, focuses on a young plane crash victim who decides to find her wild side in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: The problems with “Paradise,” Diablo Cody’s first directing effort and fourth produced screenplay, begin almost immediately as its damaged heroine, the ickily named Lamb (Julianne Hough), sits on a beach and — in singularly annoying voice-over — catches us up on her life so far. This cheap trick might help Ms. Cody avoid actually showing us things, but it doesn’t bode well for what’s to come.

headline: Into a Galaxy of New Pieces, Jittery to Enigmatic
abstract: The San Francisco Ballet opened a limited season on Wednesday with three New York premieres of works by Helgi Tomasson, Christopher Wheeldon and Wayne McGregor.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Ballet, led by the artistic director Helgi Tomasson, is a national treasure, prized for its dancers along with its fervent insistence on commissioning new ballets. For its first visit to New York in five years, the company’s two-week season showcases four mixed-bill programs, a rarity in a time when story ballets sell. (There is one scheduled, but it’s not the same-old: the New York premiere of Christopher Wheeldon’s “Cinderella” is next week.)

headline: New York Soda Ban to Go Before State’s Top Court
abstract: Although the Court of Appeals will review Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal, its fate will really be in the hands of the mayor’s successor.
lead_paragraph: The battle over big sodas is not yet finished.

headline: In Store | L.A.-Made Handbags That Feel Right at Home in New York
abstract: Clare Vivier opens her first East Coast outpost in NoLIta today, where her West Coast-made leather goods are sure to be a hit with East Coast girls.
lead_paragraph: The leather goods designer and retailer Clare Vivier is one of the most prominent ambassadors of the new Los Angeles fashion scene. Yet her bags are especially well suited to the demands of life in New York. The line, recently rebranded as Clare V., is polished enough for a party, but not too precious for the subway — auxiliary pouches and pockets cleverly accommodate gadgets or spare pairs of shoes. “New York is full of working women who want to look chic while being prepared for all sorts of situations,” Vivier said. Those women can now find the entire Clare V. range at the brand’s second boutique and first East Coast outpost, which opens tonight in a former dressmaker’s shop on Elizabeth Street in NoLIta. Walking into the space feels like being transported to California, thanks to its airy, light-flooded interior (by the L.A.-based architect Barbara Bestor, who also designed Vivier’s Silver Lake flagship) and its mostly SoCal-sourced lifestyle goods (jewelry by Annie Costello Brown, hats by Westbrook Maker, scented candles from the Chateau Marmont). Monograms, a Vivier signature, can be embossed on the spot. Also on view, and worth a visit in its own right, is a colorful nine-foot-wide collage wall by the New York florist and artist Simone Shubuck, a close friend of Vivier’s for 20 years.

headline: Reopening Is Hit-and-Miss in Chicago
abstract: On the first day back to work for government employees, not every federal office was back to functioning normally.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Government workers streamed into the John C. Kluczynski Federal Building in downtown Chicago on Thursday morning. Many of them, clutching takeout coffee, said they were late for their first day back and expected a daunting backlog of work.

headline: Oil Companies Are Sued for Waste of Natural Gas
keywords: ['Natural Gas', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Royalties']
abstract: Owners of mineral rights filed 10 suits to obtain royalties lost when the natural gas produced in oil drilling in North Dakota is burned.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In the sharpest challenge yet to the surge in flaring of natural gas in the Bakken shale oil field, North Dakota mineral owners this week filed 10 class-action lawsuits seeking millions of dollars in lost royalties from some of the nation’s largest oil companies.

headline: A Boundless Appetite for a Universe of Sound
abstract: “Enzo Avitabile Music Life,” directed by Jonathan Demme, follows this Neapolitan singer and saxophonist as he records songs with collaborators from many nations.
lead_paragraph: After a remarkable trilogy of concert films with Neil Young, the latest music documentary from Jonathan Demme, “Enzo Avitabile Music Life,” turns the spotlight on the mushier notion of world music. Not that the sounds of all nations gathered by the Neapolitan musician and groove ambassador Enzo Avitabile, the film’s focus, don’t have soul. But the fuzziness of Mr. Avitabile’s sentiments on boundary-blind unity is echoed in the movie’s slack, tag-along portraiture.

headline: Where Even the Peaches Are Charred
abstract: Oak + Almond takes its name from the woods used in the cooking, and the restaurant has a wood oven, rotisserie and grill as well as a smoker out back.
lead_paragraph: Oak + Almond may be an offbeat name for a restaurant, but its location is familiar to many: next to the Department of Motor Vehicles in Norwalk, at the Wilton border. The owners, Jon Paul Pirraglia and his sister Johanna Gannon, worked at the Tuscan Oven, which their parents ran for years at the same site.

headline: A Gene That Doesn’t Recede
abstract: “Two Jacks,” adapted from a short Tolstoy novel, is a satirical comedy about Hollywood nepotism and wheeling and dealing.
lead_paragraph: With a cocked eyebrow and a sly grin that with a slight curl of a lip can turn into a nasty scowl, Danny Huston portrays Jack Hussar, a reasonable facsimile of his father, the famed director John Huston, in “2 Jacks.” Depending on your perspective, this satirical comedy about Hollywood nepotism and wheeling and dealing, adapted from Leo Tolstoy’s early short novel “Two Hussars,” is either a son’s revenge or a tribute.

headline: What I Love | Deepak Chopra
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Deepak Chopra’s Midtown West apartment is as much a tribute to his cultural heritage as it is an expression of his spiritual beliefs.
lead_paragraph: Deepak Chopra’s Midtown West apartment is as much a tribute to his cultural heritage as it is an expression of his spiritual beliefs.

headline: Deepak Chopra: An ‘Inner Stillness,’ Even on the Subway
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Dr. Chopra’s Midtown West apartment is as much a tribute to his cultural heritage as it is an expression of his spiritual beliefs.
lead_paragraph: Deepak Chopra, the controversial New Age guru and booster of alternative medicine, lives just below the penthouse on the 69th floor of a Midtown West condominium. The long elevator ride gives fellow residents like P. Diddy abundant opportunity to buttonhole the good doctor and seek guidance about their mantra and yoga issues. Sometimes, the encounter even results in a house call. “They invite me for a cocktail or to teach them meditation and I go,” said Dr. Chopra, an internist by training. “What the heck.”

headline: A Zest for Peril and Playfulness
abstract: The Hermès Quartet made its New York debut on Wednesday with a Debussy, Schubert and Dutilleux program at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Whatever the economic challenges facing classical music, there is no shortage of superb young artists eager to enter the field. In recent years, the Ebène Quartet, comprising four young men based in Paris, emerged as the most exciting new string quartet to come out of France. Now another Paris-based ensemble, the Hermès Quartet, is ready to take its place in the new generation.

headline: Where Love Coexists With Death
keywords: ['Movies', 'Children and Childhood', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: A documentary by a first-time filmmaker, Steve Hoover, about a friend who finds his life’s work at a home for H.I.V.-positive children in India.
lead_paragraph: Rocky Braat, a few years into his career as a graphic designer, quit to seek authenticity (his word) by traveling to India, as so many young Americans have done before him. But his jaunt is different. After a chance stop to visit a home for children with H.I.V., he decided to stay. What compels him to remain there, working at the home, today?

headline: Nuggets of Frontier Greed and Justice
abstract: According to “Gold Fever,” a documentary on Friday on the Discovery Channel, greed entailed certain consequences during the 19th-century gold rush.
lead_paragraph: The Discovery Channel is teaching a pretty good lesson in money’s power to make human beings behave badly, with a four-part documentary about the California gold rush called “Gold Fever.” In recounting the story of that mid-1800s stampede westward in search of quick wealth, the program serves up one historical tidbit after another that seems like an allegory about the toll greed takes.

headline: Europe Moves to Shield Citizens’ Data
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Law and Legislation', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Lawmakers have introduced a measure that could require American companies to seek European clearance before complying with United States data warrants.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Lawmakers here have introduced a measure in the European Parliament that could require American companies like Google and Yahoo to seek clearance from European officials before complying with United States warrants seeking private data.

headline: Two Challengers to Chardonnay
abstract: Pinot blanc and viognier play minor roles in Long Island vineyards, but with likely advancements in the mastery of these wines, they could flourish in the coming years.
lead_paragraph: Pinot blanc and viognier, grapes that flourish in Europe, play minor roles in Long Island vineyards. Both yield food-friendly, dry whites that harmonize especially well with fish and shellfish from the region’s waters.

headline: Boston Tourists Make Up for Lost Time
abstract: Tourists were let into Boston’s historic sites for the first time in 16 days, and some were repeat visitors after being turned back because of the federal government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — For the first time in 16 days, tourists on Thursday spilled into the Charlestown Navy Yard, the national historic park that contains the U.S.S. Constitution, the world’s oldest commissioned warship that is still afloat.

headline: A Day in the Life of a Ghost
abstract: “Haunter,” directed by Vincenzo Natali and starring Abigail Breslin, mixes elements of “Groundhog Day” with “Poltergeist.”
lead_paragraph: Call it one kind of hell on earth: In “Haunter,” 15-year-old Lisa is the only member of her Reagan-era suburban family who realizes that they are reliving the same day, over and over. Yet, unlike Bill Murray’s weatherman in “Groundhog Day,” they are absolutely, positively dead. And the lingering menace in this serviceable ghost story from the director Vincenzo Natali and the screenwriter Brian King is that things could actually get worse.

headline: Executing Italian Civilians Was ‘Terrible’ for Executioners, Nazi Said Before Death
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: In a video interview recorded before his death last week, a convicted Nazi war criminal said the execution of hundreds of Italians by his unit in 1944 was “a terrible thing for us to have to do.”
lead_paragraph: As officials in Italy continue to search for a solution to the problem of where to bury the body of Erich Priebke, a former SS captain who died in Rome last week under house arrest, the voice of the unrepentant Nazi was heard in a video interview released on Thursday by his lawyer.

headline: In Key Races, No Sure Thing on G.O.P. End
abstract: Politics is consequential, and, unlike in sports, the banter about it matters — except when it doesn’t, like in two-high profile races on the Texas ballot in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

lead_paragraph: For news about comedy and humor, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

abstract: A look at an exhibition of works by the French modernist Fernand Léger, at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: A look at an exhibition of works by the French modernist Fernand Léger, at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

headline: University of Illinois Acquires Gwendolyn Brooks Archives
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Brooks, who won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry in 1950, spent most of her life in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: The University of Illinois Rare Book and Manuscript Library has acquired the archives of the poet Gwendolyn Brooks.

headline: Take It, and Run With It
abstract: In “The Birthday Boys,” which begins Friday night on IFC, the all-male troupe relies on a running gag throughout each episode.
lead_paragraph: The question isn’t whether “The Birthday Boys” is funny. The question is whether you can stand any more sketch comedy with a white male sensibility.

headline: The City as a Muse
abstract: The Fernand Léger show at the Philadelphia Museum of Art teems with so much work by other artists that it has the mood of a crowded, high-spirited, sometimes confusing reunion.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Fernand Léger show at the Philadelphia Museum of Art is not your typical single-star vehicle. Its title — “Léger: Modern Art and the Metropolis” — may feature only the big name of this French Modernist painter. But the show itself teems with so much work by other artists that it has the mood of a crowded, high-spirited, sometimes confusing reunion.

lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Only an Exterminator Can Save the World
abstract: “Big Ass Spider!”: the title says it all.
lead_paragraph: Asking a bug, even a very large one, to carry your whole movie seems as if it ought to be against animal cruelty codes, but that’s just what “Big Ass Spider!” does. The makers of this humorless horror comedy seemed to think that the mere existence of a gigantic, humanity-threatening spider would be enough.

headline: Snowden Says He Took No Secret Files to Russia
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: In an interview, Edward J. Snowden responded to accusations by critics, provided insights into why he disclosed secret documents and talked about the debate over surveillance.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Edward J. Snowden, the former National Security Agency contractor, said in an extensive interview this month that he did not take any secret N.S.A. documents with him to Russia when he fled there in June, assuring that Russian intelligence officials could not get access to them.

headline: In New York, Looking Forward to a Paycheck
abstract: Federal workers in New York were glad to be back on the job.
lead_paragraph: Office workers poured in and out of the imposing building at 26 Federal Plaza in Lower Manhattan on Thursday morning. Some had been deemed essential and had worked through the shutdown, but others were eager to get back to the job – and start being paid again.

headline: A Crushed Spirit, Healed by the Whispers of Angels
abstract: “Angel Heart,” a children’s story in words and music, will be performed on Monday at Zankel Hall with Chris Noth narrating.
lead_paragraph: “There.”

headline: A New Line | Whimsical Objects, Imported From the Island of Hydra Straight to Fifth Avenue
abstract: A playful jewelry line by the Greek designer Elena Votsi, which includes a gold ring shaped like a baby rattle and a sinuous swirl of rhythm, comes to Bergdorf Goodman beginning today.
lead_paragraph: Beginning today, a 10-piece collection of jewelry by the Greek designer Elena Votsi, who has stores in Athens and Hydra (where the pieces are made), will be available for the first time stateside at Bergdorf Goodman on Fifth Avenue. In the short film above, “A Day in Hydra with Elena Votsi,” the artisan, who designed the medal for the 2004 Olympic Games in Athens, discusses her own history and design inspiration for the rings, necklaces and earrings that she likens to objects, like “toys,” that can be as fun alone as they are on the body. It’s no wonder, then, that included among her selection of work at Bergdorf Goodman is a gold ball ring that resembles a baby’s rattle and a gold-and-diamond ring that looks like a wound-up ribbon, which in Greek culture is a symbol for everything from athletics to marriage. “Even from a very young age I loved Greek history,” said Votsi, who discusses her Hydra roots in the video, which was produced by LoveGold, an online community dedicated to gold jewelry.

headline: An American Adrift in Hong Kong
abstract: In “Lost for Words,” a lonely American man meets a wistful Chinese woman before coming face to face with oppression.
lead_paragraph: The conventions are trundled out in Stanley J. Orzel’s cross-cultural romance, “Lost for Words,” but not the tension or the chemistry. Sean Faris, resembling a very poor man’s Ethan Hawke, plays Michael Vance, a former Marine who has been hired by the information technology department of a company in Hong Kong. Michael is despondent, having been dumped by his girlfriend stateside, until he meets a dancer, Anna Zhou (the gorgeous if opaque Grace Huang, assaying a woefully underdrawn character). How do they meet? He bumps into her as he arrives at the airport and as he jogs in a park.

headline: Jazz Listings for Oct. 18-24
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York.
lead_paragraph: Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Love, in Its Guises, Rebounding
abstract: The choreographer David Dorfman returns to the personal with “Come, and Back Again.”
lead_paragraph: One thing is certain about David Dorfman’s “Come, and Back Again”: the show has heart. This hourlong dance production, which made its New York debut at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Harvey Theater on Wednesday, features monologues about love and grandmothers. It has video projections of the heart shapes found on the stationery of young girls. I’ve never seen a show with more hugging.

lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Fiorano Wine Estate in Italy Making a Comeback
abstract: A vineyard within Rome’s city limits is back in business.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A fresh breeze was blowing in from the Mediterranean to the west, clearing the air here at the Fiorano estate on a brilliant day this month. The harvest was in, the grapes had been crushed and the juice was settling in concrete tanks in the newly constructed winery, beginning the slow process of fermentation.

headline: Paint It Noir
abstract: “Cut to Black” has a lowlife atmosphere, as well as a broken-down private eye, a stripper in trouble and a shady boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: Displaying a near-smothering fascination with 1940s noir, “Cut to Black” is a mildly engaging lowlife odyssey that struggles not to choke on its own style.

headline: Two Mothers, Divided by Their Sons
abstract: In “Torn,” an explosion at a mall leads to questions about two teenagers killed in the blast and our own prejudices.
lead_paragraph: Subdued in mood and palette, “Torn” sensitively explores the aftermath of a mall bombing through the eyes of two mothers who each lost a teenage son in the explosion.

abstract: The new Taymour Grahne Gallery in TriBeCa couldn’t wish for a more auspicious kickoff than its excellent inaugural show of new paintings and drawings by Nicky Nodjoumi.
lead_paragraph: Taymour Grahne Gallery

abstract: Nick Hornby’s small solo show in Chelsea is a concise look at a sweeping trend in contemporary sculpture.
lead_paragraph: Churner and Churner

headline: Making Cities Work for People
abstract: “The Human Scale” looks at ways to turn urban areas into better places to live.
lead_paragraph: “It seems like you’re at a tipping point between becoming L.A. or becoming Copenhagen,” the narrator of “The Human Scale” says to an urban planner for Christchurch, New Zealand, a city rebuilding from an earthquake in 2011.

headline: ‘Burying the Lede: News as Art’
abstract: The news is ever with us, but quantity is not quality, as demonstrated by this wide-ranging group show.
lead_paragraph: Momenta Art

abstract: Mr. Blalock’s spare, seven-work show at Ramiken Crucible is a quiet knockout.
lead_paragraph: Ramiken Crucible

headline: Spare Times for Oct. 18-24
abstract: A listing of walking tours, speaking engagements, cultural events and more in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Harvest Fairs (Friday through Sunday) With Halloween less than two weeks away, pumpkin fever is high at the city’s parks, gardens and farms. On Saturday a Halloween Harvest Festival at Socrates Sculpture Park in Queens will include costumed canines competing (at 1 p.m.) for the grand prize of a visit to a doggy spa.  There will also be events for humans, including a performance of spooky tales by the Variations Theater Group. From 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. (rain or shine), 32-01 Vernon Boulevard, at Broadway, Long Island City, (718) 956-1819, socratessculpturepark.org; free.

abstract: Mr. Wirsum has his first exhibition of new work in New York since 1988.
lead_paragraph: Derek Eller

headline: ‘Mike Kelley’
abstract: Images from the new show at MoMA PS 1.
lead_paragraph: Images from the new show at MoMA PS 1.

headline: Trying to Keep Religion Out of the Charter School Classroom
abstract: As the charter school movement grows, so do the number of schools in houses of worship and other buildings with religious connections.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — At the Eleanor Kolitz Hebrew Language Academy, a fifth-grade foreign-language class is taught entirely in Hebrew, with students shifting into English only long enough to translate words like “research” and “to overcome.” In middle school, these charter school students will take a class on Israeli culture. Officials say the class is in line with the state mandate that public schools teach about the culture of the country where the instructed language is spoken.

headline: This Show’s as Big as His Career
abstract: A survey of Mike Kelley’s work at MoMA PS1 in Queens is a 40,000-square-foot blowout, an expanse appropriate for this artist who did it all.
lead_paragraph: Plainly put, the Mike Kelley retrospective, fresh from Europe to MoMA PS1, knocks everything else in New York this fall right out of the ring. It’s immense, filling 40,000 square feet of gallery space, including a sub-basement boiler room. And it’s that extremely rare thing, a huge show that should be huge. Kelley earned this blowout; his work sustains it.

headline: Academic Suggests an Entrance Test for Beijing’s Migrant Workers
abstract: A Beijing professor’s suggestion that the Chinese capital test migrant workers on subjects like law and culture has been met with widespread criticism.
lead_paragraph: A suggestion from a professor at a prestigious Beijing university that the Chinese capital begin an examination process to screen the quality of migrants has touched off criticism in blogs and in the Chinese press. The recommendation from Wen Guowei, a professor and urban planning expert at Tsinghua University, highlighted some of the difficulties faced by China’s quickly growing cities and also the discrimination outsiders can face.

headline: A Promoter Finds a New Cause: God
abstract: The rapper Ja Rule stars as a stylish concert publicist in “I’m in Love With a Church Girl,” written by a pastor who plays a pastor in the film.
lead_paragraph: In “I’m in Love With a Church Girl,” Jeff Atkins, the 37-year-old rapper better known as Ja Rule, plays Miles Montego, a drug dealer turned concert promoter. “He’s smart, he’s rich, and he’s good-looking,” audiences are instructed. Though not all of those qualities are obvious, Mr. Atkins plays the character with a perfunctory swagger.

headline: Sinning a Little to Defeat the Demons
abstract: Debauched exorcists on a suicide mission practice their craft in “Hellbenders,” a comedy from J. T. Petty.
lead_paragraph: The title “Hellbenders” refers to a Brooklyn-based group of interfaith ministers whose peculiar practice involves racking up sins. These are debauched exorcists on a suicide mission: misbehave enough to invite possession, then commit suicide, dragging the demon with them to the underworld.

headline: A Schizophrenic’s 15-Minute Fame
abstract: A gallery owner and a disturbed artist work together in the Los Angeles documentary “Mondays With William.”
lead_paragraph: Every Monday, Marcelle Danan, a French art dealer in Los Angeles, picks up William Laga, an artist she represents. They buy canvases and paints, and then Mr. Laga creates: abstract maplike visions blending hues and textures. Since Mr. Laga is a schizophrenic whom Ms. Danan met on the street, “Mondays With William,” a spare, cleareyed documentary by Steve Beebe, starts out as a feel-good film about art’s power to reclaim lives but becomes a commentary on the homeless and the mentally ill among them.

headline: For Police Commissioner, the Next Mayor Will Have a Wide Array of Options
abstract: Current New York Police Department top officials and former luminaries are being mentioned as possible successors to Raymond W. Kelly.
lead_paragraph: The topic came up late in the New York City mayoral debate, and the division could not have been clearer: Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee, would seek to keep the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, if elected; his Democratic opponent, Bill de Blasio, would not.

headline: Debate Shows Power of Cities to Limit Reach of Drilling
abstract: Dallas is considering new, stricter regulations on natural gas drilling, which encourages environmentalists but leaves some in the drilling industry feeling cheated.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Claudia and Ed Meyer do not want natural gas drilling near their West Dallas home or anywhere else in the city, for that matter.

headline: A Pizza Parlor’s Upscale Neighbor
abstract: In May, Abeetza Next Door in Greenvale added an upscale dining room to its pizza parlor and expanded its menu.
lead_paragraph: Abeetza Next Door in Greenvale hews to a classic formula. We’ve all been to one of these Italian spots that combines a pizza parlor with a more upscale dining room behind or alongside it.

headline: Ah, Berlin, Home to Concerts With Phalluses
abstract: The stage show in “Peaches Does Herself” reflects the vagina-inspired art of its title figure, who is also the director.
lead_paragraph: Based on stage shows in Berlin in 2010-11, “Peaches Does Herself” records a body-positive rock opera starring the happily raunchy, ditty-slinging singer of the title. The fan-friendly hit list spans electro thunks, guitar-riffing glam chants and even ballads as Peaches — an elfin figure at the center of yonic and phallic sets and costumes — moves from innocence to experience. It’s a mix of brash celebration and sexual-wilderness heartbreak.

headline: Remembering Pillars of Israel’s Past
abstract: The documentary “The Prime Ministers,” which is being released in two parts, profiles Golda Meier and other leaders of Israel from the 1940s to the ’70s.
lead_paragraph: This month is the 40th anniversary of the 1973 war between Egypt and Israel, and the analysis of that conflict continues to this day. The war is one of many challenges to the fledgling state of Israel examined in “The Prime Ministers: The Pioneers,” a vivid insider’s perspective based on Yehuda Avner’s memoir.

headline: The Last King of Ireland
abstract: To look back now is to realize how much has changed in the half-century since President Kennedy visited.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Oscar Wilde still lounges, louche-like, on a boulder in Merrion Square. As always, the Liffey, a river crossed by bridges named for playwrights and patriots, lumbers its way to the sea. Grafton Street is packed with moneyed pedestrians. But Irish ayes are missing.

headline: Storing Solar Energy
abstract: A new solar thermal plant in Arizona, called the Solana Generating Station, can store solar energy so it is available whenever it is needed.
lead_paragraph: A new solar thermal plant in Arizona, called the Solana Generating Station, can store solar energy so it is available whenever it is needed.

headline: Behind Bars, Where Anything Goes
abstract: A brutal off-the-grid prison leads Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone to try to break out in “Escape Plan.”
lead_paragraph: Is that political commentary lurking beneath the grunts and four-word sentences of Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sylvester Stallone?

headline: Chopping, Flipping and Feinting in Search of Lost Art
abstract: Jackie Chan revisits a quest for totemic animals in “Chinese Zodiac.”
lead_paragraph: There was an amusing Saturday morning cartoon series in the early 2000s, “Jackie Chan Adventures,” in which the title hero traveled around the globe tracking down 12 magic talismans representing the Chinese zodiac. Mr. Chan’s latest movie, “Chinese Zodiac,” also concerns a worldwide hunt for astrological symbols, but despite its bigger budget and scale, it’s hardly as entertaining.

headline: Doubts Fall on Afghan Police as Kidnappers Exact Dire Price
abstract: Even in a war-weary place like Helmand Province, kidnappings for ransom have proved a bigger threat to many people than attacks by insurgents.

headline: Action, Comedy and the Brisk Snap of Breaking Bones
abstract: A suave gangster dispatches enemies while dancing and romancing in “Boss,” a film in Hindi with English subtitles.
lead_paragraph: Everybody loves a character with absolute confidence, peerless skill and unshakable cool. The square-jawed gangster known as Boss (the undeniably appealing Akshay Kumar) is that kind of guy. He knows he can win any fight, and there are plenty for him in Anthony D’Souza’s “Boss” — in the marketplace, at the multiplex, in the desert. Between lethal kicks, as he easily dispatches 10 or 12 tough guys, Boss — whose agility is beyond Olympian — does a few dance steps and smiles. This is a man who prefers to fight to music, which is good, because sometimes that drowns out the sounds of all those necks being snapped.
