headline: Security Council Elects 5 New Members
abstract: Chad, Chile, Lithuania, Nigeria and Saudi Arabia were elected Thursday to seats on the 15-member United Nations Security Council for two-year terms starting in January.
lead_paragraph: Chad, Chile, Lithuania, Nigeria and Saudi Arabia were elected Thursday to seats on the 15-member United Nations Security Council for two-year terms starting in January. It was the first time that Saudi Arabia had sought to gain one of the nonpermanent seats on the Council; its decision to vie for a seat appeared to reflect the kingdom’s wish to be more assertive in resolving the Syria war and the Arab-Israeli conflict. The Saudis, who support the rebellion seeking the ouster of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, have criticized the Council over what they regard as its insufficient response to the turmoil in the Middle East. Last month the Saudi foreign minister canceled his General Assembly speech, apparently to show the Saudis’ displeasure. The new Council members replace Azerbaijan, Guatemala, Morocco, Pakistan and Togo.

headline: Israel: Palestinian Is Killed at Army Base
abstract: Israeli soldiers on Thursday fatally shot a Palestinian man who drove a construction vehicle into an army base near Ramallah in the West Bank, the Israeli military said.
lead_paragraph: Israeli soldiers on Thursday fatally shot a Palestinian man who drove a construction vehicle into an army base near Ramallah in the West Bank, barging through a gate and repeatedly trying to run over a soldier, the Israeli military said in a statement. The official Palestinian news agency Wafa identified the man as Yunis Radeideh, 30. In two attacks in July 2008, Palestinians driving construction vehicles in central Jerusalem were shot and killed after plowing into traffic and pedestrians, killing three Israelis. In March 2009, the Palestinian driver of an earthmover flipped over an Israeli police car, wounding two police officers before he was shot dead. According to initial reports, the driver in that episode, Marei al-Radeideh, was a brother of the driver killed at the army base on Thursday.

headline: Rivers’s Move Brings Power, and Scrutiny

headline: Small Plates, and a Taste of Many Cultures

lead_paragraph: Mistral, the restaurant that Scott Anderson and his business partner, Stephen Distler, opened in May, only solidifies the dazzling reputation that Mr. Anderson established at Elements, the other notable Princeton restaurant that he and Mr. Distler own. The new ingredient is Ben Nerenhausen, the talented chef they lured from the Restaurant at Meadowood in St. Helena, Calif., which has three Michelin stars.

headline: Blood and Screams, Before the Show Starts

Conversely, when consumers are upbeat, Madison Avenue produces ads that favor the frightful.

headline: Haunted Houses in High Definition

lead_paragraph: Every year around this time it seems fitting to give thanks to horror-movie fans, whose willingness to support their genre of choice by actually laying cash on the line is substantially responsible for keeping a lot of studio library divisions and independent video companies in operation. This Halloween, the seasonal offerings include some big-ticket gift sets, like “Chucky: The Complete Collection,” an anthology of all six films in the “Child’s Play” series (Universal; Blu-ray, $84.98; DVD, $59.88; not rated), and “Friday the 13th: The Complete Collection,” which offers Blu-ray editions of 12 films in that slasher franchise, from the original 1980 “Friday the 13th” directed by Sean S. headline: Questions Surround Mt. Everest Tragedy
abstract: The death of an Australian and three Tibetans in an avalanche on Mount Everest is tinged with questions about access to the mountain.

Of the 10 people in the party, one Australian and three Tibetans died. A Chinese news report identified the dead Australian as Kenneth Dean Higgins, age 60, but did not name the Tibetans.

headline: CMJ: Scenes From Day 3
abstract: Bands from Europe stood out Thursday night at CMJ: one built around its Minimalist repetition, and another throwback group notable for its hard-hitting attitude.
lead_paragraph: The first and possibly last amusing thing about Hookworms, a band from Leeds, is its name. Hooks and catchiness (ohrwurm, which translates to “earworm,” is a German term for an all-too-catchy song) are extremely low priorities for a band that is built around Minimalist repetition, kinetic drones and an onslaught of guitars and keyboards. They do play what could loosely be called rock songs; Matt Johnson, the keyboardist, sometimes shrieks phrases that are probably English words, though they go through so much reverb and echo there’s rarely a chance of deciphering them. But Hookworms also spent part of their set, and their debut album “Pearl Mystic,” creating and sustaining noises that are deliberately amorphous: no beat, just resonance and distortion.

headline: Facing a Pitiless Void
abstract: Some of this season’s films address adversity in solitude — “All Is Lost” at sea, “Gravity” in space — or under confinement (“Captain Phillips”).
lead_paragraph: Having endured a summer of existential threats to the planet — zombie hordes, alien invaders, the usual stuff — moviegoers can now settle in for an autumn of more intimately scaled ordeals. Spectacles of collective apocalypse, the staple of the blockbuster economy, give way to individual stories of adversity and the struggle to survive in limited space. Superheroes step aside in favor of ordinary (albeit highly competent) people equipped with nerve, resourcefulness and impressive but not always reliable technology. Their archenemies are the laws of nature and political economy, abstract forces that take the form of lethal satellite debris, heavy weather and desperate pirates.

headline: Family Films of a Very Different Sort
abstract: Claire Denis may be a fearless filmmaker, but she is preoccupied with making films about family with the help of a surrogate family of collaborators.
lead_paragraph: Some people are troubled by contradictions — by impulses clashing with intentions, needs complicating wants, violence coexisting with compassion. The director Claire Denis thrives on such things. From her autobiographical debut in 1989, “Chocolat,” to modernist reveries like “Beau Travail” (1999) and “The Intruder” (2004), she has searched for sublimity in the profane and exploited the terror in ecstasy. And while she may be the most independent filmmaker in France, she is preoccupied with belonging, making films about family with the help of a surrogate family of collaborators.

headline: The Jean-Georges Kitchen From on High
abstract: The silent dance of the dinner rush.
lead_paragraph: While designing the kitchen at his namesake restaurant on Columbus Circle, Jean-Georges Vongerichten traded American efficiency for Old World tyranny. The five food stations, staffed by six cooks (two on fish) and one floating chef (a chef de tournant) are arranged perpendicular to the pass, which is where the food is handed off to the food runners (seen at the bottom of the page), all under the scrutiny of another chef, who runs the line. Typically, Vongerichten says, “you cook against the wall, turn around, plate it and it goes out.” At Jean-Georges, the staff members cook various elements at their stations and then walk them up to the pass — where they assemble the dishes with monastic precision. When your shrimp appetizer, being plated lower left by two cooks, comes with crispy baby artichokes, crispy mushrooms, smoked paprika gel, lemon fennel purée, microthyme and parsley, a more collaborative and focused effort is required. (Also: tweezers).

headline: Terry Lenzner on Tricky Dick and Dirty Tricks
keywords: ['Watergate Affair', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Detectives (Private)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Washington’s most-feared private investigator isn’t afraid of Dumpster diving.
lead_paragraph: You’ve been called one of the most dreaded private investigators in the world. What was it like to serve Nixon with a subpoena?  I did not think, when I started the investigation into the Watergate break-in, that it was going to reach anybody in the White House, at any level. I went into the investigation with a completely open mind. I wrote the subpoena myself. When I walked through the West Wing with it, people were saying, “Great work, Terry, keep it up.” I thought that was interesting.

headline: Annual Cavity Drive
abstract: Wake up and have some candy.
lead_paragraph: Several dentists in our area offer to purchase candy during Halloween from their young patients for $1 per pound. Presumably they do this to reduce the risk to their patients of developing cavities. Unfortunately, the dentists then give the candy to the local food cupboard. There is little doubt that most (if not all) the clients who use the food cupboard can little afford proper dental care. I believe such behavior is thoughtless, unethical and unprofessional. I am a retired dentist. BILL BOWEN, ROCHESTER

headline: Kermit Lynch Knows the Terroir
abstract: The wine guru on Robert Parker, a great $15 bottle of wine and why you may not really know what you like.
lead_paragraph: For much of the last 35 years, the wine critic Robert Parker dominated the international wine scene. Parker invented the 100-point rating system for wine, and his reviews wielded such influence over sales that vintners everywhere worked to please Parker’s palate, making oaky, intensely flavored, high-alcohol wines. Kermit Lynch, meanwhile, through his wine shop in Berkeley, Calif., and also through his nationwide distribution business, chose to sell only French and Italian wines made in the unadulterated, old-school traditional style aimed at accentuating terroir — each vineyard’s unique combination of weather, soil and geography.

headline: Los Angeles: Goat-Stew City, U.S.A.
abstract: How the passion of Chowhound’s amateur critics can define a city’s cuisine.
lead_paragraph: Everyone with Internet access is a critic, but some forms of amateur criticism have higher standing than others. Amateur literary critics, like Dylan Lucia, an Amazon reviewer who gave one star to “Fahrenheit 451” (“Bradbury is a good writer [I’ll give him that], but I HATE his writing style”), may lack a nuanced understanding of the English language; some amateur film critics, like the IMDB reviewer who gave 10 stars to “Wrath of the Titans” (“i never saw a movie this good before in my life”), may have never seen another movie before in their lives. But all of us with a tongue and a functioning digestive tract are authorities on food. After all, we have a commanding range of experience to draw from: we eat, according to one study, an average of 4.9 times a day. When it comes to food, everyone is not just a critic — everyone is a connoisseur.

headline: Washington’s Metaphor War

headline: Who Made That Kale?
abstract: Plus: The kale vs. Chick-fil-A slogan battle.
lead_paragraph: Scientists disagree about when humans first tasted kale. But it is known that the ancient Greeks cultivated leafy greens, which they boiled and ate as a cure for drunkenness. And early Roman manuscripts include references to “brassica,” a word that encompassed wild turnips, cabbages and kalelike plants. By the Middle Ages, kale had spread through Europe and Asia. The Italians developed plants with “dinosaur” scales, while the Scots created varietals with leaves like frilly petticoats. The Russians produced kale that could survive in the snow. But by the time Tim Peters, who was then farming in Oregon, began experimenting with the plant in the 1980s, kale had become “boring.” “You only saw the green kind in the supermarket,” he says, “if you could find it at all.”

headline: Sweet Home Cooking Alabama
abstract: What it takes to make a restaurant last four decades.
lead_paragraph: Frank Stitt opened the Highlands Bar and Grill on a gritty street corner in Birmingham, Ala., in 1982, when most of the city’s elite still took its meals in country clubs and restaurant dining meant flambéed everything at the Hyatt downtown. His was a Southern cuisine married to French technique, which meant it was plain and simple as much as it was the exact opposite. Stitt, who was 28, intended the Highlands to evoke a classic worth-a-detour restaurant in a small European town, although transplanted to a fading American steel city.

headline: The Predawn Chowdown
abstract: What chefs eat when they’ve finished feeding everyone else.
lead_paragraph: After up to 10 hours of standing with virtually no breaks and no real nourishment, there are generally two options for a famished team of chefs, cooks, waiters, bussers, porters and everyone else it takes to run a restaurant.

headline: It’s Not What You Drink, It’s Where You Drink It
abstract: The best hotel, dive, cocktail, neighborhood and restaurant bars in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The best hotel, dive, cocktail, neighborhood and restaurant bars in New York City.

headline: The Strange Science of Creating a Perfect Bar
abstract: It’s not what you drink, it’s where you drink it.
lead_paragraph: If I’ve gleaned anything from a lifetime of drinking in bars about what makes the great ones great, it’s that every detail matters: the pictures on the walls, the range of spirits offered, how customers are greeted, the volume at which music is played. And then there’s that metaphysical quality that’s hardest to capture and impossible to fabricate: something like what Romans called genius loci, the spirit of the place. It doesn’t really matter what kind of bar we’re dealing with: It either has it or not.

headline: T FALL DESIGN
abstract: Painter, sculptor, house builder, designer, explorer, philanthropist, bon vivant — the Swiss artist Not Vital sees the universe in his own singular and most elegant way.
lead_paragraph: Painter, sculptor, house builder, designer, explorer, philanthropist, bon vivant — the Swiss artist Not Vital sees the universe in his own singular and most elegant way.

headline: Heritage: Same As It Ever Was
abstract: Don’t blame DeMint.
lead_paragraph: Senator Orrin Hatch is unhappy with the Heritage Foundation, which he worries is becoming political and losing its “reputation”.

headline: Excerpts From Colbert's Speech
abstract: A few selected excerpts from Stephen Colbert's keynote address at the Al Smith dinner.
lead_paragraph: A few selected excerpts from Stephen Colbert's keynote address at the Al Smith dinner.

headline: Video Reviews of ‘Carrie,’ ‘All Is Lost’ and ’12 Years a Slave’
abstract: Times critics on “Carrie,” “All Is Lost” and “12 Years a Slave.”
lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on the drama “12 Years a Slave,” “All Is Lost” and the horror remake “Carrie.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: 36 Hours in Cardiff, Wales
abstract: Dive deep into Welsh history, catch a performance at one of the city’s contemporary spaces or simply stroll along the waterfront during a weekend in the capital.
lead_paragraph: Tell a Londoner you are heading to Cardiff for the weekend and the response will probably be a quizzically arched eyebrow. The Welsh capital, which was largely built during Britain’s 19th-century coal boom, isn’t generally considered one of the country’s most attractive cities. But times are changing. Major regeneration projects since the 1990s — a new performing arts center, a revamped waterfront and a 74,000-seat stadium, to name a few — have given the city a fresh face. Don’t worry, though, Cardiff still has its edge: the punk rock scene is as vibrant as ever, and Welsh rugby fans have never cheered louder.

headline: From Castles to Concerts in Cardiff
abstract: Shuttle between the past and the present during a tour of the Welsh capital.
lead_paragraph: Shuttle between the past and the present during a tour of the Welsh capital.

headline: Redefining the Next Policy Debate
abstract: An undue emphasis on the federal deficit and debt is driving the next phase of Congressional discussions, and more attention needs to be paid to jobs, infrastructure, income and other issues, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline:
U.S. Army Hones
Antiterror Strategy
for Africa, in Kansas
abstract: The first-of-its-kind program will draw on the Army’s storied First Infantry Division, based in Kansas, to conduct more than 100 missions in Africa over the next year.
lead_paragraph: FORT RILEY, Kan. — Here on the Kansas plains, thousands of soldiers once bound for Iraq or Afghanistan are now gearing up for missions in Africa as part of a new Pentagon strategy to train and advise indigenous forces to tackle emerging terrorist threats and other security risks so that American forces do not have to.

headline: In Sickness and in Health: A Wedding in the Shadow of Cancer
abstract: Nancy Borowick’s parents both have cancer, and when she became engaged she asked their doctor when she should have the wedding. “As soon as you can,” he said.
lead_paragraph: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y. — Shortly after Nancy Borowick’s boyfriend got down on one knee and popped the question, she began to worry about the wedding. If everything had been normal, Ms. Borowick and her husband-to-be, Kyle Grimm, would have waited a year, until the spring of 2014. She’s 28, he’s 27 and they would have liked the extra time to build their careers and get used to living together. Ms. Borowick works as a freelance photographer and is often up by 6 a.m., calling newspaper photo desks around the city in hopes of getting an assignment. Mr. Grimm is a junior lawyer at a corporate firm who is already married, to his job.

headline: The China-Debt Syndrome
abstract: Will they lose confidence in America? Please, let’s hope so.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Yglesias notes an uptick in Very Serious People warning that China might lose confidence in America and start dumping our bonds. He focuses on China’s motives, which is useful. But the crucial point, which he touches on only briefly at the end, is that whatever China’s motives, the Chinese wouldn’t hurt us if they dumped our bonds — in fact, it would probably be good for America.

headline: Baseball Cathedrals, From on High
abstract: The baseball diamond is instantly recognizable from above — green grass (even when it is artificial), distinct dirt and stands waiting to be filled.
lead_paragraph: The National League Championship Series concludes this weekend at St. Louis’s Busch Stadium, now in its third iteration, and the American League Championship will run its course at Boston’s Fenway Park, the one and only. These stadiums, as well as many others, are where players have run the bases countless times, and where for years fans have root, root, rooted for their home teams.

headline: Dealing With a Client Who Calls and Calls and ...
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Small Business', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A constant problem for freelancers and small-business owners is deciding whether to turn down business from a demanding customer.
lead_paragraph: A LOT of us are self-employed these days — whether by choice or necessity — and eager to attract as many clients as possible. And that sometimes means agreeing to work with people who are, to put it mildly, challenging.

headline: Africa’s First World Problems — and Opportunities
abstract: What the terrorist attack in Nairobi, Kenya taught us about how to engage with Africa.
lead_paragraph: It won’t be long now before the horrors at Westgate Mall in Nairobi are out of the headlines and relegated to the annals of horrible terrorist attacks (and possibly intransigent police corruption and ineptitude).  Here in Rwanda, a nation that has, against the odds and prognosticators, moved farther beyond one of the greatest tragedies in recorded history, my friends and colleagues see Westgate as a wake-up call to start paying more, and different attention, to this part of our precarious world.

headline: Booking the Bets
abstract: People again looked to Ladbrokes, the British bookmaker, for clues about who would win the Nobel Prize in Literature.
lead_paragraph: By the time you read this, we’ll know the winner of the 2013 Nobel Prize in Literature. Is it the Japanese novelist Haruki Murakami? Did the British bookmaker Ladbrokes accurately favor him as prizewinner? “I dare say, now the odds list is part of the story,” Alex Donohue, a Ladbrokes spokesman, told me in a phone interview. “It’s in the mix for how people assess the prize.”

headline: When to Decide if Your Child Needs Outside Help
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Children and Childhood', 'Baby Boomers', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: Parents who have weathered a child’s emotional struggles are asked to share their lessons with newer parents.
lead_paragraph: How do you know when it’s time to get professional help for a child who is anxious, depressed or angry beyond her years?

headline: Horror
abstract: New books by John Ajvide Lindqvist and F. R. Tallis, and a reissue of Jeremias Gotthelf’s “Black Spider.”
lead_paragraph: LET THE OLD DREAMS DIEBy John Ajvide Lindqvist  Thomas Dunne/St. Martin’s, $27.99.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Bill O’Reilly and Jesse (the Body) Ventura both have best-sellers about the Kennedy assassination, and the former wrestler has challenged the TV host to a debate.
lead_paragraph: 11/22/63: As the 50th anniversary of the Kennedy assassination approaches, Americans remain divided on the big question: Who did it? According to an Associated Press-GfK poll conducted in April, 59 percent of the country believes in a conspiracy, while 24 percent accepts the Warren Commission’s conclusion that Lee Harvey Oswald acted alone. Another 16 percent isn’t sure. (Yes, that adds up to 99 percent. The rest probably blames President Obama.) The best-seller list reflects this split personality. “Killing Kennedy,” by Bill O’Reilly and Martin Dugard, echoes the Warren Report’s lone gunman thesis and has spent 34 weeks on the hardcover nonfiction list; it’s currently on the extended list at No. 22. Meanwhile, a new case for conspiracy hits the nonfiction ­list at No. 14: “They Killed Our President,” by the renowned historian and investigative journalist Jesse (the Body) Ventura, who with Dick Russell and David Wayne argues the president was killed by “disgruntled C.I.A. agents, anti-Castro Cubans and members of the Mafia. . . . Members of the U.S. military were also involved.” Like the former professional wrestler he is, Ventura confronts his biggest rival head on. “Since Bill O’Reilly apparently thinks he knows so much about the J.F.K. assassination,” he writes, “I’d like to publicly challenge him. . . . How about a public debate? Let’s do it. Let’s set it up! I’ll be there, Bill.”

headline: Time’s Up
abstract: In his latest thriller, “The October List,” Jeffery Deaver begins the story with Chapter 36 and methodically works his way back to Chapter 1.
lead_paragraph: The temptation to read THE OCTOBER LIST (Grand Central, $26) backward — which is to say, forward — must be resisted, or you’ll hate yourself for spoiling what might well be Jeffery Deaver’s most fiendish thriller ever. Taking inspiration from Kierke­gaard (“Life can only be understood backward; but it must be lived forward”), the devious author begins his story with Chapter 36 and methodically works his way back to Chapter 1. Let’s admit that the prose is a bit flat, and the characters lack nuance, the unavoidable consequence of withholding key information about persons and motives until those last (first!) five chapters give it all up. The reader is never lied to in Deaver’s brilliant shell game, merely misdirected, and the best part of this trick is that despite being in on the game, we continue to make false assumptions.

headline: Without a Cue
abstract: Can a socially challenged geneticist turn love into a science?
lead_paragraph: Don Tillman doesn’t know he has Asperger’s syndrome, although his symptoms are obvious to friends and colleagues. He flinches from physical contact and cooks all his meals according to an unvarying schedule; his approach to courtship consists of handing women a detailed questionnaire to test their suitability.

headline: Community Groups Still Reeling After the Shutdown
abstract: Many local service organizations for seniors are in difficult financial straits following the government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: The notices went out on Tuesday to dozens of homebound seniors in Antrim County, in the northwest corner of Michigan. Because of the government shutdown, aides that visit older adults in their homes would stop coming or reduce their hours significantly, effective immediately.

headline: Forged in Battle
abstract: Through the stories of seven veteran soldiers, Yossi Klein Halevi traces the conflicting beliefs that have shaped modern Israel.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after I moved to Jerusalem last spring, I made history as the first woman to play in a 30-year-old poker game, joining a group of graying, good-natured guys who had long ago immigrated from South Africa, England and the United States. It was just before Jerusalem Day, which celebrates Israel’s capture of the east side of the city — and the rest of the West Bank — from Jordan in 1967.

headline: Desperate Characters
abstract: First novels by Emma Chapman and Fiona McFarlane consider women on the verge of breakdown.
lead_paragraph: The title of Emma Chapman’s first novel, “How to Be a Good Wife,” is beyond ironic. What we encounter here in Marta Bjornstad is a woman clinging to domesticity as though to a flimsy plank in a turbulent sea. Marta is going under, and the power of this extraordinary book resides in large part in its unwavering focus on her deepening dislocation from the world around her, from her adult son and in particular from her husband.

headline: A House of Her Own
abstract: Jill Lepore reconstructs the life of an 18th-century woman, Benjamin Franklin’s favorite sister.
lead_paragraph: In the late 19th century B.W.H. (Before Women’s History), a flourishing genre of books focused on the lives of women connected to great men of the Revolutionary era. The mother and wife of George Washington were particular favorites, along with the wives of such men as Alexander Hamilton and James Madison.

headline: Have Another
abstract: Flann O’Brien’s shorter works, several of them republished for the first time, reveal a complicated modern writer.
lead_paragraph: In so lovingly collecting and editing Flann O’Brien’s widely scattered and almost forgotten short fiction, Neil Murphy and Keith Hopper have done the study of Irish literature a great service. They’ve also done a lot of detective work; the man born Brian O’Nolan, in Strabane, in 1911, published secretively, under a string of pseudonyms, in two languages. Several of these pieces had never been republished.

headline: How He Won
abstract: Inside President Obama’s 2012 campaign.
lead_paragraph: Richard Wolffe’s account of the 2012 election is a fine ­behind-the-scenes campaign-trail book that makes me wonder about the future of behind-the-scenes campaign-trail books. It is a well-trod genre, more so now thanks to the runaway success of John Heilemann and Mark Halperin’s “Game Change,” about the 2008 campaign. “The Message,” Wolffe’s third on President Obama, is one more entrant in the field.

headline: Who Decided?
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Peter Baker’s account of the George W. Bush administration is haunted by the question of leadership.
lead_paragraph: The Bush administration opened with a second Pearl Harbor, ended with a second Great Crash and contained a second Vietnam in the middle.

headline: Friendship, Hateship, Loveship, Manship
abstract: The second volume of T. C. Boyle’s collected stories features wildlife, drinking binges, mishaps, male-bonding rituals and heartbreak.
lead_paragraph: I wasn’t a quarter of the way through this 918-page T. C. Boyle collection before I started to worry about turning into a T. C. Boyle character myself. There’s a certain progression to many of these stories — a semi-normal person clinging to his sanity, if not his dignity, against a bruising series of misfortunes — that pretty much tracks my reading experience, too.

headline: Toyota to Recall 803,000 Vehicles for Air Bag Problem
abstract: Toyota announced a recall on Thursday of 803,000 Camry, Avalon and Venza models for a problem related to air bags caused by spider webs.
lead_paragraph: UPDATED

headline: Twins City
abstract: Scott Turow’s latest Kindle County thriller takes its inspiration from the Greek myth of Castor and Pollux.
lead_paragraph: It is always a pleasure to visit Kindle County, Scott Turow’s shadow version of greater Chicago, which he has been building and populating since he all but created the modern legal thriller in 1987 with “Presumed Innocent.” One of the many satisfactions of the string of assured and gripping novels since then has been returning to the county’s courtrooms and barrooms, catching glimpses of characters who were central to earlier works and hearing echoes of the compromises that marked them.

headline: Will Have Small Glass of Wine
abstract: Bridget Jones, unexpectedly a widow, is looking for love again.
lead_paragraph: Do we really want to hear about the ­middle-aged escapades of Bridget Jones, the tipsy, ditsy, formerly 30-ish heroine of two previous novels and two previous movies? Hapless, inept, prone to romantic calamity, lurching from one mishap to the next through a hazy fog of faux pas and cigarette smoke, Bridget was so specific to her age that allowing her to reach 51 feels like a violation of the natural order of the fictional universe, as if a new Harry Potter book had him using magic to refinance his mortgage.

headline: Price Drop: Save Millions
abstract: A look at some resale apartments in white-glove buildings where prices have dropped.
lead_paragraph: A look at some resale apartments in white-glove buildings where prices have dropped.

headline: May I Have a Price Check?
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Owners of resale apartments in Manhattan’s white-glove buildings expecting to match the soaring prices of new condos have found they were aiming too high.
lead_paragraph: It’s the era of superlatives for trophy properties in Manhattan. Not a day seems to go by without a new contender for the largest, tallest or priciest.

headline: Crossing Paths Briefly, With Life-Altering Results
abstract: An exhibition explores the profound impact that Qi Baishi, briefly a mentor, had on Isamu Noguchi’s art.
lead_paragraph: At every stage of his career, Isamu Noguchi had a knack for seeking out great mentors and collaborators: Brancusi, Buckminster Fuller, Martha Graham. A new show at the Noguchi Museum suggests that we should add to this formidable list the name of Qi Baishi, one of China’s most respected modern ink painters.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: SHE MATTERS: A Life in Friendships,  by Susanna Sonnenberg. (Scribner, $16.) The mentor, the little sister, the confidante, the rival. Sonnenberg’s redemptive memoir captures the fervor of women’s friendships, reflecting on the companions who populated her childhood and adolescence, as well as those who have left their mark on her adult selves as writer, mother and wife.

headline: Out of All the Gin Joints in New York, I Had to Pick Five?
abstract: Some more of my picks for the best bars across different categories, and a chance for readers to weigh in with theirs.
lead_paragraph: I lost some sleep after thinking about bars I love, across different categories, for my article in this week’s Food & Drink Issue of the magazine. I was limited to choosing one favorite in each of five categories: cocktail bar, dive bar, hotel bar, neighborhood bar and restaurant bar. I knew I couldn’t write about bars I’ve written about before, either in the magazine or elsewhere (Milano’s is an exception, but then, it is an exceptional kind of place). And I tried not to pick the most obvious choices, at least to me, in every category. But as I whittled my long list down to a short one, there were a few runners-up I was particularly bereft not to be able to include, so I will give them their due here:

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE GOLDFINCH,  by Donna Tartt. (Little, Brown, $30.) The “Goldfinch” of the title of Tartt’s smartly written Dickensian novel is a painting smuggled through the early years of a boy’s life — his prize, his guilt and his burden.

headline: The Year of Serena Williams
abstract: Williams has won 10 singles titles this year and will be the heavy favorite to capture an 11th in the season-ending WTA Tour Championships that begin on Tuesday in Istanbul.
lead_paragraph: A professional since 1995 and a Grand Slam champion since 1998, Serena Williams has still managed to break new ground in 2013.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: Donna Tartt, Helen Fielding and Jill Lepore
abstract: This week, Donna Tartt talks about “The Goldfinch”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Helen Fielding discusses “Bridget Jones: Mad About the Boy”; Jill Lepore on “Book of Ages,” about Benjamin Franklin’s sister Jane; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Donna Tartt talks about “The Goldfinch”; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; Helen Fielding discusses “Bridget Jones: Mad About the Boy”; Jill Lepore on “Book of Ages,” about Benjamin Franklin’s sister Jane; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Britain Looks to Fracking as North Sea Oil Dwindles
abstract: While the government has endorsed shale gas development, environmental groups worry about water pollution, noise and other disruptions.
lead_paragraph: BARTON, England — Driving down a bumpy country road in northwest England, one comes upon a bare patch the size of a soccer field at the edge of a peat bog. Workers are erecting a security fence and unrolling watertight film to protect the soil from chemical contamination. Near the middle is a big rectangular hole where a drilling rig will go.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review
abstract: This week, Donna Tartt, Helen Fielding and Jill Lepore.
lead_paragraph: This week, Donna Tartt, Helen Fielding and Jill Lepore.

headline: With Giving Season in Full Force, Seeking to Understand Donors
keywords: ['Philanthropy', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: A new report challenges some accepted wisdom about how people give money and why they sometimes don’t.
lead_paragraph: WE have entered giving season. This is the time of year when charities increase their outreach to donors who traditionally wait to the fourth quarter to make annual gifts. And what would this season be without research into the state of our giving habits?

headline: Suicide Bombers Attack International Convoy in Kabul
abstract: The blast, near a compound housing foreigners, killed two people and injured at least four, but a subsequent attack did not breach compound security.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In the first major attack in Kabul since July, insurgents struck at an international convoy on Friday as it passed a heavily fortified residential compound, killing at least two Afghans who were in the area and wounding at least four others, officials said.

headline: Is the Health Care Fight Over?
abstract: Despite the failure of the shutdown, some on the right-wing will keep trying to dismantle the Affordable Care Act.
lead_paragraph: Leading up to the crisis in Washington, the right-wing of the right-wing party stressed that blocking the continuing resolution was essential because it represented the last, best chance to stop the Affordable Care Act. “Last, best chance” was actually a mantra of sorts. “This is our last chance and our last best chance to do something about this,” said Senator Marco Rubio, Republican of Florida, on the Senate floor in late July. “[T]his may be the last best chance to defund Obamacare before it goes into effect,” the political group FreedomWorks argued over the summer.

headline: How Do You Know When Your Child Needs Outside Help?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Emotions', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Parenting', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation']
abstract: Parents asking parents: How do you know when it’s time to get professional help for a child who is anxious, depressed or angry beyond his or her years?
lead_paragraph: This week, I pose the question in the continuing New Parent, Old Parent collaboration between Booming and Motherlode. My query for experienced parents: How do you know when it’s time to get professional help for a child who is anxious, depressed or angry beyond his or her years?

headline: The Beautiful (Street) Game
abstract: Pickup soccer games, known as pelada, have long been a part of Brazilian culture, attracting players day and night.
lead_paragraph: Pickup soccer games, known as pelada, have long been a part of Brazilian culture, attracting players day and night.

headline: TV Stars Lead Online Push to Curb China’s Shark Fin Appetite
abstract: Celebrities using social media spearhead a Chinese campaign to conserve sharks by cutting demand for shark fin soup.
lead_paragraph: I was in China for the first time last weekend to speak on the role of online and social media in fostering progress on a finite planet (read my talk here). I broke away from the meeting — the first International Conference on Climate Change Communication — to check out a real-time example of how this works.

headline: Movie Review: 'All Is Lost'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “All Is Lost.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews “All Is Lost.”

headline: Delhi’s Urban Sprawl
abstract: As Delhi continues to expand, people living at the edges of the sprawling city question the benefits of urbanization.
lead_paragraph: As Delhi continues to expand, people living at the edges of the sprawling city question the benefits of urbanization.

headline: These Cleaners Never Close
abstract: DashLocker, an online service targeting buildings without doormen, allows residents to drop off and pick up laundry in a locker.
lead_paragraph: Netflix and FreshDirect were among the first Internet-based services to replace brick-and-mortar businesses in New York City. And now comes DashLocker — a service that aims to take the place of dry cleaners and laundromats, and in some ways also play the role of a full-time doorman.

headline: Google Stock Tops $1,000, Highlighting a Tech Divide
abstract: The shares closed up by a record 14 percent in another reminder that a handful of companies have taken control of the technology industry.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Google has done something few companies ever do in the stock market: it has joined the $1,000 club.

headline: Waking Up to a Bloodsucking Lover
abstract: In tackling his third Tchaikovsky ballet, the choreographer Matthew Bourne makes a few adjustments.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Matthew Bourne, the British choreographer, achieved worldwide fame when he put a corps de ballet of male, sexually alluring swans onstage in his 1995 reworking of “Swan Lake,” a brilliant expression of his ability to use physical imagery in the service of theater, and a rereading of the famous classical work that gripped audiences everywhere. “Swan Lake” followed Mr. Bourne’s witty 1992 reimagining of “The Nutcracker”; later, he went on to rework other ballet classics, among them “Cinderella” and “La Sylphide.”

headline: Black History’s Missing Chapters
abstract: The Harvard professor Henry Louis Gates Jr. chronicles five centuries of black history in a six-part series, “The African Americans: Many Rivers to Cross,” on PBS.
lead_paragraph: The television mini-series “Roots,” about the slave Kunta Kinte and his descendants, is a classic, inspired by real lives and real history. But it is a truism among historians that young people do not know enough about African-American contributions to history. Even a tiny slice of recent history — the civil rights movement — is not required teaching in most states, the Southern Poverty Law Center found in a recent assessment.

headline: Photographs From ‘Before They Pass Away’
abstract: Images from Jimmy Nelson’s book.
lead_paragraph: Images from Jimmy Nelson’s book.

headline: Calendar: Coming Events in Amsterdam; San Antonio, Tex.; London
abstract: A weekly capsule of events around the globe curated by our writers and editors.
lead_paragraph: Kazimir Malevich and the Russian Avant-Garde, Amsterdam The work of the early-20th-century Russian avant-garde pioneer Kazimir Malevich, above, is the subject of a major retrospective at the Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam from Oct. 19 to Feb. 2, 2014, and the museum’s first dedicated to a key figure from its collection since reopening in 2012. The retrospective will include more than 500 works by the artist as well as those by contemporaries like Marc Chagall and Wassily Kandinsky. The exhibition is accompanied by lectures, discussion evenings and opportunities to create D.I.Y. Malevich-inspired postcards and life-size compositions.

headline: Girl With Earring and Entourage
abstract: “Girl With a Pearl Earring” is coming.
lead_paragraph: “Girl With a Pearl Earring” is coming. Last seen in New York in 1984, this beloved Vermeer vision of a winsome young woman looking over her shoulder with wide, limpid eyes will be at the Frick Collection beginning on Tuesday. Her portrait will be joined by 14 more works by the 17th-century Dutch masters in “Vermeer, Rembrandt and Hals: Masterpieces of Dutch Painting From the Mauritshuis.”

headline: Images From the Edges of the Earth
abstract: An interview with Jimmy Nelson, who visited and photographed 35 of the world’s most imperiled tribal peoples for a new tombstone-size book.
lead_paragraph: For sheer splendor, the catwalks of New York, Milan and Paris combined can barely touch the eagle hunters of Mongolia. Riding squat ponies through the mountains, these Turkic peoples wear high-domed and winged fur hats, embroidered felt boots and leggings, cloaks of reindeer hide, studded metal belts, fearsome hooded eagles perched on their arms.

headline: If You Feel Compelled to Do Something, Don’t
abstract: Taking the time to reflect gives us the opportunity to make a more considered choice about how to act.
lead_paragraph: For a week, I kept notes about two different columns I was thinking of writing. When I finally sat down to try to write the first one, the notes had disappeared from my computer.

headline: Tough Talk, Screaming Riffs and Elegant Soul Rhythms From a New Mixtape
abstract: New albums by Oozing Wound, Danny Brown, August Alsina, Kelela and Jessy Lanza.
lead_paragraph: August AlsinaDOWNTOWN: LIFE UNDER THE GUN

headline: A Dominican Force in Latin Jazz
abstract: The Afro Latin Jazz Orchestra, led by the pianist Arturo O’Farrill, has often worked to tease out connections or pay living tribute.
lead_paragraph: The Afro Latin Jazz Orchestra, led by the pianist Arturo O’Farrill, has often worked to tease out connections or pay living tribute, with the understanding that Latin jazz is both a historical idea and a vibrant contemporary art. “A Night of Afro Dominican Jazz: Honoring and Remembering ‘El Comandante’ Mario Rivera,” which opens the band’s 12th season on Oct. 25-26 at Symphony Space, should be a case in point.

headline: The Gun Report: October 18, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last week, California Gov. Jerry Brown signed 11 new gun laws and vetoed six others. Among the vetoed bills is AB 180, which would have allowed Oakland to pass gun control measures that are stricter than the state norm. SB 299 would have required owners to report stolen guns within seven days. SB 374 would have banned the sale of semi-automatic rifles with removable magazines. And SB 755 would have added drug abuse convictions to the list of what would prohibit someone from owning a gun for 10 years.

headline: Thomas Foley, House Speaker, Dies at 84; Democrat Urged Parties to Collaborate
abstract: Mr. Foley, a Democrat from Washington State, became speaker in June 1989 and urged “our friends on the Republican side to come together and put away bitterness and division and hostility.”
lead_paragraph: Thomas S. Foley, a courtly congressman from Washington State who as speaker of the House sought to still the chamber’s rising tide of partisan combat before it swept the Democratic majority, and Mr. Foley himself, out of office in 1994, died on Friday at his home in Washington, D.C. He was 84.

headline: Glass and Steel to Invade Cast-Iron SoHo
abstract: A 14-story condominium that will rise on Avenue of the Americas near Vandam Street adds uptown flavor to a downtown neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: SoHo, the downtown neighborhood known for its cast-iron lofts and 19th-century tenements, is about to get something with an uptown flavor: a glassy high-rise.

headline: Check Out the Legs on That Viking
abstract: It’s a tossup as to which element of the 1958 film “The Vikings” plays more comically today.
lead_paragraph: It’s a tossup as to which element of the 1958 film “The Vikings” plays more comically today: Kirk Douglas’s bird-damaged eyeball or Tony Curtis’s skimpy short-shorts. Certainly, there will be unintended laughs on Friday at 6:45 p.m. at Anthology Film Archives when it opens a series called “The Middle Ages on Film: Vikings!” that considers the historical accuracy (or lack of it) in movies that have dealt with those seafaring raiders.

headline: Cracked Sondheim, Newly Repaired
abstract: The Menier Chocolate Factory will present “Merrily We Roll Along,” Stephen Sondheim and George Furth’s 1981 musical, Wednesday in movie theaters.
lead_paragraph: For all too few months in London this year, a great, unconquerable musical was finally mastered. The show was “Merrily We Roll Along,” Stephen Sondheim and George Furth’s reverse-chronology portrait of the toll of showbiz success. Since its brief original Broadway run in 1981, “Merrily” had been consigned to that limbo of beautiful, broken theater pieces that could never be put right. Then the Menier Chocolate Factory, the London company responsible for the Tony-winning revivification of “La Cage aux Folles,” came up with an interpretation, directed by Maria Friedman, that found a pulsing, unifying heart in this high-concept work.

headline: Movements at a Museum
abstract: It’s a week for the big ballet stories.
lead_paragraph: It’s a week for the big ballet stories. On Wednesday, Matthew Bourne’s “Sleeping Beauty” opens at City Center and the San Francisco Ballet begins its run of Christopher Wheeldon’s “Cinderella” at the David H. Koch Theater. But it’s also a week for other kinds of stories, as embodied in work by the French choreographer Boris Charmatz, who will present the second part of his series — “Musée de la Danse: Three Collective Gestures” — at the Museum of Modern Art.

headline: Killer Whale, Captive Whale
abstract: “Blackfish,” a film about the orca Tilikum and the treatment of whales at SeaWorld and other marine parks, will be shown by CNN on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: On Feb. 24, 2010, Dawn Brancheau, a senior trainer at SeaWorld Orlando in Florida, was killed when Tilikum, a 12,000-pound bull orca, grabbed her as they interacted in shallow water and dragged her into a deep pool, mutilating and drowning her. It was the third human death the whale had been implicated in since 1991. “If you were in a bathtub for 25 years, don’t you think you’d get a little irritated, aggravated, maybe a little psychotic?” Jane Velez-Mitchell suggested afterward in a CNN panel discussion. But had Tilikum turned violent from the stress of living outside his natural environment? Or was he, like the overgrown kid he was portrayed as, just playing?

headline: A Rising Showcase for Daring Opera
abstract: Gotham Chamber Opera’s 12th season opens this week with “Baden-Baden 1927.”
lead_paragraph: When New York City Opera went belly up recently, many aficionados turned to Gotham Chamber Opera. Like City Opera in its prime, Gotham stands for unusual repertory, creative productions and rising young singers. With intriguing shows in locations that have ranged from the Brooklyn Botanic Garden to a Lower East Side burlesque club, it is an agile, adventurous company that may benefit from audiences and donors freed by City Opera’s demise, a silver lining in a storm cloud.

The property received landmark designation in 1974.

headline: The Mexican Soda Tax
abstract: The soda tax didn’t fly in Albany, but it’s found new life in Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: The soda tax didn’t fly in Albany, but it’s found new life in Mexico City. On Thursday the lower house of Mexico’s Congress approved new taxes on sugary beverages and high-calorie foods as part of a broader reform plan proposed by President Enrique Peña Nieto. If the proposal passes the Senate, the government will levy a 1 peso (8 cent) per liter tax on sugary beverages such as soft drinks, and a 5 percent tax on packaged foods that contain 275 calories or more per 100 grams.

That number, down from 175 last year, reflects an uptick in quality control from Britain’s largest art fair, which runs through Sunday. Here, some of the microtrends to be spotted at this year’s fair.

headline: Right Place, Right Tine
abstract: Restaurateurs can become obsessed over every ridge, tine and slight variation in curvature of a fork. Can flatware spell success or failure for a restaurant?
lead_paragraph: Judging by a glance at their forks, the restaurants that appear in this weekend’s Food and Drink Issue might not seem so different from one another. Those forks you see above are just . . . forks, right? That’s not how the new management of Tavern on the Green sees things. As Max Chafkin writes, the restaurateurs are thinking very carefully about every contending fork’s curvature and heft, ridges and tines — and whether it will make Tavern on the Green a success.

headline: Q. and A. With Red Bulls’ Mike Petke
abstract: The Red Bulls’ rookie coach has his club in the playoffs and competing for No. 1 over all as the M.L.S. regular season nears a close.
lead_paragraph: After playing seven years in his 14-year professional soccer career for his hometown team, Mike Petke believes he can lead the Red Bulls to the promised land — a championship in Major League Soccer. The club, first as the MetroStars and later as an outpost in the energy drink empire of an Austrian company, have gone to the league’s title match once — in 2008, losing by 3-1 to Columbus. After two years as an assistant to Hans Backe, Petke was named the team’s interim coach, then got the job full-time only weeks before the start of the 2013 season. The first team to clinch a playoff berth, if the Red Bulls win their final two regular-season games (at Houston on Sunday and against Chicago on Oct. 27) they will finish No. 1 over all, win the Supporters Shield and a berth in next season’s Concacaf Champions League. Petke spoke with Jack Bell of The Times before training on Tuesday at the Red Bulls training complex in Hanover, N.J.

headline: Talk About Political Dysfunction ...
abstract: In Libya, no one is strong enough to seize power, but everyone is powerful enough to get in the way.
lead_paragraph: ON Oct. 5, American Special Forces captured Nazih Abdul-Hamed al-Ruqai, an operative of Al Qaeda living in Libya. Five days later, a group of Libyan militiamen kidnapped their own prime minister, Ali Zeidan. After five hours, having faced no opposition from the police or the army, they released him. The prime minister’s captors made no demands for cash, nor did they overtly request any changes in current government policy. Nor was anyone hurt — an aspect that gave the whole affair the air of a vast publicity stunt.

headline: Internal Combustion as a Term of Art
abstract: Audi’s latest V-8 engine is a masterpiece, and it is currently residing in the S7, the hot-rod version of the A7, and the S8, Audi’s highest-performing sedan.
lead_paragraph: The state of the internal-combustion art has never been more artful. Direct fuel injection, variable valve timing, computer-controlled ignition systems and a hundred other technologies have become tools for shaping how an engine performs. Engineers can add torque here, subtract it over there, let the engine rev at one point and hold it back at another. This is a new artistic medium, and Audi’s latest V-8 engine is a masterpiece.

headline: For These Young Visionaries, Design is an Illusion
abstract: All under 40, they’re deploying next-level technologies to create products, projects and experiences that test the limits of design — and our imaginations.
lead_paragraph: Pick up an iPhone 5 and you are holding 727,040 pixels in your hand. Individually, they have no smell, no texture, no meaning. They make no sound; the faint hiss of old televisions has disappeared. Only in sum do pixels become more — information, images and art; a world engorged with screens. But how can an artist or designer make something more interesting than that everyday digital reality? How do you create something technological that transcends technology? In essence, how do you get people to look up from their own devices?

headline: From Beirut to Washington
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Covering the Middle East is helpful in explaining American politics.
lead_paragraph: I’VE spent most of my career covering Middle East politics. I always thought it was its own unique field. But, in the last few weeks, I’ve felt myself to be at a real advantage trying to explain American politics. You see, it turns out that all those years covering Sunnis and Shiites, Israelis and Palestinians, tribal conflicts and “Parties of God” have been the best preparation for covering today’s Washington, D.C., and particularly the Tea Party. Seriously, you’d get a much better feel for Washington politics today by reading “Lawrence of Arabia” than the Federalist Papers. This is not good news.

headline: The Last of the Sheiks?
abstract: The Gulf states have not survived the Arab Spring because they are different. They have simply bought time with petrodollars. And that time is running out.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, England — THIS summer, disgruntled Saudis took their grievances online in droves, complaining of ever-growing inequality, rising poverty, corruption and unemployment. Their Twitter campaign became one of the world’s highest trending topics. It caused great alarm within elite circles in Saudi Arabia and sent ripples throughout the region. The rallying cry that “salaries are not enough” helped to prove that the monarchy’s social contract with its people is now publicly coming unstuck, and on a significant scale.

headline: A 1930s Farce, but Not as Groucho Played It
abstract: “Room Service,” now at the Westport Country Playhouse, is more subtle on the stage than in the Marx Brothers film.
lead_paragraph: The wallpaper in the hotel room is loud enough. But Gordon Miller, the struggling would-be Broadway producer who lives there in “Room Service,” often manages to outshout the décor. He delivers the line “My God, there must be somebody I can sue!” at the top of his lungs while jumping up and down like a frustrated 3-year-old.

headline: Revisiting a Revolution
abstract: The New York Philharmonic performed a double bill of a vast Shostakovich symphony, inspired by the “Bloody Sunday” shootings, and a Rachmaninoff.
lead_paragraph: In the third movement of Shostakovich’s Symphony No. 11, “The Year 1905,” the violas play a melancholy theme over the subdued pizzicati of the lower strings. When Semyon Bychkov led the New York Philharmonic in a brilliant performance of the work on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall, the melody unfolded tenderly. It softly re-emerged with radiant introspection at the end of the third movement, called “In Memoriam.”

headline: Audi’s V-8 Masterpiece
abstract: The S7 and S8 come with different versions of an impeccably engineered V-8 engine that sets Audi apart from its luxury performance-car competition.
lead_paragraph: The S7 and S8 come with different versions of an impeccably engineered V-8 engine that sets Audi apart from its luxury performance-car competition.

headline: Out of Network, Not by Choice, and Facing Huge Health Bills
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Doctors', 'Hospitals']
abstract: Consumers may face big payments to doctors who participate in their care, in an emergency or in a hospital, but are not in their insurance network.
lead_paragraph: Once the cardiologist figured out why Raquel and Michael D’Andrea’s 9-week-old daughter was so frail and unable to eat, he immediately sent her to the hospital for heart surgery.

headline: The Posh London Homes That Posh Londoners Covet
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Wishing a friend’s house or apartment was yours isn’t only an American trait. A chain of envy from across the pond.
lead_paragraph: In 10th grade, my English class read “Portrait of the Artist as a Young Dog,” Dylan Thomas’s great book of autobiographical short stories, featuring examples of some early poetic attempts by the Thomas-ian protagonist. One day I gushed to the teacher, Mr. Weber, about the amazingness of those poems — how could anyone have been so talented so young? It was embarrassing because, as Mr. Weber gently explained, the author was making a joke at the expense of the character: the point was that the poems were not good at all.

headline: Gwen Stefani Shimmies and Shakes in Metallic Fringe

lead_paragraph: The Girl: The singer’s fringed ensemble was full of movement at the black-tie opening-night gala for the Wallis Annenberg Center for the Performing Arts in Beverly Hills last night.

headline: A Painter’s Evolution in Abstract Landscapes
abstract: The changes in Stan Brodsky’s style, which has turned freer and bolder over the years, can be seen in his exhibition at the Heckscher Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: “The style was so controlled!” the artist Stan Brodsky said, not altogether admiringly, as he stood in front of one of his paintings at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington.

headline: A Short History of the Fainting Couch

headline: Fox Gives ‘Brooklyn Nine-Nine’ a Big Vote of Confidence

headline: Is Kent the Westchester of London?
abstract: The suburbification of a quaint corner of England.
lead_paragraph: In Turner Contemporary, in Margate, the gallery workers were hanging a new exhibition: works by J. M. W. Turner, John Constable and their peers, a collection of rarely seen early-19th-century landscape sketches offset by the shark skin and whale spine of the Irish contemporary artist Dorothy Cross. The floor was littered with cables and vacuum-cleaner components, masking tape and Stanley knives. It was a scene that could have been straight out of a gallery on Cork Street, but instead the few visitors were able to look out over the water to where the North Sea meets the English Channel.

headline: Big Sound in a Small House, Keen to Reach the Next Stage
abstract: Kodaline, an Irish band with arena ambitions, performed at Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night, part of the CMJ Music Marathon.
lead_paragraph: But who will fill the arenas? Not with fans, with sound — anthemic rock has taken a beating in recent years. Or more accurately, it’s been puréed into a softer, lighter version of its former self, be it the deep exhales of Coldplay or the turned-up muscle-folk of Mumford & Sons.

headline: In Exploring Abuse, Encountering ‘Tender Territory’

lead_paragraph: The author and actor Martin Moran calls Two River Theater’s decision to stage “A Map of the Soul,” a first-ever bundling of his one-man shows “The Tricky Part” and “All the Rage,” “brave and ambitious.”

headline: Washington Reopens for Business
abstract: The capital comes back to life with tourists and federal workers after the end of the government shutdown Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: The capital comes back to life with tourists and federal workers after the end of the government shutdown Wednesday night.

headline: Making Ballet Speak in Many Languages
abstract: New York premieres by Alexei Ratmansky and Mark Morris are on a program from the San Francisco Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: The high and rising international reputation of the San Francisco Ballet derives from its deep bench of talent and its commitment to new work. The mixed-bill programs that the company is presenting during the first week of its visit to New York put forward both strengths at once. After an opening night on Wednesday at the David H. Koch Theater that offered three New York premieres of recently choreographed pieces, the troupe went one better on Thursday, with four.

headline: Kenyan Leader Can Skip Parts of Hague Trial
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: President Uhuru Kenyatta’s request to participate by video link in his trial on charges of crimes against humanity was rejected.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Kenya’s president can be absent from parts of his trial on charges of crimes against humanity to fulfill his duties at home, but he will have to be present for a number of important hearings at the International Criminal Court in The Hague, the court announced Friday.

headline: As Baseball Integrates, Satchel Throws Heat
abstract: In “Kansas City Swing,” by Trey Ellis and Ricardo Khan, Satchel Paige, the legendary Negro Leagues pitcher, sees his star being eclipsed.
lead_paragraph: In the pleasant parlor of a Kansas City boardinghouse, a young woman excitedly flips through the pages of a magazine. It is 1947, and change for black Americans seems enticingly close. She finds what she is looking for: an ad for Wheaties cereal. The spokesman-endorser is Jackie Robinson, who has recently become the first black player in modern major-league baseball.

headline: Christopher Bailey: Burberry’s Fitting Appointment
abstract: The selection of Mr. Bailey as Burberry’s next chief executive is a welcome sign.
lead_paragraph: THIS WEEK INVESTORS weighed in on the news that Christopher Bailey would become the chief executive of Burberry, where he is already chief creative officer, and it wasn’t pretty.

headline: Video: G.M. Tries Diesel Again, This Time With an Efficient Chevy Cruze
abstract: General Motors hasn’t offered a diesel passenger car since the diesel-powered Chevette chugged unceremoniously into its lineup in 1986. But the company is back with its efficient Chevrolet Cruze Turbo Diesel.
lead_paragraph: Americans tend to think of hybrids when they want a car with high fuel economy. Europeans, on the other hand, turn to diesel-powered cars. The only manufacturers to offer diesel power to American car buyers with any regularity have been  Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz. So it’s only natural that Chevrolet is jumping into the game with the Cruze Turbo Diesel.

headline: A Year After Sandy, Collectors Consider the Lessons
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Antique and Classic Cars']
abstract: The importance of buying specialized insurance was probably the most valuable lesson that stuck with owners after their classic cars were damaged in Hurricane Sandy.
lead_paragraph: Scott Nadler’s home in Oceanside, N.Y., was among the thousands severely damaged when Hurricane Sandy’s storm surge pummeled the South Shore of Long Island nearly a year ago. There was some relief, however, in finding that although saltwater had flooded his garage, the 1971 Chevrolet Chevelle SS 396 he’d owned for 10 years was repairable.

headline: A Fix for a Chirp Under the Hood
abstract: The latest technical service bulletins include problems with spark plugs, powertrains and corrosion.
lead_paragraph: Honda Crosstours that foul spark plugs and Jeep Wranglers that run hot are among the vehicles with mechanical maladies covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Maya Angelou received a lifetime achievement award from the Norman Mailer Center on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: At the fifth annual Norman Mailer Center Benefit Gala on Thursday at the New York Public Library, honored writers and even the M.C.’s grappled with the legacy of the gala’s namesake.

headline: Landlord vs. Tenant: When It All Began
abstract: Books about the New York City rent wars during World War I, leaving New York (à la Joan Didion) and a graffiti collection.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody loves a landlord,” the Master of the House gustily sings in “Les Misérables.” At few times would that glibly insincere boast have rung less true than in New York City during and after World War I, when coal shortages, Socialist agitators and the scarcity of apartments conspired to bring about emergency rent regulation.

headline: Problems of Growing Up Female
abstract: Issues of sexuality in a superficial world are brought up, and brought up again, in Charlotte Vincent’s “Motherland.”
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Throughout Charlotte Vincent’s “Motherland,” which takes place on a white stage, several scenes repeat in exacting precision: Aurora Lubos walks onto the stage holding a bottle, unscrews its lid and flings its dark red contents onto a pristine wall. She then hikes up her dress, spreads her legs and leans against it with a hollow expression; it looks like menstrual blood. The stain sets.

headline: On Late TV, Hosts Go From Snide to Sweet
abstract: Current hosts of late-night talk shows seem far more interested in ingratiating themselves with their guests than in providing a bit of push-back snark.
lead_paragraph: In one of the signal moments of the greatest talk show in my lifetime, “Late Night With David Letterman,” on NBC, Cher called the host a big jerk.

headline: Dirty Antebellum Secrets in Ivory Towers
abstract: In “Ebony and Ivy,” Craig Steven Wilder, an M.I.T. historian, takes a broad look at the role of slavery in the growth of America’s earliest universities.
lead_paragraph: When Craig Steven Wilder first began digging around in university archives in 2002 for material linking universities to slavery, he recalled recently, he was “a little bashful” about what he was looking for.

abstract: Friday’s highlights from around the Web include news of an advertising partnership between Google’s DoubleClick and Facebook’s FBX. Plus, a conversation with director Spike Jonze on his new film, “Her,” and our bonds with mobile devices.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: NBC Cancels Two Series and Will Bring Back ‘Community’

lead_paragraph: Cancellation news arrived again on Friday evening with NBC swinging the ax this time and removing both the comedy “Welcome to the Family” and the drama “Ironside” from the schedule.

headline: Clarity at Yoga, Cheating at the Diner
abstract: The choreographer Larry Keigwin, working on the musical “If/Then” and starting the magazine ArtDesk, said Sunday was usually devoted to “catch-up and inspiration and life maintenance and yoga.”
lead_paragraph: With all the projects that the choreographer Larry Keigwin has going, his week could use four or five Sundays. This fall, Mr. Keigwin, 41, is choreographing a new musical, “If/Then,” to open in Washington next month and on Broadway in the spring, and preparing his own dance company’s 10th-anniversary performances at the Joyce Theater from Oct. 29 to Nov. 3. In spare moments he is starting a magazine, ArtDesk, which just published its first issue. He lives with his partner, Christian Keesee, 51, a banker, and sometimes Mr. Keesee’s son, Blake, 16, in a town house in the East 70s, joined by their three dogs.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 18

lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include: politicians on the campaign trail, tourists at Liberty Island and crowds admiring Banksy graffiti.

headline: An Elegant Little Soiree of String Players, Just Playing a Few Old Tunes
abstract: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center opened its season with Tchaikovsky, Mendelssohn and Bartok.
lead_paragraph: As a rule, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is all about intimacy. Its concerts often feel like conversations between a handful of players, the musical equivalent of confidences shared across a dinner table. But for the opening of its new season on Thursday, the society peopled the stage of Alice Tully Hall with a small crowd.

headline: Forget Their Dad; Just Listen to Them
abstract: Wardell, a band led by two Spielberg siblings, has found fame, though some question its merit.
lead_paragraph: When Theo Spielberg decided it was time to get serious about starting a rock group, he only had to look across the hallway of his family’s home to find a lead singer. Joined in his bedroom by his sister Sasha, he grabbed his guitar and started plunking out a chord progression he’d been toying with since college, while she sang a pleading and melodic vocal about unspecified desires.

headline: Old, but Not Off the Stage

lead_paragraph: They are out there nearly every afternoon in Balsley Park, a small plaza on Ninth Avenue, between 56th and 57th Streets.

headline: Exotic Thrills for the Privileged, to a Jazz Score
abstract: “Dancing on the Edge,” a Starz mini-series, explores the mixing of poor, itinerant musicians and the aristocracy, including members of the royal family, in 1930s London.
lead_paragraph: In early-1930s London, behind endless clouds of cigarette smoke, society was being remade. “Dancing on the Edge,” a new Starz mini-series beginning Saturday, takes place in the swank hotels, garden parties and jazz clubs of that era to capture the moment when black music served as a social lubricant that brought together poor, itinerant musicians and the aristocracy, including members of the royal family, for a marriage that was tenuous by design.

headline: The Charter School Fight

lead_paragraph: The mayor’s race, otherwise somnolently lacking in drama since the primaries retired the name Sydney Leathers to the history of grade-B scandal, received an infusion of heat recently over the dependably combustible issue of charter school education.

As you may recall, that Ridley Scott 1991 film was a game changer in Hollywood, redefining the outlaw buddy movie by starring two women, instead of men, as partners in crime and self-discovery.

abstract: Jack Hidary isn’t seen as having a chance at becoming New York City’s mayor, but that doesn’t stop him from trying to influence the discussion.
lead_paragraph: Jack Hidary had the gumption to start his first Internet company at a time when most people knew little of the Internet beyond e-mail. So when he looked earlier this year at the field of mayoral candidates, which included several career politicians and a former congressman best known for tweeting a picture of his underpants, he thought, “Why not jump in?”

headline: Into These Woods, Suspect in a Killing Vanished a Year Ago
abstract: Whether Eugene Palmer, who the police say fatally shot his daughter-in-law, could have survived for a year in Harriman State Park in New York is debated.
lead_paragraph: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y. — Last year about this time, Eugene Palmer, a 73-year-old retired truck driver with a love of the craggy backwoods, shot and killed his tempestuous daughter-in-law, Tammy Palmer, the police said, and vanished into the vast wilderness of Harriman State Park.

headline: A Risky Homecoming for White-Tailed Deer
abstract: The reappearance of the white-tailed deer in New York City represents a real threat to the city’s habitats, and possibly to the deer themselves.
lead_paragraph: Staring across Staten Island’s West Shore Expressway, the buck struck a pose in the late light of an autumn day, antlers burnished like new bronze. His muddy feet described his journey from Old Place Creek, just below the road’s shoulder, to a spot where he no doubt anticipated a better view, but instead found one of New York City’s busiest highways. The deer’s intent gaze was troubling. Suddenly driving 50 miles an hour seemed much too fast, and the road’s shoulder, much too narrow.

lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, Nicholas M. Loeb walked into the Hillstone steakhouse on Park Avenue South, not far from his penthouse duplex apartment. Tall and handsome in a dress shirt, faded jeans and loafers, he sat down, ordered spinach and artichoke dip and lined up four bottles on the table. “This is our company that I just launched, Onion Crunch,” he said. “And this year we launched three new flavors: chipotle, bacon and barbecue.”

headline: Q. and A.: Jia Zhangke on Violence, Censorship and His New Film ‘A Touch of Sin’

abstract: The director discusses social change in China, violence in society and on screen, and his take on the martial arts film.
lead_paragraph: One afternoon, as a late summer thunderstorm rolled into Beijing, a small group of Chinese and foreign journalists sat in the Beijing office of Jia Zhangke, the Chinese director, watching his latest film, “A Touch of Sin.” Mr. Jia had finished one round of appearances at film festivals and was in Beijing for a spell, before heading to festivals in the fall in Toronto; New York; San Sebastián, Spain; and elsewhere. The film had made its world premiere at the Cannes Film Festival in May, where it won a best screenplay award.

headline: The Call of the ‘Wild’ on the Pacific Crest Trail
abstract: With the author Cheryl Strayed as their inspiration, many women (and some men) seem to have decided that the road to redemption can be found on the punishing paths of the trail.
lead_paragraph: The Pacific Crest Trail, a 2,650-mile hiking and equestrian trail that reaches from Mexico to Canada, has been called the Appalachian Trail of the West Coast. But that description does it a disservice, for the Pacific trail is longer, wilder, more punishing and also grander than its East Coast cousin.

headline: For Jewish School’s Football Team, It’s Thursday Night Lights
abstract: Players at one of the only Jewish religious schools in the nation to play the varsity sport reserve Friday evenings for Shabbat dinner. But the night before is set aside for the gridiron.
lead_paragraph: NORTH MIAMI BEACH, Fla. — Early Thursday morning at a Jewish high school here, Elan Kainen donned the prayer shawl that had been a gift from his maternal grandfather and recited the prayers of the Shacharit service. Nine hours later, he went through another ritual, one involving pads, cleats and a helmet, as he suited up for what might be the final game of his high school football career.

headline: Russia: 2 Bomb Makers Die, Police Say
abstract: Two people suspected of being militants were killed when an improvised bomb that the police said was being prepared for a terrorist attack exploded in a mosque’s cemetery.
lead_paragraph: Two people suspected of being militants were killed Friday when an improvised bomb that the police said was being prepared for a terrorist attack exploded in a mosque’s cemetery in the North Caucasus region, where Russia is struggling to contain an insurgency. A police spokeswoman for the republic of Kabardino-Balkaria said officers responding to the blast in the village of Dugulubgey found the remains of two bodies, as well as two pistols and a Kalashnikov assault rifle stolen from a police officer in 2008. The device was estimated to have contained more than 20 pounds of explosives, and it shattered the windows of nearby homes when it went off, the police spokeswoman said. The region is close to Sochi, which will host the 2014 Winter Olympics.

headline: T Fall Design Issue
abstract: In our latest issue, we explore distinct forms of design, from fashion, furniture and architecture.
lead_paragraph: In our latest issue, we explore distinct forms of design, whether they’re found in the asymmetrical forms of fashion, or in the ’70s-style curvilinear lines of furniture, or in the architecture of midcentury homes in the Beverly Hills neighborhood of Trousdale. Design, like all forms of art, can be very personal; members of one of England’s most celebrated families, Emma, Issy and Stella Tennant, draw inspiration from nature, namely from the bucolic surroundings in Scotland to create their sculptures and paintings. It can also be very pared down and minimal, like in the home of two fashion designers in Tokyo, or in the distilled, spacious Antwerp residence of the Belgian architect Vincent Van Duysen. On a larger scale, we discover designers and artisans determined to reinvent neighborhoods and cities around the world. In Sydney’s Rosebery neighborhood, three businesses celebrate the best of the city’s agriculture, craftsmanship and furniture design. Meanwhile, in Belgrade, locals are turning their city into a world-class destination, with the emergence of design hotels, art museums and adventurous restaurants. We embrace those who break with convention in art and design; Not Vital, a Swiss artist obsessed with habitats, is the Picasso, the Dali, the Andy Warhol of today, claims Andrew O’Hagan. Howard Slatkin’s Fifth Avenue apartment is filled with custom-made items, from floor to ceiling; each room has a combination of textiles, lighting, objets d’art from different eras and countries. Last but not least, we celebrate visionaries who are using technology to take design — and our imaginations — to the next level. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: Mexico: Soda-Tax Bill Moves Forward
abstract: The lower house of Mexico’s Congress has approved a tax on soda and other sugary drinks as part of the government’s fight against the twin epidemics of obesity and diabetes.
lead_paragraph: The lower house of Mexico’s Congress has approved a tax on soda and other sugary drinks as part of the government’s fight against the twin epidemics of obesity and diabetes. The legislators also added a junk food tax of 5 percent to most snacks and candy when they approved a broad overhaul of Mexico’s tax system late Thursday. The beverage industry, along with sugar producers and the owners of small stores, has led a fierce lobbying campaign against the tax, but public health advocates have fought back. The Senate will take up the tax bill next week.
