headline: Outspoken Chinese Professor Says He Was Dismissed
abstract: Xia Yeliang, an economist, believes Peking University made its decision because of his public support for democratization and criticism of the Communist Party.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A politically outspoken Chinese economist, Xia Yeliang, will lose his professorship at Peking University, one of China’s most prestigious and internationally prominent schools, after a committee voted to dismiss him, Professor Xia said on Saturday. The decision came after months of contention over his future, which his supporters have said reflects the Communist Party’s efforts to deter liberal political views on campuses.

lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — By the end of the National League Championship Series, late Friday night, a cold, misty drizzle had settled over Busch Stadium. Nobody seemed to mind. The scoreboard read 9-0 in favor of the home team, just as it did last fall, when the Cardinals’ season slipped away in the San Francisco rain.

headline: Bum Phillips, Homespun Coach Behind Oilers’ Rise, Dies at 90
abstract: Phillips took over a downtrodden Houston team and took it to two consecutive American Football Conference championship games.
lead_paragraph: Bum Phillips, the homespun Texan who was caricatured as a cowboy but possessed a keen football mind that built the Houston Oilers into one of the National Football League’s leading teams of the late 1970s, died Friday at his ranch in Goliad, Tex. He was 90.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) MAMA (2013) In this modern fairy tale directed by Andy Muschietti, the uncle (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) of two feral sisters (Megan Charpentier, above, and Isabelle Nélisse), abandoned by their father in the woods, moves them into a home with his Goth girlfriend (Jessica Chastain). Then a grotesque figure the girls call Mama appears in the shadows and begins to wreak havoc on their lives. But is the monster simply a coping mechanism for dealing with tragedy? Or is Mama the essence of the girls’ dead mother? “Instead of delivering buckets of guts and gore, this ghost story offers a strong sense of time and place, along with the kind of niceties that don’t often figure into horror flicks, notably pictorial beauty, an atmosphere throbbing with dread and actors so good that you don’t want anyone to take an ax to them,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. And while the director, Guillermo del Toro, “the reigning godfather of motion picture horror,” took only an executive producing credit on the film, “it fits with the more successful movies he’s signed onto. Mr. del Toro understands that nothing says terror like a home that’s become a rattling cage.”

headline: Read!
abstract: The case for libraries.
lead_paragraph: The coolest library I’ve ever been to is in a book. It’s a literal labyrinth, made that way to scare off medieval monks from pursuing forbidden knowledge. There are 50-some seven-sided rooms and a few more square ones, and all of them have varying numbers of doors to the other rooms, and each is named after a Latin verse from the Apocalypse of John. Additional features include distorting mirrors, psychotropic herbs to induce visions and a ventilation system that whistles and feels like ghosts breathing on your face.

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A flurry of back-room Middle East diplomacy led to an ambitious international prisoner swap on Saturday that freed Lebanese citizens held by Syrian rebels and Turkish pilots kidnapped by Lebanese gunmen.

headline: Life in the Swamp
abstract: For thousands of escaped slaves, the forbidding Great Dismal Swamp in Virginia and North Carolina was a haven of freedom.
lead_paragraph: In early September 1863, a young Union soldier wrote a letter to his former professor back at Oberlin College, where he had studied before the war. The soldier, who identified himself only as “G,” had been tasked with taking a census of the freedmen on Craney Island, near Norfolk, Va. The African-American population of the area had been swelling since the arrival of Union forces the previous May, and soldiers like G were to provide the first step toward, among other things, organizing and recruiting black soldiers for the war effort.

headline: With Series Clincher, Red Sox Ensure Memories Are Lasting

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Game 2 home run by David Ortiz that turned around the American League Championship Series was indelibly memorable as soon as it was hit. But now the image of Detroit’s Torii Hunter going headfirst into the Boston bullpen has become absolutely symbolic after the Red Sox, by winning the American League pennant on Saturday night at Fenway Park with a 5-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers, reached their third World Series in 10 years.

The Nobel committee described Professor Shiller as a founder of the field of behavioral finance, an innovator in incorporating psychology into economics and a pioneering analyst of speculative bubbles in the stock and real estate markets.

headline: Alarming Abuses of Medical Credit Cards
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Credit Cards', 'Consumer Protection', 'Medicine and Health', 'Editorials', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: How some unsophisticated patients are duped into taking on debt they can’t afford.
lead_paragraph: Patients around the nation are being victimized by medical credit cards that can lead to financial calamity. These cards, issued by specialty finance companies as well as commercial banks, carry exorbitant interest rates after an initial period of zero interest expires — with heavy penalties for late payments. They are often pushed on patients with modest incomes by health care providers who want to make sure that they get paid, even if some of their patients end up with huge credit card bills they can’t afford. Unless strong regulatory action is taken to curb the abuses, financial companies will continue to gouge consumers at their most vulnerable moments, when they are in pain and need medical attention.

The only consolation at the time was that several economic forecasters expected conditions to improve later in the year.

abstract: Despite improvements, some unsexy reforms are desperately needed.
lead_paragraph: BY many measures, Japan’s economic fortunes have turned up. The Tokyo stock market has surged about 65 percent since last fall. In the second quarter, the economy expanded by 3.8 percent, which is faster than other developed economies. At last, prices are edging upward, a good thing for Japan. Yet, the mood in Tokyo among businessmen and economists remains precariously balanced between enthusiasm for the monetary and fiscal stimulus unleashed by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and worry that promised structural reforms might not be implemented.

In a case that has riveted France, the prosecutors accused three family clans from Croatia of grooming girls and boys as young as 11 to steal as part of a gang that committed 100 robberies in France, Belgium and Germany in 2011.

Frothy television programs on sentimentalized family values are interrupted by advertisements for a new smartphone app: VithU, which allows women in danger, at a double press of a power button, to send an S O S alert with their location to predesignated friends and family members.

headline: Ma’am, Your Burger Has Been Paid For

headline: My Selfie, Myself

But the best part of the discovery was the slow realization that she was holding the camera herself. It was, for lack of a better word, a “selfie.”

headline: Starting the Wine

Helping them in their work was a generator with bright lights attached, pulled by a tractor. On this morning, they harvested enough grapes to produce 220 cases of Mario Bazán Cellars wine. Picking the grapes in the early morning means that they are cooler when they go into the collection bins, which helps keep the sugars in ideal condition.

headline: Hold the Drumstick! That’s an Intellectual You’re Eating!
abstract: Readers comment on my column suggesting that poultry are smarter and more sophisticated than we give them credit for.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column looks at the ethical reasons to be wary of eating chicken, geese and other poultry produced in factory farms. My colleague Mark Bittman had an excellent column a few days ago about the health reasons to be wary, and in particular the salmonella risk. I agree with everything Mark said but want to go a step further. Even aside from the health issues, I think there are particular issues with the way poultry are raised, jammed in pens. Part of that is economics: it’s cheap to raise hens in cages, while cows and calves typically get pasture because that’s cheaper. And part of it is, I think, that we have some natural sympathy and regard for fellow mammals like cattle or hogs, but we dismiss birds as lower animals less deserving of our moral concern.

headline: Questions for Free-Market Moralists
abstract: Conservatives often present Robert Nozick’s view that an unfettered free market leads to a just society as moral common sense. But is it?
lead_paragraph: In 1971 John Rawls published “A Theory of Justice,” the most significant articulation and defense of political liberalism of the 20th century. Rawls proposed that the structure of a just society was the one that a group of rational actors would come up with if they were operating behind a “veil of ignorance” — that is, provided they had no prior knowledge what their gender, age, wealth, talents, ethnicity and education would be in the imagined society. Since no one would know in advance where in society they would end up, rational agents would select a society in which everyone was guaranteed basic rights, including equality of opportunity. Since genuine (rather than “on paper”) equality of opportunity requires substantial access to resources — shelter, medical care, education — Rawls’s rational actors would also make their society a redistributive one, ensuring a decent standard of life for everyone.

headline: What’s on Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (HBO) LIFE ACCORDING TO SAM (2013) In 1998, Dr. Leslie Gordon and Dr. Scott Berns discovered that their 2-year-old son, Sam, above, had progeria, a rare and untreatable progressive aging disorder that leads the children afflicted with it — at the time, fewer than 250 in the world — eventually to die of a heart attack or stroke at an average age of 13. But the couple weren’t about to give up on finding a cure, or empowering their son to enjoy life. Sam is now 17, a high school junior and an avid sports fan who excels at his studies, music and friendships. “I didn’t put myself in front of you to have you feel bad for me,” Sam says at the beginning of this documentary, directed by Sean Fine and Andrea Nix Fine. “I put myself in front of you to let you know you don’t need to feel bad for me.” His mother responds: “You are handed something, and what you do with it is what matters, and that’s what Sam is doing. I’m impressed continually by him.”

headline: Not Just a Hot Cup Anymore
abstract: In 1992, McDonald’s coffee was at the center of a lawsuit revisited in a Retro Report video. For consumers, much has changed since the uproar over the case.
lead_paragraph: More than 20 years ago, 79-year-old Stella Liebeck ordered coffee at a McDonald’s drive-through in Albuquerque, N.M. She spilled the coffee, was burned, and one year later, sued McDonald’s. The jury awarded her $2.9 million. Her story became a media sensation and fodder for talk-show hosts, late-night comedians, sitcom writers and even political pundits. But cleverness may have come at the expense of context, as this Retro Report video illustrates. And below, a consumer affairs reporter for The Times reflects on how the world has changed since the lawsuit.

headline: A Crucial Call From JPMorgan’s Chief
abstract: A call from Jamie Dimon of JPMorgan Chase to the Justice Department led to talks that resulted in a tentative $13 billion deal. | The bank’s board remains firmly behind Mr. Dimon. | Norway’s sovereign wealth fund to warn about the increasing computerization of stock markets. | Ignazio Angeloni is charged with doing triage on Europe’s banks.
lead_paragraph: In late September, four hours before the Justice Department planned to hold a news conference to announce civil charges against JPMorgan Chase over its sale of troubled mortgage securities, Jamie Dimon, the bank’s chief executive, personally called one of Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr.’s top lieutenants to reopen settlement talks, Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg report in DealBook. The call scuttled the news conference and set in motion weeks of negotiations that have led to a tentative $13 billion deal, people briefed on the talks said.

abstract: The agency lost its battle with the owner of the Dallas Mavericks, but preserved its ability to pursue cases that do not fit the usual model of corporate insider trading.
lead_paragraph: No one likes to lose, so the Securities and Exchange Commission is surely smarting from a jury’s decision absolving Mark Cuban, the billionaire owner of the Dallas Mavericks, of insider trading charges. Although the case garnered headlines, it is unlikely to have much effect on other investigations, and even has a potential silver lining for the S.E.C.

headline: A Landmark Building With a Fraught History
keywords: ['Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Some tenants of the Belnord, on the Upper West Side, negotiated away their apartments’ rent-regulated status; now that agreement is in dispute.
lead_paragraph: The Belnord is a powerfully built limestone rental building that occupies an entire city block on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Many windows are the width of a grown woman’s wingspan. The outer walls, as if built for a fortress, are nearly a foot thick. And the building has a 22,000-square-foot interior courtyard sprouting with well-manicured trees. Some of its apartments ask for $35,000, even $45,000, a month.

headline: By Design | Paul Smith Reintroduces Himself
abstract: After 45 years in the business, the legendary British men’s wear designer gets a retrospective at the Design Museum in London, “Hello, My Name Is Paul Smith.” It opens next month.
lead_paragraph: Known for bringing a warm, whimsical touch to classic men’s wear, Paul Smith may be one of fashion’s savviest eccentrics. Beginning next month, the Design Museum in London honors his nearly 45 years as a designer with “Hello, My Name Is Paul Smith,” a landmark retrospective of his smartly tailored, impeccably British ensembles for men and women, his charming collaborations — everything from Mini Coopers to Leica cameras — and his voluminous collection of oddball curios from around the world, quirky bits of inspiration that helped the designer bring his trademark twist to the venerable pinstripe. “Hello, My Name Is Paul Smith,” at the Design Museum in London, Nov. 15 to March 9; designmuseum.org.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: October 18-20, 2013

The toxic water overflowed those barriers at several locations, with some of it possibly spilling into the Pacific Ocean.

headline: Suicide Bomber Strikes Bus in Southern Russia
abstract: The deadly attack on a bus in Volgograd appeared to be a case of separatist violence in the North Caucasus spilling into Russia’s heartland.

The young Muslim woman, her head covered by a light green scarf, boarded the No. 29 bus in the city of Volgograd and took a seat near the back. She rode for two stops, quietly looking out the window as the bus zipped along Azure Street. Then she blew herself up.

headline: The Forgotten Preacher
abstract: Though often overshadowed by Douglass, Washington and DuBois, Henry McNeal Turner was one of the late 19th century’s most influential black leaders.
lead_paragraph: Henry McNeal Turner, the first black chaplain in the Union Army and one of the most prominent religious and political leaders of Civil War era black America, was born a free black on Feb. 1, 1834, in New Berry Court House, S.C. Turner was the oldest child of Hardy Turner and Sarah Greer Turner, and while we do not know much about Turner’s other siblings, we do know that Turner’s father died while he was still young.

headline: Is Breast Still ‘Best’ When It’s Another Mother’s Milk?
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Breastfeeding', 'Infant Formulas', 'Necrotizing Enterocolitis', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Research']
abstract: New research regarding contaminants in breast milk donated or sold online gives us an opportunity to weigh the benefits of breast milk as a substance, not breast feeding as a behavior.
lead_paragraph: When parents cannot breast-feed an infant (when a child is adopted, when a mother’s health or medical history precludes nursing or when a mother can’t produce enough milk), most parents turn to formula. Donated breast milk — milk pumped by another mother and then donated personally, via a milk bank, or through informal sharing network — is still an option pursued by a relatively small group of parents, although many neonatal intensive-care units are increasingly seeking donor milk for premature infants to reduce the risk of a potentially fatal condition called necrotizing enterocolitis.

headline: Anti-Doping Agency Exposed Armstrong, but What About Others?

headline: Maybe Economics Is A Science, But Many Economists Are Not Scientists
abstract: Testing theory has limited benefits if economists refuse to accept the results.
lead_paragraph: Raj Chetty stands up valiantly for the honor of his and my profession, arguing that economics is too a science in which careful research is used to falsify some hypotheses and lend credibility to others. And in many ways I agree: there is a lot of good research in economics, maybe more than ever as the focus has shifted somewhat from theoretical models loosely inspired by observation — which, as he suggests, was my forte — to nitty-gritty empirical work.

headline: Shakespeare in Rep Sells on Broadway

lead_paragraph: The new Broadway double bill of Shakespeare’s “Twelfth Night” and “Richard III,” running in repertory and starring the two-time Tony Award winner Mark Rylance as Olivia and Richard, had a solid first week of ticket sales, according to data released on Monday by the Broadway League, a trade association of theater owners and producers. The shows grossed $468,429 for a total of six preview performances — 73 percent of the maximum possible amount, a high level of plays. The gross is notable partly because the shows are setting aside 250 tickets at every performance for an unusually low $25, which would theoretically lower the amount of money in ticket sales somewhat. The new musical “After Midnight,” a revue recreating the Cotton Club nightclub scene, also had a good first week, grossing $235,823 for three previews (or 64 percent of the maximum possible amount). Over all, Broadway musicals and plays grossed $24 million last week, compared to $24.6 million the previous week, which fell over the Columbus Day holiday weekend. Attendance at shows totaled 233,682 last week, compared to 232,400 the previous week.

headline: Brazil: Consortium Wins Oil Rights
abstract: The Brazilian authorities on Monday awarded a license to develop oil production in a coveted deep-sea area to a consortium of five companies.
lead_paragraph: The Brazilian authorities on Monday awarded a license to develop oil production in a coveted deep-sea area to a consortium of five companies: Petrobras, Brazil’s national oil company; the Western oil giants Shell and Total; and two Chinese state-controlled oil companies. The group, the only consortium to submit a bid in the auction, will pay a signing fee of about $7 billion to start work on the 35-year concession. The deep-sea field, called Libra, is believed to be one of Brazil’s most promising exploration areas. Legislation requires the Brazilian company to take control of the new operation, but doubts persist among energy analysts as to whether Petrobras, which has soaring debt and is trying to reverse a decline in Brazil’s oil production, is overstretched with an array of offshore projects. The auction was carried out in Rio de Janeiro amid protests by oil workers and other groups that oppose the participation of foreign companies in Brazil’s oil industry.

The train, which killed two workers who were inspecting a section of track, was on a run “for training and maintenance purposes” during a strike by railroad workers, said the investigator, Jim Southworth. BART had said it would train managers to operate trains in order to provide a limited shuttle service during the walkout. headline: Dry Whites for Creamy Chowders
abstract: The richness of the broth and the brininess of the clams enhance these wines.

Adding spinach requires a slightly more discerning selection to avoid clashing with the mild, pleasing bitterness of the green. I might steer clear of Muscadet or sauvignon blanc for that reason, but it still leaves many fine choices. A Chablis, for instance, a Mâconnais or a California or Oregon chardonnay in a steely style would all be delicious. So would a good dry albariño, an assyrtiko from Santorini or almost any of the myriad variations on dry or lightly sweet rieslings now produced around the world. Of course, you could do a lot worse than a pilsner, a dry stout or a good English ale.

headline: Holding the Line in Maryland
abstract: How Lincoln and the Union Army finally brought Maryland’s Southern sympathizers to heel.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 21, 1863, an indignant delegation of slaveholders from St. Mary’s County, Md., on the western shore of Chesapeake Bay just across the Potomac River from Virginia, confronted President Abraham Lincoln at the White House. They demanded that he suspend recruiting efforts aimed at their slaves. The presence of “armed colored troops” was “frightening quiet people, and producing great confusion,” they told him. Lincoln listened sympathetically to the grievances voiced by these alleged Union supporters; he did not, he told them, want the Army behaving in “any rude or ungentlemanly manner.”

headline: How the Furloughed Will Be Counted
keywords: ['Government Employees', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Federal workers hit by the shutdown will be counted as employed in one Labor Department survey and unemployed in another, meaning a possible impact on the jobless rate but not the job growth figure.
lead_paragraph: There has been a lot of speculation about how the federal government shutdown will affect numbers for the October jobs report, due out Nov. 8. The jobs report is based on two different surveys — one of households, and one of employers — and it turns out that furloughed federal government workers will be treated as unemployed in the first survey but employed in the second. In other words, the temporary layoff of federal workers will probably increase the unemployment rate, but not (at least directly) depress the payroll job growth numbers.

headline: Why Not Medicaid For All?
abstract: Getting down to bedrock in the great health care debate.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column on the potential consequences of Obamacare’s botched rollout ended by sketching a scenario in which the program’s Medicaid expansion is deemed a success while its reform of the individual market leads to much-higher-than-expected costs and much-lower-than-expected participation rates. This combination would no doubt be politically helpful to the Republican Party in the short run, but (I argued) it would actually leave liberals with a fairly clear path forward: Keep pressing the Medicaid expansion on states that haven’t taken it (and look for John Kasich-style Republicans to partner with), return to the Joe Lieberman-killed idea of expanding Medicare to 55-and-overs, and basically try to further shrink the percentage of Americans who aren’t eligible for one or both of those single-payer programs. This wouldn’t amount to the full-on push for single payer that some people expect from the left if Obamacare fails or gets repealed, but it would move the U.S. toward the closest thing to single payer that we’re ever likely to get: A system in which both the late middle-aged and the lower middle class gradually get folded into government-run insurance alongside the poor, the disabled, and the aged; the individual market survives as a kind of de facto high risk pool (overpriced but technically accessible); and the employer mandate helps prop up employer-based health insurance for a shrunken but still substantial share of the population.

Pavel Dmitrichenko, above, the former principal dancer accused of paying two co-defendants to ambush the artistic director, Sergei Filin, with a mixture of sulfuric acid and urine in January, entered the courtroom in handcuffs and wore a slight smile as he stated his name and place of birth before the judge. Prosecutors were expected to read charges against Mr. Dmitrichenko on Tuesday but the case was rescheduled to next week because a lawyer for another of the accused did not attend the hearing. While the Bolshoi had been known for its atmosphere of extreme, and sometimes destructive, competition, the acid attack sent shock waves through Russia’s theater community and further exposed animosities among some of the troupe’s most gifted dancers.

headline: The Shanghai Secret
abstract: How these schools in China made it to No. 1 in the world.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Whenever I visit China, I am struck by the sharply divergent predictions of its future one hears. Lately, a number of global investors have been “shorting” China, betting that someday soon its powerful economic engine will sputter, as the real estate boom here turns to a bust. Frankly, if I were shorting China today, it would not be because of the real estate bubble, but because of the pollution bubble that is increasingly enveloping some of its biggest cities. Optimists take another view: that, buckle in, China is just getting started, and that what we’re now about to see is the payoff from China’s 30 years of investment in infrastructure and education. I’m not a gambler, so I’ll just watch this from the sidelines. But if you’re looking for evidence as to why the optimistic bet isn’t totally crazy, you might want to visit a Shanghai elementary school.

On Tuesday, Mr. Najar earned about $21 for nine hours harvesting a neighbor’s grove, part of a new program that pays Palestinians whose trees have been destroyed by Jewish settlers to help farmers whose access to the land is limited to a few days by the Israeli authorities.

headline: Iran: Man Who Survived Hanging Might Not Be Hanged Again
abstract: His survival attracted worldwide attention and focused scrutiny on Iran’s heavy use of the death penalty.
lead_paragraph: The judicial authorities suggested they might not rehang a convicted drug felon who survived the first attempt to hang him and who has been convalescing in a hospital pending a second execution attempt. The semiofficial ISNA news agency quoted the justice minister, Mostafa Pur-Mohammadi, as saying, “I do not think there is any need for a rehanging of the convict,” although he said he would defer to the courts. The condemned man, identified only as Alireza M., 37, a father of two, was left for dead in the morgue this month after he had swung in a prison gallows for 12 minutes. His survival attracted worldwide attention and focused scrutiny on Iran’s heavy use of the death penalty.

headline: France: U.S. Wiretapped Envoys, Newspaper Reports, Citing Leaks
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: The N.S.A. wiretapped the offices of the French mission to the United Nations and the French Embassy in Washington, according to an article published Tuesday in the French newspaper Le Monde.
lead_paragraph: The National Security Agency wiretapped the offices of the French mission to the United Nations and the French Embassy in Washington, according to an article published Tuesday in the French newspaper Le Monde. The disclosure, as well as similar material published in the German magazine Der Spiegel in September, was based on secret documents provided by Edward J. Snowden, a former N.S.A. contractor. Both reports cited documents from September 2010 that showed that the Americans had singled out French diplomats for surveillance while they were working in the United States. The article in Le Monde quoted an internal communications from Susan E. Rice, then the American ambassador to the United Nations, saying that the intelligence on how the French were forming their position on Iran, in particular, was helpful in keeping the United States one step ahead in the negotiations.

headline: Deferral Sought for Kenya Trials
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The African Union submitted a formal request to the United Nations Security Council to defer, for at least a year, the trials of Kenya’s president and deputy president in the International Criminal Court at The Hague.
lead_paragraph: The African Union submitted a formal request to the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday to defer, for at least a year, the trials of Kenya’s president and deputy president in the International Criminal Court at The Hague in order to allow them to deal with the aftermath of last month’s deadly terrorist attack at the Westgate mall in Nairobi. The African Union said the attack showed that “Kenya is a front-line state in the fight against terrorism” and that the trials would prevent President Uhuru Kenyatta and his deputy, William Ruto, from “fulfilling their constitutional responsibilities.” Both are accused of crimes against humanity related to violence that roiled Kenya after disputed 2007 elections.

headline: Impossibly Light, Totally Sleek Handmade Bikes Built by a Tokyo Shipwright
abstract: Custom-made from Honduras mahogany, Sueshiro Sano’s beautiful two-wheelers have become objects of veneration and, occasionally, scorn.
lead_paragraph: Sueshiro Sano, a ninth-generation shipwright, makes lightweight, bespoke wooden bicycles in his Tokyo workshop. His bikes, which take three months to assemble and can cost up to $20,000, use Honduras mahogany and are custom built for a 100-percent tailored fit. They’re also impossibly light — a result of Sano’s well-honed boat-building methods — and have become objects of worship, and in some cases, derision, for hipsters and bike experts everywhere. Case in point: at a handmade-bike convention in Denver earlier this year, several incredulous participants accused Sano of using carbon fiber in his designs. (He doesn’t.) But Sano, who built his first boat at 13 and subscribes to the Japanese principle of monozukuri (“making things”), shrugs off such accusations. “For me, it’s about pride,” he says. 011-81-3-5569-6567.

headline: Could New York City Subways Survive Another Hurricane?

headline: The Faces of Balthazar

lead_paragraph: One of the more striking things about Balthazar, which I wrote about in this past Sunday’s Food & Drink issue, is how many workers have stayed there for several years. For waiters, it makes perfect sense — this is among the best service jobs you can find in New York because the tips are so good. (One server I spoke to is an architect who works only part time at his craft, because he makes more money at the restaurant.) But the management earns no tips, and neither does the back-of-house — still, those employees come in and peel potatoes, tenderize steaks, make stocks and generally make the place function. Below are portraits by Marvin Orellana of some of the people who have served Balthazar the longest, behind the scenes. (And one of a busboy, widely rumored to be a real estate magnate.)

lead_paragraph: SAN JOSÉ, Costa Rica — I am not one of those who believe the United States’ days of world leadership are behind us. All my life I have been an admirer of our northern neighbor. I believe its strengths — its democracy, its founders’ wisdom, its people’s ingenuity and diversity — give it unique authority in the world. But many of its citizens and their leaders seem to take such authority for granted now, as if it were American property. The truth is, it must be earned, and today the United States is passing up opportunities to earn it.

headline: Our Last Name Meant ‘Bad Luck.’ So We Changed It.
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Luck', 'Names, Personal', 'Parenting']
abstract: Our family name meant “bad luck man” in Polish, German, Dutch, Hungarian and Czech. When half of Europe reads it, they think instantly of misfortune. Who would want to saddle their children with that?
lead_paragraph: “What is your name?” the judge asked my 3-year-old daughter who sat quietly, her feet dangling from her chair. She looked up, her big brown eyes barely visible over the imposing wood table in front of the judge’s bench. “Go ahead and say your name,” I said, shifting in the seat next to her, trying to fit my pregnant belly below the table. “Lena,” she answered almost inaudibly. I glanced at my husband, Russ, and wondered if he, too, thought this judicial inquisition was going to scar her for life.

It was all to secure a good view of Prince George of Cambridge on his christening day Wednesday. The prince had not been seen in public since he was born three months ago.

headline: Lorde and Eminem Battle at the Top of the Singles Chart
abstract: Lorde’s song “Royals” held the No. 1 spot for the fourth week in a row, holding off Eminem’s “Rap God.”
lead_paragraph: Here’s a contest that few could have predicted even a couple of months ago: Lorde vs. Eminem. But the two — a megastar rapper who has sold tens of millions of albums, and a 16-year-old rookie from New Zealand — are currently contending for dominance of Billboard’s singles chart.

headline: Nina Arianda Returning to New York Stage in ‘Red Vienna’
abstract: The actress will play a widow who joins the criminal underworld after her husband is killed in World War I in the Manhattan Theater Club production.
lead_paragraph: Nina Arianda, who who won the 2012 Best Actress Tony award for her turn as a dominatrix in “Venus in Fur,” is returning to the stage and staying on the dark side. She will star in the world premiere of “Tales From Red Vienna,” by David Grimm, which begins previews on Feb. 26 and opens March 18 at Manhattan Theater Club’s Off Broadway home at City Center.

headline: An Evening of Mark Morris ... and Some Other People
abstract: The Houston Ballet is presenting works by Stanton Welch, Ben Stevenson and, most notably, Mr. Morris, in Chelsea.
lead_paragraph: There is Mark Morris, and then there are all the other choreographers who are deprived of possessing even a sliver of his art. At least that’s what it felt like on Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, where Houston Ballet unveiled its opening-night program of four repertory ballets beginning with Mr. Morris’s enchanting and sophisticated “Pacific.”

headline: Following the Stars in a Rush to Riches
abstract: Eleanor Catton’s “Luminaries,” this year’s winner of the Man Booker Prize, is an immense period piece set in 19th-century New Zealand.
lead_paragraph: This year’s winner of the Man Booker Prize, “The Luminaries” by Eleanor Catton, is long and demanding, as Booker winners often are. In the past five years, two Bookers have gone to Hilary Mantel, whose “Wolf Hall” is at first a grueling read, since Ms. Mantel artfully complicated her Tudor tableau by eschewing names for pronouns. But “Wolf Hall” rewards the effort it demands, and in the end everything is fully, triumphantly clear. The same cannot be said for “The Luminaries,” nor is it Ms. Catton’s intent.

headline: A Night to Pay Homage With Their Wardrobes
abstract: Miley Cyrus, Sofia Coppola and Linda Wells were among the guests at the Fashion Group International Awards.
lead_paragraph: When you are the recipient of a Fashion Group International superstar award, lots of people show up wearing your clothes.

headline: Three Men Lean in for Mutual Support
abstract: The Christian McBride Trio opened its six-night run at Dizzy’s Club Coca-Cola on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: The bassist Christian McBride’s new trio is constant sleek fun, organized and coordinated. It’s connected to a line in small-group jazz going back to the 1950s that made elegance and continuity and affability a priority, one that includes Hank Jones, Dr. Billy Taylor and, more recently, Mulgrew Miller. Its solos run hot when it’s time for them to do so, and within formatted spaces; then they subside and lead into the next solo, or two-way conversation, or three-way themes.

headline: A Guitar Opens Up Some Musical Spaces That Only a Voice Can Fill
abstract: In a sold-out show, Fiona Apple and Blake Mills performed their own songs, as well as a few they wrote together.
lead_paragraph: Fiona Apple has found a way to let her moods swing even more widely. She has always thrived on a precarious blend of the meticulous and the impulsive, and her current tour, which is billed as a duo with the guitarist, songwriter and producer Blake Mills, opens up new extremes for her to toy with. On Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater, she was skittish and stubborn, baleful and whimsical, giggly between songs and, when she sang, cathartically serious. With the seeming casualness of a club show (despite a set list that has been consistent throughout the tour), the concert held a sold-out theater audience rapt.

headline: Student Ensemble’s Sound Belies Its Origin
abstract: The student-members of the Juilliard Orchestra tackled Bartok and Bruckner in a Carnegie Hall concert.
lead_paragraph: There are experts — I’m not one of them — who can identify an orchestra by its sound. During Monday evening’s concert of the Juilliard Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, I found myself wondering what these people would have heard if they had sat blindfolded through this program of works by Bartok and Bruckner, conducted by Alan Gilbert. As powerful waves of rich brass chords rolled out during the last movement of Bruckner’s Symphony No. 7, would they have guessed that the players are students, most in their early 20s? When the sound of the violins intensified with the heat and gleam of molten metal, could they have known that the section was almost entirely made up of women?

headline: From the Wilderness to an Electric Role
abstract: Diane Davis was vacationing in Canada when she auditioned for and won the role as a mentally Ill woman in “The Model Apartment,” now at 59E59 Theaters.
lead_paragraph: Diane Davis was 12 hours from New York last June, vacationing in the Canadian wilderness without electricity or running water — but, luckily, with cellphone service — when her agent called her about an audition for the Primary Stages revival of “The Model Apartment,” Donald Margulies’s surreal, darkly comic 1988 play. “So I got in a canoe, with an iPad in a dry bag, and I paddled over to my friend’s house,” Ms. Davis said.

headline: Lundqvist’s Backup to Make N.H.L. Debut
abstract: Goalie Henrik Lundqvist will miss Thursday’s game at Philadelphia and Cam Talbot, 26, will appear in his first N.H.L. game.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Henrik Lundqvist’s nightmarish season took another bad turn Wednesday when the Rangers confirmed he had a lingering injury that would keep him out of Thursday’s game at Philadelphia.

headline: Bach in a String Concert, Sharing a Program With Bluegrass
abstract: The mandolinist Chris Thile, of Punch Brothers, gives a solo concert of Bach and traditionals at Zankel Hall.
lead_paragraph: The most impressive musicians are often versatile, but few match the breadth of the brilliant mandolinist Chris Thile. Even in an era when eclecticism is the prevailing aesthetic, Mr. Thile, a member of the progressive-bluegrass quintet Punch Brothers, stands out for his novel artistic juxtapositions.

headline: Q. and A.: Tom Byer on Soccer in China
abstract: After years of poor play, China has begun to revamp its soccer program by emulating its rival Japan and fostering grassroots development
lead_paragraph: In recent years Chinese athletes have won international competitions in sports ranging from archery to weightlifting. But their performances in soccer, one of the country’s most popular spectator sports, have long stagnated.

headline: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from the West Bank, Gaza, Pakistan and China.
lead_paragraph: Photos from the West Bank, Gaza, Pakistan and China.

headline: Anatomy: ‘Blue Is the Warmest Color’
abstract: In this Anatomy of a Scene, Abdellatif Kechiche narrates a sequence from “Blue Is the Warmest Color.”
lead_paragraph: In this Anatomy of a Scene, Abdellatif Kechiche narrates a sequence from “Blue Is the Warmest Color.”

headline: A Seattle Theater’s Broadway Credentials
abstract: Quickly grabbing Broadway credits wasn’t enough for Louis Hobson. He’s now returned to Seattle, where he is artistic director of the Balagan Theater.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — By the fall of 2008, Louis Hobson had starred in enough Seattle productions of Broadway musicals — “Hair,” “Evita,” “West Side Story” — that he decided to shoot for Broadway itself. Within weeks, the dream came true: He was cast as the two doctors in the Broadway musical “Next to Normal,” supporting roles that earned him good notices and better money during the show’s 22-month run.

headline: Could Obamacare Discredit Neoliberalism?
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: And if so, would it discredit conservative health policy ideas as well?
lead_paragraph: As a kind of companion piece to my last post on the liberal and conservative visions for health insurance, I strongly recommend reading this post by Mike Konczal, which strikes a note that you can expect to hear sounded more often on the left if the Obamacare rollout continues to go badly. Contra conservatives suggesting that HealthCare.gov represents some kind of discrediting moment for liberalism, Konczal argues that the potential policy problems associated with a nonfunctional web portal really just point to the problems with neoliberalism — a much-debated term of art, but defined for his purposes as the post-1970s idea that social insurance should be “heavy on private provisioning and means-testing,” that it should preserve as much “choice and competition” as possible, and that it should be delivered at the state level or through state-and-federal coordination rather than by the federal government alone.

headline: Sparse Competition and Higher Premiums
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: More than half of the counties in the 34 states on the federally run health exchange are served by just one or two insurers.
lead_paragraph: More than half of the counties in the 34 states on the federally run health exchange are served by just one or two insurers.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘Blue Is the Warmest Color’
abstract: Abdellatif Kechiche narrates a scene from him film, with Adèle Exarchopoulos and Alma Jodorowsky.
lead_paragraph: In the French coming-of-age drama “Blue Is the Warmest Color,” a high school student named Adèle (Adèle Exarchopoulos), finds romance with an art student, Emma (Léa Seydoux). In this video, the director Abdellatif Kechiche discusses a scene that takes place before Adèle meets Emma, and involves a conversation she has with a girl at her school, Béatrice (Alma Jodorowsky). Their exchange becomes an important moment in Adèle’s self-discovery.

headline: $45 for a Premium Hockney Viewing
abstract: The de Young Museum in San Francisco is selling a limited number of tickets costing up to $45 that allow visitors to see a David Hockney show at any time on a prearranged day. Timed tickets cost up to $25.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Think of it as the art-world equivalent of extra leg room — a museum’s resourceful way to turn a customer perk into a profit. Along with selling its regular timed tickets, priced up to $25, for “David Hockney: A Bigger Exhibition,” which opens on Saturday, the de Young Museum here is also offering a premium ticket online for up to $45. This ticket allows visitors entry at any time on the day of their choosing.

headline: London’s Tech City Takes Root
abstract: The British capital’s growing credibility in the tech scene has attracted companies to East London — or Tech City, as some local politicians call the area.
lead_paragraph: The British capital’s growing credibility in the tech scene has attracted companies to East London — or Tech City, as some local politicians call the area.

headline: Technology on the Thames
abstract: The number of technology companies in East London has roughly quadrupled over the last four years, to around 1,400, according to government statistics.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Parts of this city have the outward signs of a budding high-tech scene. Run-down warehouses have been remodeled into gleaming office spaces. Some greasy diners have been transformed into trendy restaurants. And many wood-paneled pubs have become wine bars.

headline: A Liberal Parts Ways With Fox
abstract: Sally Kohn, one of the Fox News Channel’s most visible liberal pundits, parted ways with the network this week.
lead_paragraph: Sally Kohn, one of the Fox News Channel’s most visible liberal pundits, parted ways with the network this week and turned up almost immediately on one of its rivals — MSNBC.

headline: Music History at Caffè Lena
abstract: Since 1960, this venue in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has been an important outpost of the folk music revival.
lead_paragraph: Since 1960, this venue in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has been an important outpost of the folk music revival.

headline: Everyone Except Mozart
abstract: The opera “Das Labyrinth,” performed by the Amore Opera, has the same characters and librettist as “The Magic Flute,” but a different composer.
lead_paragraph: The Amore Opera is in many ways recognizable as an outgrowth of the old seat-of-the-pants Amato Opera, now defunct. But the Amato knew its limitations and made itself lovable by tweaking pretension, starting with its miniature theater, fitted out with retractable chandeliers à la the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Folk Music Heaven, Upstairs
abstract: Since 1960, Caffè Lena in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., has been an important outpost of the folk music revival.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — The first sign that Caffè Lena is different from other joints where guitars are strummed and coffee is sipped comes before you even enter the place. Next to it, off a picturesque side street here, runs Lena Lane, an alleyway commemorating the club and the woman who ran it and became a local legend.

headline: Blurring Lines Between People and Other Creatures
abstract: In “Our Other” by Melanie Maar, a woman changes into a birdlike creature.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, Melanie Maar’s dances are subtle creations, but by the final blackout, it’s hard to shake the feeling that you’ve traveled to a mystical land where nothing is what it seems. In “Our Other,” performed Friday at Danspace Project at St. Mark’s Church, Ms. Maar weaves an intricate tapestry pairing ideas related to nature and religion, humans and animals, sexuality and restraint. It’s earthy, but refined. Sound emanates both from people and from nature, so that once you’re good and settled inside Ms. Maar’s imagination, you’re rarely sure where you are. A factory? A dewy forest?

headline: Hollywood Stars Ask N.S.A. to Stop Mass Surveillance
abstract: Oliver Stone, Maggie Gyllenhaal, John Cusack and Wil Wheaton team up with the Electronic Frontier Foundation for a video that criticizes spying practices and companies that have cooperated with government requests for information.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The debate over National Security Agency spying has gone Hollywood.

headline: A Chef in the Field | Pumpkins
abstract: Add sage and apples to roasted cheese pumpkins, the disc-shaped variety available at most farmers’ markets this time of year, for a delicious and hearty soup.
lead_paragraph: This series by the chef Jeff Schwarz and the photographer Greg Kessler traces the trajectory of seasonal food — from its original source to a place on your table.

headline: Jury Finds Bank of America Liable in Mortgage Case
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgages', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The jury decision will be seen as a victory for the government in its aggressive effort to hold banks accountable for their role in the housing crisis.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:20 p.m. | Bank of America, one of the nation’s largest banks, was found liable on Wednesday of having sold defective mortgages, a jury decision that will be seen as a victory for the government in its aggressive effort to hold banks accountable for their role in the housing crisis.

abstract: There’s a spirited new entry on the men’s wear scene.
lead_paragraph: There’s a spirited new entry on the men’s wear scene.

headline: Sophie Calle Mounts an Exhibition of Missing Art
abstract: “Last Seen,” at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, is a meditation on the theft from that institution of 13 works more than two decades ago.
lead_paragraph: When the French artist Sophie Calle’s exhibition “Last Seen” opens tomorrow at the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum in Boston, it will mark an ironic homecoming of sorts for her.

headline: A Roundup of Worthy Apps for the New iPads
abstract: To showcase what makes a tablet special, try apps beyond the usual Web browser and e-book reader.
lead_paragraph: Tablets have altered the barriers of the computer world, shattering the belief that a personal computer must have a keyboard. And while laptops have become associated with boring Excel documents and the other digital trappings of work, tablets are making computing fun again.

headline: Joel Grey, M.C. in ‘Cabaret,’ to Publish Memoir
abstract: Mr. Grey’s book will cover both his work and his personal life.
lead_paragraph: Joel Grey, the actor best known for his role as the M.C. in “Cabaret,” for which he won a Tony Award and an Oscar, will publish a memoir with Flatiron Books, a new imprint of Macmillan.

headline: Art You Can Live With
abstract: Hundred Mile, a design shop, opens in Rhinebeck, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Josh Ingmire, whose Hundred Mile showroom opened last weekend in Rhinebeck, N.Y., thinks that the shop, which offers rugs, Carl Hansen classic furniture, fresh design from Established & Sons and other tasteful things, is perfectly located. “The riffraff goes to Poughkeepsie,” he said. (Rhinebeck, a historic village 18 miles north of Poughkeepsie, is, significantly, beyond the Metro-North commuter line.)

headline: Designer Theremin
abstract: Dorit Chrysler plays a theremin designed by François Chambard at the Judith Charles Gallery, where a dozen one-of-a-kind theremins are on display in the show “Odd Harmonics.”
lead_paragraph: Dorit Chrysler plays a theremin designed by François Chambard at the Judith Charles Gallery, where a dozen one-of-a-kind theremins are on display in the show “Odd Harmonics.”

headline: What Would They Do with Axl Rose?
abstract: “Wild Art” features artworks that flourish outside of galleries like a bacon portrait of Kevin Bacon.
lead_paragraph: “Wild Art” (Phaidon, $39.95), a new bricklike illustrated tome by David Carrier and Joachim Pissarro, aims to cover art that doesn’t find its way to the galleries, at least for a while. The expected subjects are represented, like graffiti and street art, two forms that don’t lack for attention, but so are plenty of weirder examples. Like Jason Mercier’s portraits of Kevin Bacon and Condoleezza Rice, made from the materials their surnames suggest. Or Kyle Bean’s sculpture constructed from eggshells, left. Or Carol Hummel’s crocheted sweater for a tree, above.

headline: Eating in a Most Peculiar Way
abstract: The conceptual artist Mary Ellen Carroll will introduce her Ground Control chair at a dinner party in Houston.
lead_paragraph: For her “Itinerant Gastronomy” project, the artist Mary Ellen Carroll stages intimate dinners in non-culinary-oriented settings. On Sunday, she will host the heart surgeons Dr. Bud Frazier and Dr. Billy Cohn, the chef Hugo Ortega and several other formidable figures in a vacant office at the top of the Pennzoil Place building in Houston.

headline: The Cavendish Invitational in Monaco
abstract: The Cavendish Invitational began on Friday in Monaco with a preliminary team tournament.
lead_paragraph: Look at the South hand. The dealer on your left opens one heart, your partner passes, and responder raises to two hearts. What would you do?

headline: A Wave of Strange Creatures
abstract: The gallery show “Odd Harmonics” features a dozen unique theremins designed by François Chambard.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, François Chambard had not heard of a theremin, one of the first electronic instruments, though chances are he had caught its sound on movie soundtracks. But when Allen Farmelo, a music producer friend, told him about the device, which is played by waving one’s hands around its two antennas, Mr. Chambard, the principal of UM Project, a furniture design company in Brooklyn, attempted to make one. Or 12.

headline: Yes, That’s Right: Sconces
abstract: The versatile fixtures create an interesting play of light and shadow.
lead_paragraph: Why do you need a sconce? Brian McCarthy can give you a list of reasons.

headline: A Blueprint for Misery
abstract: The artist Michael Elmgreen, on his design with Ingar Dragset of an apartment for a fictional failed architect at the Victoria and Albert Museum.
lead_paragraph: The Scandinavian artists Michael Elmgreen, 52, and Ingar Dragset, 44, like to place statues of imaginary unhappy inhabitants inside their sculpture installations. For the 2009 Venice Biennale, they floated a simulated corpse of a wealthy, balding art collector face down in a swimming pool. This fall, they turned decrepit galleries at the Victoria and Albert Museum in London into “Tomorrow,” the London apartment of Norman Swann, a mediocre modernist architect who has contracted H.I.V. and run out of inherited money. Along with about 100 objects from the museum’s collection, like an 18th-century Japanese ivory horse figurine and an 1850s plaster fig leaf used to make the museum’s male sculptures less shocking, evidence of Swann’s fictional life is strewn about, including a passport, cigarette butts, unpaid bills, models of unrealized buildings and a biographical script 100 pages long.

headline: Where Peace Comes Whizzing By
abstract: While making a movie, Carrie Schoenfeld built a fossil-fuel-free country house with her husband.
lead_paragraph: While making a movie, Carrie Schoenfeld built a fossil-fuel-free country house with her husband.

lead_paragraph: GHENT, N.Y. — There’s the everyday juggling of work and chores that most of us do, and then there’s the amped-up kind that Carrie Schoenfeld — artist, writer, inventor — thrives on.

headline: Only Slightly Mad
abstract: If you’re looking for David Bromberg, the folk musician-turned-luthier-turned-recording artist (again), just follow the beads.

abstract: If you’re looking for the folk musician-turned-luthier-turned-recording artist (again), just follow the beads.
lead_paragraph: WILMINGTON, Del. — On the kitchen counter of the Bromberg-Josephson household, a voluptuous cremation urn glitters with sequins, glass beads and one very gnarly molar. Nancy Josephson, who bedazzles not just reliquaries but taxidermy, furniture and automobiles, envisions it as both her final resting place and a shout-out to her great-great-grandchildren.

headline: Pension Alert Is Issued in Chicago Budget Talk
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Government Employees']
abstract: Mayor Rahm Emanuel says the small cuts for 2014 won’t address pension obligations in the city’s 2015 budget.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Mayor Rahm Emanuel on Wednesday proposed a spending plan for his city next year that is full of nips and tucks: a 75-cent per pack increase in the cigarette tax, higher zoning permit fees for big developments, an end to some retirees’ health insurance subsidies and a rolling hiring freeze. Left alone, for now, were more controversial taxes, on property, sales and gasoline.

headline: The Devil Is in the Details, but Few Take Notice
abstract: Many visitors to haunted houses are too scared to notice the attention to detail, like intricate costuming and props.
lead_paragraph: Haunted house designers have a curious relationship with their finished work. They fill each haunt with meticulous, lifelike details, yet the disorientation and fear they aim to induce doesn’t encourage appreciation by the public.

headline: Face to Face With My Inner Mean Old Man
abstract: The writer takes retribution against noisy neighbors by screaming at them in a haunted house. By invitation, of course.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to noise, I am, to put it generously, a sensitive neighbor. So when the bloodcurdling screams started emanating from the Gateway’s Haunted Playhouse up the street from my weekend retreat in Bellport, Long Island, several years ago, it irked me. I had just spent the summer battling the teenagers in the house behind me for talking late into the night on a screened-in porch. And now, with summer barely over, I’d

headline: How to Haunt a House
abstract: For designers who specialize in haunted houses, it’s high season. What scares them is how little time there is to furnish the home of your nightmares.
lead_paragraph: For designers who specialize in haunted houses, it’s high season. What scares them is how little time there is to furnish the home of your nightmares.

headline: House Haunters
abstract: For designers who specialize in haunted houses, it’s high season. What scares them is how little time there is to furnish the home of your nightmares.
lead_paragraph: Pomona, Calif. — On a recent morning, Steve Kopelman stood inside a hangar-size building at the Fairplex event center here, drinking his third or fourth Diet Dr Pepper of the day and eyeing a giant inflatable goat skull. The skull had arrived by truck from Colorado two days earlier and had just been suspended above a plywood wall spray-painted black that had been hastily erected near the building’s main entrance.

headline: The Over-the-Topcoat
abstract: A spirited new entry on the men’s wear scene is challenging the prevailing wisdom on outerwear: a sport coat meets a topcoat.
lead_paragraph: Among the popular ideas now in circulation about how our primeval cave-man brain influences modern behavior is the theory that when we go shopping, women “forage” and men “hunt.” You know, just as they did back in Paleolithic times, when women brought home mushrooms (and a new mink pelt), and men brought home a mastodon (and a high-definition wide-screen cave painting).

headline: Fall Fashion Trends: Jewelry, and Skirts that Flutter
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Lingerie and Underwear']
abstract: The full ‘50s skirts are already being worn by the fashion-forward; lingerie that can be layered or worn as outerwear; a shop that features rings for every finger and more shopping news.
lead_paragraph: Given the ubiquity of street photography, it can now be easier to trend-spot outside fashion shows than inside. Case in point: the big and bold retro skirts so many women were wearing at the shows last month. You almost expected Carmel Snow to pull up in a Cadillac Brougham. Zanita Morgan, a model turned blogger and photographer, was a latter-day Grace Kelly in a voluminous skirt and angora sweater; Eva Chen, the Lucky editor, was uptown chic in a brocade Tibi; and Eleanor Strauss, the style director of Shopbop, wore a shorter style with a fitted crop top and leather jacket. While the days are still mild, you can pull off a hint-of-skin top under a leather jacket or peacoat.

headline: Competition Rises for AT&T, as Does 3rd-Quarter Profit
abstract: Even as smaller carriers like T-Mobile tried to muscle in, AT&T said third-quarter profit was up, to $3.8 billion from $3.6 billion a year ago.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — T-Mobile USA, the underdog among the four big American phone carriers, has made aggressive moves to shake up the wireless industry this year — and AT&T in particular. But AT&T’s results have not budged.

headline: How Winglets Work
abstract: Winglets help lessen the wind vortexes which normally form at the tip of an airplane wing during flight.
lead_paragraph: Winglets help lessen the wind vortexes which normally form at the tip of an airplane wing during flight.

headline: Funding Circle, British Peer-to-Peer Lender, Expands to U.S.

lead_paragraph: When the soccer team F.C. Barcelona asked Nick Daffern whether his company could set up some merchandise kiosks at its legendary stadium, the Camp Nou, the British businessman knew he had to find some cash fast to fulfill the order.

headline: Makeup Trend: Matte Base Layers
abstract: A gel, a mist and a lotion promise to smooth complexions.
lead_paragraph: “Modern” matte, a shine-free finish without any hint of chalkiness, was a big trend at New York Fashion Week. Here are three products that can help lay a base for the season’s velvety blushes and eye shadows.

headline: Prospect Park Closing on Friday for Obama Visit
abstract: The park in Brooklyn will be shut down for six hours while Marine One uses it during President Obama’s visit to a nearby high school.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Prospect Park was closed for several days during and after Hurricane Sandy. In May, parts of the park were taken over by the Great GoogaMooga, a food and music festival. Now comes Marine One.

headline: New Mexico Justices to Rule on Gay Marriage
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'State Legislatures', 'Supreme Courts (State)']
abstract: The New Mexico Supreme Court is addressing an issue that the Legislature has for years failed to resolve and the governor has avoided.
lead_paragraph: SANTA FE, N.M. — The New Mexico Supreme Court is poised to decide once and for all whether same-sex marriage is legal in this state, addressing an issue that the Legislature has for years failed to resolve and the governor has avoided — but that Democratic county clerks have embraced, under threats of legal action and at considerable political risk.

headline: The Biggest Economy Killer: Our Government
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The single biggest impediment to a stronger economic recovery has been the years of dysfunction in Washington and the policies that have emerged.
lead_paragraph: The government shutdown and debt ceiling crisis inflicted a toll on the American economy, but that cost is only a fraction of the total damage that the federal government has been causing to the American economy.

headline: New Clean Air Rules Would Do Little
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Coal', 'Natural Gas', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Air Pollution']
abstract: Proposed regulations are irrelevant because of cheap natural gas.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — PRESIDENT OBAMA’S recently proposed regulations to limit carbon-dioxide emissions from new power plants have been much heralded by environmentalists because they would make new coal-fired power plants too costly to operate. In truth, they accomplish almost nothing.

headline: For Emily Ratajkowski, ‘Blurred Lines’ Brings a Career Path Into Focus
abstract: Ms. Ratajkowski is using the fame of Robin Thicke’s video as a path toward an acting career.
lead_paragraph: It was a few days after New York Fashion Week, and Emily Ratajkowski was at the Gemma restaurant on the Bowery, huddled over a pot of chamomile tea and nursing a cold.

Another couple of months and Orion will be visible when the dogs and I go out for the last walk at night.

Those so-called hominids had chimpanzee-size bodies and brains, and they still had adaptations in their limbs for climbing trees. But the fossils of hominids from 1.8 to 1.5 million years ago are different. They had bigger brains, flatter faces and upright bodies better suited to walking.

Here, passages excerpted from “White Girls” (out Nov. 12 from McSweeney’s; $24), which Als describes as a kind of “philosophical whodunit.”

headline: 36 Hours in Milwaukee
abstract: Sausage, cheese and beer? Sure. But look around Wisconsin’s largest city and you’ll also find everything from books to art.
lead_paragraph: Milwaukee is a city that evolves slowly. Its roots as a blue-collar town — as the German Athens, as Brew City — are still evident in the names of local landmarks (Pabst Theater, Pfister Hotel, Miller Park, where the Milwaukee Brewers play); the neatly demarcated enclaves that still retain strong traces of their ethnic origins; the countless cozy neighborhood taps; and the locals’ love of sausage, cheese and beer, not to mention the array of festivals (German Fest, Irish Fest, Polish Fest) that overtake the lakefront every summer. Yet this city — Wisconsin’s largest, population 600,000 — is hardly a backward-looking place. Following a few decades of diminishing population, numbers have risen slightly in the years since the 2010 census, much of the increase due to young people moving into a few revived downtown neighborhoods like Walker’s Point and the southerly, suddenly hip Bay View, with its bars and galleries. The result is a city that possesses a renewed vitality while still holding on to an Old World character.
