headline: R.L. Stine to Revive ‘Fear Street’ Series
abstract: The first new book in the horror series for young adults, written by the author of the “Goosebumps” books, is due in October 2014.
lead_paragraph: R.L. Stine, whose “Goosebumps” books are a children’s publishing phenomenon, is reviving another beloved series: “Fear Street,” a best-selling line of young-adult horror books set in the fictional town of Shadyside.

headline: The Weekly Health Quiz
abstract: In the news: tainted breast milk, scoliosis and biking accidents. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.
lead_paragraph: In the news: tainted breast milk, scoliosis and biking accidents. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: F.D.A. Urging a Tighter Rein on Painkillers
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In a major shift, the Food and Drug Administration recommended new limits on prescriptions for widely abused narcotic painkillers like Vicodin and Lortab.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday recommended tighter controls on how doctors prescribe the most commonly used narcotic painkillers, changes that are expected to take place as early as next year.

headline: Adding Rauschenberg and Richter at MoMA
abstract: The Museum of Modern Art announced the acquisition of two works from 1963, “Overdrive,” by Robert Rauschenberg, and “Tote,” by Gerhard Richter.
lead_paragraph: Fifty years ago, when Robert Rauschenberg was experimenting with the relationship between photography and painting in New York, Gerhard Richter was doing the same thing in Düsseldorf, Germany. This week, the Museum of Modern Art announced two acquisitions by these artists — both paintings from 1963 — that illustrate their similar explorations. “They were specific paintings we had our eyes on for years,” said Ann Temkin, MoMA’s chief curator of painting and sculpture.

headline: Chucky, Now Part of the Family
abstract: The fearsome Chucky is now beloved in many ways.
lead_paragraph: The fearsome Chucky is now beloved in many ways.

headline: Abrams and Kasdan Take Over Writing of New ‘Star Wars’ Movie
abstract: Michael Arndt, who wrote “Toy Story 3,” has been replaced as screenwriter of Lucasfilm’s new movie by its director, J.J. Abrams, and Lawrence Kasdan, a Lucasfilm veteran.
lead_paragraph: There has been a (minor) disturbance in the force: Lucasfilm on Thursday said that Michael Arndt would be replaced as the screenwriter of “Star Wars: Episode VII,” which is scheduled to begin filming in the spring, for a planned 2015 release.

headline: Recalling Painful Lessons in Forgiveness
abstract: It is so perilous to love people because eventually you will hurt them.
lead_paragraph: My mother started screaming, and I whipped around fast enough to see her staggering from my car, hunched over, hugging her arm to her belly.

headline: Force of Evil Becomes Cute and Collectible
keywords: ['Movies', 'Children and Childhood', 'Dolls', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Memorabilia and Souvenirs']
abstract: A quarter-century after the evil doll Chucky made his film debut, he has morphed into an object of affection, a plaything (or collectible) for children and their parents alike.
lead_paragraph: It’s been 25 years since an evil plaything terrorized moviegoers and forced parents to reassure their children that their toys wouldn’t turn on them. Chucky, as the overalls-wearing miscreant was called, started his rampage in “Child’s Play,” Tom Holland’s darkly comic 1988 horror film about a little boy whose redheaded Good Guy doll is inhabited by the spirit of a foul-mouthed killer. With its depiction of a child in danger, the film was controversial “to the degree that sometimes parents and parents groups get up in arms about having kids watch horror movies,” said Don Mancini, the creator of Chucky and a writer of the film.

headline: French Fault Banks Over Tax Evasion
abstract: Lawmakers issued a report that blamed a chain of financial players in connection with a flight of revenue estimated at 80 billion euros a year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French lawmakers proposed measures on Thursday to combat tax evasion and faulted a chain of financial players, including banks, that enable a flight of tax revenue estimated at 80 billion euros, or $110 billion, a year.

headline: Giants’ Pierre-Paul Says He Won’t Be Fully Healthy Till Next Year
abstract: Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul, who has one sack this year, conceded on Thursday that he is not 100 percent healthy, and won’t be for a while, after off-season back surgery.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul conceded Thursday what has been fairly obvious to those watching him play this year: he is not 100 percent healthy after off-season back surgery. But Pierre-Paul now believes he will not be completely healthy until next season.

headline: Should Medical School Last Just 3 Years?
abstract: For several years, medical educators have been engaged in an increasingly heated, and occasionally cantankerous, debate about streamlining medical education and training.
lead_paragraph: Sandwiched between three mind-numbing years of basic science courses and hospital rotations and the lockdown years of residency training, the fourth year of medical school has long been a welcome respite for future doctors. It is the only time in their medical education when students have few requirements and a plethora of elective course offerings – and the time to go on vacation and spend time with friends and family.

headline: Agency Initiative Will Focus on Advancing Deep Brain Stimulation
abstract: The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency announced Thursday that it intended to spend more than $70 million over five years to jump to the next level of brain implants.
lead_paragraph: Worldwide, 100,000 people have electrical implants in their brains to treat the involuntary movements associated with Parkinson’s disease, and scientists are experimenting with the technique for depression and other disorders.

headline: Ice-Skating Archive Seeks a New Home
abstract: A historian prepares a book of Staten Island scenes, and World War II-era Venetian glass will be the focus of a show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: The most comprehensive collection of equipment and souvenirs from ice-skating shows sits in an unprepossessing brick photo studio in Minneapolis. Costumes, skates, props, dolls, jewelry, spoons, posters, programs, tickets and even popcorn containers are neatly packed into boxes and binders. They date to the 1910s, when nightclubs started installing minirinks and appreciative audiences would carry star skaters through the streets after shows.

headline: A Neighborhood Prowl Through the City of Chianti
abstract: Tasting the “other Chiantis” besides Classico.
lead_paragraph: I’m in love with the sangiovese grape. This is no new infatuation. I’ve always loved Chiantis, the wines of Montalcino and the various other expressions of Tuscan sangiovese. But this year the affair has intensified.

headline: Ackman to Sell Part of His Stake in Canadian Pacific
abstract: The activist investor will have nearly tripled his investment in Canadian Pacific, at a time when he needs it most.
lead_paragraph: More than a year after the activist investor William A. Ackman won a bitter battle for control of the Canadian Pacific Railway, he is cashing in part of his investment at a substantial profit.

headline: ‘John Ashbery Collects’: ‘Poet Among Things’
abstract: The poet John Ashbery has tight connections to art. He wrote about it professionally for years. Recently, he’s been producing it at quite a clip.
lead_paragraph: Loretta Howard Gallery

headline: A New Ethiopian Lodge With a Focus on Conservation
abstract: The Bale Mountain Lodge in Ethiopia is within a park known for its biodiversity and employs a resident naturalist.
lead_paragraph: The first resort in Ethiopia’s wildlife-rich Bale Mountains National Park, Bale Mountain Lodge, opening Nov. 1, is poised to expand the African safari checklist beyond the Big Five.

headline: Donald Judd: ‘Stacks’
abstract: Mr. Judd once wrote that an artist’s main challenge is to find “the concatenation that will grow” — in other words, an artistic preoccupation that will sustain a lifetime of development.
lead_paragraph: Mnuchin Gallery

headline: Kenya Assails Coverage of an Attack on a Mall
keywords: ['Nairobi, Kenya, Westgate Mall Shootings (2013)', 'News and News Media', 'Looting (Crime)']
abstract: Journalists connected with showing a video that appears to show Kenyan forces looting at the Westgate mall have been summoned by the police.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenyan journalists came under threat this week from the authorities over their coverage of last month’s Westgate mall attack, after video suggesting possible looting by Kenyan forces was broadcast on national television.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Pakistan, Australia, South Africa and Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Pakistan, Australia, South Africa and Bangladesh.

headline: Amazon’s Revenue Soars, but No Profit Is in Sight
abstract: Low prices and a heavy investment in building warehouses ate into the company’s earnings.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Amazon’s third quarter followed a familiar script: it sold vast quantities of things, lost money while doing so, and investors were delighted.

headline: ‘Art of Byzantium From Greek Collections’
abstract: An exhibition at the National Gallery of Art takes a processional sweep through Byzantine iconography, with about 170 items for many centuries.
lead_paragraph: An exhibition at the National Gallery of Art takes a processional sweep through Byzantine iconography, with about 170 items for many centuries.

headline: William Anastasi: ‘Sound Works, 1963-2013’
abstract: Mr. Anastasi’s work questions notions of art, perception and reality.
lead_paragraph: Hunter College Art Galleries

headline: France Begins New Anti-Islamist Sweep in Mali
abstract: France said the operation was coordinated with Malian forces and United Nations peacekeepers to thwart  “a resurgence of terrorist movements.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — French soldiers in Mali have begun a major anti-insurgent sweep with Malian forces and United Nations peacekeepers, the Defense Ministry said on Thursday, calling it the largest operation to counteract a revival of Islamist militant activity since France intervened early this year.

headline: Annette Kelm
abstract: Ms. Kelm shows obvious debts to Düsseldorf School photographers like Candida Höfer, but her affinities lie with American post-conceptualism
lead_paragraph: Andrew Kreps

headline: Christoph Ruckhäberle: ‘Frühstück im Freien’
abstract: Mr. Ruckhäberle is back in New York with an arresting show that makes us remember what all the fuss was about.
lead_paragraph: ZieherSmith

headline: G.O.P. Roots for Failure
abstract: Republicans have done everything in their power to dismantle the Affordable Care Act. It’s understandable that Democrats question their motives.
lead_paragraph: In theory, lawmakers hope that government programs work well, and if they don’t, try to fix them. In theory, our representatives hope that government agencies carry out their missions smoothly, and if something goes wrong, try to figure out what happened to avoid making the same mistake in the future.

headline: Fantasy Precedes Melancholy Darkness
abstract: The delicacy of the textures of Mendelssohn’s Overture to “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” work complemented the precision of the scoring in a Britten cycle in an Orchestra of St. Luke’s program.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, it seemed the height of timidity for the excellent and adventurous conductor Pablo Heras-Casado to open the Orchestra of St. Luke’s program on Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall with a frequently heard staple: Mendelssohn’s Overture to “A Midsummer Night’s Dream.” Big things are expected of this exuberant Spanish artist, 35, who was appointed principal conductor of St. Luke’s in December 2011.

headline: Lots of Dim Sum Feeds a Starry Career
abstract: Chris Cannon has had a long career in fine dining, and its genesis was at a simple dim sum parlor in Chinatown.
lead_paragraph: First love dies hard.

headline: Brisk Sales to Business at Microsoft; Devices Lag
abstract: The earnings of $5.24 billion beat expectations, and were helped in large part by a surge in the company’s corporate software business.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The person named to be Microsoft’s new chief executive will inherit two companies. One is thriving, the other is sluggish.

headline: Ruling Lets Times Co. Complete Globe Sale
abstract: The completion of the sale to John W. Henry, owner of the Boston Red Sox, had been held up by a lawsuit involving the Worcester, Mass., paper.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company completed the sale of the New England Media Group, which includes The Boston Globe, to John W. Henry on Thursday, after a Massachusetts judge lifted an injunction that had temporarily halted the sale.

headline: ‘My West Coast Martha’s Vineyard’
abstract: The Point Reyes area, north of San Francisco, strikes the author as similar to the Massachusetts island — only better.
lead_paragraph: That first time I walked through the grassy dunes of Point Reyes National Seashore, back in 1997, it felt familiar. On this stretch of California sand, I’d found the West Coast doppelgänger of Gay Head, on the southwestern point of Martha’s Vineyard, from where I’d recently moved. Though it was summer, I was wearing a fleece, and the sandstone cliffs of Limantour Beach were shrouded in fog. But the echoes of the Vineyard in Point Reyes were immediately clear: a rugged, relatively remote refuge with salty air, fresh fish and a strong sense of place.

headline: Part Ostentatious, Part Intimate
abstract: Dozens of dealers show works at the International Fine Art & Antique Dealers Show at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: If you like old clocks — and who doesn’t like old clocks? — there’s one you must see in the International Fine Art & Antique Dealers Show at the Park Avenue Armory. Displayed by Richard Redding Antiques, one of the show’s 67 vendors, it’s called “The Hartmann Exhibition Clock,” and it’s spectacular. A gleaming, complicated assemblage of gilt bronze, it has a neo-classical base from which columns resembling minarets made of basket-woven metal bands rise. These flank a roughly pyramidal tower of eight different clocks with enameled faces keeping time according to as many different systems. At the summit a little figure of Victory blows a trumpet. It also has a variety of automata, including small silver rods whose revolutions suggest streams of falling water.

headline: Exploring Point Reyes
abstract: Sun and fog, oysters and organic produce in this area north of San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Sun and fog, oysters and organic produce in this area north of San Francisco.

headline: A Fairy Tale Heroine Finds Her Magic Tree
abstract: Christopher Wheeldon’s “Cinderella,” performed by San Francisco Ballet, has no fairy godmother or a magic pumpkin.
lead_paragraph: In his ambitious “Cinderella,” performed by San Francisco Ballet on Wednesday at the David H. Koch Theater, the British choreographer Christopher Wheeldon discards the magic pumpkin. Instead of a fairy godmother, Cinderella has four male Fates, who have the aura of the Blue Man Group, even though their faces are painted gold. Among other duties, they tidy the kitchen.

headline: Excerpt: 'The Snow Geese'
abstract: Mary-Louise Parker and Danny Burstein in a scene from Sharr White's new Broadway play at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.
lead_paragraph: Mary-Louise Parker and Danny Burstein in a scene from Sharr White's new Broadway play at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater.

headline: Christopher Wool at the Guggenheim
abstract: The museum is featuring paintings and works on paper.
lead_paragraph: The museum is featuring paintings and works on paper.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 8 Tiered Player Rankings
abstract: Applying an algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data reveals natural tiers and clusters within the data.
lead_paragraph: In this statistical model, I apply a clustering algorithm called the Gaussian mixture model to an aggregation of expert ranking data provided by Fantasypros.com. The algorithm finds natural tiers and clusters within the data. The charts that result visualize the tiers and help you decide your starting lineup each week.

headline: Fed Proposes a Rule to Help Big Banks Stay Liquid in Times of Crisis
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The rule asks banks to estimate how much cash might flee in a 30-day period, and requires them to enough assets that they could sell to cover that outflow.
lead_paragraph: During the financial crisis of 2008, the big banks fell dangerously short of cash, forcing them to take out enormous government loans to survive the tumult.

headline: Samsung Electronics Fined for Fake Online Comments
abstract: A Taiwanese trade agency has punished Samsung Electronics for paying people to post fake online comments that mocked its competitor, HTC, the struggling handset maker. The South Korean manufacturer will have to pay a fine of about $340,000.
lead_paragraph: A Taiwanese trade agency has punished Samsung Electronics for paying people to post fake online comments that mocked a competitor.

headline: She’s Glad to Be Onstage and Turning Back the Clock
abstract: Marilyn Maye performed nearly 30 vintage show tunes, with a special emphasis on songs from “Guys and Dolls,” in her show at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: “I’m glad to be anywhere,” said Marilyn Maye, the inexhaustibly sunny 85-year-old trouper — who has every reason to be joyful — at 54 Below on Monday evening. In the opening-night performance of her new show, in which she jazzed up nearly 30 vintage show tunes, with a special emphasis on songs from “Guys and Dolls,” she exhibited no signs of the kind of faltering stamina that would seem almost inevitable for someone her age.

headline: Their Names Are Legion
abstract: It has been more than three decades since the People’s Republic embraced the outside world, and to judge from the range of English names adopted by the educated and upwardly mobile, the Chinese appear to be taking it very personally.
lead_paragraph: When Hu Yinan meets someone new, say, in a meeting or at a party, she prefers to introduce herself by her English name: Number.

headline: Filling in the Blanks in the Tale of a Death
abstract: “Strike Back,” Cinemax’s globe-hopping counterterrorism series, is showing Season 1 for the first time in the United States, following Seasons 2 and 3, which have already been broadcast.
lead_paragraph: When “Strike Back,” Cinemax’s post-Sept. 11, globe-hopping counterterrorism series, began in 2011, something felt missing. In the premiere, a British special-forces soldier was kidnapped in Pakistan and executed, and people back in London were very upset, which made sense. But viewers were left wondering: Who was that guy? Why were we supposed to care so much about him?

headline: Fangs Follow the Fairy Tales
abstract: Jonathan Rhys Meyers stars as the title character in “Dracula,” a new vampire drama on NBC.
lead_paragraph: During its short life so far, NBC’s splendid fairy tale action-adventure “Grimm” — one of the network’s few nonfootball successes — has been stranded on Friday nights. For company, the network has given it a motley crew of “Dateline,” a few disposable reality shows and the last months of “Chuck.”

headline: Focused Effort to Narrow the Gender Gap on Corporate Boards
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Boards of Directors', 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: A program at George Washington University School of Business is helping women be considered for board seats and training them to step into those posts.
lead_paragraph: The dearth of women on corporate boards has been a persistent issue for decades. Yet little has changed over the years, despite much public hand-wringing over the stubborn gender gap.

headline: After Muddy Waters Report, NQ Mobile Falls by Half
abstract: The short-selling firm known for its scathing reports on Chinese companies released a harsh assessment of the mobile security company.
lead_paragraph: When the stock market opened on Thursday, NQ Mobile, a Chinese mobile security company, had a valuation of $1.1 billion. Just hours later, half of its value was erased.

headline: Murder, Mayhem and Cross-Dressing Zombies
abstract: The Filipino horror comedy “Remington and the Curse of the Zombadings” features zombie drag queens, a gay curse and a serial killer with a gaydar gun.
lead_paragraph: Don’t be fooled by the unwieldy title: “Remington and the Curse of the Zombadings” is nothing if not narratively succinct. Hailing from the genre-loving Philippines, this batty horror-comedy, directed by Jade Castro (who was also one of the film’s three writers), knows exactly what it is and where it’s going.

headline: Viewing for Your Inner Michael Myers
abstract: Three authors make recommendations for what to watch during your own Halloween film festival.
lead_paragraph: LET’S say you’re more “Halloween” than Halloween. You love scary movies, but the actual holiday makes you want to punch a drunken Dracula in the plastic fangs. You’d much rather turn off the lights, ignore the trick-or-treaters at the door, dig your nails into the couch and enjoy a good (or bad-good) horror movie at home. But first you must sort through the fright-flick detritus.

headline: Internet Archive Will Shield Visitors
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Inspired by recent revelations of the depth of the N.S.A.’s monitoring of online behavior, the Internet Archive is taking a step to ensure the privacy of its users.
lead_paragraph: Reading, once the most private of acts, is going public. The simple act of buying a book can be automatically publicized through social media. The makers of reading devices know who skipped chapter three and how many people made a note of that lovely passage in chapter four.

headline: Tripping All the Way to the Gates of Hell
abstract: In Jason Banker’s “Toad Road,” two young people high on drugs check out a local legend and its supposedly sinister secrets.
lead_paragraph: If you enter “Toad Road” expecting a conventional horror movie, you will be sorely disappointed. But if you’re looking for an uncomfortably authentic drama about the horrors of dedicated drug use, then this strange little number from Jason Banker (who also wrote the screenplay and wielded the camera) might just do the trick.

headline: Social Media, the Spiritual Version
abstract: Centuries of iconography are depicted in “Heaven and Earth: Art of Byzantium From Greek Collections,” at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After arriving with no particular buzz, then being kept on ice by the government shutdown, “Heaven and Earth: Art of Byzantium From Greek Collections” has finally opened at the National Gallery of Art here, and it’s ambushingly resplendent, like a somber cloud with a fire inside.

headline: Excursions in a Digitally Fabricated Landscape
abstract: “Out of Hand: Materializing the Postdigital,” at the Museum of Arts and Design, offers a chance to catch up on the 3-D fabrication technologies remaking art and architecture.
lead_paragraph: If you haven’t quite wrapped your head around the concept of 3-D printing, or haven’t yet had a digital scanner wrap itself around you, now you can do both in “Out of Hand: Materializing the Postdigital,” at the Museum of Arts and Design. The technologies in this survey of computer-assisted art, architecture and design may not be entirely new; the Museum of Modern Art’s 2008 exhibition “Design and the Elastic Mind” covered much the same territory and included some of the same artists and projects. But these tools are becoming more pervasive in both art and life, making this a good time for the uninitiated to get up to speed.

headline: On the Road With the Vienna Boys Choir
abstract: Curt Faudon’s “Bridging the Gap” chronicles the Vienna Boys Choir’s cross-cultural journeys.
lead_paragraph: In the opening of “Bridging the Gap,” members of the Vienna Boys Choir, clad in its traditional sailor suits, arrive in a rowboat on what is apparently the shore of New Zealand and plunges into welcome rituals with Maori people. The situation almost recalls a memorable scene from “Lord of the Flies,” in which a storm-tossed choir sings “Kyrie eleison” in procession on a beach, but the photography here has the color cranked way up, and a plummy, National Geographic-style voice-over pours forth platitudes and edifying narration.

headline: Painting’s Endgame, Rendered Graphically
abstract: An exhibition of Christopher Wool’s paintings and works on paper at the Guggenheim Museum offers lessons about the act of looking as exploration.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Wool is one of many painters who have experimented with bringing their medium to extinction. They strip it of familiar attributes like imagery, brushwork or flatness, often ending up with some kind of monochrome that suggests the last painting that could possibly be made.

headline: Stop by These Subway Stops
abstract: The best locations in New York’s sprawling train system.

headline: Wildlife Is Tame; Not the Humans
abstract: Ridley Scott and Cormac McCarthy team up for “The Counselor,” a tale of a corrupt, high-flying lawyer dealing with a drug cartel.
lead_paragraph: “The Counselor,” Ridley Scott’s terrifying, implacable new movie, opens on a seductive scene. The setting is a softly lighted bedroom in which two people are murmuring sweet, dirty nothings under a white sheet. You don’t see who they are until there’s a cut to under the sheet, bringing you close enough to Michael Fassbender and Penélope Cruz to feel like an interloper.

abstract: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss the surprise hits among this year’s new comedies.
lead_paragraph: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss the surprise hits among this year’s new comedies.

headline: ‘You’re Fired,’ in Terms Only a Boss Could Love
abstract: In a video, The Times’s David Gillen explains how companies like HSBC, AOL and Hewlett-Packard are getting creative with the jargon behind major layoffs, from “downsizing” to “right-sizing.”
lead_paragraph: Through booms and busts, profits and losses, the vacuous jargon and happy euphemisms of the business world endure. In fact, they flourish. At a time when the nation’s economy is plodding and job growth is sluggish, corporations are coming up with new ways to sugarcoat words no employee wants to hear: You’re fired.

headline: In Jil Sander’s Exit, Echoes of the Past
abstract: Ms. Sander announced that she is leaving the Jil Sander company for unspecified personal reasons, for a third time.
lead_paragraph: EVER SINCE she sold her company to Prada, in 1999, Jil Sander has not been sure she wanted to stay. She has left three times. The third occurred on Thursday with the announcement that she is leaving for unspecified personal reasons.

headline: Response to a City’s Smog Points to a Change in Chinese Attitude
abstract: Rising concern about pollution in China and a more active response signal that some officials are serious about tackling the chronic problem.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Emergency measures came swiftly in Harbin, the northeastern city blanketed with hazardous smog this week: Schools were shut down, buses ordered off the roads, the airport closed, police roadblocks set up to check tailpipe emissions from cars. City officials even fanned out in the surrounding countryside, ordering farmers to stop burning the cornstalks left in their fields after the harvest.

headline: Brave Optimism of Tahrir Square Meets Other Fierce Forces
keywords: ['Movies', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: “The Square,” Jehane Noujaim’s new documentary, makes the Egyptian uprising and the political fallout of this summer feel close and personal.
lead_paragraph: In the language of politics, “the people” is a great abstraction, an idea that can be invoked to justify noble projects and terrible crimes. “The Square,” Jehane Noujaim’s stunning new documentary, is partly about the contested status of the Egyptian people between the winter of 2011, when crowds of protesters gathered in Tahrir Square to demand the removal of President Hosni Mubarak, and the summer of 2013, when the army ousted his successor, Mohamed Morsi, and began a violent campaign against his followers in the Muslim Brotherhood. Mr. Morsi, the military and the demonstrators — and, for that matter, Mr. Mubarak himself — all claimed to be true agents and loyal servants of the popular will.

headline: Dani Shapiro’s Provident Move to the Country
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Religion and Belief', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The author and her husband left the city for Connecticut and found a more spiritual life.
lead_paragraph: Dani Shapiro, the novelist and memoirist, has awesome real estate karma. In the 1980s and 1990s, she lived in three of the Upper West Side’s most storied landmark buildings: the Ansonia, the Dakota and the Hotel des Artistes. When she and her husband, the screenwriter and director Michael Maren, decided to move to Brooklyn in the late 1990s, they bought a town house in gentrifying Prospect Heights right before yoga studios arrived and prices escalated.

headline: The Man Beneath the Hairspray
abstract: Divine, a muse to John Waters and the star in many of his studies in bad taste, is the subject of the film “I am Divine,” directed by Jeffrey Schwarz.
lead_paragraph: Before Boy George, before RuPaul, there was Divine, the zaftig drag diva and provocateur of early John Waters films who, once glimpsed, was hard to forget. Facetiously dubbed “the filthiest person alive” for a notorious scene in the 1972 film “Pink Flamingos,” in which he ate dog feces, Divine expanded the concept of the drag queen from brash female impersonator into something much larger, more subversive and less gender specific.

headline: Learning From Rejection
abstract: A rejection from a mortgage lender is no cause for shame. Instead, think of it as a call to action.
lead_paragraph: A rejection from a mortgage lender is no cause for shame. Instead, think of it as a call to action.

abstract: A listing of cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

abstract: A demand for stand-alone mansions, driven by the rare opportunity they offer wealthy buyers for complete privacy and autonomy.
lead_paragraph: A run-down parking garage is for sale on the corner of Perry and Greenwich Streets in the West Village, and at least one of the bidders wants to tear it down to its bones and replace it with a 40,000-square-foot mansion — creating what would be the largest single-family home in New York City.

headline: So Evil, They Cackle at Strategy Meetings
abstract: “Capital,” directed by Costa-Gavras, centers on the machinations of ruthless financiers during a takeover attempt.
lead_paragraph: Who doesn’t hate, at least a little bit, the high-flying wheeler-dealers who recently brought the world to the brink of economic collapse and were never held accountable? As you watch the Costa-Gavras financial thriller “Capital,” it may rekindle some of the rage and fear that people felt when the pillars trembled.

headline: Being Gay in Lebanon
abstract: “Out Loud,” from Samer Daboul, is a film from Lebanon engaging the taboo: homosexuality.
lead_paragraph: Samer Daboul’s “Out Loud” bills itself as the first gay film from Lebanon. Six rebellious young idealists break all the social and religious rules and decide to live communally. In hot pursuit are the relatives of the two who are gay, Rami (Ali Rhayem) and Ziad (Jean Kobrously), closeted lovers who were caught kissing and are marked for death for having brought shame to their families.

headline: ‘You’re Demised!’ Getting Fired Evolves
abstract: The Times’s David Gillen explains how companies like HSBC, AOL and Hewlett-Packard are getting creative with the jargon behind major layoffs, from “downsizing” to “right-sizing.”
lead_paragraph: The Times’s David Gillen explains how companies like HSBC, AOL and Hewlett-Packard are getting creative with the jargon behind major layoffs, from “downsizing” to “right-sizing.”

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: New Debate About Sexism, and Battle for Power of the Internet
abstract: Thursday’s highlights from around the Web include a discussion about Silicon Valley’s so-called meritocracy when it comes to women, and a battle for power in cyberspace between hackers and citizens on one side and governments and corporations on the other.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: A Geriatric Biker Gang
abstract: “Go Grandriders” follows a gang of elderly motor scooter riders as they try to circumnavigate Taiwan on its scenic and crowded coastal roads.
lead_paragraph: There is undeniable exhilaration in the aerial shots of “Go Grandriders,” as a gang of motor-scooter-riding 70- and 80-somethings in matching helmets, shirts and jackets rides along majestic Taiwanese coastal roads. There is mystery, too, in this documentary about their cross-country ride, but mostly from omission in the sometimes inept storytelling.

headline: Fishing as Therapy
abstract: “Not Yet Begun to Fight” shows combat veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan undergoing an unusual form of therapy: fly-fishing as regenerative meditation.
lead_paragraph: Like a documentary antidote to the adrenaline flow of “The Hurt Locker,” the modest, becalmed “Not Yet Begun to Fight” shows veterans of combat in Iraq and Afghanistan undergoing an unusual but apt form of therapy. These warriors, hobbled by injuries and psychologically fragile, enter a program that treats the guy’s-guy pastime of fly-fishing as regenerative meditation. The directors, Shasta Grenier and Sabrina Lee, delicately find moments of openness in casual, lapidary interviews with five men at different points in recovery.

headline: Troubles in the Kitchen
abstract: “Spinning Plates” portrays the challenges faced by the proprietors of three very different restaurants.
lead_paragraph: Joseph Levy’s ordinary documentary “Spinning Plates” rotates among the challenges faced by the proprietors of three restaurants: the 150-year-old Breitbach’s Country Dining, in Balltown, Iowa; a struggling roadside Mexican joint in Tucson; and the chef Grant Achatz’s Alinea in Chicago, which has three Michelin stars. While a lot could be said about each, and about food and culture generally, this dully structured film makes its points early and often, treading water before a purposely delayed big finish.

headline: Crudely Closing a Generation Gap
abstract: Johnny Knoxville’s latest prankfest has him portraying 86-year-old Irving Zisman on a cross-country trip with an 8-year-old grandson named Billy.
lead_paragraph: Attending “Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa,” Johnny Knoxville’s new prankfest, could be life-changing. It may cause you never to use another vending machine, never to enter another bingo parlor, never to put your child on one of those coin-operated rides, never to eat in another diner.

headline: Finding Love in a Cruel Time
abstract: In “The Pin,” Naomi Jaye tells a tale of two young Eastern Europeans hiding in a barn during World War II and creates a mood of unadulterated romance.
lead_paragraph: One man and one woman against the world is a familiar story, among the oldest, told from Genesis to “The Blue Lagoon.” “The Pin,” a Canadian film about two young Eastern Europeans hiding in a barn during World War II, is a variation in which the couple are enclosed in menace. Here their island is an underground hiding place and the Yiddish they speak to each other.

headline: Incalculable Loss, Inconsolable Mother
abstract: Postpartum depression takes a homicidal turn in Le-Van Kiet’s “House in the Alley.”
lead_paragraph: We have seen J-horror from Japan, K-horror from South Korea, and now, with Le-Van Kiet’s “House in the Alley,” V-horror from Vietnam. Postpartum depression takes a murderous turn in this slight exercise, which, for all its modesty, generates a measure of dread.

headline: Filmmaker Chronicles His Battle With Illness
abstract: The director Jason DaSilva records his daily battle with a degenerative disease in “When I Walk.”
lead_paragraph: The title is “When I Walk,” but Jason DaSilva’s hard-hitting record of his daily battle with primary-progressive multiple sclerosis is really an exploration of creeping immobility. From the moment his legs gave way during a 2006 Caribbean vacation, to the film’s improbably upbeat 2012 conclusion, Mr. DaSilva, a successful documentary filmmaker and just 25 when he received his diagnosis, ruthlessly chronicled his dismayingly rapid decline.

headline: A Game of Shark and Minnow
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States International Relations', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: The shell of a forsaken ship has become a battleground in a struggle that could shape the future of the South China Sea and, to some extent, the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: In a remote corner of the South China Sea, 105 nautical miles from the Philippines, lies a submerged reef that the Filipinos call Ayungin. There’s little to commend the spot, apart from its plentiful fish and safe harbor. In most ways it resembles the hundreds of other desolate reefs, islands, rock clusters and cays that collectively are called the Spratly Islands. But Ayungin is different. It sits on the southwestern edge of Reed Bank, an area rumored to contain vast reserves of oil and natural gas. And its shallows are home to a World War II-era ship called the Sierra Madre, which the Philippine government ran aground on the reef in 1999 and has since maintained as a kind of post-apocalyptic military garrison, manned by eight Filipino troops struggling to survive extreme mental and physical desolation. Of all places, the scorched shell of the Sierra Madre has become an unlikely battleground in a geopolitical struggle that will shape the future of the South China Sea and, to some extent, the rest of the world.

headline: DuPont to Split Into 2 as It Plans to Spin Off a Major Segment
abstract: The move is an effort to focus on businesses with better growth prospects.
lead_paragraph: The industrial conglomerate DuPont is splitting in two.

headline: Group Linked to Kochs Admits to Campaign Finance Violations
abstract: The nonprofit, which has ties to the billionaire conservative businessmen Charles and David Koch, failed to disclose over $15 million in contributions it funneled into California referendum battles.
lead_paragraph: A secretive nonprofit group with ties to the billionaire conservative businessmen Charles and David Koch admitted to improperly failing to disclose more than $15 million in contributions it funneled into state referendum battles in California, state officials there announced Thursday.

headline: A Portal to the Old World
abstract: At Dubrovnik, a Croatian restaurant in New Rochelle, home-style fare and nautical ambience transport diners to a faraway place.
lead_paragraph: A G.P.S. comes in handy on the way to Dubrovnik, an exciting, handsome restaurant on an unprepossessing block on Main Street in New Rochelle. This authentic Croatian spot — my Croatian-American guests thought the only thing missing was the Adriatic lapping at limestone cliffs — is polished but not fussy, just like the dishes created by its Croatian owner and chef, Zeljko Tomic, known as Jerry.

headline: To Combat Elder Abuse, Doormen Are Enlisted to Keep a Watchful Eye
keywords: ['Elder Abuse', 'Doormen', 'Building Service Employees', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A program offers free on-site training and assistance to doormen, concierges, porters and other building staff across New York City.
lead_paragraph: Michael Marlow, a doorman at the Gracie Mews apartment building on the Upper East Side, does a lot more than just open doors for residents. He unscrews their jar lids, runs to the store for apple juice, listens to their complaints about spouses and children, and even reaches into his own pocket to lend a couple of dollars for cab fare.

headline: American Comfort Food From Asia
abstract: At Sweet Chilli, in West Hartford, a brother and sister cook familiar favorites from Thai cuisine, with a few deviations.
lead_paragraph: It’s interesting to recall how exotic Thai food once seemed, now that pad Thai is almost as American as spaghetti. My newest Thai favorite is Sweet Chilli on Park Road in West Hartford, a restaurant with a casually sumptuous look and soothing feel. It is often full but never loud. (And yes, the extra “l” in the restaurant’s name is intentional — meant to help distinguish its fare from Tex-Mex chili.)

headline: Despite Rising Sticker Prices, Actual College Costs Stable Over Decade, Study Says
abstract: The net cost of a private college works out to about $23,000 this year, a figure that, adjusted for inflation, has not varied much for 10 years.
lead_paragraph: Every year, price increases at private colleges prompt a round of appalled responses and calls for corrective action. But even as some sticker prices approach $60,000 a year, the amount that students actually pay — because of increased discounts, grants and tax benefits — has barely changed over the last decade, according to a major analysis of college costs published this week.

headline: Where Soul Food Is a Family Affair
abstract: Run by a couple and their daughters, Pretty Toni’s Cafe advertises its cuisine as “soul food and more.”
lead_paragraph: “There are no good restaurants in Valley Stream” was a complaint I heard recently from friends who live there. I begged to differ and proved my point by taking them to Pretty Toni’s Cafe. This very good restaurant, which opened in January 2009, seems to have been overlooked by some of the local residents.

headline: City Says Principal Didn’t Tell of Abuse Claim
abstract: A Bronx student told a principal, Angelyn Donald, that he saw a teacher kissing a 10-year-old girl but the principal took no action, the city says.
lead_paragraph: In May, a student at a Bronx elementary school told his principal he saw a teacher kissing a 10-year-old girl in the back of a dark, empty classroom. Another student told the principal, Angelyn Donald, that the man and the girl had exchanged a sexually explicit note during class.

headline: Ukraine: Boxing Champion Throws His Hat in a New Ring
abstract: Vitali Klitschko, who is the reigning World Boxing Council heavyweight champion and leads an opposition political party in Ukraine, declared his candidacy for president of Ukraine in an election scheduled for 2015.
lead_paragraph: Vitali Klitschko, who is the reigning World Boxing Council heavyweight champion and leads an opposition political party in Ukraine, on Thursday declared his candidacy for president of Ukraine in an election scheduled for 2015. His decision to challenge the incumbent, Viktor F. Yanukovich, came in response to an effort in the Ukrainian Parliament to pass a bill that would prohibit him from running because he holds permanent resident status in Germany, where he has trained.

headline: New York City Amends Fee Policy for a Visit to the Met
abstract: Clarifying decades of legal vagueness, the amended lease spells out that the Metropolitan Museum of Art is allowed to charge a suggested admission fee.
lead_paragraph: Clarifying four decades of legal vagueness, the Bloomberg administration has amended New York City’s lease with the Metropolitan Museum of Art, spelling out that the Met is allowed to charge a suggested admission fee, as the museum has done since 1971 under an agreement with the city. The amendment adds that fees for special exhibitions may also be charged, a widespread practice in the art world but something the museum decided against in the 1980s.

headline: Winning Sports Fans’ Hearts by Giving Them Somewhere to Go
abstract: Procter & Gamble is transporting trailers with about 20 restrooms — stocked with the company’s Charmin toilet paper — to N.F.L. stadiums for pregame revelers to use.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDING product samples is a relatively simple affair for many products, whether it’s fragrance brand representatives spritzing consumers in department stores or snack brand representatives handing out tortilla chips in supermarkets. For toilet paper brands, getting consumers to try the product on the spot is decidedly more complicated.

headline: Why the Government Never Gets Tech Right
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Government Procurement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama has had to watch his signature achievement be held hostage by that most banal of captors: a clunky computer system.
lead_paragraph: MILLIONS of Americans negotiating America’s health care system know all too well what the waiting room of a doctor’s office looks like. Now, thanks to HealthCare.gov, they know what a “virtual waiting room” looks like, too. Nearly 20 million Americans, in fact, have visited the Web site since it opened three weeks ago, but only about 500,000 managed to complete applications for insurance coverage. And an even smaller subset of those applicants actually obtained coverage.

headline: Anthony Caro, Sculptor, Dies at 89
abstract: Anthony Caro followed sculpture from the monumental to the abstract.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Caro followed sculpture from the monumental to the abstract.

headline: Would-Be Virginia Governors Spar, Continuing Bitter Tone
abstract: The Virginia governor’s race has been characterized by negativity and a great deal of outside money, with voters feeling little enthusiasm for any candidate.
lead_paragraph: BLACKSBURG, Va. — Trailing in polls and outspent on the airwaves, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, who has sought to capture the swing state of Virginia by building on his Tea Party base, faced his last, best chance to reboot the race for governor in a debate here Thursday.

headline: Fighting for a Hallowed and Grueling Ground
abstract: The nearly 100-year old cross-country course in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, a 3.1-mile stretch of woods, hills and ankle-twisting obstacles, has been badly eroded.
lead_paragraph: There are many who dread Cemetery Hill.

headline: The Bad News for Local Job Markets
abstract: The number of education and health care jobs could grow in the coming years, but this does not imply job growth in small and midsize cities that depend on these sectors.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C. — THE September jobs numbers, finally released this week after the government reopened, indicate that the job market remains on a painfully slow upward trajectory. Unemployment has fallen a full percentage point since early 2012, but at this pace, our economy could still be years away from its prerecession level. To make faster progress, many analysts are banking on job growth from two key sectors, education and health care.

headline: Hitting the Wall: For Marathon Charities, Numbers Are Slowing
abstract: Some race and nonprofit organizers are worried that charitable fund-raising tied to marathons may be wheezing like a runner at Mile 25, with fewer charity runners and less money raised.
lead_paragraph: By this time of year, the height of fall marathon season, the e-mails have long piled up: marathon aspirants seeking charitable donations from family and friends to help them secure a spot in a particular race. On race days, charity logos on runners’ gear have become as ubiquitous as mile markers, an integral part of an event’s feel-good message of fitness and philanthropy.

headline: Timeline of the Skakel Case
abstract: More than a decade after the conviction of Michael Skakel in the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley in Greenwich, Conn., a judge has ordered that Mr. Skakel be released on bail. Here is a look at how the case unfolded through the years.
lead_paragraph: More than a decade after the conviction of Michael Skakel in the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley in Greenwich, Conn., a judge has ordered that Mr. Skakel be released on bail. Here is a look at how the case unfolded through the years.

headline: Upstart in Miami Lures Luxury Stores From a Chic Citadel
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Many high-end brands have left behind Bal Harbour Shops, for years a magnet to the wealthy, for more breathing room in Miami’s Design District.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For decades, the wealthy tourists and transplants who flock to South Florida bought their Chanels, Cartiers, Diors and the like at one place: Bal Harbour Shops, an open-air mall housing many of the highest-end retailers in the world around a courtyard of palm trees and koi ponds at the northern end of Miami Beach.

headline: After Baby Hope Confession, Assessing the Value of Taped Interrogations
keywords: ['Confessions', 'Interrogations', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Video Recordings and Downloads', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Police']

lead_paragraph: Q. The police commissioner announced more than a year ago that detectives would videotape their interrogations of suspects in serious cases like murder. That’s what they did in the Baby Hope case, right?

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for Oct. 24, 2013
abstract: Lottery numbers for Oct. 24 for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Addicted to the Apocalypse
abstract: The sky is falling! The sky is falling. When it comes to all the talk of economic catastrophe, why are these disaster fantasies taken so seriously?
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, walking around shouting “The end is nigh” got you labeled a kook, someone not to be taken seriously. These days, however, all the best people go around warning of looming disaster. In fact, you more or less have to subscribe to fantasies of fiscal apocalypse to be considered respectable.

headline: City to Fit All Streetlights With Energy-Saving LED Bulbs
abstract: The phaseout is part of a long-term plan to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 30 percent by 2017 and, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said, would save taxpayers money.
lead_paragraph: The amber glow of the New York City streetlight is going away. In an energy-saving effort, the city plans to replace all of its 250,000 streetlights with brighter, whiter, energy-saving, light-emitting diode fixtures in one of the nation’s largest retrofitting projects, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the transportation commissioner, Janette Sadik-Khan, said in a news conference on Thursday.

headline: In the Skakel Case, 2 Women on 2 Sides in an Endless Vigil
abstract: Dorthy Moxley has attended years of hearings for her slain daughter, Martha Moxley, and Ann Skakel McCooey for her nephew who was convicted of the 1975 killing but has been granted a new trial.
lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, they have driven themselves to court hearings, sat a few feet apart through countless hours of harrowing testimony, and exchanged cordial greetings, if not quite warm ones.

headline: The Ghosts of October
abstract: As each icon from our baseball childhood retires, we are forced to admit that we must be aging, too.
lead_paragraph: As I push my 4-year-old daughter on the swing, I wonder when the day will come when she will not need me to supply the power. My children remind me that time is marching on even when the frenetic pace of a parenting day convinces us that we don’t have time to age.

headline: French to Strike, but This Time Owners Call It
abstract: A group representing France’s professional soccer owners plans to cancel matches next month to protest a tax on salaries of more than one million euros.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The labor strike being something of a national sport in France, it should come as no surprise that its practitioners occasionally include professional athletes.

headline: No to More Casinos in New York State
abstract: Gov. Andrew Cuomo wants to expand gambling through a constitutional amendment on the Nov. 5 ballot. The answer from voters should be no.
lead_paragraph: New York State is home to five casinos run by Indian tribes and nine casinos that are called “racinos” because they are large slot machine parlors near racetracks. Gov. Andrew Cuomo and the Legislature now want to expand gambling by putting a constitutional amendment on the Nov. 5 ballot that would add seven full-blown casinos. The answer from voters should be no.

headline: Seeking a New Relationship With Pakistan
abstract: After a decade of turmoil and mistrust, big obstacles lie in the way of a more constructive relationship between Pakistan and the United States.
lead_paragraph: After so many years of animosity between Pakistan and the United States, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif and President Obama used their first meeting at the White House this week to begin to set the relationship on a more constructive path.

headline: White House Official’s Career Twitters Out
abstract: Colleagues of Jofi Joseph, a National Security Council employee unmasked as an acerbic commentator on Twitter, say he was funny and smart. But many also saw a negative tendency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Until his Twitter adventures under the handle @NatSecWonk ended his career this week, Jofi Joseph embodied all the elements of a Washington cliché, down to the security card around his neck. His degree in foreign service was earned at Georgetown, which propelled him to his first job as an analyst in the Congressional Budget Office, the ultimately anonymous D.C. gig.

headline: @NatSecWonk Snark
abstract: A selection of Twitter posts about top administration officials written by Jofi Joseph, the National Security Council staff member who was fired for using an anonymous Twitter handle to knock public figures, reporters and colleagues.
lead_paragraph: A selection of Twitter posts about top administration officials written by Jofi Joseph, the National Security Council staff member who was fired for using an anonymous Twitter handle to knock public figures, reporters and colleagues.

headline: In Search of Republican Grown-Ups
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Editorials']
abstract: The Republican Party will have to do much better than avoiding default to earn back the public’s trust after their disastrous and juvenile shutdown stunt.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of the Republican Party, in full flight from their disastrous and juvenile shutdown stunt, now want to restock their ranks with grown-ups. “Let’s face it: it was not a good maneuver,” Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah told The Times recently. “You’ve got to have the adults running the thing.”

headline: Allegation of U.S. Spying on Merkel Puts Obama at Crossroads
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Officials in the Obama administration say that the National Security Agency, in its push to build a global data-gathering network, has rarely weighed the long-term political costs of some of its operations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The angry allegation by the German government that the National Security Agency monitored the cellphone of Chancellor Angela Merkel may force President Obama into making a choice he has avoided for years: whether to continue the age-old game of spying on America’s friends and risk undercutting cooperation with important partners in tracking terrorists, managing the global economy and slowing Iran’s nuclear program.

headline: The Assistants: The Mensa Member
abstract: Tom Herman, Ohio State’s co-offensive coordinator and quarterbacks coach, would prefer not to be known as the Mensa assistant, but it has trailed him.
lead_paragraph: The first name on Urban Meyer’s list of assistant candidates: Tom Herman, he of the documented high I.Q. Herman, now Ohio State’s co-offensive coordinator and quarterbacks coach, would prefer not to be known as the Mensa assistant, but he did list his membership in the group on his first résumé at his mother’s suggestion, between his team captaincy and all-conference accolades. He asked various universities to remove that from his biography, but it trailed him like a blinking neon sign: I’m smart. Really, really smart.

headline: National Guardsman Accused of Shooting and Wounding 2 in Tennessee
abstract: A National Guard recruiter opened fire with a handgun on two of his superiors on Thursday at a military armory near Memphis, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — A Tennessee National Guard recruiter wounded two of his superiors on Thursday when he opened fire with a handgun at a military facility near Memphis, the authorities said.

headline: The Assistants: The Roommates
abstract: Luke Fickell wanted to be a wrestler yet ended up on the football team at Ohio State. Mike Vrabel, his roommate, wanted to coach in Columbus.

headline: Portugal: Investigators Reopen Case of Missing British Child
abstract: The case, one of the most notorious recent child-abduction cases in Europe, was formally closed in 2008.
lead_paragraph: Portuguese prosecutors on Thursday reopened an investigation into the disappearance of Madeleine McCann from her British parents’ hotel room six years ago, when she was 3. The case, one of the most notorious recent child-abduction cases in Europe, was formally closed in 2008. But after a campaign by the girl’s parents, Kate and Gerry McCann, British and Portuguese investigators began reviewing the evidence two years ago and independently uncovered new leads. In July, British officials opened a formal investigation, and now Portugal has followed suit. Portuguese investigators did not specify what the new leads were, but according to the police in London they are separate from the ones being followed in Britain. Teams from both countries met a week ago to compare notes and to brief the McCanns on the progress. Madeleine disappeared on May 3, 2007, from an apartment in a resort in Praia da Luz, Portugal, while her parents were having dinner at a nearby restaurant.

headline: The Anxious Parent Daily
abstract: Don’t click on that baby newsletter asking “How Well Do You Know Your Baby?” or promising “The 10 Best Foods for Babies.” You’ll regret it.
lead_paragraph: When I was pregnant with my first son, I spasmodically clicked through to every parenting/pregnancy newsletter that landed in my in-box and obsessed over its contents until I was a twisted skein of parental anxiety. These days, I reflexively delete those same newsletters without reading, but that doesn’t stop me from internalizing their frequently fear-mongering headlines and prognosticating doomsday contents:

headline: Editing Microsoft Word Files on an Android Tablet
abstract: Google Play has several apps for working with Microsoft Word files on Android tablets.
lead_paragraph: Q. I don’t have a subscription to the Office 365 site, so what’s the easiest way to read and edit Microsoft Word documents on an Android tablet?

headline: How an Indian Stranger’s Blood Saved a Young Pakistani in Delhi
abstract: A Pakistani American author recalls the bonhomie of Indians in Delhi.
lead_paragraph: I ended up in India, oddly, because I could not get to Pakistan. I had lived half my life in Pakistan. Both of my parents are Pakistani, with family roots in and around the city of Lahore as far as either one could see. But I am a citizen of America. I was born in the United States and had spent the other half of my life living in this country. I was a few hours’ drive from New York when the planes struck in September 2001.

headline: In Store | Waris Ahluwalia Opens an Old-World Market in Venice
abstract: The jeweler, actor and man-about-town will stock unique items from artisans in his new boutique, opening in November, which takes inspiration from ancient trade routes.
lead_paragraph: Think of Waris Ahluwalia, the jeweler, actor and man-about-every-town, as a modern-day Marco Polo, bringing back implements of leisure from foreign ports of call: Morocco, Bali, India, Sweden, Lebanon. Next month, he opens his House of Waris Rare shop inside the library of Venice’s lavish Gritti Palace hotel. “I’m not just interested in well-designed trophies,” he says. “Whatever we stock should serve an actual purpose.” He steers away from comparisons to Paris’s Deyrolle or any upscale curiosity boutique, talking instead about revisiting ancient trade routes. In some ways this project is the culmination of a three-year expedition he began with the Luxury Collection, which owns the hotel and commissioned Ahluwalia as its global explorer. Everything sold at the shop — engraved tumblers hand-blown in Murano, vintage Fortuny fabrics fashioned into stuffed animals — is the type of affectionate object one might imagine, say, Ernest Hemingway gifting his mistress. Ahluwalia has stocked the shop with unique goods from artisans both emerging and established, including his own fine jewelry. “You can’t just ogle and awe,” he says about these collectibles. “You must engage as a patron. It’s not just the items that are unique — so too are the people who make them.”

lead_paragraph: Long-term unemployment — defined as people who have been out of work for at least a year — remains elevated in the United States, and is also a problem internationally.

headline: Why So Few Women in the Panthéon?
abstract: Hundreds of candidates have been put forward for the honor of eternity in the hallowed shrine.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In the politics of national identity, as with the politics of real estate, there are three cardinal rules: location, location, location. Few events better illustrate this truth than the current debate in France over whose earthly remains best belong in the basement of a hulking neo-Classical pile with a fissuring dome and bricked-up windows that looms over Paris — otherwise known as the Panthéon.

headline: Ridley Scott: ‘Most Novelists Are Desperate to Do What I Do’
abstract: The director on Cormac McCarthy, monsters and Moses.
lead_paragraph: Your new film, “The Counselor,” stars Michael Fassbender as a lawyer who gets in over his head on a huge drug deal. It’s pretty harrowing.  There’s a deep sense of stress that starts about halfway through, and you can’t put your finger on why. When you’re reading the script, it’s like there’s a series of cogs in a very clever clock. The cogs start to engage and — a good word is dread. And the dread sets in, and it stays there.

headline: The Harvard Doctor Who Accidentally Unleashed a Zombie Invasion
keywords: ['Hoaxes and Pranks', 'Radio', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: With a little help from the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Roughly two years ago, one of the most popular radio programs in America finally alerted the country to the coming zombie apocalypse. The weekend host of the radio program, Ian Punnett, was interviewing me, a Harvard Medical School physician and national expert on the compelling world of zombie neuroscience. Punnett asked me to help make sense of a new and terrifying threat to our planet, and I told him what I had learned from a discovered manuscript penned by a doctor from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention who had succumbed to a zombie plague while studying its origins. The newly uncovered disease was called Ataxic Neurodegenerative Satiety Deficiency syndrome (A.N.S.D.), I explained, and the C.D.C. expert worried that the disease had been engineered by nefarious hedge-fund managers, in hopes that the stock market would plunge and become vulnerable to manipulations as the chaos spread.

headline: Who Made That Coffee Lid?
abstract: How a lawsuit sent America’s inventors to work.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1970s, when you ordered coffee to go, you usually had to tear a hole in the plastic lid if you wanted to drink through it. This maneuver was so awkward that you risked burning your hand. So in the 1980s, a number of food-packaging engineers tried to fix the problem. William and Kenneth Dart, of the Dart Container Corporation, created one of the first of a new breed of coffee-cup lids, filing a patent in 1981 for a plastic disc with a press-down tab that acted like a valve. The inventors called this feature a “lip-engaging buttress”; you pushed on it with your upper lip to release a gulp of coffee. Once you finished drinking, the tab snapped back into place to prevent spills. (Kenneth Dart, who made a fortune in this and other business ventures, later renounced his citizenship and moved to Belize, where he was exempt from U.S. taxes.)

headline: Does the Golden Rule Hold Up in Modern Society?
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The problem with treating others as you would like to be treated.
lead_paragraph: The Golden Rule (usually defined as “One should treat others as one would like to be treated”) is attractive to people as a guiding principle for ethical conduct. However I feel that in our diverse, modern world, it is less than ideal. By assuming other people should be treated the way I want to be treated, it imposes my preferences and values on those around me. Wouldn’t a better rule be “One should treat others as they want to be treated”? GARRETT FRY, MONROVIA, CALIF.

headline: Hunting a Chimp on a Killing Spree
abstract: A moment of indecision would have grave consequences.
lead_paragraph: I raised the gun as the chimpanzee inspected a bunch of bananas, close enough that I could hear him softly grunting. Taking aim, I leaned back against a tree to control my trembling. My weight made the giant banana leaves rustle overhead, and he turned to face the noise. He walked unsteadily a few feet in my direction at first, clutching a bunch of bananas to his broad chest. Then he dropped the fruit and broke into a four-limbed run straight at me.

headline: The Past Can Hold a Horrible Power
abstract: Wladyslaw Pasikowski’s thriller “Aftermath” finds a man returning to his hometown to confront buried secrets concerning the fate of local Jews.
lead_paragraph: A man returns to his hometown after 20 years abroad. Something is clearly amiss. Neighbors are unaccountably hostile. The family farm is seemingly under siege. His estranged brother greets him with an ax in hand for a reunion rendered all the more tense by a rock crashing through the window.

lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Israel goes off daylight saving time on Sunday, like countries in Europe do. The clock will take a small step backward, but Israel will take a giant leap forward.

lead_paragraph: The Times’s Sam Tanenhaus explains government efforts to keep immigrants out of the country and links President Reagan’s amnesty for Latino Americans to today’s debate.

headline: Before Malala
abstract: Pashtun society was, for many years, a center of Gandhian nonviolent resistance against British rule.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Ever since Malala Yousafzai recovered from her shooting by the Taliban last year, she has been universally honored: As well as a nomination for the Nobel Peace Prize, she has been given everything from the Mother Teresa Award to a place in Time Magazine’s “100 Most Influential People in the World.”

headline: Clearing the Air in China
abstract: A carbon tax would be a strong jump-start in exactly the right direction.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Massachusetts — IN the northeast Chinese city of Harbin last week, the air pollution was so thick that schools were closed, traffic became gridlocked and flights in and out of the metropolis were canceled. For years, severe air pollution and rising carbon emissions have been downsides to China’s economic growth, even as that growth has lifted more than 600 million people out of poverty.

headline: Seeing You Seeing Me
abstract: It isn’t sex that makes “Blue Is the Warmest Color” problematic; it’s the patriarchal anxieties about sex, female appetite and maternity.
lead_paragraph: It was her derrière that first caught my eye. Specifically, it was the way the camera captured the pretty teenager’s rear end in “Blue Is the Warmest Color” so that it was centered and foregrounded in the frame. It is a lovely derrière, no question, round, compact and firm, and I became well acquainted with how it looked whether tucked into snug jeans or perched prettily in the air when Adèle, who’s 15 when the movie opens, lies splayed sleeping face down in bed, as young children often do. The director, Abdellatif Kechiche, I realized fairly quickly, likes a tight end.

headline: Dear Mr. President
abstract: The estimated two million letters that flowed through the White House during John F. Kennedy’s presidency included many from and to children.
lead_paragraph: “The Letters of John F. Kennedy,” to be published on Tuesday, includes correspondence to and from Harry Truman, Winston Churchill and Nikita Khrushchev, about nuclear weapons, the Cuban missile crisis and other momentous subjects. It also contains responses like the one Kennedy wrote to a young girl in 1961, which begins, “I was glad to get your letter about trying to stop the Russians from bombing the North Pole and risking the life of Santa Claus.” Martin W. Sandler, the book’s editor, estimates that two million letters came in and out of the White House during Kennedy’s presidency. “Of course I didn’t read two million letters,” he told me in a telephone interview, “but I went blind reading a hell of a lot of them.”

headline: How Did It All Happen?
abstract: The historian Margaret MacMillan probes the origins of the Great War.
lead_paragraph: President John F. Kennedy once remarked that “in 1914, with most of the world already plunged in war, Prince Bulow, the former German chancellor, said to the then-chancellor Bethmann-Hollweg: ‘How did it all happen?’ And Bethmann-Hollweg replied: ‘Ah, if only one knew.’ If this planet is ever ravaged by nuclear war,” Kennedy went on, “if the survivors of that devastation can then endure the fire, poison, chaos and catastrophe, I do not want one of those survivors to ask another, ‘How did it all happen?’ and to receive the incredible reply, ‘Ah, if only one knew.’ ”

headline: If Only One Knew
abstract: The historian Max Hastings’s account of World War I’s first few months disposes of many misconceptions.
lead_paragraph: World War I continues to exert a powerful pull on the popular imagination, especially in Britain, France and Australia, which, although victorious, suffered much more heavily in the trenches than did the late-arriving Americans. (There is less appetite for remembrance in the states that lost — Germany, Austria, Russia, Turkey.) Its ravages formed a backdrop to the television series “Downton Abbey” and to the movie and play “War Horse,” and they are being recounted anew in a profusion of books tied to the war’s centenary next year.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE OLD WAYS: A Journey on Foot,  by Robert Macfarlane. (Penguin, $18.) Macfarlane’s expansive travelogue takes him from the British Isles to the West Bank and the pilgrims’ paths of Spain and the Himalayas. With a command of natural history, cartography, geology and literature, he tries “to read landscapes back into being” — sailing in the Atlantic and matching strides with footprints made 5,000 years ago.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: ROTH UNBOUND: A Writer and His Books,  by Claudia Roth Pierpont. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) This clever account is an authorized critical life of the old school, but invaluably topped up with reported comments from the Roth of today.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: “Humans of New York,” which makes its debut on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1, collects Brandon Stanton’s photos of strangers from the popular documentary blog of the same name.
lead_paragraph: People Person: Brandon Stanton, the man behind the documentary photo blog Humans of New York, has just released his first book — also called “Humans of New York” — and it makes its debut on the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 1. Stanton, a 29-year-old Georgia native, started photographing strangers in 2010 after finding his way to New York from Chicago, where he had recently lost his job as a bond trader. “My mom basically thought this was my glorified way of not working,” he told ABC’s “Nightline” last month. “Like, oh, Brandon’s in New York taking pictures of people on the street and putting them on Facebook, you know what I mean?” That description isn’t far off the mark, actually. But it misses the primal voyeuristic appeal of Stanton’s blog, which only increased after he started interviewing his subjects and including short quotations or anecdotes with their portraits. (“Q. Where are you from? A. Russia. If you see a doctor smoking, he’s from Russia.”)

lead_paragraph: Twitter’s roadshow may not get under way until next week, but on Friday, bankers and the public got a taste of how the company plans to pitch itself to investors.

abstract: Color-blocked eye shadow is a chic way to achieve a dramatic, outré look, and the technique is less complicated than you might think.
lead_paragraph: This season opposites attract, as eyes are dusted with complementary colors for a moody two-tone effect.
