lead_paragraph: Slate’s Jessica Winter and The Times’s Ben Ratliff discuss “Autobiography,” the new memoir by the polarizing British pop star.

headline: Traveling Players
abstract: Daniel Alarcón’s protagonist joins a provocative theater troupe in a country much like Peru.
lead_paragraph: The young performer at the center of Daniel Alarcón’s wise and engaging new novel, “At Night We Walk in Circles,” isn’t the only one acting. The book is full of players and posers, among them a widow who writes to the newspapers in her dead husband’s name and mourners who “performed their sadness flamboyantly, pushing the very limits of realism.” Even the elusive narrator, a magazine writer, is playacting, pursuing a story that is unlikely ever to see print.

headline: Restless Romantic
abstract: A biography of the British wayfarer, soldier and travel writer Patrick Leigh Fermor.
lead_paragraph: Surprise is the keynote of the best travel writing. The travel writer should be knowledgeable but not an expert, open in mind and body to the unforeseen twists of serendipity. But what we most require from travel writing, as opposed to mere guidebooks, is that elusive quality Nick Carraway defined as “romantic readiness.” Few 20th-century figures combined these traits in a more appealing package than the English writer Patrick Leigh Fermor, Paddy to his many friends, who died in 2011 at the age of 96. One of these was Diana Cooper, a famous beauty who turned up in the fiction of Evelyn Waugh. Now Artemis Cooper, her granddaughter, has written an affectionately intimate, informative and forgiving biography of Diana’s complicated friend.

headline: Her Dynasty
abstract: Jung Chang portrays the Empress Dowager Cixi as a proto-feminist who “brought medieval China into the modern age.”
lead_paragraph: For historians, there is no more powerful aphrodisiac than an exciting topic buoyed by a raft of unexploited sources, raising the prospect of a revisionist look at an important figure or even an entire era. There are few leaders in modern Chinese history more layered with prejudice begging to be stripped away than Cixi, the dowager empress who ruled China for almost half a century until her death in 1908. For decades, she was condescendingly referred to in the West as “the Old Buddha,” the “She Dragon,” the usurper of a throne “over whose disintegration she presided.”

headline: Root Notes
abstract: Neil Powell examines the complex character and life of the composer Benjamin Britten.
lead_paragraph: In Tony Palmer’s film “A Time There Was . . . ,” Leonard Bernstein describes Benjamin Britten’s music as seemingly “decorative, positive and charming, and it’s so much more than that. You become aware of something very dark. He was a man at odds with the world in many ways. And he didn’t show it.”

headline: The Governess and the Ghost
abstract: Mysterious occurrences plague a Victorian teacher who moves in with two eerily well-mannered children.
lead_paragraph: Upon the death of her father, bookish, dowdy Eliza Caine answers an ad for a governess position at Gaudlin Hall, a rambling pile in the outer darkness of Victorian-era Norfolk. Eliza — totally alone in the world, her sole companions the protagonists of Dickens, her recent dreams filled with “dark graveyards and irregular vistas” — seems primed for a richly horrifying experience. Arriving soaked to the bone and in the dead of night, the new governess of Gaudlin finds not the greeting of a warm fire and a noble family at its ease, but two eerily well-mannered children alone in an otherwise empty house.

headline: The Reawakening
abstract: Sara Wheeler follows six 19th-century women who left England and reinvented themselves in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Just give in — I finally did — to the rough-edged charms of Sara Wheeler’s latest hybrid of historical narrative and travelogue. Never mind that Wheeler, a British author whose previous book, “Terra Incognita,” chronicled her adventures in Antarctica, commits the same sin as at least two of the six women writers she profiles: Fanny Trollope, whose withering account of life along the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers, “Domestic Manners of the Americans,” infuriated American readers; and Fanny Kemble Butler, whose reflexively judgmental “Journal of a Residence in America” provoked a breach with her American husband. Wheeler seems not to have calculated the effects of her own gratuitous insults, whether aimed at the “agreeable Fatty­towns” of the Midwest or the “crap of contemporary America” she encounters at a once-grand seaside resort community in Massachusetts. Even her praise can be faintly damning: “On the whole Americans are a friendly, polite lot.”

headline: It All Adds Up
abstract: A mathematician says that his subject “directs the flow of the universe.”
lead_paragraph: Recovering from an illness, I sat in my hospital bed reading Edward Frenkel’s book “Love and Math.” I was following along, scrawling equations on scratch paper when my doctor walked in and gazed at my work. “Looks interesting,” he said cheerfully. But when he came closer, he grimaced. “Oh, yuck, it’s math,” he said. “Never was any good at math. I hate it!” Then his smile reappeared. “How’s your bowel?” he asked.

headline: On Guard
abstract: This novel’s quiet heroine works in a museum.
lead_paragraph: There are few jobs more toothless than those of museum guards. Their cautions are irksome, their inattention worrying, their reflexes dulled by the uneventful hours between bursts of activity. And yet, although poorly conditioned and compensated, they are called upon to protect rooms full of fragile, invaluable objects. Of those to whom little is given, much, apparently, is required.

headline: Blithe Spirits
abstract: Fay Weldon’s novel is driven by Maori apparitions.
lead_paragraph: Metafiction is often more fun to write than it is to read. Everything on the page is the result of a series of strenuous choices, none inevitable, and reminding the reader just who made these choices (whether conscious or not) can be amusing, aesthetically useful and a great relief from the constraints of the traditional conventions of fiction. But intelligent readers may not need reminding, may even take it as an insult. They know who the puppets are and who the puppeteer. They have sought out fiction for a reason: quite often they simply wish the puppeteer would shut up, back away and get on with the storytelling.

headline: Jamie Dornan Named as New Lead in ‘Fifty Shades’

headline: Return to the Fray

lead_paragraph: In a bear market, most developers are not inclined to hibernate like bears as a strategy for self-preservation. Be they a Macklowe, Zeckendorf, Trump or Barnett, their modus operandi borrows from feline superstition: if they have nine lives, they’re going to spend them all building or go bankrupt trying.

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Donmar Warehouse, which is currently presenting Phyllida Lloyd’s all-female production of “Julius Caesar” at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn, on Friday announced the theater’s spring season program. It includes two new plays, “Versailles,” by Peter Gill and “Privacy” by James Graham, as well as Brian Friel’s stage adaptation of Turgenev’s “Fathers and Sons,” directed by Lyndsey Turner.

headline: Dropping a Name (Or, Goodbye, John Wesley Harding)
abstract: After 25 years of performing with a stage name, I’ve finally reclaimed my own, and it’s all a great relief.
lead_paragraph: There’s a rich tradition of fake names in rock music. Assuming them is easy: “I’m Elton John now!” “I’m Ringo Starr!” Getting rid of them is much harder: ask John Cougar (who had to ease into being John Mellencamp by slow degrees) or The Artist Formerly Known as Prince about the irreproducible hieroglyph that never caught on.

headline: Speaking to Young Latinos, in English
abstract: After market research, the new cable network Fusion decided to aim its programming not just at young Hispanics, but the millennial generation as a whole.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Since 1986, Jorge Ramos has anchored the Univision network’s 6:30 p.m. news broadcast, a vital source of information for the nation’s 50 million-plus Spanish speakers. But this week, his routine will change in a way that could have profound consequences not just for him but also for the American media landscape.

headline: Women on the Verge of a Moral Crisis, as Set to Song
abstract: New recordings from Brandy Clark, Best Coast, John Tchicai and Aaron Parks.
lead_paragraph: Brandy Clark 12 STORIES

headline: Such Stuff as Dance Is Made On
abstract: Alexei Ratmansky is bringing his storytelling skills and a poetical and fantastical streak to create a new version of “The Tempest,” long a challenge for choreographers.
lead_paragraph: Shakespeare, who turns 450 in April, doesn’t seem to have lost any power to inspire creators in every art form. Dance is no excaption. Choreographers have been turning to his plays at least since Jean-George Noverre created “Antony and Cleopatra” in the 1760s, and there’s barely a midlevel ballet company today that doesn’t perform a version of “Romeo and Juliet.”

headline: An Eternal Youth, Now 90
abstract: Ned Rorem’s birthday isn’t passing by unnoticed. The New York Festival of Song, for one, is presenting three concerts of his compositions.
lead_paragraph: “Like everybody else, I think I’m never going to die,” the composer and diarist Ned Rorem said, warming instantly to the subject of a recent interview: his 90th birthday. “That’s sort of an unrealistic answer, and 90 is realistic,” he continued. “Everyone else can be 90, but not me.”

headline: Immigration Poses Threat of Another Republican Rift
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: A push to bring legislation to the House floor, led by a coalition of executives, conservatives and evangelical leaders, could affect campaign contributions before the midterm elections.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A push to bring immigration legislation to the House floor, led by an unusual coalition of business executives, prominent conservatives and evangelical leaders, threatens to create another schism in the Republican Party and could have a noticeable effect on campaign contributions before the midterm elections.

abstract: A house on the outskirts of Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir, with shell marks allegedly caused by firing from the Pakistani side.

lead_paragraph: Officially, Sunday’s Formula One race just outside New Delhi is the Indian Grand Prix, the 16th event of the season counting for the series’ World Drivers Championship.

headline: On the Market in the Region
abstract: An 1882 Victorian in Larchmont that’s fully renovated but retains original details; and a waterfront house in Fairfield that includes three fireplaces, two terraces, and a private dock.
lead_paragraph: An 1882 Victorian in Larchmont that’s fully renovated but retains original details; and a waterfront house in Fairfield that includes three fireplaces, two terraces, and a private dock.

headline: BMW Releases Its New 2 Series Coupe
abstract: The successor to the diminutive 1 Series coupe will be slightly larger, with two fuel-efficient, but powerful, engine options.
lead_paragraph: BMW announced Thursday details of its new 2 Series coupe models, the successors to the 1 Series cars introduced in 2004. The official debut of the 2 Series will be in January, at the North American International Auto Show in Detroit.

headline: End of a Line Reflects a Weakened Peugeot
abstract: By the time the last car rolled off the assembly line in Aulnay-sous-Bois on Friday, the plant’s importance had declined amid ebbing profitability for the subcompact cars it produced.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The last car rolled off the assembly line at PSA Peugeot Citroën’s factory in Aulnay-sous-Bois on Friday, marking the end of four decades of production at the auto plant on the outskirts of the French capital.

lead_paragraph: From a Wednesday Addams-style Peter Pan collar to glitzy jewels fit for a Disney princess, here are some costume staples that will remain highly wearable parts of your wardrobe long past Oct. 31.

headline: Bale Could Start for Real Madrid in Clásico
abstract: Real Madrid’s coach has hinted that the Welsh wing could be in the lineup at Barcelona on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — The attention will understandably be on the newcomers Saturday, as the Brazilian star Neymar and the Welsh wing Gareth Bale are set to play key roles in their first Barcelona-Real Madrid Clásico game. But while Neymar works his way into the Barcelona attack and Bale eases into the Madrid midfield, the long-running comparison between their top teammates, Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo, continues unabated.

headline: 5 Signs That It’s Time to Seek Outside Help for a Struggling Child
keywords: ['Anxiety and Stress', 'Children and Childhood', 'Depression (Mental)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Parenting', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Parents who have watched a child wrestle with anxiety, depression and other challenges name these as the signs that it’s time to seek help.
lead_paragraph: The current open question in the New Parent, Old Parent collaboration between Motherlode and Booming brought forth some of the most helpful advice I’ve ever seen from a “crowdsource.” I asked, “How do you know when it’s time to get professional help for a child who is anxious, depressed or angry beyond her years?”

headline: WQXR to Celebrate Polish Music With Online Festival
abstract: Three 24-hour marathons to be streamed by Q2, the Web station run by WQXR, will celebrate the music of Witold Lutoslawski, Krzysztof Penderecki and other Polish composers.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve been eager to brush up on your expertise in contemporary Polish concert music – a repertory that is plentiful and varied – now is your chance: Q2, the Web station run by WQXR, is presenting “Celebrating Poland: Lutoslawski, Penderecki and New Music Now,” an online festival that includes three 24-hour marathons between now (the first is on Friday) and Nov. 12, to be followed by a concert Webcast on Dec. 13.

headline: Grand Jury Urged Charges in JonBenet Ramsey Case
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: Although the jury chose to charge John and Patsy Ramsey in 1999 with child abuse, prosecutors declined to file criminal charges.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Nearly a decade before DNA evidence cleared the parents of JonBenet Ramsey in the killing of their 6-year-old daughter, a grand jury pursuing the case decided to indict the couple on charges of child abuse leading to the girl’s death, according to documents unsealed on Friday.

headline: CommScope, Backed by Carlyle, Has a Rocky Debut
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']
abstract: The company, which makes telecommunications equipment, is among those being sold this year as private equity firms hope to realize gains on their investments.
lead_paragraph: Private equity firms have been eager to sell companies to public investors this year, with the stock market on a tear. But on Friday, one company sold by the Carlyle Group had a rocky start.

headline: Big Ticket | A Nascar Star Sells for $25 Million
abstract: A three-bedroom condominium owned since 2007 by the Nascar driver Jeff Gordon included a built-in sushi bar and treetop vistas of Central Park.
lead_paragraph: An elegant apartment at 15 Central Park West with treetop vistas of Central Park just outside and a host of sophisticated customizations inside — like a built-in sushi bar in the great room overlooking the park — sold for $25 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records. The asking price for the 3,454-square-foot unit when it entered the market in May was $30 million, and the monthly carrying charges are $7,221.80.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Jung Chang Reconsiders Cixi
abstract: Ms. Chang discusses “Empress Dowager Cixi: The Concubine Who Launched Modern China.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Orville Schell reviews Jung Chang’s “Empress Dowager Cixi: The Concubine Who Launched Modern China.” Mr. Schell writes:

headline: Skills Practice | Making a Presentation on Health Topics, Using the PechaKucha Method
abstract: This week we’ve suggested an exercise that can help them both research some solutions to everyday health issues and learn a new presentation skill in the bargain.
lead_paragraph: Feeling stressed? Can’t sleep? Too much homework? Students the world over complain of these problems, and this week we’ve suggested an exercise that can help them both research some solutions and learn a new presentation skill in the bargain.

headline: Rituals and Restaurants in Rome
abstract: Gabrielle Hamilton, chef of the New York restaurant Prune, shares some of her favorite spots in the Eternal City.
lead_paragraph: “On the back of a motorcycle with my soon-to-be husband, who at the time was my secret Italian lover in New York,” is how Gabrielle Hamilton, chef of the New York restaurant Prune, said she discovered Rome.

headline: Inside the Walls of Fez
abstract: Relying on instinct, hospitality and a bit of technology, the author discovers the rewards of exploring the Moroccan city’s medina without a guide.
lead_paragraph: We spotted the craftsman first, alone in his workshop, a cubby barely larger than a closet. There are hundreds, if not thousands, of such stalls in the medina in Fez, an ancient city within a city of winding paths and centuries-old artisanship, where vendors tout their leather and oils on every corner. But this stall stood out. It was nearly bare, not crammed as most of the others were with doodads to be fussed and negotiated over. A few tools hung on the wall, alongside the red Moroccan flag with its green pentagram, and some old photos of the craftsman, now white-haired and wearing a traditional long robe.

headline: Off Ireland, a Rugged Journey to Remote Ruins
abstract: It takes a sturdy stomach and a strong sense of purpose to brave the trip to Skellig Michael, an island eight miles off the coast of Ireland. Here’s what people find once they get there.
lead_paragraph: If anyone can explain why 10,000 people each year make the stomach-churning passage to Skellig Michael, a desolate rock pinnacle eight miles off Ireland’s southwest coast, John O’Shea can.

headline: The Gun Report: October 25, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Because the Gun Report is a daily accounting, the details of the shootings we cover aren’t always filled in by the time we publish. So the report is rife with phrases such as “unidentified victim” and “police have no suspects.” In the days that follow, the identities of the victims and perpetrators, and the circumstances behind the violence, are revealed, but by then we’re covering a slew of new shootings.

headline: Competing to Tell Jack the Ripper’s Story
abstract: With this fall marking the 125th anniversary of the Jack the Ripper murders in London, tour operators are battling over customers interested in the macabre tale.
lead_paragraph: Just before 9 p.m. on a recent Thursday in London, five guided tour groups, about 150 people in all, converged on a nondescript courtyard on the eastern edge of the central financial district. Some tour guides wore 19th-century top hats and long, dark cloaks. Others grasped photographs of mortuary corpses. And each guide jostled for the best spot: near the tiny flower bed in the far corner where, in 1888, Jack the Ripper murdered a prostitute named Catherine Eddowes — slitting her throat, slashing her face, pulling out her innards and walking off with her uterus.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

lead_paragraph: Obama gets an earful from Merkel on American surveillance.

headline: The Long Trip Into a Dark Season
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Dementia', 'Elder Care', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Just when you thought there couldn’t be another caregiving memoir worth reading, “The Fifth Season” arrives.
lead_paragraph: I told myself I wasn’t going to write about any more memoirs, at least not for a while. The act of honoring thy aging father or mother has already generated so many magazine articles and op-eds and blogs and books, including Katie Hafner’s account of moving her mother into her home and Katy Butler’s story of her family’s struggle to deactivate the pacemaker that kept her father’s heart beating while his brain and the rest of his body failed.

headline: When ‘Eat It’ Isn’t the Answer: The Halloween Candy Dilemma
abstract: In my family, we just eat the Halloween candy. It’s a great festival of sugar that ends only when we can’t take it anymore. But if that’s not an option in your house, what do you do with the annual haul?
lead_paragraph: I have long been an advocate of a relaxed approach to what some parents term the “problem” of Halloween candy. It’s Halloween, I wrote for Slate in 2011:

headline: Storm Still Brews Over Scalding Coffee
abstract: Hundreds of wide-ranging and intense reactions followed the Retro Report video revisiting a 1992 case of Liebeck v. McDonald’s.
lead_paragraph: Even 21 years later, it’s clear that the case of Liebeck v. McDonald’s hasn’t lost its power to provoke. The Retro Report video about the lawsuit featured here this week has been watched more than a million times on several websites and attracted hundreds of comments, many vehement.

headline: For Cool Autumn Days, Warm Red-Cooked Flavors
abstract: The Chinese technique of red cooking involves simmering meat with soy sauce, sugar and sweet aromatics like star anise and cinnamon.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese technique red cooking involves simmering meat with soy sauce, sugar and sweet aromatics like star anise and cinnamon. It happens in a wok, but instead of a quick high-heat stir-fry, it is a slow braise, more like a savory stew.

headline: Eat Your Broccoli
abstract: Five ways to prepare broccoli, with cooking and without, to benefit from its many nutrients.
lead_paragraph: When my son was younger he was happy to eat broccoli every day, as so many children are. I would steam it and drizzle vinaigrette over it; that was the way he liked it best. But by the time he was a teenager he grew tired of broccoli; he never wanted it, so I stopped buying it. He has always been a good vegetable eater, so I didn’t mind; I didn’t really miss broccoli either.

headline: Plan to Tax the Rich Could Aim Higher
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Tax', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: The mayoral candidate Bill de Blasio’s proposal to raise taxes on the city’s wealthy won’t touch many of the wealthiest.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio has made New York’s “Tale of Two Cities” a centerpiece of his Democratic campaign for mayor. “One New Yorker is rushing past an attended desk in the lobby of a majestic skyscraper,” Mr. de Blasio said in a speech at the New School earlier this year, while “a few miles away, a single mother is also rushing, holding her two young children by the hands as they hurry down the steps of the subway entrance.”

headline: Feeling For | Halloween-Inspired Finds You Can Wear Year-Round
abstract: From a Wednesday Addams-style Peter Pan collar to glitzy jewels fit for a Disney princess, here are some costume staples that will remain highly wearable parts of your wardrobe long past Oct. 31.
lead_paragraph: Halloween is the one time a year when character dressing is O.K. for everyone, no matter what your age. But most style icons are better left to adults than pint-size trick-or-treaters. Wear these modern pieces to pay tribute to Edie Sedgwick, Andy Warhol’s legendary Factory girl; Wednesday Addams, the gothic adolescent with the braided pigtails immortalized by Christina Ricci in the 1991 film “The Addams Family”; and Disney princesses like Cinderella, Aurora and Ariel, those prim leading ladies who always get their happily-ever-afters. As an added bonus, all of these items are perfectly wearable the other 364 days of the year, long after the ghosts and goblins have been put to rest.

headline: The Latest Getaway Holiday? Halloween
abstract: The VooDoo Fest in New Orleans and Horror Nights in Orlando are just two events that have made Halloween a weekend destination.
lead_paragraph: Halloween is no longer just one night of dressing up and eating too much candy on a school night. Like most holidays, it’s been amplified with a monthlong roster of events aimed at kids both young and old. For travelers, that means sweet deals from hotels and attractions looking to capitalize on those who want to celebrate all things darkly hallowed.

headline: It’s Time to Parse Pole-Dancing
abstract: Pole-dancing may be a fitness fad, but for the Filipina performance artist Eisa Jocson, it’s the politically complex subject at the heart of her one-woman show.
lead_paragraph: Pole-dancing may be a recent fitness fad, right up there with aerial aerobics. But for the Filipina performance artist Eisa Jocson, it’s the politically complex subject at the heart of her one-woman show “Macho Dancer.” The title refers to a form of nightclub entertainment in the Philippines performed by young men for both male and female clients. Ms. Jocson, who has a background in visual arts and exotic dancing, intends to raise questions about gender, seduction and the economics of performance.

headline: From Catchy Jolts to Minimalist Buzz
abstract: How do you want your jolts? Steady state, like a finger stuck in a socket? Or frantic and quick changing, like a haywire carnival ride? Both kinds are available this week.
lead_paragraph: How do you want your jolts? Steady state, like a finger stuck in a socket? Or frantic, angular and quick changing, like a haywire carnival ride? Both kinds are available this week from experienced administrators of their chosen thrills: Thee Oh Sees, from San Francisco, and Melt-Banana, from Tokyo.

headline: Hell Hath No Fury Like a Pink Pompon
abstract: In “All Cheerleaders Die,” witchcraft is employed to resurrect the vengeance-seeking cheerleaders who died in a car accident caused by football players.
lead_paragraph: The pitch reads: “What’s worse than mean girl cheerleaders? How about resurrected mean-girl cheerleaders with supernatural powers?” Find out more at Thursday’s United States premiere of the horror film “All Cheerleaders Die” at the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center at Lincoln Center. In this satire of high school horror movies, witchcraft is employed to resurrect the vengeance-seeking cheerleaders who died in a car accident caused by the football players.

headline: Bach’s in His Blood. Beethoven, Too.
abstract: New Yorkers will have a chance to hear Andras Schiff’s engaging commentaries on music when he gives a lecture-recital on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The masterly pianist Andras Schiff, admired for his elegant and intelligent artistry, is also an insightful lecturer, as he demonstrated some years ago in a series of lecture-recitals on the 32 Beethoven piano sonatas at Wigmore Hall in London. (Audio recordings of those talks are available at Wigmore Hall’s Web site.) New Yorkers will have a chance to hear Mr. Schiff’s engaging commentaries on music when he gives a lecture-recital on Tuesday at the 92nd Street Y. Mr. Schiff will discuss Bach’s influence on Beethoven by comparing Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations and Beethoven’s “Diabelli” Variations, playing excerpts from both. (8:15 p.m., Tuesday, Kaufmann Concert Hall, 212-415-5500, 92y.org; $62, $25 for people 35 and under.)

headline: Recalling the Wave of Water and Panic
abstract: The Museum of the City of New York is opening an exhibition of photographs whose size and scope seem intended to rival that of Hurricane Sandy itself.
lead_paragraph: As the first anniversary of Hurricane Sandy’s onslaught of the New York region arrives, the Museum of the City of New York, with help from the International Center of Photography, is opening an exhibition of photographs whose size and scope seem intended to rival that of the storm itself. “Rising Waters: Photographs of Sandy,” which began with an open call for images, draws on work submitted by more than 900 photographers, “many of whom,” as the museum says, “were personally and profoundly impacted by the storm.”

headline: A Grand Old Name With a Gory Past
abstract: Investigation Discovery presents “Bloody Marys,” about murders linked only by the coincidence that they were committed by women named Mary.
lead_paragraph: Investigation Discovery, the true-crime network, has made theme packaging of mayhem an art form, with shows grouping murdered beauty queens, dates that turned deadly or bad behavior involving twins. Its midnight offering to close out Halloween night on Thursday is a classic example: “Bloody Marys,” about murders linked only by the coincidence that they were committed by women named Mary.

headline: The Great Republican Makeover
abstract: The party’s hired a 23-year-old to “reach out” to young people.
lead_paragraph: Big news from the Great Republican Makeover: The Grand Old Party has hired a 23-year-old to “reach out” to young people.

headline: No More a Slave
abstract: The forgotten story of George Washington Fields, whose harrowing memoir was recently discovered in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Most people who study the Civil War are familiar with the classic autobiographical narratives, written by such luminaries as Frederick Douglass and Booker T. Washington. But there are countless other unpublished works, written by lesser-known men and women who successfully navigated the treacherous path from slavery to freedom. One of these, “Come On, Children: The Autobiography of George Washington Fields, Born a Slave in Hanover County, Virginia,” recently rediscovered in museum archives in Hampton, Va., is a particularly stirring and valuable account of a slave’s path to freedom.

headline: A Menagerie of Music Lives in a Box
abstract: The musician Jack White has helped lead a project that resulted in a huge boxed set of music from Paramount Records.
lead_paragraph: In the annals of American music in the 20th century, no record label had a more unlikely origin or trajectory than Paramount Records. Founded in 1917 as a subsidiary of the Wisconsin Chair Company, which was eager to supply content for the phonographs it had begun to manufacture, Paramount took a scattershot approach to its business, recording more than 10,000 tracks of blues, gospel, hot jazz, treacly pop, and hillbilly and ethnic music before going bust during the Depression.

headline: Hockney Returns
abstract: A look at works in a David Hockney exhibition in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: A look at works in a David Hockney exhibition in San Francisco.

headline: Mariel Hemingway’s Smoothie Therapy
abstract: This recipe — which calls for live marine phytoplankton and, of course, kale — might ward off that cold that’s been going around.
lead_paragraph: The first morning I visited Mariel Hemingway — actor, author, activist, granddaughter of Ernest — I watched as she and her partner, Bobby Williams, prepared a smoothie. This is part of her daily routine: because she comes from a family with a history of mental illness, addiction and suicide (a legacy explored in “Running From Crazy,” a new documentary directed by Barbara Kopple), health and wellness and the preventive measures that promote both are at the center of her life — and thus at the center of my article about her in this Sunday’s magazine.

headline: Promised Fix for Health Site Could Squeeze Some Users
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: The White House said that it would fix the insurance marketplace by Nov. 30, raising the question of how people whose current policies do not comply with the law will get new coverage in time.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said Friday that it would fix problems in the federal health insurance marketplace by Nov. 30, just two weeks before the deadline to sign up for coverage to replace health insurance policies being canceled because they do not meet new federal standards.

headline: He’s Back, in a Defiant Blaze of Color
abstract: As his survey exhibition at the de Young Museum demonstrates, David Hockney’s return to California has been accompanied by a return to dazzling hues.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Although it would be hard to tell from the volume of his work, David Hockney, now 76, has had a rough year. Last October, this celebrated British artist had a stroke, which left him unable to complete his sentences for a time. In March, one of his studio assistants in East Yorkshire, part of a tight-knit circle of aides, collaborators and former lovers, died in Mr. Hockney’s home after drinking drain cleaner on the heels of a drug binge. And slowly but surely, Mr. Hockney’s hereditary deafness has progressed to the point that he depends heavily on two hearing aids and still needs to lean in for conversations.

headline: Scene City: Giorgio Armani Day in New York
abstract: A fashion extravaganza for Giorgio Armani at the SuperPier, with a marathon show, exhibition and celebrity-filled nightclub.
lead_paragraph: A fashion extravaganza for Giorgio Armani at the SuperPier, with a marathon show, exhibition and celebrity-filled nightclub.

headline: What We’re Reading Now
abstract: A smattering of food news from near and far.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration proposed rules on Friday that would govern the production of pet food and farm animal feed for the first time. Related: Nearly 600 dogs and cats have died and more than 3,600 have been sickened after eating tainted jerky treats made in China since 2007.

headline: For Better and for Worse, Long Before the Wedding
abstract: An actress and a teacher find that their love has endured through prior marriages, divorces and illnesses.
lead_paragraph: Jay Nickerson spent 20 years listening to a friend, the comedian and actress Suzanne Whang, talk about her relationships, silently thinking that she could do so much better than this guy, whoever the guy happened to be at the time. During those conversations, Mr. Nickerson, an actor turned special-education teacher, kept pushing away the nagging feeling that maybe he was the right guy.

headline: Twitter Tantalizes, but Beware the I.P.O.
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Some offerings get so much attention they can cloud people’s judgment, but investors must understand how a company’s stock will fit in their portfolio.
lead_paragraph: PERHAPS you’ve heard that Twitter is planning an initial public offering.

headline: Giorgio Armani Runway Show Is an Extravaganza of Extremes
abstract: Armani held an elaborate event on the Hudson River, where it was hard to stay afloat amid the celebrities, Champagne and other displays of excess.
lead_paragraph: Fifteen years ago, Giorgio Armani brought a fashion show to New York City with a set and dinner so dazzling that fashion people with long memories still talk about it giddily. And that only happened after the police in Paris, where he had originally planned to show his Emporio Armani collection that year, shut down his production (with a reported cost of $1 million, two black tents and 1,200 guests waiting outside) at the last moment, citing security concerns. Mr. Armani retaliated by bringing the whole shebang to Wall Street, barely flinching at the expense.

headline: How No-Strings Aid Affects the Poor
abstract: A new study in Kenya shows that giving money to the poor without dictating how they use it can have a powerful impact on their quality of life, not just a one-time effect on consumption.
lead_paragraph: GiveDirectly is an unusual charity. Donors give money. GiveDirectly, well, gives it directly to the poor. It does not tell them how to spend it or when to spend it. And it does not give money to a specific group, like mothers or farmers or the elderly.

headline: When ‘Frankenstorm’ First Caught Our Eye
abstract: A year ago today, the National Weather Service’s highly technical Extended Forecast Discussion veered off into a digression about something it dubbed a Frankenstorm, “an allusion to Mary Shelley’s gothic creature of synthesized elements.”
lead_paragraph: From time to time, the weather-forecasting authorities issue warnings of some type.

headline: A Bachelorette’s Night (or Four) to Remember
abstract: Destination bashes are becoming the celebration of choice for brides to be.
lead_paragraph: When Tracy S., a 33-year-old creative agency account director, began thinking about her bachelorette party, she knew getting out of town was a must.

headline: Even More Money Coming to an Election Near You
abstract: A federal appeals court panel said New York State’s $150,000 cap on contributions to independent political groups was probably unconstitutional.
lead_paragraph: After the 2010 Citizens United ruling, which allowed corporations and unions to overwhelm federal elections with unlimited “independent” expenditures, the courts began overturning reasonable state-specific campaign finance rules — in Montana, for instance. Now it is New York’s turn.

headline: Review: 2014 Acura RLX P-AWS Advance
abstract: Steering with the front wheels has worked well since the day automobiles were invented. Is 4-wheel steering better? Tom Voelk drives the P-AWS equipped 2014 Acura RLX to find out.
lead_paragraph: Steering with the front wheels has worked well since the day automobiles were invented. Is 4-wheel steering better? Tom Voelk drives the P-AWS equipped 2014 Acura RLX to find out.

headline: Publishing Executive at Amazon to Depart
abstract: Laurence Kirshbaum also worked at Random House and eventually became the chairman and chief executive of the Time Warner Book Group.
lead_paragraph: Laurence J. Kirshbaum, a stalwart of New York publishing who joined Amazon in 2011 to lead its New York publishing imprint, will leave the company in January, Amazon said on Friday.

headline: The Un-Facebook I.P.O.
abstract: Twitter so far seems to be avoiding the premature heights of Facebook’s flawed 2012 market debut, the author contends.
lead_paragraph: Twitter seems to be avoiding Facebook’s overreach – so far. The microblogging site’s provisional pricing for its initial public offering is $17 to $20 a share. Calculations by Reuters Breakingviews suggest that’s modest by the metrics available, though without profit these require a leap of faith. At least Twitter seems to be avoiding the premature heights of Facebook’s flawed debut last year.

headline: Health Insurance Options Aren’t Limited to Government Exchanges
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Most shoppers for health insurance can leave the new exchanges and buy coverage through brokers or company Web sites, but it is unclear if they will find a better deal.
lead_paragraph: WITH so much attention being paid to the troubled debut of the Obama administration’s health insurance exchanges, another alternative has largely gone unnoticed: unless you live in Washington, D.C., or Vermont, you can also buy insurance outside the exchanges — by going directly to insurance brokers, agents or company Web sites.

headline: The Grand Animal Costume Party
abstract: Trying to look scarier than you really are is a common strategy, and not just for humans.
lead_paragraph: IT’S every traveler’s little dream.

headline: Spicy Mussels With Cauliflower

headline: Were There Ever Liquor Carts at The Times?
abstract: Arthur Gelb, a former managing editor of The Times, weighs in on the booze situation in the newsrooms of yesteryear.
lead_paragraph: Whenever the topic of liquor comes up at the magazine — as it always does, if for no other reason than that we publish a regular Drink column and two Food & Drink issues every year — my colleagues and I start talking about the liquor carts of yesteryear that were wheeled around the newsroom of The Times like the coffee carts of today. Everyone is so certain they existed, perhaps convinced by the drunken desk workers in “Mad Men” that all midcentury offices were filled with booze. Of course there was hard stuff on the drink carts! And yet, I haven’t been able to find any proof that that was ever the case.

headline: Mussels, Difficult? A Myth Without Legs
abstract: Cooking mussels is simple and, with a vegetable along, you have an easy, tasty one-pot meal.
lead_paragraph: I have a friend who makes kimchi from scratch, can produce molecular-cuisine-inspired foams and gelées and has even deep-fried an entire Thanksgiving turkey on his petite patio.

abstract: Assessments by Steve Serio, a collector and Aston dealer in Waltham, Mass., of some of the most collectible DB models.
lead_paragraph: Prices for postwar Aston Martins have been very strong, with the recent peak coming at the Bonhams sale in Britain last May. There, the 1960 DB4GT Jet coupe with coachwork by Bertone sold for $5.2 million, the highest price ever paid for an Aston Martin road car.

headline: Beyond Bond
abstract: As Aston Martin celebrates its centennial, we look back at some memorable models.
lead_paragraph: As Aston Martin celebrates its centennial, we look back at some memorable models.

abstract: Architects should use their noses as well as their eyes.
lead_paragraph: SUFFERING from writer’s block? Try sniffing rotting apples.

headline: An Undiluted Pedigree in the Hamptons
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Windmills', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: A 3.7-acre property in East Hampton is the only lot from the original settlement still owned by descendants of the family that settled on it.
lead_paragraph: A pastoral and historic 3.7-acre piece of prime residential and agricultural property on James Lane near Town Pond, the idyllic gateway to the Village of East Hampton, is about to enter the market for the first time in more than three centuries.

headline: Weekend Reading: 2 Key Players in JPMorgan’s $13 Billion Deal
abstract: Two of the central players in the biggest settlement of the financial crisis were once on opposite sides of the negotiating table.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a conference call on the night of Oct. 18, JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive and the attorney general left their top lieutenants to hash out the details of a tentative $13 billion settlement. The talks, led Tony West, the associate attorney general at the Justice Department, and Stephen M. Cutler, JPMorgan’s general counsel, could still fall apart over how much wrongdoing the bank will admit on its questionable mortgage practices.

headline: Lincoln Center to Expand Discount Ticket Sales
abstract: The box office at the David Rubenstein Atrium will sell discount tickets to a week’s worth of events at New York City Center, the 92nd Street Y, Merkin Concert Hall and Miller Theater.
lead_paragraph: Music and dance fans have long wished for the equivalent of the theater world’s TKTS booth, where tickets to concerts could be found at reduced prices. Lincoln Center announced on Friday that starting Tuesday, the box office at the David Rubenstein Atrium will sell discount tickets not only for events at Lincoln Center (which began offering discounted same-day tickets in 2010), but for a week’s worth of performances at New York City Center, the 92nd Street Y, Merkin Concert Hall and Miller Theater.

headline: New York State Seeks to Scale Back Student Testing
abstract: Critics say that the state’s plan is not aggressive enough, and that too many schools rely too heavily on test scores.
lead_paragraph: The New York State Education Department, responding to concerns that standardized exams in reading and math have become excessive and unwieldy, will seek to ease the burden of testing.

headline: Video: Acura Brings 4-Wheel Steering to the RLX
abstract: You may not be able to tell the difference while you’re driving, but Acura’s new 4-wheel steering system moves the front and rear wheels in concert to improve high-speed steering response.
lead_paragraph: Automotive innovation over the years has given us seat belts, hybrid powertrains and – most importantly – cup holders. Steering? It has changed somewhat, but for more than 100 years most cars have done just fine with the front wheels handling that job.

headline: The Week in Pictures for Oct. 25
abstract: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include urban running crews, a sugar refinery in Brooklyn and same-sex marriages in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include urban running crews, a sugar refinery in Brooklyn and same-sex marriages in New Jersey.

headline: Potential Merger Would Vault Law Firm to Top 10 in U.S.
abstract: Law firm mergers are booming, and a combination of Orrick and Pillsbury, which would create a formidable presence in Silicon Valley, would be the year’s largest.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:50 p.m. | The law firms Orrick Herrington & Sutcliffe and Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman are in advanced merger talks, with an announcement of a deal expected as early as next week.

headline: A Fitful Start-Up That Became a Symbol of Privilege
abstract: Aston Martin has a long history, and its cars have earned a reputation for being sexy, raffish and yet buttoned-up — like a panther in a three-piece suit.
lead_paragraph: From its founding a century ago, Aston Martin created cars meant to appeal to the sporting instincts of upper-class Britons who appreciated their design, exclusivity and, perhaps, scarcity. Judging by today’s models, which start at more than $115,000 and stretch to the brink of $300,000, the formula has proved durable.

headline: Where St. Vincent’s Once Stood
abstract: A look at the transformation of the St. Vincent’s Hospital site in the West Village, a mega-work-in-progress.
lead_paragraph: The developers of a 200-unit condominium complex on the site of the former St. Vincent’s Hospital campus, which to its opponents was a symbol of the overdevelopment of New York during the Bloomberg era, hope to leave its contentious past behind.

headline: Three Cellos in Conversation, Together, Alone and Intense
abstract: The conductor Charles Dutoit brings back some favorites, including Penderecki’s “Concerto Grosso,” with three solo cellos, in a New York Philharmonic appearance.
lead_paragraph: For all his vast experience in the orchestral world, the conductor Charles Dutoit has not been a particular champion of living composers. Over the years, though, certain pieces have clearly excited him, including the Polish composer Krzysztof Penderecki’s Concerto Grosso, composed in 2000 and scored for three solo cellos and orchestra. Mr. Dutoit conducted the 2001 premiere of this work with the NHK Symphony Orchestra in Tokyo and has presented it over the years with other ensembles.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Just Dropped In to Take Your Pulse
abstract: The Volkswagen Scirocco R performance hatchback is a European car that the company is showing off in America. Will it come here? VW isn’t ready to say.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As corporate entities go, the Volkswagen Group is known for carrying out its affairs with a certain deliberation — of setting goals, conducting extensive research and delivering on its objectives.

headline: Taut Wires as a Foil for Curves
abstract: The Brian Brooks Moving Company is presenting its latest work, “Run Don’t Run,’ danced on a set with hundreds of taut strings, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Brian Brooks has become as known for his sets as for his choreography. His latest work, “Run Don’t Run,” which had its debut on Tuesday, seats audience members facing one another on two sides of the BAM Fishman Space. Across their field of vision stretch hundreds of strings, like a giant’s harp laid on its side.

headline: Civil War Comes Alive in Artifacts
abstract: “Civil War 360” looks at history through evocative objects.
lead_paragraph: The overall history lesson in “Civil War 360” is fairly elementary, but this three-part series, which begins Sunday night on the Smithsonian Channel, does a commendable job of elevating museum objects from dry collection displays to living pieces of the past. And the three celebrity hosts walking viewers through the episodes seem genuinely moved by what they’re seeing.

headline: U.N., Fearing a Polio Epidemic in Syria, Moves to Vaccinate Millions of Children
keywords: ['Poliomyelitis', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Officials said that the discovery a few weeks ago of a cluster of paralyzed young children in Deir al-Zour, a heavily contested city in eastern Syria, had prompted their alarm.
lead_paragraph: United Nations officials said Friday that they were mobilizing to vaccinate 2.5 million young children in Syria and more than eight million others in the region to combat what they fear could be an explosive outbreak of polio, the incurable viral disease that cripples and kills, which has reappeared in the war-ravaged country for the first time in more than a dozen years.

headline: Rio Police Officer Is Indicted for Torture While Lecturing on ‘Smart Policing’ in New York
abstract: A Brazilian police officer who spoke at a technology conference in New York was indicted by prosecutors back home in connection with a notorious case of torture and murder by her unit.
lead_paragraph: A Brazilian police officer who spoke at a technology conference in New York on Tuesday about the potential of a new smartphone app to aid in the “pacification” of Rio de Janeiro’s lawless favelas was indicted the same day by prosecutors back home in connection with a notorious case of torture and murder by her unit in July.

headline: Wake Up, Sleepyhead: A Virtual Poke to Drivers
abstract: Studies have shown that too much help behind the wheel may not always be an advantage for safety.
lead_paragraph: As automakers rush to assign more driving chores to computers, researchers who analyze driver workload could be left shaking their heads. Studies have shown that too much help behind the wheel may not always be an advantage for safety.

headline: On the Road to Autonomous, a Pause at Extrasensory
abstract: Autonomous cars have been arriving in bits and pieces for years. Bristling with sensors and microprocessors, cars have been lightening the driver’s workload and improving safety, and more bits of self-driving technology are arriving with 2014 models.
lead_paragraph: The self-driving car, whenever it arrives, is sure to be hailed as a breakthrough.

headline: Obama, at Brooklyn School, Pushes Education Agenda
abstract: The president went to the Pathways in Technology Early College High School, which he mentioned in his State of the Union address this year, to talk about education.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Friday visited the innovative Brooklyn high school he praised in his State of the Union address this year, to deliver a message about the urgency of education reform in the global economy.

headline: What If We Just Gave the Poor Money?
abstract: A new study found that cash transfers to poor Kenyan families helped reduce hunger and increase investment in small businesses.
lead_paragraph: Can we reduce poverty simply by giving the poor money, with no strings attached? A new study from Innovations for Poverty Action, a non-profit research organization, found that cash transfers of $300 or $1,100 to 500 poor Kenyan families helped reduce hunger, improve living conditions and increase investment in livestock and small businesses.

headline: Strange Goings-On in a See-Through House
abstract: Zimmermann & de Perrot’s “Hans was Heiri” is physical theater in a set that moves, too.
lead_paragraph: In 1957, in an exchange that passed quickly into performance lore, the critic Louis Horst published a blank column in response to “Duet,” a Paul Taylor dance comprising stillness and set to John Cage’s “4’33.” I thought with longing of Horst’s gorgeous expanse of silence Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Harvey Theater, during “Hans was Heiri” by the Swiss duo Zimmermann & de Perrot — not because this physical theater work is minimalist, but for the opposite reason. Blankness seemed the only possible antidote to this relentlessly busy and manic spectacle; it was like the desire to slip into a hermetically sealed, fragrance-free chamber after shopping at Sephora.

headline: Obama Visits Brooklyn High School

headline: New Bolt Service on the West Coast
abstract: A new Bolt Bus route on the West Coast will include stops in Los Angeles, San Jose, and Oakland, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Bolt Bus, the intercity bus line and transportation solution for cash-strapped college students and thrifty business travelers alike, is expanding its service to include three more cities on the West Coast. On Oct. 31, the big orange buses will begin a new route with stops in Los Angeles, San Jose and Oakland, Calif. In honor of the occasion, the company is selling one-way tickets on the new route for $1 to passengers who book travel within the first four days of service, Oct. 31 to Nov. 3.

headline: Bill Sharman, Two-Time Basketball Hall of Famer, Dies at 87
abstract: A guard for the Boston Celtics in the 1950s, Sharman went on to lead the Lakers to their first N.B.A. title in Los Angeles, in 1971-72, and is credited with introducing the morning shootaround.
lead_paragraph: Bill Sharman, who was elected to the Basketball Hall of Fame twice, first as a sharpshooting guard who helped establish the Boston Celtics dynasty of the 1950s and then as a coach who led the 1971-72 Los Angeles Lakers to a record 33-game winning streak and the N.B.A. title, died on Friday at his home in Redondo Beach, Calif. He was 87.

headline: Beyond the Velvet Rope, With the Bumps and Grinds
abstract: “Eager to Lose,” a play that combines rhyming couplets with burlesque, is running at Ars Nova.
lead_paragraph: After serving as a Russian nightclub for the original incarnation of “Natasha, Pierre and the Great Comet of 1812,” Ars Nova has undergone another extravagant transformation, this time into a velvet-swathed house of neo-burlesque called the Tim Tam Room.

headline: Stricken, an Actor Stays in Character
abstract: Starring as Eugene O’Neill in “And Give Us the Shadows” at the Schoolhouse Theater, Jerry Lanning collapsed in the middle of performing.
lead_paragraph: If an actor is going to collapse onstage in the middle of a performance, he might as well pick an appropriate moment.

headline: Steeped in Hip-Hop Lore
abstract: Mack Wilds performed at S.O.B.’s, using material from his new album and recalling hip-hop styles of yesteryear.
lead_paragraph: For a time after “The Wire” completed its five-season run on HBO in 2008, Spot the “Wire” Character was a fun parlor game. Actors so indelibly linked to those Baltimore street roles often ended up disrupting other perfectly calm environments: the corner boy Bodie (J. D. Williams) in a FedEx commercial; the reformed thug Cutty (Chad L. Coleman) on “I Hate My Teenage Daughter”; and, of course, the ambivalent street recruit Michael (Tristan Wilds) on the too-clean reboot of “90210.”

headline: Calcutta Pairs at the Cavendish Tournament
abstract: The premier events at the Cavendish tournament in Monaco were the Calcutta Pairs. There were 16 entries in the women’s and 60 in the open.
lead_paragraph: The premier events at the Cavendish tournament in Monaco were the Calcutta Pairs. There were 16 entries in the women’s and 60 in the open.

keywords: ['Automobiles', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Wind Power', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The jobs report delayed by the federal shutdown showed modest growth, but carried warning signs, and states joined together to promote electric cars.
lead_paragraph: The jobs report delayed by the federal shutdown showed modest growth, but carried warning signs, and states joined together to promote electric cars.

headline: Surviving the Etiquette Demon of Steubenville
abstract: In Jeffrey Hatcher’s semi-autobiographical comedy “Mrs. Mannerly,” he recalls the deportment lessons absorbed in 1967 by his pudgy, going-on-10-year-old self.
lead_paragraph: Hang up the white gloves, Emily Post. Retire the oyster fork, Amy Vanderbilt. And step gracefully aside, Letitia Baldrige. Mrs. Mannerly has invited herself to your party and brought her 1967 etiquette class from Steubenville, Ohio, to Hartford.

headline: Bringing New Life to Druid’s Sacrifice
abstract: Angela Meade and Jamie Barton join the cast of “Norma” at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: I have had the enduring — and enduring and enduring — pleasure of seeing all seven performances of Bellini’s “Norma” so far this season at the Metropolitan Opera. (What can I say? I like Druids.)

headline: JPMorgan Reaches Deal With Agency Over Loans
abstract: The Federal Housing Finance Agency,which helped forge a tentative $13 billion settlement with JPMorgan Chase split off with its own deal on Friday, extracting a $4 billion payout from the nation’s biggest bank.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase has secured important concessions in a $13 billion settlement over its mortgage practices, allowances that could ultimately reduce the bank’s financial burden and leave the government itself on the hook for a small portion of the cost.

headline: A Farewell to Pianists Who Aim for the Gut
abstract: A Saturday night concert by Bowed Piano Ensemble, whose members reach into the piano’s guts with motley tools to extract sound, may be its last in New York.
lead_paragraph: Few chamber groups deploy their musicians as oddly as the Bowed Piano Ensemble. The 10 players, students led by the composer Stephen Scott, stand around, and sometimes under, a concert grand, armed with items of all kinds — nylon fishing line, piano hammers, guitar picks, strips of paper, rolls of plumber’s tape — and reach into the instrument to draw sounds from its strings. The music is tactile and otherworldly, sometimes percussive and often lyrical.

headline: Through a Dance Kaleidoscope, the Throbbing Grooves of Soul’s Godfather
abstract: “James Brown: Get on The Good Foot,” a dance revue presented at the Apollo Theater, honored Brown for his enormous influence on music and dance and his place in the theater’s history.
lead_paragraph: How many choreographers does it take to celebrate the many sides of James Brown? To do justice in dance to his incalculably huge and global influence? According to “James Brown: Get on the Good Foot,” an enjoyable miscellany of a dance revue that had its premiere on Tuesday at the Apollo Theater, the answer is 10.

headline: After a 100-Year Sleep, a Beauty Wakes to Vampires
abstract: “Matthew Bourne’s Sleeping Beauty” takes Tchaikovsky’s ballet and makes it the choreographer’s own.
lead_paragraph: That the full title of “Matthew Bourne’s Sleeping Beauty” includes the name of its director and choreographer isn’t vanity. It’s truth in advertising. As do Mr. Bourne’s “Nutcracker” and “Swan Lake” (the international success, with the male swans), his “Sleeping Beauty” retains the Tchaikovsky score of this classic ballet. His version is still a fairy tale about a princess who sleeps under a spell for 100 years. But it truly is his. The subtitle is telling: “A Gothic Romance.”

headline: Movie Review: 'The Square'
abstract: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Square."
lead_paragraph: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews "The Square."

headline: Prices That Fly Under the Headlines
abstract: Those who want to buy art and not spend millions can find works in less-popular forms, like drawings, prints and small sculptures, or by lesser-known but first-rate artists.
lead_paragraph: LET us, for the moment anyway, dispense with the phrase “record prices” and forget about all the auction frenzy — the $120 million paid for a pastel by Munch; the $106.5 million for an oil painting by Picasso; the $104.3 million for a Giacometti sculpture. These numbers seem more like money in a Monopoly game than reality.

headline: Serving Museum Patrons Something More
abstract: With the opening of a multimillion-dollar restaurant, the Brooklyn Museum joins the ranks of culture centers offering high-end dining experiences to their visitors.
lead_paragraph: HIS voice barely audible above the screech of power tools, Saul Bolton — chef and founder, with his wife, Lisa, of the Michelin-starred Saul restaurant in a modest storefront in Brooklyn — was not only describing the construction site around him, but also the newest embodiment of his dream.

headline: Welcoming Art Lovers With Disabilities
abstract: Museums are making art accessible to people with visual, hearing or mobility difficulties, as well as reaching out to residents of nursing homes and children on the autism spectrum.
lead_paragraph: ON a recent Friday night, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York held its first public exhibition of original art made in its “Seeing Through Drawing” classes. Participants — all blind or partly sighted — created works inspired by objects in the museum’s collection that were described to them by sighted instructors and that they were also allowed to touch.

headline: Auctions Organized by Theme, With a Narrative Pull
keywords: ['Art', 'Auctions', 'ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: Auctions with a theme — say, Samurai arts or objects from princely European courts — are taking their place alongside the traditional categories, like contemporary art or old masters.
lead_paragraph: FOR Swann Auction Galleries, the inspiration for its Nov. 5 sale, “The Armory Show at 100,” wasn’t far away. The auctioneer’s premises sit right across the street from the 69th Regiment Armory in New York, where the famous “International Exhibition of Modern Art,” whose displays of nontraditional paintings from Europe shocked the public and changed the course of American art, made its debut.

headline: Pigeon Racing: Faster and Farther, but Fair?
abstract: Pigeon racing’s followers were stunned when six Belgian birds failed tests for banned performance-enhancing drugs. It would be comical if it weren’t true.
lead_paragraph: They no doubt would plead ignorance. Or blame their coaches. Or say they were victims of jealous rivals who spiked their water bottles with banned substances, or claim that the liquid they had been squirting under their tongues was only flaxseed oil, not performance-enhancing drugs meant to turn them into rockets.

headline: A Revamped Home for Philadelphia’s Favorite Son
abstract: The Benjamin Franklin Museum in Philadelphia has thrown out the phones and animatronics in favor of interactive exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the Benjamin Franklin Museum opened in the wake of the American Bicentennial in 1976, it had to be one of the funkiest museums ever conceived for the National Park Service.

headline: Artists Take Up Digital Tools
abstract: An exhibition at the Museum of Arts and Design in New York highlights artists, architects and designers who use technologies like 3-D printing and numerically controlled milling.
lead_paragraph: “PEOPLE have this idea about ‘digital’ that you just press the button and the machine spits something out, which really couldn’t be further from the truth,” said Richard Dupont, a sculptor who makes startling distortions of the human form.

headline: Photos of Luminaries, by a Luminary
abstract: An exhibition at the Emily Lowe Gallery in Hempstead showcases 64 portraits of influential figures taken by Arnold Newman.
lead_paragraph: Pablo Picasso comes first in the lineup, facing the viewer, one hand on his forehead. He is followed by Max Ernst, sitting in his studio in a majestic armchair, a cloud of cigarette smoke circling his head. Next is Piet Mondrian, perched behind his easel in front of panels that form a grid reminiscent of his paintings. Then we come upon Jean Arp, peeking around one of his own curvy sculptures, only one eye visible.

headline: At 80, Mnuchin Remains a Passionate Promoter of Postwar Art
abstract: Robert Mnuchin, a Manhattan gallery owner who abandoned a Goldman Sachs career, starts over without a longtime partner.
lead_paragraph: SINCE Robert Mnuchin recently turned 80, some might expect him to be slowing down. Instead, he is speeding up, or at least starting a new chapter with the Mnuchin Gallery. He opened it this year after parting ways with Dominique Lévy, his partner at L&M Arts, a gallery that was a prominent player in the art market during the economic boom, bidding large sums at auction.

headline: In a Blaze of Hope, Flickering Menace
abstract: The Irish Repertory Theater revives “Juno and the Paycock,” Sean O’Casey’s classic about a buffeted Dublin family, with J. Smith-Cameron in the title role.
lead_paragraph: Trouble breaks in great, surging waves upon the Irish family in Sean O’Casey’s classic “Juno and the Paycock,” now being revived with all the requisite big heart and black humor by the Irish Repertory Theater. The waters swirl most strongly around Juno Boyle, the matriarch of a small family barely subsisting in the strife-torn Dublin of the 1920s. And when you first glimpse the careworn Juno, portrayed by the veteran J. Smith-Cameron, you may wonder whether this petite figure with the haunted blue eyes has the fortitude to endure the worst, and then the worse than worst.

headline: Miami Museum Celebrates the Art of a Crossroads
abstract: The Pérez Art Museum Miami, which reopens in December, will focus on artists of the Americas and is intended as a draw for the international art world.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — MIAMI’S status as a transnational city is highlighted in the programming and collecting strategies of the new Pérez Art Museum Miami, formerly the Miami Art Museum, which reopens Dec. 4 in a new location overlooking Biscayne Bay and bordered by MacArthur Causeway.

headline: At Historic Homes, Unearthing a Deeper View of Slavery
abstract: Sites like the Rock Hall manor on Long Island have discovered a more complex picture of slavery in colonial America.
lead_paragraph: TUCKED into suburban Lawrence, N.Y., in the southwest corner of Long Island’s Nassau County, Rock Hall is a hard place to find. But despite its relative obscurity, this stately, 18th-century Georgian manor has a new and intriguing story to tell, thanks to evidence uncovered through recent archaeological work.

headline: Pictures of the Day: New York and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Brooklyn, Italy, Madagascar and the Vatican.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Brooklyn, Italy, Madagascar and the Vatican.

headline: Esteem for the Art of the American West
abstract: Thirty years ago, Western art was often seen as an out-of-touch genre, fed by a love of nostalgia and history, but that is changing.
lead_paragraph: THE art of the American West has long been honored in the states whose history it records, but it hasn’t always been accepted in the larger art world. Thirty years ago, it was often seen as an out-of-touch genre, fed by a love of nostalgia and history.

headline: Obama Visits a Brooklyn School
abstract: President Obama went to Pathways in Technology Early College High School, and spoke to students Friday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: President Obama went to Pathways in Technology Early College High School, and spoke to students Friday afternoon.

headline: A Portfolio That Surprises Even Its Creator
abstract: Renzo Piano has designed 25 major projects, and his work has become a reference point in the field.
lead_paragraph: DISTINGUISHED architects often wait their entire careers for a big museum commission. Many are still waiting.

headline: ‘Rights’ Exhibit to Display Documents From the Mighty and the Modest
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The streamlined National Archives will include a copy of the Magna Carta and papers on slavery, women’s struggles and immigration.
lead_paragraph: A COMPENSATION claim from a former slave. A World War II guide helping officers adapt to women in industry. A newspaper for Japanese-American internees in Oregon. Those will be among the artifacts on exhibit when a new National Archives gallery opens in Washington devoted to “Records of Rights.” The centerpiece will be an original 1297 Magna Carta, the only copy on public display in the United States.

headline: From a Twitter How-To, Another Lesson
abstract: A Florida man briefly became flooded by notifications from Twitter after a headline about how to use the social platform incidentally included his user name.
lead_paragraph: It was in the wee hours of Thursday when Bill Costello, known as @BC on Twitter, realized that something unusual was happening. His phone kept vibrating, notifying him of activity on his Twitter account.

headline: In Dallas, 10 Sculptures for 10 Years

For its 10th year, it is going much bigger — to all of Dallas. It has commissioned 10 public sculptures by 10 artists at 10 diverse locations around the 385-square-mile city, all on view as of Oct. 19.

headline: So Many Stories to Tell for Met’s Digital Chief

headline: Museum Explores ‘The Power of Poison’

Was it the chocolate he found in the garbage can? Did a snake, or a black widow spider, bite him? Or was a poisonous cane toad to blame?

headline: Galleries as the Art World’s Leading Indicators
abstract: This fall and winter, galleries are displaying art in a range of media, addressing an almost dizzying array of social and cultural issues — adolescent humor not included.
lead_paragraph: TASTE in art is in constant flux. One season’s penchant for abstract paintings may be another’s fascination with chocolate Santas, or lead balloons, comic strips, or a less-is-more aesthetic. Steering through this weather are commercial galleries, in the thick of things, taking the art world’s pulse. Unlike museums, where exhibitions are planned years in advance, galleries can be more nimble, finalizing shows a couple of months ahead of time. Indeed, there is probably no better barometer of current collective rumblings than what’s being shown at the top New York and Los Angeles galleries.

headline: An Obscure Building Where Surrealism Thrived
abstract: “Surrealism and the Rue Blomet,” at Eykyn Maclean gallery in New York, will focus on a building in Paris where Joan Miró and André Masson lived and worked in the 1920s.
lead_paragraph: IT has been 74 years since World War II fractured the Surrealist movement, forcing many of its artists to flee Europe for other parts of the globe. But now one of their earliest gathering spots in Paris will be resurrected, figuratively, in “Surrealism and the Rue Blomet,” from Friday through Dec. 13 at Eykyn Maclean gallery in New York.

headline: Museums Draw on Events That Shaped the World
keywords: ['Art', 'Museums', 'ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)']
abstract: A number of coming exhibitions will highlight milestones in history this fall, including the New-York Historical Society’s centennial celebration of the 1913 Armory Show.
lead_paragraph: MOST curators strive for novelty when they are putting together an exhibition. Museums nearly always want to boast that a show is “the first,” “the largest,” “the longest” or “the fill-in-the-blank-est.” For the New-York Historical Society’s latest attraction, “The Armory Show at 100,” however, a measure of success is how closely its curators can recreate the experience of this seminal 1913 exhibition.

headline: A Thrill Now Sadly Rare

My summers were filled with bat sightings, as were fall evenings after my homework was done. That bats were familiars, or consorted with the dead, never occurred to me. I only wanted to see one up close.

This time of year, it is less a job than a way of life; as Halloween approaches, the store is open from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m. She lives in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn — “In real estate they call it Clinton Hill, but it’s really Bed-Stuy,” she said — with her boyfriend, Scott Bredengerd, 31, who works in film production, and their dog, Rocko, a pug-boxer mix.

headline: Tentative Approval for Faster-Acting Hepatitis C Drug
abstract: Advisers to the Food and Drug Administration unanimously voted in favor of a hepatitis C drug from Gilead Sciences.
lead_paragraph: Advisers to the Food and Drug Administration unanimously voted in favor of a hepatitis C drug from Gilead Sciences. All 15 members of the agency’s panel of virus experts voted to recommend approval of Gilead’s pill, sofosbuvir, to treat several forms of the disease, which afflicts more than three million people in the United States. The agency is not required to adhere to the group’s advice, though it often does. Current treatments can take up to a year of therapy and cure only about three out of four patients. Gilead’s daily pill can cure up to 90 percent of patients infected with the most common form of the virus in just 12 weeks. Gilead, based in Foster City, Calif., is one of a half-dozen companies racing to develop more effective treatments for hepatitis C. The agency is expected to make a decision on the drug by Dec. 8.

Earlier this week, Mr. Ferrari took the stand, against his lawyer’s advice, and pinned the murder on Adam Kidan, a business partner of the former lobbyist Jack Abramoff, and on one of his own former employees. “I never thought about killing anybody in my life,” he said. “It’s just not in my DNA.” Mr. Ferrari, 56, faces the death penalty when he is sentenced Dec. 16.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) CLOUD ATLAS (2012) Tom Hanks and Halle Berry, above, take on multiple roles — for Mr. Hanks, a Hawaiian goatherd, a scientist, a London gangster and a 19th-century quack; for Ms. Berry, a muckraking journalist, a researcher and the wife of a temperamental maestro — in this adaptation of David Mitchell’s 2004 novel, written and directed by Lana and Andy Wachowski and Tom Tykwer. “ ‘Cloud Atlas’ is a movie about migratory souls and wayward civilizations, loaded with soaring themes and flights of feeling, as vaporous and comprehensive as its title,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, adding that perhaps the film’s achievement “should be quantified rather than judged in more conventional, qualitative ways. This is by no means the best movie of the year, but it may be the most movie you can get for the price of a single ticket.” Its six sections also star Doona Bae, Jim Broadbent, Keith David, Hugh Grant, Susan Sarandon, Jim Sturgess, Hugo Weaving and Ben Whishaw. “Together the filmmakers try so hard to give you everything — the secrets of the universe and the human heart; action, laughs and romance; tragedy and mystery — that you may wind up feeling both grateful and disappointed.”

The filing did not detail the infractions that prompted the conference with Sergeant Patton, who was facing a reduction in rank and a possible dismissal from active National Guard duty. It’s complicated because political constraints made a straightforward single-payer system unachievable.

headline: Italy Breaks Your Heart

lead_paragraph: ROME — ON my first night back in Italy, at a dinner party in Milan, I watched and listened to a successful couple in their late 40s plot their escape from a country that they love but have lost faith in. They cleared the plates, opened a laptop, and began checking out real estate in London, where one of them had been offered a transfer. The prices horrified but didn’t deter them. They have a 10-year-old son, and they fear that Italy, with 40 percent unemployment among young adults and an economy whose listlessness has come to seem the new normal, doesn’t promise a particularly bright future for him.

headline: Division Street, U.S.A.

abstract: Neighborhoods matter even more than we think they do.

That location matters greatly for housing values, for example, is taken for granted. Less appreciated is the persistence of neighborhood inequality and its extensive reach into multiple aspects of everyday life. An increasing separation at the top has intensified the effect of spatial divisions on everyone else.

She went to college at night and was living in subsidized housing when she felt God urge her to make an unexpected choice. “I started tithing. To tithe while I was living on food stamps — that was a tough decision,” she said. “The conversation I had with God was: ‘You’ve got to be kidding me. abstract: Trailing, 17-0, in the third quarter, South Carolina replaced Dylan Thompson with Connor Shaw at quarterback, which spurred a comeback against Missouri.

South Carolina was trailing in the third quarter, 17-0, and quarterback Dylan Thompson had looked lost and claustrophobic against Missouri’s swarming defense. So the Gamecocks turned to Connor Shaw, usually the team’s starter, who had sprained his knee a week earlier.

headline: Chinese Newspaper Apologizes for Articles by Detained Reporter
abstract: Days after using its front page to demand the release of its detained reporter, the Guangzhou-based New Express said that Chen Yongzhou took money to attack a prominent company.
lead_paragraph: Days after it used its front page to campaign for the release of a detained reporter, a Chinese newspaper has again taken to its front page, this time to admit that the reporter had been paid off to write a series attacking a prominent company. “To all walks of society we hereby express our profound apology,” The New Express, a tabloid based in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou, said Sunday in a notice at the bottom of its front page.

headline: Wave of Car Bombs Kills Dozens in Baghdad
