headline: Blasts Fail to Deter a Rally in India
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Elections', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: A series of low-intensity bombs exploded on Sunday in the northeastern city of Patna, targeting a rally featuring the opposition leader Narendra Modi.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A series of low-intensity bombs exploded on Sunday in the northeastern city of Patna, apparently targeting a vast rally featuring the opposition leader Narendra Modi, whose Bharatiya Janata Party hopes to unseat the long-dominant Congress Party in national elections next spring.

headline: The Food Writer and Her Picky Eater
abstract: My son is no different from many other picky eaters. I’m what’s different. I’m a food writer. So you can’t blame me for my son’s poor eating habits. (Only I can do that.)
lead_paragraph: Some children are omnivorous, equally enthusiastic for broccoli and brownies. Mine, on the other hand, is non-nivorous. For almost five years now, since he turned 2, Harry’s will-eat list has allowed fruit, snacky things, plain pasta with olive oil, yogurt and mozzarella (shredded only, thank you very much), and sometimes chicken. Oh, and hot dogs. His favorite “vegetables”: olives and capers.

headline: A Year of Recovery After Hurricane Sandy

headline: Coming Back: A Year of Recovery
abstract: Times Documentaries presents “Coming Back: A Year of Recovery After Hurricane Sandy,” a video portrait of four neighborhoods struggling in the aftermath of the 2012 storm.
lead_paragraph: For all the heightened alarm and panicky warnings that a monstrous storm was heading New York City’s way, no one was quite prepared for the deadly lashing that Hurricane Sandy delivered one year ago, on Oct. 29, 2012, to the coastline stretching from Connecticut to New Jersey.

headline: The Choices That Haunt Boston’s Manager
abstract: Fielding misplays and managerial blunders, which once haunted the franchise, came into sharp focus again in Game 3.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — If the Boston Red Sox win this World Series, they will not do it here, as they did nine years ago, when they broke an ancient curse and forged a bold new identity. If they lose, the twists and turns of Game 3 will be dissected and debated until the moment they win their next championship.

headline: PPP and Japanese Inflation Expectations (Extremely Wonkish)
abstract: Things you probably don’t care about.
lead_paragraph: I’m doing a bit of work on Abenomics, which will surface in a week or so. One thing I discovered along the way is that nobody much likes any of the existing measures of inflation expectations, as this New York Fed post by Mandel and Barnes explains. In particular, the Japanese market in inflation-protected securities is considered too thin to rely on.

headline: Disruptions: Are Eager Investors Overvaluing Tech Start-Ups?
abstract: A sign that enthusiasm might be getting ahead of reality: the number of Internet companies valued at more than $1 billion even though they have no profits.
lead_paragraph: Pinterest is a kind of Internet message board where people post their favorite images of clothes or furniture. It’s a three-year-old company and though it has an estimated 50 million unique monthly users, it doesn’t have any revenue yet.

headline: Concussions and the Classroom
abstract: The American Academy of Pediatrics on Sunday released new recommendations regarding students who return to school following a concussion.
lead_paragraph: Because of heightened awareness about the hazards of sports-related concussions, many states have implemented standards determining when an injured student may resume playing contact sports. But only a few states have begun to address how and when a student should resume classwork.

headline: What’s on Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (A&E) THE GOVERNOR’S WIFE Edwin Edwards, now 86 and popularly known as the King of Louisiana for his four terms as governor, and Trina Grimes Scott, now 35, both above, became pen pals when he was serving an eight-and-a-half-year prison sentence for extortion. They married after his release, to the chagrin of his 60-something daughters, Anna and Victoria. This series follows Ms. Edwards, already a mother of two teenage sons, as she tries to get pregnant using sperm Mr. Edwards froze a decade earlier; get along with stepdaughters nearly twice her age; and disarm skeptics who think she’s a gold digger. (Her desire to jump out of a cake at her husband’s 85th birthday party doesn’t help.) “The family feuding is played for laughs,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times, “but there is some pathos peeking out of the margins.”

headline: Johnny Knoxville and Latest ‘Jackass’ Movie Are No. 1 at Theaters
abstract: “Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa” generated $32 million in ticket sales at North American theaters over the weekend. “Gravity” fell to second place.
lead_paragraph: The vulgarity-loving masses returned to North American multiplexes over the weekend, powering “Jackass Presents: Bad Grandpa” and its star, Johnny Knoxville, to $32 million in ticket sales, easily enough for first place. This R-rated comedy cost $15 million to make and ended a dry spell for Paramount Pictures, which last released a movie in June. “Bad Grandpa,” the fourth film in a franchise that started 13 years ago on MTV, did not deliver the same kind of box-office euphoria as its series predecessor: “Jackass 3D” took in $50.4 million over its first three days in October 2010.

headline: Of Fact, Fiction and Cheney’s Defibrillator
abstract: Dick Cheney writes that to prevent terrorists from sending a fatal shock to his defibrillator, he had his doctors disable the  wireless capability. Could somebody really kill you that way?
lead_paragraph: In a chilling episode of “Homeland” last year, a terrorist killed the vice president with a fiendishly clever weapon: a remote-control device that attacked the computerized defibrillator implanted in his chest.

headline: Joe on WNYC’s “Money Talking”: Oct. 25, 2013
abstract: Joe discusses President Obama’s visit to a technical school in Brooklyn and a new model of schooling.
lead_paragraph: President Obama was in Brooklyn this weekend to visit P-Tech, a technical high school where students earn a diploma and associate’s degree in six years. WNYC’s Money Talking examines this new model of schooling, which promises to prepare students for jobs in our changing economy.

abstract: Representative Mike Rogers, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, said the National Security Agency’s surveillance program was designed to protect the countries from the threat of terror.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Representative Mike Rogers, on Sunday offered one of the most vigorous defenses of American surveillance activities in Europe, saying that much of the anger and resentment they have engendered were the result of misunderstandings.

headline: Outsider Whose Dark, Lyrical Vision Helped Shape Rock ’n’ Roll
abstract: Mr. Reed was a singer, songwriter and guitarist whose work with the Velvet Underground in the 1960s had an impact on generations of rock musicians.
lead_paragraph: Lou Reed, the singer, songwriter and guitarist whose work with the Velvet Underground in the 1960s had a major influence on generations of rock musicians, and who remained a powerful if polarizing force for the rest of his life, died on Sunday at his home in Amagansett, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 71.

headline: Second Win Has Giants ‘Humble’ but Hopeful
abstract: The Giants used efficient offense, solid defense and five field goals to stop an eight-game road skid and hand Philadelphia its 10th straight home loss.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The unforeseen bliss of a two-game winning streak has not exactly gone to the Giants’ heads. On Sunday, in the waning moments of their second victory in seven days, their sideline was not a party zone. The sting of six losses to start the season remained.

abstract: New ideas of 1998, served fresh.
lead_paragraph: Binyamin Applebaum’s piece on the growing acknowledgment that moderate inflation can help, especially under current circumstances. But I can’t help thinking, only now they notice? I mean, this was all worked out and carefully explained fifteen years ago.

headline: A Lion of the Left Wing Celebrates Six Decades
abstract: Dissent Magazine’s circulation has long hovered around 5,000, but its influence has been outsize, and a new generation of editors and writers is helping with its appeal to younger readers.
lead_paragraph: When Irving Howe and Lewis Coser started Dissent in 1954 as a quarterly magazine of independent left-wing thought, they imagined they would be lucky to last a year. Their budget was too small, and the forces against them — both the McCarthyism of national politics and the sectarian dogmatism of the broader American left — were too strong.

headline: The Crusader Leaps Back Into the Past
abstract: Batman: Arkham Origins, the third installment in the well-received Arkham series, looks at how Batman first encountered some of his notable allies and adversaries.
lead_paragraph: Video games and comic book superheroes ought to be an irresistible combination, like chocolate and peanut butter, pancakes and maple syrup, anger and Dr. Bruce Banner. Instead, comics and games have gotten along about as well as Superman and Kryptonite.

headline: Compositions Created to Be Seen ... as Well as Heard
abstract: In “Up-close,” the composer Michel van der Aa, using “extra layers,” pairs a cello soloist with a silent woman who appears in a film he wrote and directed.
lead_paragraph: “In the solo concerto musical interest is aroused and sustained on the basis of an opposition between one instrument and many,” Abraham Veinus wrote in “The Concerto,” a 1944 study. “In this sense it has been described as a musical reflection of the everyday and ever-engrossing human drama of the individual lost in, emerging from, and pitted against the multitude.” From Vivaldi’s groundbreaking “Estro Armonico” of 1711 to today, attributes of theater have adhered to the genre.

headline: A Festival That’s Rich in Music but Puzzling in Name
abstract: This year’s White Light Festival began with Handel’s little-known dramatic cantata “Aci, Galatea e Polifemo.”
lead_paragraph: The White Light Festival is back at Lincoln Center for a fourth season: another opportunity for music lovers to try to puzzle out the exact meaning of the title. Not that the first classical program — Handel’s little-known dramatic cantata “Aci, Galatea e Polifemo,” performed by Le Concert d’Astrée on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall — was much help.

headline: When the Numbers Don’t Add Up, a Movement Has to Be Left Out
abstract: In “Levée des Conflits Extended” (“Suspension of Conflicts Extended”), 24 dancers are cycling through a sequence, whose core concept is mathematical.
lead_paragraph: Several times this past weekend, 24 people sat in the atrium of the Museum of Modern Art and scrubbed the floor with circling hands. Sometimes they did this in near unison. Sometimes one person did the scrubbing, while the other 23 did 23 other actions: rocking, rolling, running, spinning, leaping. Sometimes 24 actions were happening, and scrubbing wasn’t one of them.

lead_paragraph: In August, the director-producer J. J. Abrams released a video teaser for his latest mystery project, “S.” Shot in inky black and white, the video featured a strange man staggering out of the ocean, as a narrator intoned, “Who is he?”

lead_paragraph: “Is reality TV art?” asked the mezzo-soprano Jennifer Rivera, dressed as a Kim Kardashian look-alike in heels and a leopard-print dress, tossing a long black mane while flouncing around the Gerald W. Lynch Theater on Wednesday evening.

headline: Economic Reports for the Week of Oct. 28
abstract: Many big-name companies are reporting earnings, including Apple, Exxon Mobil, Facebook, General Motors and Chrysler, and the Fed is expected to keep up its stimulus efforts.
lead_paragraph: APPLE EARNINGS Apple has become one of the most valuable companies in the world largely because of the success of iPhones and iPads. But over the last year, the growth of its profit has slowed as fewer people have been upgrading their smartphones each year, and as more competitors have produced low-cost tablets. In response, Apple in September introduced not one, but two new iPhones. When the company announces its third-quarter earnings on Monday, investors and analysts will watch closely to determine whether the new iPhones have given Apple’s profit a much-needed lift.

headline: Cavendish Open Pairs in Monaco Won by Bulgarian Team
abstract: The winners of the Cavendish Open Pairs in Monaco last week were Rossen Gunev and Ivan Nanev.
lead_paragraph: The winners of the Cavendish Open Pairs in Monaco last week were Rossen Gunev and Ivan Nanev of Bulgaria. In the auction, they went for 14,000 euros ($19,300), and the purchasers received 185,000 euros ($255,400) in return: a 13-for-1 increase. Almost as good was the payoff for the second-place pair of Krzysztof Martens and Dominic Filipowicz of Poland: 110,000 euros ($152,000) for 10,000 ($13,800) paid. Third place was not nearly so profitable. To buy Tor Helness and Geir Helgemo of Monaco cost 52,000 euros ($72,000) and brought in 75,000 euros ($103,500).

headline: Joyce Theater Plans
abstract: The New York City Ballet principal Wendy Whelan, DanceBrazil and Pilobolus are among those slated to perform on the Joyce Theater stage in 2014.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Ballet principal Wendy Whelan, DanceBrazil and Pilobolus are among those slated to perform on the Joyce Theater stage in 2014. Joyce officials are to announce on Monday that the spring and summer season will kick off Feb. 19 to 23 with Jessica Lang Dance, followed by Brazil Festival from Feb. 26 to March 16. The festival is to feature four contemporary companies, including DanceBrazil, a group founded in 1977 and specializing in Afro-Brazilian movement, contemporary dance and capoeira. headline: Better Than a Tweet? In Four Characters, a New World of Meaning

abstract: New phrases popular among young Chinese on the Internet retain the format of classical Chinese idioms but are distinguished by their ironic, contemporary, and sometimes political themes.
lead_paragraph: There is a Chinese idiom that might be used to describe the place of idioms in Chinese literary tradition: jianding buyi (坚定不移), meaning “firm and unchanging.” The use of such expressions, especially the classical set phrases known as chengyu (成语), has long been seen as a mark of erudition in China. Most chengyu consist of only four characters, but they don’t follow the grammar and syntax of modern Chinese, and as many frustrated Mandarin students can tell you, they are often indecipherable without some knowledge of their origins, often in ancient Chinese literature that preceded the birth of Christ.

headline: Is the ‘Dumb Jock’ Really a Nerd?
abstract: In a seminal brain study, a cultural bias that separates knowledge and physical skill skewed interpretation of the results. Philosophy can help overcome that bias.
lead_paragraph: In the frequent debates over the merits of science and philosophy, or the humanities in general, it is often assumed that the factual grounding and systematic methodology of the sciences serve as a corrective to the less rigorous wanderings of the humanities. And while many take the position that the humanities can provide their own important path to enlightenment, few argue that considerations from philosophy can or should correct the considered judgment of scientists. Even most defenders of the humanities hold that the sciences are directed at truth, whereas the humanities have an alternate goal, perhaps the molding of ideal citizens.

(HBO) SEDUCED AND ABANDONED (2013) In May 2012, James Toback and Alec Baldwin (from left above) spent 10 days schmoozing their way through the Cannes Film Festival as they tried to secure financing for a proposed movie project: a political-erotic Middle Eastern adventure inspired by Bernardo Bertolucci’s “Last Tango in Paris” and starring Mr. Baldwin and Neve Campbell as the characters played by Marlon Brando and Maria Schneider. The men filmed the proceedings — from pitches to billionaires and studio moguls to encounters with movie stars and directors — then turned it into a cinematic romp about Hollywood deal making. “ ‘Seduced and Abandoned,’ which uses split screens much of the time, rambles entertainingly from topic to topic,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “It begins with a complaint ascribed to Orson Welles that he spent 95 percent of his life running around trying to raise money for movies and 5 percent making them. There is hardly a dull moment.” It may be, he added, “the year’s most entertaining put-on.”

headline: By Design | High Season for High Jewels

The Paris-based Joel Arthur Rosenthal, known professionally as JAR — an acronym synonymous for more than 35 years with ne plus ultra jewels fashioned into spirals, flowers and butterflies — will unveil his first American retrospective, “Jewels by JAR,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. Meanwhile, Sotheby’s will showcase the rarest pieces made by the retired Alexandre Reza, in addition to designs by his son Olivier, with an exhibition, “The Extraordinary Jewelry of Alexandre Reza.” Finally, Sheikh Hamad bin Abdullah Al Thani of Qatar boasts an unparalleled private collection of Indian jewels spanning the past 400 years — from handcrafted jade daggers of the Mughal courts to emerald turban ornaments favored by 19th-century maharajahs — which have been bound into a beautiful tome.

abstract: The band canceled a 14-date tour of Australia and New Zealand, saying that the bassist John McVie will be seeking treatment for cancer.

abstract: Dressing like a ninja, a thief made off with horse racing and golf memorabilia worth nearly $1 million in a string of museum burglaries in New York and New Jersey, the authorities say.
lead_paragraph: As far as heists go, the disguise was cartoonish — the thief was swaddled like a ninja from head to toe. His method was neither high-tech nor elegant — he kicked in doors and smashed glass cases. But his taste was impeccable, and sporting: his haul included the 1903 Belmont Stakes trophy, a silver Fabergé soup tureen and ladle given by Czar Nicholas II of Russia to an American harness horse impresario and the United States Amateur Championship trophy that completed golfer Bobby Jones’s Grand Slam in 1930.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: October 25-27, 2013
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Keenan A. Draughon, 23, of Clarksville, Tenn., was arrested at Kennedy International Airport in New York on Saturday when officers discovered a shotgun, two pistols and two rifles as he was checking in for his flight to Charlotte, N.C. Draughon approached a United Airlines counter and told an attendant that he had two cases containing firearms—two 9-millimeter pistols, two magazines capable of holding 15 rounds of 9-millimeter ammunition, and two .22-caliber rifles. The rifles had been painted purple and silver, and one of them had a round in the chamber. Both were missing serial numbers.

headline: Another Way Samsung Can Copy Apple
abstract: The South Korean giant has almost $40 billion in cash. It can afford to mimic Apple by giving more to investors.
lead_paragraph: Here’s one idea that Samsung could safely copy from Apple: As a proportion of its $221 billion market capitalization, the South Korean giant’s near $40 billion cash pile is almost as big as that of its American archrival. With its reserves accumulating quickly, it can afford to mimic Apple by giving more to investors.

headline: Conquering Fears, Without Drinking the Samples
abstract: Ms. Smith, head of mixology and spirit creation at Belvedere Vodka, said she spent many flights chatting with flight attendants in the back of the plane.
lead_paragraph: I LOVE airports, hotels and anything involving getting from Point A to Point B. But it wasn’t always like that. When I first started out with Belvedere Vodka more than 10 years ago, business travel involved jumping on a train and going to places like Cambridge, Bristol or Exeter to talk to anyone who would listen to me talk about Belvedere. After two years, I guess you could say I graduated from only traveling by train in Britain to traveling by plane throughout Europe and eventually to the Americas, and every place else in the world.

headline: Goldman, Feeling Robbed, Still Has to Pay for Accused’s Defense
abstract: The bank’s bylaws require it to advance the legal fees of an ex-employee accused of stealing computer code. The case may lead to a wider examination of bylaws.
lead_paragraph: A victim of a crime would never be expected to pay for the perpetrator’s lawyer to defend the case. But corporate law can be counterintuitive, and Goldman Sachs found itself on the wrong side of a court decision that found that the bank’s bylaws require it to advance the legal fees of a former employee who has been accused of stealing its computer code.

headline: A.D.H.D. Medication Is a Hit for Red Sox Hero
abstract: Shane Victorino of the Red Sox is like many athletically talented children with A.D.H.D. who are not just impulsive or energetic, but also perpetually one incident away from being asked to skip Little League tryouts next year. Without medication to manage his condition, it’s unlikely he’d be playing in the major leagues.
lead_paragraph: Shane Victorino has it all. He is a member of a Boston Red Sox team that is two victories away from a World Series title. He has a championship ring (won with the Philadelphia Phillies in 2008), three Gold Glove awards, and a yearly income of over $6 million. He has a beautiful wife and two insanely adorable children. He has the undying love of Boston sports fans, after hitting a pennant-clinching grand slam that sent the Red Sox to the World Series against the St. Louis Cardinals.

headline: Judicial Neglect
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Cold War Era', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Law of the Sea (UN Convention)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Political Prisoners', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: A look at Russia’s recent interactions with international courts shows there is no court in the world whose authority Russian officials recognize.
lead_paragraph: MURMANSK, RUSSIA — The 30 Greenpeace activists who are in jail here and the large group of volunteers who are organizing their legal and humanitarian aid got their first ray of hope in a month on Oct. 21 when the Netherlands filed a claim in the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea. The Dutch government demanded that Russia release the Greenpeace ship, “Arctic Sunrise,” which had flown the Dutch flag. The ship was seized in international waters and escorted to the port of Murmansk, where the crew and passengers from 18 different countries have been held since Sept. 24. And now, their supporters hoped, the tribunal would order them released.

headline: Giorgio Armani’s Dolce Vita
abstract: A look at the multibillion dollar empire and sweet, sweet life of the titanic Italian designer.
lead_paragraph: It is one of the fashion industry’s more epic feats of longevity that Giorgio Armani is breezily approaching his fifth decade of design under his namesake label. But you don’t create a multibillion dollar empire that spans clothes, home décor, hotels, restaurants and even the silver screen without raising a few eyebrows. After all, this is the man responsible for shifting the boundaries of permissible images of male eroticism with Richard Gere’s wardrobe in “American Gigolo,” and for helping to define the prowess of grab-and-greed 1980s power-suit dressing for women — which, by extension, has become the uniform of choice for Hollywood honchos, Wall Street bigwigs and red-carpet mainstays to this day. But as is the Armani M.O., all epoch-making moments appear as effortless as his signature bronzed physique and glowing white smile.

headline: The Automatons of Yesteryear
abstract: Humanoid machines have been around since the early 20th century, but technology has only recently begun to fulfill some of the aspirations of the earliest inventors.
lead_paragraph: The metallic monster had slanted, yellow eyes, skin like a suit of armor, and the halting, unsteady movements of one of Frankenstein’s creations. On a bright September day in 1928, a curious crowd of onlookers got their first glimpse of Eric the Robot. The mechanical man rose from his chair, stretched out an arm for silence, and made a speech, of which few people understood more than a few words. In a special cable to The New York Times, one reporter remarked on the event, held at the exhibition of the Model Engineer’s Society of London: “Of all orators, Eric seemed the coldest and most lacking in magnetism.”

lead_paragraph: On a recent morning Natanel Dukan walked into the Paris offices of the French robot maker Aldebaran and noticed one of the company’s humanoid NAO robots sitting on a chair. Mr. Dukan, an electrical engineer, could not resist. Bending over, he kissed the robot on the cheek. In response the NAO tilted its head, touched his cheek and let out an audible smack.

headline: Japanese Autos Lose Ground in Consumer Reports’ Reliability Ratings

Two of America’s most popular cars, the V-6-equipped Honda Accord and the Nissan Altima, no longer have the consumer advocacy publication’s coveted “Recommended” rating, according to the report.

He succeeds Carl Allen, the program’s director since 2008.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Vettel Wins His Fourth Consecutive World Championship
abstract: This weekend, 26-year-old Sebastian Vettel became the third and youngest Formula One driver to win four consecutive championship titles.
lead_paragraph: Sebastian Vettel, the Red Bull Infiniti driver, clinched his fourth consecutive Formula One championship with a victory Sunday in the Indian Grand Prix at the Buddh International Circuit near New Delhi. Vettel now joins Juan Manuel Fangio and Michael Schumacher as the only drivers to win four titles in a row. (Alain Prost won four, although not consecutively.) Fangio ultimately won five titles, while Schumacher went on to collect an unparalleled seven.

headline: An Insect? For Me? You Shouldn’t Have
abstract: When male nursery-web spiders give their female companions a gift, their mating produces more spiders.
lead_paragraph: When mating, some male nursery-web spiders offer their female companions a nuptial gift: an insect wrapped in white silk. Now researchers in Europe and South America have found an evolutionary basis for the practice: females were more likely to store sperm from gift-giving males, and their eggs were more likely to hatch. No wonder the spider, Pisaura mirabilis, has evolved in favor of generosity: more presents seem to mean more spiders.

headline: Double-Decker Vertigo Is Coming to Take You Away
abstract: “The Downtown Loop,” Ben Gassman’s new play at 3LD Art & Technology Center, immerses the audience in a tour bus experience with video projections and a guide who strolls up the aisle.
lead_paragraph: The set dazzles in Ben Gassman’s “The Downtown Loop,” at 3LD Art & Technology Center. Designed by Dave Ogle, it simulates the top of a double-decker New York City tour bus, albeit at an incline. Audience members are seated on the bus, while actors portraying tour guides walk the aisle bisecting the rows of seats. There is also a hot dog stand offering actual hot dogs that greets arriving spectators. And floor-to-ceiling video images by Jared Mezzocchi surround the set on three sides, providing a vertiginous theme-park-style panorama in motion of Manhattan streets.

headline: Bookshelf | An Erotic Magazine for Voyeurs and Literati Alike
abstract: The new quarterly magazine Adult is jampacked with stylishly naughty content aimed at the smart set.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, the downtown set gathered in a photo studio in Chelsea to celebrate the introduction of a new “literary and erotic magazine” called Adult. Stepping off of the quiet street and into the large, vaulted space — barely decorated but stocked with an abundance of beer and bubbly, a few bowls filled with nostalgic Halloween candy like Dubble Bubble and standard issue lollipops, a couple of penis-shaped piñatas hanging next to a stage (where Kelela and Lauren Devine performed later in the night), and old-school pornography, projected onto a large white wall for the party’s duration — was like discovering a clandestine and slightly naughty affair, which is the same experience the founding editor Sarah Nicole Prickett wants you to have when opening her inaugural issue. “I wanted Adult to feel like a secret,” she said about the quarterly magazine, which will hit select newsstands, including Marc Jacobs’s bookstore, BookMarc, and the Museum of Modern Art, in mid-November. Despite the “Not for sale to minors” disclaimer on its cover, Prickett isn’t shy about hoping the young and curious find it, even if they have to steal it. “I want to go on the record as being very pro-minors,” she said. “I love teen girls. I wish I could have been one — I was awful at it. The best I can hope for is the feeling I had as a teen, which is that I couldn’t wait to get older. I want people to feel like that until they’re 70.”

abstract: Where are the public-spirited New Yorkers who would fight overblown development?

headline: Junior Varsity Is Where the Work Gets Done
abstract: How getting into the mind of a teenager changed the life of this grown-up writer.
lead_paragraph: Six years ago I published my second book, a novel for adults featuring a brutalized teenager and snappy conversation on yachts. After my commercial debut, I had museum-hush hopes that this follow-up… was… Literature. But in retrospect all I’d written was a strange, unwieldy novel, which my publisher quietly escorted out back to sink into the bog. It didn’t even go paperback, and my editor was always out to lunch when I’d call to ask why. A review summed the book’s prospects up in one word: “grim.”

headline: Texas: Deal Reached Over Claims That Company Misused Visas
abstract: Infosys was accused of misusing temporary visas to bring Indian technology workers to the United States, justice officials said.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Texas have reached a civil settlement with Infosys, an Indian outsourcing company, over charges that it misused temporary visas to bring Indian technology workers to the United States, justice officials said. In an investigation started in February 2011, prosecutors have examined whether Infosys systematically used short-term visitor visas to bring software programmers and technology engineers from India to work in American companies, instead of more costly H-1B visas, deceiving immigration authorities and undercutting wages for American workers.  Infosys has said it set aside $35 million for the settlement, which will be announced on Wednesday.

headline: A Bold Bid for Better Schools
abstract: One Western state’s proposed school overhaul has created a model patch of common ground. Will voters go for it?
lead_paragraph: If there’s a key to this nation’s sustained competitiveness, it’s education. And if there’s a key to the kind of social mobility that’s integral to our country’s cherished narrative, to its soul, it’s giving kids from all walks of life teachers and classrooms that beckon them toward excellence. But like all aspects of American policy making these days, the push to improve public schools bucks up against factionalism, pettiness, lobbies that won’t be muted and sacred cows that can’t be disturbed. Progress that needs to be sweeping is anything but.

headline: Aqueducts’ Defenders Volunteer to Fill Breach in Upkeep of Park
keywords: ['Volunteers and Community Service', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'AQUEDUCTS', 'Vandalism', 'Roman Civilization']
abstract: As budget cuts and vandalism have taken a toll on a park of Rome’s ancient aqueducts, volunteers have come forth to help, but they cannot completely fill the gap.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In their day, Rome’s aqueducts — 11 elevated pipelines that carried more than 3,400 gallons of water per second to the ancient capital — stood as the height of public administration, providing the “best water service in the ancient world and perhaps of any era,” in the words of one archaeologist, Filippo Coarelli.

headline: Stabbing Suspect Silent; Grieving Goes On
abstract: Mingdong Chen was charged with five counts of murder on Monday in the stabbing deaths of his cousin’s wife and her four young children in their Brooklyn home.
lead_paragraph: His dark hair spiked and his gaze fixed, Mingdong Chen appeared in a Brooklyn courtroom on Monday, saying nothing as he was charged with five counts of murder in the stabbing deaths of his cousin’s wife and her four young children. But the reverberations of the tragedy could be keenly heard in Sunset Park, by the family’s home and at an elementary school, suddenly confronted with the deaths of three of its students.

headline: Sandy’s Unfinished Business

lead_paragraph: A year ago Tuesday evening, Hurricane Sandy slammed into the Eastern Seaboard, destroying lives and homes and entire neighborhoods. On the first anniversary of the storm, politicians are busily touting what they’ve done since, while, at the same time, assiduously dodging legitimate complaints from people who are still suffering.

headline: Iran: Dispute with Azerbaijan Over Polo
abstract: Iran said that it would oppose attempts by Azerbaijan to officially register polo with the United Nations as a purely indigenous sport, arguing that polo is an international game.
lead_paragraph: Iran said Monday that it would oppose attempts by Azerbaijan to officially register polo with the United Nations as a purely indigenous sport, arguing that polo is an international game and Azerbaijan has no right to claim that it originated there. The official Islamic Republic News Agency quoted Mohammad-Ali Najafi, the head of Iran’s Cultural Heritage, Handicrafts and Tourism Organization, as saying in a letter to Unesco that “Iran strongly requests the rejection” of Azerbaijan’s application to register polo — which both nations call chogan — as an entry on the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity list. Iran, Afghanistan, Pakistan and India are among the countries that also have a claim on the game, the world’s oldest known competitive team sport, in which players on horseback use mallets to swat a ball through the opposing side’s goal posts. Unesco — the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization — will decide on Azerbaijan’s application during a meeting of its Intergovernmental Committee for the Safeguarding of the Intangible Cultural Heritage to be held in Baku, Azerbaijan, Dec. 2-7.

lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (13, 49) THE AFRICAN AMERICANS: MANY RIVERS TO CROSS Henry Louis Gates Jr., above, continues his exploration of African-American history in “The Age of Slavery (1800-1860),” which picks up with Eli Whitney’s cotton gin, the “second middle passage” and Nat Turner’s rebellion. “Mr. Gates — the Harvard professor, author and critic — is highly visible, interviewing historians, talking to older black Africans who acknowledge that their ancestors became wealthy through the slave trade, chatting with contemporary black Americans over Hoppin’ John and iced tea, standing at seemingly innocuous city intersections where shameful history unfolded,” Anita Gates wrote in The New York Times. “It is revelatory just how different a story sounds when it begins with ‘There, at the door, stood an enslaved man,’ rather than ‘a slave.’ ” In “The War of the Worlds,” at 9, “American Experience” revisits Orson Welles’s radio drama about an alien invasion on Oct. 30, 1938, and the hysteria it caused.

headline: Cracking the Apple Trap
abstract: Is it a coincidence when your iPhone stops working just as the new models come out?
lead_paragraph: At first, I thought it was my imagination. Around the time the iPhone 5S and 5C were released, in September, I noticed that my sad old iPhone 4 was becoming a lot more sluggish. The battery was starting to run down much faster, too. But the same thing seemed to be happening to a lot of people who, like me, swear by their Apple products. When I called tech analysts, they said that the new operating system (iOS 7) being pushed out to existing users was making older models unbearably slow. Apple phone batteries, which have a finite number of charges in them to begin with, were drained by the new software. So I could pay Apple $79 to replace the battery, or perhaps spend 20 bucks more for an iPhone 5C. It seemed like Apple was sending me a not-so-subtle message to upgrade.

headline: Are You Competent? Prove It.
abstract: College leaders say that by focusing on what people know, not how or when they learn it, and by tapping new technology, they can save students time and lower costs.
lead_paragraph: IN 1893, Charles Eliot, president of Harvard, introduced to the National Education Association a novel concept: the credit hour. Roughly equivalent to one hour of lecture time a week for a 12- to 14-week semester, it became the basic unit of a college education, and the standard measure for transferring work between institutions. To be accredited, universities have had to base curriculums on credit hours and years of study. The seat-time system — one based on the hours spent in the classroom — is further reinforced by Title IV student aid: to receive need-based Pell grants or federal loans, students have had to carry a certain load of credits each semester.

headline: In Performance: Kristen Sieh and Libby King of ‘RoosevElvis’

lead_paragraph: In the surreal new dramedy “RoosevElvis,” Ann (Libby King), a lesbian factory worker in South Dakota, channels the spirit of Elvis Presley to help her work up the courage to ask out Brenda (Kristen Sieh), a woman she meets online. But when their first date doesn’t go well, Ann imagines Brenda as Theodore Roosevelt as a way to keep her spirit close. In this scene, Elvis and Roosevelt introduce themselves. The show, directed by Rachel Chavkin and mounted by the theater collective the TEAM, is at the Bushwick Starr through Nov. 3.

headline: The Latest Style
abstract: On Monday we introduced a number of revisions and updates to the stylebook. After Deadline will highlight some of those changes over the next few weeks.
lead_paragraph: This week, we’ve introduced a number of updates and revisions to our in-house stylebook, The New York Times Manual of Style and Usage. The changes are mostly modest and don’t alter our goal of publishing clear, literate prose that is largely free of jargon, journalese, slang and sloppiness. But a lot has changed since 1999, when the stylebook was published. While we have updated many entries over the years, we thought it was time for a more systematic look. (For now, the updated style guide is available only to Times writers and editors. But we hope that the revised version may be published for general readers in the foreseeable future.)

headline: Responding to an Insurgent Attack on an Afghan Base
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: An Air Force officer remembers the horrors of the night 15 Taliban insurgents attacked an American base in Afghanistan. But the experience had an unexpected after-effect: the discovery of a mentor he had never met.
lead_paragraph: At around 10 p.m. on Sept. 14, 2012, 15 heavily armed insurgents penetrated the perimeter of Camp Bastion, a base in the Helmand Province of Afghanistan. Slipping through a hole in the wire, heavily armed and outfitted in American military uniforms, they wreaked havoc across the northeast flight line, killing two American Marines, wounding nine others, destroying six AV-8B Harrier jets and causing hundreds of millions of dollars in damage. One of the dead was the Harrier squadron’s commanding officer, Lt. Col. Christopher Raible, who died using only his 9mm handgun against five insurgents.

lead_paragraph: Situated just down the beach from Cannes, the storied Hôtel du Cap-Eden-Roc was originally conceived in the 19th century as a writers’ retreat before helping to transform the French Riviera from a sleepy, if well-appointed, backwater into the summertime playpen of the international jet set. Hemingway, Chagall and Picasso were all guests. Winston Churchill turned up, as did Marlene Dietrich, the Duke and Duchess of Windsor, and a honeymooning Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton. The palatial Cap d’Antibes hostelry even had something of a star turn itself, checking in under a pseudonym, as it were — the Hôtel des Étrangers — in “Tender Is the Night,” the work of F. headline: For Red-Cooked Beef, a Softly Fruity Wine
abstract: The spike of heat in this dish makes it one of the more difficult to pair with wine, but a well balanced zinfandel may go surprisingly well.
lead_paragraph: The spike of heat from the red chiles and the vivid, electric tingle of the Sichuan peppercorns make this red-cooked beef dish one of the more difficult to pair with wine. A softly fruity wine like a well-balanced zinfandel or Russian River Valley pinot noir may go surprisingly well, cushioning the jagged flavors and complementing the harmony of spices, provided they are not extravagantly alcoholic and are served slightly cool. As a sherry fanatic, I think oloroso, even with its high level of alcohol, around 20 percent, would pair beautifully. You might also try sweet wines, like a demi-sec Vouvray or an auslese riesling from the Mosel. These wines will be even better with 10 or 15 years of age.

abstract: The New York Times invites student actors and actresses to submit their performances of lines from “Hamlet” using Instagram.
lead_paragraph: “Brevity is the soul of wit,” declares Polonius in William Shakespeare’s “Hamlet.” And perhaps short videos of lines from one of the Bard’s most-loved plays will expose the souls of their performers, too. So The New York Times invites student actors and actresses to submit their performances of lines from “Hamlet” using Instagram.

headline: Revenue Slides at Martha Stewart Living, Partly From Curbing Ties to J.C. Penney
abstract: The company, which has hired Daniel W. Dienst as its next chief executive, had losses in broadcasting and publishing, where advertising revenue fell when it cut back its relationship with J. C. Penney.
lead_paragraph: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia posted troubling third-quarter results on Tuesday, largely because of losses in its publishing and broadcasting divisions. That was not surprising. What was unexpected was the company’s acknowledgment that its curtailed relationship with retailer J. C. Penney had significantly hurt advertising revenue of its magazines.

headline: French Interest Rates in the 1920s
abstract: It’s complicated.
lead_paragraph: Jeremie Cohen-Setton raises questions about the NBER series I used in the draft of my IMF Mundell-Fleming lecture. Fair enough; I’ve actually referenced the study he mentions in earlier work. I wish I understood it better. Still, that’s why I put the draft out there — comments, especially on historical data, are always welcome.

headline: How a Burned Out Owner Got Back Into the Game
abstract: At first, the founder of Parties That Cook was devastated by the way her employees responded.
lead_paragraph: Last week, we published a case study about a business owner who sought a better work/life balance in her early fifties by downshifting — cutting back on her hours and working two to three days a week from home. But then, two years closer to 60, Bibby Gignilliat, founder of Parties That Cook, a San Francisco company that offers cooking classes as employee-appreciation and corporate team-building events, had a change of heart. She had spent 14 years building her business to $2.2 million in revenue, but she knew she had more work to do if she ever wanted to sell the business.

headline: Syrians Flee What Some Called the ‘City of Death’
abstract: Of the many Syrians evacuating Moadhamiya in the latest civilian exodus from the Damascus suburb, some were reported to be weak and being transported on stretchers and in wheelchairs.
lead_paragraph: New video images show hundreds of civilians, balancing belongings on their heads, carrying children and assisting people using canes or wheelchairs, streaming out of the Damascus suburb of Moadhamiya, which had been blockaded for months by the government.

headline: College Painters to Face Off Onstage
abstract: A competition called ArtBattles U will invite student painters to compete at an event in the East Village, with the winners chosen by the audience.
lead_paragraph: The gladiatorial side of the art world is usually kept under wraps, in the jockeying for prominence among artists, gallery owners and curators. But ArtBattles U wants to get the sparring out in the open. The company, which specializes in finding opportunities for student artists to show their work, is presenting what it is calling a Live Art Battle — painters create works while audiences watch — on Nov. 14 in the Marlin Room at Webster Hall, the rock club on East 11th Street.

headline: Valium for Obamacare Worriers
abstract: A fairly robust program.
lead_paragraph: Suppose that healthcare.gov isn’t fixed by the end of next month. How bad is it for Obamacare? Would the program be doomed?

headline: N.S.A. Head Says European Data Was Collected by Allies
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Two top United States intelligence officials defended their operations on Capitol Hill amid growing criticism of the nation’s surveillance efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of the National Security Agency on Tuesday vigorously challenged recent reports that the United States had been gathering the phone records of millions of Europeans, saying that the records had in fact been turned over by allied spy services.

headline: Garlicky Chicken
abstract: Elevate pan-seared chicken thighs by adding anchovies, capers, garlic and plenty of lemon. Melissa Clark shows how.
lead_paragraph: Elevate pan-seared chicken thighs by adding anchovies, capers, garlic and plenty of lemon. Melissa Clark shows how.

headline: Business-Conservative Alliance Presses for Immigration Action
abstract: A group of more than 600 leaders from roughly 40 states descended on the Capitol, taking aim at House Republicans who they think could support broad legislation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For the business group from Utah, the lobbying blitz started well before their plane touched down in the nation’s capital.

headline: The Gun Report: October 29, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: * Every year in America, 500 children and teenagers die, and an estimated 7,500 kids are hospitalized, from gun violence, according to findings presented at an American Academy of Pediatrics conference held in Orlando, Fla., last weekend. The study found that handguns account for the majority of childhood gunshot wounds, and states with higher percentages of household firearm ownership have higher proportions of firearm injuries among children.

headline: Mariel Hemingway, Beyond ‘Manhattan’
abstract: Bet you didn’t realize how many films she has appeared in.
lead_paragraph: Many know Mariel Hemingway from her role in Woody Allen’s 1979 movie, “Manhattan,” in which she played Allen’s sensitive and precocious 17-year-old girlfriend. Some of her other work in films and TV seems to be less familiar. One online commenter, responding to Amanda Fortini’s article in this past weekend’s magazine, wondered how Hemingway could afford her lifestyle, which includes a home in Malibu on a 1.5-acre ranch with organic vegetable beds, a climbing wall and at least one horse: “The math doesn’t add up. She hasn’t had a real film career in thirty years.” In fact, she has appeared in quite a few films and TV shows, including one of the ”Superman” sequels and an episode of the sitcom “Roseanne.” Here are some of the highlights.

headline: Street Style: Blazer
abstract: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Oct. 21.
lead_paragraph: The best of readers’ photos from the week of Oct. 21.

headline: Anchovies Elevate a Pan-Seared Chicken Dish
abstract: What was once timid and a little dull turns vibrant, tangy and impossible to stop eating when you add anchovies, capers and lemon.
lead_paragraph: What’s for Dinner? answers that universal question, offering recipes for simple, relatively quick dishes that use ingredients you can pick up on the way home.

headline: Pan de Muerto Is Bread That Gets Into the Spirit
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Bread', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Mexican-Americans']
abstract: On the Mexican holiday meant to honor the dead, Día de los Muertos, or Day of the Dead, this treat is in demand.
lead_paragraph: Over the next few days, space will grow increasingly tight at the Guadalupana Bakery in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. The counters are piled high with displays of colorful breads in the shapes of skulls or figures in repose, and customers are coming in droves to buy special pan de muerto, or bread of the dead, some of them 10 loaves at a time.

headline: Documentary Association Announces Awards Nominations
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Dominating the feature film nominations were documentaries about issues and politics.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Issues and politics mostly ruled, as the International Documentary Association on Tuesday announced its nominees for its annual documentary awards. In the feature film category, nominations went to “The Act of Killing,” about Indonesian genocide; “Blackfish,” about orca whales in captivity; “Let the Fire Burn,” about a 1985 standoff between police and activists in Philadelphia; and “The Square,” about Egyptians struggling for social change. Those were joined by one very personal story, Sarah Polley’s “Stories We Tell,” about her discovery of a family secret that surrounded her own birth. The association also announced nominees for short films, television documentaries, and entries in other categories. The awards are to be presented at a ceremony in Los Angeles on Dec. 6.

headline: Egyptian Jihadists Cite Zawahiri in Video Claiming Responsibility for Cairo Attack
abstract: A video released by militants who claimed responsibility for an attack on the country’s interior minister included footage of Ayman al-Zawahiri, the Egyptian leader of Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: As our colleagues David Kirkpatrick and Mayy El Sheikh reported from Cairo, a little-known Islamist militant group claimed responsibility for a failed attempt to assassinate Egypt’s interior minister last month, in a slickly produced video message posted online Saturday.

headline: Target Bans the Box
abstract: The retailer will remove questions about criminal history from its job applications throughout the nation.
lead_paragraph: Sanctions that make it more difficult for ex-offenders to obtain jobs, housing and even basic documents like drivers’ licenses only serve to drive them back to jail. With that in mind, a growing number of states and municipalities now prohibit public agencies — and in some cases private employers — from asking about a job applicant’s criminal history until the applicant reaches the interview stage or gets a conditional job offer. These eminently sensible “ban the box” laws are intended to let ex-offenders prove their qualifications before criminal history issues enter the equation.

headline: Top British Official in Ulster Is Target of a Letter Bomb
abstract: The parcel, which was defused and caused no injuries, was the fourth letter bomb sent to Northern Ireland authorities in the past week.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — A letter bomb was sent to Britain’s top official in Northern Ireland on Tuesday, forcing an evacuation at the sprawling estate near Belfast that houses the offices of the province’s political leaders until the parcel was defused by the British Army. It was the fourth letter bomb mailed to a high-profile figure in Northern Ireland over the past week.

headline: Reese Accepts Some Blame and Expresses Some Hope
abstract: General Manager Jerry Reese did not attempt to deflect the criticism leveled at him after an 0-6 start, but he tried to emphasize that the Giants were still in the chase for the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Giants General Manager Jerry Reese has customarily waited until the team’s bye week to speak with reporters, a policy that went unchallenged for years because the team typically did not start seasons with mortifying losing streaks.

headline: The New Sushi Chef
abstract: At various spots in New York City, fish-and-rice specialists in their 20s and 30s have been making their own mark.
lead_paragraph: At various spots in New York City, fish-and-rice specialists in their 20s and 30s have been making their own mark.

headline: Sushi’s New Vanguard
abstract: All over New York, a more adventurous attitude awaits.
lead_paragraph: If you’re expecting all the whispery delicacy of a haiku at New York Sushi Ko on the Lower East Side, you may be a tad taken aback when John Daley grabs the blowtorch.

headline: Ahead of I.P.O., Twitter Alters Feed to Add Images
abstract: The change could increase user numbers, and also help the company sell more visual ads.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter has gone visual.

headline: Vertical Living: Exploring Identity, Social Class and Global Change Through the Highrise
abstract: In this lesson, students explore the interactive Op-Doc “A Short History of the Highrise” to learn 2,500 years of history through images, verse and interactives and use it as a jumping-off point for inquiry and discussion.
lead_paragraph: Overview | How can thinking about where and how people live be a window into issues of identity, social class and global change? In this lesson, students explore the interactive Op-Doc “A Short History of the Highrise” to learn 2,500 years of history through images, verse and graphics and use it as a jumping-off point for inquiry and discussion. Finally, they can choose to take the project further by focusing on a range of related ideas, from Chinese urbanization to New York City affordable housing to students’ own neighborhoods.Materials | Computers with Internet connection (high-speed Internet is necessary for some of the interactive features mentioned in this lesson)

headline: It’s Autumn, Time to Check Flexible Spending Accounts
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Flexible spending accounts allow you to set aside pretax money for medical expenses, but you lose the money if it is not spent by the annual deadline.
lead_paragraph: AS the end of the year approaches, it’s a good time to check if you have a balance remaining in your health care flexible spending account.

headline: On Monday Night, World Series Tops N.F.L.
abstract: Game 5 of the Red Sox-Cardinals World Series on Monday drew a local television rating four times as large as the Rams-Seahawks N.F.L. game played nearby.
lead_paragraph: Baseball, which often plays second fiddle to football in television ratings, found something to smile about Monday night when Game 5 of the Boston Red Sox-St. Louis Cardinals World Series faced off against the Seattle Seahawks-St. Louis Rams N.F.L. game.

headline: Fairfield Beach: Buildings Rise; Values Stay Put
abstract: A year after Sandy, property values seem to have remained unaffected, but new building codes have changed the look of some homes.
lead_paragraph: If it’s dangerous for a house to be close to the water, plenty of places in Fairfield Beach seem to be asking for trouble.

headline: AMC Orders a Fifth Season of ‘The Walking Dead’
abstract: The zombie apocalypse drama is more popular than anything else on AMC.
lead_paragraph: “The Walking Dead,” the zombie apocalypse drama that is more popular than anything else on AMC (and most other channels, for that matter), will continue for at least a fifth season, the channel said on Tuesday.

headline: Listen Up | Cass McCombs and His Vagabond World
abstract: The singer-songwriter’s latest album, which includes a track recorded with the actress Karen Black before her death, is a rebuke against the very concept of an album.
lead_paragraph: Aeon of Aquarius Blues (Alternate Take)

headline: New Confections, Coconut Chips and More
abstract: Recommendations for the week of Oct. 29.
lead_paragraph: To Indulge: The Next Sweet Treat, From Paris to New York

headline: ‘Sightseeing at 26.2 Miles at a Time’
abstract: Thom Gilligan, a tour company founder, on the allure of marathons in destinations both familiar and exotic.
lead_paragraph: Among the throngs of runners crossing the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge on Sunday for the New York City Marathon, a fair number of them will travel not to Boston for their next race, but to lesser-known, far-flung destinations like Napa Valley, Mont-St.-Michel, France, even the savanna of South Africa.

headline: Hotel Review: The Marker Hotel in Dublin
abstract: This luxury property, which opened in April, is part of a vibrant new commercial district in the city’s docklands.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Lievito Madre al Mare in Naples, Italy
abstract: A member of a pizza-baking Neapolitan clan opens his newest venture just yards from the Bay of Naples, pairing pies with sprawling views.
lead_paragraph: Pizza-making runs deep in the Sorbillo family DNA: dozens of members of this Neapolitan clan have become renowned pizzaioli in their home city and beyond. Perhaps the best known is Gino Sorbillo, a 39-year-old business school graduate whose father was one of 21 pizza-baking siblings.

headline: Syria Fires Official Who Tried to Broker Peace
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Qadri Jamil, a deputy prime minister who met with American and Russian officials about peace talks to end Syria’s war, was dismissed for not coordinating such meetings with the government.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government on Tuesday fired a deputy prime minister who has lately been its most outspoken voice in favor of reform and who recently held meetings with American and Russian officials about peace talks that world leaders are trying to arrange to end Syria’s civil war.

headline: King Cole Bar & Salon Opening
abstract: The bar is set to reopen with its restored Maxfield Parrish mural and a new menu at its adjoining restaurant, the Salon; and more restaurant openings.
lead_paragraph: Headliner

headline: Built With a Loudspeaker in Mind
abstract: Bowers & Wilkins, a company known for its hi-fi speakers, rounded out its roster of luxury headphones with the P7.
lead_paragraph: Primarily known for making hi-fi speakers for audio studios and luxury hotels, the British company Bowers & Wilkins recently turned its expertise to headphones. The company quickly built a high-quality lineup, and rounding out the roster is the P7, its first over-ear headphones.

headline: A Hobbyist Plants Seeds of Bluegrass on 7th Ave.
abstract: The country star Alan Jackson played the songs of his new bluegrass album in Carnegie Hall on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The pop star quest for seriousness has checkpoints: Make an album in a well-aged, roots-oriented genre that’s miles away from your native sound. Collaborate with people far more gifted but far less renowned. Play a room that confers authority on the cheap. Be humble while never getting off the mount.

headline: Hearth
abstract: Inside the restaurant that, approaching its 10th anniversary, has remained true to its vision.
lead_paragraph: Inside the restaurant that, approaching its 10th anniversary, has remained true to its vision.

headline: Pictures of the Day: China and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from China, Malta, Afghanistan and New York.
lead_paragraph: Photos from China, Malta, Afghanistan and New York.

headline: With Season at Hand, Knicks’ Defense Remains a Work in Progress
abstract: Coach Mike Woodson said the team’s defense was not where he wanted it to be heading into Wednesday’s season opener against the Milwaukee Bucks at Madison Square Garden.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Metta World Peace went through a series of majors when he was a student at St. John’s. He initially wanted to study architecture so he could learn to build community centers, but he was disappointed to discover that too many of his classes clashed with basketball practice.

headline: A Chef Remains True to His Vision
abstract: Hearth relies on its strengths, not the latest fad.
lead_paragraph: Reading the opening lines of Hearth’s last review in The Times, published in 2004, is like strolling among the headstones in New York’s vast restaurant graveyard. The critic at the time, Amanda Hesser, observed that one-word names had become fashionable, and gave recent examples:

headline: Trying to Outrun the Cardinals’ Long Reach
abstract: KMOX, the powerful St. Louis radio station, has been broadcasting Cardinals baseball to Middle America since 1926, but could a reporter outdrive its signal?
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — About 7 p.m. Central on Wednesday, a voice will declare on a radio wave transmitted at 1120 kilohertz, “This is KMOX, the voice of St. Louis,” and millions of homes from Denver to Alabama and Louisiana to North Dakota will be able to hear Game 6 of the World Series come to life on an AM radio.

headline: Trepidation and Restrictions Leave Crowdfunding Rules Weak
abstract: Crowdfunding has great potential for fraud, but the S.E.C.’s proposed rules for this investment model do little to protect investors.
lead_paragraph: Crowdfunding is becoming a reality, but the question is whether it will thrive or become largely a vehicle for fraud.

headline: Ensconced in Luxury, as Terror Pays a Visit
abstract: “The Siege” is a ticktock account of the attack on the Taj Mahal Palace Hotel, in which 33 people were killed, during a terrorist attack in Mumbai in 2008.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of Nov. 26, 2008, as heavily armed Pakistani terrorists raced to infiltrate the five-star Taj Mahal Palace Hotel and other tourist sites in Mumbai in a spectacular coordinated attack, the hotel’s executive chef, Hemant Oberoi, feared he was falling behind.

headline: Share Your Views for Veterans Day
abstract: Our colleagues at Home Fires invite veterans, or friends or relatives of someone who served in the military, to share recollections, photographs and messages for a post on Veterans Day, Nov. 11, 2013.
lead_paragraph: Our colleagues at Home Fires invite veterans, or friends or relatives of someone who served in the military, to share recollections, photographs and messages for a post on Veterans Day, Nov. 11, 2013.

headline: Yearning for Tenderness, and More, in a Vale of Cynicism
abstract: “In the Name Of,” directed by Malgoska Szumowska, focuses on a Polish priest transferred to the countryside who struggles with his longing for a local teenager.
lead_paragraph: Bathing everyday cruelties in an ethereal, golden light, Malgoska Szumowska’s “In the Name Of” maximizes the tension between harsh content and softly seductive presentation. This dissonance between sight and sound is only one of the many contrasts that define this contemplative study of a young priest whose repressed desires threaten to derail his chosen vocation.

lead_paragraph: Sounds Like Somewhere

lead_paragraph: Nothing But Time

headline: Does It Say ‘Arrgh’ When You Make a Kill?
abstract: The newest entry in the Assassin’s Creed game series, Black Flag, explores 18th-century pirate life in the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: The pirate adventure Assassin’s Creed IV: Black Flag is nearly as long and almost as beautiful as an actual vacation to the tropics.

headline: Ackman Sees Expansion of Activist Investing to Europe
abstract: In a speech at the University of Oxford, William A. Ackman also spoke about his investments in J.C. Penney and his bet against Herbalife.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 11:40 a.m. |

headline: Today’s Scuttlebot: How Glass Magnifies Desire, and Motorola Channels Pixar
abstract: Tuesday’s highlights from around the Web include an argument for how glass, from Google’s with a capital “G” to the kind in your car’s windshield, is no longer something we just look through, but something we increasingly want to interact with and have look back at us. Plus, a tale of how Google-owned Motorola is tackling storytelling on smartphones by taking a page out of Pixar’s playbook.
lead_paragraph: Every day, The New York Times’s staff scours the Web for interesting and peculiar items.

headline: Fantasy Football Week 9: Mining for Waiver Wire Gold
abstract: Andy Dalton, fantasy football’s sixth-best quarterback, is still owned in less than half of fantasy football leagues.
lead_paragraph: After two weeks of injury decimation, fantasy owners somehow managed to escape relatively unscathed in Week 8. As we start moving toward the tail end of bye weeks, waiver wires are getting barren, so you have to dig deep to find those waiver gems.

headline: Artists on Artists | Will Cotton on the Elegant Iraq War Watercolors of Steve Mumford
abstract: Though their subjects couldn’t be more different — Cotton paints candy-colored dreamscapes, Mumford, war zones — the two men have long had a close kinship.
lead_paragraph: The name Will Cotton immediately brings to mind images of gorgeous nudes cavorting in fantasy landscapes made of sugarplums and candy canes. The painter’s current show at New York’s Pace Prints (through Nov. 16) is a case in point: it features prints of women wearing garments bedazzled with sweets and petit fours (in some cases hand-painted over lithographs), as well as crazily towering stacks of cakes built from pastel-colored paper pulp. In December, the French patissière Ladurée will introduce a limited-edition ginger whipped cream macaroon that Cotton dreamed up, housed in a box decorated with his painting of a woman wearing only whipped cream.

headline: Like a Blizzard of Dance Fragments
abstract: Boris Charmatz’s “Flip Book,” an ever-evolving piece inspired by a book of images of Merce Cunningham’s dance works, is to be presented Friday through Sunday at MoMA.
lead_paragraph: It was an ordinary Christmas and an ordinary gift. A few years ago, the French choreographer Boris Charmatz unwrapped a hardcover book about Merce Cunningham, a present from his father. His heart sank. A book about Cunningham might have excited him when he was 13, but now?

headline: Beijing Police Strive to Save Women From Driving ‘Mistakes’
abstract: Not all women are grateful for tips helpfully offered to a category of driver deemed prone to panic, lacking a sense of direction and never switching gears.
lead_paragraph: The Beijing police have helpfully offered women an online lecture on driving. Under the rubric “Women Drivers Please Take Care to Avoid These Mistakes,” the Beijing Municipal Public Security Bureau generously listed tips on its official Sina Weibo page on Tuesday for confused women who somehow find themselves behind the wheel.

headline: Making Silly Showdowns for YouTube
abstract: Epic Rap Battles of History, which just began its third season on YouTube, hopes to hold onto viewers by presenting a new segment every other week.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On a recent evening, Peter Shukoff and Lloyd Ahlquist, two breakout stars of the YouTube era, were trying, very seriously, to look like teenage girls from 2006: long hair, pink headbands, embroidered jeans.

headline: A Choreographer Wrestles With Wartime Tragedies
abstract: A dance by Robin Becker commemorates two simultaneous events from 1967.
lead_paragraph: During the same two days in October 1967, an American battalion, ambushed in Vietnam, lost some 60 men, and an antiwar protest at the University of Wisconsin-Madison was met with violent police force. This juxtaposition of events is the subject and structure of “They Marched Into Sunlight,” an acclaimed 2003 book by David Maraniss. That book, in turn, has inspired “Into Sunlight,” a dance by Robin Becker that had its New York debut this weekend at Gould Hall at the French Institute Alliance Française.

headline: For ‘SNL’ Cast, Being Diverse May Be Better Than Being ‘Ready’
keywords: ['Television', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: For a show of topical parody rooted in politics and mass culture, diversity is a question not just of fairness, but of art.
lead_paragraph: One decade after “Saturday Night Live” began in 1975, it added the first black woman to its primary cast. Danitra Vance, a gifted downtown actress and Second City veteran, lasted just one season.

headline: Ghoulish Mirror Images, Young and Older, Live and on Screen
abstract: A younger woman, her older alter ego on video and a live score, all conceived by Michel van der Aa, at the Lincoln Center White Light Festival.
lead_paragraph: No matter how closely images on screen might reflect a score and vice versa, sound, live performers and film are invariably separate entities in most multimedia works. But a remarkable intertwining occurs in the chilling “Up-close,” a film-noir cello concerto by the Dutch composer and filmmaker Michel van der Aa. On Monday evening in the Manhattan Center’s ornate Grand Ballroom, Lincoln Center’s White Light Festival presented the American premiere of this 2010 work, which won the prestigious Grawemeyer Award for Music Composition for 2013.

headline: Delayed Gratification for Maker of Grand Theft Auto
abstract: Take-Two Interactive Software, the games publisher behind Grand Theft Auto V, had to delay its recognition of sales from the blockbuster title because of accounting rules.
lead_paragraph: When your company has one of the best-selling products in the history of your industry, it must be mildly annoying to delay the booking of the sales bonanza because of an accounting quirk.

headline: Faces of Foster Care
abstract: Students at U.C.L.A. and Los Angeles City College who have beaten the odds.
lead_paragraph: Students at U.C.L.A. and Los Angeles City College who have beaten the odds.

headline: Where the Wild Things Are (at Home)
abstract: While photographing pagan beasts, “Star Wars” characters, knights and aliens, Klaus Pichler plumbed his subjects’ imaginations to make portraits of them sitting around at home.
lead_paragraph: While photographing pagan beasts, “Star Wars” characters, knights and aliens, Klaus Pichler plumbed his subjects’ imaginations to make portraits of them sitting around at home.

headline: Good-for-You Motorcycles That Can Move You
abstract: In a quest for younger riders, Honda and other manufacturers are building cheaper, more practical motorcycles with the look and handling of more expensive models.
lead_paragraph: HOW can you sell motorcycles when people are more worried about losing their jobs than how they will look on the latest Harley? How do you keep assembly lines humming when the baby boomers who have sustained the motorcycle business since the ’70s are now pushing 70?

headline: From China to Los Angeles, Taking the Electric Bus
abstract: China-based BYD has contracts to provide electric buses, built at its plant in Southern California, to transit agencies in Los Angeles and Long Beach.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — THERE’S a newcomer to this city’s auto row. Compared to the shiny showrooms displaying the latest Mercedeses and Toyotas, the Chinese carmaker BYD’s outpost in the shadow of downtown skyscrapers looks rather forlorn.

headline: Image of Hindenburg Haunts Hydrogen Technology
abstract: One of the strongest psychological impediments to hydrogen fuel cell technology is the searing image of the Hindenburg catching fire and crashing in 1937.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Rebecca Markillie of ITM Power  in Sheffield, England, attends trade shows to promote her company’s ambitious plan to build hydrogen fueling stations for cars in Britain, she sometimes must calm skittish consumers. “You get people saying, ‘Oh, no: hydrogen. That is dangerous,’ ” she said. “And you go, ‘Well, why do you say that?’ And straightaway, the only knowledge of hydrogen would be the Hindenburg.”

headline: A Woman’s Touch, Still a Rarity in Car Design
abstract: Women make up more than half of American drivers and are a major force in car-buying decisions, but they are underrepresented in the design of new cars.
lead_paragraph: FOR Monika Zych and Sandy McGill, becoming car designers for BMW started with Matchbox toy cars, racing the tiny replicas around the living room as little girls.

headline: A Concept Goes From Paper Sketch to Metal Reality
abstract: Long before it went public, when it was still only a designer’s sketch, the Cadillac Elmiraj had to win over General Motors executives.
lead_paragraph: “YOU can lie to yourself quite easily in a sketch,” said Niki Smart, a designer at the General Motors Advanced Design studio in North Hollywood, Calif., who makes dozens of sketches a day.

headline: 100 Years Down the Line
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Automakers like Ford are finding that building multiple models on an updated, ever-evolving line is integral to success in the global marketplace.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — THE moving assembly line was the simplest of inventions, born of necessity to meet the exploding demand for automobiles in America in the early 20th century.

headline: Natural Gas Waits for Its Moment
abstract: With natural gas plentiful and cheap in the United States, its market share as a vehicle fuel may be ready to rise substantially.
lead_paragraph: CARS and trucks powered by natural gas make up a significant portion of the vehicle fleet in many parts of the world. Iran has more than two million natural gas vehicles on the road. As of 2009, Argentina had more than 1.8 million in operation and almost 2,000 natural gas filling stations. Brazil was not far behind. Italy and Germany have substantial natural gas vehicle fleets. Is America next?

headline: 18 and Talented, a Racecar Driver Is Open to Logos
abstract: Sage Karam’s racing pedigree is in location only. He grew up near Mario Andretti in Nazareth, Pa., and is determined to prove one does not need to be rich to be successful.
lead_paragraph: NAZARETH, PA. — JODY AND KAREN KARAM built a home on a lot that sits on a hill next to a cornfield in a subdivision outside this town. But before that, Jody raked out a track on the land for his 4-year-old son, Sage, to learn how to race a go-cart. That was many laps and many trophies ago.

headline: Hail to the Minivan, Dowdy but Not Out
abstract: Although surging sales for the minivan are a distant memory — Americans bought 1.37 million in 2000 — the vehicle has found its niche.
lead_paragraph: THE minivan was a cliché almost from the moment the first Dodge Caravan rolled off Chrysler’s assembly line in 1983. It was the boxy family hauler aimed at harried soccer moms, a symbol of the soul-crushing conformity that was the price Americans paid for suburban comfort.

headline: Dreamworks Animation Profit Falls, Though Shares Stay Strong

headline: Morocco in a Bottle
abstract: Made with a blend of natural oils, the new body serum from the New York skin care line Kahina Giving Beauty has a scent that's intended to transport its wearer straight to Fez.
lead_paragraph: Pure argan oil, responsibly sourced from Morocco, is the key ingredient in all of the products made by the New York organic skin care line Kahina Giving Beauty, founded five years ago by Katharine L’Heureux. The brand’s signature product, a bottle of 100 percent organic argan oil, works as well on the face and body as it does on hair, soothing dryness and replenishing moisture. But for Kahina’s first body serum, L’Heureux combined a lightweight argan oil base with 16 other oils, from watermelon and coconut to cumin and clove, to “create this more luxurious spreadable texture,” she said. It’s also the brand’s first scented product. The aroma is called Fez. Putting it on is a warm, sensory experience meant to transport the wearer to the Moroccan city, one of L’Heureux’s favorite places. “I wanted something evocative of that multilayered city that combines spirituality with all the scents of the spice market and the souk and the floral notes that happen in the spring, when the orange flower blossoms are just spilling through the streets,” L’Heureux explained. “I’ve never personally been a big scent person, but I love the idea of evoking places.” She plans to introduce additional products with the same spicy scent. $98; givingbeauty.com.
