headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 1:15 A.M. (TCM) THE CONVERSATION (1974) Gene Hackman, above, plays Harry Caul, a surveillance expert and paranoid loner who has been hired to eavesdrop on a married woman (Cindy Williams) and her lover (Frederic Forrest) by her suspicious husband, known as the Director (Robert Duvall). (A young Harrison Ford portrays the Director’s assistant.) But three people have already died because of Harry’s work, and now he’s worried that two more may soon lose their lives. The movie, written and directed by Francis Ford Coppola, received three Oscar nominations, including for best picture and best original screenplay. In the same awards season, his film “The Godfather: Part II” won for best director, best picture and best adapted screenplay. Writing in The New York Times, Vincent Canby called “The Conversation” haunting and bothersome: “Haunting because its suggestion that technology has gotten out of hand, though not exactly new, is so convincingly and fastidiously detailed. It’s bothersome because Mr. Coppola, the writer as well as the director, has nearly succeeded in making a great film but has, instead, made one that is merely very good.” Worth a listen: David Shire’s evocative score for solo piano.

headline: Kenya: Soldiers Punished Over Looting
abstract: The Kenyan military said Tuesday that it dismissed and jailed two soldiers for looting from the Westgate mall in Nairobi last month, as security forces fought off armed militants.
lead_paragraph: The Kenyan military said Tuesday that it dismissed and jailed two soldiers for looting from the Westgate mall in Nairobi last month, as security forces fought off armed militants. A spokesman said that allegations of looting by forces had prompted an internal investigation, and that two soldiers had been identified with cellphones and cameras that the army said had been stolen from the mall as security forces secured the building. Another soldier is under investigation. The Westgate mall was attacked by militants claiming to be from the Shabab, an Islamic extremist group in Somalia, on Sept. 21. Security forces spent four days securing the mall. Shop owners said that myriad merchandise was looted from the mall between the day of the attack and when shop owners were allowed back, one week later.

The location, currently home to an auto repair shop, a construction firm, a warehouse and a deli, was once used by the Wolff-Alport Chemical Company, which sold thorium to the federal government for research on atomic bombs.

headline: North Korea: Work Seen at Missile Site
keywords: ['Satellites', 'Embargoes and Economic Sanctions', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems']
abstract: Commercial satellite imagery taken a few weeks ago suggests that North Korea is upgrading its main launch facility with the possible intention of handling both larger and more mobile missiles, a Washington-based research institute that monitors the country said.
lead_paragraph: Commercial satellite imagery taken a few weeks ago suggests that North Korea is upgrading its main launch facility with the possible intention of handling both larger and more mobile missiles, a Washington-based research institute that monitors the country said Tuesday. In a report posted on its website, 38 North, the U.S.-Korea Institute at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies said the new construction at the Sohae Satellite Launching Station in North Korea suggested it may become “the main, and perhaps sole, test facility in the future.” The report was the institute’s second in less than a week that utilized satellite imagery to suggest North Korea is proceeding with proliferation activities that have been banned by the United Nations Security Council, which has imposed severe sanctions on the country in response.

headline: Egypt: Inquiry Opened Into Satirist
abstract: The country’s general prosecutor opened an investigation into Bassem Youssef stemming from citizen complaints including that he had insulted the military on his popular weekly television show, state news media reported.
lead_paragraph: The country’s general prosecutor on Tuesday opened an investigation into Bassem Youssef, an Egyptian satirist, stemming from citizen complaints including that Mr. Youssef had insulted the military on his popular weekly television show, state news media reported. On Friday, the program returned to the air for the first time since the military ousted President Mohamed Morsi in July, in a test of the boundaries of free speech under the new military-backed government. The new complaints, which include broadcasting false statements and “portraying Egypt as a promiscuous woman,” have yet to result in any formal charges.

headline: France: Hostages in Niger Are Freed
abstract: The four French hostages who were kidnapped three years ago in Niger by Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb have been released, President François Hollande of France said.
lead_paragraph: The four French hostages who were kidnapped three years ago in Niger by Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb have been released, President François Hollande of France said Tuesday. Mr. Hollande did not describe the conditions of the release of the hostages — Daniel Larribe, Pierre Legrand, Thierry Dol and Marc Féret — who were working for the French nuclear giant Areva, and Sogea-Satom, a subsidiary of the French construction group Vinci in Arlit, in northern Niger, when they were kidnapped in September 2010. Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb claimed responsibility and later posted videos showing that the men were alive. They were believed to have been kidnapped by Abu Zeid, the militant group’s deputy commander, who was killed in an airstrike in Mali this year.

headline: Russia: New Indictment for Navalny
abstract: Russia’s Investigative Committee said Tuesday that it had completed a new indictment of Aleksei A. Navalny, the country’s most prominent opposition leader.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s Investigative Committee said Tuesday that it had completed a new indictment of Aleksei A. Navalny, the country’s most prominent opposition leader. The indictment charged him and his brother with embezzlement and money laundering, this time involving a commercial cosmetics contract worth nearly $1 million. The new charges came only two weeks after a judge suspended a five-year sentence in a previous conviction that had widely been denounced as politically motivated, allowing him to remain free though with his political future in doubt. Mr. Navalny denounced the indictment as an expected, though baseless effort to maintain pressure on him after his strong showing in the Moscow mayoral election in September.

By Wednesday morning, hours after it had begun to go viral, the photo had landed on the front page of The Beijing News.

headline: Argentina: Court Loss for Media Group
abstract: After four years of combat between the government and Argentina’s biggest media conglomerate, Supreme Court judges declared constitutional a law that forces media companies to shrink their broadcast divisions.
lead_paragraph: After four years of combat between the government and Argentina’s biggest media conglomerate, the Clarín group, Supreme Court judges declared constitutional on Tuesday a law that forces media companies to shrink their broadcast divisions. The law, which was passed in 2009, has not been fully put in effect because of Clarín’s challenges in the courts. But the ruling means the group must immediately start the process to divest itself of assets, according to Martín Sabbatella, president of the government agency enforcing the law. The ruling concluded that the law “favors freedom of speech by limiting market concentration.”

headline: The President Wants You to Get Rich on Obamacare
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The crusade to sign up Americans is getting all the attention. But behind the scenes, investors are seeing dollar signs.
lead_paragraph: Tom Scully bolted through the doors and up the stairs to a private dining room on the third floor of the “21” Club. Scully, 56, is slightly taller than average and has tousled graying hair, an athletic build and a lopsided smile. He typically projects a combination of confidence and bemusement, but on this rainy September afternoon, he was frenzied. Scully was scheduled to deliver the keynote address at an event hosted by the Potomac Research Group, a Beltway firm that advises large investors on government policy (tag line: “Washington to Wall Street”). Today’s discussion centered on the most significant change in decades to the nation’s health care policy, the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, a.k.a. Obamacare. As Scully walked to the front of the room, some 50 managers from hedge funds, mutual funds and private equity firms tucked into the round tables. Others gathered in the hallway. A hush of anticipation hung in the air.

headline: Israel Gets a Mixed Message on American Jews
keywords: ['Americans Abroad', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Marriages', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States International Relations', 'Zionism']
abstract: Strong support for Zionism continues, as assimilation of American Jews increases.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Pew Research Center released a comprehensive and nuanced study on Oct. 1 about the character of the American Jewish community. The reaction here was typical Israeli apprehension about Jews’ place in the world, mixed with a general sense of confusion over how to interpret the results. Most discussions focused on two aspects: The high percentage of interfaith marriages and the vast support among American Jews for Israel.Fifty-eight percent of Jews who married between 2005 and 2013 have a non-Jewish spouse. Mixed marriages inevitably lead to the assimilation of Jews into American culture, and tap long-standing Israeli fears over the future of the Jewish people. To some Israelis given to these worries, assimilation is tantamount to accepting annihilation.

headline: Strips and Stones
abstract: “Art Spiegelman’s Co-Mix: A Retrospective” opens this week at the Jewish Museum.
lead_paragraph: It’s no accident that Art Spiegelman’s drawings of himself almost always show a butt hanging off his lower lip. Mr. Spiegelman, now 65, smokes the same way he does everything else — with feeling and with urgency. In his SoHo studio not long ago, he lit up a Camel while fretting about how he was going survive without tobacco on a 20-hour flight to Australia in a couple of days. He puffed on another while talking about the exhibition of his work that opens next Friday at the Jewish Museum. headline: Rentiers, Entitlement, and Monetary Policy

He is, of course, not alone — it has actually been amazing how wide a variety of reasons people in or close to the financial industry have come up for tight money in an economy that seems to need to opposite. Many of the people making these arguments started with dire warnings about runaway inflation; but when inflation failed to materialize, they didn’t change their policy views, they came up with new rationales for doing exactly the same thing.

headline: Painting Freedom
abstract: The many levels of meaning in Eastman Johnson’s great emancipation work, “The Lord Is My Shepherd.”
lead_paragraph: Sometime in the early fall of 1863, the artist Eastman Johnson composed a small work that he titled “The Lord Is My Shepherd.” At first glance, the image seems to posit the gentle nature of a formerly enslaved man reading the Psalms as a model of emerging humanity and citizenship. Johnson’s warm, sepia-toned brushwork provides little detail in the architecture of the setting. The young black man sits on a folding stool with a canvas seat, absorbed in the book he holds in his powerful hand; a dark blue coat lined in scarlet is draped over the back of the chair, possibly hinting that he has served in the Union Army. Wide wooden planks mark the transition from hearth to floorboards, sketching out a crude dwelling.

headline: Filly Can Add to Storybook Rise at Breeders’ Cup
abstract: Princess of Sylmar, a 3-year-old filly with humble beginnings, is a favorite to win the Breeders’ Cup Distaff on Friday and is a candidate for horse of the year.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — Princess of Sylmar’s pedigree changed with one well-placed kick, and her roots were not promising to begin with. She was born at Sylmar Farm in Pennsylvania, a state that is not known for producing high-caliber thoroughbreds. She made an inauspicious debut last October, when she took fourth at Penn National Race Course, off the beaten path in central Pennsylvania.

headline: Borscht Belt Republicans
abstract: But the joke may be on us.
lead_paragraph: Has anyone else noticed how much the GOP position on Obamacare resembles the classic borscht belt joke about the two ladies at a Catskills resort? Lady #1: “The food here is so terrible, it’s inedible!” Lady #2: “And the portions are so small!” Republican #1: “Obamacare is slavery!” Republican #2: “And it’s so hard to sign up!”

headline: Greek Police Say 10 Officers Have Links to Golden Dawn
keywords: ['Police', 'Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: An internal investigation found that the officers had ties to the neo-fascist party, but that no signs of “organized cells” affiliated with the group had been discovered.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The Greek police on Wednesday announced the findings of an internal investigation into suspected links between the force and the neo-fascist Golden Dawn party, which is the focus of a criminal investigation, saying that 10 officers had been linked to the party but that no signs of “organized cells” affiliated with the group had been discovered. The inquiry began last month, after the killing of an anti-fascist singer by a self-professed supporter of Golden Dawn. The killing was the culmination of a string of assaults attributed to members or supporters of the fiercely anti-immigrant party, which has 18 seats in Greece’s 300-member Parliament. Out of 319 police officers questioned, 15 were arrested on various charges, including illegal weapons possession and trading in contraband goods, and of those, 10 were found to have “direct or indirect involvement with the criminal activities of Golden Dawn,” according to the head of the police’s internal affairs unit, Panagiotis Stathis. The investigation found no “organized cells, factions or unconstitutional hubs” but highlighted “inadequate supervision” within the force, he added at a news conference. The 15 officers who were arrested were suspended pending the outcome of their cases, a police spokesman said.

headline: What It Means to ‘Ban the Box’
abstract: Ban the box laws do not “require” employers to hire people with criminal convictions.
lead_paragraph: Some readers misunderstood my blog post yesterday on Target “banning the box.”

headline: Iran Denies Halt to 20 Percent Uranium Enrichment
abstract: The top nuclear official in Iran contradicted assertions made last week by an influential lawmaker that Iran had stopped the enrichment.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran has never stopped 20 percent uranium enrichment, Iran’s top nuclear official said on Wednesday, contradicting an influential lawmaker who last week said the country had voluntarily halted its production.

headline: A Modern Flood Barrier Aims to Protect Verizon’s Landmark Building
abstract: The portable wall should protect Verizon equipment from inundation and keep stock exchange communications open should another hurricane strike.
lead_paragraph: To protect their Manhattan settlement in the 17th century, the Dutch built a wall.

abstract: Highlights from the testimony before a House committee by Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, who called the first month of the HealthCare.gov site “flawed.”
lead_paragraph: Highlights from the testimony before a House committee by Kathleen Sebelius, the health and human services secretary, who called the first month of the HealthCare.gov site “flawed.”

headline: A Halloween Risk: Racism in Disguise
abstract: Halloween costumes in which white people darken their skin or play into racial stereotypes are drawing criticism.
lead_paragraph: Are Halloween costumes an annual excuse to frighten or to offend?

headline: Bankruptcy Filing Is a Stunning Fall for a Brazilian Tycoon
abstract: The action by the petroleum company OGX was the culmination of a decline that had been apparent for months.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:35 p.m. | The flagship company of the Brazilian entrepreneur Eike Batista, who once boasted that he was on his way to becoming the richest man in the world, filed for bankruptcy on Wednesday.

headline: Kindness, and Cold Shoulders, After Sandy
keywords: ['New York City Marathon', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)', 'Running', 'Marathon Running', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: After visiting a neighborhood devastated by Hurricane Sandy a year later, it seems even more callous that city leaders suggested we needed a sporting event to bounce back.
lead_paragraph: Yana Fishman stood on the porch of her townhouse Saturday and remembered what it was like to come home to “something straight out of a nightmare.”

headline: Decoding the Fed’s Statement
abstract: The statement on Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions.
lead_paragraph: The statement on Wednesday from the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making group of the Federal Reserve, offers its assessment of current economic conditions.

headline: How to Live: A Compendium of Wisdom One Snippet at a Time
abstract: Selected outtakes from the 100 “how to” interviews in the One-Page Magazine.
lead_paragraph: Last week’s issue of the magazine included the 100th interview I’ve conducted for the One-Page Magazine. To mark the occasion, I culled my favorite unpublished moments from two years’ worth of interviews, which have ranged from three minutes (the comedian Kathy Griffin) to 55 (Dustin Diamond of “Saved by the Bell” fame). The first one I did was with Dr. Oz on how to look five years younger, the 100th with the architect Moshe Safdie on how to be worldly; one of the most memorable conversations was with Rodney King on finding inner peace.

headline: Fall Fashion Is All About the Soft and Furry Bits
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Wool and Woolen Goods', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: The latest in retail trends including pullovers and cardigans with furry bits, metal belts, cozy knit caps, and Alexis Bittar adds a fine jewelry collection.
lead_paragraph: Designers were not averse to showing scads of fur for winter, and retailers followed suit, picking up lots of the fluffy stuff. Are you ready to join the party? Rita Ora is. Ms. Ora appeared at a recent event in a Fendi sweater with a mink front in multicolor stripes (above, center). Undeniably fabulous, the Fendi costs roughly $7,000. Happily, great pullovers and cardigans with furry bits are plentiful, minus a zero on the price tag. Pair any of these with jeans or a leather skirt. Anything more teeters on too much look.

headline: Several Skin Products Include an Obscure Nut Oil
abstract: The latest miracle ingredient is called tamanu.
lead_paragraph: Tama-who? Tamanu. Derived from nuts that grow on trees found mostly in Southeast Asia and the Polynesian Islands, this newly modish oil can heal scars, help skin repair itself and soften lines and wrinkles, say proponents. Below, three new products that contain it.

headline: Why Chrysler Needs an $18 Billion Valuation to Justify an I.P.O.
abstract: With a union trust and Fiat at loggerheads, a stock offering could end up being a lot of work for nothing, the author contends.
lead_paragraph: Chrysler’s valuation needs to hit $18 billion to justify an initial public offering. That’s the point where the union trust fund that owns 41.5 percent of the automaker would reap more than it could get from controlling shareholder Fiat. But it’s also way more than either owner has ever considered to be a reasonable price.

headline: You Make the Call: Inappropriate Travel Behavior
abstract: What type of behavior do you find annoying while traveling? We asked, and here is some of what you told us.
lead_paragraph: This week in the Travel section, Stephanie Rosenbloom tackled behavior on airplanes, examining why we act the way we do while traveling. (Bare feet anyone?)

headline: F.D.A. Finds 12% of U.S. Spice Imports Contaminated
keywords: ['Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Salmonella (Bacteria)', 'Spices', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: The imports, from countries like Mexico and India, are said to be tainted with insect parts, whole insects, rodent hairs and other things.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — About 12 percent of spices brought to the United States are contaminated with insect parts, whole insects, rodent hairs and other things, according to an analysis of spice imports by federal food authorities.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: Video of ‘About Time’
abstract: Richard Curtis narrates a scene from his comedy featuring Domhnall Gleeson and Rachel McAdams.
lead_paragraph: In this video Richard Curtis, the writer and director of the comedy “About Time,” narrates a scene featuring Domhnall Gleeson as a man with the ability to time travel and Rachel McAdams as his love interest.

headline: More Vexing Challenges for That Mississippi Lawyer
abstract: John Grisham’s “Sycamore Row” uses many of the same characters as “A Time to Kill” to tell the story of a court case over a will.
lead_paragraph: John Grisham’s “Sycamore Row” revisits Clanton, Miss., the site of his first and still most famous book, “A Time to Kill.” Just three years have passed since young Jake Brigance crusaded his way through Clanton’s most racially inflammatory murder trial. It is 1988, and Jake now has a small practice, a big reputation and a housing problem created when Ku Klux Klan members torched his lovingly restored Victorian home.

headline: This Time Out, Parting Is Such Sung Sorrow
abstract: “The Last Goodbye,” based on “Romeo and Juliet,” relies on Jeff Buckley’s music to supply the emotional resonance and depth of character established by Shakespeare’s verse.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The sound of rock ’n’ roll is the sound of romance and rebellion, and there are no greater romantic rebels than Romeo and Juliet, Shakespeare’s heedless young lovers, who defy the authority of their warring tribes, marry in secret, and willingly embrace the dark fate that unhappy circumstance has ordained for them. “The Last Goodbye,” a new musical adaptation of the play at the Old Globe Theater here, audaciously attempts to find the spiritual kinship between Shakespeare’s tragedy and the keening angst in the music of Jeff Buckley, the singer-songwriter who died in 1997 at the age of 30, as his promising career was gaining momentum.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Kenya and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Kenya, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Norway.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Kenya, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Norway.

headline: A Statement of Purpose From First-Time Visitors
abstract: The San Diego Symphony, led by Jahja Ling, made its debut at Carnegie Hall with a new work, a performance by Lang Lang and Prokofiev’s Fifth Symphony.
lead_paragraph: For all the economic turmoil within many classical-music institutions, there are encouraging stories out there as well. For one, the San Diego Symphony. This orchestra, which gave its first concerts in 1910, has endured periods of financial crisis when activities ceased, most recently in the mid-1990s.

headline: Jeep Delays Fuel Tank Recall; G.M., Bentley, Lamborghini and Nissan Issue Recalls
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Brakes', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Jeep owners have still not been contacted months after Chrysler said it would address a fuel tank defect for which N.H.T.S.A. directed a recall.
lead_paragraph: Four months after Chrysler agreed to recall about 1.6 million 2002-7 Jeep Liberty and 1993-98 Jeep Grand Cherokee models over rear-impact fire danger, owners still have not been told by the company to bring their vehicles to dealerships for repairs.

headline: Puccini’s Passions, Still in Stark Production
abstract: The main singers in the Met’s lastest revival of “Tosca,” in Luc Bondy’s gritty, spare staging, are veterans of this production.
lead_paragraph: For a time after the critically savaged opening of Luc Bondy’s gritty, spare and somewhat smarmy production of Puccini’s “Tosca” at the Metropolitan Opera in 2009, some nourished the forlorn hope that the Met would come to its senses and revive the immediate predecessor, by Franco Zeffirelli, widely beloved for its grand and hyper-realistic sets. But it is clear by now that the Bondy version — revived every year since its premiere and shorn of its worst excrescences, sexual and otherwise — is here for at least a while. So it is probably time to stop the comparisons and accept or reject it on its own terms.

headline: Newly Released Books
abstract: Four novels that explore the needs and fragility of human psychology, and two books about life (and the search for life) far from Earth.
lead_paragraph: This month, four novels that explore the needs and fragility of human psychology, and two books about life (and the search for life) far from Earth.

headline: In a Surprise, Pakistan Says Fewer Civilians Died by Drones
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Pakistan sharply reduced its official estimate of civilian deaths caused by American drone strikes in the tribal belt, highlighting how contentious statistics are in the C.I.A.’s covert campaign.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a surprise move, Pakistan’s government on Wednesday sharply revised downward its official estimate of civilian casualties caused by American drone strikes in the tribal belt, highlighting again the contentious nature of statistics about the covert C.I.A. campaign.

headline: For a High-Powered Career, It’s Finance vs. Tech
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Hiring and Promotion']

lead_paragraph: Wall Street or Silicon Valley? That’s the choice facing many ambitious students across the United States looking to gain a toehold in a powerful industry after graduation.

headline: Katy Perry on Top in a Dismal Week for Music Industry
abstract: Katy Perry’s album “Prism” is No. 1, but over all, album sales reached a weekly low.
lead_paragraph: Record sales over the last week were kind to Katy Perry and Lou Reed, but for the music industry over all they were terrible.

headline: Back to St. Louis on the Way to Brazil
abstract: Vedad Ibisevic, who spent part of his teenage years in the American Midwest, scored the goal that sent Bosnia-Herzegovina to the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: Vedad Ibisevic admits he is not much of a baseball fan, even though the team from his adopted hometown, St. Louis, was again in the World Series.

headline: Mobile Ads Fuel a Jump in Profit at Facebook
abstract: Profits doubled in the third quarter, and the social network reported that mobile ads now accounted for about half its advertising revenue.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Perhaps Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, should ditch the hoodie and dress up as a mobile phone for Halloween.

headline: La Scala Confirms Barenboim Departure
abstract: The Teatro alla Scala in Milan has confirmed that Daniel Barenboim will step down as musical director at the end of 2014.
lead_paragraph: The Teatro alla Scala in Milan has confirmed that Daniel Barenboim will step down as musical director at the end of 2014, two years before his contract is set to expire. He will probably be succeeded by Riccardo Chailly, a Milanese conductor. In an interview, Carlo Maria Cella, a spokesman for La Scala, said that Mr. Barenboim had no comment. Mr. Cella confirmed that the conductor had sent a letter to the opera house saying that he would conclude his tenure with a production of Beethoven’s “Fidelio,” which opens the opera’s 2014-15 season.

headline: New Guidelines Aim to Help Financial Caregivers
abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has published a series of guides called “Managing Someone Else’s Money.”
lead_paragraph: Your aging aunt, worried that she won’t be able to pay her bills if she becomes sick, signs a power of attorney document making you her legal agent for financial decisions. Or your retired father needs help managing his monthly Social Security payments, and the government appoints you as his “representative payee.”

headline: Office Romance: Ghost Stories
abstract: Weird things happen to people in The Times building.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes late in the day, I head up to the 15th floor. Like a moth lured by a candle flame, I am drawn by the light coming into the west side of our building. It bounces off the Hudson River, sweeps over the parking lot above Port Authority, pours in through the floor-to-ceiling windows and ignites the frosted-glass walls of the conference rooms, stirring up light spirits. People passing by disintegrate into shadow selves, sometimes completely disappearing into the walls. The light along the stairs bookending the southwest and northwest sides of the building swelters at the witching hour, causing people to evaporate. The shades that line the windows are scrims for a sinister Broadway show. Weird things happen with the light on the sixth floor, too. A shadowy figure appears suddenly on a filing cabinet. A hand darts up from the depths of a cubicle. Edward Scissorhands is trapped in the carpet.

headline: American Academy in Rome Names New President
abstract: Mark Robbins, the executive director of the International Center of Photography, will take over from Adele Chatfield-Taylor.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The American Academy in Rome is expected to name Mark Robbins, the executive director of the International Center of Photography, as its new president. Mr. Robbins, an architect and artist who has also been the director of design at the National Endowment for the Arts, will follow Adele Chatfield-Taylor, who is stepping down in January after 27 years as the head of the independent research institution.

headline: A Singer Is Tough on Herself
abstract: Sky Ferreira’s debut album, “Night Time, My Time,” is bracing, aggressive and surprisingly tender.
lead_paragraph: How much longer will Sky Ferreira not get what she wants? The agony of disappointment is wearing on her, and animating her. See “Nobody Asked Me (If I Was Okay)” — which turns lashing out into a sticky, moody song — from her bracing, aggressive and surprisingly tender debut album, “Night Time, My Time” (Capitol).

headline: Wrangling Data From a Huge Variety of Fitness Gadgets
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Smartphones', 'Exercise', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Measuring and tracking your body’s functions and activities has never been easier — but what to do with all that data?
lead_paragraph: The human body is in data overload.

headline: Churches and Cheap Seafood Off the Coast of Chile
abstract: Chiloé, an archipelago off the southern part of the country, offers a number of choices for frugal-friendly exploration.
lead_paragraph: Around dusk on my last day in Chiloé, an archipelago just off the coast of southern Chile, I finally made it to the farthest point on the island of Lemuy, winding around sheep farms on tidy dirt roads to a little town called Detif, home of one of Chiloé’s traditional wooden churches, which are recognized as a World Heritage site by Unesco.

headline: In the Backwoods of Lost River, a Gay Retreat
keywords: ['Homosexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: With the legalization of gay marriage in Washington, D.C., and Maryland in recent years, more gay couples are holding their wedding receptions in this area of West Virginia.
lead_paragraph: The beauty of Lost River — beyond its rolling green hills and picturesque grain silos and clear streams snaking through West Virginia’s hardwood forests — is its surprising cosmopolitanism. The area, in the state’s eastern panhandle and just two hours from Washington, is definitively the backwoods, with poultry farms and scant cellphone service and grocery-store cashiers who say “What’s that?” when asked about organic milk.

headline: Proving That the Medium Really Is the Message
abstract: Galleries and museums are rediscovering the work of Robert Heinecken, who used found imagery to explore themes that still feel urgent today.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — To walk into “Waking Up in News America,” a rarely seen room-size installation by the artist Robert Heinecken, is to enter weirdly familiar Marshall McLuhan territory.

lead_paragraph: By Blitzen Trapper

headline: A Mix of Duets and Solos Proves a Recipe for a Feast
abstract: The soprano Jessica Rivera and the mezzo Kelley O’Connor recital at Zankel Hall, accompanied by Robert Spano at the piano, made for a fragrant, appetizing blend of sounds.
lead_paragraph: The urge to combine a soprano and mezzo-soprano can be easily understood by anyone who’s ever made chocolate milk. It’s the same alchemy: mixing something pure and light with something dark and syrupy to make something sweet, substantial and refreshing.

headline: Shining Despite the Shadow of Guest Vocalists
abstract: Mr. Glasper’s jazz-R & B quartet was joined by the rapper Common and Marsha Ambrosius, formerly of Floetry, at the Best Buy Theater.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Robert Glasper has been moving between the cultures of jazz and hip-hop — or, technically, the R&B that extends from the New York hip-hop a generation ago. He’s a natural multitasker, a guy who enjoys looseness, hybridity. Since he established himself in New York in the early oughts, his gigs have often felt like workshops or rehearsals or parties, whether in small acoustic-music rooms or at bigger clubs with serious speakers, like the Best Buy Theater, where on Tuesday night the Robert Glasper Experiment performed, or at least accompanied its guests.

headline: Robert Glasper and Friends at Best Buy Theater
abstract: The Robert Glasper Experiment, led by the pianist, performed at the Best Buy Theater to celebrate the band’s new album, “Black Radio 2.”
lead_paragraph: The Robert Glasper Experiment, led by the pianist, performed at the Best Buy Theater to celebrate the band’s new album, “Black Radio 2.”

headline: Your Recipes for Holiday Sweets
abstract: Send us recipes for your favorite sweet homemade gifts; we’ll select three to publish in time for the holidays.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to holiday gifts, it’s the thought that counts. But what happens when your thoughts run blank, and you just can’t think of anything to get all the people on your list? Like your nice next-door neighbors, the ones who take in your packages when you’re not home? Or your second cousin’s third husband whose name you pulled out of the secret Santa hat?

headline: No Lights, No Camera, No Action
abstract: “Golden Slumbers” — a film about Cambodian cinema, whose history was wiped clean by the Khmer Rouge — gleans traces of the erased past through interviews.
lead_paragraph: Often a documentary tackles a topic that, however tempting, poses visual challenges (or exhausts the imagination of the filmmaker). That problem is the focus of “Golden Slumbers,” a film about Cambodian cinema, a history wiped clean by the Khmer Rouge. In the hands of the filmmaker Davy Chou, that vanished past becomes a remembered fantasy, expressing the absence of much more than a couple of hundred missing melodramas.

headline: Though the House Is Closed, Inside, Satie’s Ghost Giggles
abstract: Satie’s music and a contemporary choreographer’s movement combine in John Heginbotham’s “Dark Theater,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Pay attention! The opening movements of “Dark Theater,” the choreographer John Heginbotham’s new work to music by Erik Satie, show straightaway a true theater artist’s instinct for commanding his audience. The six dancers — dressed by Maile Okamura in lime green body tights with high red collars — burst into movement that exhibits sharpness, energy, formality and, yes, oddity. These qualities all feel right for the music, too. “Dark Theater,” which opened on Tuesday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Fishman Space, captures several facets of Satie — not least his very precise eccentricity.

headline: Philadelphia Inquirer Majority Owners Seek to Buy Out Others
abstract: The majority owners said they wanted to provide stability to the newspaper after a month of upheavals and lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: After nearly a month of upheaval at The Philadelphia Inquirer, including the abrupt firing of the paper’s top editor and lawsuits among its owners, the majority owners on Wednesday offered to buy out the minority investors, in what they described as an effort to provide stability to the company.

headline: A Lonely Passion: China’s Followers of Friedrich A. Hayek
abstract: Friedrich A. Hayek believed that economic planning by the state always leads to a loss of individual liberty, and that the best life is delivered by a private economy run by people whose rights are protected by law — which makes promoting his ideas in China an uphill battle.
lead_paragraph: As quixotic causes go, working in China to spread the ideas of Friedrich A. Hayek, the Austrian-born liberal economist and philosopher of freedom, is up there.

headline: Under Fire, Hedge-Fund Billionaire to Sell Choice Art
abstract: Steven A. Cohen is selling some $80 million in art at Sotheby’s and Christie’s this fall, though people close to him say the sales are not an effort to raise money for his mounting fines and legal fees.
lead_paragraph: In the two decades that the hedge fund billionaire Steven A. Cohen has collected art, he has been not only a high-profile buyer but also a high-profile seller, disposing of a painting one season, a sculpture the next.

abstract: By Blitzen Trapper
lead_paragraph: By Blitzen Trapper

headline: A Bandleader in His Element
abstract: Jimmy Heath led his big band and played a little saxophone on Tuesday in the first set of a night at Blue Note.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Heath picked up his tenor saxophone at only a couple of choice moments in his first set at the Blue Note on Tuesday, and somehow he made that feel almost magnanimous. Leading his big band in the second of four nights at the club, he was in brisk conductor mode, often moving his small frame with the spry dynamism of a jack-in-the-box. His fallback demeanor, gleeful but alert, suggested the air of a machinist watching his parts whirl magically into gear.

headline: What Would Mr. Roper Say?
abstract: Suzanne Somers’s commentary on the Affordable Care Act in The Wall Street Journal did not go unnoticed.
lead_paragraph: Who would have guessed that 36 years after she helped introduce “jiggle TV” as part of the original “Three’s Company” cast (and decades after she first touted the body-shaping benefits of the ThighMaster), Suzanne Somers would have been recruited by The Wall Street Journal to offer criticism of the Affordable Care Act? Her article, “The Affordable Care Act Is a Socialist Ponzi Scheme,” in which Ms. Somers cited the Canadian health care system as a cautionary tale and quoted (somewhat inaccurately, it appears) Churchill and Lenin, quickly caught the attention of the Twittersphere.

headline: New York Raising Age to Buy Cigarettes to 21
abstract: Aiming to curtail smoking among young people, the City Council adopted the strictest limits on tobacco purchasing of any major American city.
lead_paragraph: Buying cigarettes in New York City is about to become a lot harder for young people, as lawmakers on Wednesday adopted the strictest limits on tobacco purchases of any major American city.

headline: Missoni, More Than a Zigzag
abstract: After a year of tragedies, the Missoni family begins to chart a new course forward.
lead_paragraph: The night of Sept. 18, at La Scala opera house in Milan, more than a few heads turned when Rosita Missoni, the 82-year-old matriarch of the famous Italian knitwear company, made her way to a seat near the center of the first row. Eva Cavalli, in a white pantsuit, sat next to her and gently wrapped an arm around Mrs. Missoni, as her husband, the designer Roberto, all in black, doted. Giorgio Armani, among the many familiar designer faces gathered for a party sponsored by Condé Nast, paid his respects as well to this proud, bright-eyed woman whose cropped white hair is punctuated by a thin braid at the nape of her neck.

headline: At Todd Snyder’s New Store, the Past Gets a Workout
abstract: City Gym in NoLIta will feature casual clothing primarily, in a setting that includes elements like old football trophies and medicine balls.
lead_paragraph: THE NAME OF the new Todd Snyder store that opens on Saturday in NoLIta is City Gym. While catchy, this may confuse people who are more familiar with the designer’s two-year-old collection of finely tailored dress-up designs than his hit sweats collaboration with Champion.

headline: Kimberly Chandler Coming Into Her Own
abstract: Ms. Chandler, wife of the New York Knicks center Tyson Chandler, skillfully navigates the New York social circuit, where she has recently become a vivid presence.
lead_paragraph: Kimberly Chandler is no stranger to the camera. In the last couple of months alone, she has been snapped on the red carpet at the Broadway opening of “Romeo and Juliet”; in a front-row seat alongside Kerry Washington at the Alexander Wang show; and at the New York premiere of “Boardwalk Empire,” snuggled beneath the arm of her husband, Tyson Chandler, the towering center for the New York Knicks. Clearly she has in a brief span of time learned to make the camera do her bidding.

headline: Mystery Man, Painting the Town
abstract: The graffiti artist known as Banksy has made New York his personal outdoor gallery for the month of October.
lead_paragraph: It has been a perfect tempest in a teapot, the distracting, frothy combination of art, money, celebrity and urban exploit that Banksy has brought to New York. This British graffiti artist, purported millionaire, activist, filmmaker and prankster spent the last month roaming the city, perpetuating what is — depending upon your point of view — street art, political resistance or vandalism.

headline: Following the Grim Reaper, Equipped With a Camera
abstract: Eight people fall ill and die in the course of “Time of Death,” a six-part documentary on Showtime.
lead_paragraph: If there was ever an argument against binge viewing, it’s “Time of Death,” a documentary series beginning on Friday night on Showtime. Over the course of six hours we watch eight people sicken and die, succumbing to cancers and other diseases at ages ranging from 19 to 77. For the viewer, some recovery time between episodes is probably a good idea.

headline: Red Sox Rout Cardinals, 6-1, to Win Series in Six Games
abstract: Follow along and join the conversation as The Times offers notes, analysis and insights throughout Game 6 of the World Series, as the Red Sox try to beat the Cardinals and clinch their third championship since 2004.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The Fenway Park crowd was eager all night, standing, yelling, cheering. All that pent-up energy exploded as Shane Victorino crushed a Michael Wacha fastball high off the Green Monster, scoring three runs. Victorino pounded his chest and yelled as he advanced to third base. It seemed over then. The Red Sox had the lead.

headline: 'Our City'
abstract: The most recent ad from the de Blasio campaign focuses on many different voices in New York.
lead_paragraph: The most recent ad from the de Blasio campaign focuses on many different voices in New York.

headline: Restoration Hardware’s Next Move? A Quarterly Journal for Art Lovers
abstract: The sleek, beautifully produced publication is one of the tentpoles of RH Contemporary Art, the furniture retailer’s grand entrée into the art world.
lead_paragraph: The home furnishings giant Restoration Hardware — or rather, RH, as it was rebranded in 2012 — may bring to mind ecru linen sofas and distressed steamer trunks. But under the lead of co-C.E.O. Gary Friedman, the company is muscling its way into the business of contemporary art. On Nov. 9, it will also become a publisher, with a quarterly called RH Contemporary Art Journal that will be available for free to visitors of its new wood-beamed art gallery on West 16th Street. The debut issue is a glossy, minimalist affair that feels rather like an exhibition catalog, except for the heartfelt introductory letter from Friedman. (Fans of Restoration Hardware’s “source books” will recognize his favored sign-off — “Carpe Diem, Gary.”) Both ventures are part of RH Contemporary Art, a platform that also includes documentaries, artist residencies and a web emporium, all aimed at selling creations by the artists it works with (who currently number about 50).

headline: More Than a Chaise, a Thing of Beauty
abstract: In addition to his furniture for Baker, Jacques Garcia offers a recent collection he designed for a Marrakesh hotel.
lead_paragraph: The French interior designer Jacques Garcia has ladled on opulence in hotels and restaurants from Moscow to Miami Beach and in homes for private clients like the Sultan of Brunei. His encrusted portfolio now has a new gem: the Hotel Selman, in Marrakesh, Morocco, a luxury resort for which he designed all the furnishings, including Le Meridienne Victor, above, a stately chaise. Fashioned after the French sofa known as a récamier, the piece is edged in contrasting trim, which highlights its contours. “It’s a shape he has long loved,” said Agnes de la Mure, Mr. Garcia’s director of product development. Unlike his designs for Baker, the American furniture company, where each piece must stand on its own, the $10,500 chaise blends in with its surroundings. But it emanates from the same philosophy, Ms. de la Mure said: “Elegant nonchalance.” Information: 212-684-0707 or cotefrance.com.

keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Books and Literature', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Restoration and Renovation']

lead_paragraph: Julie Carlson’s childhood home, a modest but elegant, mid-19th century white clapboard near the main street of Wellfleet, Mass. — also known as the “seacoast of Bohemia,” as Mary McCarthy slyly described the town — has been evoked so many times in the poems of so many late-20th-century poets it deserves its own anthology. Patricia Goedicke imagined its “white curtains like loaves of bread.” Deborah Garrison wrote how “The porch that needs painting peels its white skin in the sun.” Cynthia Zarin decried its penetrating cold in the winter, and “the knocking boiler’s burned old heart.”

The men, who were arrested, had dug a hole under a fence around the power plant in order to sneak the purloined scrap metal out and sell it, he said. “These people were thieves, not nuclear saboteurs,” the minister said. “They were from a village close to the power plant, and they had done such things before.”

On Nov. 12, during the second of the two big auction weeks that start in New York on Monday night, Christie’s is offering one painting — a Francis Bacon triptych — that is expected to bring $85 million. Its archrival, Sotheby’s, has a 1963 Warhol that it anticipates will sell for $60 million to $80 million.

headline: Afraid of Snakes? Your Pulvinar May Be to Blame
abstract: Scientists have discovered that certain neurons in the brain, in a region known as the pulvinar, respond only to snakes.
lead_paragraph: Multiple Walter Whites will walk the streets on Thursday in search of candy. But some frights endure the fashion cycle and never go out of style.

headline: Black and White and in the Red
abstract: College newspapers have until recently managed to stave off industry challenges. Now many traditional papers are struggling for survival.
lead_paragraph: WITHIN a month of taking over as editor of The Hatchet, George Washington University’s student newspaper, Cory Weinberg knew that something had to change. Advertising dollars had been steadily declining. Printing costs continued to rise. At the same time, visits to the website were up. The number of students reading articles on their mobile devices had doubled. Traffic from Twitter had increased 300 percent in the last year.

headline: 1961: Rue des Mauvais Garçons to Keep Name
abstract: The Prefect of Paris ruled that the name was part of the capital’s ancient heritage and worth keeping intact like historic buildings.
lead_paragraph: PARIS —The City of Paris came to the defense of its rowdy past today when Prefect Jean Benedetti refused to change the name of the Rue des Mauvais-Garçons (Street of Bad Boys—or hoodlums in French slang).

lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company reported a quarterly loss on Thursday, attributable in large part, the company said, to expenses related to the sale of the New England Media Group, which included The Boston Globe, and some pension expenses.

headline: Time Warner Left Bruised in Fee Battle With CBS
abstract: The cable company lost 306,000 television subscribers in the third quarter, hurt by a contract dispute that resulted in a blackout of CBS programming.
lead_paragraph: The CBS blackout in homes with Time Warner Cable ended in early September. But the damage from the feud is still being tallied up — and it may be lasting.

lead_paragraph: On the endlessly fascinating subject of journalists, press rights and government surveillance, in what might be called the Snowden era, a few recently published articles (and a television interview) may be of interest.

headline: Young, Restless and Indian
abstract: What is the mood of privileged young people in India today?
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — Back in 2003, when I lived in a small, liberal California town near Berkeley, the prospect of George W. Bush’s re-election filled my neighbors and me with palpable dread. At our annual block party some of us facetiously repeated things he’d said, Bushisms like “I know the human being and fish can coexist peacefully.” What we really meant was that we could not coexist with Bush, peacefully or otherwise.

headline: In Shadows, Hints of a Life and Even a Job for Snowden
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Edward J. Snowden, a former National Security Agency contractor who received temporary asylum in Russia, will start work on Friday at an Internet company, a lawyer said.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — On very rare occasions, almost always at night, Edward J. Snowden leaves his secret, guarded residence here, somewhere, in Russia. He is always under close protection. He spends his days learning the language and reading. He recently finished “Crime and Punishment.”

headline: After a Run of Growth, Concern Over Japan’s Next Moves
abstract: Many of the growth plans laid out in June lack detail and risk being watered down, analysts say.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Nearly a year after the Japanese began to hope that their economy could turn around under new leadership, a sense of realism is replacing the euphoria.

headline: A Doggie Bag for Your Jeep
abstract: Jeep’s soft pet carrier offers pet owners a safe, portable way to transport them.
lead_paragraph: Just about anyone with a large dog can appreciate a vehicle with a large rear compartment. The trouble is, with all that space back there it can be difficult to keep things secured in one spot — particularly an animal with a mind of its own. Many dog owners buy those cagelike steel partitions that mount just behind the rear seats of a sport utility vehicle, crossover or wagon, but what if you want to drive a car that doesn’t look like a mobile animal control unit?

headline: Loud and Colorful, With Total Recall
abstract: Penny Arcade, a longtime downtown performance artist and archivist, takes on a role in “The Mutilated,” a Tennessee Williams play.
lead_paragraph: In 1967, the same year that the playwright Tennessee Williams found himself in the depths of substance abuse, depression and critical failure, a short, busty, outspoken 17-year-old named Susana Ventura completed her tenure in reform school and ran away from working-class New Britain, Conn. She moved to downtown Manhattan, was sheltered by drag queens and fell under the tutelage of gay artists including Andy Warhol; the filmmaker and performance artist Jack Smith; and John Vaccaro, founder of the avant-garde Play-House of the Ridiculous theater group.

headline: And a Child Shall Lead Them Into Space Battle
abstract: “Ender’s Game” imagines a future in which youngsters are trained as warriors from an early age to fight Earth’s enemies, the large, insectlike Formics.
lead_paragraph: At one point in “Ender’s Game,” the boy brainiac Ender Wiggin stands on a podium waving his arms. A vast, immersive image of outer space is spread out before him, and if you didn’t know better, you might think he was playing Wii on an Imax screen. It’s an amusingly self-reflexive moment in a humorless movie about children who play war games as part of their very grown-up military training. As he furiously moves spaceships and troops across computer screens, he looks, by turns, like a superexcited kid, an orchestra conductor, Mickey Mouse as the Sorcerer’s Apprentice and even a Christ figure. Childhood can be tough in movies, but rarely do screen children suffer for our sins as they do here.

headline: Free Speech, for the Loudest
abstract: Even those who oppose New York City’s “stop and frisk” policy should be chagrined about the way protesters at Brown greeted Ray Kelly.
lead_paragraph: Even those who oppose New York City’s “stop and frisk” policy should be chagrined about the way noisy protesters at Brown University on Tuesday greeted the city’s police commissioner, Raymond Kelly.

headline: Filling Cavities Can Be a Laugh, but Dentists Still Suggest Limiting Gummies at Halloween
abstract: Nitrous oxide, or laughing gas, can make the process of getting a filling much more pleasant, even for a 5-year-old.
lead_paragraph: No Sour Patch Kids, no Skittles, no Swedish Fish. Same goes for Starbursts, gummi bears and Nerds.

headline: A Journalist With a Mission
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Glenn Greenwald believes that he faces possible arrest if he returns to the United States but is unbowed.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A young American lawyer comes to Brazil in 2005, falls in love, finds that his gay relationship confers greater legal rights than back home, starts a blog called Unclaimed Territory focusing on illegal warrantless eavesdropping by the National Security Agency, takes a place in the hills of Rio with a bunch of rescue dogs, denounces the cozy compromises of “establishment journalists,” gets hired to write a column by Britain’s Guardian newspaper, is sought out by the N.S.A. whistle-blower Edward J. Snowden, becomes the main chronicler of Snowden’s revelations of global American surveillance, is lionized for work that prompts a far-reaching debate on security and freedom, files repeated thunderbolts from his leafy Brazilian perch, and ends up, in just eight years, as perhaps the most famous journalist of his generation.

headline: Another Delay for Small-Business Health Exchanges? Depends on Whom You Ask.
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Small Business']
abstract: The administration says SHOP will be fully functional by the end of November — but that small businesses have other options in the meantime.
lead_paragraph: If you thought that the small business health insurance exchange would be fully working Friday, prepare for some disappointment. On Tuesday, while testifying at a House hearing, Marilyn Tavenner, the head of the Center for Medicare & Medicaid Services, the government agency implementing the federally run health insurance exchanges, said that the Small Business Health Options exchanges would be functional “at the end of November.”

abstract: Dusty Kennedy and Clint Watson head out with their dogs to hunt feral hogs.
lead_paragraph: Dusty Kennedy and Clint Watson head out with their dogs to hunt feral hogs.

headline: Slower Growth: It’s Not Just Government
abstract: The Federal Reserve’s finding of “growing underlying strength in the broader economy” is belied by the deceleration of expansion in both the private sector and over all, an economist writes.
lead_paragraph: Jared Bernstein is a senior fellow at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington and a former chief economist to Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

headline: F.A.A. Approves Use of Devices on Flights
abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration has approved in-flight use e-readers, tablets and smart phones in airplane mode.
lead_paragraph: It’s game on, quite literally, for airline passengers who want to use their cellphones and other portable electronics during flights. The Federal Aviation Administration announced Thursday morning that it has approved the use of electronic devices during all phases of a flight, with a few exceptions, according to a release from the agency.

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘The Fisherman’
abstract: In this Poetry Pairing, two well-known Irish poets are remembered. There is the nearly 100-year-old poem “The Fisherman” by William Butler Yeats, paired with the August 2013 obituary “Seamus Heaney, Irish Poet of Soil and Strife, Dies at 74.”
lead_paragraph: Two well-known Irish poets are remembered in this Poetry Pairing, which features the nearly 100-year-old poem “The Fisherman” by William Butler Yeats, and the August 2013 obituary “Seamus Heaney, Irish Poet of Soil and Strife, Dies at 74” by Margalit Fox.

headline: F.A.A. Moves to Ease Electronics Ban, Opening the Runways to Angry Birds
abstract: The change, expected before the end of the year, will allow passengers on most flights to use tablets, MP3 players and other personal electronic devices.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The days of airline passengers being hounded to turn off their tablets or e-readers for takeoff and landing are coming to an end.

headline: Baby Book as Battleground
abstract: Jon Scieszka’s “Battle Bunny” merrily upends expectations about what a children’s book should be.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, you might mistake this little book for one of those slightly old-fashioned illustrated stories grandparents give preschoolers as holiday gifts. It could be a Golden Book, say, illustrated by Garth Williams. This one is already inscribed: “To my little birthday bunny on his special day. Love, Gran Gran.” The note appears to have been written in ballpoint by someone who studied penmanship. But below that inscription, the book’s title has been defaced: What was once “Birthday Bunny” has been scrawled over, with a marker and in a far less steady hand. It now reads, “Battle Bunny.”

headline: The Gun Report: October 31, 2013
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The police chief in Sanford, Fla., where George Zimmerman, a neighborhood watch volunteer, shot and killed 17-year-old Trayvon Martin last year, is set to unveil rules stressing that volunteers are not to carry guns or follow suspects. In a community meeting next week, Police Chief Cecil Smith, who took over the department in April and quickly and suspended the neighborhood watch program, will emphasize that members are to call police when they see a suspicious person or activity. Zimmerman was acquitted of second-degree murder in July.

headline: Reshuffling at Time Inc. to Set Table for Spinoff
abstract: The appointment was part of a reorganization of Time Inc. as it prepares to be spun off from its parent company, Time Warner.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to increase revenue by building a closer partnership between business and the newsroom, Time Inc. said on Thursday that the editors of its individual magazines would report directly to the company’s business side for the first time in its history, instead of the editor in chief of Time Inc.

headline: James Blake Wins Britain’s Mercury Prize
abstract: Mr. Blake won the award for his album “Overgrown.”
lead_paragraph: James Blake, a pianist and singer whose music is a blend of gentle, soulful ballad structures with beats and electronic textures, was awarded this year’s Barclaycard Mercury Prize for his second album, “Overgrown,” at a ceremony at the Roundhouse in London on Wednesday. The $32,000 prize, which was established in 1992 by the British Phonographic Industry and British Association of Record Dealers, is for the best British or Irish album of the year, selected by an anonymous jury.

headline: A Property Fight in the Adirondacks, Brewing for a Century, Is on the Ballot
abstract: A constitutional amendment would put more than 200 parcels in Township 40 in private hands, with the state getting new public land in exchange.
lead_paragraph: TOWNSHIP 40, N.Y. — There are no road signs leading to this place, a square swath of Adirondack Park greenery in Hamilton County. There is no “Welcome to...” or “Thanks for visiting...” sign. Indeed, visitors would have to be a cartographer, or maybe an environmental lawyer, to know they were there.

headline: M.V.P. Goes to a Most Valuable Papi
abstract: David Ortiz batted .688 in the World Series with 2 home runs and 6 runs batted in, leading the Red Sox to the World Series title with his words and his deeds.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — David Ortiz had done everything else right in this World Series. He had hit just about every pitch. He had said the right things, at the right moments. Now, he could make one more memory. He held the World Series Most Valuable Player trophy high, in his right hand, looked out at his people, and shouted, “This is for you, Boston!”

headline: T WINTER LUXURY
abstract: At their Milan atelier, one of the last truly Old World interiors firms, Studio Peregalli, is making history — mining everything from the high Renaissance to the Victorian era — to create deeply poetic spaces that transcend the bounds of time.

headline: Intimidating Pakistan’s Press
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media', 'Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A fatwa issued by a group affiliated with the Pakistani Taliban raises concerns about journalists’ safety in a country that is already already among the deadliest in the world for reporters.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Shura-e-Mujahedeen, a group affiliated with the Pakistani Taliban, recently reissued a year-old fatwa describing Pakistani journalists and media outlets as “enemies of the mujahedeen.” The decree threatened several radio stations and included photographs of the popular political talk show hosts Hamid Mir and Hasan Nisar, accusing them of promoting secular and Western values and spreading anti-Muslim propaganda. The fatwa was first issued following widespread condemnation by Pakistani journalists of the Taliban’s attempt to kill the teenage education activist Malala Yousafzai in October 2012. The announcement raises concerns about journalists’ safety in a country that is already among the deadliest in the world for reporters.

headline: Fantasy Football: Week 9 Matchup Breakdown
abstract: The Rams’ Zac Stacy is a must-start against the Titans, who have been burned on the ground for an average of 28 fantasy points per game over their last three contests.
lead_paragraph: In a season in which Knowshon Moreno, who was undrafted in some leagues, is fantasy football’s No. 2 running back and Doug Martin, who was supposed to be fantasy’s No. 2 running back (based on average draft position), is probably available on your league’s waiver wire, nobody should be surprised that the rookie Marvin Jones (CIN) is suddenly a top-15 wide receiver.

headline: Scores of Migrants From Niger Found Dead in Sahara
abstract: The 87 men, women and children were apparently stranded after a desperate search for water as they tried to make their way across the border to Algeria.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The decomposing bodies of 87 migrants from the impoverished West African nation of Niger were discovered in the Sahara this week just a few miles from a well, apparently stranded after a desperate search for water, said the head of a local humanitarian organization who helped bury many of the bodies.

headline: The Dreams of War
abstract: How the Civil War invaded Americans’ sleep.
lead_paragraph: The Civil War placed new and unique strains on Americans, and their dreams reflected those hardships. Sometimes the war intruded on people’s slumber, vividly bringing to life the horrors of the conflict; for others, nighttime was an escape from the hard realities of life and death in wartime. When Americans recorded their dreams in their diaries, letters and memoirs, they sought to make sense of the changing world around them, and to cope with the confusion, despair, and loneliness of life amid the turmoil of a gigantic civil war.

headline: Former Premier Can Be Charged, Czech Court Rules
abstract: The Czech Supreme Court ruled that Petr Necas was not entitled to immunity from prosecution on possible corruption charges.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Czech Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that former Prime Minister Petr Necas was not entitled to immunity from prosecution for the period when he was head of government, clearing the way for prosecutors who have been seeking to charge him with corruption.

headline: U.S. Teams Up With Operator of Online Courses to Plan a Global Network
abstract: The classes, offered in partnership with the California company Coursera, will include weekly sessions in which students will meet in person.
lead_paragraph: Coursera, a California-based venture that has enrolled five million students in its free online courses, announced on Thursday a partnership with the United States government to create “learning hubs” around the world where students can go to get Internet access to free courses supplemented by weekly in-person class discussions with local teachers or facilitators.

headline: A Play That’s Sure to Make You Sweat
abstract: “Dutchman,” Amiri Baraka’s 1964 play about race and assimilation, is being restaged in an East Village sauna room by the visual artist Rashid Johnson.
lead_paragraph: THE Russian and Turkish Baths on 10th Street in the East Village is a place where people (including, legend has it, Frank Sinatra, Timothy Leary and John Belushi) have gone for escape for more than a century. But the baths could easily pass for a place you would want to escape from, under different circumstances. Inside, they are dark and dank and sweaty, packed with masses of hot, sagging flesh, a spa version of Dante’s City of Dis, where the heretics are punished in burning stone coffins.

headline: Are Caregivers Healthier?
abstract: More evidence that caregiving may improve health.
lead_paragraph: The idea that caring for a chronically ailing or disabled family member might be good for you is so startling, so counterintuitive, that it sends researchers rummaging through their data to see where they went wrong.

headline: What to Do When Your Child Asks About Your Income
abstract: Five things to think about when your children want to know how much money you make, including honesty, not making them feel badly and considering what they already know.
lead_paragraph: Of all the money questions that our kids will eventually ask, the inquiry about our income may be the toughest one of all to answer. Why, exactly, do they want to know how much money we make? And what are they going to do with the information?!

lead_paragraph: After a four-month investigation the Nevada Occupational Safety and Health Administration has fined Cirque du Soleil and the MGM Grand Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas for safety violations that the agency said led to the death of a 31-year-old French acrobat, Sarah Guillot-Guyard, in a fall during a performance of “KA” on June 29.

lead_paragraph: Secretary of State John Kerry will begin a nine-day trip to the Middle East, Europe and North Africa on Sunday by stopping in Saudi Arabia for talks with King Abdullah, a major ally who is angered over what he sees as Obama administration failures on Syria, Egypt, the Palestinian-Israeli conflict and relations with Iran.

headline: One Complicated Life, Illustrated
abstract: “American Mirror” grapples with the aesthetic and psychological influences on the illustrator Norman Rockwell’s work.
lead_paragraph: In her engaging and ultimately sad biography of Norman Rockwell, Deborah Solomon fills in the partly known life of one of America’s most famous and popular illustrator-artists. Because Rockwell has been well documented — from his own autobiography in 1960 to periodic monographs from art-book publishers in later decades — a skeptic might ask if a new accounting is needed. Well, no and yes.

headline: If Your Child Was Bullied, When Did You Intervene and When Did You Stay Out?
keywords: ['Bullies', 'Parenting', 'Youth', 'Baby Boomers', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Education (K-12)', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Seeking advice from parents whose children were bullied, and asking when they chose to do something about it.
lead_paragraph: It is a very painful and scary thing for parents to learn that their child is being bullied. Though my four — now young adults — were relatively popular and athletic kids, I watched them go through bullying several times. It was one of the the harder problems I faced as a dad, and it’s the topic we are asking our readers to discuss this week: Do I intervene on behalf of my children or hold back and let them work out the problem themselves?

headline: A Vital Measure: Your Surgeon’s Skill
abstract: The dexterity of a surgeon’s hands can account for much of the differences in how well patients do, a new study confirms.

abstract: What economic theory can tell us about whether companies like Apple would even have an incentive to limit the useful life of their products, and under what market conditions.

That means, as I wrote in a column for the coming issue of The New York Times Magazine, that conspiracy theories again abound about ways that older models start to become more unattractive and dysfunctional around the time that a shiny new upgrade is available.

headline: Booker Joins the Senate and Casts His First Vote
abstract: Cory A. Booker of New Jersey, who won his seat in a special election, was the first African-American to be elected as a senator since Barack Obama in 2004.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Cory A. Booker, who gained celebrity as a danger-defying, super-tweeting mayor of Newark, was sworn in as New Jersey’s junior United States senator on Thursday. He is the first African-American to be elected to the chamber since Barack Obama in 2004.

headline: G.O.P. Filibuster of 2 Obama Picks Sets Up Fight
keywords: ['Appeals Courts (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Filibusters and Debate Curbs']
abstract: Senate Republicans thwarted the confirmation of two of President Obama’s nominees, one to an appeals court and another to a home-lending oversight post.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Thursday thwarted the confirmation of two of President Obama’s nominees, one to a powerful appeals court and another to a home-lending oversight post, setting up a confrontation with Democrats that could escalate into a larger fight over limiting the filibuster and restrict how far the minority party can go to block a president’s agenda.

headline: A Landmark Turn in India’s Medical Negligence Law
abstract: The Supreme Court’s 60.8 million rupee award took into consideration the complex socioeconomic conditions of Dr. Kunal Saha, the pain his wife endured, the doctor’s loss of income and his copious legal expenses.
lead_paragraph: Anuradha Saha died painfully in May 1998 at the age of 36, her skin sloughed off all over her body, except for her skull. She was encased in bandages meant to prevent infections that had already lodged in her system. Her immunity had been compromised after receiving a high dosage of steroids from some of the top doctors in Kolkata.

headline: Love Trouble
abstract: “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” may have earned its high berth on the Shakespeare hit parade because it’s a bundle of high-spirited hijinks, but its view of love is divided.
lead_paragraph: It should not be strange to encounter any of Shakespeare’s plays at any time of the year, so firmly ensconced are they in the canon. And yet there’s something a little startling in the arrival of a production of “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” opening in November, as Julie Taymor’s upcoming production at Theater for a New Audience will. The play is among Shakespeare’s most beloved and most frequently produced, but it has mostly become a rite of summer, often performed outdoors, with picnickers sharing bottles of wine and children romping on grass.

keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'International Relations']

Snowden and published this week in the German newsmagazine Der Spiegel.

The Federal Aviation Administration announced on Thursday that passengers could soon be allowed to use tablet computers, e-books, music players and other devices in planes at almost all times as long as their wireless functions are disabled by putting the device in “airplane mode.” (The editorial board backed changing F.A.A.’s policies earlier this month.)

headline: In Amish Country, on the Train to Paradise
abstract: A caboose-themed motel, a steam-train ride and Thomas the Tank Engine are just three of the attractions visitors can find during a visit to Strasburg, Pa., in Lancaster County.

headline: In Stockholm, ABBA, Alcohol and Animals
abstract: Recent openings are infusing new life into oft-overlooked Djurgarden, one of the capital’s urban islands.
lead_paragraph: Buzzy new gastropubs and drinking salons have been proliferating throughout Stockholm’s urban islands, from pockets of the tourist-heavy Gamla Stan to hip Sodermalm, which today is a virtual Little Brooklyn with its bars, body art and beards. But Djurgarden, the tranquil two-mile-long island in the middle of the capital, had largely been a stalwart against these waves of change. Dense with meadows, an aging amusement park and staid museums, Djurgarden lacked the dynamic appeal that pulses in nearby areas. But recent openings on the western edge are infusing new life into this oft-overlooked island.

headline: After Fraud, the Fog Around Libor Hasn’t Lifted

headline: In Namibia, Conservation and Tourism Intersect
abstract: For nearly two decades, the southern African country has been part of an experiment to help wildlife and local communities.
lead_paragraph: Uamunikaije Tjivinda squatted in the sand and threw a few strips of dried giraffe meat into a pot of boiling water. Like many Himba women in the arid, northwestern part of Namibia called Kaokoland, she wore sandals, a goatskin skirt and little else. Her skin and long, plaited hair were a striking rust-red, rubbed with ocher dug from the earth.

headline: A Mood Change at Security Checkpoints
abstract: Airports in Charlotte, N.C., and Dallas-Fort Worth are testing security checkpoints that feature mood lighting, upbeat music, and plush sofas.
lead_paragraph: Mood lighting and upbeat music aren’t revolutionary ideas for romancing a date, but they may be for wooing travelers at airport security checkpoints. At least that’s the hope of the creators of a new security experience being tested at the Charlotte-Douglas and Dallas-Fort Worth International Airports over the next few months.

lead_paragraph: Soon after church groups denounced Monty Python’s “Life of Brian” as blasphemous, John Cleese was asked, in a television interview, what he thought of the ruckus. “These people have made me,” he said, calmly, and with a dramatic pause, “a very rich man.”

headline: 10,000-Year Study Finds Oceans Warming Fast, But From a Cool Baseline
abstract: Recent ocean warming is from a relatively cool baseline, a new study finds.
lead_paragraph: I had a fascinating and fruitful chat with Yair Rosenthal of Rutgers and Braddock Linsley of Columbia University — two authors of an important new Science paper extracting 10,000 years of temperature changes in fairly deep Pacific Ocean waters from fossil plankton buried in the seabed off Indonesia.

lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night, after the Red Sox took a 6-0 lead against the St. Louis Cardinals in Game 6 of the World Series, the Boston police were getting ready for an onslaught of emotional fans, announcing on Twitter, “Anyone who is not in a bar and does not have a ticket to the game must leave the permitter area around #Fenway.”

lead_paragraph: A Benjamin Britten orchestration of Chopin piano music that was believed to be lost will re-enter the repertory on Friday night when American Ballet Theater uses it for its performance of Michel Fokine’s “Les Sylphides” at the David H. Koch Theater.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Every day, Google crawls and indexes the entire Internet to help deliver the best search results on its website. Now the company wants to apply the same firepower to dig through applications on smartphones that run the Android operating system.

headline: A Southwest Orientation
abstract: The latest of Rafael Palomino’s restaurants offers modern fusion cuisine.
lead_paragraph: With the opening in June of Palomino, Rafael Palomino added to his “nuevo Latino” restaurant holdings, which include the perennially popular Sonora, in Port Chester, N.Y.; Bistro Latino and Pacifico, both in Connecticut; and Mesa, Pacifico and Tapas on Main, all in Pennsylvania. (There has been some shuffling: this Palomino is not to be confused with Palomino in Old Greenwich, Conn., which became Greenwich Tavern and then Bistro Latino; Bistro Latino in Tuckahoe and Pacifico in Port Chester have closed). The author of several books, he also runs a consulting company, Latino Chef, and a catering company, Pasión. With his jazzy branding and meticulously built dishes, Mr. Palomino has made a name for himself.

headline: A Modest Reminder of Rome
abstract: Gastronomia Culinaria feels true to a certain type of small trattoria, where the food is plain-spoken and the pricing temperate.
lead_paragraph: The bread lay on a notched wooden board, anchored by a saucer of something creamy and wildly green that evoked pesto but tasted like ocean floor. When asked about the ingredients, the waiter looked startled. “I do not know the name for this in English,” he said. “Rucola? Also a small fish.” Arugula and anchovy, a woman at my table suggested. He smiled, shrugged and vanished.

lead_paragraph: PIO XII, Brazil — It was midafternoon that Sunday when Otávio Jordão da Silva Cantanhede left on his bike to play pickup soccer. His father said he did not see him tuck a knife into his shorts or slide a blade into his backpack.
