headline: Market Report | Timeless, Feathery Finds
abstract: From cocktail dresses to jewelry, blue feathers are marking their territory as a timeless wardrobe addition.
lead_paragraph: The plume briefly disappeared from the fashion scene after last year’s Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge-inspired fascinator craze died down. But now it’s back, this time on clothes and accessories and in varying shades of blue, from deep sapphire to a bluish gray. Feathers complement satin as a shapely detail on a Christopher Kane cocktail dress, a dangling tassel on a Roger Vivier heel and on the diamond-encrusted face on a Harry Winston watch; and take center stage as the main material of a Louis Vuitton handbag. Fanned around a white gold and diamond cuff from Wilfredo Rosado, sapphire feathers add interest to any evening look. And unlike the fascinator, Stephen Russell’s archival feather brooch, made entirely of actual sapphires and diamonds, will never go out of style.

headline: An Abundance of Asian Flavors
abstract: At Aja, a culinary mash-up in New Brunswick, the menu is large, the dining room is lively and the quality of the ingredients is high.

headline: What You Can’t See Is Even Cooler
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Dark Matter (Astronomy)', 'Dark Energy (Astronomy)']
abstract: “Dark Universe,” a new space show at the Hayden Planetarium, takes viewers through a century of discovery about the past, present and future of the cosmos.
lead_paragraph: Mordecai-Mark Mac Low, a curator at the American Museum of Natural History, was showing off an exhibit about the history of the universe outside the Hayden Planetarium there eight years ago, he says, when a schoolteacher approached him and said, “You don’t really believe all this Big Bang stuff, do you?”

lead_paragraph: PARIS — To beat back the British, the United States Davis Cup team is prepared to get dirty.

headline: A Floating Historian’s Hot-Air Adventure

lead_paragraph: Richard Holmes, author of “Falling Upwards,” takes a ride in a balloon.

headline: Salonen Meets Sibelius
abstract: Esa-Pekka Salonen led the New York Philharmonic Wednesday night in a program including his own Violin Concerto.
lead_paragraph: During his adventurous 17-year tenure as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the conductor Esa-Pekka Salonen was so preoccupied with his work there, and with carving out time to compose, his top priority, that he had limited occasions for guest appearances with American orchestras, including the New York Philharmonic.

headline: Where Horses Wet Their Whistles
abstract: Of the few horses that remain in New York, many may soon be out of a job.
lead_paragraph: So, with both main mayoral candidates opposed to allowing horse-drawn carriages in the streets, a major chapter in the history of New York may be about to close. The first horses served man here no later than the 1620s, and since then they have pulled, plodded, trotted and galloped in our service.

headline: Imagining the First Strains Wafting, When the Ink Was Scarcely Dry
abstract: “Beethoven’s Ninth: A Masterpiece Reunited,” an exhibition at the Morgan Library & Museum, focuses on two copied scores of that symphony that were edited by the composer.
lead_paragraph: The handwritten score on display at the Morgan Library & Museum is open to a passage near the end of Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony: As the orchestra and chorus are ecstatically hailing Joy, the “bright spark of divinity,” the music’s reins are suddenly pulled back, the meter shifts, and exuberance gives way to majesty.

headline: Conservative Group Tests New Attack on Health Law
abstract: A new Web video from Americans for Prosperity criticizes President Obama for his promise that those with health care coverage could keep their current plans.
lead_paragraph: A promise President Obama may come to regret — “If you like your health care plan, you can keep it” — is the centerpiece of the latest web video attacking the Affordable Care Act, released Thursday by Americans for Prosperity, the conservative advocacy group that is working to undo the health law.

headline: The Philanderer Reconsiders
abstract: In “A Perfect Man,” Liev Schreiber plays an architect who, after his affairs lead his wife to leave him, begins to rethink his behavior.
lead_paragraph: “A Perfect Man” is a platitude-packed romance that might never have seen the light of day had its star, Liev Schreiber, not hit a career high with the success of Showtime’s “Ray Donovan.” As it is, this feature debut from Kees Van Oostrum, set in Amsterdam among the members of an unpleasant clique of upper-middle-class malcontents, is one of those projects whose very existence should baffle anyone hardy enough to endure all 94 minutes.

headline: A Dog’s Tail Wag Says a Lot, to Other Dogs
abstract: When watching a tail wag to the left, dogs showed signs of anxiety, scientists found. When the tail went in the opposite direction, they remained calm.
lead_paragraph: When dogs wag their tails, they can convey not just happiness but a wide array of emotions. As Italian researchers reported in 2007, a wag to the left indicates negative emotions; a wag to the right indicates positive ones.

headline: Oh, to Slip the Bonds of Earth
abstract: Richard Holmes, whose new history of balloon travel, “Falling Upwards,” was published this week, takes to the skies in Orange County, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y. — “The first rule of ballooning,” Richard Holmes said, “is to forget all your troubles and let the world fall away.” Almost as soon as he spoke, the wicker basket in which he was standing, attached to a 100-foot-tall hot-air balloon, began to rise, goosed by a blast of flame from its propane burner, and before long, he was skimming over the treetops here in Orange County. As the balloon slowly ascended, the landscape underneath increasingly resembled a train set. Startled, a buck down below began crashing through bushes. A moment later, the balloon drifted over a quiet country road, and a tractor-trailer gave a three-honk salute.

headline: Renaissance Prayer Book Is Set for Auction
abstract: An illuminated Renaissance prayer book — which once sold for $13.3 million — is scheduled to come up for auction in January.
lead_paragraph: HIGH-PRICED PRAYER BOOK

headline: Making a Home for Pakistani Runaways
abstract: The documentary “These Birds Walk” chronicles a humanitarian’s efforts to help street children in Karachi, Pakistan.
lead_paragraph: Asad, a kind young van driver in Karachi, Pakistan, carries two kinds of passengers: lost children and corpses. He takes the children to a home for runaways or back to their parents; he is paid (usually) for the corpses.

headline: Strident Video by Chinese Military Casts U.S. as Menace
abstract: The film, “Silent Contest,” shows a senior Chinese military official criticizing military exchanges with the United States and warning that the Americans will use them for “infiltration.”
lead_paragraph: A conspiracy-minded 100-minute film produced by the Chinese military that was circulating widely on the Internet Thursday accuses the United States of trying to undermine the Communist Party’s control of the People’s Liberation Army and impose American values on China.

headline: Book Details Obama Aides’ Talks About Replacing Biden on 2012 Ticket

lead_paragraph: President Obama’s top aides secretly considered replacing Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. with Hillary Rodham Clinton on the 2012 ticket, undertaking extensive focus-group sessions and polling in late 2011 when Mr. Obama’s re-election outlook appeared uncertain.

headline: The Politics of Acoustic Guitars
abstract: “Musicwood,” a documentary by Maxine Trump, examines the thicket of issues that pit Native Americans in Alaska against the makers of acoustic guitars.
lead_paragraph: Even if you can’t tell the difference between a soundboard and a fretboard, “Musicwood” will hold your attention. Merging the sustainability worries of guitar enthusiasts and environmentalists with the hard-cash concerns of logging corporations and Native American land developers, Maxine Trump’s thoughtful documentary wrests clarity from complexity.

headline: A Harmonic Marriage
abstract: In John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey’s wonderful new show at the Café Carlyle, the couple reflects on what matters most.
lead_paragraph: “Children and Art,” John Pizzarelli and Jessica Molaskey’s wonderful new show at the Café Carlyle, isn’t just the title of a Stephen Sondheim song from “Sunday in the Park With George.” This reflection on what matters most is paired with “Children Will Listen,” from “Into the Woods,” to make a sweeping reflection on the rewards and stresses of balancing the roles of parent and artist by musicians who are married with two children. Both songs address personal responsibility for that which we create and leave behind: “Careful the things you say/Children will listen.”

headline: Pairings for Tasting Menus: A 30-Piece Puzzle
abstract: Multicourse meals really test the sommelier.
lead_paragraph: Setting out on the madcap journey through a chef’s imagination that is otherwise known as a tasting menu can be a delight. It requires a commitment of time, attention and money, and the right mood and the company, but the results can be dazzling.

headline: Shaping the Future, in the Kitchen and Beyond
abstract: “Designing Modern Women 1890-1990,” at the Museum of Modern Art, examines how women helped shape future ways of living and served as muses to modernity.
lead_paragraph: Shoehorned into half the Museum of Modern Art’s design department, “Designing Modern Women 1890-1990” is a confusing exhibition but an excellent conversation starter.

headline: A Little Shop of Possibilities

abstract: “Sweet Dreams” looks at how a Brooklyn ice cream company helped a group of Rwandan women start their own business.
lead_paragraph: “Sweet Dreams,” a documentary about efforts by the Brooklyn-based Blue Marble Ice Cream company to help a group of Rwandan women open their own shop, could have come off as insensitive or twee. And in the first 10 minutes, I worried that it was, indeed, about how artisanal food could save Africa.

headline: Q. & A.: Jung Chang on Censors, Bound Feet and the Chances of a Woman Leading China
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Women and Girls', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The author of a new biography of the Empress Dowager Cixi sees a need for a true women’s liberation movement in China, arguing that even very liberal men have deep-rooted biases.
lead_paragraph: It was first thing Thursday morning, and the author Jung Chang, in a dramatic emerald cloak, was already holding court in a suite overlooking Hong Kong’s skyline. She was in town to promote her latest book, “Empress Dowager Cixi: The Concubine Who Launched Modern China,” which she wrote after gaining access to historical documents in Beijing that she says “have not been seen or used outside the Chinese-speaking world.”

headline: Leaping Into a New Home, With Poetry and Storms
abstract: American Ballet Theater opened its fall season at its new Lincoln Center home with a world premiere of “The Tempest’ by Alexei Ratmansky.
lead_paragraph: The David H. Koch Theater is fast becoming New York’s prime year-round dance house. With its large upstairs foyer, it’s also a happy home for galas, and on Wednesday, American Ballet Theater opened its first season there in 37 years with a night that was seriously glamorous. That foyer was transformed into a spectacular alternative set for “The Tempest” — the evening’s main event — with vast pillars and successive thunderclaps.

lead_paragraph: A new show at the Whitney takes a look at performance art’s beginnings.

headline: Nothing to Spend, Nothing to Lose
abstract: “Rituals of Rented Island,” at the Whitney Museum of American Art, collects the ephemera of 1970s performance art in New York.
lead_paragraph: With the end of daylight saving time this weekend, we’ll set our clocks back an hour. But already in New York this fall, American art has been set back 40 years. It’s the early 1970s again, with abstract painting and performance art the fashionable modes.

lead_paragraph: The Times reporters Bill Carter and Brian Stelter discuss this week’s TV cancellations and renewals.

headline: The Ad Campaign: Lhota Issues Warnings and Makes Promises
abstract: In his latest ad, Joseph J. Lhota tries to meld warnings of what would befall New York if Bill de Blasio became mayor with a positive message about what he himself would do in the job.
lead_paragraph: Joseph J. Lhota, the Republican nominee for mayor, released his latest television ad on Thursday. Titled “Promises,” it is airing on broadcast channels across New York City.

headline: Shrimp, Grits and Everything in Between
abstract: At J. Christian’s in Wallingford, down-home Southern favorites like shrimp and grits, buttermilk-fried chicken and fried green tomatoes mingle with New American fare.
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Harris has a talent for grits. A native of North Carolina, Mr. Harris is the executive chef at J. Christian’s in Wallingford, where he has been offering his version of the Southern specialty since the restaurant opened in 2010. Cooked in a mixture that is equal parts chicken stock and milk, the grits are made lusciously creamy and gooey with Asiago cheese. Why Asiago? “Wallingford is an Italian town,” Mr. Harris explained on the phone after my visits. “I figured if I threw Italian cheese into the Southern grits, they would catch on faster.”

headline: Taking On Broncos and a Plague
abstract: Matthew McConaughey stars as an unlikely advocate for patients with H.I.V., taking his treatment into his own hands in “Dallas Buyers Club.”
lead_paragraph: Skinny as a whippet and fierce as a snapping turtle, Matthew McConaughey brings a jolt of unpredictable energy to “Dallas Buyers Club,” an affecting if conventional real-life story of medical activism. The film, directed by Jean-Marc Vallée from a script by Craig Borten and Melisa Wallack, tells the story of Ron Woodroof, a Texas electrician and rodeo rider who, after receiving a diagnosis of H.I.V. in 1985, took his treatment into his own hands and helped others with the disease obtain medication not legally available in the United States at the time.

headline: Where Photography Alone Wasn’t Enough
abstract: The Rubin Museum of Art’s “Allegory and Illusion: Early Portrait Photography From South Asia” looks at pictures from British-run or -influenced countries.
lead_paragraph: A new show of portrait photography at the Rubin Museum of Art, “Allegory and Illusion” is a fascinating little piece of a very complicated puzzle. Ostensibly a focused, regional exhibition, it has much to say about the larger relationship between photography and colonialism (a subject big enough to fill several museums).

headline: A Veteran Wave Rider Tells His Life Story in Art
abstract: Herbie Fletcher went from being the subject of artists like Bruce Weber and Julian Schnabel to a creator in his own right. His totally tubular exhibit, “Path of the Wave Warrior,” is on view in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: “Surfing to me is metaphysical yoga,” the surf icon-turned-art world fixture Herbie Fletcher said. “When you’re in big waves and you take a drop, you lose your mind. It’s being in the void. There’s no thought. It’s bliss for a moment. That’s the state of mind these paintings are in,” he said about the work on view in “Path of the Wave Warrior,” a massive exhibition of his paintings, collages and sculptures on view at Known Gallery on North Fairfax Avenue in Los Angeles, through Nov. 9.

headline: Manly? Yes, in That Present-Day British Way
abstract: A Hugh Grant wannabe (Domhnall Gleeson) and his father (Bill Nighy) indulge the supernatural talent shared by the men in their family.
lead_paragraph: It is about time we addressed the crisis of British manhood. The once proud nation that in the last century gave us such vital and varied paragons of masculinity as Winston Churchill, Laurence Olivier, Mick Jagger and Morrissey is now represented in the popular imagination mainly by rabbity, passive-aggressive stammerers. With all due respect — or maybe just, sort of, well, just the tiniest smidgen of due respect, if you see what I mean — to Hugh Grant, it all seems to be his fault. When he sweet-talked Julia Roberts in “Notting Hill,” the whole world swooned, and the sun slid further below the horizon of John Bull’s manly old empire.

headline: A River in Trouble, a Question of Who Has to Sacrifice
abstract: Because of a drought and Texas’ population growth, the Colorado River is suffering as there is competition for its limited resources.
lead_paragraph: Like nearly every other river in Texas, the 600-mile Colorado River — which flows from West Texas to the gulf coast — is under serious threat. Drought and surging population growth have taken their toll on the water’s flow and its wildlife and, by extension, on the farmers and fishermen who rely on it.

abstract: A dangerous flood reveals a couple’s strong connection.

headline: Tipping Points
abstract: Advice on if and when to tip, what a child can say when adults comment on his height and how to handle interruptions when visiting friends at a retirement home.
lead_paragraph: I recently moved to the mecca of small coffee shops. Many have tip jars on the counter. When I receive my change, I usually drop the coins into the jar. I figure this is better than no tip at all, and I don’t like carrying lots of change. But it occurs to me that this may come across as cheap and insulting. If I were a barista, I might not want a customer’s dimes and pennies. Should I tip? And if so, only with dollar bills?

headline: Bahrain Crackdown Extends to Exhibit on Crackdown
abstract: After the police in Bahrain shut down an exhibition on the security crackdown following the 2011 uprising, a spokesman contended that the display was an attempt to illegally “reinforce hatred.”
lead_paragraph: One day after the police in Bahrain raided the offices of an opposition party to confiscate materials being used in an exhibition on the security crackdown following the 2011 uprising, the authorities released a video statement in which a spokesman contended that the display of painting, spent tear-gas canisters and the belongings of dead protesters was being used to illegally “reinforce hatred.”

keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']

abstract: ‘Priming’ experiments often show that human reason is highly susceptible to suggestion, but do the results have any real meaning outside the lab?
lead_paragraph: Reports of psychological experiments are journalistic favorites.  This is especially true of experiments revealing the often surprising effects of “priming” on human behavior. Priming occurs when a seemingly trivial alteration in an experimental situation produces major changes in the behavior of the subjects.

headline: Old Hatreds Just Won’t Stay Buried
abstract: Wladyslaw Pasikowski’s “Aftermath” is a Holocaust-related story set in the modern-day in a Polish town.
lead_paragraph: Virulent ethnic hatred doesn’t die; it lies dormant until it is suddenly prodded awake, at which point it can flare into a consuming wildfire. That is the ugly message of the Polish filmmaker Wladyslaw Pasikowski’s lurid “Aftermath,” which delivers its Holocaust-related story with the clunking force of a blunt instrument slammed into the skull.

headline: Boeing Says It Will Raise Production of the 737
abstract: The aircraft maker says it will increase monthly production of its highly profitable, top-selling 737 jets to 47 from 38 by 2017.
lead_paragraph: Riding a surge in demand for new fuel-efficient planes, Boeing said on Thursday that it would increase production of its top-selling 737 jets to 47 a month by 2017, from 38 now.

headline: A Spicy Outlier of Pink Grapes
abstract: The Gewürztraminers at the Lenz Winery were made to evolve slowly and the 2009 is waiting in the wings for the 2008 to run out.
lead_paragraph: From a distance, the five bottles arrayed on my kitchen counter for a recent tasting — tall, with slender necks — looked Alsatian, but they were not. All contained dry Long Island gewürztraminers, which, broadly speaking, trace their style to Alsace, in northeastern France.

headline: A Writer Who’s Beat in Search of a Refuge
abstract: Michael Polish’s film “Big Sur” is based on Jack Kerouac’s visits to that coastal California region, where he fled the literary success that followed the publication of “On the Road.”
lead_paragraph: “Big Sur” cracks the code of how to adapt Jack Kerouac for the screen. The secret is deceptively simple: Go to the source and stay there. The hot-wired energy and spontaneity of the Beat mystique are embedded in writing that distills its feverish essence better than any hyped-up action. The hard part is melding readings with live action, but “Big Sur” makes it look so easy that you hardly notice the transitions.

headline: Tattoos and Bluegrass Music in the Wilds of Belgium
abstract: In “The Broken Circle Breakdown,” directed by Felix van Groeningen, a Belgian couple are buffeted by the news that their daughter has cancer.
lead_paragraph: Much like the tattoos etched on the beautiful body of one character and the beard sprouting on the face of another, the narrative two-step performed in “The Broken Circle Breakdown” goes a long way toward distracting you from the familiarity of the story. The ink adorns Elise (Veerle Baetens), a tattoo artist, who lives with her bearded partner, Didier (Johan Heldenbergh), a bluegrass musician, and their young daughter, Maybelle (Nell Cattrysse), in the kind of picturesque country spread where a dog chases chickens that roost in a pickup truck. It looks like a slice of hillbilly heaven, except that this isn’t Kentucky but a pastoral corner near the Flemish city of Ghent in Belgium.

headline: Censorship in China
abstract: From Hong Kong, the publisher of a book about China by Prof. Ezra F. Vogel that was the focus of a front-page article discusses censorship issues.

headline: F.D.A. Lays Out Rule to Avoid Drug Shortages
abstract: The rule, which is open to public comment for 60 days, applies for the first time to makers of “biological medicines,” which are produced in microorganisms, animal or plant cells.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration detailed a plan on Thursday to prevent drug shortages. It fleshes out changes in a 2012 law that requires makers of important prescription drugs to notify the agency of interruptions in production that might disrupt supply. The rule, which is open to public comment for 60 days, applies for the first time to makers of “biological medicines,” which are produced in microorganisms, animal or plant cells. The agency said the number of new shortages fell to 117 last year, down from 251 in 2011.

headline: The Private Heartaches of a People’s Princess
abstract: Naomi Watts portrays the Princess of Wales in a film that revisits her affair with a Pakistani heart surgeon, based on Kate Snell’s book “Diana: Her Last Love.”
lead_paragraph: Naomi Watts is one of those performers who seemingly can do no wrong, even in a waxworks like “Diana.” A slice of biographical conjecture about the Princess of Wales, this movie isn’t especially good, but it wins you over a little just because it succeeds where truckloads of sanctifying reminiscences have failed: Anchored by Ms. Watts’s sympathetic performance, it humanizes the woman behind the smile, the helmet hair and the myth. Part reheated gossip, part moony romance, it revisits an affair Diana had with a Pakistani heart surgeon, Hasnat Khan, a liaison she managed to keep from the ravenous media maw that she routinely fed and spectacularly failed to control.

headline: More Yang Than Yin? Better Fix Your Life Force
abstract: “Man of Tai Chi,” Keanu Reeves’s directorial debut, is all about the fight.
lead_paragraph: The fight is the thing in “Man of Tai Chi,” Keanu Reeves’s down-and-dirty and generally diverting directing debut. A story about the past and the future, the good and the bad, the strong and the weak, the movie finds a Januslike Mr. Reeves looking in two directions at once: toward the old-school kung fu movies of once upon a matinee time and the modern China emblemized by the high rises that slice through smog-swathed Beijing, where most of the story unwinds. It’s there that Tiger (Tiger Chen) logs hours between lessons with a tai chi master, Yang (Yu Hai).

headline: Malaria in United States Is at a 40-Year High
abstract: Of the 1,925 cases detected in 2011, almost 70 percent were in people who had visited Africa.
lead_paragraph: Malaria cases in the United States have reached a 40-year high, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced Thursday, but virtually all were in travelers who were infected overseas. Of the 1,925 cases detected in 2011, almost 70 percent were in people who had visited Africa, particularly West Africa. Most others were from India. Five ended in death. Cases peaked in January and August after the Christmas and summer travel seasons. Only five cases occurred in the United States, said Dr. Paul M. Arguin, the agency’s chief of domestic malaria. One was a lab accident, another was from a blood transfusion, two were in babies born to mothers who had traveled and one occurred in winter in a patient whose travel history might not have been fully disclosed.

abstract: The retailer raised $225 million after demand from potential shareholders prompted the company to seek even more in its market debut.
lead_paragraph: The business of selling bins and closet storage has drawn big investor interest.

headline: Drop in LSAT Takers Shows Legal Field’s Slump
keywords: ['Law School Admission Test (LSAT)', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Law Schools', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: The latest figures released this week by the Law School Admissions Council show that nearly 11 percent fewer people took the LSAT in October than the year before.
lead_paragraph: Once again, fewer candidates are taking the Law School Admission Test, a sign that students recognize the continuing slump in the legal field. The latest figures released this week by the Law School Admissions Council show that nearly 11 percent fewer people took the LSAT in October than the year before. The Wall Street Journal’s Law Blog calculated that this October’s 33,673 test takers represent a drop of 45 percent since the test-taking peak in 2009. Daniel M. Filler, a professor at the Earle Mack School of Law at Drexel University, blogged that some schools might see applications decline to the point that they could have to “radically restructure” to make ends meet.
